title: Keeping Seeds Safe
description: When an American farmer gets ready to plant a crop like corn or soybeans, he has two basic choices. Traditional seeds are the kind farmers have planted throughout history, developed by crossing parents with desirable traits to get a superior variety. Genetically modified seeds, first widely planted in 1996, contain trangenes from other organisms that convey specific advantages to mature plants -- the ability to resist herbicides, for instance. The acreage planted with genetically modified crops has exploded: a third of this country's corn by 2002 and three-quarters of its soybeans. Whatever you make of this trend -- and there are strong arguments on both sides -- one question it raises is whether genes from modified plants might somehow drift into unmodified ones. The answer is yes.

title: PARIS REVIEW APPOINTMENTS
description: The Paris Review has announced the appointment of a deputy publisher, Lea Carpenter, who will supervise the day-to-day financial health of the magazine. The Paris Review, founded in 1953, was edited by George Plimpton until his death last year. Ms. Carpenter will work under its longtime publisher, Drue Heinz. Ms. Carpenter, 30, received an M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School in June and before that spent five years in magazine and book publishing in New York. She worked at George magazine and helped start Francis Ford Coppola's literary quarterly Zoetrope All-Story. In addition she was managing editor of Lipper/Atlas Publications, which published the Penguin Lives biography series. The Paris Review Foundation, which runs the magazine, also announced the appointment of Michele Clarke as its director of development. Ms. Clarke helped produce the magazine's 50th anniversary celebration last year and was previously program development officer at the African Wildlife Foundation in Washington. DINITIA SMITH

title: Shattered Democracy in Haiti
description: The forced resignation of Haiti's democratically elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, yesterday morning followed three weeks of armed rebellion and increasingly open pressure from a Bush administration too willing to ignore democratic legitimacy in order to allow the removal of a leader it disliked and distrusted. President Bush moved quickly yesterday to dispatch a contingent of marines to serve as the core of an international peacekeeping force. The United Nations Security Council authorized such a force last night. Sending the Marines was the right thing to do, but Mr. Bush should have done it days ago, when there was still a chance for an American-proposed compromise that would have reinforced the framework of constitutional democracy. Mr. Bush's hesitation leaves Washington looking as if it withheld the Marines until Mr. Aristide yielded power, leaving Haitians at the mercy of some of the country's most vicious criminal gangs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly Approves Minimum Wage Plan
description: The State Assembly approved a bill yesterday to gradually raise New York's minimum wage to more than $7 an hour by 2006, saying it would give workers more disposable income, help lift them out of poverty and energize the economy. By an unofficial 127-to-19 vote, the Assembly, which is led by Democrats, voted to raise the state's current $5.15-an-hour wage, the same as the federal minimum, to $6 an hour on Oct. 1; $6.75 an hour on July 1, 2005; and $7.10 an hour on Jan. 1, 2006. The minimum wage has not been increased in New York since March 2000. Twelve states, including many in the Northeast, have a minimum wage above the federal standard. The State Senate, which is led by Republicans, was reluctant to act, arguing that raising the wage would put New York at a disadvantage with other states' wages. But if the federal government does not act soon to raise the minimum wage nationally, ''then we will reassess things,'' said John E. McArdle, a spokesman for the Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, who supports an increase. Al Baker (NYT)

title: At Least 25 Die in Attack on Shiites in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 2  Unidentified gunmen lobbed grenades and sprayed bullets at a procession of Shiite Muslim worshippers in the city of Quetta in southwestern Pakistan today. Government officials said at least 25 people were killed and more than 150 injured, but hospital officials put the death toll at at least 35. The attack came on the Shiite holy day of Ashura, marked by Shiite mourning processions commemorating the martyrdom of Hussein, the grandson of the Prophet Muhammad whom Shiites revere. The attack in Pakistan coincided with a series of bombs and explosions that ripped through major Iraqi Shiite shrines in Karbala and Baghdad, killing more than 140 people.

description: Martha Stewart conspired with her former stockbroker to lie about the circumstances that led to her sale of nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems, a federal prosecutor said in his closing argument yesterday, but ''probably never thought she would get caught.''

description: One of Chechnya's most prominent rebel commanders, Ruslan Gelayev, was killed over the weekend in a clash with Russian border troops in the remote mountains bordering Chechnya, a senior Russian official said. Mr. Gelayev's death has been reported before, most recently after a firefight in neighboring Dagestan that left nine Russian soldiers dead in December. But Sergei N. title: Jury Hears Clashing Views of Roles of Rigas Family in Adelphia
description: A federal jury in the Adelphia Communications fraud case heard clashing portrayals yesterday of John Rigas and two of his sons, with a prosecutor contending that they had betrayed and looted the company and defense lawyers arguing that the Rigases had acted honorably and always intended to repay money they had borrowed from Adelphia.

title: Designer Deals, Red-Carpet Style
description: Last week, with the Academy Awards days away, the designer Carolina Herrera spoke to Women's Wear Daily about Rene Zellweger, who the newspaper guessed might be wearing a Herrera gown on the red carpet. ''What Rene wears is her decision,'' Ms. Herrera demurred. ''I always say, 'You never know until they're in the car.' ''

title: CYTYC TO BUY MAKER OF MEDICAL DEVICE FOR $311 MILLION
description: The Cytyc Corporation, which makes tests for cervical cancer, agreed to buy the closely held Novacept for $311 million to add to its women's health products. Novacept makes a device that treats excessive menstrual bleeding. The price is net of Novacept's cash balance, Cytyc said. Cytyc, based in Boxborough, Mass., has been focusing on products related to cervical cancer screening, the chief executive, Patrick J. Sullivan, said. Novacept's NovaSure System for excessive menstrual bleeding is expected to add to earnings next year, Cytyc said.

title: Lewis and Garnes Jettisoned by Jets
description: The out-with-the-old part of the Jets' off-season moves continued yesterday with the release of linebacker Mo Lewis, whose 13-year career with them came to an end in the latest salary purge. Also sent packing were safeties Sam Garnes and Tyrone Carter.

title: Lobbing A Grenade At Women's Magazines
description: When Myrna Blyth, the former editor of Ladies' Home Journal and the author of a new book excoriating women's magazines, walks through Michael's restaurant in Midtown Manhattan, all eyes in that gathering spot for the media elite seem to follow her. She appears not to notice, but when she takes a seat, she sits with her back against a wall.

title: Skillfully Exposing the Heart of the Avant-Garde
description: Blair McMillen set himself a challenge when he decided to devote his entire recital at Miller Theater on Feb. 19 to music by Giacinto Scelsi and Luciano Berio. Those composers, towering figures in the mid-20th century Italian avant-garde, favored spiky textures, irregular rhythms and unresolved dissonances, and they demand concentration on either side of the footlights. It is music to grapple with, not to bathe in.

title: Flu Season Seems Over, Officials Say
description: The flu season appears to have ended early and as abruptly as it started, and was not much more severe than usual seasonal outbreaks, federal health officials said here on Monday.

title: Javits Center Expansion Overshadowed by Stadium Debate
description: Almost from the day the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center opened in 1986 on the West Side of Manhattan, hotel and tourism executives have lobbied to expand it to attract more conventions and trade shows, and with them the patrons who will book rooms, eat at restaurants and attend Broadway shows.

title: Closing Remarks in Terror Trial Touch on Paintball and Pakistan
description: In closing remarks in the trial of three men accused of assisting a Pakistan-based terrorist group, federal prosecutors said Monday that the men were Muslim extremists whose goal was to train for ''violent jihad'' against allies of the United States, and possibly the country itself.

title: For Babies, Going With the Grain
description: Adding folic acid to breads and grains sold in the United States has cut by a third the number of fetuses at risk for birth defects caused by folic acid deficiency, a new study has concluded.

title: HSBC Says Profit Jumped 41% in 2003
description: HSBC Holdings, the world's second-largest bank, on Monday reported an increase of almost 41 percent in profit in 2003, buoyed by its purchase of the consumer lender Household International in the United States.

description: Senators pushing to renew a 10-year ban on military-style assault weapons showcased their backing from law enforcement officials on Monday as the Senate headed toward a series of politically charged votes on gun issues.

description: A rare health study of homeless children shows that about half of those entering the New York City shelter system have asthma, a finding that underscores the increased health risk to the most vulnerable population and the challenges faced by those who serve them.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Miner Posts Profit
description: The Kinross Gold Corporation, a Canadian gold producer, said it had net income of $32.4 million in the fourth quarter, its first profit since early 1998, as bullion prices rose and the company cut jobs to lower costs. The result was in contrast to a net loss of $12.7 million a year earlier, the company said. Per-share profit was 9 cents after payment of dividends on preferred stock, in contrast to a loss of 12 cents. Kinross, which is based in Toronto, said revenue rose to $150.5 million from $78.9 million a year earlier.

title: Yahoo to Charge for Guaranteeing a Spot on Its Index
description: Yahoo said yesterday that it would start charging companies that want to ensure that their Web sites are included in its Web index from which research results are selected.

title: A Set Surveys the Work of a Record-Setting Producer
description: Even after this year's Oscars, the films of Arthur Cohn still hold the record for the most won by any producer. Beginning with ''The Sky Above, the Mud Below'' (1961), Cohn productions have won six in the documentary and foreign-language categories. That called for a collection and last week Home Vision released the six winners and four of his other films in a boxed set of nine DVD's with a suggested retail price of $199.95.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Care Workers' Union For Kerry
description: New York State's largest union of health care workers, 1199/SEIU, announced yesterday that it was endorsing Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts for the Democratic presidential nomination. Dennis Rivera, left, president of 1199, which has more than 240,000 members, announced the endorsement while appearing with the senator's wife, Teresa Heinz Kerry, at the Children's Hospital of New York-Presbyterian. Officials from the union, one of the most politically active in the state, said they would call voters today to urge unionmembers to vote for Mr. Kerry. Four months ago, Mr. Rivera played a major role in persuading 1199's parent, the Service Employees International Union, to endorse Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: PEABODY ENERGY TO BUY 3 MINES FROM GERMAN COMPANY
description: The Peabody Energy Corporation, one of the largest coal producers in the nation, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two mines in Australia and one in Colorado from RAG of Germany for $441 million. The mines in Queensland, Australia, produce seven million metric tons a year of high-quality coal used by steel producers in the Pacific Rim, Peabody said. The Twentymile Mine in Colorado produces 7.5 million short tons a year of low-sulfur steam coal for power generators in the Southwest, Midwest and Mexico. RAG, the biggest coal miner in Germany, has been selling assets to trim debt and to focus on specialty chemicals. Peabody is based in St. Louis.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Postal Worker Gets Prison In Mail Theft
description: A postal worker was sentenced yesterday to 20 months in prison after admitting that she stole blank checks from a bulk-mail sorting facility and sold them to an identity-theft ring. Bank checks and other items pass through the New Jersey International and Bulk Mail Center in Jersey City, where the employee, Eloise Smith, sorted them into mail bags. Authorities accused Ms. Smith, 48, of Jersey City, of selling the checks to an identity-theft ring led by Joe Nathan Levine for $20 a box. Impersonators, using identification that matched the checks, would then use them to buy goods at stores, the United States attorney's office said. Prosecutors said that about $134,000 was taken from the accounts of bank customers, mainly from Bergen County, from February to December 2000. Mr. Levine, 41, also of Jersey City, pleaded guilty in October to buying the stolen checks. He is to be sentenced on Monday. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Microsoft And eBay Plan Venture
description: Microsoft announced a partnership with eBay yesterday that will allow Office applications to tie into the online auction service. The software giant plans to offer free sample code through the eBay Developers Program and later Microsoft's MSDN developer site for tying selected Office applications to the auctioneer's listing servers. The eBay Developers Program allows developers to create programs that help large-scale sellers on the site manage inventory, automate listings and do other tasks.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: New Chief At Airline
description: The new chief execu-tive of Alitalia, Marco Zanichelli, left, will meet trade union representatives today in Rome to discuss his plans for returning the state-owned airline to profitability. Mr. Zanichelli took over as chief executive on Friday after the resignation of Francesco Mengozzi, who ignored government pressure to amend a restructuring plan that called for 2,700 job cuts. Mr. Zanichelli, in an interview published in the Rome daily Il Messaggero on Sunday, praised Mr. Mengozzi's plan, but said that it had to be discussed with union leaders. The unions confirmed yesterday that they would strike on Friday. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: Financial Scandal Hits Hong Kong
description: Investigators have arrested 20 people here in a financial scandal involving accusations of bribery and rigging of share prices by corporate executives, fund managers, a research analyst and a securities broker.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Fatal Attack
description: A baker's assistant was killed and another injured in an explosion in the northern town of Taloqan that officials said was a suspected Taliban-inspired attack on a video store. The explosion early Saturday, the second in two weeks in the same place, destroyed the video store, said Gen. Mohammad Daoud, the military commander of northeast Afghanistan. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Woman, 34, Waiting for Cab Is Fatally Hit by Stray Bullet
description: A 34-year-old woman who had just left the Queens strip club where she worked overseeing dancers was fatally shot early yesterday as she waited for a cab on a Long Island City street. The woman, the authorities said, was hit by a stray bullet fired as a group of men argued across the street.

title: Blasts at Shiite Ceremonies in Iraq Kill More Than 140
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 2  Terrorist attacks ripped through Shiite Muslim religious ceremonies in Baghdad and the city of Karbala today, killing more than 140 people in the deadliest day of violence since the American-led occupation of Iraq began.

title: State Dept. Denies Leader Was Forced Out of Office
description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide asserted Monday that he had been driven from power in Haiti by the United States in ''a coup,'' an allegation dismissed by the White House as ''complete nonsense.''

title: Rescuing Education Reform
description: Democratic presidential candidates have discovered that there's no more surefire applause line than an attack on the No Child Left Behind Act. The law was meant to deliver on President Bush's promise to improve public school education. But many teachers and school districts resent being forced to meet the law's tough standards. Some of the strongest resistance has come from Republican states like Utah, which are considering laws that would limit their compliance.

title: U.S. Wants to Place Its Own Inspectors at Airports Abroad
description: Domestic security officials plan to station American inspectors at a number of airports in Europe, Asia and elsewhere to look for terrorists who may be using fraudulent travel documents, officials said Monday.

title: Paul Sweezy, 93, Marxist Publisher and Economist, Dies
description: Paul M. Sweezy, a Harvard University economist who left academia and became the nation's leading Marxist intellectual and publisher during the cold war and the McCarthy era, died Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 93.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Ruling Hurts Drug Maker
description: The Indian drug maker Dr. Reddy's Laboratories said its sales would probably fall short of its target in its next financial year after a court in the United States barred it from selling a version of Norvasc, Pfizer's $4-billion-a-year hypertension drug. The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on Friday reversed a judge's ruling permitting Dr. Reddy's to sell AmVaz, its chemically altered version of Pfizer's medicine. ''Our growth will be much lower because AmVaz was going to be a big part of sales,'' the chief executive, G.V. Prasad, said in a telephone interview from Hyderabad, India, where the company is based. ''Margins may also be hit for lack of a major launch'' of a medicine in the United States. He did not specify if earnings would fall.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit In Semiconductors
description: Wolfson Microelectronics, which makes semiconductors for Microsoft and Apple Computer, said full-year profit more than tripled, helped by increased demand for consumer electronics like digital cameras. Net income climbed to $9.24 million, or 9 cents a share, from $2.41 million, or 2 cents a share, a year ago. Sales more than doubled to $75.7 million from $33.7 million, the company said. ''We're in the sweet spot of the industry,'' David Milne, the Wolfson chief executive, said. ''We expect to see continued growth.'' Wolfson, based in Edinburgh, Scotland, is benefiting from surging sales of portable music players like Apple's iPod, which carries a Wolfson chip, and mobile phones that take pictures.

title: In Haiti, Mobs Are the Easy Part
description: It was June 1995, and I was standing beside a nervous Jordanian police officer in the doorway of a dusty, sweltering office as a gang of drunken Haitian thugs moved slowly up the porch stairs toward us, angry and menacing. The young Jordanian and I had been sent to the town of Corail, on Haiti's southwest coast, by the United Nations as observers for ongoing parliamentary elections. Haiti had been on edge in the eight months since 20,000 American troops deposed the military regime of Raoul Cedras and returned President Jean-Bertrand Aristide from exile the year before.

Kano is one of 12 northern states that adopted Shariah in 1999. (Reuters)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Contract For Iron Ore
description: The world's big-gest mining company, BHP Billiton, agreed to sell $9 billion of iron ore to four Chinese steel makers, under a 25-year contract. BHP Billiton, which is based in Melbourne, Australia, said it would supply 12 million metric tons of ore a year under a joint venture with the Chinese steel makers. The steel makers are the Maanshan Iron and Steel Company, the Tangshan Iron and Steel Company, the Wuhan Iron and Steel Company and the Jiangsu Shagang Group. The agreement expands BHP Billiton's iron ore sales in a market forecast to grow 21 percent this year. The company and rivals like the Rio Tinto Group are selling more minerals and metals to China, where demand for cars, homes and electronic appliances helped industrial production increase at a record monthly pace of 19 percent in January.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Human Body Parts Found
description: The police are investigating the discovery of a human head and partial torso stuffed into a black plastic bag yesterday morning in front of an apartment complex in Hollis. A building superintendent and his helper noticed the bag inside a fence outside 91-30 191st Street around 8 a.m. yesterday. Doug Patience, the site manager for the apartment buildings, said they thought at first that the bag contained a dead dog. ''Once we slit the bag open, we noticed it wasn't a dog when we saw skin,'' Mr. Patience said. The police have not identified the body, but said it was apparently that of a black man. The investigation will proceed once the medical examiner determines the cause of death. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALDANO, DANIEL
description: CALDANO -- Daniel. 64, passed away suddenly in his sleep on February 22, 2004. He is survived by his beloved sister Joan Caldano, f.s.p., cousins and many dear and treasured friends. Born and raised in NYC, Dan reveled in every aspect of the city's vibrancy. For 32 years he worked in the Butler Library at Columbia University and retired as the User Support Specialist in the library's systems office. His days of retirement were taken up by an almost daily commute between his home in Greenwich Village and either Lincoln Center or the Great White Way. He will be remembered for his vast knowledge and love of the arts, his keen intellect and quick wit, but most of all for his kind and generous heart which embraced all those around him. And he did it all with gusto one day at a time. A memorial service to be annoucned.

title: UNION PACIFIC SAYS PROFIT WILL NOT MEET FORECAST

The company said in January that earnings would be at least 30 percent more than last year's 57 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected the company to earn 79 cents a share. Union Pacific is not giving a new projection, a spokeswoman, Kathryn Blackwell, said.

title: Post-Oscar Reflections, Before We Forget
description: On the morning after the Academy Awards, most people, sensible people, go back to work, perhaps a little bleary-eyed from the broadcast, perhaps to claim their share of the office Oscar pool. (This was a bad year for cashing in big, since in virtually every category the long-established favorite was the winner, and there is no point spread to beat.) Others wake up to the gray Los Angeles dawn and sort through the detritus of the weekend -- the crumpled valet parking stubs, the strange skin-care products handed out in party goody bags, the cocktail napkins stained with the grease of too many minicrabcakes -- in search of, how to say it, meaning.

title: GENZYME IS LEAD BIDDER FOR IMPATH CANCER-TESTING UNIT
description: The Genzyme Corporation, which last week agreed to buy Ilex Oncology Inc. for about $1 billion in stock to enter the market for cancer treatments, said it was the lead bidder for the cancer testing business of Impath Inc. The company bid $215 million in cash for Impath's physician services unit, said Dan Quinn, a spokesman for Genzyme. The purchase may be completed in the second quarter, subject to a bankruptcy court's approval, he said. The acquisition would be Genzyme's third in six months as growth slows for its best sellers, the enzyme-replacement therapy Cerezyme and the dialysis drug Renagel. Impath, with $127 million in debt, sought protection from creditors in September.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN PRESIDENT WILL ADD CHIEF ROLE

Stevens, will become chief executive on Aug. 6, after the retirement of the current chairman and chief executive, Vance Coffman. Mr. Stevens, 52, will retain the title of president, while Mr. Coffman, 59, will continue as chairman until April 2005, Lockheed said. Mr. Coffman has worked at Lockheed for 37 years, including 7 years as chief executive. Mr. Stevens joined Lockheed in December 1993, became chief financial officer in 1999 and was promoted to president and chief operating officer in October of the following year. Lockheed is based in Bethesda, Md.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Acxiom To Buy Consodata Companies
description: The Acxiom Corporation, which makes software for database management, said yesterday that it offered to buy some of Seat Pagine Gialle S.p.A.'s Consodata companies for about $37.5 million (30 million euros) in cash to expand in Europe. Seat would sell its Consodata companies in Britain, France, Germany and Spain, and keep the units in the United States and Italy, Acxiom said. Consodata manages one of Europe's largest databases of information on consumer lifestyles and behaviors, Acxiom said. The purchase will add $63 million to $69 million to sales in its 2005 fiscal year. The companies expect the transaction to close in the quarter beginning April 1. Acxiom's shares rose 39 cents, to $19.87.

title: America's Expanding Middle
description: Most of us know only a few of the technical terms for the parts of our anatomy. We prefer the common names, which -- useful as they are -- don't always cover everything that needs naming. We can be grateful, therefore, to the SizeUSA survey for bringing us the phrase ''lower front waist.'' The SizeUSA survey is an attempt to measure accurately the shapes of Americans -- 10,000 of them -- as they really exist in the here and now and to reformulate the idea of average sizes based on those measurements. A lot has changed since 1941, when the last such national survey was done -- including the girth of Americans.

A prominent pediatrician, she lived and worked for more than three decades in Leningrad, Russia until her immigration to the United States in 1979. Her absolute dedication to work was reciprocated by the love of her little patients and their families, as well as the respect of her colleagues. In addition to being an outstanding physician, she was also a wonderful wife and mother. She is survived by her husband Ruvim Poretsky of Manhattan, and her two sons, Dimitry Poretsky of Laguna Beach, CA. and Dr. Leonid Poretsky of Manhattan. Funeral service Wednesday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Dr. Nina Poretsky Memorial Fund, Division of Endocrinology and Metabolism, Beth Israel Medical Center, 317 E. 17 St., 7th Flr, N.Y., N.Y. 10003, Attn: Leonid Poretsky, M.D.

title: MEDIMMUNE FLU VACCINE WILL NOT HELP PROFITS UNTIL 2007
description: MedImmune Inc. said sales and profit would be hindered for years as it works to develop an improved version of the slow-selling FluMist influenza vaccine. Shares of MedImmune declined 6.2 percent. FluMist will not significantly add to earnings until the new version becomes available in 2007, MedImmune said. The chief executive, David M. Mott, said the company, which is based in Gaithersburg, Md., will keep selling FluMist with or without its partner, Wyeth. Sales of FluMist fell short of MedImmune's goals even after supplies of traditional flu shots ran out in the United States, partly because the spray is about nine times as expensive. FluMist revenue will be no more than $55 million this year, and first-quarter profit will fall short of analysts' estimates, the company said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Street Vendor Bill Goes To Governor
description: The State Legislature adopted a bill yesterday to control vendors in Times Square and other congested areas of New York City. A law regulating vendors lapsed last spring and legislators had failed to reinstate it, despite a clog of vendors in some of Manhattan's busiest neighborhoods. The new measure passed by a vote of 60 to 1 in the Senate and by an unofficial vote of 143 to 3 in the Assembly, officials said. Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to sign it into law, said Lynn Rasic, a spokeswoman. The bill would keep many aspects of the old law intact but add new restrictions. It would make the area around ground zero in Lower Manhattan off limits to vendors and would add a block of 42nd Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, to the list of restricted areas. title: 'GREY ALBUM' DOWNLOADS
description: Tens of thousands of copies of the underground unauthorized music collection ''The Grey Album'' were downloaded last Tuesday in a one-day Internet protest of EMI's attempt to halt its dissemination. The album, by Brian Burton, a Los Angeles D.J. who records as Danger Mouse, combines raps from Jay-Z's ''Black Album'' with re-mixed music from the Beatles' classic White Album. The protest's organizer, Nicholas Reville, a co-founder of the music industry watchdog group Downhill Battle, said the ''The Grey Album'' was downloaded more frequently than the best-selling album in America, Norah Jones's ''Feels Like Home,'' was purchased. At least 360,000 tracks from ''The Grey Album'' -- or 30,000 albums' worth (the album has 12 tracks) -- were downloaded from just 54 of the more than 150 Web sites taking part in the protest. Those 54 responded to an inquiry by The New York Times with data transfer documentation. Jeanne Meyer, an EMI spokeswoman, called the numbers ''irrelevant to the fact that we are asking those who have illegally made an unauthorized work available to stop doing it.'' Ms. Meyer declined to comment on whether EMI would pursue legal action against the Web sites. BILL WERDE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUBBARD, DAVID RICHARDSON
description: HUBBARD--David Richardson, of Bloomfield, CT, formerly of West Hartford, CT, died Monday, March 1, 2004. Born in 1916 in Pelham Manor, NY, he was the loving son of the late Allen Skinner Hubbard and Harriet Richardson Hubbard and lived in the Hartford area most of his life. He graduated from Hotchkiss School in 1935, Yale University in 1939, and Cornell Law School in 1947. He was the beloved husband of the late Margaret Ackerly Hubbard, beloved father of Edna Hubbard Travis Adams of NYC and Colebrook, CT; Rev. Harriet Hubbard McConnochie of Pittsford, NY; Dr. David Richardson Hubbard, Jr. of Poway, CA; and Dana Hubbard Kaminsky of Ft. Wayne, In; beloved grandfather of 11 grandchildren and three great grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother, Allen Skinner Hubbard, Jr. of Vero Beach, FL; and his sisters Betsy Hubbard Stott of Bloomfield, CT, and Charlotte Hubbard Fries of North Andover, MA. He served as Navigator in the U.S. Army Air Corps during WWII. He was associated with the law firm of Day, Berry, and Howard from 1947 to 1952. From 1953 to 1974 he was with the Trust Division of the former Hartford National Bank. At the time of his retirement in 1974 he was a Vice-President in charge of the Legal Section of the Trust Division. He was also an active volunteer for many years in the Hartford area. His family and friends will miss him and always remember him for his cheerful, kind, and supportive nature which, combined with his fairness, honesty, humility, and loyalty, encouraged others. A memorial service will be held Monday, March 22, 2004, at 1:00 P.M. at St. John's Episcopal Church, 679 Farmington Avenue, West Hartford, CT. Contributions may be made to Yale University, St. John's Episcopal Church, or a charity of one's choice.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Coke Questioned On Bottled Tap
description: Britons harrumphed when they discovered that a brand of bottled water introduced by Coca-Cola was no more than, well, water. The new brand, Dasani, is the second-biggest seller in the United States. But when British newspapers discovered that it was tap water purified in south London, they complained. ''It's the real thing -- Coke's tap-water from Sidcup,'' sniped the London Times. Others said the price -- up to $1.77 a bottle -- was several thousand times higher than tap water itself. Coca-Cola said its product was ''compliant with all guidelines and regulations.'' But the regulatory Food Standards Agency asked local authorities to investigate whether the company was entitled to use the word ''pure'' on Dasani labels. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers Offer Alternative
description: Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers, proposed an alternative yesterday to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to hold back third graders who fail citywide tests. Ms. Weingarten's plan would set up special fourth-grade classes for students who score in the lowest of four levels on their third-grade citywide tests. Failing third-graders would be promoted to special fourth-grade classes with only 15 students each, highly trained teachers and other extra resources. The union plans to detail the proposal today at a City Council Education Committee hearing. Mr. Bloomberg's plan would provide a summer school for such third graders, but would hold them back if they still failed the tests at the end of the summer. Jerry Russo, the press secretary for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said the mayor's plan would reverse the trend of pushing forward unprepared children. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Copy Protection Technology Developed
description: Hewlett-Packard and Royal Philips Electronics said yesterday that they had developed copy protection technology that enables recording of digital television broadcast signals only once. The technology has been submitted to the Federal Communications Commission for approval, said Philips, based in Amsterdam, and Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif. The technology consists of new discs for the so-called DVD+R, DVD+RW and DVD+R Double Layer formats that allow only single copies to be made from digital TV broadcasts. The discs will be compatible with current and future DVD-format players and recorders, the companies said.

title: WASHINGTON: KENNEDY CENTER'S SEASON
description: A six-month festival celebrating the arts in America during the 1940's, including a tribute to the jazz great Charlie Parker and performances by Dance Theater of Harlem, American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet, will be the centerpiece of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts next season, officials announced yesterday. With a budget of nearly $14 million, the festival is the most comprehensive and expensive program that the center has produced, officials said. It will reflect what the center's president, Michael M. Kaiser, called the decade's ''varied palette'' of arts, including film, dance, jazz and popular music, fashion and theater. Dance Theater of Harlem will perform ''St. Louis Woman: A Blues Ballet,'' the company's newest ballet, with choreography by Michael Smuin to songs by Harold Arlen and Johnny Mercer, in January 2005. The American Ballet Theater presentation will span two weeks in February 2005 with three programs, to include ''Giselle'' and ''Swan Lake,'' both part of the company's repertory during the 1940's. The National Symphony Orchestra will perform its season-opening concert on Sept. 26 in honor of the music director Leonard Slatkin's 60th birthday. Participating artists will include the flutist James Galway, the violinists Joshua Bell and Midori, the pianists Emanuel Ax, Michel Camilo, Joseph Kalichstein and Katia and Marielle Labque and the violinist and conductor Itzhak Perlman. JOHN FILES

title: Congress and the Gun Lobby
description: Anyone concerned about having a rational gun policy in this country had reason for grave concern yesterday as Congress snarled itself into a frenzy of election-year politicking and bare-knuckle pressure from a gun lobby aided by President Bush. In the end, the Senate killed a disastrous bill that would have compromised justice and public safety by gutting the rights of crime victims to sue irresponsible gun makers and shady weapons dealers. Lawmakers whose votes against the bill were dictated by the National Rifle Association's display of raw power deserve no praise. Their aim was to kill two amendments that would have extended the nation's ban on assault weapons and required background checks on weapons buyers at gun shows.

title: A Promising Choice in Russia
description: Everything Vladimir Putin does these days is perceived as a move to further consolidate his power. Certainly, he has no shortage of power, with a rubber-stamp Parliament in place and an inevitable landslide in the presidential election on March 14. But the real question is how he intends to use that power, and the nomination of Mikhail Fradkov as the new prime minister points in a promising direction. Mr. Fradkov, 53, has spent the last few years working on some of Russia's toughest issues -- as a foreign trade official, as chief tax collector and, most recently, as envoy to the European Union. He's been doing what Russia needs to do: reform the administration, get the books in order, combat corruption, halt capital flight and work on Russia's international standing.

Revenue rose 4.8 percent, to 1.9 billion euros ($2.3 billion). Fyffes was helped by last year's currency fluctuations because it buys most of its bananas and other produce in dollars. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGELHARD, JANE
description: ENGELHARD--Jane. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Jane Engelhard, whose generosity--together with that of her late husband Charles--enhanced a whole generation in the life of the Metropolitan Museum. Beginning in 1968, they donated works of art as well as funds for a broad range of activities, from acquisitions and building initiaties to exhibitions and curatorial programs. Always thoughtful and involved as Trustee from 1974 to 1981, and as Trustee Emerita in the years since, she helped to guide this institution through an important period of growth and advancement. One of the most loved spaces at the Metropolitan, The Charles Englehard Court--an airy, glass-enclosed garden for the display of American sculpture and architecture that serves as the gateway to the vast collections of The American Wing--is a tribute to the vision and devotion of the Englehards that will inspire and enlighten visitors for many years to come. To our beloved Vice Chairman Annette de la Renta, and to the entire family, we extend our deep condolences. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director David E. McKinney, President

The ambitious goals of their advertising and marketing campaigns: persuade millions of consumers who increasingly prefer to leave home for their coffee fixes to stay home -- and add another appliance to crowded kitchens.

title: Hubris and the Fall of a Telecommunications Empire
description: No one has reflected the tumultuous ups and downs of the telecommunications business in recent decades more clearly than Bernard J. Ebbers, the former junior high school basketball coach from Canada who is scheduled to be arraigned today on federal fraud charges arising from the spectacular collapse of WorldCom, the corporate empire he built through dozens of aggressive acquisitions.

title: Inquiry Finds Sharp Increase In Health Insurance Schemes
description: Federal investigators said Tuesday that they had found a sharp increase in health insurance scams by unlicensed companies that offer cheap coverage, collect millions of dollars in premiums from consumers and small businesses, but then refuse to pay claims.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Weapons Inquiry To Continue
description: A spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair said an inquiry into how intelligence was used to justify the war in Iraq would go forward despite a decision by the Conservative Party leader, Michael Howard, to withdraw his endorsement of the bipartisan investigation. The inquiry is headed by Lord Butler, a former private secretary to three prime ministers. In a letter, Mr. Howard criticized Lord Butler for focusing narrowly on ''structures, systems and processes'' of how intelligence was developed on Iraq without examining how politicians used intelligence to mobilize public opinion for war. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: House G.O.P. to Drop Idea of Penalty for Steep Rises in Tuition
description: House Republicans plan to announce today that they are withdrawing legislation that would have imposed financial penalties on colleges and universities that raised tuition too sharply.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Cliffside Park: Woman Found Dead
description: A woman was found dead on Monday and her boyfriend was arrested and charged with murder, the police said yesterday. The police said that responding to a 911 call, they found the body of Morgan Cameron, 36, in bed while her boyfriend, Ronald Daigle, 27, was found bleeding from his wrists. Mr. Daigle was treated at a hospital in North Bergen, then was arrested and taken to the Bergen County Jail. Bail was set at $1 million. Co-workers of Ms. Cameron , an account executive at an Internet company, had reported her missing from work. The Bergen County prosecutor's office said Ms. Cameron was hit in the head and strangled. Mr. Daigle does not have a lawyer yet, prosecutors said. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: When a Lightweight Is Just What You Need
description: I'D like to speak out in defense of pinot grigio. It's a wine that gets little respect, and perhaps rightly so. But it is also a wine that is damned even in theory, and that's not right at all.

title: Because Few Dishes Call for Fingernail Clippings
description: A chef's legerdemain with a knife is stunning to watch, as an onion becomes a pile of translucent shards or a cucumber turns rapidly into disks that could have come from a mandoline. Such skill requires a good, sharp knife, of course, and lots of practice. A little gadget is now available that might help home cooks build enough confidence to make proper slicing strokes: a stainless steel cap for the three fingers that gently hold the food in place, offering protection from less-than-accomplished whacks. The regular-size guard is $12.95 from Williams-Sonoma catalogs, (800) 541-2233 or www.williams-sonoma.com; at Art of Cooking, 555 Hudson Street (Perry Street), both regular and large sizes are $12.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COGGESHALL, DR. BAYARD
description: COGGESHALL--Dr. Bayard, 87, of Basking Ridge, NJ formerly of Mendham and Morristown in NJ passed away at home Friday, February 27th. He was born in Morristown on Tuesday, June 27, 1916 to the late Murray and Jane (Magor) Coggeshall. He was the husband of Mary S. (Achilles) Coggeshall. Dr. Coggeshall was a practicing Pediatrician in Morristown for 41 years retiring in 1990. He graduated from Princeton University in 1939 where he was a member of the Ivy Club, and from McGill University Medical School, Montreal, Canada in 1943. Dr. Coggeshall served during WWII from 1943 to 1946 as a Medical Officer in the US Naval Medical Corp. He was a member of St. John's on the Mountain, Bernardsville, NJ, where he had served as a member of the Vestry. He also served as a volunteer for the Dover Free Clinic, was a member of the Board of Directors for the Princeton-Blairstown Center in Blairstown and was a member of Somerset Hills Golf Club. In addition to his wife Dr. Coggeshall is survived by his 3 daughters Patricia Dominick of Olympia, WA., Joan Nordberg of Orebro, Sweden and Cynthia Trask, of Old Greenwich, CT.; 2 sons Charles of Bethesda, MD and David of Morristown. He is also survived by 13 grandchildren and 5 greatgrandchildren. He was predeceased by his brothers Murray Jr. and John and his sister Marion Pitman. There will be a memorial service at St. John's on the Mountain, 379 Harmony Rd, Bernardsville, NJ at 1 PM on Thursday, March 4th. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to: Princeton-Blairstown Center, 350 Alexander St., Princeton University, Princeton, NJ. 08544-7106 or Cystic Fibrosis, New Jersey State Organization, 555 Preakness Avenue, Totowa, NJ 07512. For information: Rowe-Lanterman Home for Funerals, 973-538-0520.

title: Many at Successful Middle School Oppose Its Expansion
description: The Manhattan East School for Arts and Academics, on the fifth floor of a brick school building overlooking the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, is an oasis of excellence in East Harlem and among New York City middle schools. While many middle schools are failing, Manhattan East is one of 200 with test scores so high it was exempted from a new citywide curriculum. Its jazz ensemble has won awards, and its graduates go on to the city's top high schools.

description: A Queens man charged in the death of a pedestrian who was struck by a vehicle on Park Avenue in January now faces the more serious charge of second-degree manslaughter, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Bid Off, but Barclay Brothers Are Said to Still Want Papers
description: The billionaire Barclay brothers formally withdrew their offer to acquire Hollinger Inc. on Tuesday, but people close to them said that the brothers still want to buy the Daily and Sunday Telegraph newspapers -- the jewels in Conrad Black's media empire.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Visa Names Executive
description: Visa Internation-al, the payments processing system that is shared and owned by 21,000 banks around the world, named a British banking executive, Christopher J. Rodrigues, left, as chief executive. Mr. Rodrigues, 54, is currently the chief executive of Bradford & Bingley, a mortgage lender based in Yorkshire, but has previously held positions at American Express and Thomas Cook. Mr. Rodrigues will focus on using new technology to process the $2.7 trillion in payments that Visa handles annually, and on expanding Visa's network in developing countries, he said in an interview. Visa International is based in San Francisco. Heather Timmons (NYT)

An All-American Afternoon of Life in America
description: The all-American baritone is as much a part of the opera scene these days as the high-strung tenor, and they don't get much more all-American and wholesome than Nathan Gunn. On Sunday afternoon Mr. Gunn, famed for his fine voice, fine looks and fine physique, made his recital debut at Alice Tully Hall, with his wife, Julie Gunn, at the piano. They offered an unusual and ambitious American program that at once broke the mold of the conventional recital and shored up Mr. Gunn's wholesome image, almost to the point of tedium.

title: Houston Tries to Banish Enron's Ghosts
description: The 40-story tower in the heart of this city's central business district was built for the Enron Corporation, but the bankrupt energy trading company never moved in. Instead, the building at 1500 Louisiana Street has stood empty for most of the two years since it was completed, a grim reminder of a financial debacle that rippled through the merchant energy business and the downtown office market.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Corruption Figure Sentenced
description: Lisa A. Thiesfield was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison for her role in the state treasury scandal. Ms. Thiesfield, 33, of Hartford, the former mistress and campaign manager of former Treasurer Paul J. Silvester, pleaded guilty last September to participating in a corrupt payment to Mr. Silvester by accepting a $1 million contract with Triumph Capital, a Boston investment firm. Mr. Silvester, an appointee of Gov. John G. Rowland, gave Triumph management of a $200 million state pension fund. Ms. Thiesfield also has to serve six months of house arrest and three years of probation and pay a $50,000 fine. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: A Grasso Supporter Sells a Big Board Seat
description: Kenneth G. Langone, the former director of the New York Stock Exchange who is most closely associated with its former chairman, Richard A. Grasso, sold one of his seats on the exchange for $1.5 million yesterday.

title: Rape Shield Law Becomes Focal Point in Bryant's Case
description: In the eight months since his arrest on a charge of sexual assault, Kobe Bryant has been the unquestioned star of his own legal case, as much the center of attention in a court of law as he is on the basketball court as a guard for the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Skyscraper Rampage Suit Dismissed
description: A state appeals court panel in Manhattan has dismissed the complaint of two men who sued the owners and operators of the Empire State Building after being wounded in a 1997 shooting on the building's observation deck. The gunman killed one person and wounded six others, including the plaintiffs, Matthew Gross and Mario Carmona, before fatally shooting himself. The lawsuit charged that security at the building was inadequate. In its decision released yesterday, the panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said that in this instance, landlords are not responsible for the safety of everyone who visits their property and could not have reasonably foreseen this danger. A lawyer for Mr. Gross and Mr. Carmona did not immediately return a call for comment. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Firefighter Convicted Of Theft
description: A retired firefighter who was accused of stealing from ground zero while volunteering after the Sept. 11 attack was convicted in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday of all but two charges of petty larceny. The former firefighter, Samuel Brandon, 60, was charged with 11 counts of petty larceny. According to court papers, an investigator found items belonging to victims of the attack during a search of Mr. Brandon's home in Pine Bush, N.Y., in 2002. The items included a photograph of a bride and groom at a wedding reception, identification cards for employees of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a two-way radio. Mr. Brandon faces up to nine years in jail when sentenced. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: 1,100 JOBS TO BE LOST IN CLOSINGS OF OFFICEMAX STORES
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation said yesterday that it expected to close 45 of its recently acquired OfficeMax stores in the second quarter and eliminate 1,100 jobs. In its annual report filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Boise Cascade said it had identified stores that were not strategically or economically viable and planned to close them by June 30. Of the 1,100 employees whose jobs are to be eliminated, Boise Cascade said, 500 will be offered transfers to other OfficeMax stores. Boise Cascade has 55,618 employees, which includes about 18,000 part-time workers, according to the filing.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: 'Boy In The Window' Settles Suit
description: Patrick Ireland, the Columbine High School student who became known as ''the boy in the window'' after escaping the shooting there on April 20, 1999, by falling out of a window, has settled with Jefferson County for $117,500. Mr. Ireland, now a college student, had sued the county because, he said, rescuers did not do enough to help him as he struggled to get out of the school after being shot twice in the head. Law enforcement officials positioned a truck underneath the school's second-floor library window, but no one entered the school to help the injured boy, who crawled through the window and landed on the truck. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: AIDS Financing Increased
description: New York City has received the largest Ryan White Title I grant ever awarded from the federal government. The grant, $122 million, was awarded by the Department of Health and Human Services to finance H.I.V.-AIDS services and is $18.2 million more than the city received last year. ''The increase in funding was merited by strengthening our coordination of H.I.V. services and federal recognition'' that the disease disproportionately affects the city, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said in a written statement. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

But if you want a seasonal delicacy here now, you will need a sharp auger and some ear flaps. Or you can wait at the Shelburne Supermarket for Albert Gebo's next delivery.

title: Technology Briefing | Courts: I.B.M. Settles Birth Defects Suit
description: Less than a week after I.B.M. prevailed in a similar case in California, the company yesterday settled a lawsuit filed in White Plains by a woman who claimed she suffered birth defects as a result of her mother's working conditions at I.B.M. The woman, Candace Curtis, now 22, was born without kneecaps and with a deformed skull, conditions she claimed were caused by her mother's exposure to hazardous chemicals when working at I.B.M.'s Fishkill plant while she was pregnant. The terms of the settlement were not disclosed. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

description: Georgia's headlong rush to block gay marriages through a constitutional amendment has been stalled, for the moment, by an unlikely group of legislators: black members of the House of Representatives, many of them church deacons and ministers who already support the state's laws banning same-sex marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, MELBA
description: SILVER--Melba. The National Basketball Association is deeply saddened by the loss of Melba Silver, beloved mother of our colleague Adam Silver. Devoted mother of Ann, Erik, Owen and Adam, Melba will be remembered for her numerous accomplishments and benevolent involvement in the Cities of Rye, New York and Boca Raton, FL. As a resident of Rye for more than 50 years, she co-authored the Rye City Charter, served as Chair of the City of Rye Planning Commission and President of the Rye Library. In Boca Raton, she was an active Board Member of Planned Parenthood of South Palm Beach and Broward Counties, President of the Boca Raton Symphony and Chair of the Florida Philharmonic's Boca Raton Board of Directors. Her passing is a sad loss to the NBA Family and we send our heartfelt condolences to Adam and his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Melba Silver to Planned Parenthood of South Palm Beach and Broward Counties, 455 N.W. 35 St., Boca Raton, FL. 33431.

This toy and clothing store, which opened last year, has a section devoted to playing house, especially in the kitchen. It has stacked bins of bright enameled-wood fruits and vegetables, $3.50 each, as well as sets of sturdy pots and pans and dishes, make-believe stoves and even painted wooden foods boxed in the four food groups. Diana Rudman, the owner, buys her well-made, nonelectronic educational toys in Europe. (Her children, Nicky and Laura, play customer, above.) Some of the toys are also sold at www.didis.net.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: KATY SPARKS is now in charge of the kitchen at COMPASS, 208 West 70th Street. Ms. Sparks, left, who was the chef at Quilty's in SoHo, which closed, had been trying to open her own restaurant. ''The deals kept falling through, and I just wanted to be cooking again,'' she said. She described her new menu at Compass as global, with some Germanic touches like spaetzle, horseradish and pumpkinseed oil. She replaces Mark Andelbradt. The front room of the restaurant is to become a wine bar.

title: MARATHON OIL DROPS PLAN TO BUILD ENERGY COMPLEX
description: The Marathon Oil Corporation said that it was dropping plans to build a $1.7 billion energy complex south of Tijuana, Mexico, after the Baja California state government expropriated the site this weekend. State officials said the site did not meet land-use requirements for the region. Some nearby residents have opposed the project, saying it posed a safety risk. Marathon, based in Houston, planned to build a liquefied natural gas terminal, a power plant and a wastewater treatment operation in the area and had received approval from the federal government's Regulatory Energy Commission. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

description: BRADY -- Mary (Hagerty) ''Mimi,'' of Scarsdale, NY, passed into eternal life on March 1st, after a brief illness. A graduate of Manhattanville College ('48), she is survived by her five children: Mary Elizabeth Brady of Scarsdale, NY; Edward A. Brady, Jr. of White Plains, NY; Suzanne Forlivio of New Britain, CT; Margot Hill and her husband, William Hill, of Stoneham, MA; and Thomas C. Brady of Bedford Hills, NY. She is also survived by her brother, Harry C. Hagerty, Jr., and his wife, Mary Ann Hagerty, of Sea Island, GA. Mimi is also survived by three granddaughters, Leah Forlivio, Meaghan and Shannon Brady. Family will receive friends Wednesday, March 3rd, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Ave., Scarsdale, NY 10583, (914) 725-1137. Mass of Christian Burial will be held Thursday, 10 AM, at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Strathmore Rd., Scarsdale, (914) 723-7421, followed by interment at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Mimi's memory to Our Lady of Fatima Vestment Fund.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 9/11 Registry Tops 25,000
description: More than 25,000 people have signed onto a registry devised to track the long-term health effects of the World Trade Center attack, the City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene announced yesterday. City officials urged anyone who lives or attends school in Lower Manhattan, was in the area on Sept. 11, 2001, or was involved in the rescue and cleanup, to enroll in the registry, along with those who think their health might have been affected. Anyone can take part by calling 1-866-NYC-WTCR (1-866-692-9827), toll-free, and giving a 30-minute interview. The registry will periodically call people who enroll, to track their health problems over the years. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

Actually, the trip began at L'Impero in Tudor City, where the question was put to Christopher Cannon, an owner and the wine director. As long as the pinot grigio had the ''Germanic and Austrian accents you find in the Alto Adige,'' he said, he would suggest ''roasted pheasant with juniper berries and smoked ham.''

title: Estrogen Therapy Woes
description: Another stake has been driven into hopes that long-term hormonal treatment might provide health benefits to postmenopausal women. The National Institutes of Health halted a trial of estrogen therapy in thousands of American women this week because it increased the risk of stroke and failed to protect against heart disease, the main potential health benefit. The findings give further reason to limit hormone therapy primarily to uses where all agree it is valuable: short-term treatment to relieve acute symptoms of menopause, like hot flashes and vaginal discomfort.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLIVE, JONATHAN MILLER, PH.D.
description: CLIVE -- Jonathan Miller, Ph.D., 58. Biostatistician Jonathan Clive, longtime director of biostatistical research at the University of Connecticut Health Center, died on Friday after a long illness. Charismatic, mercurial and brilliant, Jon was beloved to family and friends, as well as distinguished in the realm of applied science. At Duke University and later at UConn he spearheaded research and turned dreaded courses into popular electives. Jon is survived by his mother, two brothers, a sister-in-law, two nieces and a loving extended family. Contributions may be sent to: The UConn Foundation-Jonathan Clive, Ph.D. Biostatistical Fund, 263 Farmington Ave, Farmington, CT. 06032.

title: BAYER RECEIVES APPROVAL TO TEST BLOOD PLASMA FOR H.I.V.
description: Bayer, the German drug and chemical maker, received regulatory approval in the United States to test for H.I.V. in blood plasma, enabling Bayer to confirm the safety of plasma used in its treatments. The Food and Drug Administration also approved a Roche Holding test for H.I.V. in blood plasma, and Bayer uses some of that technology. The test, which examines nucleic acid in blood plasma, is as sensitive as those available through commercial laboratories, Bayer said. Bayer, based in Leverkusen, Germany, will be the first plasma processor to conduct internal testing of plasma after the F.D.A. approval, meaning infected donors can be notified and prevented from making further donations.

title: For Lower Manhattan, Tower Offers a Residential Stairway to the Sky
description: Santiago Calatrava has designed a skyscraper with the buoyancy of a child's balloon. The design takes me back to 1966 and the helium-filled Mylar ''Silver Cloud'' sculptures that Andy Warhol presented that year at Leo Castelli's gallery. The tower is effervescent, lighter than air. Yet its impact on the skyline is likely to be profound, not merely as an individual work of genius but as an example of what can be achieved when a city rediscovers the quality of delight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGELHARD, JANE
description: ENGELHARD -- Jane. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Libary mourn the death of Jane Engelhard. She served as a valuable member of the Board of Trustees from 1974 to 1986 and was a Trustee Emerita from 1986 to 2004. Jane, exceptionally intelligent and deeply committed to the highest standards in all things, was a singularly inspiring presence at the Morgan Libary, to which she made contributions of lasting importance. And her kindness, like her elegance and generosity, will not be forgotten. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family, especially to her daughter Annette de la Renta, a Trustee of the Libary, as well as her daughters Sophie Craighead, Susan O'Connor, Sally Engelhard Pingree, and Charlene Engelhard Troy, Fellows of the Library. The plan, part of a larger move to streamline the menu and make customer service more efficient, is already under way at the company's 13,000 American restaurants. Among other changes, the company said it would cut the number of French fry sizes to three from five and reduce its largest order to 6 ounces from 7 ounces. Maurine's generosity to and faithful participation in these committee's events always ensured a lively and stimulating discussion and celebration of the Museum's research resources. Lowry, Director Agnes Gund, President Emerita Barbara Jakobson, Chair, Trustee Committee on Museum Archives, Library & Research Milan R. Hughston, Chief of Library & Museum Archives The Museum of Modern Art, New York

title: A Simple Shape For a Puzzle of a Clock
description: The ubiquitous Philippe Starck has turned his designing hands to making a clock -- a complicated one. Some models even have a remote unit that will tell the temperature and humidity outside, and others have a radio and can project the time onto the ceiling. But hark: only the shape is simple. Clark Chen, a senior marketing manager for Oregon Scientific in Tualatin, Ore., which makes the clock, estimated it would take someone two hours to learn how to use it.

title: A Bet on a Brazilian Brewery Pays Off for 3 Investors
description: When Jorge Paulo Lemann, Carlos Alberto Sicupira and Marcel Telles bought Companhia Cervejaria Brahma in 1989, what the three investment bankers got for their $50 million was a traditional, but somewhat tired Brazilian brewery that barely dripped dividends.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 24 about the bonds forged between John Kerry and the crews of the Swift boats he commanded during the Vietnam War referred incorrectly to casualty statistics cited by Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., who devised the boat operation. He said the officers involved had a 75 percent chance of being killed or wounded -- not of being killed.

title: When the Intern Needs A Crash Course on Life
description: She seemed the perfect fit. About a year and a half ago, managers at Slack Barshinger, a Chicago advertising agency, hired a recent graduate of a local college for a paid three-month internship.

title: Chief Executives Planning to Hire Outnumber Those Who Foresee Cuts
description: Chief executives of the nation's largest companies say they are finally ready to begin hiring again.

title: Helping the Elderly Stay Put
description: ELDERLY New Yorkers who would rather stay in their apartments than move into nursing homes got a potential boost last week from the New York State Department of Health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEHREND, BERNARD, M.D.
description: BEHREND -- Bernard, M.D. Died on March 2, at 95, of congestive heart failure in Philadelphia. He was former Medical Director at the Philadelphia Inquirer, and former Director of Occupational Health at Smith, Kline & French. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Medical School in 1933. He was also Emeritus Associate Professor of Occupational Medicine at the Medical College of Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Rose Susan (Hirschhorn) Behrend, his sons, David and Daniel of Philadelphia, and daughter, Catherine of New York City, a sister, Sara, four grandchildren, two daughters-in-law, and two great-nephews. Services will be held at Congregation Rodeph Shalom, 615 North Broad St, today, at 2 PM. Private interment.

title: A River Shortchanged, Again
description: The Army Corps of Engineers is still refusing to do right by the once-majestic Missouri River. Three years ago, the Fish and Wildlife Service ordered the corps to alter seasonal flows on the heavily dammed river -- raising water levels during the spring, lowering them during the summer -- to save an endangered fish called the pallid sturgeon as well as two endangered bird species. Last Friday, defying not only the service but also the courts, the corps essentially refused. The only winners here are a few Missouri politicians. The environment and the larger economic interests of the region all lose.

title: Earth-Friendly Pieces In Dances of Color
description: With Q Collection's first line of furniture and fabrics, it has made green haute. The company, founded by Jesse Johnson, who has a degree from Yale in environmental management, and the interior designer Anthony Cochran, is dedicated to sustainable production and fine design. The 17 pieces in its Curves collection, with sofas and chairs, tables and stools, come in fabrics that embrace the use of color, putting to rest the notion that natural means neutral. Right, the Abigail settee in Luna satin wool, $17,830, and the Bessie chair, $2,717.50, in a mustard-seed-colored wool in the Acrobat pattern. (Pillows start at $220.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOINGS, MARY LOUIS
description: GOINGS--Mary Louis. Beloved daughter of Brenda Nichol Goings of Mount Airy, NC and Rick Goings of Windermere, FL, passed away on Sunday, February 29, 2004. She was born on October 19, 1977 in Charlottesville, VA. She was a graduate of Salem Academy, Winston Salem, NC and North Carolina State University. She is survived by sisters, Anna, Amy, and Kristina Goings; brothers, Rett and Todd Goings, Christopher, Miles, and Nico Porcaro; her stepmother, Susan Porcaro Goings; and her grandmother Louise Goings, Winston Salem, NC. She was preceded in death by her maternal grandparents William and Iris Nichol, and her paternal grandfather E.V. Goings. Donations may be made to The Boys & Girls Club of America, 1230 West Peachtree Street, Atlanta, GA. 30309.

title: Corporate Democracy and the Power to Embarrass
description: Corporate democracy in America has most often been a lot like Soviet democracy: the votes didn't really matter, because only one candidate was on the ballot and was assured of winning, whatever the voters thought.

title: The Collections / Paris : Dior is big, bright and bold
description: Wednesday should have been V for victory day at Dior. First affiliated luxury company LVMH (Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton) announced a 30 percent rise in profits for 2003, so that Bernard Arnault sat front row with dark and dashing Liz Hurley and blonde Rebecca Romijn-Stamos looking like the proverbial cat with the cream.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Councilman Supports Mayor
description: In a highly unusual move for a Democratic councilman, Kendall Stewart, who represents the 45th District in Brooklyn, yesterday endorsed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for re-election. ''I know the mayor is on our side,'' Mr. Stewart, left, said during a visit with the mayor and Simcha Felder, a Democrat who represents the 44th District, at a center for the elderly in Borough Park. ''We have to keep him in office,'' Mr. Stewart added. Mr. Felder, who will soon be using the mayor's Upper East Side town house for a fund-raiser, also praised the mayor, saying that he had preserved services for the elderly and had pursued education reform. The City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, is expected to challenge Mr. Bloomberg in 2005. Jennnifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REESE, CHRISTOPHER M.
description: REESE--Christopher M. On March 2, 2004. Beloved husband of Georgiana (nee Pugliese). Devoted brother of Judy Fontanez and Katie Sarisky. Loving, special uncle of Theodore Anderson, Chris and Michael Sarisky, and Debbie Fontanez. Devoted brother-in-law of Paul T. Pugliese, Catherine Anderson and Regina Pugliese. title: What the Body Knows
description: It's hard for most of us to think of an autopsy as an essential part of normal medical practice. It seems, somehow, so after the fact. In the past few decades, the rate at which hospitals conduct autopsies has plummeted, to perhaps 5 percent of hospital deaths today, from 41 percent in 1961. No one knows the exact number because the National Center for Health Statistics stopped collecting autopsy numbers after 1994, when the rate stood at 9.4 percent.

title: Council Members Question Plan to Hold Back 3rd Graders
description: City Council members questioned Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday on his new plan to hold back third graders who fail citywide tests, criticizing elements of the plan as well as the Department of Education's efforts to publicize it.

title: Bush Mining California For Voters, Too
description: President Bush spent the first day of the general election campaign in California Wednesday, trying to convince his own party and the Democrats that the state can be a source of electoral support for him -- and not just financial support.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the stabbing of a woman in her Bronx home gave an erroneous account from the police about the condition of her body. The New York medical examiner's office said yesterday that the victim, Betzaida Eva Madera, died with her heart in her body, and that it was not removed by her killer. An article about the investigation appears today on Page B4.

description: A bomb ripped into Iraq's main international phone exchange on Wednesday, killing one man and cutting service to hundreds of thousands of Iraqis just days after being restored.

title: Law Dept. Backs Barring Marriage Licenses for Gays
description: The city's Law Department told the city clerk yesterday that gay couples should be denied marriage licenses, as City Council members and gay groups increased their pressure on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to take a personal position on same-sex marriages.

title: For Audio Players, A Chance to Cut the Cord
description: ELECTRONIC devices have been cutting the cord for years, with one notable exception: portable music players. From the earliest Walkman to the latest fashion-accessory MP3 player, music on the go has generally meant cables trailing from ears to pocket or purse. But a short-range communications technology based on magnetism may mean those days will finally be on the wane.

description: With combination gadgets like wireless camera phones or personal organizers that function as MP3 players, multitasking is not just for busy humans anymore.

description: Buoyed by record margins for its star leather goods and fashion brand, Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton on Wednesday announced a 30 percent jump in its net income for 2003.

description: Last month Bishop William F. Murphy acknowledged and apologized for decades of child sex abuse in the Roman Catholic Church on Long Island. He offered sympathy to victims and their families and offered them help.

description: DESIGNING death is not a simple matter.

title: Dcor by Dresser, Frogs, Tongues and All
description: COLLECTORS of work by Christopher Dresser, whether his minimalist silver teapots or the more grotesque ceramics, sometimes encounter skeptics puzzled by Dresser's wide-ranging style or repelled by his gothic sense of humor. A Scotsman who died in 1904, Dresser was one of the first industrial designers, and he created a seemingly endless supply of Wedgwood, wallpaper and floral fabrics for Victorian households. Some 30 manufacturers produced the Dresser studio's products, which included rugs, silver-plate and sterling silver teapots, and ceramic vases decorated with demons and insects, presumably for Victorians bored with fairies and dragonflies. Mass production made Dresser an international brand (many of his pieces carried a facsimile of his signature), as popular as Martha Stewart, Philippe Starck and Michael Graves are today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Hotel Company's Profit Falls
description: The hotel and leisure company Accor reported a 37 percent decline in net income for 2003 as the global economic slowdown, the war in Iraq, the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome and foreign exchange fluctuations hurt results. The company said it earned 270 million euros ($329 million) last year, down from 430 million euros in 2002 and below the 281 million euros expected by analysts. The company said, however, that it had seen signs of recovery in the second half of the year, particularly in the United States, Britain and Germany. The company, which is based in Paris, said it cut its debt by 370 million euros and maintained its dividend; and its share price rose 3 percent.

title: In Paris, It's All About Boys
description: Boys will be boys except when they're girls in boys' clothes. This is fashion's great running line -- from Coco Chanel through Yves Saint Laurent through Comme des Garons and, on Friday, when Karl Lagerfeld will put men in tweed jackets on his runway, back again to Chanel.

title: Researchers Retract a Study Linking Autism To Vaccination
description: Ten of the 13 scientists who produced a 1998 study linking a childhood vaccine to several cases of autism retracted their conclusion yesterday.

title: Costco Says Profit Was Up in Quarter
description: The Costco Wholesale Corporation, the warehouse club chain, said yesterday that second-quarter profit increased 25 percent, helped by surging overseas sales and reduced health care costs.

title: A Backup Makes the Most of His Minutes on the Court
description: PHOENIX, March 3  The real opportunities rarely come for Brandon Armstrong. He gets two minutes here, six minutes there, but only occasionally does the third-year backup out of Pepperdine play significant, crucial minutes for the Nets.

title: SBC, Tired of Courts and Regulators, Offers to Settle Network Leasing Issue
description: A day after a federal court rejected government regulations intended to govern competition in the telephone industry, SBC sent a letter to rival carriers suggesting that they settle their differences outside of the regulatory structure.

title: Sounds That Surround You Make It Onto Your Playlist
description: The air is full of sounds that are not filed on your digital music player: new recordings and live performances on FM radio, not to mention the ambient music of the world around you. The JMTek MelodiBox MP3 lets you add them to your collection on the fly.

title: Jury Starts Deliberations In Stewart Case
description: The jury in the Martha Stewart trial completed its first day of deliberations yesterday after making several requests for transcript excerpts, charts and phone logs, most of them focused on Dec. 27, 2001, the day she sold nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: School District Wins On Banning Student Groups
description: The Lubbock district did not violate the rights of a student group, the Lubbock Gay-Straight Alliance, by refusing to let it meet at school, Judge Sam R. Cummings of Federal District Court ruled. Judge Cummings said officials acted within their authority in preserving ''a community's standard of what subject matter is considered obscene and inappropriate.'' Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Musicians in Chicago Seek To Hold On to Barenboim
description: Musicians of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra met with management on Wednesday to discuss the departure of their music director, Daniel Barenboim, who announced two weeks ago that he would resign after the 2005-6 season. Mr. Barenboim has hinted that he might stay if management stopped asking him to spend more time raising money, socializing and promoting the orchestra.
