title: Other Attacks Averted in Iraq, A General Says
description: A senior American military commander said Wednesday that his men had foiled several terrorist attacks intended to accompany those that killed as many as 185 people in two cities here on Tuesday.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Snail's Pace At Detroit Housing Agency
description: The Detroit Housing Commission, given a $2.2 million grant in October 2002 to remove lead paint from 130 houses by next year, is far from its goal, the Department of Housing and Urban Development said. Federal officials said the commission had used $67,000 and had not hired a full-time director. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Reality and a Cartoon (or Vice Versa), Both on Sci Fi
description: Two unsettling shows arrive tonight to test our nerves on the Sci Fi Channel. The first, ''Mad, Mad House,'' is a ghoulish reality show that may inadvertently work to sound the depths of casual American religious belief. The second, ''Tripping the Rift,'' is an outer-space cartoon with a pushy ''sick'' aesthetic; it could be dismissed if it weren't for its mysterious traces of intelligence.

title: Go Time For Garden Olympics
description: IN the last 15 years, Dr. Gerald Barad and his wife, Beatrice, have swept up so many blue ribbons for their cactuses and succulents at the Philadelphia Flower Show that most competitors do not stand a chance. So this year, Ed Lindemann, the show's director, invited the Barads, both 81, who have 50 years of cactus growing experience, to be professional exhibitors.

title: SPITZER'S OPINION MIXED ON STATUS OF GAY MARRIAGE
description: New York State law requires same-sex marriages that are legally performed in other states to be recognized as lawful in New York, but does not now permit such marriages to be performed in the state, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said on Wednesday in a legal opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LADENSON, SAM
description: LADENSON--Sam, April 5, 1927-March 2, 2004, in New York City. A prolific artist who worked extensively in collage for many years. He attended the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts and later studied at the Ecole des Beaux Arts while stationed in Paris as a Master Sergeant in the Army. His work is in private and public collections in the United States and Europe. He leaves his wife, Irene, and daughter, Elisabeth.

title: Accounts
description: Procter & Gamble, Cincinnati, expanded its relationship with the Media Company, Toronto, by naming the agency to handle broadcast media buying duties for English-language advertising in Canada, which had been handled by the Toronto office of Starcom MediaVest. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cigarette Maker's Profit Rises
description: The Gallaher Group, the maker of Benson & Hedges and Silk Cut cigarettes, said profit rose 13 percent in the second half as it sold more cigarettes in Eastern Europe and in Ireland. Net income climbed to 145 million ($265 million) from 128 million a year earlier, according to Mark Rolfe, finance director of the company, which is based in Weybridge, England. Gallaher is trying to overcome falling consumption at home by expanding in countries like Russia and Kazakhstan, where some smokers are switching to Western brands. The acquisitions of Liggett-Ducat and Austria Tabak have also increased Gallaher's share of the Russian market.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: New U.S. Sanctions
description: The United States tightened economic sanctions against Zimbabwe, blacklisting seven companies tied to the nation's leaders and the ZANU-PF party, and threatened further strictures should the government ''continue to oppress its citizens and to resist forthright efforts toward resolving the country's political crisis.'' Separately, Zimbabwe's state-run radio accused the United States of trying to topple President Robert Mugabe by distributing millions of ''revolutionary condoms'' with stickers urging citizens to ''Get up! Stand up!'' and fight for their rights. The slogan is from a song that the reggae star Bob Marley performed at the nation's 1980 independence celebration. One news agency reported that a few hundred such condoms were recently distributed by Enough! -- an underground opposition group. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Creative Director Quits Bartle Bogle Hegarty
description: Kevin McKeon has left the New York office of the London agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty, where he had been executive creative director since March 2001.

title: Despite Charges, Mayor Pledges To Keep Marrying Gay Couples
description: Shortly after being arraigned on misdemeanor charges on Wednesday for the same-sex marriage ceremonies he performed in this village last week, Mayor Jason West defiantly said he would continue solemnizing such marriages. Standing before Village Hall on the same parking lot where he married 25 gay couples on Friday, Mr. West, 26, called gay marriage the greatest civil rights issue of his generation.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Names Chairman
description: The Reuters Group, the world's largest publicly traded provider of financial information, named Niall FitzGerald as chairman to succeed Sir Christopher Hogg, who will retire. Mr. FitzGerald, 58, will take over from Sir Christopher, 67, on Oct. 1, Reuters said. Mr. FitzGerald has been on the board of Reuters since January 2003. He said last month he would retire as co-chairman of Unilever, the world's largest maker of food and soap, after 37 years at the company.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Announces Cost Of Merging Stocks
description: Sprint said yesterday that costs related to combining shares that track its wireless and main phone units will lower 2004 profit by about 3 cents a share. When Sprint announced the plan Sunday, it forecast consolidated profit, excluding unspecified items, of 70 cents to 75 cents a share. That includes costs for combining the stocks, the chief executive, Gary D. Forsee, said on a conference call with analysts and investors yesterday. Sprint is scrapping shares that track its PCS Group mobile phone unit as the company simplifies its structure for investors. On April 23, each PCS share will be converted into half a share of the FON Group, which includes Sprint's long-distance and local-phone operations. Restructuring the stock could make the company more attractive to a potential acquirer, analysts have said. FON shares fell 29 cents, to $18.65. PCS slipped 10 cents, to $9.32.

title: Hard Realities in Haiti
description: Rescuing Haiti from a crisis Washington too long ignored and then badly mishandled is going to take a lot more than whisking its democratically elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, off to Africa and gingerly deploying a few hundred United States marines. Yesterday, those marines rightly moved beyond their original mission of safeguarding only American lives and property, and began patrolling the tense streets of Port-au-Prince. Earlier in the day, fierce gun battles raged in the capital's strongly pro-Aristide slums, where rampaging rebel bands battled Aristide supporters.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Kill 29 Soldiers

title: World Briefing: Europe

title: Bush Policy on Human Stem Cells Faces New Challenges
description: The White House's policy on research with human embryonic stem cells has been put under new pressure by the dismissal of a leading biologist from the President's Council on Bioethics last week and by the development, announced today, of new stem cell lines by a Harvard researcher.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yonkers: Superintendent Sets a Fire
description: The superintendent of a co-op building in Yonkers accidentally started a five-alarm fire when a propane torch he was using to fix a kitchen sink ignited insulation in the walls. ''I tried to get it out,'' said the superintendent, Antonio Delgado, 41, showing burn marks on his hands. ''There was nothing I could do, so I called the Fire Department.'' Ten residents of the building at 1340 Midland Avenue were displaced after the fire, which flared in a first-floor apartment and spread to the fourth floor and attic, said the Yonkers Fire Department deputy chief, John Hoffman. Three firefighters were treated for smoke inhalation and a sprain. Fire officials said that they had not yet determined whether Mr. Delgado would be charged with a crime. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: A Modern Sense With Vintage Sensibility
description: WEBBED furniture never goes out of style. Webbing is a material that looks just as fresh, clean and varied in color today as it did half a century ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Mount Holly: Former Official Sentenced
description: The Burlington County Superior Court sentenced the former finance officer for Hainesport Township yesterday to three years in prison in a case involving the diversion of municipal money. The official, Kristine Wisnewski, 32, was also ordered to pay $179,669 in restitution and to forfeit any public office in the future. She pleaded guilty in December to misconduct in conspiring with the township's mayor in diverting $339,000 of municipal money into a secret account for their personal use, the authorities said. The mayor, Ronald Corn, 57, pleaded guilty in January to a charge of official misconduct. He is scheduled for sentencing in the Burlington court on April 8. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: Image Conscious
description: In politics, sometimes you have to fight firefighters with firefighters.

title: With Super Tuesday Behind Him, Kerry Shifts to High General-Election Gear
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts began his general election campaign at a full sprint on Wednesday, flying here to rally voters in the battleground state that is his party's bloody shirt, naming a Democratic financier to oversee his search for a running mate and orchestrating a takeover of the Democratic National Committee.

title: Lima Journal; The Peruvians Surrender to Surfing, Body and Soul
description: Hawaii may have the north coast of Oahu. California may have Malibu. But Peru has Punta Hermosa, south of Lima, the longest waves in the world at Chicama and, for 62 years, the fabled Waikiki Club.

title: GENESCO SAYS IT IS CLOSING 34 JARMAN SHOE STORES
description: Genesco Inc., which sells shoes, said that it will close 34 of its Jarman stores and convert the rest to Underground Station outlets. The company also said its fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 21 percent, to $16.9 million, or 77 cents a share, from $14 million, or 55 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose to $252.7 million from $249.7 million, Genesco said. Jarman, which was hurt by slowing demand for men's casual footwear, now has 96 men's shoe stores in the United States. The Jarman closings affect fewer than 60 employees, a Genesco spokeswoman, Claire McCall, said.

title: Ex-WorldCom Chief Pleads Not Guilty to Fraud
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of conspiracy and fraud growing out of the accounting scandal that drove the company into bankruptcy protection in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRODIN, ESTHER D.
description: GRODIN -- Esther D. On March 3, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, loving mother of Martin and Madeline, Lenny and Barbara and the late Sylvia. Dear sister, adoring grandmother and great-grandmother, devoted aunt and great friend. Service Friday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Fashionable Protest, Lost in Translation
description: It has been said that there are two schools of thought about what fuels conflict between Israelis and Palestinians: one, that the two peoples do not understand each other; two, that they understand each other all too well and so are trying to do one another in.

title: Official Tells of Investigation Into Mad Cow Discrepancies
description: The government has begun a criminal investigation into whether documents were falsified in the lone case of mad cow disease found in the United States, the Agriculture Department's inspector general said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTLETT, AMY
description: BARTLETT--Amy. The Dalton School community mourns the loss of Amy Bartlett, mother of Byron, Class of 2005. We extend our deepest sympathy to Byron and his family. Ellen C. Stein, Head of School

title: To Avert Blackouts, a Sag-Free Cable
description: THE electric power grid may be complex, but the way that transmission lines fail is simple. As the current travels through them, they heat up, their metal cores expand, and the lines sag. Utility companies monitor how much power is being sent through a line and weather conditions like air temperature, but if a line gets hot enough and sags low enough to come near the ground or vegetation, it can short-circuit.

title: Lawyers Can Ask Bryant Accuser About Sexual Past, Judge Says
description: Defense lawyers for the basketball star Kobe Bryant, who is charged with sexually assaulting a hotel clerk at a Colorado resort last summer, will be allowed to question his accuser about the details of her sexual past in a closed-court session, the judge in the case ruled Tuesday night.

title: Dell Founder Steps Down as Chief Executive
description: Michael Dell, who started a computer business in his dorm room and turned it into the biggest personal computer company in the world, said today that he would step down as chief executive of Dell Inc. but remain chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAPPNER, ETHEL
description: LAPPNER--Ethel. On March 2, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Jess. Devoted mother of Andrew Richard. Loving aunt of Willa Reichbach, Robert Mitchel, Dolly Wooden, Barbar Francis and Doris Francis. Visitation Saturday 7-9 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Services private.

title: THEATER: ARTHUR MILLER'S NEXT
description: A new play by Arthur Miller, left, described as a ''fable of the perversion of the American dream,'' will have its world premiere in September at the Goodman Theater in Chicago. The play, ''Finishing the Picture,'' will be directed by Robert Falls, a Tony Award winner who is the Goodman's artistic director. According to a summary provided by the Goodman, the play is about a film director who must deal with an unstable starlet. ''She's recognized all over the world, loved by millions, but unable to believe in herself,'' the summary says. ''The studio owners are threatening to pull the plug, and a temperamental acting teacher is flown in to coax the actress out of bed and onto the set.'' The Goodman's season will also feature the world premiere of ''Silk,'' a play by Mary Zimmerman, whose ''Metamorphoses'' became a Broadway hit after its Chicago run. ''Silk'' is based on the Allesandro Baricco novel of the same title, about a silkworm dealer in France who travels to Japan and becomes involved with a wealthy village lord and his young mistress. Ms. Zimmerman will adapt the novel and also direct the stage production, scheduled to open in April 2005. STEPHEN KINZER

title: CALENDAR
description: Talking Preservation

title: Reformers' Feud
description: One of the dangers of life on the edge of the reform movement in Albany is that people can sometimes get a little too far out there. That may have happened recently to David Grandeau, executive director of the New York Temporary State Commission on Lobbying. Mr. Grandeau has been one of the few people in Albany who does more than talk about lobbying reform. He has done well on his important task, enforcing the state's lobbying law by demanding that lobbyists register or pay the requisite fines.

title: A Small School's Challenges Only Get Bigger
description: No one tried to underplay what happened Tuesday night in a gym that shook with energy and emotion as the 15 players from the little college from Philadelphia wrapped up an undefeated regular season with an 82-50 rout of St. Bonaventure. The celebration was enduring, continuing well after the final buzzer in another victory by No. 2 St. Joseph's, which now stands 27-0.

title: Venezuelan Ambassador to the U.N. Resigns
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 - The Venezuelan ambassador to the United Nations announced his resignation today, saying he could no longer support a government he accused of violating democratic principles and human rights.

description: BOUTWELL--Charles. The Board of Tudor City Greens records with sorrow the loss of Charles Boutwell, a member of our Board since 1994. Charles gave generously of his time and talents adding to the success of our many activities. He will be missed. Board of Directors Tudor City Greens, Inc.

title: Tom DeLay and the Lobbying Game
description: The quest by the House majority leader, Tom DeLay, for greater Republican clout in the lucrative world of lobbying is bearing an embarrassment of riches. Two Washington lobbyists with close ties to Mr. DeLay have harvested a cool $45 million across three years by selling lobbying and public affairs services to four Indian tribes flush with casino profits. This is such an eye-popping profit that Senator John McCain is planning hearings on what he calls ''disgraceful'' suggestions of profiteering. Actually, the tribal contracts, reported by The Washington Post, exemplify the way the Capitol works. One of the enriched lobbyists had been a ranking staff assistant to Mr. DeLay, the other a close political ally.

title: Down-to-Earth Directions For the Well-Shod Tourist
description: Travelers can download directions from online services like Mapquest onto a palmtop computer. But those directions are intended for motorists. If you are on foot, such maps can lead you on strolls along highways or unnecessary detours to take account of one-way streets.

title: Yankees Will Not Rehire Giambi's Trainer
description: Jason Giambi's personal trainer, Bob Alejo, will have a lot less access to his high-profile client after the Yankees told Giambi yesterday that they would not rehire Alejo this season. The decision greatly reduces Alejo's ability to monitor Giambi's workouts and preparation before and after games.

description: The Organization of American States met Wednesday with electoral officials and opposition leaders in a last-ditch effort to find a peaceful solution to Venezuela's political turmoil, while opponents of President Hugo Chvez called for a major protest march on Thursday.

title: Loan Office in New York Looks to Tap Mexican Market
description: Seeking to tap into the billions of dollars that Mexicans working in the United States send home each year, a Mexican mortgage finance company is opening a New York branch on Thursday to offer loans to Mexicans who want to buy a house in their country.

title: National Briefing: South
description: SOUTH CAROLINA: BOMB SUSPECT SEES HIS LAWYERS Jose Padilla met with his lawyers for the first time since being locked up without charges in June 2002. His lawyers, Andrew Patel and Donna Newman, met for about three hours at the Navy brig in Charleston with Mr. Padilla, who is accused of plotting with Al Qaeda to detonate a radioactive "dirty bomb." Mr. Patel said they mainly gave Mr. Padilla news of his family and did not discuss his case because the government was closely monitoring the meeting. (Reuters)

title: Making a Surreal Trip Onto a Nightclub Runway
description: How could one fail to love a city that opens its fashion season with a show in which models appear wearing stuffed bird heads and roughly sutured overcoats, sleepwalking to a Patti Smith drone across the dance floor of a nightclub near Place Pigalle? That Jun Takahashi's Undercover show on Monday night was both hypnotic and a bit creepy makes sense if you consider that Mr. Takahashi amuses himself by taking apart Japanese monster toys and then assembling even stranger mutants from the pieces.

description: IN addition to rebuilding the fabled souks of Beirut, designing truck stops in Morocco, and working on a beach resort in the French Antilles, Annabel Karim Kassar, a French-born architect, designs products for the home. The O.V.N.I. light, right, is one of her creations for Ca Light, a lighting firm that is run by Ms. Karim Kassar, Christophe Hascot and Isabelle Rolland. Its products were shown last month at Maison et Objet, the Paris design exposition, and will be exhibited again in London in September, at 100 Percent Design.

description: In last weeks column , I described the weird and wonderful Comfort Keyboard, a three-section split keyboard whose universal joints permit total 3-D freedom of positioning. I mentioned in passing that I also use speech-recognition software to avoid typing and speed up my work.

title: National Briefing | West: California: 2 Plead Guilty In Terrorist Plot
description: Two men pleaded guilty in federal court in San Diego in a scheme to trade hashish and heroin for antiaircraft missiles. Officials said the men, wanted to sell the missiles to the Taliban and Al Qaeda, but their contacts in Hong Kong were undercover F.B.I. agents. The men, Muhamed Abid Afridi and Ilyas Ali, pleaded guilty to charges of drug conspiracy and conspiracy to provide material support to terrorists. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: FOOTSTAR FILES FOR CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Footstar Inc., an athletic-shoe retailer that has delayed its financial reports for five quarters because of accounting problems, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The company, based in West Nyack, N.Y., said it had arranged for $300 million in financing from a group of lenders. The Footaction and Just for Feet stores remain open, as do the Kmart footwear departments run by its Meldisco unit. Footstar listed $5.5 million in cash as of September 2002 in a statement issued the following month and has more than $100 million in debt and in assets, according to court filings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JUSSIM, DR. ESTELLE
description: JUSSIM--Dr. Estelle. Granby, MA., 76 noted author and former Simmons College professor, died March 1. Among her works, ''Slave to Beauty'' won her the acclaimed award, New York Historical Society's Prize for Distinctive achievement in the History of Photography. She has also written numerous biographies on notable photographers such as Barbara Crane, Gerry Liebling, Carl Chiarenza and F. Holland Day. Estelle was also a well known lecturer, speaking at Smith College, Amon Carter Museum in Texas, The Museum of Ottawa and the College of Santa Fe. Her great collection of Pre-Columbian Sculpture was recently donated to the Mt. Holyoke College Art Museum as well as her collection of original photographs of notable photographers. Dr. Jussim is survived by a sister, Matilda Van Witzen, of Hewlett, NY along with nieces and nephews. There will be a service to honor her memory at the Unitarian - Universalist Church of Amherst, MA on Saturday, April 3rd at 2:00pm. For more information or to sign guest register, please visit www.beersandstory.com

title: Logical Layout Speeds Up The Hunting and Pecking
description: More than a century ago, according to lore, early typewriter makers arranged the keys in an intentionally confusing pattern with the aim of slowing typists so that the machines would be less likely to jam. Jammed keys are a thing of the past, but the qwerty keyboard layout remains nearly universal for English speakers, tormenting people who have not learned to type.

description: In a remarkable vote of defiance against a once unassailable executive, shareholders owning an estimated 43 percent of the Walt Disney Company declined on Wednesday to support the re-election of Michael D. Eisner, the chairman and chief executive, to the board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMSON, ARTHUR LEAROYD II
description: ADAMSON--Arthur Learoyd II, respected businessman, sailor, sportsman and civic leader, passed away from heart failure following hip surgery on February 2. Lea was 90 years old and lived at his home on the Shrewsbury River in Rumson, NJ. A Princeton Phi Beta Kappa and Harvard Law School graduate, Lea and the Signal Corps team he served with during World War II founded Electronics Associates, Inc. to build analog computers. As Executive Vice President, and later President, he helped grow EAI from a small startup to a large manufacturing company with a listing on the New York Stock Exchange. He served as Pack Leader of the local Cub Scouts and was President of the Board of Education during the 1950's and 60's, leading the successful campaign to combine the local high schools into the Rumson Fair Haven Regional High School. An active sailor, he was Commodore of the Shrewsbury Sailing and Yacht Club, as well as longtime member of the New York Yacht Club. His yacht ''Wing II,'' which he raced for many years, was one of the first Cal-40 racing sloops on the east coast. He is also a founding member of the ''Polly's Pond Sailing Association,'' a group of fun-loving sailors which grew over 45 years to include three generations. A founder of Wayside Skeet Club, he won the state skeet shooting championship in 1964 and helped coach teams at Fort Monmouth and the Lawrenceville School. A member of the Sea Bright Beach Club and the Navesink Country Club, Lea was an avid golfer, playing rain or shine, summer and winter well into his 80's, when he claims to have finally shot his age. He is the husband of the late Martha Adamson, father of Lee, Nick, Jim, and the late Robert, the brother of Catherine Montgomery and the late Cassel Adamson, and the grandfather of Terry Adamson and Robert Musser. We will all miss him, his logic and ability to best in argument anyone foolish enough to engage him. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 am on March 27 at St. George's by-the-River in Rumson.

description: Marines in Haiti began patrolling Port-au-Prince in their first direct attempt to quell the violence that has racked the city since President Jean-Bertrand Aristide fled Sunday, and the rebel leader, Guy Philippe, said he would disarm his men and leave the city.

title: Meyer Blinder, Penny Stock King, Dies at 82
description: Meyer Blinder, who with his gold jewelry and extravagant promises became the self-proclaimed king of the nation's penny stock market in the 70's and 80's, died last Thursday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 82.

title: A Neighbor and a Stranger: Canada Portrayed in Film
description: ''Canadian Front: New Films 2004'' sounds a bit like the punch line to a very tired joke. The series, which begins today at MoMA Film at the Gramercy Theater in Manhattan, consists of Canadian projects assembled to showcase idiosyncratic and diverse filmmakers. But neither the pictures nor their directors should be written off as feeble stereotypes.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Orders Controls On Bugging
description: The Constitutional Court ruled that parts of a law that allows telephone surveillance in private homes were unconstitutional and must be corrected. The eavesdropping legislation was passed in 1998 to fight terrorism and organized crime. The court said that conversations in homes should be kept out of the reach of crime investigators and that such eavesdropping could be ordered only when there was a suspicion of an offense that could carry a prison sentence of more than five years. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Dissident's Sentence Cut
description: A prominent ethnic Uighur dissident had her eight-year prison sentenced reduced after sustained international pressure, an American rights group said. The dissident, Rebiya Kadeer, 57, is now due to be released a year early, in 2006. The government cited good behavior. Ms. Kadeer, a well-known businesswoman and activist in China's western region of Xinjiang, was imprisoned for supplying state secrets to foreigners, a vague charge often used to ensnare people the government considers subversive. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

description: Shell Chairman Forced Out

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chip Engineer Sues Toshiba
description: A former engineer at the Toshiba Corporation sued the company seeking 1 billion yen ($9 million) for his work in developing the flash memory chips that are widely used to store data and pictures in cellphones and digital cameras. The suit, which was filed in Tokyo District Court by Fujio Masuoka, who is now a professor at Tohoku University in Japan, is the latest in a series of claims on patent rights by Japanese corporate engineers seeking larger shares of the profits generated by their inventions. Last month, the same Tokyo court ordered the Nichia Corporation to pay 20 billion yen ($181.6 million) to the inventor of a blue-light-emitting diode, a widely used semiconductor device. A spokesman for Toshiba, which is based in Tokyo, refused to comment on the latest legal action, saying that the company had not yet seen the lawsuit. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Suds, Sequins And Even A Little Song From Spears
description: Britney Spears's white terry-cloth robe dropped to the floor, revealing a sequin-covered body stocking. She stepped into a bathtub that, like her bodysuit, was see-through. In shadow to her left, like silhouettes seen through hotel room windows, men and women in beds mimed passionate sex with one another.

title: Sex, Drugs and Ego: A Music Mogul's Swath of Destruction; A Deposed President of CBS Records Chronicles His Debauchery and Detox
description: In the living room of his sleek, two-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, Walter Yetnikoff sat enjoying a picturesque sunset, ''a real cocaine view,'' he called it. It was just after 4:30 and Mr. Yetnikoff, the most powerful man in the music industry for much of the 80's, was sober. This would not have been the case 15 years ago.

title: The end of the ugly aesthetic

title: Corrections

title: Carry a Concert Home in Your Pocket
description: MAXWELL'S in Hoboken is better known as a showcase for new rock acts than for new technology. But that could change later this month when the club becomes a testing ground for digital kiosks that will enable clubgoers to download a recording of the show to a small U.S.B. drive almost immediately after a performance.

title: Making 'Petrouchka' Fit the Times and Politicians
description: Never one to mince steps when he finds the world askew, Paul Taylor is often most serious when he is at his funniest. ''Le Grand Puppetier,'' the premiere with which the Paul Taylor Dance Company opened a two-week season at City Center on Tuesday night, masquerades as a highly entertaining trifle.

description: The Rangers' trade of Brian Leetch had been discussed openly for weeks and became inevitable in recent days as the team began to purge its roster of other high-salaried stars.

description: Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a two-term Colorado Republican and the Senate's only American Indian, said on Wednesday that he would not seek re-election this year, citing concerns about his health.

title: Sharon Faces New Questions Over an Exchange of Prisoners
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon was embroiled in a new controversy on Wednesday after an Israeli newspaper questioned his motives for approving a lopsided prisoner exchange in January that freed more than 400 Arabs in return for an Israeli man kidnapped while pursuing a dubious business venture.

title: Loan Applications Rise
description: Mortgage applications rose for a third consecutive week as low borrowing costs helped spur refinancing, an industry group said.

title: Outside the Meeting, the Sounds of Protest
description: Eager to grab the attention of more than 100 news media organizations here to cover the Walt Disney Company's shareholder meeting, an assortment of protest groups demonstrated on Wednesday against everything from sweatshop conditions in developing countries to the loss of jobs in the United States.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Denim Company To Build Centers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that Federal Jeans Inc., an importer, manufacturer and distributor of denim products in Brooklyn, would build two new light manufacturing and warehouse distribution centers in the Bronx and Queens. The company was designated to acquire and develop a 156,000-square-foot site in the Zerega Industrial Park in the Throgs Neck section of the Bronx, and is working with the city to acquire a 270,000-square-foot parcel in Far Rockaway, Queens. These new centers will create about 200 jobs in addition to the existing 100 jobs at its Brooklyn operation, Mr. Bloomberg said. Additionally, he said, the Bronx and Queens projects will create more than 150 jobs during construction, which is expected to begin next year.

title: Grown Cautious, Fox Expects Delay on U.S. Action on Migrants
description: In an interview to discuss his scheduled visit to Texas this weekend, President Vicente Fox of Mexico said this week that he did not expect the United States to adopt sweeping reforms that would give legal status to millions of undocumented workers until well after the presidential election this fall.

title: Judge's Ties With Rowland Threaten His Confirmation
description: The job prospects of an interim judge who provided free legal work to Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut darkened on Wednesday, after the State Ethics Commission issued an opinion stating that it is illegal for public officials to accept free services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REYCRAFT, GEORGE D.
description: REYCRAFT--George D. On March 1, 2004 in Miami, Fl. George loved the law, flying, boating and fishing, especially in the Florida Keys and Alaska. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANATOOR, JEROLD MARK, Z''L.
description: GRANATOOR--Jerold Mark, z''l. 72 years old. Died March 3rd, 2004. Beloved husband and best friend of Sylvia (Wollowitz). Adored and adoring father of Rabbi Gary (Marianne) Bretton-Granatoor, Richard (Leslie) Granatoor and Robin (Todd) Rosenfeld. Doting grandfather, Papa Jerry to Samantha, Max, Jacob, Zachary, Lindsay and Lucas. Pharmacist and co-owner of Kollman's Pharmacy in New Rochelle, he was a dispensor of prescriptions and concern. A friend to all customers and passers-by alike. In his retirement he lavished his laugh and joy of life on his friends in the Old Guard. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El of Yonkers at 11 AM on Friday, March 5. While his heart may have failed him in the end, he never failed to give his heart to all he met. The memory of the righteous is always a blessing.

title: Dells Founder Surrenders Chief Executive Role
description: Michael Dell, who started a computer business in his dorm room and turned it into the biggest personal computer company in the world, said today that he would step down as chief executive of Dell Inc. but remain chairman.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Gay American Bishop Pulls Out Of Debate
description: The Rev. V. Gene Robinson, who was consecrated Episcopal bishop of New Hampshire last year, has decided not to participate in an Oxford Union debate in which he was to argue in favor of allowing gays to become bishops. Bishop Robinson is the first openly gay bishop in the church, and his appointment has divided the worldwide Anglican Communion. An Anglican commission is studying how to prevent a permanent schism. Bishop Robinson said in a statement that it was not in the best interests of the church to participate in the debate ''at this delicate moment.'' Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: While Critical of Aging Buses, City Has Funds It Hasn't Used

title: CANTOR FITZGERALD ADDS 15 TO BOND TRADING STAFF
description: Cantor Fitzgerald, the stock and bond trading firm that lost 60 percent of its employees in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, hired 15 people from the Advest Group to expand its trading and sales of corporate bonds and mortgage securities. Cantor also hired Jeffrey Kidwell, 43, from Morgan Stanley as managing director to lead its funding and repurchase agreement business, Tom Ryan, a spokesman for Cantor Fitzgerald, said. The company is building its bond trading business to complement the more than 125-employee equity unit in place since the 1960's, Mr. Ryan said.

title: California Approves Bond Issue, but Fiscal Problems Remain

title: National Briefing: Washington
description: HOUSE PASSES 9/11 INQUIRY BILL The House passed a bill to give the commission that is investigating the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks more time to work. The bill would add 60 days, to July 26, for the panel's final report. The Senate passed the same version of the bill Friday. (AP)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: G.M. To Buy Assembly Plant
description: General Motors said it had offered to buy an assembly plant in India from the South Korean automaker, the Daewoo Corporation, to expand in the small-car market there. General Motors, which has less than 3 percent of India's vehicle market, said that it intended to acquire all the car-making assets of Daewoo, which is under bankruptcy protection, for undisclosed terms. The factory will help General Motors to double its sales and produce a new generation of cost-competitive vehicles, the company said. General Motors said it expected to roll out cars with the Chevrolet nameplate from Daewoo's assembly plant next year. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Ex-Agriculture Chief Gets 4-Year Term
description: Meg Scott Phipps, former state agriculture commissioner, was sentenced to four years in federal prison for extortion, mail fraud and conspiracy on Tuesday. Two ex-aides, who prosecutors say helped her demand political donations from contractors, were sentenced Wednesday. One aide, Bobby C. McLamb, was sentenced to 16 months in prison. The other, Linda J. Saunders, received three months in prison and nine months of house arrest. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bill To Raise Indecency Fines
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee approved a bill to increase fines on broadcasters that violate indecency laws, to $500,000 a violation from $27,500. Support has been building for such bills after criticism of the Super Bowl halftime show. John Files (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shooting Victim's Family To Sue
description: The family of Ousmane Zongo, an unarmed West African man shot dead by the police in a Chelsea storage center last May, will file a federal lawsuit today against the city and the police officer involved, their lawyer, Sanford Rubenstein, said yesterday. The lawsuit alleges that the city and Officer Bryan Conroy, who shot Mr. Zongo, violated his civil rights. Mr. Zongo was not part of a CD counterfeiting circle the police were raiding at the storage center on the day he was killed. The lawsuit, to be filed in United States District Court, does not specify damages, but a notice of claim filed with the city asks for $150 million. The Zongo shooting has yet to be presented to a grand jury, and the statute of limitations for a civil suit is running out, Mr. Rubenstein said. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYDON, ELIZABETH SCHUTZ
description: LYDON -- Elizabeth Schutz, active environmentalist, died on February 9, 2004 at her home in New York. She was 47 years old. Betsy worked for the National Resource Defense Council, first staff member of Mothers and Others for a Livable Planet, Coordinator of Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems Funders of the Environmental Grantmakers Association, Program Coordinator for CORE Values Northeast and BuyGreen Virginia. As the first consumer advocate on the FDA National Organic Standards Board she helped draft the Foods Production Act of 1990. She is survived by her husband Jeffrey Lydon; her children, Gardner Leu and Lucy Hafner; brothers, Peter A. Schutz and Jeffrey H. Schutz, both of Denver, Colorado; half-sisters, Stewart McCloy of Darien, CT., and Leslie Panayotopoulos of Athens, Greece; and her stepmother, Suzanne Schutz of Greenwich, CT. title: Technology Briefing | Software: SCO Sues Companies On Use Of Linux
description: The SCO Group sued DaimlerChrysler's United States unit and AutoZone, accusing the companies of using Linux software without permission. The suits broaden SCO's legal efforts to assert itself as the owner of parts of the Linux code. SCO, based in Lindon, Utah, said that Linux contains code stolen from its Unix operating system and that users of the software like DaimlerChrysler and AutoZone owe it billions in royalties. The chief executive, Darl C. McBride, who had previously aimed at I.B.M. and Linux software makers, widened his reach to companies that buy the programs. SCO is suing I.B.M. for as much as $50 billion. On a conference call with analysts yesterday, Mr. McBride compared the case to the music industry's fight against illegal downloading of music from the Internet. SCO also said its first-quarter loss widened on litigation costs and declining sales, sending the shares down. Shares of SCO fell $1.83, or 13.6 percent, to $11.59. AutoZone shares dropped $4.76, or 5.4 percent, to $83.64.

title: ICAHN INCREASES STAKE IN IMCLONE BY 1.6 MILLION SHARES

Icahn, the billionaire financier, and affiliates bought about 1.63 million shares of ImClone Systems Inc. in the last two months, raising their stake to 6.9 percent, according to a regulatory filing. Mr. Icahn now controls 5.24 million ImClone shares, according to the Securities and Exchange Commission filing. ImClone won federal approval last month to sell its Erbitux colon cancer drug. Erbitux developments were at the center of the insider-trading scandal that sent the company's former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, to prison and put his friend Martha Stewart on trial. Mr. Icahn was ImClone's second-biggest shareholder as of December, S.E.C. filings state.

title: Beirut Gets Its Groove Back
description: TWENTY-THREE years ago, Annabel Karim Kassar left a dinner party here and stepped into the street as it suddenly echoed with machine-gun fire. Unable to get to her car, she cowered in a doorway for two hours. Back then, Lebanon was being savaged by a civil war that lasted 15 years, and Beirut had been split into warring Christian and Muslim enclaves. When the guns fell silent that night, Ms. Karim Kassar, a visiting French architect then living in London with her Lebanese husband, swore that she wouldn't be coming back to Beirut anytime soon.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Covad To Buy GoBeam For $48 Million
description: The Covad Communication Group, which sells high-speed Internet service, will buy GoBeam for $48 million in stock to acquire technology for making telephone calls online. Covad plans to complete the transaction in May, Charles E. Hoffman, its chief executive, said yesterday. GoBeam, based in Pleasanton, Calif., has annual sales of $6 million and 50 employees, Mr. Hoffman said, compared with Covad's 2003 sales of $388.9 million. Voice over Internet uses a broadband connection instead of a public telephone network to carry local and long-distance phone calls. Covad, based in San Jose, Calif., expects American customers of the technology to grow more than fivefold from 2002 levels, to five million subscribers by 2007. GoBeam provides voice-over-Internet technology in California and Chicago. It has more than 13,000 phones in service. Mr. Hoffman said service would expand to all of Covad's 96 United States markets.

title: Long Island Girl Assaulted and Left for Dead Near Home
description: A 13-year-old Long Island girl who had been beaten, choked, sexually assaulted and left for dead under a heap of leaves, twigs and tires on Sunday night pulled herself up from a ditch and managed to stumble home to safety, the police said Wednesday. The girl, who regularly walked from her Brentwood home to a nearby gas station for snacks, was taking the route home after buying candy on Sunday night when a man who lives nearby attacked her, the Suffolk County police said.

The nationwide death toll from the mosquito-borne disease since Jan. 1 stands at 352, with 22,384 others infected, according to Health Ministry figures. Jakarta, the capital, has been hit especially hard, with more than 3,200 people being treated in city hospitals as of late Tuesday. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Greener Paths From Fitness to Fashion
description: Last month, Milan chose Petra Blaisse, a landscape architect in Amsterdam, and her firm, Inside Outside, to design a 25-acre park called the Library of Trees. It will contain buildings dedicated to sports and fashion designed by the Los Angeles architect Michael Maltzan. The park will have circular groves of trees, each a different species, linked by 30 paths, each a different material, and will connect a railroad station in western Milan, the Stazione di Porta Garibaldi, with a mass transit station in the eastern part of the city, the Stazione Centrale. The paths, below, will be lettered with the Latin names of plants. ''One path could be concrete with inlaid aluminum lettering,'' Ms. Blaisse said. The budget is $25 million. Completion is expected in 2010.

title: Between Soaring Sopranos and Alluring Altos: Motherly Mezzos
description: Mezzo-sopranos, that slightly lower variant of the female soprano voice, are much among us these days, but it was not always so. Right now, Olga Borodina is winning deserved acclaim as Isabella in the Metropolitan Opera's revival of Rossini's ''Italiana in Algeri.'' She may lack that last dollop of charismatic sparkle, but this is still a thrilling performance, all the more exciting since it represents a stretch into theatrical wit and coloratura agility from a singer best known for more lyrical or stentorian mezzo roles, especially from her native Russia.

title: Gauguin's Paradise: Only Part Tahitian And All a Fantasy

And if we did find it, it wouldn't be paradise anymore because we would bring to it all our worldly needs and expectations and alter the perfect atmosphere, dim the glow. John Milton can tell you how this spoilage works. So can any reflective modern tourist.

title: Weekender | Deep River, Conn.
description: IN Deep River, one building looms large: the four-story, red-brick industrial structure at the heart of Main Street was built in 1914 as the headquarters of Pratt, Read & Company, a business with roots reaching to 1809 when it began making ivory combs. By 1839, it was making piano keys, and for nearly a century, millions of pounds of elephant tusks were hauled up the hill from the Connecticut River, an enterprise that sustained the town and its work force. But in the 1940's, with Pratt, Read gone, the building became an empty hulk and went mostly unused the next 40 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADAMSON, ARTHUR LEAROYD II
description: ADAMSON--Arthur Learoyd II, respected businessman, sailor, sportsman and civic leader, passed away from heart failure following hip surgery on February 2. Lea was 90 years old and lived at his home on the Shrewsbury River in Rumson, NJ. A Princeton Phi Beta Kappa and Harvard Law School graduate, Lea and the Signal Corps team he served with during World War II founded Electronics Associates, Inc. to build analog computers. As Executive Vice President, and later President, he helped grow EAI from a small startup to a large manufacturing company with a listing on the New York Stock Exchange. He served as Pack Leader of the local Cub Scouts and was President of the Board of Education during the 1950's and 60's, leading the successful campaign to combine the local high schools into the Rumson Fair Haven Regional High School. An active sailor, he was Commodore of the Shrewsbury Sailing and Yacht Club, as well as longtime member of the New York Yacht Club. His yacht ''Wing II,'' which he raced for many years, was one of the first Cal-40 racing sloops on the east coast. He is also a founding member of the ''Polly's Pond Sailing Association,'' a group of fun-loving sailors which grew over 45 years to include three generations. A founder of Wayside Skeet Club, he won the state skeet shooting championship in 1964 and helped coach teams at Fort Monmouth and the Lawrenceville School. A member of the Sea Bright Beach Club and the Navesink Country Club, Lea was an avid golfer, playing rain or shine, summer and winter well into his 80's, when he claims to have finally shot his age. He is the husband of the late Martha Adamson, father of Lee, Nick, Jim, and the late Robert, the brother of Catherine Montgomery and the late Cassel Adamson, and the grandfather of Terry Adamson and Robert Musser. We will all miss him, his logic and ability to best in argument anyone foolish enough to engage him. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 am on March 27 at St. George's by-the-River in Rumson.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Inquiry At Ericsson
description: Ericsson's auditor, Carl-Eric Bohlin, quit without signing the company's 2003 accounts after prosecutors questioned him on whether Ericsson obstructed a tax assessment, according to a published report. Mr. Bohlin left his job at Oehrlings PricewaterhouseCoopers in November, the newspaper Dagens Nyheter said. The accounts were instead signed by his assistant, Jeanette Skoglund, the newspaper said. Mr. Bohlin confirmed the contents of the article in a telephone interview but declined to comment further. An investigation focuses on more than 2.5 billion kronor ($341 million) Ericsson paid to 33 so-called trading agents in 1998 and 1999, police have said.

title: CLEAR CHANNEL TO PAY $755,000 FINE IN INDECENCY CASE
description: Clear Channel Communications, the radio broadcaster, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay a $755,000 fine for allowing lewd material on a program broadcast on four stations in Florida. Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, was accused by the Federal Communications Commission of broadcasting explicit sexual material on the programs, which were called ''Bubba the Love Sponge.'' Clear Channel fired the host, Todd Clem, last week. ''We fully accept our responsibility for airing inappropriate content,'' the president of Clear Channel Radio, John Hogan, said. The company also announced a policy of zero tolerance for indecency and took the disc jockey Howard Stern off the air in six cities.

title: ARCH CHEMICALS AGREES TO BUY MAKER OF POOL SANITIZERS
description: Arch Chemicals, the maker of HTH pool-care products, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a unit of Avecia Group for about $210 million. Arch will pay Avecia $200 million in cash and 446,500 of its shares for the unit, which makes chlorine-free sanitizers for pools and spas. The agreement includes a $5 million contingency payment based on future performance of the acquired businesses. The Avecia unit had revenue of $137 million in 2003. Avecia, based in Blackley, England, has been selling businesses to cut debt.

It is an artful blend of storytelling and picture-painting that reaches very high. Throughout her new show, ''Portraits,'' Ms. Buckley, who prides herself on her connoisseurship of songs, conveys a mystical sagacity.

The man, identified as Joseph Pierre, of Irvington, N.J., told an emergency medical technician that he fell to the tracks, the police said. The accident occurred about 9 a.m., as Mr. Pierre was standing on the northbound platform of the No. 5 line in the station at Fulton Street and Broadway, the police said. Mr. Pierre was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was listed in serious but stable condition. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

description: New York City's plan to have the state pay back the last $2.5 billion of the city's debt from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's can proceed with some changes, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled here on Thursday.

title: A Kiss Is Not Just a Kiss to an Angry Arab TV Audience
description: Abdel Hakim, a strapping young Saudi, kissed Kawthar, a raven-haired Tunisian beauty, and all hell broke loose.

title: A Fiery Fall Into the Abyss, Unknowing And Unknown
description: THE question is posed in arrogance, but it sets off reverberations that humble like an act of God. ''Dost thou know me, fellow?'' thunders Christopher Plummer, who is giving the performance of a lifetime in the title role of ''King Lear'' at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the reaction among evangelical Protestants in Western Michigan to a proposed Constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage misstated the name of the denomination founded in the area by Dutch Calvinists in the mid-19th century. It is the Christian Reformed Church, not Reform. The article also misspelled the name of a church in the area. It is the Ravenna Baptist Church, not Revenna.

title: Albert Axelrod, 83, a Champion in Fencing
description: Albert Axelrod, a champion fencer and one of the few Americans of his era to achieve success in international competition in the sport, died on Feb. 24 at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 83.

title: Missouri Tells Charity To Change
description: The attorney general of Missouri recommended on Thursday that the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation make broad changes in the way it governs itself, strengthening its conflict of interest provisions and transferring many powers from its chief executive to the board of directors.

title: U.S. Presses States for Strict Seat Belt Laws
description: After six years, efforts to persuade states to enact tougher seat belt laws have stalled, prompting the federal government to step up its lobbying to have such bills passed by state legislatures.

title: Liz Phillips
description: Frederieke Taylor

title: Separation of Powers For Differing Reasons
description: Correction Appended

title: You Have the Right to Remain Silent (and to Wear Creased Jeans and Polyester)
description: The writer and director Todd Phillips's big-screen adaptation of ''Starsky & Hutch'' has a crafty, can-you-dig-it? spirit, derived from his affection for the 1970's and the original television cop series. All that's missing from the flaky fun is an announcement over the film's end credits: ''Tonight, on 'The Love Boat' . . .''

title: Surrounded by Suburban Grass, Pluckily Trying to Be a Star
description: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen

title: A Plot Written by a Mustang? He's Smart Enough Not to Say
description: ''Mister, you say anything you want about me,'' says the likable Frank Hopkins (Viggo Mortensen), just before punching a snobby Englishman, Preston Webb (C. Thomas Howell), whose accent is so bad you initially think he's being belted because no one believes him.

title: Budget Director Says City Can't Keep Up With Deficits
description: To hear Mark Page tell it, New York City's budget glass is most definitely half empty.

title: Companies Facing Ethical Issue As Drugs Are Tested Overseas
description: Dr. Louis G. Lange, a cardiologist and the chief executive of a small biotechnology company, has a new drug that, if approved, will be the first new treatment for angina in a quarter-century.

title: Private Bus Lines Attract a Public Outcry
description: Certain people actually love the sporadic service offered by private bus lines in and around the Jamaica, Queens, transportation hub.

title: McAuliffe Still Wants to Send A Message to Republicans
description: Terry McAuliffe, the effusive chairman of the Democratic National Committee, was holding forth recently in front of big-time donors in the buttery yellow living room at Hickory Hill, the fabled manor of the Kennedy clan in McLean, Va.

title: Winning Ways of Ex-Yankees Need to Rub Off
description: Shane Spencer and Karim Garcia meet every morning at 8:15 for breakfast at the Bob Evans in Port St. Lucie. They sit at the bar, they read the local newspaper and they do not talk about the Yankees.

title: With Polite Refusal, Same-Sex Marriage Issue Reaches City Hall
description: The growing fight over same-sex unions reached New York City yesterday as dozens of gay and lesbian couples seeking marriage licenses were turned away at the City Clerk's office in Manhattan and hundreds of protesters demanding same-sex marriage rights rallied outside City Hall.

title: QUICK ESCAPES
description: Los Angeles

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Jury In Crematory Trial
description: A jury has been chosen in the civil trial of Ray B. Marsh, who operated a crematory in Noble, where at least 334 sets of human remains were found buried in 2002. Instead of ashes, families were given cement dust and what appeared to be potting soil. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Alcohol And Cold Kill 2 Boys
description: Two 11-year-old boys from the Flathead Indian reservation died from alcohol poisoning and hypothermia after they skipped school last Friday. The boys, Justin Benoist and Frankie Nicolai, were members of the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes. An investigation is under way to determine where they got the alcohol. The boys' families reported them missing on Friday. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Where There's No Room for All Three of Them
description: Correction Appended

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Libya Discloses Mustard Gas Program and Stockpiles
description: Libya disclosed in a formal declaration today that it had produced and stored a vast stockpile of over 20 tons of deadly mustard gas, according to an international disarmament body that monitors the ban on chemical weapons.

title: Giambi Tries to Adjust To Change in Routine
description: When Jason Giambi was a young player with the Oakland Athletics, he absorbed everything Mark McGwire told him. Giambi noticed the way McGwire's pregame preparation never changed. ''You need to figure out what gets you ready for a baseball game,'' McGwire told Giambi, who followed the advice.

title: Leading Chinese Dissident Released From Prison
description: Under international pressure for its human rights record, the Chinese government on Thursday released a prominent pro-democracy dissident, the second political prisoner set free in just over a week, a human rights group said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: New York
description: NEW YORK

title: Miriam Schapiro -- 'A Retrospective'
description: Kristen Frederickson

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Green Won't Run For Mayor
description: Mark Green said yesterday that he would not run for New York City mayor in 2005. Mr. Green, who lost a bid for mayor in 2001 against Michael R. Bloomberg, did say that he might run for New York State attorney general in 2006, but only if Eliot Spitzer, a fellow Democrat, does not seek re-election. Mr. Spitzer may run for governor. So far, four other candidates have said they plan to run for attorney general, if Mr. Spitzer seeks the governorship: State Assemblymen Richard Brodsky of Westchester County; Michael Gianaris of Queens; Jeffrey Klein of the Bronx; and Charles King, a Manhattan lawyer. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Loss At Phone Company
description: PCCW, Hong Kong's largest telephone company, had a second consecutive annual loss after a charge of 4.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($539 million) for investments in its unprofitable cable venture with the Telstra Corporation. The net loss was 6.1 billion Hong Kong dollars, compared with a loss of 7.8 billion Hong Kong dollars a year earlier. The cable venture, Reach, has been hurt by competition and the finance chief, Alex Arena, said the company would not invest more money in it.

title: Mother and Daughter, Out Looking for Hope
description: In ''La Vie Promise'' Isabelle Huppert, an actress incapable of making a mawkish gesture, fights tooth and nail to keep the soft-boiled story of an embittered prostitute and her 14-year-old daughter from turning to mush. Even for an actress of Ms. Huppert's severity, however, it's a losing battle. The gauzy story has to win.

title: The Beauty of the Pacific, Enshrined and Exploited
description: Like many thematic surveys of contemporary art, ''Paradise Now? Contemporary Art From the Pacific'' at the Asia Society circles its organizing theme erratically. It alternates between the substantial and the flimsy, the revelatory and the merely didactic, art that argues its case directly and art whose intended (if not actual) effect is supplied primarily by wall labels.

title: Ethics Panel Calls Contributions To Rowland Defense Fund Gifts
description: A draft opinion to be released today by the executive director of Connecticut's ethics commission recommends that contributions to Gov. John G. Rowland's legal defense fund should be considered gifts, which are subject to state regulation, a state official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PAPERTSIAN, HARRY LEVON
description: PAPERTSIAN--Harry Levon, February 25, 2004, of Riverdale, NY, son of Hagop and Olive Papertsian. WW II veteran who dedicated his life to the mentally disabled. Survived by his wife Joyce and children Harry Andre, Lisa, Michelle, Matthew and Mark. Memorial service at Dobbs Ferry Lutheran Church, Saturday March 6, 2004, at 10:30 AM. Donations may be made to the Living Memorial Fund, Dobbs Ferry Lutheran Church, 914-693-0810.

title: Well-Traveled Furniture Settles Down
description: The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam has achieved a coup: it has just bought a cache of early Chinese Export decorative arts that for two centuries had been carefully retained by the American descendants of a Dutch-American, Andreas Everardus van Braam Houckgeest (1739-1801). The sale of 15 items includes furniture, a family portrait, two reverse paintings on glass, a dressing table set and a carved ivory fan, all made in China before 1795.

title: Bullies, Bears And Bullets: It's Round 5
description: HBO's new season of ''The Sopranos'' opens Sunday night with an extended, mournful tour of the exterior of the Soprano mini-mansion in New Jersey, lingering over dead leaves, abandoned patio furniture and other signs of neglect and loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRAZER, GRACE ELIZABETH
description: FRAZER--Grace Elizabeth, on February 28, 2004 in Englewood, NJ. Beloved sister of Edwin. She was a longtime employee of Time, Inc. Services are private.

title: In Texas, Hire a Lawyer, Forget About a Doctor?
description: As domestic security director for 16 north Texas counties, Greg Dawson of Fort Worth has many dealings with doctors and hospitals, preparing for a terrorism emergency he hopes will never come.

title: 'Orchid Pavilion Gathering' -- 'Chinese Painting From the University of Michigan Museum of Art'
description: Wallach Art Gallery

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Rutgers Protest Over Labor Talks
description: Rutgers University professors and graduate students staged a symbolic protest at the office of Richard L. McCormick, the university's president, yesterday. The protest involved what they called a lack of progress in labor talks and lack of a pay increase. Professors and teaching assistants have been working without a contract since June 2003. Mr. McCormick said in an interview that he sympathized with the protestors and blamed state budget cuts for pay limits. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: Closing America's Education Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: If Ebbers Masterminded the Fraud, Why Didn't He Sell More Stock?
description: THERE is -- or at least many corporate executives used to believe there was -- a gray area between flexible accounting and fraud. And that gray area may help answer a perplexing question: Why didn't WorldCom's chief executive sell before the stock collapsed?

title: Judge Drops Key Count on 2 Ex-Chiefs at Tyco
description: AManhattan judge today threw out the most serious charge against two former top executives accused of looting $600 million from Tyco International .

title: Hungary Eager and Uneasy Over New Status
description: Few places have witnessed the ebb and flow of the global economy as much as this genteel spa town in western Hungary.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column in Business Day on Feb. 26 about changing incomes in different regions misstated New Mexico's rank among states in income per capita for 2002. It was 47th, not last.

title: Colorado Places Stringent Limits On Its Recruiting
description: In the wake of numerous allegations of sexual misconduct involving its football program, the University of Colorado announced major steps yesterday to make the process of how it attracts high school players among the most stringent in the nation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Feb. 26 about an agreement by a consortium of international oil companies to develop an oil field in Kazakhstan misstated the oil production of Saudi Arabia. It is 8 million barrels a day, not 10.5 million.

title: Former Head of United Way in the Washington Area Pleads Guilty to Theft
description: The executive who ran the United Way here for 27 years pleaded guilty on Thursday to stealing $497,298 from the charity in a plea agreement that might send him to prison for 27 months. The charity's current president said that much more was taken and that a longer prison term was warranted.

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about former Representative Bill Janklow's South Dakota Supreme Court appeal of his convictions for manslaughter and reckless driving misstated the sources of the justices' appointments. Four justices, not all five, were appointed by Mr. Janklow when he was governor.

title: Upset Over Leaks, Lawyers For Balco Want an Inquiry
description: Lawyers for Victor Conte Jr. and James J. Valente, executives of the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative, the company at the heart of a steroid distribution investigation, called Thursday for a federal investigation into news leaks about the case.

title: Chicago Musicians Won't Pursue Barenboim
description: Musicians of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra have voted not to pursue attempts to hold on to their music director, Daniel Barenboim, who has resigned, effective at the end of the 2005-6 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DONN, ALBERT
description: DONN--Albert. March 5, 2004, the 100th Anniversary of Albert W. Donn's birth. Poet, patriot, pharmacist. Richard Donn, Doris Lipman Andy and David Donn Andy and John Lipman

title: Yesterday's Weapons
description: The Pentagon's decision last week to cancel the $38 billion Comanche helicopter program was a good, relatively easy step down a path that will require the Bush administration to make some much tougher decisions if it is truly serious about remaking the armed forces for 21st-century warfare. The country's revenues have been so hollowed by President Bush's tax cuts that they simply cannot sustain all of the weapons programs on the books, much less the changes the military needs to make.

title: Job Growth Stalls in February, Surprising Forecasters
description: Job creation all but stalled in February, surprising Wall Street forecasters and giving Democrats more economic ammunition to use against President Bush as he begins his re-election campaign.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: 25 Years For Killing Husband
description: Susan Wright, convicted of murdering her husband by stabbing him 193 times, was sentenced by a Houston jury to 25 years in prison. Ms. Wright acknowledged killing Jeffrey Wright, 34, but said she did so after years of abuse and in fear of her life. Prosecutors said she killed Mr. Wright to collect insurance benefits. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: An Astronaut Changes His Tune
description: What a difference a few months makes. Last July, John Grunsfeld, an astronaut, waxed enthusiastic about the value and sheer pleasure of participating in servicing missions to upgrade the Hubble Space Telescope, one of the most productive scientific instruments of all time. In testimony prepared for an expert panel, Mr. Grunsfeld called Hubble missions ''highly coveted assignments'' and said his own two Hubble flights had been the most important achievement in his life. Despite the tragic loss of the space shuttle Columbia, he said, he judged Hubble missions as little more risky than other shuttle flights. ''I can say without hesitation that traveling to space to upgrade the instruments and ensure the future of the Hubble Space Telescope was worth the potential risk to my life,'' he testified.

title: 36 Hours | San Diego
description: WITH 70 miles of sandy beaches matched by postcard-perfect weather and a laid-back atmosphere, San Diego is a destination for sun seekers the world over. But this Southern California city is not that one-dimensional: it also has history. Spanish explorers noted its natural harbor in 1542; in 1602 another expedition named it San Diego. It was finally colonized in the mid 1700's, making it the oldest port on the West Coast. In 1769, the Mission San Diego de Alcal was the first of the 21 missions built by Spanish friars throughout the state. In modern times, the city has become closely associated with its naval station and home to such famous attractions as the San Diego Zoo and SeaWorld. It also has a cultural centerpiece in Balboa Park, one of the country's best urban parks. The city, however, may be most famous for its glorious sunsets over the Pacific. FELICIA PAIK

title: Election Rules Proposed by Panel May Curb Interest Groups' Work
description: The Federal Election Commission proposed new rules on Thursday that could severely curtail the work of organizations established to get around fund-raising restrictions in the new campaign finance law.

title: Signing of Iraqi Charter Is Delayed by Shiite Objections
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 5 - Shiite leaders refused to sign Iraq's temporary constitution this evening, saying that they were backing out of an agreement struck earlier this week unless changes were made that would strengthen Shiite power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIER, PROFESSOR LIONEL D.
description: BIER--Professor Lionel D., 61, died March 4, 2004. Son of the late Judy and Max Bier, he taught art history at Brooklyn College for more than three decades. Survived by brother Ronald G. Bier of Emeryville, CA and fiancee Maria Aurenhammer of Vienna, Austria. Memorial serivce will be held in Spring. Donations may be made to the New York Public Library.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAUFMAN, MICHAEL AN DREW
description: KAUFMAN -- Michael An drew. Your 44th Birthday. We love you and miss you every day. Mother, Bill & Stephanie.

title: An Eminent Victorian Who's a Modernist, Too
description: The great 19th-century British designer Christopher Dresser (1834-1904) must have been some kind of maniac. The 300-object retrospective of his career at the Smithsonian Institution's Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum is pervaded by a sense of his multidexterous talent, evangelical ambition and detail-obsessed perfectionism that is almost off-putting.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Convicted Of 2001 Murder
description: A gang member was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday for his role in the shooting death of a Long Island girl, prosecutors said. The man, Marvin Osorio, 21, of Westbury, a member of the street gang MS-13, was the driver during a drive-by shooting on Aug. 26, 2001 in New Cassel. A fellow gang member, Olvin Reyes, 23, was riding with Mr. Osorio when he fired several shots at a rival gang member, but instead killed Jennifer Grimes, 14. Though Mr. Osorio did not pull the trigger, ''he willfully did everything he could to make this murder possible,'' Nassau County District Attorney Denis Dillon said in a statement. Mr. Osorio will be sentenced in Nassau County Court on April 12. Patrick Healy (NYT)

title: Torre, Feeling Wanted, Is Working on Extension
description: Joe Torre understands the unprecedented clout he has with the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner. Torre, who has won four World Series as the Yankees' manager, said he knew that if he campaigned for a contract extension last season, he could have forced Steinbrenner's hand.

title: Brushing off Paris clothiers
description: PARIS  Like most of the clothing merchants whose shops line the narrow streets in the Sedaine-Popincourt quarter, Lin Changli rarely speaks to the press. But in February, as he watched customs agents block off Rue Sedaine at the heart of this de facto garment district in eastern Paris, he grew incensed.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telecom Sale Proposal Revived
description: Australia's government resubmitted draft legislation that would allow it to sell its 51 percent stake in the telephone operator Telstra. An earlier draft was rejected in October in the Parliament's upper house. The government wants to sell its stake to pay off debts, but opponents say doing so will lead to more limited service, especially in the country's remote Outback. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Is Hard Work Enough to Escape From Poverty?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saint Laurent reborn
description: PARIS  Yves Saint Laurent has no doubt which artist gave him the most fun over 40 fashion years.

title: Iraq Threat Deliberately Inflated, Kennedy Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts today delivered a blistering indictment of President Bush's decision to go to war in Iraq, accusing Mr. Bush of deliberately exaggerating the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's regime.

title: Lindbergh and Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Arson Fires Strike 2 Muslim Sites in France
description: PARIS, March 5  A Muslim prayer center in the Alpine town of Seynod was destroyed today and the annex of a mosque in nearby Annecy was damaged in separate arson attacks before dawn.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: SEARCH OF RAIL NETWORK FINDS NO BOMBS Rail workers completed a search of the country's entire 20,000 miles of train track but found no bombs after an unknown terrorist entity threatened to explode bombs throughout the French railway system unless more than $5 million was paid. The state-run railway, S.N.C.F., began the ambitious search to ease commuters' fears. The railway has also tightened surveillance. The government, which is treating the blackmail plot as a criminal case rather than one involving international terrorism, has mobilized 600 police officers to work on it full time, the Interior Ministry said. Elaine Sciolino (NYT)

title: Beyond Marriage

description: To the Editor:
