description: WHO -- Courtney Leigh Hyan, 16, high school sophomore, Yorba Linda, Calif.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Order On School Lunches
description: Public schools must adhere to sweeping changes in school breakfast and lunch programs or face a loss of federal nutrition assistance, the Texas Department of Agriculture said. The new rules, intended to combat child obesity, forbid candy vending machines at elementary schools and require fresh fruits and vegetables on the menus where possible. Fried foods would be banned. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Former Senator-Astronaut Criticizes Space Plan
description: John Glenn, the former senator who was the first American to orbit the Earth, said Thursday that he opposed cutting money from the International Space Station and basic scientific research to pay for President Bush's goal of sending astronauts to the Moon and Mars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCLINTOCK, MARY MITCHELL
description: McCLINTOCK--Mary Mitchell (1911-2004) March Third, peacefully at home. Service at 3PM Saturday at St. John's Episcopal Church, Salisbury, Connecticut.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a shortage of foreign-language speakers at American intelligence agencies referred incompletely to the release of congressional testimony by the office of Representative Rush D. Holt of New Jersey, a member of the House Intelligence Committee. The material that was released was an unclassified version of testimony presented in a closed session of the committee on Feb. 26. It was provided to Mr. Holt outside of the closed session, and his office did not release it in classified form.

title: Bush Campaigns Amid a Furor Over Ads
description: Correction Appended

title: For These Men, Lots of Guts But Little Glory
description: Their classmates notice that they are invited to the popular athletes' parties on campus. They wear exclusive athletic logo apparel, and they hang around the athletic complex. Once in a while, they even sign an autograph.

title: Corrections
description: The Shopping List column on Feb. 6, about knitting supplies, referred incorrectly to the Clover Thread Cutter Pendant, a device for clipping yarn. Though it is intended to be worn as a pendant, it does not come on a cord.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: U.N. Ambassador Resigns
description: Milos Alcalay, left, the Venezuelan ambassador to the United Nations, announced his resignation, saying he could no longer support a government he accused of violating democratic principles and human rights. The announcement in New York energized opponents of President Hugo Chvez. The opposition has held protests and called for international pressure since electoral authorities sidelined an effort this week to hold a referendum on recalling Mr. Chvez from office, and they accuse National Guard troops of beating and detaining demonstrators. Seven people have been killed in the last week. ''Today, human rights in my country, I consider, are being violated,'' Mr. Alcalay said. He said the disqualification of hundreds of thousands of signatures on the recall petitions ''violates the spirit and purpose'' of Venezuela's Constitution and ''robs Venezuelans of the right to effect change through the democratic process.'' Juan Forero (NYT)

title: A Volatile Mix
description: Americans are increasingly anxious about their own economic futures, critical of the way President Bush is handling the country's economic troubles and worried that things in the country are not going well, according to polls this week.

title: Haitian-Americans Can Help Rebuild
description: To the Editor:

title: Orchid Pavilion Gathering; Miriam Schapiro; Sheila Pepe
description: Orchid Pavilion Gathering'

title: The Frenchwoman, In All Her Moods
description: For most of the world's women, the evolution of high-fashion conglomerates in the 1990's had all the impact of a Glimmerglass opera performed for an audience of Justin Timberlake fans. But for those who look to the runway as muse, the rise of corporate superbrands narrowed the range of stylistic roles a woman could play.

title: 9/11's Miracle Survivor Sheds Bandages; A 1907 Landmark Will Be Restored for Residential Use
description: Veiled in its 23-story shroud and braced in scaffolding for more than two years, the cherished little skyscraper at 90 West Street has been a building in mourning. To those living and working near ground zero, it has been a grimly persistent reminder of the terrorist assault on the World Trade Center.

title: New Beginning For Leetch, Not for Rangers
description: For the first time since he broke into the National Hockey League in 1988, Brian Leetch did not wear a Rangers sweater last night.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HOGAN, CARRIE
description: HOGAN--Carrie. You are deeply missed and loved. Love, your daughters, sister and brother.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Prime Minister To Appeal For Investment
description: Worried about the low level of investment by foreign companies, the Japanese government will sponsor television commercials in the United States and Europe, one featuring Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, to encourage foreign companies to set up shop in Japan. The 60-second ads will begin March 8 on CNN, the BBC and other overseas networks. The ads will stress Japan's economic might and the huge pool of savings held by Japanese families. Well-known foreign business leaders in Japan, like the chief executive of the Nissan Motor Company's, Carlos Ghosn, above, will also be featured. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: A Dispassionate Look at the Wolf in Priest's Clothing
description: THE child sexual abuse scandal was raging through the Roman Catholic Church. The nation's bishops, accused of covering up the sins of their priests, commissioned a study to explore the problem. Many individual bishops fumed. So did victims, worried about a whitewash.

title: A few upscale brands are proud to ignore the vagaries of seasonal fashion
description: PARIS  Fashion, by its very nature, is a cyclical phenomenon. Short skirts follow long, tight tailoring follows soft; the '50s follows the '70s (yet again), as we all get ready for an imminent '90s revival.

title: Hollinger to Avoid Default
description: Hollinger International Inc. agreed yesterday to lend its parent company the $7.4 million its needs to make a bond payment and avert a default that would erode Conrad M. Black's controlling stake, or guarantee a loan for the same amount.

title: A Logjam for Transportation in China
description: Strained by rapid economic growth, China's transportation system has bogged down, especially in the last six weeks, causing delays in deliveries of raw materials and raising a serious risk of higher inflation.

title: In Two Festivals, One Wide World Of Children's Film
description: Last year Eric Beckman and Emily Shapiro did not hold the New York International Children's Film Festival. For this married team, an even more important creative project was due: their third child. But while Mr. Beckman says their baby-making days are over, the festival is definitely not. Its sixth edition opens tonight in Manhattan, and for the first time this monthlong event will also feature an award from a jury, one that this year includes Gus Van Sant, Jonathan Demme and Susan Sarandon.

title: 4 Finalists For Memorial To Sept. 11 In Hoboken
description: The horror of 9/11 played out here, too.

title: Unveiling the Modern's Works From South of the Border
description: The first work by a Latin American artist that I remember seeing in New York was Wifredo Lam's huge and (to me, then) menacing canvas ''The Jungle'' (1943). For varying periods it hung in the entrance hall of the Museum of Modern Art, its powerful Surrealist presence a sort of logo for the museum as a stronghold of avant-garde culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAMARA, YVONNE
description: SAMARA--Yvonne. Bon vivant and bright light to all who knew her. Beloved mother and grandmother, devoted sister, loyal friend and the world's best mother-in-law. Educated in Florence and Alexandria, her style, grace and love of travel lasted throughout her life. Mass 11AM Tuesday, March 9 at St. Patrick's Church, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations to Children's Aid Society, Greenwich Village Center, 219 Sullivan St, NYC 10012.

title: Even as Order Dawns in Capital, Day of the Vigilante Stretches On in Haitian Towns
description: After what the thugs did to his son, no punishment seemed harsh enough to Roland Lysias.

title: From Fiber Optic Fountains to Trickling Waterfalls
description: IN addition to getting a more upscale name -- spas -- hot tubs have gotten increasingly elaborate. Here, a selection of spa companies and designers and what they offer. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Children Examined After Handling Medicine
description: Sixteen elementary school students in the Bronx were taken to hospitals as a precaution yesterday after handling vials of prescription asthma medicine that one child brought from home, officials said. The children, from Public School 5, were released after they were found to be unharmed, said Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education. Officials said a girl in the second grade whose brother has asthma brought the medicine, Albuterol, to school and distributed it to her classmates. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about ''Love Letters: Dutch Genre Paintings in the Age of Vermeer,'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., gave an incomplete history of the love letter. What began in 17th-century Holland was the widespread custom of writing intimate letters; there were indeed earlier love letters, including those written by Hlose and Ablard in the 12th century.

title: The Collections / Paris : Dark romance at Comme des Garcons; a futuristic Miyake
description: The pull of gravity in fashion is going in two opposing directions  the romantic and the futuristic. At Dior, John Galliano tried to have it both ways, showing graphic over-sized Teddy Boy jackets mixed with turn-of-the century coats. Balenciaga looked both forward and back to the house archives. Comme des Garcons created a dark romance and Issey Miyake's collection took off to the moon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEPRIN, LOUIS
description: WEPRIN--Louis. 8/15/103/5/79. Happy are those who dwell in Your house; they forever praise You. Love, Earle and Barry Wepri

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, RICHARD J.
description: ROBERTS--Richard J. On March 4, 2004. Beloved husband of Roberta. Devoted father of Robin and Dennis, Randi and Iven and Rhonda and Matthew. Loving brother of Joyce Popiel. Caring nephew of Muriel Brinn. Cherished grandfather of Kyle, Jonathan, Katherine, Olivia and Lawrence. Services Friday, 1PM, at Central Synagogue, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Europe's Central Banker Resists Push to Cut Rates
description: When Jean-Claude Trichet took charge of the European Central Bank last fall, his supporters predicted that he would be both disciplined and resistant to political pressure.

title: Stephen Sprouse, Design Pioneer, Dies at 50

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jobless Rate Rises To 8.4 Percent
description: The city's unemployment rate rose in January to 8.4 percent, up from 8.1 percent in December, despite some modest job creation, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said yesterday. The city has continued to lag behind the rest of the country in recovering from the recession, Mr. Thompson said. Adored and adoring father of Rabbi Gary (Marianne) Bretton-Granatoor, Richard (Leslie) Granatoor and Robin (Todd) Rosenfeld. Doting grandfather, Papa Jerry to Samantha, Max, Jacob, Zachary, Lindsay and Lucas. Pharmacist and co-owner of Kollman's Pharmacy in New Rochelle, he was a dispensor of prescriptions and concern. A friend to all customers and passers-by alike. In his retirement he lavished his laugh and joy of life on his friends in the Old Guard. Funeral services at Temple Emanu-El of Yonkers at 11 AM on Friday, March 5. While his heart may have failed him in the end, he never failed to give his heart to all he met. The memory of the righteous is always a blessing.

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS IS BUYING SEALY FOR $1.5 BILLION

Kohlberg Kravis and Sealy's management will buy about 92 percent of the company, which is privately held, from an investment group that includes Bain Capital, Charlesbank Capital Partners, J.P. Morgan Partners, CIBC Argosy Merchant Fund and BancBoston Capital. The remaining 8 percent of the company will be held by current shareholders. Sealy shareholders have approved the deal, which is expected to close in April. Sealy, based in Trinity, N.C., employs more than 6,000 people and has 31 plants.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Marches Over Nazi War Criminal
description: A demonstration planned for Saturday to rally support for the release of Erich Priebke, a 90-year-old convicted Nazi war criminal serving a life sentence under house arrest in Rome, has angered Jewish groups and city officials, and his critics are also planning a demonstration, also for tomorrow. Mr. Priebke, a former SS captain, was convicted in 1997 for a 1944 massacre in which more than 300 Italian civilians were killed. Jason Horowitz (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Optimistic Economic Outlook
description: The Ministry of Finance said its survey of business sentiment showed that on balance big Japanese companies remained optimistic about the business environment for a second consecutive quarter after 10 straight periods of overall pessimism. Survey data also showed that business sentiment improved at small- and medium-size businesses in the first quarter, although those groups remained pessimistic about business conditions over all. The survey results suggest that Japan's strong economic performance for the fourth quarter of 2003 is continuing into 2004, economists said. A separate survey yesterday showed that Japanese companies increased capital investment by 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 2003, compared with the quarter a year earlier. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Justice Department Backs Scouts
description: The Justice Department expressed support of the Boy Scouts in arguing that it is not a religious organization and should not be barred from operating on public property. In a brief filed in federal court in San Diego, the department said the Scouts' lease of city-owned property for an aquatic center did not violate the Constitution's prohibition on the establishment of religion. Six San Diego residents have sought to bar the center. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: Seeking Human Truths Through the Stage
description: ''The Reckoning,'' which opens today nationwide, begins with a lovely, elusive montage that seems intended to plunge modern viewers into a scary, alien world. The film, directed by Paul McGuigan from a script by Mark Mills, takes place in England in 1380, and in the first few minutes the film confronts us with austere, haunting images that throw our modern moviegoing expectations off balance. Extreme close-ups of plants, water and a pale-blue human eye (belonging to the British actor Paul Bettany) may evoke art films of the recent past, but they also immerse us in a strange premodern landscape.

title: When Older Is Smarter
description: In the 1960's, when French hippies were getting stoned and taking to the barricades, Lucien Pellat-Finet was living a life typical of those lucky enough to be born into the class known as grand bourgeois. A son of a wealthy family from Nice, Mr. Pellat-Finet was probably the last person one would have associated with any sort of counterculture. As a young man, he found himself drawn to fashion. He went to work for Georges Rech, Thierry Mugler and Chanel. He opened a Parisian boutique with a friend. He developed a reputation as a talented journeyman, known well enough but far from central to the scene.

title: DELTA ADDS $10 TO SOME FLIGHTS TO COVER AIRPORT FEES

Delta, based in Atlanta, said that it had been absorbing the charge, which can be as much as $18 a round trip, for customers' connecting flights. A Delta spokeswoman declined to say how many flights were affected. A majority of airports in the United States impose a so-called passenger facility charge for every traveler using the airport. American Airlines, a unit of AMR, and United Airlines, a unit of UAL, said they would study Delta's change.

The loan was due last May and the European Commission has sued France to force it to collect. title: There Must Be Consequences
description: The Catholic bishops' painful report on the sexual abuse of children was a chilling tally of thousands of victims and thousands of predators. But the report lacked an equal measure of candor about holding accountable not just abusive priests but also the bishops and cardinals who covered up their crimes. It was distressing to hear the suggestion by Bishop Wilton Gregory, the prelate charged with directing the inquiry, that the ''terrible history'' is just that -- history.

title: Sheila Pepe -- 'Bridge and Tunnel'
description: Susan Inglett Gallery

title: Latest Design Revisions Push Innovation
description: Design guidelines intended to give three-dimensional form to the World Trade Center redevelopment project -- but not quite as exactingly as a draft prepared last year -- are now being circulated for comment among planners, architects and officials.

title: In Florida, Can 1950's Motels Become Hip Enough to Survive?
description: AS the sun sets on the Surf, 93-year-old Florence Strong sits outside enjoying the play of light on the sharply angular surfaces of the kitschy mom and pop motel in Treasure Island, Fla., a beachfront barrier island community near St. Petersburg. Mrs. Strong, a retired nurse, has been a seasonal visitor at the Surf ever since she and her late husband drove down from Auburn, N.Y., in the 1950's. ''I've come back every year since,'' she says, shading her eyes from the sunlight that sparkles on the aqua surface of the pool. ''I truly hate to see them tear it down.''

title: China's Leader Urges Shift in Development to Rural Areas
description: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao, delivering China's equivalent of the State of the Union address, vowed Friday to cool China's surging economy and focus more resources on the hundreds of millions of people left behind in the boom of the last decade.

description: Shift by Chinese Premier

description: Weyerhaeuser, Federal Way, Wash., the world's biggest lumber company, said it planned to sell three wood-products mills in the Southeast United States.

description: Revivals of "King Lear" and "Fiddler on the Roof" and plays by Nicky Silver, Charles L. Mee and Tracy Letts recently opened in New York.

title: The Hipper Dinner Suit
description: If last week's Oscar broadcast is any indication, the familiar black tie is going the way of the fedora and the fish fork.

description: After Martha Stewart was convicted guilty of all four charges against her, reporters, lawyers, and jurors left the courthouse.

description: PARIS  Karl Lagerfeld has traveled a long 21-year road with Chanel and his show on Friday took him both back to Coco's start  and forward to the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   URDANG, NATHAN, ESQUIRE.
description: URDANG--Nathan, Esquire. Beloved husband of Deborah. Loving brother of Henry Urdang, Sol Urdang and Bess Kalstein. Devoted uncle of many nieces and nephews. Visitation at Beth Abraham Memorial Chapel, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC, Sunday 10:3011:30AM. Funeral service at 11:30AM. Interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Markets Hold as Low-Interest Hopes Counter Jobs Report
description: Bond prices rose, yields plunged and the dollar fell yesterday in the wake of a surprisingly weak February jobs report, suggesting that any interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve will not come as soon as had been predicted. The stock market, where slow job creation is a negative and low interest rates a positive, was little changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERMAN, LINDA MERONI
description: LIEBERMAN--Linda Meroni of Harrison on March 4th. Loving wife of the late Elwyn Lieberman. Devoted mother of Loren (wife Lory) Lieberman and Amy (husband Greg) Lamb, cherished grandmother of Brandon, Matthew and Trevor Lamb and Avery Lieberman. Dear sister of Gloria Caliguire. Funeral service Monday 11AM Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck 914698-5968. Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery. Donations to NYU Medical Center.

title: Missing Witnesses
description: Until and unless the Bush administration starts making their prosecution a priority, those implicated in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks can rest assured that they will not be held accountable by the law. That was the message delivered by a German appeals court on Thursday, when it threw out the year-old conviction of a suspect who had been denied access to an important witness held in American custody.

title: Drugstore's return gives lift to Parisian shopping circuit
description: PARIS  Parisians are spoiled for choice this season with the opening of a wide variety of stores. But perhaps the most dramatic retail event in town is not a new shop but the reopening of a classic: the Drugstore Publicis just a short walk from the Arc de Triomphe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Martha Stewart and Broker Are Convicted of Lying

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: REPERCUSSIONS FROM PRISON INCIDENT A prison warden was demoted and eight other supervisors reassigned after an investigation into a 15-day hostage standoff at the Arizona State Prison Complex-Lewis in Buckeye found gaps in security compounded by "years' worth of bad decisions" in the state's prison system. The panel, appointed by Gov. Janet Napolitano, a Democrat, found that a crisis at a state prison was almost inevitable because of underfinancing by the Legislature, a lack of adequate training for officers and staff shortages. (AP)

title: In a Historic Black Hamlet, Wal-Mart Finds Resistance
description: Alexander Luten's grandfather did well for a man born into slavery. So, too, did the other newly emancipated field hands who worked the nearby rice plantations and settled this buggy strip of coastal Georgia. Like the others, Benjamin Luten built a prim four-room shack for his family and made sure his children and grandchildren got a nice wedge of land and a decent education.

title: Bush Is Considering Waiver For Mexicans Entering U.S.
description: President Bush welcomed President Vicente Fox of Mexico to his ranch here on Friday night, and the White House said it was seriously considering a plan that would exempt many Mexicans from strict new requirements that all visitors to the United States be fingerprinted and photographed.

title: STEWART FOUND GUILTY OF LYING IN SALE OF STOCK
description: Martha Stewart, who used her image of domestic perfection to build a multimillion-dollar company, was found guilty by a Manhattan jury yesterday of lying about the reasons she sold shares of a biotechnology company more than two years ago.

title: On Baseball; Scope of Balco Subpoena of Steroid Tests Is Greatly Reduced
description: ITS critics can say what they want, but they could do worse than have lawyers of the Major League Baseball Players Association representing them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Move Against Milosevic Charges
description: Lawyers acting as a defense team in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic filed a motion asking that genocide charges against the former Yugoslav president -- the gravest charges against him -- be dropped for lack of evidence. The three lawyers -- two Britons and a Serb -- were appointed by the United Nations war crimes tribunal to ensure a fair trial for Mr. Milosevic, who is defending himself. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: New York Has Weaker Voice In Congress Led by G.O.P.
description: Representative Gregory W. Meeks of New York City went through something of a legislative dry spell while the 107th Congress was in session, being the chief sponsor of exactly two resolutions and five bills. None of them passed, Congressional records show.

title: McGreevey's Ties to Donor Under Scrutiny
description: The United States attorney's office is investigating whether a member of Gov. James E. McGreevey's campaign finance committee received a favorable settlement on several tax liens held by the state as a reward for his fund-raising, according to state officials and others familiar with the inquiry.

title: Libya Discloses Production Of 23 Tons of Mustard Gas
description: In a formal declaration on Friday, Libya disclosed that it had produced and stored some 23 tons of deadly mustard gas, according to an international disarmament body that monitors the ban on chemical weapons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NADEL, ROBERT
description: NADEL--Robert. Of Hartsdale, NY died suddenly March 4, 2004. Much loved husband of the late Joan Klein Nadel, father of Steven, grandfather of Marcy, fatherin-law of Cindy, uncle of Valerie Eisman, caring friend and family member of many and a dedicated community leader. Family and friends will gather in Bob's memory 3:30PM Sunday, March 7th at Greenburgh Nature Center, 99 Dromore Rd., Scarsdale, NY. Those who wish to make a donation in Bob's memory, may do so to the Greenburgh Nature Center.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Possible Vote On Houston Pension Plan
description: Mayor Bill White of Houston said he would request a special election in May to change the city's employee pension plan, which actuaries say has liabilities that could total $1.5 billion. The current retirement plan, expanded in 2001, pays retired city employees with 25 years' service 90 percent of their salaries. Mr. White called the plan ''a fraud.'' Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Moving to Singapore : The twists and turns of apartment hunting
description: SINGAPORE  Southeast Asia's cities conjure up some nightmarish images: horrendous traffic, ghastly pollution, crime, slums and prostitution  not the kind of places you want to live, in other words.

title: Kennedy Gives Bush Stinging Rebuke on War
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts delivered a blistering indictment on Friday of President Bush's decision to go to war in Iraq, accusing Mr. Bush of deliberately exaggerating the threat posed by Saddam Hussein's government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATKOVIC, KSENIJA DE CERINEO
description: MATKOVIC--Ksenija De Cerineo, wife of the late Ivo (Gino) Matkovic, died after a brief illness on March 4, 2004. She is survived by her daughters, Lydia Klyver, Tina Spiro and June Goldfinger, along with eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. She was born the Countess de Cerineo, daughter of Count Dinko de Cerineo and Tinka de Cerineo, in Brac, Yugoslavia in 1918. She and her husband Gino were long-time residents of Manhasset, New York and members of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club. She was a loving, devoted mother, arbiter of style and owner of Artium Gallery in Port Washington, New York. Her radiant memory is treasured by her family. Donations to the Jupiter Medical Foundation would be appreciated in lieu of flowers. For information, Aycock Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL.

title: Homeless Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Rehnquist's Book on a Disputed Election (No, Not That One)
description: Twice members of the Supreme Court have played a decisive role in choosing an American president. In the 2000 Bush-Gore race a vote by five justices, including Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, halted a recount of Florida's popular vote, giving the presidency to George W. Bush.

title: Iraq's Real Holy War
description: The first celebration of the Muslim holiday Ashura since the fall of Baghdad has been particularly bloody for Shiites -- and ominous for American foreign policy. Some 140 Iranian and Iraqi Shiite pilgrims died in suicide bombings in Baghdad and Karbala this week, and 43 Pakistani Shiites were killed in Quetta, Pakistan.

title: Bling-Bling, Party Party: Some Rappers Just Want to Have Fun
description: For all the things hip-hop has been -- reportage, confession, protest, tall tale, provocation, marketing ploy -- it has always been party music, and best-selling hip-hop has lately been shedding most other ambitions. On Thursday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom, Ludacris headlined a concert full of good-time party chants and testosterone testimonials. The rappers came from Atlanta (Ludacris), St. Louis (Chingy), Mississippi (David Banner) and Los Angeles (Knoc-Turn'al), and they made the elaborate rhetoric and multilevel messages of New York hip-hop seem elitist.

title: Accusations in Capitol On Lead Levels in Water
description: High levels of lead in the city's drinking water, a problem disclosed last month, prompted several members of Congress to say on Friday that three agencies had misled residents and could have begun correcting the problem last year or even earlier.

title: Using 9/11 in a Political Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: State To Allow Same-Sex Unions
description: A judge in the southernmost state in Brazil, the world's largest Roman Catholic country, has authorized same-sex couples to register civil unions at any public notary office. The decision came after gay rights groups complained of discrimination and local prosecutors sought an injunction on their behalf. ''Notwithstanding the ethical, philosophic, anthropological and religious discussion, the fact is that homosexual relations exist and, therefore, in the name of judicial security, deserve to be regulated,'' the court ruling said. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, VIRGINIA W.
description: SMITH--Virginia W. Suddenly on March 3, 2004. Beloved wife of Herbert L. Smith III, her loving husband of almost fifty years. Devoted mother of Herbert L. Smith IV and Victoria Smith Walsh. Adored grandmother of Samantha G. Smith, Morgan M. Smith, Herbert L. Smith V, Christopher J. Smith, Virginia S. Walsh, Charlotte G. Walsh, Nelson S. Walsh, Jr. Loving sister of George W. Morosani, Reto W. Morosani, Roopa Morosani, John W. Morosani, and the late Francesca M. Thompson. She is survived by her mother, Virginia W. Morosani. She was a past president of the North Country Garden Club of LI, a committed conservationist and a skilled and assured horticulturist. In lieu of flowers, her family would be grateful for contributions to the North Country Garden Club of Long Island, memo: the Virginia W. Smith Fund, 80 Wolver Hollow Rd, Glen Head, NY 11545. A service will be held on Tuesday, March 9, 11AM at Christ Church, Oyster Bay, NY.

title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: IMMIGRANT HID IN JET'S WHEEL WELL A stowaway from the Dominican Republic was discovered emerging from the wheel well of a passenger jet after it landed at Miami International Airport, officials said. The man, whose name was not released, was taken into custody by Customs and Border Protection agents for interviews and processing for repatriation, immigration officials said. He was not injured. An American Airlines ramp employee saw him climb out of the right wheel well around 11:30 a.m., shortly after the plane arrived from Santo Domingo. Customs officials and American Airlines security workers tried to determine how security measures were breached for the flight of 1 hour and 40 minutes. (AP)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Suit On Same-Sex Marriages
description: A new group of clergy members, politicians and state residents filed a lawsuit seeking to keep Multnomah County from issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples four days after the county attorney said not doing so would violate the state's Constitution. Tim Nashif, spokesman for the group, the Defense of Marriage Coalition, said the suit contends that county commissioners violated the state's open meeting law before the decision. Efforts are also under way to get an initiative on the November ballot for a state constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. Multnomah County includes Portland, the state's largest city. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Hare Count
description: Gamekeepers and biologists have begun a nationwide count of the country's brown hares, which are on the list of endangered species in Germany. After dark, when the rabbits come out to feed, watchers in more than 800 districts will be scanning fields with powerful spotlights. Their count is expected before Easter. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Martha Stewart Is Denied New Trial by U.S. Judge
description: Afederal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant a new trial for Martha Stewart and her former stockbroker, rejecting arguments that a juror in their case was biased and provided false information about his background.

title: Devils Deal Cup Finals Star Rupp For Hrdina
description: Mike Rupp is 24 and weighs 230 pounds, and he scored the winning goal in the game that clinched the Stanley Cup for the Devils in June. But he is not a veteran center who can do a little of everything. Apparently, the Devils think Jan Hrdina is.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Feb. 17 about the new Comme des Garons Guerrilla Store in Berlin, which plans to close after a year whether it is successful or not, omitted the name of one business partner. She is Lil Schlichting-Stegemann.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Adecco Sets Date For Results
description: Adecco, the world's largest employment services company, said it would release its full-year 2003 results and its first-quarter profits for 2004 on April 20, two and a half months later than scheduled. The company, which is based Glattbrugg, Switzerland, postponed the release of 2003 profit figures on Jan. 12, after accounting and control problems were found at a North American unit, Adecco Staffing North America, and results had to be audited again. In a statement, the company tried to reassure investors that 2004 operations had been ''healthy'' so far, that February group sales in local currencies had grown faster than in the corresponding period in 2003 and that the company had not uncovered ''major misappropriations or irregularities that would be financially significant to the company as a whole.'' Adecco's share price, which fell by one-third after the January announcement, rose slightly after the latest announcement. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Frank and Kenneth Stubbolo, brothers who were acquitted of all but one charge in connection with accusations that they had lied to a New York State agency about their experience as general contractors, misstated the earlier disposition of two other charges -- insurance fraud and grand larceny. They were dismissed by a judge, not dropped by prosecutors.

title: Mono brand store craze may be ebbing : A multibrand comeback?
description: MILAN  One of fashion's most formidable weapons in the last decade has been the mighty mono brand store, a retail enclave designed to get customers up close and personal with a single brand. In this oasis of carefully chosen music, lighting, furniture, sales people  even beverages  one brand's image flourishes in a tight cocoon controlled by its designer's distinct vision. For the last 10 years, fashion's collective consciousness gave a green light to this formula and, as a result, identical single brand stores multiplied at lightning speed across the globe.

title: Gay Marriage Licenses Create a Quandary for the Clergy
description: For three weeks, the grand marble staircase at City Hall has been wedding central in San Francisco, with thousands of gay and lesbian couples lining up to be married by city officials.

title: ORACLE FILES RESPONSE TO LAWSUIT BY JUSTICE DEPARTMENT
description: The Oracle Corporation filed its response to the Justice Department lawsuit that asserts Oracle's takeover of PeopleSoft would violate federal antitrust laws. In the 26-page response, filed late Thursday in United States District Court for the Northern District of California in San Francisco, Oracle denied that the merger of the two companies would reduce competition. The response states that the proposed merger is procompetitive ''in that it will enable Oracle to better compete with the clear market leader, SAP A.G., and other existing competitors.'' Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''To the extent that companies can squeeze another drop of blood out of their existing work force, they're doing it. Eventually you reach the point where there's no more blood to be given, but we haven't reached it yet.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAZZUCCA, MICHAEL LAWRENCE
description: MAZZUCCA--Michael Lawrence, of Valley Cottage, NY, passed away Thursday, March 4, 2004 at the age of 60. Born in NYC on June 6, 1943, he was the son of Michael Alexander and Viola Piccolino Mazzucca. Mr. Mazzucca married Mary Driscoll on June 26, 1965 at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx, NY. He was the President of Regional Scaffolding & Hoisting Co., Inc. on Webster Ave. in the Bronx. Survived by his wife Mary and his loving children, Catherine McGrath, Paul Mazzucca and Daniel Mazzucca, and by his cherished grandchildren, Hannah, Ethan and Michael, and his sister, Lenore Gavigan. Friends may call Sunday and Monday March 7th and 8th, 24 and 7-9pm, at the familyowned and operated Joseph W. Sorce F.H. Inc., 728 W Nyack Rd., W. Nyack, NY 845358-4433. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held Tuesday, March 9th at 9:45am at St. Francis of Assisi Church. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Michael's name to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 432 Park Ave. So., 15th Flr., NY NY 10016 (212) 689-2860 or to the Hudson Valley Council, Boy Scouts of America Endowment Fund, PO Box 374, Salisbury Mills, New York 12477.

description: To the Editor:

title: Blair Reiterates Case for War, Asserting Grave Danger
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair argued Friday that the possibility that Islamic extremists might collaborate with countries that possessed unconventional weapons to carry out acts of terror justified an aggressive new standard in international law for breaching the sovereignty of nations.

title: Millions For Moochers
description: The business world finally cracked down this week on one of the world's biggest welfare moochers, dragging Michael Eisner out of the chairman's seat at the Walt Disney Company. Probably the only thing that allows Mr. Eisner to hold on to the job of chief executive is that he has been so incompetent -- or shrewd? -- that he has failed to cultivate not only profits, but also a successor.

title: Best and Worst of the Primaries
description: Correction Appended

title: A Book With a Rich Tradition, This Time for Average Players
description: Bridge literature has a rich tradition of collections of deals featuring fictional characters. One of the most famous is S. J. Simon's foursome: the Unlucky Expert, Mr. Smug, Futile Willie and Mrs. Guggenheim. Another is Victor Mollo's Hideous Hog, Rueful Rabbit and other denizens of the Griffins Club.

title: City's Sprint Champion Goes for a State Title
description: On a recent morning in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the city's fastest scholastic sprinter was strapped into a harness and pulled from behind as he trained at an old school gym that once vaulted top teenage athletes to national prominence.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary of the fashion designer Stephen Sprouse yesterday included an incorrect paraphrase of an observation by his friend Candy Pratts Price, director of Style.com, about something he shared with other ''American fashion greats.'' She said that they too had Indiana backgrounds, not that they used Norman Norell's tailor.

title: Sports of The Times; After Schott Spoke Out, The Air Needed Clearing
description: Correction Appended

title: Baseball's Shame
description: Considering all the noise over steroids, one would expect Major League Baseball to move briskly to strengthen its laughably timid drug-testing program. After all, President Bush spoke of the scourge of performance-enhancing drugs in his State of the Union address, and Attorney General John Ashcroft personally announced the indictments of four men affiliated with a San Francisco laboratory accused of peddling illegal steroids. Several stars, including Barry Bonds of the Giants and Jason Giambi of the Yankees, appeared before the grand jury investigating the lab. No athlete has been accused of wrongdoing, but there is a gnawing feeling in baseball's clubhouses that unpleasant revelations lie ahead.

title: Will Love Find Lonely Ann-Margret? What Do You Think?
description: With wide, embellished eyes, a golden complexion, and thick go-go hair, Ann-Margret at 62 still looks kittenish against the odds; she can't be convincingly pastured in television movies for senior citizens. She is miscast in ''A Place Called Home,'' tomorrow night on the Hallmark Channel.

title: Employers Reluctant to Hire
description: While the economy has been expanding at a healthy pace for six months by most measures, employers remain stubbornly reluctant to add jobs. News analysis, Page C1.

title: Republicans and Democrats Step Up Efforts to Register Millions of Voters
description: Republicans have stepped up their push to register three million voters this year with the help of an election-year prop -- an 18-wheel truck full of laptops, plasma TV's and multimedia equipment -- designed to help communicate the party's message.

title: George D. Reycraft, 79, Corporate Litigator and Trustbuster
description: George Dewey Reycraft, a leading Wall Street litigator of complex corporate tangles and a former trustbuster for the Justice Department, died on Monday in Miami. A resident of Key Largo, Fla., he was 79 and formerly lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Iona's Trying Season Lives for Another Game
description: At 6 feet 9 inches, with a lumberjack's build, Iona Coach Jeff Ruland casts an imposing sideline presence.

title: U.S. Special Forces in Haiti Seeking Out Rebel Leaders
description: Newly arrived United States Special Forces sought out rebel leaders on Friday, as marines at the presidential palace were jeered and cursed by demonstrators loyal to the deposed president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VASSOLER, MARY ANNE
description: VASSOLER -- Mary Anne. Born New York City 1936. Artist Le Mer of Valewood Atelier. Beloved mother of John, Kiki and Christian Vassoler. Died March 4, 2004.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a tour of the Whitehall ferry terminal in Manhattan by members of the City Council misidentified the scene shown. It was on the Staten Island ferry after the tour, not in the terminal.

title: Jorge Guinle, 88, a Playboy Who Outlived His Millions
description: Jorge Guinle, one of the last of the millionaire playboys whose free-spending ways and romantic exploits made them global celebrities from the 1930's onward, died early Friday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 88 years old and died in a suite at the luxurious Copacabana Palace Hotel, which his family built and owned for more than half a century.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEAVY, ESTHER
description: LEAVY--Esther. 3/6/76. In loving memory. Never forgotten. Your children and grandchildren

title: Clash Of Titans
description: We're so full of it. We pretend to be a middle-class, democratic nation, but in reality we love our blue bloods. We love our Roosevelts, Rockefellers, Kennedys, Bushes, Deans and Gores. We love the prep school manners, the aristocratic calm, the Skull and Bones mystery, the dappled lawns stretching before the New England summer homes. How else can you explain the Bush vs. Kerry matchup that confronts us this year?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHEINBERG, LABE C., M.D.
description: SCHEINBERG--Labe C., M.D. Goodbye, Labe, from your wild Tiger Lily. Keep in touch. You always found a way. Elayne S.G. Waller, Scarsdale

title: Videotapes Showing Corruption Set Off Waves in Mexican Politics
description: The nation's capital was rocked this week by the release of a videotape that appeared to show a local legislator and trusted ally of Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, considered Mexico's most popular politician, accepting a $45,000 bribe.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: From Train Station To Police Station
description: Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick, left, of Detroit announced plans to buy the long-vacant Michigan Central Depot and turn it into the city's police headquarters. The plan involves spending $100 million to $130 million to buy the 91-year-old train station and surrounding land from a trucking company. The 500,000-square-foot building was designed by architects Whitney Warren and Charles Wetmore, who also designed Grand Central Terminal in New York. The station thrived until the end of World War II and has been abandoned since 1988. Ben LeFebvre (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Turk Killed In Highway Ambush
description: A Turkish engineer and his Afghan guard were killed on the new American-built highway linking Kabul and Kandahar, Afghan and Turkish officials said. A second Turkish engineer and his driver were believed kidnapped. Gunmen thought to be Taliban members have carried out numerous attacks on the road in an apparent effort to slow its construction. David Rohde (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBOTTA, JACK
description: LUBOTTA--Jack. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member, Jack Lubotta, and extends sincere sympathy to his wife Constance, and other members of his family. Michael Stein, President Stephen Fiverson, Secretary

title: Firehouses to Remain Closed Despite a Healthier Budget
description: The Fire Department will not reopen any of the six fire companies it closed last May despite having $2 million more in its preliminary budget than it did last year, Fire Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta said yesterday.

title: Buyers Step In to Try to Save Camden Baseball Team
description: Since the owner and founder of the Riversharks died last May, the minor-league baseball team in Camden, N.J., has been struggling financially.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the issuance of marriage licenses to gay couples in Multnomah County, Ore., misspelled the surname of a University of Oregon law professor who said he believed state law did not prohibit the marriages, and referred incompletely to his background. He is Dominick Vetri, not Vetir; and he is a supporter of gay marriage.

title: Administration Sets Forth A Limited View on Privacy
description: In a sharp departure from its past insistence on the sanctity of medical records, the Bush administration has set forth a new, more limited view of privacy rights as it tries to force hospitals and clinics to turn over records of hundreds and perhaps thousands of abortions.

title: Gay Marriage in Oregon
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki in Tentative Deal With Largest Union
description: The Pataki administration and the state's largest public employees union said yesterday that they had agreed on a tentative contract that would raise the salaries of 70,000 state workers by what union officials said was 11 percent over the next four years.

title: There's More Welfare to Reform
description: When the landmark 1996 welfare reform law came up for reauthorization in 2002, easy approval was expected. After all, the legislation was popular, it had originally passed with significant bipartisan support and, well, it was working, with the number of people on welfare down an astonishing 60 percent since states started putting reforms in place.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Drug Maker To Buy Back Shares
description: Schering, Germany's third-largest pharmaceutical company and a leading manufacturer of birth control pills worldwide, plans to buy back four million of its shares and to raise profitability by cutting costs, the company said at its annual news conference in Berlin. With more than 50 percent of its sales generated overseas, the drug maker's profits have been hurt by the stronger euro. Reiterating its outlook for 2004, Schering expects profit to fall for another year, though it expects the introduction of new drugs to compensate for cuts in public health spending in Germany and Japan. The company also repeated its expectations of doubling annual sales in the United States, currently at $1 billion, by 2006.

title: Toward Order in Haiti
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Win the Battle of Rebuilders
description: The fans at Madison Square Garden, who have been coming up with chants throughout the season, added another one last night in the Rangers' first home game since Brian Leetch was traded to Toronto: ''Go Leafs, go!''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MCGUIRE, MURIEL MARGARET
description: McGUIRE--Muriel Margaret. Dearest Mom, Happy Birthday. 101 hugs and kisses! 101 special memories! Love, Sissy

title: Hidden Cameras Upset Riders and Crew
description: The train doors opened in Hazlet, N.J., on a recent evening, and David Rodriguez stepped inside and found himself a seat. The train resumed its rumble north, and Mr. Rodriguez, a 46-year-old perfume maker on his way home to Belleville, N.J., handed his ticket to a conductor as if it contained winning lottery numbers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHR, RUTH (NEE FRANKFURTER)
description: LEHR--Ruth (nee Frankfurter) age 87. Of New York, N.Y., on March 4, 2004. Wife of the late George M. Dear mother of Nancy L. Lee and the late Barbara Ida. description: A group of Shiite leaders refused to sign Iraq's temporary constitution on Friday unless changes were made that would strengthen Shiite power, throwing the political process here into disarray and posing a major embarrassment for American officials.

title: Turks Breach Wall of Silence on Armenians
description: Taner Akcam doesn't seem like either a hero or a traitor, though he's been called both. A slight, soft-spoken man who chooses his words with care, Mr. Akcam, a Turkish sociologist and historian currently teaching at the University of Minnesota, writes about events that happened nearly a century ago in an empire that no longer exists: the mass killings of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire during World War I. But in a world where history and identity are closely intertwined, where the past infects today's politics, his work, along with that of like-minded Turkish scholars, is breaking new ground.

He is charged with attempted robbery, assault and possession of a weapon, they said, but he is not believed to have acted as the getaway driver.

title: A Banquet of Bel Canto Sound With Its Delicious Vocal Menu

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: The Netherlands: Asian Acquisition
description: ING Groep, the largest Dutch financial company, plans to buy a real estate developer, Rodamco Asia, for about 418 million euros ($510 million) to gain properties in China, South Korea and Thailand. ING Real Estate, based in the Hague, is offering 18 euros a share, 7.1 percent more than Rodamco Asia's closing stock price Thursday, the companies said. ''While we continue to see opportunities for attractive investments in our markets of focus, we haven't been able to seize them fully,'' Rodamco Asia's chief executive, Ton de Boer, said in a statement. Rodamco Asia's properties include apartment complexes in Beijing and Shanghai, and offices and malls in Seoul, Bangkok and Manila.

title: Love, marriage and passports : The pros and cons of taking on your spouse's nationality
description: LONDON  Getting married is a leap into the unknown, more so when half of the couple is marrying a foreign national and contemplating taking the other's citizenship. Expat newlyweds and their spouses must contend with legal, tax and immigration matters in two countries that compatriot couples are unlikely to face, even in just one.

title: World Briefing | Europe: 2003 Summer Was Hottest In 500 Years
description: The heat wave that scorched Europe last summer was part of a three-decade-long warm period on the continent that was ''very likely unprecedented for more than the past 500 years,'' Swiss scientists are reporting in the current issue of the journal Science. Their study also showed that European summers since 1994 were the hottest consecutive string of summers in the same span. The researchers did not speculate on the cause, and other climate experts said the warming was likely to continue. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: FOOTSTAR PLANS TO CLOSE 165 ATHLETIC-SHOE STORES
description: Footstar, an athletic-shoe retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection this week after its business with Kmart faltered, plans to close 165 stores. Footstar will close 88 Just For Feet stores and 77 Footaction stores, which are ''underperforming,'' the company said. Footstar, which is based in West Nyack, N.Y., filed a motion with the court yesterday requesting authorization to hold going-out-of-business sales, said Kimberly Kriger, a spokeswoman for the company.

title: Deputy Chancellor Is Accused of Nepotism
description: Deputy Chancellor Diana Lam, the New York City school system's highest-ranking instructional official, took aggressive steps to get her husband hired by the school system without the required conflict-of-interest clearance, city investigators said yesterday.

title: Stewart's Lawyers Gambled With a Minimal Presentation
description: Lawyers for both sides told jurors that the outcome of the trial of Martha Stewart and Peter E. Baconvoic should turn on which version of events they believed. But in the end, the jurors seem to have heard only one story, that of the prosecution.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: MACEDONIA: PRESIDENT IS BURIED Schools and shops closed, and tens of thousands of people lined the streets of Skopje, the capital, for the state funeral of President Boris Trajkovski, who is credited with ending a conflict between Macedonians and ethnic Albanians and bringing stability to the country. Mr. Trajkovski, 47, died last week in a plane crash in Bosnia. Government officials from more than 60 countries attended. No date has yet been set for an election for a new president. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRAZEN, MARTIN
description: DRAZEN--Martin, 85, formerly of Armonk, NY, passed away after a long illness in Jupiter, FL on March 4, 2004. A graduate of NYU with a Doctor of Laws and a Master of Laws in taxation former Senior Partner of McCarthy, Fingar, Donovan, Drazen & Smith in White Plains, Past President of the Westchester County Bar Association and its former Chairman and Founder of the Section on Taxation and former President of the White Plains Bar Association. Founder and Board Member of the Life Long Learning Society of Florida Atlantic University. Survived by his loving wife and best friend of 61 years Margaret (Paul) Drazen, his devoted daughters and sonin-law, Laurel Drazen and Karen and Martin Berger, his adoring granddaughters Staci Barber, Sueann McCarthy and Ryan Krobath, his two grandsons-in-law John and Peter, and three great grandchildren Morgan, Matthew and Eric. He is also survived by three step-grandchildren and five step-great grandchildren. A great man and a brilliant lawyer, he deeply cherished his family. All will sorely miss his wise, kind and gentle nature. We love you GG Marty. Funeral service Sunday, March 7, 1:30 PM at Temple Beth Am, 2250 Central Blvd, Jupiter. In lieu of flowers, we would be grateful for contributions in his memory to CARE LINK C/O Dr. Rosenberg, 412 Center Street, Jupiter, FL. 33458.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL CLIMBS. Crude oil rose above $37 a barrel for the first time since March 2003. The contract for April delivery jumped 62 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $37.26 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: S.E.C. LOOKS INTO FIRING OF TWO BOEING EMPLOYEES
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had requested information on events leading to the firing of the chief financial officer, Michael Sears, and a United States Air Force official he had hired. The Pentagon is investigating whether the former Air Force official, Darleen Druyun, helped Boeing get favorable terms on a $17 billion deal to lease or sell 100 refueling planes to the Air Force, Boeing said in a regulatory filing. Boeing said Mr. Sears offered Ms. Druyun a job while she was negotiating for the Air Force. Boeing fired them in November. Separately, Boeing said it could face a $310 million charge if the government decides to withdraw its proposal to give the company a $5.3 million contract to lease refueling tankers.

title: Courtroom Tales; Of Martha Stewart's Lies . . .
description: Martha Stewart, the woman who capitalized on her sense of decorum and good taste to build a business empire, is likely to go to jail for lying. Despite some significant overreaching in framing the original charges against her, the trial vindicated the government's decision to prosecute her and her broker. A Manhattan jury convicted Ms. Stewart yesterday of lying to federal prosecutors and of conspiring with her broker, Peter Bacanovic, to obstruct inquiries into why she sold her nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone Systems on Dec. 27, 2001. Ms. Stewart was found guilty on all four counts considered by the jury; her broker, on four of five.

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: INDIANA: CHANGES IN DRUG STUDY AFTER SUICIDE Eli Lilly and Company said it would lengthen the withdrawal period, to eight days from four, for participants in a drug study after the suicide of an Indiana college student who was taking part in the tests. Lilly also required mental-health evaluations of test subjects after the Feb. 7 suicide of the student, 19-year-old Traci Johnson. Some participants complained of sleeplessness, anxiety or nervousness during their withdrawal from duloxetine, a drug being tested in treating depression and urinary incontinence. A coroner's report did not cite the drug as a factor in Ms. Johnson's suicide. (AP)

title: PFIZER SUES TO PREVENT SALES OF GENERIC PAINKILLER
description: Pfizer, the world's biggest drug maker, sued Teva Pharmaceutical Industries to block a generic version of the painkiller Celebrex, the world's top-selling arthritis drug. Teva is seeking Food and Drug Administration approval to sell 100-milligram, 200-milligram and 400-milligram doses of celecoxib, the main ingredient in Pfizer's Celebrex. Celebrex generated $1.88 billion in global sales last year with 23.5 million prescriptions sold. Pfizer contends there are three patents that protect Celebrex from generic competition until June 2015 and that any F.D.A. approval would infringe those patents. Pfizer, which is based in New York, acquired Celebrex in its $60 billion purchase last year of Pharmacia Corporation. The lawsuit, which seeks to block approval until all three patents expire, was filed Feb. 19 in federal court in Newark.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Divided TIgers
description: The Tamil Tigers, among the world's most disciplined guerrilla groups, have acknowledged a rift between their commander in the east and the movement's leaders in the north. The disagreement is over the desire of Colonel Karuna, as the eastern commander is known, for greater autonomy within the organization. The Tigers' political head, S. P. Thamilselvan, described the crisis as ''temporary.'' Amy Waldman (NYT)

The success of the sale lifted the leading Bombay stock market index by 1 percent. Oil and Natural Gas, the country's most valuable and most profitable company, expected to raise about $2.16 billion. In a series of six asset sales, mostly in the energy sector, the government expects to raise about $3.5 billion in a period of three weeks. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: 1478 Assassination Solved. The Humanist Did It.
description: On April 26, 1478, Lorenzo de' Medici (who escaped) and his brother Giuliano (who died) were repeatedly attacked with knives by a gang of men who invaded the Duomo cathedral in Florence during a high Mass. It was part of a plot against the powerful Medici family, de facto rulers in the Florentine republic for hundreds of years. Now a Wesleyan University scholar says he has cracked the 500-year-old case with the help of a recently discovered coded letter.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Volvo Sells Shares In Rival
description: Volvo, Europe's largest truckmaker, sold shares worth $2 billion in a competitor, Scania, partly complying with a European Commission demand. Volvo sold 63.7 million Scania Class B shares to Deutsche Bank ''for placement in the market,'' the truckmaker said. Volvo, based in Gothenburg, Sweden, now holds 27.3 million Class A shares corresponding to almost a quarter of Scania's votes and 13.7 percent of its capital. Volvo has been trying to find a buyer for Scania after a $6.9 billion takeover attempt was blocked by the European Commission four years ago. The commission, the European Union's antitrust regulator, ordered Volvo to get rid of the shares by April 23.

title: METLIFE SAYS S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING SALES OF LIFE INSURANCE
description: MetLife said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating market timing and late trading in variable life insurance sold by its General American unit. MetLife said the agency was examining ''a limited number'' of contracts sold by the division, according to a company report filed with the S.E.C. MetLife said in November that it had been contacted by regulators for information about market timing and late trading of mutual funds and variable life insurance. The company, which is based in New York, said it was not aware of ''systemic problems'' that would have an adverse effect on its finances.

title: LOCKHEED SAYS TITAN IS BEING INVESTIGATED
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that the Justice Department had started a criminal investigation of payments made to foreign officials by the Titan Corporation, the company Lockheed agreed to buy last year. The investigation centers on whether payments were made by consultants for Titan, a maker of military communications equipment, in violation of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, Lockheed said. Lockheed also said it was reviewing whether payments by Titan to its consultants were accurately reflected on the company's books. Titan's shareholders are scheduled to vote on the $1.8 billion sale to Lockheed on March 16. The Titan and Lockheed internal reviews and federal investigations may not be completed by that date. In that case, Lockheed would have to decide if conditions of the purchase agreement were met.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Review Board For Prison System
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, saying he was ''gravely concerned'' about the state's brutal and crowded prisons , appointed an independent review board to recommend a sweeping overhaul. Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, named as chairman George Deukmejian, a former Republican governor and state attorney general, who oversaw a boom in prison construction during the 1980's. The panel will include Joseph Gunn, the former executive director of the Los Angeles Board of Police Commissioners, and George Camp, a former assistant commissioner of the New York City Department of Corrections. The panel, which is to report its findings by the end of June, will look at issues including aging buildings, endemic violence, high rates of recidivism, poor medical and educational programs and a reported ''code of silence'' among prison guards regarding abusive treatment of inmates. John M. Broder (NYT)

title: He Harms/She Harms: A Distinction With Real Difference
description: When David Williams, a psychologist at the University of Westminster in London, was deciding how to construct a pain machine, he realized a kitchen scale would do the trick. title: Washington: Some Of My Favorite Things
description: Whether in London, New York or Los Angeles, negative reactions to Washington are common: it's a one-horse town; it's a dangerous town; it's a boring town; it's a town, not a city. Even its citizens complain of it -- it's the sort of place where everyone affects to have landed by sheer accident -- although, in the wake of Sept. 11, a groundswell of affection and solidarity has arisen, a desire to defend the city, not just physically, but in emotional defiance of its cynical detractors. The inhabitants have come to remember that it is a city with its beauties (the cherry blossoms, in spring, around the reflecting pool; or the late sunlight upon the marble monuments) and its privileges (almost all the museums are free; the spectacle of politics is always near at hand), with amusements all its own. (Even the taxicabs are entertaining in their way: the supremely illogical zone system, which, instead of using meters, divides the city into payment sectors designed to make the politicians' commute cheap; the disconcerting oddity of multiple customers with multiple destinations, crammed into a single cab; and the eccentricity of the drivers, whose knowledge of the city may be tenuous at best, but whose interest in global politics is often passionate and voluble.)

title: A Prettier Jobs Picture?
description: Virginia Postrel suggests that job growth in boutique cottage industries like day spas and graphic design may offset the enormous losses from manufacturing work going overseas (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 22). But not all jobs are created equal. Working in a unionized factory with good pay, affordable health care and a pension is not the same as giving facials for $7 an hour without benefits or job security. Sure, manicurists and others should be counted in national job figures. But we should also be clear that the jobs created in these areas generally don't pay enough or provide the kind of benefits needed to raise a family. The debate about manufacturing job loss isn't just about numbers; it's about quality too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASEY, JOHN L. JR.
description: CASEY--John L. Jr., author of business ethics and managing director of the investment firm Scudder, Stevens & Clark, died on February 9, 2004 at 80. Born in Medford, MA, the son of Ruth Jones Casey and John Louis Casey, Sr., Jack graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School, served in the US Navy during World War II, and became Chairman of Youth for Eisenhower. He spent over 30 years at Scudder, went on to publish two books on business ethics, titled ''Ethics in the Financial Marketplace'', and ''Values Added'', and became the first Executive Fellow at the Bentley College Center for Business Ethics. Jack also served as president and chairman of the board of trustees at Saint David's School in New York. Married for 42 years to the late Marilyn Fuller Casey, Jack is survived by three sons, John Milton Casey, Charles Frederic Casey and Edward Canfield Casey. He loved his family, playing his clarinet, and sailing, and had an eternally positive outlook on life. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas More Church in New York on March 16, 2004 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John L. Casey Jr. Scholarship at The Bentley College Center for Business Ethics (781.891.2981).

title: Motel of the Mysteries
description: Scattered clues situate Judson Mitcham's slender second novel in the mid-1990's, but SABBATH CREEK (University of Georgia, $22.95) is a transcendent coming-of-age story that feels unshackled to any particular time. Its sense of place, however, is pungently particular, infused with the surface languor and latent violence of the Deep South. Prompted by a black eye from her alcoholic husband, Charlene Pope embarks with her son, Lewis, on a road trip through southern Georgia, until their broken-down car forces them to establish temporary residence in the tiny town of Sabbath Creek. There, they become the sole guests in a motel run by a startlingly spry 93-year-old black man named Truman Stroud, whose scowls and gripes poorly disguise a playful prankishness. Thirteen-year-old Lewis, our sensitive narrator, spends his days ruminating, practicing his pitching technique and listening to Stroud's dubious yarns, as well as the old man's more reliable reminiscences of Jim Crow laws and Negro League baseball heroes. This spare, lovely novel, while generous in humor, is anchored by sorrow and interspersed with portents of tragedy. Especially poignant are Lewis's flashbacks to the tense dread of living at the whims of an alcoholic father. ''When he was like that,'' Lewis recalls, ''I didn't know how to stand, how to hold my face.'' Lewis observes everything with the alertness of someone who does not yet take common experiences, such as kissing and drunkenness, for granted; he never resorts to shorthand to convey them, but describes them with a scrupulous fidelity to his own perceptions. Rebecca Tuhus-Dubrow

title: Wake-Up Call
description: Startling breakfasts: lying in bed one morning many years ago in a B & B next to Anne Frank's house in Amsterdam, awakened by the owner offering a basket of Boerenkaas, Texelaar and aged Gouda cheeses (no red paraffin here), thick black bread, rich Dutch butter and coffee the shade of bitter chocolate; in a truck stop near Staunton, Va., trying out steak and eggs, which in those pre-Atkins, pro-Pritikin days of the 80's were considered as poisonous as bread and rice are today and discovering the silkiness that all French chefs know eggs (yolks in particular) bring to whatever they touch; a whole, oiled tsipoura (porgy) stuffed with only sprigs of rosemary, grilled on a beach near Mount Olympus in Greece; the first eggs Benedict, resulting in an early crush on hollandaise (not the subtlest of sauces but just about the most accessible), followed by all those insanely delicious egg dishes dreamed up at Brennan's in New Orleans; askew under a duvet with a loved one near an open window in Salzburg, munching gossamer croissants and brioches spread with European butters and jams while a brass band in historic dress marched by below; a finnan haddie at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Boston with a beloved uncle, and years later a chicken hash at ''21'' when, for about a year, the venerable former speakeasy housed a breakfast club; bacon, bacon, bacon wherever and whenever; my first soup bowl of caf au lait at a friend's pad near the Bois de Boulogne in Paris; freshly chunked summer fruits dashed with a mixture of grappa and honey, then huevos rancheros on a hotel balcony in Santa Monica overlooking the Pacific and the negotiation of a mango on a scorching hot morning in Manila looking toward the South China Sea; the comic poignancy of children bringing hard-fried eggs and burned toast as breakfast in bed on Mother's Day and Father's Day; enthralled by a half-dozen circles of dough as they slid into the hot fat, then under the glazer, then down my gullet at the original Krispy Kreme in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: The Nation; Profiling The Picky
description: A few weeks ago, it was fashionable to ignore the swing voter, as the parties rallied their bases. Now, polls show John Kerry, the all-but-certain Democratic nominee, in a dead heat with President Bush, and the undecided voter is suddenly popular again. Below, an early look at the fence riders.

description: Anyone wondering what the Islanders might be shopping for as Tuesday's trade deadline approaches saw their deficiencies on full display Saturday night in a 4-2 loss to the St. Louis Blues.

description: While it was a stomach-churning week for shareholders of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, the stock market turned in modest, steady gains.

description: NEXT door to the State Capitol where a House committee is considering whether the governor should be impeached, 24 bills with the word ''ethics'' in them are being debated. Lawmakers have vowed to begin restoring public confidence in government before this legislative session ends.

title: In Divorce, Property Matters
description: ''A LAWYER'S worst nightmare is walking into a real estate closing and seeing a husband and wife glaring at each other from opposite sides of the closing table,'' said James G. Samson, who is himself a Manhattan real estate lawyer. ''I've had closings where we've had to put the parties into separate rooms. I really hate dealing with divorces.''

title: The Paranoid States of America
description: Picking candidates for the Great American Novel may be a fool's game, but it's hard to resist. Though it's impossible to write a single book that sums up the experience of a nation that is, by definition, a grab bag of people each pursuing his or her own notion of freedom, sometimes a novel so perfectly captures a corner of it you recognize that you want to jump up and shout, ''This is it!'' Stephen Wright's undersung ''M31: A Family Romance'' is that sort of book. ''Unsung'' wouldn't be the right word, since the novel was well reviewed when it came out in 1988, but Wright has never quite had the readership he deserves. Perhaps he wavers too much between the standard categories. There may be enough violence, drugs and chaos to put off readers likely to appreciate the beauty and daring of his style, and yet his fiction isn't callow enough to attract the following of a bad-boy cult writer. Also, he's not easy. Starting one of his books feels a little like being jumped the moment you walk into a room: it's disorienting and challenging, with more going on than you can possibly grasp at first.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KELLEN, STEPHEN M.
description: KELLEN--Stephen M. Died on February 11, 2004. A memorial service will be held on Friday, March 26, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th St., at 2 PM. A reception will follow at the cathedral.

title: Life in the Age of Old, Old Age
description: Neither Ruby Landau nor Diana Aharonian could live independently at home if it weren't for the psychological dependence they have created in their children. I find it sad that the world has been deprived of the younger Aharonian's talents as a pianist so that her mother can be maintained in an old age in which she seems to take so little pleasure. If we have raised them right, most of us will not have adult children who are willing to wait on us, hoping for a crumb of praise now and then.

title: A Prettier Jobs Picture?
description: All that optimistic verbiage without one mention of salaries in the new jobs. If outsourced computer engineers or factory workers become manicurists or massage therapists, do their salaries go up or down? Take a guess.

title: Page Two: Feb. 29-March 6; Steroids and the Home-Run Asterisk
description: EVERY time Barry Bonds smashes another baseball over another fence in what has become a procession of historic homers, he ends his trot around the bases by pointing to the sky. But this season, there are already countless fingers, fairly or unfairly, pointed at him.

title: Designs Kept for Posterity (And Maybe Later, Cash)
description: TOM FORD and the house of Yves Saint Laurent parted ways today, and so Mr. Ford, whose contract expired this month, joined a handful of other designers -- Michael Kors of Celine among them -- who seemed to take their cues from Carrie Bradshaw in the finale of ''Sex and the City,'' bidding Paris a bittersweet adieu. Leaving the fashion houses their names are linked to may leave their future uncertain, but one thing is sure: Their exit will ratchet up the value of their past designs, retailers say, ensuring their status as collectibles.

title: Giving Coleus Their Chance to Shine
description: LAST year, I became a coleus convert. Walking up a gentle incline to an ornamentals exhibition at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx one day in September, I rounded a corner by the garden cafe to confront a blanket of coleus foliage -- oranges, reds, yellows, purples, maroons, pinks, crimsons, chartreuses and creamy whites. Rather than being jumbled together, as they have since Victorian times, these coleus were grouped by color to form distinctive swirls. I was smitten on the spot.

title: A Place Where Burgers Are the Draw
description: THE Blazer Pub, a long established, low-frills hamburger roadhouse on Route 22 here, takes its name from the Galway Blazers, an elite fox-hunting club in western Ireland. Lore has it that the first of these Irish equestrians would carouse after the hunt in a shed, then burn it to the ground. In the case of the Blazer Pub, known for its juicy, globe-shaped burgers and hand-cut French fries, one can only believe that the erstwhile pyromaniacs would have left it standing.

title: If You Don't Like Your Daughter's Boyfriend
description: IF you can stand the wait, Act II of ''Emil,'' Benjamin Bettenbender's new romantic comedy making its debut at New Jersey Repertory Company under SuzAnne Barabas's direction, is full of genuine laughter.

title: Timely Hymns to a Timeless City
description: IN Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, the transformation to a free market can practically be measured in days. Thirteen years after the end of the Soviet Union, high-end boutiques, fancy foreign restaurants and Internet cafes are among the more obvious signs of change. But these novelties are superficial. Just as the Soviet era failed to homogenize Yerevan -- which, at 2,700 years, is one of the oldest cities on earth -- the forces of the free market will have a tough time remaking it.

title: Alec Baldwin, Restrained
description: A FEW weeks ago, Alec Baldwin was pacing around a dingy rehearsal space near the Empire State Building, his cell phone pressed to his ear. Mr. Baldwin was using a lunch break from his six-day-a-week rehearsal schedule for the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Twentieth Century,'' the 1932 screwball comedy now in previews, to go over the details of a court case. As he went from room to room, each time closing the door behind him, he grew increasingly worked up, speaking louder and louder until he was almost yelling and it was impossible not to hear his words.

title: Highlighting the Need For Firefighting Aid
description: The large ''Thank You'' sign from the Armonk Volunteer Fire Department was placed on the construction site to acknowledge the 70 percent of voters who said yes to the need for an updated facility to protect their community. The article, ''Outgrowing the Red Suspenders,'' Feb. 29, 2004, however, highlighted the ''not in my backyard'' contingent and confused the issue of changes in firefighting by providing a platform for those opposed to other pending tax referendums.

So let us spare a thought (or, if you like, a prayer) for an even more fragile institution: the rock 'n' roll band. Everybody's heard the factoid that 50 percent of all marriages end in divorce, but with rock bands, the percentage seems closer to 100: sooner or later, just about every band splits up.
