The wheelchair, at just three years old, was almost as battered as a trash truck. But it will have to last as long as Ms. Blair does. She does not have the money to replace it.

As the train chugged slowly along the Oregon shore of the Columbia River from Portland to the Pacific Ocean, I sat across from a two-foot-tall stuffed bear decked out in a coonskin cap, a miniature buckskin suit and tiny circular moccasins tied to his lower paws. On his back he carried a knapsack holding a small bedroll, a journal and a letter of introduction.

As ''The Passion of the Christ'' approached the $100 million mark, the star appeared on ''The Tonight Show,'' where Jay Leno asked if he would forgive me. ''Absolutely,'' he responded, adding that his dispute with me was ''not personal.'' Then he waxed philosophical: ''You try to perform an act of love even for those who persecute you, and I think that's the message of the film.''

My body gets me up early in the morning, and by the time darkness falls I'm starting to lose consciousness, fast. All the corners of the night, therefore, everything associated with the sleeping world, is as foreign to me as Antarctica. In my regular life I know the time so well that I can usually tell the hour to the minute without looking at my watch.

title: Wynton Marsalis Simplifies Matters
description: IN all outward signs, Wynton Marsalis's new album, ''The Magic Hour,'' represents a change in his career. It's on a new label: last year, Mr. Marsalis signed with Blue Note after more than 20 years and 30 jazz records with Columbia/Sony. It also presents a new band, at least new to most listeners, who are used to the septet he has played with for more than a decade. But most strikingly, it is a statement about simplicity, a virtue that has often escaped him.

title: The Birth of Venus
description: Looking back now, I see it more as an act of pride than kindness that my father brought the young painter back with him from the North that spring. The chapel in our palazzo had recently been completed, and for some months he had been searching for the right pair of hands to execute the altar frescoes. It wasn't as if Florence didn't have artists enough of her own. The city was filled with the smell of paint and the scratch of ink on the contracts. There were times when you couldn't walk the streets for fear of falling into some pit or mire left by constant building. Anyone and everyone who had the money was eager to celebrate God and the Republic by creating opportunities for art. What I hear described even now as a golden age was then simply the fashion of the day. But I was young then and, like so many others, dazzled by the feast.

title: 'Europe Central'
description: William T. Vollmann's 12th book of fiction, ''Europe Central'' -- almost a novel in stories -- is his most welcoming work, possibly his best book. Vollmann has often been an off-putting writer, sometimes intentionally so. There is the seamy (and admittedly autobiographical) subject matter -- living with prostitutes, using drugs -- of too many early works, and also of his novel ''The Royal Family'' (2000). There is the remote North American history of the four published novels in his ''Seven Dreams'' series. And, of course, there is his vaunting ambition: since 1987 Vollmann has released 14 books, 20 if one counts as separate works the seven volumes of ''Rising Up and Rising Down'' (2003), his valiant attempt to comprehend worldwide violence.

description: SCHEERER--Gladys Knight, March 4, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Paul R. Scheerer died at her home on Jupiter Island, Hobe Sound, FL. She was 103 years old. Mrs. Scheerer was the mother of Lynda T. Stokes, Of Gulfstream, FL and East Hampton, NY; Mary S. Babcock of Stanfordville, NY and Hobe Sound, FL; and Paul R. Scheerer Jr, of East Hampton, NY. Born in Scranton, PA, August 18, 1900, she leaves twelve grandchildren: John B. Babcock, Jr, Linda B. Wilson, Joanne B. Wilmerding, Frederick H. Babcock, Mary H. Scheerer, Jill Scheerer, Wendy S. FItzpatrick, Paul R. Scheerer III, Michael W. Tiernan. W. Scott Tiernan, Ann P. Tiernan and Martha T. Ely, and one step-granddaughter Sandra Thomas. Her great grandchildren, who affectionately called her ''Contessa,'' total 24, plus two step-greatgrandchildren. A person of tremendous energy, in her early years she was active in volunteer work. During WWII she established and personally manned an officers' club, after which she helped found the antique store Linlo House. She also was an early contributor to the establishment of Planned Parenthood. In golf she was a low handicapper and was one of the first women's champions of both the Seminole Golf Club and of the Essex County Club in New Jersey. Besides Florida, she formerly had homes in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, NJ and East Hampton, Long Island, NY. Her husband, Paul R. Scheerer, was president of the Alderney Dairy Co, and director of several companies including the Fidelity Union Trust and Chubb & Sons Insurance. Funeral service will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asks you to give to your favorite charity.

title: THAT WOMAN: REBECCA WEST REMEMBERS
description: IN 1947, Time magazine referred to the British writer Rebecca West as ''indisputably the world's No. 1 woman writer.'' Seven years later, the critic Kenneth Tynan called her ''the best journalist alive.'' Today, West, who was born in South London in 1892 and died in 1983, is a relative unknown, especially compared to a contemporary like Virginia Woolf. Part of the reason might be that the diversity of her writings has made her legacy difficult to categorize. She was a critic, novelist, essayist, playwright, poet, biographer, political reporter and a magnificent letter writer. Her greatest work, ''Black Lamb and Grey Falcon,'' is an epic mix of personal history, travel writing and political journalism about Yugoslavia; the book drew new attention in the early 1990's during the Yugoslav wars.

title: As Shocks Replace Police Bullets, Deaths Drop but Questions Arise
description: The police here have had their share of high-profile violent or deadly run-ins with protesters, mentally ill suspects and other lawbreakers. But in 2003, for the first time in 15 years, no one here was shot and killed by the police.

title: Hope and Clarity
description: As a breast cancer survivor, I have found over the years that it is not the optimists or the pessimists who thrive in the face of ill health -- it is the realists. These are the people who allow themselves a good cry when things are bad and rejoice when they are good. And they understand that even with optimism or pessimism, illness or good health, that we all eventually run out of road.

title: The Apex DVD Player
description: When we talk about ''aspirational'' shopping, we tend to mean the process of buying slightly above our true stations in life -- using consumption to get a little piece of luxury or pleasure. But these are not the only values that motivate us as shoppers. For instance, everybody loves a bargain. Bargain culture, says Sharon Zukin, a sociology professor and the author of ''Point of Purchase,'' a book about shopping and America, is based on ''a kind of aspirational shopping for the lowest price, rather than the highest status.''

title: When These Friends Get Together, the Talk Is Rarely Small
description: Every weekday at noon, a group of eminent scientists gathers for lunch at a round table in the middle of the dining room of the Athenaeum, the slightly musty faculty club at the California Institute of Technology.

title: Art Throb
description: These days, people like to say, art collecting is ''event driven.'' More and more, collectors aren't content simply to take in a gallery show, glide discreetly into the back room and buy something. Now they want an occasion -- buzz, options, competition, witnesses. They want their consumption to be conspicuous, to see and, more important, be seen, caught in the act of collecting at one of the chic art fairs held annually in places like Paris, Berlin, Basel, London and, more recently, Miami, where these photographs were taken.

title: Sports of The Times; Maris Did Not Need Performance Enhanced
description: WAS it all ''Bulk Fiction''? That delirious moment when Mark McGwire wrapped his 19-inch biceps around No. 62 and almost hopscotched to first base on his joy ride to history in 1998.

title: Correspondence/The Blackmun Papers; At a Shrine of American Documents, Pathos, Poetry and Blackmun's 'Rosebud'
description: DURING the six weeks I spent reading Justice Harry A. Blackmun's collected papers in the Library of Congress, I often felt that I had left the familiar surface of the earth and plunged down a rabbit hole into a separate world.

title: Investing; The Bulls Are Back. The Brokers Are Wary.
description: WHEN Don Logvin met with his financial planner in October, he brought along some investment charts that he had created on his home computer. They showed that his stock funds were up 24 percent for the year, while his bond funds, highlighted in red, had returned only about 4 percent.

title: The Week Ahead; TRADE
description: On Wednesday, the government will release the first trade figures for this year, and the biggest question is whether the sliding dollar will help reduce the deficit --$489.4 billion, which represents 5 percent of the gross domestic product.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, YVONNE
description: EPSTEIN--Yvonne. Beloved wife of Seymour. Adored mother of Cynthia and grandmother of Laurel. Dear friend of Janice.

title: The Heartfelt Mass of a Humanist
description: THE hope Beethoven inscribed on the manuscript of his ''Missa Solemnis'' -- ''From the heart -- may it return to the heart!'' -- is at once touchingly simple and vastly bold. Beethoven here places his trust in a direct response from his hearers, even to a work of great length, substance and complexity. But he also dares to bypass all clerical authority in conveying his thoughts on the divine. Instead of being an act of worship, voiced by people together speaking of God in hallowed surroundings, the Mass becomes a text to be considered, even pummeled, for its truth by one person so that others may consider it for themselves. Here he stands, with us, without a church or temple roof above.

title: Got Breath Mints?
description: VINE VALLEY, a cheerful two-year-old Lebanese restaurant at the fast-beating heart of the Middle Eastern community that straddles the border of Paterson and Clifton, has three defining characteristics. The first is the vine, about which more in a minute. The second is garlic. The third is smoke.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the movie theater operator Marcus Loew misidentified his Times Square theater and its exact location. It was the Loew's State, between 45th and 46th Streets, not at 44th. (The Loew's National was in the Bronx.) The article also misidentified a theater with stars on the ceiling recalled by the radio personality Jonathan Schwartz. It was the Loew's 72nd Street, not the 72nd Street Orpheum.

title: 'Jaws,' the Ethos
description: ON that list of stylish films from the 1970's -- ''Shampoo,'' ''The Night Porter,'' ''The Eyes of Laura Mars'' -- that designers cite as inspiration, ''Jaws'' (1975) does not often show up. It may have a place in history as the first A-list B movie and the first summer blockbuster, but as fashion muse it has yet to be exhumed.

title: Zeile's Final Spring Training Is Proving to Be His Hardest
description: These are the days when Todd Zeile misses waking up at 3 a.m. and sticking needles into his little girl's fingertips. The ritual is almost as painful for a doting father as for his diabetic 6-year-old daughter, Hannah. But it hurts more to miss it.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Takeshi Kovacs is back. This is not surprising, since Richard K. Morgan's ferociously readable first novel, ''Altered Carbon,'' introduced Kovacs as a 25th-century mercenary with access to the technology of ''resleeving'' -- downloading a digitally stored personality into a new body whenever the previous ''sleeve'' suffers the indignity of death.

title: Hope and Clarity
description: I am a 41-year-old Stage 4 lung cancer patient who is full of hope and optimism and truly believes that both are contributing to my healing (The Way We Live Now: Abraham Verghese, Feb. 22). I have also seen mountains of sound scientific studies that connect mind, body and healing. To my fellow cancer patients: I hope you don't let this essay bring you down. Follow your hearts and greet each day with love and hope.

title: Foreign Aid
description: The Israeli government partly sponsors Birthright Israel, inviting young Jewish people to travel to the Holy Land. Would my participating in this program be an endorsement of all the policies of the Israeli government? Or may I go and still criticize Israel for what I see as some foolhardy decisions? When politicians take gifts from an interest group, they are indelibly linked to its mission. C. A. Hancock, Coral Springs, Fla.

title: Norval Morris Dies at 80; A Leading Expert on Criminal Justice Systems
description: Norval Morris, long a prominent criminologist at the University of Chicago, former dean of its law school and a strong voice for criminal justice reform, died Feb. 21 in Chicago. He was 80 and lived in the city's Hyde Park neighborhood, near the campus.

title: Teaching the Niceties of Life, Like No Name Calling
description: WITH all the time our children spend being tested and held to strict educational standards and all the whining that goes on about it, a lot of us have forgotten to get in an uproar about something else schools spend an inordinate amount of time on: the new emphasis on character education.

title: Training New Stewards to Care for the World
description: NEAR the beginning of ''Jane Goodall's Return to Gombe,'' we see Dr. Goodall, with her familiar ponytail and serene demeanor, sharing her childhood daydreams with a packed audience of wildlife enthusiasts in Edinburgh.

title: Attention-Getter in West Islip
description: THE BRIDGE in West Islip is as packed as the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on marathon morning. ''Fully booked'' was the reply we received when calling a week ahead for a Saturday night reservation. Our waiter informed us that diners had to call three weeks in advance to get a table for a Saturday night. Even on a slow Tuesday elsewhere, we had to circle the lot before settling for on-the-road parking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRIOR, DONALD L.
description: PRIOR--Donald L. of North Plainfield, NJ, past president of Prior Chemical Corporation, died March 4th. Born July 30, 1914, Mr. Prior grew up in Brooklyn and Scarsdale, NY. He was a graduate of Scarsdale High School and Pratt Institute. He had wide ranging interests and was an avid collector of clocks and other timepieces, kites, knives and recorded music. He is survived by his wife Kathryn, four children, Patricia, Audrey, Peggy, and Thomas; 22 grandchildren and 41 great-grandchildren; his sister and four brothers. Private services were held. Donations may be made to the McCutchen Friends Home in North Plainfield, the National Psoriasis Foundation, or the Fanwood Presbyterian Church

title: In Hanoi, Traffic and History Hum
description: TO cross the street in Hanoi requires nerves of steel, a Buddha's inner calm, or failing that, a stiff drink. Striking out in all three departments on my first walk around Vietnam's capital, I stood at an intersection and waited. Ahead was a torrential river of noisy scooters, weaving bicycles, cars and the occasional creaky, packed bus -- no light, no officer directing traffic, no crosswalk. Five, ten minutes passed, without any break in the flow. Just as I was about to give up, someone gripped my forearm.

title: Fighting the Evil Called Genocide
description: AT a time when public schools are being bombarded with the demands of the No Child Left Behind Act and other mandates, their work in another area -- promoting respect and tolerance -- is sometimes overlooked.

title: Paying the Price For Playing Hooky
description: Not so fast, young truants. Playing hooky is against school rules and, if legislators have their way, it may become illegal and very expensive.

Our hearts and prayers are with her and her family. As his life was a blessing so may his memory be as well. Michael Goldstein, President Matthew Bronfman, Chair Sol Adler, Exec Director

The Assumption of Mary, which the festival commemorates, was declared dogma in 1950; it does not appear in Scripture.

title: Preschool Gives Cancer Children Normalcy
description: BEFORE she went to preschool on a recent morning, Molly Guarton, 2 1/2, stopped at the Schneider Children's Hospital in New Hyde Park for her daily dose of intravenous chemotherapy. A short while later, with a bounce in her step and a gleeful expression on her face, Molly pranced into her classroom at the Morgan Center in Plainview and began whipping up a make-believe meal in the play kitchen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOYD, FRANCES S.
description: BOYD--Frances S., of Islip, New York, passed away at home on March 1 at the age of 84. She was born and raised in Islip and attended Pratt Institute. She utilized her art training during WW II working at Grumman where she lofted new aircraft designs. In later years she was a partner in a home business producing hand - decorated women's hair accessories for department stores in New York City. She and her late husband of 57 years, Richard Boyd, restored an 18th century colonial home in Islip and she was an active member of the Southside Garden Club. She leaves two children, Cathy A. Boyd, of Brooklyn, N.Y., and Richard F. Boyd, Jr., of Madison, CT, along with her daughter-in-law, Maura Boyd, & three grandchildren, David, Annie and Evan Boyd. She also leaves a sister-inlaw, Jean Weill, of Sayville, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to Seatuck Environmental Association, P.O. Box 31, Islip, New York 11751, would be appreciated.

title: How To Keep Them Down On The Farm

Developers are constantly circling.

description: Year Dali 2004 is under way, marking the centennial of the birth of Salvador Dali. The artist who proclaimed "I am Surrealism" would not be disappointed by the roster of exhibitions, performances and conferences honoring him.

Potter, Episcopal bishop of New York, stood resplendent in black robes with velvet mortarboard and purple tassel and implored his audience to honor the memory of the square's noble namesake by emulating ''his freedom from sordid aims and motives.''

title: All in Good Time
description: There's a photograph of me with the family dog, maud, a wire haired terrier who seems to be laughing, Maud sits to my right on the brick stairs leading up to our front door. The house on La Brea Terrace has been rented for a year. It's a snug little place with a front lawn and no backyard, atop La Brea, just a bit into the Hollywood Hills. It is December 7, 1941. In short pants, suspenders, a white short-sleeve shirt, and black high shoes, I look bathed and scrubbed for the Sunday to be. It is morning, perhaps ten. My father, ever the photographer, is taking his time. "No, hold it right there. Hold it. Now. One more." My face does not reflect irritation. That would come years later. In fact, I appear to be happy, smiling in the sunshine, with Maud, the "smartest dog who ever lived"-my mother's view of Maud, always-right there next to me. The smartest dog, the smartest boy-me. The best movie, the most delicious piece of pie, the most succulent pear, the most wonderful, the most beautiful, the most thrilling, the greatest. Katherine Carrington Schwartz, a natural hyperbolist, was also inclined to the malaprop. "My, how time passes so fly." And always that strong clear speaking voice, with a song inside. Katherine had been an ingenue on the Broadway stage. Arthur Schwartz had spotted her in Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein's Music in the Air singing "I've Told Every Little Star" to a young Walter Slezak. My father had attended the opening on election night 1932, a secondary event to FDR's first plurality but not secondary to the composer of "Dancing in the Dark." He sought out the ingenue almost before the curtain went down. I've occasionally imagined him, oh so eager, leaping upon the stage midway through the second act. "Good evening, I'm Arthur Schwartz," he might have said. Katherine, still in character, might have attempted to incorporate him. "Well, hello," she might have replied. "We've all been waiting for you." She might have extended her arm to the rest of the bewildered cast. The orchestra, trying to cover the disruption, would almost certainly have struck up "The Song Is You," a ballad in the score, while Arthur was hustled away by stagehands, his friends and peers Kern and Hammerstein in the back of the theater, burying their faces in their hands.

title: Tired of Being Good Neighbors, Residents Oppose a Group Home
description: To an outsider, the protests over a proposed group home for emotionally disturbed teenagers in the East Bronx neighborhood of Westchester Square might seem out of proportion. After all, only eight teenagers would live there. But residents say they already have more than their share of such places and that a little more is too much.

title: The Virus Underground
description: Clive Thompson's article (Feb. 8) was well written and informative. The representative responses to it (Letters, Feb. 22) seemed to be uniformly negative and included descriptions like ''reckless,'' ''criminal,'' ''Luddite,'' ''arsonists,'' ''extortion'' and ''terrorists'' (word of the decade). In my opinion, these responses all miss the point.

title: Stories of Sneetch, Lessons in Lorax
description: ''THEODOR GEISEL is the subject's real name, but he changed it to Dr. Seuss and found fame,'' rhymed Barbara Raber, principal of Lakeville Elementary School in Great Neck. ''It seems he was quite a creative concoctor, and no, he wasn't really a doctor.''

title: The Governor Formerly Known as an Arena
description: The guest list for Brendan Byrne's 80th birthday party reads like a Who's Who in New Jersey and environs. About 200 revelers, from Thomas H. Kean and James Florio to Yogi Berra, and from Jon Corzine and Hugh Carey to John McPhee, have been invited to Drumthwacket on April Fool's Day. But it's no hoax: April 1 is the former governor's birthday.

title: Athens: An Olympian Metamorphosis
description: Charles Baudelaire wrote that ''No human heart/changes half so fast as the face of a city.'' Although the line refers to 19th-century Paris, it certainly applies to 21st-century Athens as it prepares for this summer's Olympics. The metamorphosis of their capital runs so deep that some citizens question what has happened to the sprawling city's distinctive soul and psyche.

title: An Artistic Bounty From the Australian Wilderness
description: JOHN W. KLUGE bought his first pieces of Aboriginal art in 1988, on commission from artists in Ramingining, a tiny Aboriginal township in the remote northern Australian wilderness known as Arnhem Land. The price was $500,000 for 130 paintings and sculptures.

title: Life in the Age of Old, Old Age
description: The ''happy aberration'' of the Blaylock sisters was a breath of fresh air (Susan Dominus, Feb. 22). I could almost hear the sisters laughing and teasing one another. My own sister (whom I've been bossing around only since the Eisenhower administration) and I had our first good laugh since our mother died several months ago at age 92. She was vigorous until age 88 without medical intervention and then joined the 50 percent of the very elderly who suffer from dementia. The last two years of her life were spent in a nursing home, where despite good intentions and daily attention from us, her quality of life declined rapidly. The larger story here, and the sadder one, is how to promote a good quality of life for those in old, old age who arrive there with physical and mental disabilities. Thanks for a thoughtful article.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAENIKE, JOHN R., MD ''JACK''
description: JAENIKE -- John R., MD ''Jack''. Passed away at age 78 on March 3, 2004. He is survived by his loving wife of 57 years, Betty Jane ''BJ'' (Anderson) Jaenike; children John R. Jaenike, Jr. (Liz) of Rochester, NY, Paul G. Jaenike (Kay) of Morehead City, NC, and Sarah J. Demo (Bill) of Ithaca, NY; brother Richard C. Jaenike of Medina, NY; and grandsons Jeffrey, Kevin, Peter, and David. Jack graduated from Charlotte High School ('42), Hamilton College, and the University of Rochester Medical School ('48). He served in the Naval Medical Corps in the Korean War (1949-1951). He then became Chief Resident in medicine at the University of Rochester. From 1958-1960 he did research on renal function and kidney disease at the NIH in Maryland, which he continued at the University of Rochester. From 1960-1980, he was Professor of Medicine at the University of Rochester. He went on to be Chief of Medicine at Highland Hospital (1980-1990). He won the Doran-Stevens Prize and was elected to the Alpha-OmegaAlpha Society. He was later elected to the Society for Clinical Investigation, an honor society of physician-scientists who translate findings in the laboratory to the advancement of clinical practice. He retired to Fearrington, NC in 1991 and moved to Morehead City, NC in 1996. He moved back to Rochester in 2000. Jack enjoyed tennis, golf, skiing, gardening, fishing,birding, bridge, and, most of all, spending time with his family. He was fun-loving and enjoyed singing by the piano and dancing. He was a very caring and generous man who believed in helping those less fortunate. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer s Association, 435 E. Henrietta Rd., Rochester, NY 14620.

title: Are Peanuts No Longer Enough?
description: NO-FRILLS efficiency, cheap seats and a few laughs thrown in. That has always been the hallmark of Southwest Airlines, whose flight attendants still entertain passengers by telling jokes on board. For its first three decades, that formula propelled it to consistent profitability, even as bigger airlines stumbled and smaller ones sputtered and spun out of business.

title: Last Game Gives Stanford First Taste of Defeat

title: Jesus as Box-Office Superhero
description: WHATEVER else you might say about it -- and there is very little, at this point, that has not been said -- ''The Passion of the Christ,'' both as a movie and as a cultural phenomenon, has battered an awful lot of conventional wisdom and wishful thinking, in Hollywood and elsewhere. The notion that an unstintingly violent, purposefully controversial film -- to say nothing of one without a word of English in the script or a major star in the cast -- could become a blockbuster almost defies belief. But ''The Passion,'' helped by the synergy between Mel Gibson's shrewd media-baiting and the media's eager swallowing of the bait, will in all likelihood, by the time you read this, have surpassed ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'' as the highest-grossing foreign-language film ever released in the United States. On its opening day -- Ash Wednesday -- it came close to earning back its reported $30 million production costs, and by the end of its first weekend had easily passed the $125 million mark. Those are superhero numbers.

The particularity of a Parisian boulevard or a New York street corner is being eroded, he argues, by phone-clutching pseudo-citizens who pretend to inhabit an urban space but are in reality mere nodes on a cellular network.

title: Rat Tales
description: Robert Sullivan (Feb. 22) does not mention one of the best New York rat tales, by one of New York's best tale tellers. Joseph Mitchell, in a 1944 New Yorker article, ''Thirty-Two Rats From Casablanca,'' told the story of a tramp freighter from wartime Casablanca -- the Wyoming -- that evaded rat-control inspection using fraudulent certificates. After the ship visited several docks, it was fumigated, and bubonic-plague-infested rats were discovered aboard. Health inspectors feared that some rats had gotten ashore and would spread their fleas to the local population, potentially infecting the city with the Black Death. A secret emergency program of rat-trapping and rodent autopsies was imposed for four months, before frightened health officials concluded that they had dodged a bullet, and ''the Wyoming matter'' was quietly closed.

Mrs. Grunebaum was born Gabriele Neumann in Cottbus, Germany, in 1910. She earned her law degree in Berlin before fleeing Germany with her late husband Erich in 1938. After settling in Scarsdale, Mrs. Grunebaum earned a masters degree in social work from Adelphi University and was a founder of Camp Shalom, a summer program for underprivileged New York City kids based at Congregation Habonim. Mrs. Grunebaum served for many years as the Vice President of the Okiyoe Society of New York. A resident of Dobbs Ferry for 27 years, she was a member of the Historical Society, the Friends of the Croton Aqueduct, and the Hudson River Museum. She is survived by her three children, Ernest Michael Grunebaum of Pound Ridge, NY, Dr. E. Irene Koppel of Springfield, NJ, and David F. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Survey On Preparedness
description: Though most New Yorkers say they think creating an emergency preparedness plan for themselves is important, 74 percent of them acknowledge that they have not done so, according to a survey by the American Red Cross in Greater New York. Eighty-three percent of residents and 64 percent of small-business leaders say they would be interested in receiving emergency training, according to the survey. The poll was conducted from Feb. 23-27 and included telephone interviews with 602 New York City residents and 204 small-business leaders in the city, the Red Cross said. A majority of people in both groups cited lack of time and money as obstacles to preparing a plan, and 73 percent said they did not know how to develop a plan. The poll for residents has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percent, and for the business leaders it is 7 percent. The Red Cross offers preparedness classes in Manhattan for New York residents, and said it planned to hold a class for businesses. The city's Office of Emergency Management publishes ''Ready New York: A Household Preparedness Guide,'' which is available online at nyc.gov/html/oem/home.html. Vicki Vila (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: $1,000 Stolen From Synagogue
description: A man stole $1,000 yesterday afternoon from a cash box at the Jewish Center, a synagogue on West 86th Street, a synagogue official said. Witnesses at the scene said they saw a man wearing a knapsack take the money from a cardboard cash box and run down 86th Street. Families who were celebrating Purim in the building at the time refused to let the incident spoil their holiday. ''Nobody was hurt, and a poor person got the money,'' said Nathan Lowe, 43, who attended the celebrations with his wife and six children. Giving money to the poor, Mr. Lowe explained, is one of the traditions of Purim, which celebrates the foiling of a plot to destroy the Jews in ancient Persia. Other traditions include dressing up and playing games, as dozens of children were doing at the synagogue yesterday afternoon. ''We fulfilled the commandment but not in the way we expected,'' said Mr. Lowe, as he clutched a pink tutu that had been worn by one of his children. ''We would have preferred to give the money to many poor people.'' Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Downsize That Order!
description: There must be, somewhere deep within our prehistoric selves, an urge to eat all we can whenever we can -- to gorge in the almost certain knowledge that the next feast may be days or weeks or even months away. You don't just walk off, half-full, after felling a woolly mammoth, an occasion that was surely the inspiration for the $3.99 buffet. But like a lot of prehistoric instincts, this is one that causes trouble in the modern world. Eating a great deal less than all you can eat is a very good idea in terms of health and life expectancy. And yet the basis of America's eating habits is that if the food isn't as good as it should be, more of it will make it better. Thus, America's waistline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STONE, SANFORD HERBERT
description: STONE -- Sanford Herbert. Scientist, professor, WWII soldier, loving husband and father, dedicating his life to public service, health and wellbeing of all people, died at home in Mt. Dr. Stone (Sandy), immunologist at NIH for 40 years, and professor for 15 years at Howard University, Washington, DC, was an international leader in cellular immunity research. His seminal adoptive-immune guinea pig model of multiple sclerosis advanced understanding of chronic auto-immune diseases and possible treatments. Sandy enlisted in WWII was NCO Med Tech in a clearing company, served in the liberation of Wobbeline Concentration Camp in Germany, and remained a deeply committed fighter against Fascism. He received his bachelors at CCNY and Doctor of Science, in 1951, at University of Paris, Sorbonne, Pasteur Institute, with very high honorable mention. He leaves bereaved wife Audrey Larack Stone, sons Andrew, Leland and Roger, their wives Barbara and Christine, and three grandchildren. A memorial gathering for Sandy will be held March 14, 2004, in Plaza Room, 777 United Nations Plaza, NYC, at 2:30 pm; reception until 4 pm.

A Gateway 200X notebook will cost as little as $1,400 after a $200 mail-in rebate, Office Depot said yesterday. Office Depot, based in Delray Beach, Fla., also agreed to begin selling a Sony notebook computer. Gateway sells PC's by telephone, on the Internet and at its own unprofitable retail stores, as well as other stores like RadioShacks in Canada. Gateway agreed in January to pay $234.5 million for eMachines, which sells most of its PC's at stores including Best Buy, Circuit City and Wal-Mart. OfficeMax quit selling Gateway computers in 2001. Shares of Gateway, based in Poway, Calif., fell 9 cents, to $5.74. Office Depot shares dropped 35 cents, to $17.47.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Impeachment Backed
description: Talk of trying to impeach President Roh Moo Hyun gained momentum in the National Assembly. The country's second-largest political opposition party, the Millennium Democratic Party, said it planned to submit an impeachment motion to the assembly today. Lawmakers aligned with the larger opposition Grand National Party were divided. Only a simple majority is required to put an impeachment motion to a vote; a two-thirds majority is needed to pass it. Mr. Roh set off the latest clash with his opponents when he said in a televised news conference last month that he wanted to do everything within legal limits to drive votes to the Uri Party, made up of lawmakers supporting him. The National Election Committee warned that Mr. Roh could unfairly prejudice National Assembly elections next month. He has yet to bow to opposition demands that he apologize for the comments. description: Texas Instruments, whose chips powered more than half the mobile phones sold last year, said yesterday that first-quarter sales would reach the high end of its forecasts as demand accelerates for cellphones with advanced features. Revenue for the quarter will rise to $2.84 billion to $2.95 billion, said the company, which is based in Dallas. Earnings will be 19 cents to 22 cents a share. In January, Texas Instruments predicted profit of 16 cents to 22 cents a share on revenue of $2.72 billion to $2.95 billion. Phone makers including Nokia are increasing chip orders as consumers demand new phones that give them access to the Internet or allow them to take and send pictures. This year will be the first that shipments of handsets with color screens will surpass those of phones with monochrome screens, according to the iSuppli Corporation, a market researcher. Revenue from the semiconductor unit will be $2.5 billion to $2.6 billion, Texas Instruments said. Analysts had forecast profit of 19 cents a share on sales of $2.85 billion, the average of 33 estimates in a Thomson Financial survey. The shares rose 9 cents, to $30.69, after adding as much as $1.29 in after-hours trading. In regular trading, shares dropped 87 cents, to $30.60.

title: Vanguard Alters Trading Day
description: The Vanguard Group, the mutual fund company, is lengthening the trading day for index and international funds to give its less affluent clients the same advantages as wealthy customers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Guilty Plea In Fraud Case
description: A Queens man who was arrested in Columbia last year after an international manhunt has pleaded guilty to defrauding several companies out of computer equipment and other goods valued at more than $2 million, according to the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. The man, Rami Hassan, 24, a naturalized citizen originally from Kuwait, was part of a ring that "ripped off blue-chip computer firms" by creating dummy corporations and phony documents to lease or buy equipment with no money down, then sell it to legitimate retailers, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Hassan, who could be sentenced to up to eight years in prison, fled the country in 2001 when he learned that detectives were on his case, leading to an 18-month manhunt. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

description: The prevalence of genital herpes has declined significantly in this country in recent years, federal health officials said here on Monday, but syphilis cases continue to rise.

My wife, Bambi Vincent, and I spend seven months each year traveling the world to film pickpockets and other street thieves who prey on unsuspecting tourists. As a security consultant to business travelers, law enforcement and corporations, I live to expose the latest tricks of scoundrels.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Opens Research Center In Korea
description: Intel, the world's largest maker of computer chips, said yesterday that it set up a research operation in South Korea to develop technologies for products used in wireless technology and the home. The chief technology officer, Patrick P. Gelsinger, signed a preliminary agreement in Seoul to develop technologies with the Electronics and Telecommunications Research Institute, a Korean research organization. Mr. Gelsinger declined to specify the investment amount or financial details. The center will hire 20 people to research technologies for wireless communications and for movies and games, Mr. Gelsinger said. Intel hired K.S. Lee, who formerly worked at the Samsung Electronics Company, to head the research center.

Mohamed El-Moctar, imam of the mosque, the Islamic Center of the South Plains, said the building had been vandalized before but not on such a scale. The Lubbock police and the F.B.I. are investigating. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Annual Trade Hearing Turns Into Political Forum
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  With trade looming as a major issue in the Presidential campaign, the annual, staid Senate hearing on American trade policy became a political forum today, with Democrats pushing issues supported by their presumptive nominee John Kerry and Republicans pleading for strong ammunition for their side.

title: World Briefing | Africa: U.N. Is Hopeful On Refugees
description: The United Nations high commissioner for refugees, Ruud Lubbers, said the end of wars in a number of African nations should lead to a mass migration home of people who have long been languishing in refugee and displacement camps across the continent. He was speaking in Geneva to delegates from 60 countries who agreed to support the return and reintegration of refugees who have fled across national borders and those displaced within their own countries in nine nations. The nine, all recovering from decades of violence and civil war, are Angola, Burundi, Congo, Eritrea, Liberia, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, Somalia and Sudan. ''The resolution of these conflicts could, over the next few years, lead to the voluntary repatriation of up to two million refugees from several African countries and the return of several million more displaced persons,'' Mr. Lubbers said. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: KOS BUYS RIGHTS TO AVENTIS ASTHMA TREATMENT
description: Kos Pharmaceuticals Inc., the maker of the cholesterol drug Advicor, agreed to buy the rights to the asthma treatment Azmacort from Aventis of France for about $200 million to enter the respiratory drug market. The acquisition includes worldwide rights to Azmacort in its current aerosol form and another propellant version being developed, Kos's chief executive, Adrian Adams, said in an interview. The purchase will increase 2004 revenue to as much as $470 million from a previous forecast of $410 million, Kos said. Kos, which is based in Miami, is expanding into new areas, like respiratory treatments, as its cholesterol line ages and faces competition from generic drug makers. The company's only products on the market now are the cholesterol medicine Niaspan and the similar drug Advicor.

description: Deputy Chancellor Diana Lam, the New York City school system's top instructional leader, resigned yesterday, three days after city investigators issued a report saying she tried to get her husband a job in the schools without the required conflict-of-interest clearance.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Stake Sale
description: Troubled by falling sales and big losses, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation plans to sell its stake in the Malaysian carmaker Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional, or Proton, to help raise cash, a Mitsubishi spokesman said. Mitsubishi, which owns 7.9 percent of Proton, is looking to raise money to help offset losses from sharp declines in sales in the United States and Japan, its top markets. Mitsubishi's American sales sank about 25 percent last year. The sale of the stake, which could raise about $100 million, could end a two-decade relationship in which Mitsubishi provided Proton with automotive technologies. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: Federal investigators looking into the capsizing of a water taxi here on Saturday that killed one passenger and left three missing were looking on Monday night at what led to the accident and whether passengers could get to life jackets quickly.

description: At least 92 accusations of rape involving Air Force personnel in the Pacific were reported to military authorities there from 2001 to 2003, according to a new study by the service. The findings, which surprised some top Air Force officials, also singled out serious flaws in the reporting of sexual assault claims and assistance to victims.

description: WOLF--Ephraim, Rabbi, Dr. The Great Neck Synagogue community mourns the loss of our beloved Rabbi Emeritus, Ephraim Wolf. Rabbi Wolf was the founder of the modern orthodox community in Great Neck and served as its leader for more than 30 years. It was his vision that enabled our community and synagogue to grow and prosper. Rabbi Wolf was instrumental in the establishment of the North Shore Hebrew Academy providing a Torah education for the children of Great Neck and neighboring communities. The Great Neck synagogue embodies a sense of family, community, warmth, compassion and friendship. This was Rabbi Wolf's legacy to our community. title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Corvis To Buy Focal For $101 Million
description: The Corvis Corporation, which makes networking hardware and last year expanded into telecommunications services, agreed yesterday to acquire the Focal Communications Corporation for $101 million in stock. Focal, based in Chicago, sells voice and data services, mainly to large corporations. Corvis, based in Columbia, Md., said the acquisition would further support its growth strategy for Broadwing Communications, the telecommunications subsidiary it bought from Cincinnati Bell last year. Corvis makes switching and routing equipment for optical networks. Broadwing, which has an all-optical network, provides services for carriers and large enterprises. Focal emerged from bankruptcy protection last July and had cash and cash equivalents of $24.9 million as of Dec. 31. Corvis has agreed to assume $109 million of Focal's debt. The boards of Corvis and Focal have approved the acquisition, and Corvis expects to complete the deal in late summer. Shares of Corvis rose 11 cents, to $2.04.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: Impeachment Delayed For Court's Ruling
description: Parliament opened formal hearings to impeach President Rolandas Paksas, then promptly adjourned to await a ruling by the Supreme Court on the charges against him. Mr. Paksas's political opponents accuse him of abusing his office by aiding a Russian businessman suspected of ties with Russia's mafia and intelligence services and by releasing classified information related to a state investigation. Next week, the court is expected to begin considering whether his actions violated the Constitution. A final vote on impeachment may not happen before April, on the eve of Lithuania's membership in NATO and the European Union. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: A Village Washes Its Cares Away
description: A 52-year-old man said to have gone 10 years without taking a bath was grabbed by fellow villagers in western Kapenguria, tied up and forcibly given a public bath, the BBC reported on its Web site, citing The Kenya Times. A neighbor said the villagers could no longer stand the man's odor. Joining the crowd that turned out to watch the washing was the local chief.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Economic Growth
description: Thailand's economy posted its fastest growth in the fourth quarter since the Asian financial crisis in 1997, as rising exports and consumer spending offset the effects of bird flu on chicken exports. Gross domestic product grew 7.8 percent compared with the period a year ago, the government reported, resulting in a 6.7 percent expansion for 2003. The government predicts that the economy will grow as much as 8 percent this year. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Nuclear Plant, Closed After Corrosion, Will Reopen
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Monday that it would allow an Ohio company to restart a nuclear plant that has been shut down since early 2002, when technicians discovered that acid used in the cooling water had eaten almost through the lid of the reactor.

title: In an Obese World, Sweet Nothings Add Up
description: How sweet it is. I'm referring to the American diet, replete with sweet foods and drinks, commercially sweetened cereals, sodas, fruit drinks and ''ades,'' ice cream, cake, muffins, cookies and candy, as well as naturally sweet fruits and fruit juices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISHMAN, MARGARET W., (PEGGY) NEE WESTHEIMER

Tishman, who predeceased her by seven weeks. Darling mother of Peggy (Pat) T. Hall, the late David Henry Tishman and the late Virginia (Nina) Alexander. Adored grandmother of Adam and Laurie Bramwell, Margaret and David Doyle, and David and Lauren Alexander. Cherished mother-in-law of Richard Alexander and James Q. Hall. Beloved great-grandmother of Patrick, Christopher and Katharine Doyle. Loving sister-in-law of Robert V. Tishman and Virginia Meyerson. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Mrs. Tishman served as the first president of United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. A graduate of Wellesley College, she served on its Board of Trustees and was past president of its National Development Fund Council. Family will receive at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, at 1076 Madison Ave., on Sunday, March 7, 2004 between 4:00 and 7:00. Funeral services at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 St., on Monday, March 8, 2004, at 11 AM. The Shiva observance will be at the Tishman residence on Monday, March 8, 2004, from 6:00-9:00, and Tuesday, March 9, 2004, from 5:00-8:00. Interment private. Gifts to UJA-Federation, Wellesley College and the charity of your choice would be greatly appreciated.

title: A Marriage Made in History?
description: Both supporters and opponents of same-sex marriage make their case with hypothetical arguments about its social effects and claims about the history of marriage. Unfortunately, we know next to nothing about the first subject, and proponents of same-sex marriage have mischaracterized the second.

title: Ravens Evermore: Secrets of America's Undercover Warriors in Laos
description: During the Vietnam War, the neighboring kingdom of Laos was home to a sideshow with Alice in Wonderland rules. Because Laos was nominally neutral, the outside powers kept their presence secret and fought in part through proxies. The Communist North Vietnamese soldiers camouflaged themselves as members of the local Pathet Lao. The C.I.A. ran a three-way anti-Communist alliance of Americans, Thais (who camouflaged themselves as Laotians) and a guerrilla force of Laotian tribesmen, principally the Hmong.

title: FINANCIAL OFFICER RISES TO CHIEF AT WASTE MANAGEMENT
description: Waste Management Inc., the trash collection company, promoted David P. Steiner to succeed A. Maurice Myers as chief executive. Mr. Myers, 63, who took over in 1999, will be chairman until he retires in November. Mr. Steiner, 43, who had been chief financial officer, will assume the job immediately, the company said. Waste Management, which is based in Houston, also promoted Lawrence O'Donnell III, 46, to president and chief operating officer; he had been an executive vice president.

The ice reminds him of former teammates like Patrick Ewing, who used to endure the ritual every night when Houston arrived in New York in 1996.

description: Paul Taylor's ''Mercuric Tidings'' and ''Runes'' share characteristics like the signature quick, floor-nibbling sideways runs for poised bodies. Like Martha Graham, with whom he performed early in his career, Mr. Taylor uses big male bodies to suggest not only power but a special kind of grace. But the two pieces, performed by the Paul Taylor Dance Company on Thursday night at City Center and being repeated tomorrow, Friday and Saturday, might almost have been created by different choreographers.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: LITHUANIA: IMPEACHMENT DELAYED FOR COURT'S RULING Parliament opened formal hearings to impeach President Rolandas Paksas, then promptly adjourned to await a ruling by the Supreme Court on the charges against him. Mr. Paksas's political opponents accuse him of abusing his office by aiding a Russian businessman suspected of ties with Russia's mafia and intelligence services and by releasing classified information related to a state investigation. Next week, the court is expected to begin considering whether his actions violated the Constitution. A final vote on impeachment may not happen before April, on the eve of Lithuania's membership in NATO and the European Union. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, OREN L.
description: BROWN--Oren L. The Juilliard School mourns the death of Oren Brown, a distinguished member of our voice faculty from 1972-1991. With dignity, erudition and grace, Oren prepared generations of singers for successful participation in the profession. We send our deepest condolences to his family. Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARKHORN, JEAN COOK
description: BARKHORN -- Jean Cook. Died on March 6, after a long struggle with cancer. Born in New York City on April 3, 1931. Raised in New York City and East Hampton, NY. Graduate of Westover School and Vassar College. Professional career of 38 years at Town & Country Magazine, where she was Managing Editor from 1968-1992. Loving and caring wife of the late Henry C. Barkhorn, and spirited and generous step-mother and grandmother to his children, Joan Barkhorn Hass, Henry C. Barkhorn III, and William B. Barkhorn, and grandchildren, Norah and Claire Hass and Eleanor and Philip Barkhorn. Burial in Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, on Tuesday, March 9, at noon. Family and friends are invited to call at the home of her stepson Henry, 1095 Park Avenue, from 47 pm, on Saturday, March 13. A memorial service is planned for June in East Hampton. Contributions in her memory may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital or the East Hampton Library.

title: Minority Issues Gaining New Attention in Suffolk
description: In New York City, the scene would have been as regular as a crosstown traffic jam -- a dozen black and Hispanic government officials gathered around a conference table, discussing issues concerning the minority community.

title: Head of Farm in Bird Flu Outbreak Is Found Dead
description: The chairman of a Japanese poultry company blamed for failing to alert the authorities about an outbreak of avian influenza committed suicide with his wife, as the disease showed signs of spreading in Japan.

title: Elections Board Asks City For an Extra $20 Million
description: The New York City Board of Elections surprised City Council members yesterday with a request for almost $20 million it says it needs to cope with federal voting changes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Rises
description: Lloyds TSB, the British bank, said that net profit for 2003 rose 82 percent, mainly on gains from sales of international operations but underlying profit growth was modest. The bank reported net profit of 3.25 billion ($6 billion), up from 1.79 billion in 2002, but 80 percent of the increase was from asset sales. Without the asset sales, profit grew 5 percent, the bank said. The sale of businesses in Brazil, France and New Zealand and of its emerging-market debt portfolio raised 1.16 billion. The bank said it would maintain its dividend but would not buy back shares.

title: Technology Shares and Other Recent Big Gainers Retreat
description: Stocks fell yesterday, led by technology shares, as investors shifted out of companies that have led the market's rally during the last year.

title: ARTIFICIAL JOINT MAKER TO BUY MAKER OF SPINAL PRODUCTS
description: Biomet Inc., a maker of artificial hips and knees, agreed to buy Interpore International Inc. for about $280 million in cash to expand its line of spinal products. Interpore provides products for spinal surgery and had sales of $67.5 million last year, Biomet said. The offer of $14.50 a share is 18 percent more than Interpore's closing price on Friday. Biomet's shares rose 17 percent yesterday. The purchase will raise Biomet's revenue from spinal products to $200 million, the chief executive, Dane A. Miller, said in a statement. Biomet is based in Warsaw, Ind., and Interpore is based in Irvine, Calif.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Patchogue: Man Killed In Initiation Accident
description: A man was accidentally shot dead last night during an initiation ceremony at a Masonic lodge on Long Island, the police said. The man, identified by the police as William James of Medford, was being inducted into the Fellow Craft Club, a social club within Southside Masonic Lodge No. 493 in Patchogue at 8:40 p.m., according to Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick, commanding officer of the homicide squad for the Suffolk County Police. Mr. James, 47, was shot in the head by another club member, who fired his own gun instead of the designated gun with blanks, Lieutenant Fitzpatrick said. Early today, the police had still not determined whether they would arrest the man who fired the shot, who they said had a license for the gun he used. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT).

title: Italy and Assisted Reproduction
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CONCLUSIONS ON CHOLESTEROL
description: Lowering cholesterol far beyond the levels recommended by most doctors can substantially reduce heart patients' risk of suffering or dying of a heart attack, a study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRIGGS, HENRY LITTLE, JR. ''HARRY''
description: GRIGGS--Henry Little, Jr. ''Harry''. Died March 6, 2004 at age 78. Survived by his loving wife Barbara L. Griggs; children Henry, Elisabeth and Peter Griggs; step-daughters Penny Kjellberg and Pamela Blumberg, brother Thomas S. Griggs, Sr.; grandchildren Cornelia and William Griggs; step-grandchildren Caroline and Jessica Kjellberg. A Yale graduate and World War II veteran, he worked at the Hartford Courant, the Patent Trader and then joined NBC News in 1962, with posts in Washington, London and New York. Visitation 5 to 7 PM and services at 7 PM Wednesday, March 10, at the Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Statoil Names Executive
description: Helge Lund, a 42-year-old executive at an engineering company, was named chief of Statoil, the state oil company. Statoil, which produced 1.1 million barrels of oil a day in 2003, has been without a permanent chief executive since last September when Olav Fjell resigned amid an investigation into accusations that he had authorized improper payments to gain production deals in Iran. Mr. Lund is the chief executive of the engineering and construction group Aker Kvaerner. He will move to Statoil on Aug. 15, Statoil executives said. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: New Hubble Images Show Deepest View of Universe
description: BALTIMORE, March 9  Astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope said Tuesday that they had reached far enough out in space and back in time to be within "a stone's throw" of the Big Bang itself.

title: Flavored Kool Cigarettes Are Attracting Criticism
description: Correction Appended

title: Garcia and Spencer To Talk With Police
description: Karim Garcia lounged by the dugout railing before the first intrasquad game of spring training last week, wearing a strip of tape around his left hand.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: 10 Years For Starting Fire
description: A former firefighter was sentenced to 10 years in prison for starting the largest wildfire in the state's history in 2002. The man, Leonard Gregg, 31, told the authorities that he set the fire in June 2002 to create work for himself. That fire merged with one started by a lost hiker and burned 469,000 acres and hundreds of homes. The hiker was not charged with a crime. Mr. Gregg has also been ordered to pay restitution of $27 million. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Magazine Ad Pages Fall For a Ninth Month
description: Magazine advertising pages declined in February for the ninth consecutive month, according to the Publishers Information Bureau in New York. Ad pages fell 5 percent in February compared with February 2003, after a decline of 0.3 percent in January. For 2004, ad pages are down 2.7 percent compared with the same period in 2003.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: COLOMBIA: REBEL COMMANDER GOES ON TRIAL Ricardo Palmera, the most senior Colombian rebel ever captured, pleaded guilty to a charge of rebellion but said he was innocent of murder and kidnapping as his trial began via an unprecedented video hookup. Mr. Palmera, known as Simon Trinidad, a commander in the largest guerrilla group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, entered his pleas in the two-way link from his maximum-security jail. The authorities said it was too risky to take him from his prison north of Bogota to the courthouse in Valledupar, 430 miles away. "I assume full responsibility for my association with the FARC as an act of rebellion against the state," he told the judges. He denied that he had ordered the kidnapping and murders of the Valledupar mayor and his brother in 1998. He was arrested in neighboring Ecuador in January. (AP)

title: Educating World Leaders
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: McGraw-Hill Cos., New York, the media company, said it had sold J.J. Kenny Drake, a municipal bond broker, to Rafferty Capital Markets LLC, Garden City, N.Y. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Defying Psychiatric Wisdom, These Skeptics Say 'Prove It'
description: They have been called assassins and parasites. They receive hate mail from the proponents of a variety of popular psychotherapies. The president-elect of the American Psychological Association has accused them of being overly devoted to the scientific method.

title: Long Before Oprah, a Celebrity Bared Her Soul
description: A young actress experiences great success early in her career. She begins drinking or using drugs, leading to erratic behavior and lost roles. Then, with the help of family and friends, she realizes the error of her ways and enters rehabilitation. Within two years, she turns her comeback into a best seller, then a made-for-television movie.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Commissioner To Pay Fine
description: The commissioner of New York City's Department of Records and Information Services agreed to pay a $1,000 fine after he acknowledged that he had used department records to conduct genealogy research for private clients, according to a statement released yesterday by the city's Conflict of Interest Board. The commissioner, Brian G. Andersson, previously told the board he was conducting a private business outside of his job. But in the settlement he acknowledged that he had gone against the board's advice when he provided private clients with marriage and birth certificates and photographs from department records. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK -- Niles Eldredge; Bursts of Cornets and Evolution Bring Harmony to Night and Day
description: By his own admission, Dr. Niles Eldredge is a pretty mediocre horn player. Tootling on a cornet in his living room in Ridgewood, N.J., he pumps out a few bars of Bach, then puts down the instrument with a good-natured sigh.

title: On Baseball; Ticket Sales Show Fans Will Forgive and Forget
description: NORMALCY returned to City of Palms Park yesterday; the Yankees were gone, lowering the intensity level in the stands at least as much as the cooler southwest Florida temperature. But even with a Minnesota Twins split squad playing Boston, those stands were full, another demonstration of the Red Sox' record spring exhibition attendance.

title: Lessons From the Stewart Verdict
description: To the Editor:

title: Older of Washington-Area Snipers Is Sentenced to Death
description: AVirginia judge today upheld the recommendation of a jury and sentenced John A. Muhammad to death for his role in the Washington-region sniper attacks that left 10 people dead and terrorized millions of people.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: ARIZONA: 10 YEARS FOR STARTING FIRE A former firefighter was sentenced to 10 years in prison for starting the largest wildfire in the state's history in 2002. The man, Leonard Gregg, 31, told the authorities that he set the fire in June 2002 to create work for himself. That fire merged with one started by a lost hiker and burned 469,000 acres and hundreds of homes. The hiker was not charged with a crime. Mr. Gregg has also been ordered to pay restitution of $27 million. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Colorado Faces New Divide: De-iced Roads vs. Ecosystems
description: Interstate 70 in the Rockies can be at its busiest in winter, when hordes of skiers from around the world join the daily tide of commuters and long-haul truckers climbing the Continental Divide. All of them expect the road to be free of ice. And that is creating an environmental problem that lasts far beyond winter.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the effect that Martha Stewart's guilty verdict may have on her company, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, omitted the identification of a public relations executive who suggested that the company keep the brand name but scuttle the corporate name. He is Robert A. Marston, chief executive of Robert Marston & Associates.

title: The High Cost of Gasoline
description: To the Editor:

title: A Star's Brilliant Tantrum
description: Two years ago, a distant star with the prosaic name V838 Monocerotis flared like a flashbulb to become the brightest star in the Milky Way before fading into obscurity again. Astronomers do not know what caused the eruption, but a new image from the Hubble Space Telescope has revealed that it was not unique.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOFFMAN, FAYE
description: HOFFMAN--Faye. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Alan (Terri) Hoffman and Nina (Robert) Marks. Cherished grandmother of Jessica. Loving sister of Esther Ertrachter. Services private.

title: In Weighing an Impeachment, A Hartford Panel Avoids Rules
description: The 10 state lawmakers charged with considering whether to recommend the impeachment of Gov. John G. Rowland left unresolved the big question of the day:

title: An Appreciation; On Stage and in Life, A Comic Desperation
description: Spalding Gray didn't invent the monologue any more than Bob Dylan invented the folk song. But just as Mr. Dylan loosed on the world all manner of sincerely howling street singers, Mr. Gray opened the stage door for every actor with a penchant for public confession.

title: Cutting Back on Antibiotics
description: To the Editor:

title: Telefnica Buys BellSouth Unit
description: Telefnica of Spain said Monday that it would buy the BellSouth Corporation's remaining Latin American wireless assets in a deal worth $5.85 billion, strengthening the company's position across the region.

title: Up in the Air On Estrogen: Women Under 50
description: Last Wednesday morning, Dr. Jennifer Hays went on a television talk show to explain why a large federal study of estrogen therapy for menopausal women had been stopped.

title: Bard College Student Facing No Charges in Disappearance
description: ABard College student who spent two weeks hiding at a deliveryman's house in the Hamptons while her parents feared her dead will not be charged with any crime, police investigators said Monday.

title: National Briefing | South: Winds Claim Lives
description: At least two people were killed on Sunday night when high winds swept through North and South Carolina. The storm also knocked out power to more than 370,000 people, and 90,000 remained without power yesterday, energy companies said. A Huntersville, N.C., man was killed by a falling tree, and a 13-year-old boy drowned in Lake Greenwood, S.C., after the boat he was in capsized. The winds reached gusts of 66 miles an hour. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, IDA B.
description: GORDON--Ida B. Wife of the late William. Mother of Lenore, the late Jay, Ronnie Zackman and Lance. Grandmother and great grandmother. Friends may call at 15 Senate Place, Larchmont, NY, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 1 and in some copies on Feb. 29 about Daniel J. Boorstin, the author, social historian and former librarian of Congress, referred incompletely to his book ''The Image: Or What Happened to the American Dream.'' It was also known by its paperback title, ''The Image: A Guide to Pseudo-Events in America.''

title: Tackling Two Religious Monuments Back to Back
description: It is widely thought that music critics of some experience -- if not simply jaded -- are all too ready to dismiss a new performance, measuring it against one from the golden past. Matters are not so simple.

title: Repairing a Recall in Venezuela
description: After years of political unrest, including an abortive coup in 2002, last year Venezuelans agreed to resolve their differences through peaceful electoral means. As they struggle over whether there is to be a recall vote, President Hugo Chvez and the opposition parties need to abide by their commitment to democracy.

title: No. 3 Connecticut Hits the Floor With a Thud
description: The Connecticut women's basketball team may be the defending national champion, but for the second straight season the Huskies will not win their conference tournament.

title: Indonesia Cuts Sentence of Cleric Tied to Terror Group
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 9  The Indonesian Supreme Court today reduced the prison sentence of the accused spiritual leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, which has been designated a terrorist organization by the United States.

title: Former Boston Globe Columnist Is Returning, but to a Rival
description: Mike Barnicle, who resigned as a columnist for The Boston Globe in 1998 after failing to credit the comedian George Carlin as the source for a series of jokes in one column and being unable to verify the identities of two cancer patients in another, has been hired as a columnist at The Boston Herald, The Globe's main rival.

title: Focus on Congressional Primaries in Texas
description: The eyes of Texas won't be on the presidential race today, but will be glued to the outcome of a series of Congressional primaries around the state. Well, the eyes of Texans interested in politics, at least.

title: Giants Sign Lions' Green
description: The Giants continued to remake their linebacking corps yesterday, signing Barrett Green, a free agent considered one of the brighter spots in a dismal Detroit defense.

title: Deal Would Limit Increases In Rent at a TriBeCa Complex
description: After months of intense negotiations, the tenants and owner of the Independence Plaza North housing development in TriBeCa announced yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement to protect tenants from escalating rents once the development leaves the Mitchell-Lama program in June.

title: A Poet's Spirit Springs to Life On Death Row; Following a Brutal Crime, A Literary Reputation Grows
description: Stephen Todd Booker, who at 50 has been on death row for more than half his life, was explaining how his imagination kept working without the stimuli that most people take for granted. ''I remember thinking one time -- I'd already been here a while -- and I realized I hadn't seen a star in 12 years,'' he said in an interview at the Union Correctional Institution here. ''And I started to wonder about them, thinking they'd changed or something, and I wrote this poem imagining stars but from the perspective of a bat.''

title: MEMO PAD
description: Three Airlines Join United Express Unit

title: AmSouth Faces Inquiry
description: AmSouth Bancorp, which operates 650 branches in six states in the Southeast, said in a regulatory filing yesterday that it was under investigation by the United States attorney in Mississippi over accusations of a ''fraudulent note scheme.''

title: PARENT OF ORKIN TO BUY SMALLER PEST CONTROL BUSINESS
description: Rollins Inc., owner of Orkin Exterminating, agreed to buy the pest control business of Western Industries for as much as $110 million to add customers in the Northeast. The unit will continue to operate as Western Pest Services, and the transaction is expected to close in the second quarter, Rollins said. Western Pest Services, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., has more than 130,000 customers from New York to Virginia and operations in Georgia and Florida. Orkin, based in Atlanta, has about 1.6 million customers and 400 locations in the United States, Canada and Mexico.

title: Sharp Questions for Tenet as He Faces Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, told a Senate committee today that he had privately intervened on several occasions to correct what he regarded as public misstatements on intelligence by Vice President Dick Cheney and others, and that he would do so again.

title: Our Presidents: Not All Blue Bloods
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Rift in South Korea Widens With Impeachment Motion
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 9  South Korea's two main opposition parties submitted an impeachment motion today to remove President Roh Moo Hyun from office in a dispute over election regulations, widening a rift with his political foes that has plagued his 13 months in office.

title: On Mars, Signs of Water Don't Necessarily Mean Signs of Life
description: Following the news from Mars, people might think it was the story of scientists who cried ''Water!'' over and over.

title: Promises, Promises
description: Despite a string of dismal employment reports, the administration insists that its economic program, which has relied entirely on tax cuts focused on the affluent, will produce big job gains any day now. Should we believe these promises?

title: Equal Chance Of Divorce For All
description: IF same-sex marriage becomes a legal reality in New York, and it may be just a matter of time, will same-sex divorce follow close behind? Do boom times, then, lie ahead for that special breed of New Yorker known as the divorce lawyer?

title: Ratings and Labor Woes Cloud N.H.L.'s TV Talks
description: The National Hockey League's immediate future is uncertain, with the possibility of a work stoppage next season. But one thing is virtually certain: the league will not duplicate its five-year, $600 million deal with ESPN and ABC, which expires after this season.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Kodak To Acquire Heidelberg Printing Unit
description: Heidelberger Druckmaschinen, the world's largest maker of offset printing machines, said it would sell its digital printing operations to the Eastman Kodak Company. Kodak will purchase Heidelberg's 50 percent interest in NexPress Solutions, a Rochester-based joint venture of Kodak and Heidelberg that makes digital color printing systems, and the equity of Heidelberg Digital, a leading maker of digital black-and-white printing systems. Kodak will also acquire NexPress G.m.b.H., Heidelberg's German subsidiary based in Kiel. The purchase price could reach a maximum of $150 million in cash if certain sales goals are met under the terms of the acquisition. Heidelberg also said that it has agreed to transfer its web offset division to Goss International. Financial details of the deal were not disclosed. Shares of Kodak fell 96 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $26.83. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Sheffield May Need Surgery on Thumb
description: Gary Sheffield left Legends Field on Monday morning, bound for New York for an appointment with a hand specialist. Sheffield, the Yankees' right fielder, sounded confident that he would not be limited by his injured right thumb. ''I could play right now if I had to,'' he said. ''It's just a little sore.''

title: Margaret Westheimer Tishman, 84, a Leader in Jewish Charities
description: Margaret Westheimer Tishman, an organizer of the merged UJA-Federation of New York and its first president, died on Friday in Manhattan. She was 84 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: A Musical Gift to Faithful Messengers
description: Some people who review theater for a living were not kind to Elizabeth Swados when ''Missionaries'' played the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1997. They dismissed her musical meditation on the murder of four American churchwomen in El Salvador as earnest and preachy.

title: Accounts
description: Doner, Southfield, Mich., was named agency of record on two accounts. One is Hotels.com, Dallas, part of the InterActive Corporation, which had been handled internally and on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $75 million. The other is Lexmark International, Lexington, Ky., which had been handled by LB Works, Chicago, absorbed last fall by a sibling, Leo Burnett, part of the Publicis Groupe. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Action Vowed In Women's Killings
description: Following a report by Amnesty International that put the number of women murdered over the past decade in Ciudad Jurez at more than 400, President Vicente Fox vowed to get to the bottom of the crimes and punish those responsible. Mexican authorities have said some 260 women had been murdered in the gritty, industrial border city since 1993, including 100 women who appear to be the victims of serial killers. Amnesty International disputed that figure in a report delivered to the government last week. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHEN, CHIN
description: CHEN--Chin, age 76, of Bayside, NY, died on March 5, 2004 after a brief illness. Dr. Chen was a Professor of Marine Biology at Western Connecticut State University until his retirement in 1993. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Church of GraceFujianese NY, 133 Allen St, NY 10002. Service on Wednesday March 10 at Shaffer Funeral Home, 45-09 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck.

title: Pope Names Four Bishops for Church in U.S.
description: ROME, March 9 — Pope John Paul II appointed four new bishops in the United States today and promoted an American professor to head a pontifical academy, making her the church's highest ranking lay woman in an advisory position.

description: Ants to the Right, Please

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITTMAN, MARY
description: LITTMAN--Mary. On March 7, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Mitchell. Loving mother of Charles and Dennis Littman, Francine D'Anna and Susan Carney. Cherished grandmother. Services Tuesday, 11:15AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Inquiry Widens After 2 Arrests In Cadaver Case at U.C.L.A.
description: As police served search warrants on the University of California's Center for Health Sciences here on Monday, looking for evidence in what the authorities said were illegal sales of human remains, university officials began trying to limit the damage.

title: Paul Winfield Is Dead at 62; Known for Film and TV Roles
description: Paul Winfield, an actor known for his versatility and power in stage, film and television roles that included a highly praised televised portrayal of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1978 and an Oscar-nominated part in ''Sounder'' in 1972, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 62.

title: Asbury Park Deputy Mayor Officiates at a Gay Marriage
description: The movement for same-sex marriages reached New Jersey yesterday when a gay couple who had been issued a marriage license by the city clerk's office were married in Asbury Park by the deputy mayor.

title: A Cultural History Faces Stringent Smoking Laws
description: Of the roughly 20 hookah bars in New York City, about half are clustered along a short stretch of Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, known as Little Egypt. Here in the hazy cafes, owned mostly by Egyptian immigrants, men smoke fruit-flavored tobacco called shisha through water pipes called hookahs as they banter in Arabic, play chess or backgammon, or simply pass the day in a fragrant fog.
