title: The Privatization of Stem Cells
description: The Bush administration's limits on federal financing for embryonic stem cell research are turning out to be a lot more restrictive than originally advertised. Only a minority of the stem cell lines that the president implied might become available under his policy have actually panned out. Thus it was extremely good news when Harvard researchers, supported by private funds, said they had produced and would freely share some 17 new embryonic stem cell lines, doubling the number available. Private and state funds may need to pick up the slack if this promising field of research is to expand in coming years.

title: Soprano Says Her Weight Cost Her Role In London
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Meriden: No Retrial For Woman In Son's Death
description: A woman who was convicted last year of risking injury to a minor after her 12-year-old son committed suicide is not entitled to a new trial or acquittal, a judge ruled Monday. In October, a lawyer for the woman, Judith Scruggs, complained that comments made by one juror, Vincent Giardina, after the verdict were grounds for a mistrial. He had been quoted in newspaper articles saying that he supported the verdict in part because he did not want to see her sue the City of Meriden and profit from the death of her son, J. Daniel, who hanged himself in January 2002. Mr. Giardina denied making the comments. The judge, Stephen F. Frazzini of Superior Court, noted that the boy had been the victim of incessant bullying at school. The boy's mother was convicted for having a chaotic and filthy home that endangered the boy further. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Norway: Overspending Minister Resigns
description: The minister of labor, Victor D. Norman, who tried to soften up Norway's rigid workplace rules but lost credibility by charging lavish meals, airline tickets and even a piano to his expense account, resigned. Mr. Norman said he would return to his previous post as head of the Norwegian School of Economics and Business Administration. He denied that the controversy over his spending had anything to do with his resignation. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

title: Iraq Council, With Reluctant Shiites, Signs Charter
description: Iraq's leaders signed an interim constitution on Monday and agreed to embark on a common path toward democratic rule, but the celebratory mood was dampened by calls from the country's most powerful Shiite leaders to amend the new charter before it goes into force.

description: The competitive spirit that permeates children's lives from sports to spelling bees to cheerleading is no stranger to the dance world, creating a growing market for dance competitions.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Groups Seek Ouster Of Education Secretary
description: Two organizations critical of the Bush administration have posted a petition online urging the president to fire Education Secretary Rod Paige, who recently said the country's biggest teachers' union, the National Education Association, was like a ''terrorist organization'' for its opposition to the No Child Left Behind law. The groups, MoveOn.org and Campaign for America's Future, said they hoped to gather 50,000 to 100,000 electronic signatures. Dr. Paige has apologized for the remark, and Susan Aspey, his spokeswoman, said, ''This isn't about politics; it's about kids being able to read and do math on grade level.'' Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: Inmate Returns to Stardom, This Time Posthumously

That would make him just another statistic to most of us. But in 1981 he became a literary celebrity by publishing ''In the Belly of the Beast: Letters From Prison.''

description: The personal trainer for Barry Bonds, Greg Anderson, who is charged with drug and steroid conspiracy charges, would seek a plea bargain in an effort to keep Bonds and other top athletes from appearing as witnesses in a federal trial, Anderson's lawyer said Monday.

title: When the Games Began: Olympic Archaeology
description: Opening day of the ancient Greek games was a spectacle to behold, a celebration of the vigor and supercharged competitiveness that infused the creative spirit of one of antiquity's most transforming civilizations.

description: Citing budgetary concerns, the Bush administration has proposed new toxic waste sites for the Superfund program at a much slower rate than previous administrations, a practice criticized by state environmental officials who say it masks the true demand for cleanup in the country.

description: Clint Mathis probably wishes he was a bit more attentive in his German language classes when he was in high school in Conyers, Ga.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEMLICH, MAISIE NEE SCHEVELENKO
description: LEMLICH -- Maisie nee Schevelenko. Born in New York City, died on March 6, 2004, at age 95. Beloved daughter of the late Minnie and Louis. Devoted and beloved wife of the late Stanley Lemlich for over 50 years. She is predeceased by her dear daughter-in-law Betty Gladys. Our beloved matriarch, she is survived by a family she adored including her sister, Dora Gurary, son Arthur Lemlich, M.D., granddaughters Gabrielle Lemlich, M.D. (Steven Cagen, M.D.), Giselle Vargas (Sergio), and Claudia Lemlich, great grandchildren Katherine and Brent Cagen, and Marielle and Michael Vargas, niece Fanya Shatrovatoya (Misha) and grandnieces Inna Suslik and Stella Gozina and their families. Maisie Lemlich touched all of our hearts and will continue to be an unforgettable source of strength and inspiration to all who knew her. Services, Monday, March 8, 2004 at 1:00 P.M., at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan. Donations to Hadassah or Red Magen David.

title: Three Marketers Make Changes in Accounts
description: Three large marketers are making changes.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Chile; Argentine Retailer Acquired
description: A Chilean retailer, Cencosud, said it had reached an agreement with Royal Ahold, the Dutch retailer, to buy its Argentine chain, Supermercados Disco. Cencosud, which bought Ahold's Chilean interests last year, and three investment partners -- Capital International, AIG Capital Partners and the International Finance Corporation -- will pay $315 million for the chain. Cencosud will own 62 percent and its partners will take the rest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMAN, EDITH
description: SELIGMAN--Edith. We are deeply saddened by the untimely and tragic death of Edith. She was a very good friend and we will miss her terribly. No bridge game will ever be the same to us. Miriam Kaplan Estelle Florence

title: In Seattle, a Legal Challenge to Marriage Laws
description: The gay marriage debate rippled into Washington State on Monday, as six same-sex couples filed a lawsuit challenging the state's Defense of Marriage Act and the Seattle mayor said the city would now recognize gay marriages forged elsewhere.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Classified Ad Concern Acquired
description: The Telstra Corporation, the country's biggest phone company, has agreed to pay 636 million Australian dollars ($484 million) for the Australian unit of Trader Classified Media to increase its share of the country's classified advertising market. Telstra expects the purchase of the unit, the Trading Post Group, to increase market share of its Sensis classified advertising unit to 15 percent from 13 percent. Telstra is seeking acquisitions to increase growth amid rising competition. The chief executive, Zigmund Switkowski, acknowledged that the company paid a high price for the business but said the acquisition was a crucial part of Telstra's growth strategy.

title: Thawed Ovary Tissue Yields Healthy Embryo
description: For a 30-year-old with breast cancer, the outlook was harsh. Though chemotherapy might cure her, it would almost certainly damage her ovaries and leave her unable to have children.

title: Run or Hide, Smoke Still Lingers
description: Sneaking off to the kitchen for a cigarette or puffing away on the back porch is not enough to protect other household members from secondhand smoke, researchers have found.

title: N.C.A.A. Trip Is Set in Motion For Manhattan
description: Around Manhattan College, they call him Hurricane Bobby. And, as usual, Jaspers Coach Bobby Gonzalez spent Monday night's Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament final as a blur of motion.

title: The High Cost of Gasoline
description: To the Editor:

title: Spot the Sane One Among the Kooks
description: The naif must be marooned in the house of horrors. He or she must be book smart but enchantable, a figure vulnerable to being dazzled, menaced and finally corrupted -- or saved by -- the grotesques in the house. Those characters can be drawn freely and fast, and they may be primarily visual (a missing hand, a set of fangs). But the naif must be subtly made and can't be a fool, because it is this unassuming creature in whose eyes Thornfield Hall or Carfax Abbey or Cold Comfort Farm will come to life. An author errs who loves his freaks too much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, GLORIA G.
description: FEINBERG--Gloria G. Brilliant, charming, generous, with rapier wit. Phi Beta Kappa, University of Pennsylvania. President of BFS Psychological, an international consulting organization. Pioneer in the Rorschach application for corporate executive selection. Survived by her loving family, husband Dr. Mortimer Feinberg, sons Dr. Todd Feinberg, and Dr. Stuart Feinberg, daughter - in - law Marlene, grandchildren Rachel and Joshua. Service Tuesday, 1 pm, Temple Israel, Glengary Road, Crotonon-Hudson. Shiva at the home Wednesday and Thursday. Donations: Yarmin Neurobehavior and Alzheimer's Disease Center of Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, New York, NY, 10003.

title: Nicknamed or Not, Devils' Line Clicks
description: Devils left wing Patrik Elias is somewhere in the thicket of bodies flying down the ice, but only center Scott Gomez seems to know where. It is as if they are the only players fitted with global positioning devices. Then one finds the other. Goal.

title: For Wildlife, Migration Is Endangered Too
description: In September, when the snow starts to bury Grand Teton National Park, pronghorn antelope follow an ancient exit strategy. They descend from the mountains and travel more than 300 miles south to a broad treeless mesa where life is made easier by winds that scour snow off the grasses.

title: AMERICAN STANDARD RAISES FIRST-QUARTER FORECAST
description: The American Standard Companies, the maker of Champion toilets and Trane air-conditioners, raised its first-quarter profit forecast, saying earnings will be helped by the weak dollar and higher productivity. Profit will rise to $1.09 to $1.15 a share, from 87 cents in the quarter a year ago, the company said. In January, it forecast profit of $1.02 to $1.12. American Standard is based in Piscataway, N.J.

description: Resorting once again to political brinkmanship, Argentina has locked horns with the International Monetary Fund, threatening to default on a $3.1 billion payment to the fund due today unless it gets assurances of continuing I.M.F. support for rolling over the debt.

title: The Rural Life; Skunk Thaw
description: You don't really notice a skunk's smell. It notices you. It loiters in the air, nearly sentient, waiting to knock you down, strong enough to make you wonder how a skunk can smell anything but itself. I walked into a fresh scent on my way to the barn one morning a couple of weeks ago. In the warmth of that afternoon I heard the sound of bees. The skunk had attacked a corner of one of the hives in the night. Its claws hadn't done much damage, enough to open only a crack, which the bees were trying to patch.

description: Since an announcement in January that it had overstated its oil and natural gas reserves, Royal Dutch/Shell has puzzled and frustrated investors and analysts.

title: JETBLUE PLANS DAILY FLIGHTS TO DOMINICAN REPUBLIC
description: The JetBlue Airways Corporation, a low-cost carrier with orders to more than quadruple its fleet by 2011, plans to begin daily flights to the Dominican Republic's two largest cities, expanding Caribbean service beyond Puerto Rico. The airline is seeking approval from regulators in the United States and the Dominican Republic to start twice-daily flights on June 10 between New York and Santiago, the country's second-largest city, and a daily flight between New York and Santo Domingo, the capital, on June 17. JetBlue began flights in 2002 to San Juan, P.R., its only destination outside the continental United States.

description: A budget watchdog group ratcheted up pressure on state elected leaders on Monday to change New York's antiquated budget process, something Albany has long promised but has been unable to do.

description: Many women have trouble shedding extra pounds after giving birth. But a new study finds that fathers also tend to gain weight after babies arrive -- and the more children, the greater the couple's risk of becoming obese.

description: WASHINGTON, March 9  The head of the Central Intelligence Agency encountered hostile and skeptical questioning from Democratic senators today as he defended the C.I.A.'s work in gathering intelligence before the Iraq war and in tracking down terrorists.

title: Where Brave Constitutions Are Often Window Dressing
description: Egypt's Constitution says the state may not detain people unless they are charged with a crime. Syria's Constitution declares that no citizen shall be tortured. Jordan's Constitution guarantees freedom of expression in speech and writing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, FREUND, SYL VIA (NEE BARNETT)
description: GOLDBERG - FREUND -- Syl via (nee Barnett). Of Floral Park, N.Y. and West Palm Beach, FL., formerly of Woodmere, N.Y. Adored wife and best friend of the late David Goldberg and Dr. Sonny Freund. Beloved mother of Pommy and Gerald Levy, and Henry and Pauline Goldberg. Darling grandmother of Deena and Brett Weinhouse, Jackie Levy and fiance Michael Geiser, and Alana and David Goldberg. Proud great grandmother of Maxwell Weinhouse. She filled our lives with grace and beauty. Her wisdom and gentle guidance will continue to inspire us.

The actions of mayors in places like New Paltz and Nyack fed the debate and helped trigger a declaration by the attorney general that gays and lesbians were not permitted to wed under current state law.

title: 'McFashion' puts squeeze on middle market
description: LONDON  Fashion used to be simple for Britain's middle classes: there wasn't much of it around. So for most middle-class shopper-mothers, this meant Marks & Spencer, Britain's biggest clothing retailer, which has a store on every decent high street in Britain, selling M&S label merchandise from suits to swimwear.

title: Philippine city makes its mark in global furniture design
description: HONG KONG  It is easy to be underwhelmed by Cebu, the Philippines' second-largest city. The tourism brochures boast sun-drenched beaches lined with coconut trees, but those who venture outside the resorts find a different place. The sun, sand and tropical fruit are certainly part of what is Cebu, but the general reality is that it is an industrial town. Cebu lives off the trade that goes on inside the squat, uninspired and often unattractive buildings of the downtown business district, and off the cargo hauled on the backs of the large trucks that rumble through its main streets.

title: DOLLARS FROM DANCE
description: Dance in New York City generated hundreds of millions of dollars last year, said a survey by AMS Planning & Research that was released yesterday by Dance/NYC, a service and advocacy group. According to the survey, ''The Economic Activity of Dance in New York City,'' dance audiences spent $135.4 million, including $68.1 million on tickets, $29.1 million on food and $11.4 million on shopping. Dance organizations spent $121 million and employed more than 2,600 people, allocating more than $80 million to salaries during the year for full-, part-time and contract workers. The report is based on data collected from 41 New York-based dance companies and producers and from audience surveys at 19 dance performances by 13 dance companies at 9 theaters in New York between August 2002 and January 2003. The survey estimated annual direct and indirect tax benefits to the city and state at $23.2 million. Dance schools, which draw many foreign students, were not included in the survey. JENNIFER DUNNING

description: The details sounded familiar: a Fire Department ladder truck rushing to a fire collided with a minivan on Friday. Six people were injured.

title: Shiites May Demand Lifting Of Limits on Their Power
description: Iraq's most powerful Shiite leaders kept up the pressure on Tuesday for changes in the interim constitution they signed on Monday, hinting that they may entangle the next phase of the American political timetable here, choosing a transitional government, by continuing their push for fewer constraints on the powers of the country's Shiite majority.

description: When Braden Looper reported to spring training last month, a piece of him was still on the parade route.

title: Study Finds That Teenage Virginity Pledges Are Rarely Kept
description: Among teenagers who pledged not to have sex before marriage, a majority did not live up to their vows, according to a national study reported here on Tuesday. The teenagers also developed sexually transmitted diseases at about the same rate as adolescents who had not made such pledges.

title: Lost Opportunities Cost The Knicks a Victory
description: In the final 18 seconds of a tug of war between two streaking teams battling for a playoff berth, the Knicks unraveled quickly last night. Afterward, in the locker room, there were 18 minutes of torturous slow-motion replay.

title: EchoStar Removes Some CBS Stations And Viacom Service
description: EchoStar Communications pulled CBS from its satellite service in 16 cities yesterday and dropped all of Viacom's cable networks, including MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, nationwide because of stalled contract negotiations over fees for carrying the channels.

title: Video Game Heroes: Just Folks
description: Raquel Smashenburn resembles Susan Sarandon, with smooth locks of red hair, eye-popping curves and a sweet, estrogenic aura. The wife of Rip, a Grand Prix driver from a racing video game, and herself a government agent par excellence in another video game, Raquel is computer-generated, yes, but she's all too human: a working mother drunk on exciting work and sobered, against her will, by standard-issue family life.

title: Heinlein's Prophetic First Novel, Lost and Found
description: In 1939, after leaving the United States Navy and failing in local politics in California, Robert A. Heinlein, then 32, decided to become a writer. He wrote a Utopian novel, ''For Us, the Living,'' taking the title from Lincoln's Gettysburg Address. Two publishers rejected it, so he shelved the book and later discarded the original manuscript.

title: Sexual Repression Unleashed Where Randiness Is Rampant
description: Promising that something is going to be scandalous is usually as unwise as promising someone good sex: anticipation leads to disappointment. But ''Opera Scandal 1920's,'' the American Symphony Orchestra's concert presentation of three one-act operas by Paul Hindemith at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, did indeed offer scandal and sex aplenty.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New DVD Models
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said it hoped to raise its share of the global market for DVD recorders to 50 percent this year from 40 percent last year as it unveiled a new line of the devices under its Panasonic brand. Matsushita said it planned to roll out six new DVD recorders in Japan by July, including one that uses an advanced blue laser to store the huge amounts of data needed to record high-definition programming. Currently, only Sony offers a blue laser DVD recorder. Matsushita plans to introduce two of its new DVD recorders in the United States, although it has no plans yet to sell the blue laser model there. Matsushita said it expected global demand for DVD recorders to grow to more than 10 million units this year and 20 million next year from 4 million last year. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EAGAN, JOSEPH T.
description: EAGAN -- Joseph T., 85, passed away March 7, 2004. Beloved husband of Margaret for 64 years. Devoted father to Ann Marie, Philip and Claire. Loving father-inlaw to Marjorie and Tony. Cherished grandfather of Nick and Claire, Joseph, Tony, Zeke and Gregory. Dear brother to Rita. His generous spirit touched all. Friends may call on Tuesday, March 9th from 4-6 PM at Lorne & Sons Funeral Home in Delray Beach, FL. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10 AM on Wednesday, March 10 at St. Lucy's RC Church in Highland Beach, FL. Donations in his name may be made to Duke University Medical CenterMedical Oncology Research, Attn Sr. Administrator, Division of Medical Oncology, Box 3406, Durham, NC 27710.

title: World Briefing: Americas
description: MEXICO: PROSECUTOR IN CRIME-TORN STATE QUITS The leading prosecutor in the crime-plagued state of Chihuahua, Jesus Jose Solis, resigned amid a storm of accusations in the press that allege he is linked to drug trafficking organizations. The state has been the focus of international outrage over the murders of some 300 women over the past decade in the border city of Ciudad Juarez, and rights groups have charged state officials with neglect in the investigations. This week, a Juarez newspaper published accusations that Mr. Solis was suspected of providing protection to the powerful Juarez cartel. He denied the accusations. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sharp To Double Spending On Chip Plants
description: The Sharp Corporation, Japan's biggest maker of liquid crystal displays for televisions and cellphones, will double spending on chip-making plants next year to raise production of sensors for camera-equipped cellphones and build more efficient production lines. Sharp will spend 27 billion yen ($242 million) on semiconductor development and equipment in the year ending March 2005, compared with 13 billion yen for the year to March 2004, Hiroshi Saji, a Sharp vice president, said in an interview yesterday at the company's headquarters in Osaka. Net income at Sharp almost tripled last year as the company benefited from surging sales of flat-screen televisions using its liquid crystal display panels. Sharp's additional spending this year is focused on flash memory chips and digital camera sensors for cellphones, two of the fastest growing electronics sectors. Flash memory will store images and data even when a device is turned off. The chips are used mainly in cellphones, digital cameras and digital audio players.

title: A Ritual Gone Fatally Wrong Puts Light on Masonic Secrecy
description: The initiation rituals at the Masonic lodge here had been bathed in secrecy over the years. The climax of Monday night's ceremony was to be a simple prank. A new member of the Fellow Craft Club, a select group within the lodge, would sit in a chair while an older member stood 20 feet away and fired a handgun loaded with blanks.

title: A Rumsfeld Favorite Is Out as Army Secretary Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 — The White House is withdrawing the nomination of Air Force Secretary James G. Roche to become secretary of the Army after months of controversy over a sex scandal at the Air Force Academy and a tanker-leasing deal involving the Boeing Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIHS, KURT
description: WEIHS--Kurt. We mourn the loss of a great man, a pioneering designer and art director, as well as an immensely powerful painter and sculptor. His design oeuvre is remarkable, including the actual design of the CBS Eye as the master designer in the Bill Golden atelier at CBS Television, and then a forty-year career as a creative director and designer working alongside George Lois at his ad agencies. As young Holocaust survivors, Kurt and his wife Erika, also an accomplished artist, forged a magnificent artistic and spiritual life in America. Our deep condolences to Erika, their son John and their grandson, Kris, as they lay Kurt to rest beside his beloved son Tommy. Service Wednesday, March 10 at 12:00 noon, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave at 80th St.

title: A Glimmer of Peace
description: Two years ago this month, at a summit meeting in Beirut, Lebanon, Arab leaders adopted a Saudi-initiated resolution that they said was intended to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. They urged Israel to relinquish all the territory it captured in the 1967 war -- in the Golan Heights, Gaza Strip, West Bank and East Jerusalem. They called for a ''just'' and ''agreed'' solution to the vexed issue of Palestinian refugee claims to a right of return to sovereign Israel. And in exchange they promised to ''establish normal relations with Israel.''

title: National Briefing | West: California: Arrest In Vandalism Of S.U.V.'s
description: A California Institute of Technology student, William J. Cottrell, 23, has been arrested in the firebombing and spray-painting of 125 sport utility vehicles last summer at auto dealerships in the San Gabriel Valley of Southern California, the F.B.I. said. The attacks, which also destroyed a commercial building, caused an estimated $1 million in damage. In an e-mail message sent to The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Cottrell said he was affiliated with the Earth Liberation Front, a group that has claimed responsibility for acts of arson and vandalism, the F.B.I. said. Chris Dixon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANDERSON, FRANK
description: ANDERSON -- Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Anderson, associated with The Times from June 1969 until retiring in June 2001.

title: To the Middle East for Dinner
description: Did you know that limes are dried in Iraq, Oman and Iran and sometimes pulverized to use as a seasoning? Or that okra is cooked with sugar and lemon juice in Arab countries and then served cold? These are among the tidbits in ''The Middle Eastern Kitchen'' by Ghillie Basan (Hippocrene Books, $29.50), a colorful and useful excursion through markets and pantries in more than a dozen countries that have a common culinary tradition. The pictures were taken by the author's husband, Jonathan Basan. Ms. Basan gives a historic overview of the region, then discusses about 100 ingredients, giving a history for each. There is information on cultivation, storage and use and 150 recipes, including one for orange and onion salad, below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDSAY, MARY
description: LINDSAY--Mary. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are saddened by the death of Mary Lindsay, loving and beloved wife of Founding Chairman, John V. Lindsay. Mary was such an extraordinary and vivacious person whose enthusiasm swept away all obstacles and impediments that life threw in her path. She reveled in John's success in bringing this theater back to life and was an avid first nighter here. Condolences and sympathy to Mary, Margaret, Anne, John Jr., & the grandchildren. John B. Beinecke, Chairman John Chalsty, President Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Summer Jobs From Neediest Cases Fund
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund announced yesterday that for the second year it would create 1,000 summer jobs for low-income teenagers in New York City. The fund, which gives money to seven charities that help New Yorkers in need, will provide $1.4 million for jobs at day camps, summer schools and programs for at-risk children in all five boroughs. The jobs will go to teenagers 14 to 18 years old, and they will work an average of 24 hours a week, earning $5.15 an hour. The program also offers 40 hours of job training and college preparedness. The After-School Corporation, which works with social service agencies throughout the city, will again administer the program. Lucy N. Friedman, president of the After-School Corporation, said the program would help the development of teenagers and assist families in need of extra income. The program will also reduce the impact of city cutbacks in summer jobs for teenagers. Jack Rosenthal, the president of The New York Times Company Foundation, said that another goal of the program is to encourage other donors to help in replenishing the number of jobs available for teenagers. He said companies interested in supporting the program may write to Mary Bleiberg, vice president for policy and planning, the After-School Corporation, 925 Ninth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10019; send an e-mail message to mbleiberg@tascorp.org; or call (212) 547-6923.

title: Five Britons Released From Guantnamo Arrive Home
description: Five Britons held without trial for two years as terrorism suspects at the United States military base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, arrived back in this country aboard a military transport plane on Tuesday night, flying into an air base west of London and an uncertain future. They were the first Britons known to have been released from the prison camp.

title: The Trouble With Germany
description: Europe is doing much worse than the United States economically, right? Not if you subtract Germany. Without Germany's figures, Europe's economic performance would arguably look as good as America's. That gives some sense of how bad things are in the German economy, the continent's biggest, and how critical it is for the Germans to get serious about reform -- not only for their own sake, but also for the sake of the European Union, which is bracing for the entry of a host of far poorer members.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Food Unit Acquired
description: Associated British Foods, whose businesses range from Twinings tea to Primark clothes stores, will buy the Mexican edible oils and fats unit of Unilever for $110 million to expand its Mazola brand into Mexico. Unilever is selling its Mexican Capullo canola oil, Mazola edible oil and Inca white fat brands, the finance director of Associated, John Bason, said. Those brands have sales of about $124 million in Mexico. Associated British Foods, based in London, will look at expanding Capullo into the United States, Mr. Bason said. ''There is a growing appetite for authentic Mexican brands in the U.S.,'' he said. The purchase also helps the British company's United States Mazola unit, which it bought from Unilever in 2002. Unilever is in the final year of a plan to reduce the number of its brands as it focuses on best sellers like Lipton teas.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Fall
description: New machinery orders, an important measure of corporate spending, sank 12.2 percent in January from a month earlier as a result of a decline in orders from telecommunications and transportation companies and steel makers. The larger-than-expected decline wiped out a surprisingly strong 8.1 percent gain in December. Economists said, however, that the long-term trend of recovery in corporate spending, which has been a crucial driver of Japan's economic recovery, will probably remain intact because of strong corporate profits. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Progress for Indian Point, And a Setback for Its Critics
description: In a setback and rebuke to opponents of the Indian Point nuclear plant in Westchester County, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has pronounced the plant's two active reactors fit and has moved to reduce their level of oversight to standard from heightened.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Seized Plane Adds To Coup Jitters
description: Amid conflicting accounts of the mission and destination of an aging plane seized in Zimbabwe on Sunday, at least three governments have begun investigations: Zimbabwe, which impounded the plane on suspicion that it carried mercenaries; Equatorial Guinea, where coup rumors have the government on edge; and South Africa, where the flight apparently originated. Officials from the United States, where the plane was registered, said they were also following the saga closely. The authorities in Equatorial Guinea claimed that the plane was part of coup attempt it has now thwarted by arresting 15 people they said were linked to a group of 64 detained in Zimbabwe. ''They were the advance party of that group,'' the information minister told Reuters. But the operator of the Boeing 727, Logo Logistics Ltd., said it was on an innocent mission to deliver security workers to mining companies in Congo and had stopped in Zimbabwe only to buy mining equipment. Charles Burrows, a senior executive, denied there was any connection to a coup. ''I haven't the foggiest idea of what they're talking about,'' he said. Sharon LaFraniere (NYT)

description: The Justice Department is dropping its demand, at least for now, that six Planned Parenthood clinics around the country produce medical records on abortions, officials said Tuesday.

title: What Hawthorne Didn't Tell About Hester
description: After finishing ''The Scarlet Letter'' Nathaniel Hawthorne tried to read its final scene to his wife but was overcome with emotion. ''My voice swelled and heaved,'' he recalled, ''as if I were tossed up and down on an ocean, as it subsides after a storm.''

title: Leader of '85 Achille Lauro Attack Dies at Prison in Iraq
description: Abu Abbas, the Palestinian mastermind of a deadly 1985 cruise ship hijacking in which an American passenger in a wheelchair was shot and thrown into the sea, has died at a prison in Iraq, a Pentagon spokesman said Tuesday.

title: At Poor Schools' Libraries, Time Stops on the Shelves
description: FEBRUARY was Black History Month, and all students big and small at Edward Williams Elementary -- which is 97 percent black -- were assigned reports on a famous black American. Francis Powell, a sixth grader, wanted to do Langston Hughes, but when Francis visited the school library, there were no books about the great poet, nor any of his poems.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Student Accused Of Punching Dean
description: A 15-year-old student was arrested yesterday at Port Richmond High School on Staten Island after he punched the school's 51-year-old dean in the chest, the police said. Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education, said the arrest was made in the school's cafeteria about 10:30 a.m. She said the dean, whose identity was not disclosed, felt dizzy and was treated at St. Vincent's Staten Island Hospital and released. The police said the student, whom they declined to identify because of his age, was charged with assault, harassment and disorderly conduct. He may be suspended from school, Ms. Feinberg said. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOANE, ANNETTE
description: SLOANE--Annette, on March 8, 2004. Beloved wife of Leonard, devoted mother of Elliot and Steven, adored grandmother of Jack, Jaime, Brandon, Charles and Juliet. Funeral services Wednesday, 10AM, at Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Call for New Jersey Bear Hunt Pits Council Against Governor
description: The small, obscure agency that writes New Jersey's hunting laws rebuffed the state's environmental commissioner yesterday and proposed a new black bear hunt this December, similar to last December's controversial six-day hunt. The move is likely to put the group, the New Jersey Fish and Game Council, on a collision course with Gov. James E. McGreevey's administration.

title: 'Sopranos' Premiere Sets a Record (Sort Of)
description: The fifth season premiere of ''The Sopranos'' on Sunday night set a ratings record for HBO, though because of a change in the Nielsen ratings system it was not credited with quite as many viewers overall as last year's premiere or finale.

title: Weathering the Rising Prices of Energy
description: In recent weeks, the price of West Texas crude oil has climbed to its highest level since the eve of the Iraq war, resulting in gasoline prices approaching $3 a gallon in some cases. Natural gas prices have remained elevated during the winter, translating into higher heating and electricity costs for millions of homes and businesses.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Suspect In Minister's Killing Deemed Sane
description: Psychiatrists concluded that Mijailo Mijailovic, 25, the confessed killer of Foreign Minister Anna Lindh, was not suffering from a serious mental illness when he stabbed her to death in a Stockholm department store in September. Judges had ordered a psychiatric examination of Mr. Mijailovic to determine whether he should be sent to prison or into psychiatric care. In testimony, he said voices in his head ordered him to kill Ms. Lindh. Prosecutors are seeking a life term for murder; Mr. Mijailovic's lawyers say the charge should be reduced to manslaughter. A court will decide his fate later this month. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the growing trend among American Jews to celebrate the circumcision ritual of the bris outside the home or synagogue and with increasing elaborateness included a quotation from Rabbi Adam Mintz of the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan that referred imprecisely to his attitude about the timing of the rite, ordinarily carried out eight days after birth. He says that in remarking, ''Sunday is the most popular day, and even among the Orthodox, people are choosing the date that's most popular,'' he did not intend to suggest that a bris could be postponed for the sake of holding a party at a convenient time -- but rather that if it had to be delayed on justifiable grounds, there might then be flexibility in scheduling.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 1 about the Academy Awards ceremony referred incorrectly in some copies to the species of the fish that is looking for its son in ''Finding Nemo,'' which was named best animated feature. It is a clownfish, not a blowfish.

title: CHEVRONTEXACO PLACES $535 MILLION IN PENSION PLANS
description: ChevronTexaco Corporation said yesterday that it had contributed $535 million to shore up its domestic pension plans early this year and that it expected to add about $50 million more by the end of 2004. Contributions to the United States plans totaled $1.2 billion last year and are expected to average about $250 million annually after 2004, ChevronTexaco said in a public filing. The company expects contributions of $200 million to its international pension plans this year, down from $214 million in 2003. ChevronTexaco and other employers faced shortfalls in their pensions after equities, as measured by major stock indexes, fell for three consecutive years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELIGMAN, EDITH
description: SELIGMAN--Edith. We are deeply saddened by the untimely and tragic death of Edith. She was a very good friend and we will miss her terribly. No bridge game will ever be the same to us. Miriam Kaplan Estelle Florence

title: John H. Williams, 35, Ted Williams's Son
description: John Henry Williams, who sent the body of his father, Ted Williams, the Boston Red Sox Hall of Famer, to be frozen at an Arizona cryonics laboratory, died on Saturday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 35.

title: Unions Put Early Kerry Backer on Strategy Panel
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. rewarded the president of the first union to endorse Senator John Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, by naming him on Tuesday as vice chairman of a new campaign strategy committee.

title: Oughta Be in Pictures? So Just Drink Up!; Amateur Celebrities Pick a Movie and Join In
description: All the evidence in the room pointed to imminent karaoke. There was a tiny stage and a television monitor flashing words. There was an energetic hostess trying to whip people into the mood. And the people, about a dozen, were waiting patiently for their third beer to lend them the necessary talent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TODER, FLORENCE
description: TODER--Florence. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Florence Toder, associated with The Times from January 1944 until retiring in April 1972.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Saturday, about Marge Schott, the former owner of the Cincinnati Reds who died on March 2, misstated the given name of the political candidate whose placard recalled the name of a Nazi official and led her to make the comment ''Hitler was good in the beginning, but he went too far.'' The name was Goering, not Goebbels.

title: Once Upon a Time in the Italian Wild West
description: ON a wintry Thursday, about a century after Buffalo Bill Cody passed through Rome and, so the story goes, challenged a posse of Italian cowboys to a rodeo competition, Cesare Casella commemorated the occasion by preparing pork ribs slow-cooked in tomatoes, hot pepper and garlic. He wore a Ferrari-red Western shirt, cowboy boots of pale blue python skin and a grin as wide as the Texas plains.

title: A niche no more: gay celebrities are in demand as endorsers for mainstream campaigns.
description: MADISON AVENUE is offering a queer aye for the straight buy, increasingly using openly gay and lesbian celebrities in campaigns aimed not at the homosexual market but at the wider general audience.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sharpton May Get Federal Money
description: The audit division of the Federal Election Commission said yesterday that the Rev. Al Sharpton qualified to receive federal matching money to help his financially struggling campaign. The full commission is scheduled to vote on that determination on Thursday, and, if it agrees, Mr. Sharpton's campaign could soon receive about $150,000 in tax dollars. The campaign has said it needs the money to pay off a loan due on March 15. At the same time, the audit division said Mr. Sharpton may have violated a limit on the amount of their own money candidates can spend on their campaigns when they are receiving tax dollars. If the division investigates and determines that Mr. Sharpton spent more than $50,000 of his own money on his race, the commission could suspend future payments or make his committee pay back some or all of the money it received, said Bob Biersack, a commission spokesman. Michael Slackman (NYT)

title: El Paso Corp. Delays Earnings Report
description: The El Paso Corporation said today that it would delay the release of its fourth-quarter earnings, the latest fallout from the renewed examination of the way oil companies assess their energy reserves.

title: Argentina Skirts Default On $3 Billion With I.M.F.
description: Argentina and the International Monetary Fund reached a last-minute agreement yesterday to avoid a potentially damaging $3.1 billion default.

title: The Collections / Paris : Horses and boys bring shift in pace
description: The neigh of a horse and the strut of a boy were the two surprise elements of the Paris fashion season, which closed the monthlong international collections this week. The equestrian ride from designers as diverse as Ann Demeulemeester, Jean Paul Gaultier and Helmut Lang, proved how creative minds think alike. And the fact that leading designers  starting with Chanel  put males on their runways emphasized a change of fashion pace. After the girly, fluttery and barely-there sexually titillating fashions since the start of the millennium, designers are going back to something much more substantial.

title: Europe Moves To Strengthen Piracy Laws
description: The European Parliament on Tuesday approved an antipiracy law intended to bring lax national laws in countries like Greece and the new entrants to the union into line with countries with stricter standards like Britain.

title: A Premier Is Picked in Haiti; Marines to Disarm Militants
description: A new prime minister was appointed Tuesday to head Haiti's government until elections are held, and, in an abrupt reversal, international forces announced that they would begin disarming militants.

title: Chance to Revive Sales Draws Nuclear Industry to China
description: China plans to significantly expand its nuclear power in the coming decades, and the Bush administration has been courting the country's top officials on behalf of American companies seeking a starring role in that expansion.

title: Hevesi Says New York Gave Tax Breaks That Failed to Create Jobs
description: A state program that doles out millions of dollars in tax breaks to businesses that promise to create jobs in economically struggling areas is poorly managed and has rewarded some companies that actually ended up losing jobs, State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi charged in an audit released here on Tuesday.

description: Kodak Accuses Sony Of Patent Infringement

A memorial gathering for Sandy will be held March 14, 2004, in Plaza Room, 777 United Nations Plaza, NYC, at 12:30 PM; reception until 4 PM.

title: Rubens, the 'Prince of Painters,' Finally Gets His Due in France
description: Rubens is so omnipresent in museums and collections, so renowned for his portraits and religious, historical and mythological paintings, that any retrospective of his work raises the question: Is there anything new to say? In France there is. Remarkably, a major Rubens exhibition that opened March 6 in this northern city is the first overview of his work to be presented in France.

title: When Cars Are Locked Up, Owners Try to Spring Them
description: ''Every car has its own story,'' said the officer standing outside the New York City Police Department's vehicle pound, in a bleak industrial zone in northern Queens. ''One car might have killed someone; another might have been stolen.''

description: GOLDBERG - FREUND -- Syl via (nee Barnett). Of Floral Park, N.Y. and West Palm Beach, FL., formerly of Woodmere, N.Y. Adored wife and best friend of the late David Goldberg and Dr. Sonny Freund. Beloved mother of Pommy and Gerald Levy, and Henry and Pauline Goldberg. Darling grandmother of Deena and Brett Weinhouse, Jackie Levy and fiance Michael Geiser, and Alana and David Goldberg. Proud great grandmother of Maxwell Weinhouse. She filled our lives with grace and beauty. Her wisdom and gentle guidance will continue to inspire us.

description: Pakistan successfully test fired a new long-range missile capable of carrying nuclear warheads, the state-run media reported. The missile, known as Shaheen II, has a range of 1,250 miles. Salman Masood (NYT)

description: The United States agreed Tuesday to tone down its criticism of Iran in order to win European support for a demand that Tehran divulge more about its nuclear program, according to European diplomats here.

title: Internet Providers Sue Hundreds Over Unsolicited E-Mail
description: Four major Internet providers said today they filed a series of lawsuits meant to shut down some major senders of unsolicited junk e-mail known as spam. The suits are among the first to invoke the federal Can-Spam Act, which went into effect on Jan. 1.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Parties Move To Impeach President
description: South Korea's two main opposition parties filed a motion to impeach President Roh Moo Hyun for breach of election rules. The action -- the first in South Korea -- deepened the political turmoil that has gripped the country for months. A total of 159 legislators endorsed the motion to begin a debate on impeachment, well above the majority of the 270-member National Assembly required. Mr. Roh, who took office in February 2003, has no party affiliation but has said he plans to join the liberal Uri Party, which has just 46 seats in the assembly. He set off the latest clash with his opponents last month when, in a televised news conference, he called for support of the Uri Party in elections next month. The national elections watchdog ruled that Mr. Roh's comments had violated presidential neutrality, but it said the violation was minor. Political analysts said the chances of success for an impeachment were not very high. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ZALE CORP., Irving , Tex., the jewelry retailer, said that Richard Marcus, director and former Neiman Marcus Group Inc. chief executive, would succeed Robert DiNicola as chairman on July 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'HANLON, THOMAS J.
description: O'HANLON--Thomas J. Died peacefully at his home in Greenwich, CT on March 8 after a brave battle with cancer. His beloved daughter Isolde O'Hanlon of Manhattan, his long time companion Jean Conwell and her children Jennifer, Kelly and Brian and his former wife Grainne O'Hanlon, survive him. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, March 27, at 1:30 PM at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church, 469 North St., Greenwich, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to the Friends of the Greenwich Library, 101 W. Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIKER, WALTER, MD.
description: RIKER--Walter, MD. The Department of Anesthesiology of The New York Presbyterian Hospital-Weill Cornell Medical College is saddened by the loss of Walter Riker. Through his many years as Chairman of the Department of Pharmacology at the Cornell Medical College, Dr. Riker was a dear, highly respected and cherished colleague who served as an intimate liaison and mentor in the understanding of many of the fundamentals of contemporary anesthesiology. His work on the neuromuscular junction and inhalational anesthetics are a part of the foundation for our profession. Dr. Riker's scientific focus on the importance of the motor nerve terminal in the physiology and pharmacology of the neuromuscular junction was ahead of its time when he first began to publish in the 1950's and 60's. He will be remembered as a person of great warmth and sincerity and as a scientist, teacher, and humanist. Our sincere sympathy & condolences are extended to the Riker family.

title: Cleric's Sentence Is Reduced by Indonesian Court
description: On the eve of a visit to Indonesia by the secretary for homeland security, Tom Ridge, the Indonesian Supreme Court has reduced the prison sentence of the suspected spiritual leader of an Islamic group, Jemaah Islamiyah, which the United States has labeled a terrorist organization.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MATTIA, LOUIS
description: MATTIA--Louis. Known from 1960 to 1995 for his antique light fixtures at his Second Ave. store, Mr. Mattia died peacefully at age 87 in his Manhattan apartment on Sunday, March 7. Friends may call at Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, Thursday, March 11, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Memorial service on Saturday, March 20, 11 AM, St. Ann's Church, 25 Eastern Avenue, Ossining, New York, interment St. Augustine's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations can be sent to cancer, heart or kidney foundations. Mr. Mattia leaves a wife and two daughters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISHMAN, MARGARET W. (PEGGY)
description: TISHMAN -- Margaret W. (Peggy). The leadership, Board of Trustees and staff of United Jewish Communities note with deep sorrow the loss of Peggy Tishman, an extraordinary and articulate advocate for the needs of the Jewish community. In addition to sixty years of inspired leadership and dedicated service to the Jewish community, Peggy had the unique distinction of being the first woman president of a major Jewish federation. Her compassion for the plight of needy elderly and the unselfish manner with which she opened her heart and home to those around her, set a standard of leadership that was unprecedented. Peggy served as the president of the UJA-Federation of New York from 1986-1989 through the merger, which established the organization. She helped found the Jewish Association for the Aged and developed an endowments program to secure the community's future. She served as a board member of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee and the Jewish Home and Hospital, and as President of the Jewish Community Relations Council of NY. Peggy's contributions to the Jewish community were nationally recognized. Her tireless spirit, honesty and determination serve as a model of grace under pressure, the best in voluntary leadership. Her humanitarian spirit and ability to turn ideas into action will be sorely missed. To Peggy's daughter, Pat Hall, and to the entire Tishman Family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. May they all be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Robert Goldberg Chairman of the UJC Board Morton B. Plant Chairman of the Executive Committee Kathy Manning Treasurer Stephen H. Hoffman President and CEO

title: WEYERHAEUSER TO PAY $34.5 MILLION SETTLEMENT
description: Weyerhaeuser Company agreed to pay $34.5 million to settle claims that it monopolized the market for alder, a wood used to make furniture and flooring that grows only in the Pacific Northwest. The settlement with four mills follows a $79 million court decision against the company in a separate case last year, when jurors found that Weyerhaeuser sold alder at below-market prices and prevented a competitor from bidding on timberland. Two similar suits are scheduled to go to trial later this year. The settlement resolves claims by Cascade Hardwoods Inc. and Alexander Lumber Mill of Washington and Oregon's Westwood Lumber Company Inc. and Morton Alder Mill Inc. Weyerhaeuser admitted no liability and said it would take a $23 million charge, or 10 cents a share, in the first quarter to pay for the accord.

title: A right to vote:Many U.S. youths abroad are denied
description: PARIS:  Many overseas Americans  possibly thousands  may not be able to vote in this year's presidential election because of an omission during the latest round of U.S. electoral reform, according to U.S. officials and organizations representing Americans abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTFRIED, TED M.
description: GOTTFRIED--Ted M. Age 75. Died March 7, 2004. A lifelong New Yorker, he was the author of over 100 books ranging from racy adult fiction to young adult non-fiction, including a notable series on the Holocaust. He worked for social justice, first in the civil rights and anti-war movements, recently in the peace movement. He was an avid chess player, playing for the Stuyvesant Town Chess Club. He was a founding member of the National Writers' Union. A world wide traveler, he also enjoyed kayaking and vacationing in Vermont. He is survived by his wife Harriet, five children, Julie, Daniel, Katherine, Toby and Valerie, two stepdaughters, Melanie and Lisa, twelve grand children and many friends. He will be greatly missed. Memorial service will be held Saturday, March 13th at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York at 11AM. Memorial donations may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

description: WASHINGTON, March 10  President Bush campaigned in Ohio today as though it were Labor Day instead of eight months before the election, saying how much he loved "dreamers and doers" as opposed to those who embrace "economic isolationism."

description: The deputy New York City schools chancellor who resigned this week in a conflict-of-interest scandal had the right temperament for pushing a calcified school system toward the sweeping administrative reforms envisioned by City Hall. But the single-minded, hard-driving style that made the official, Diana Lam, a potent force for change also seems to have led to overconfidence and a lapse in judgment that prematurely ended her tenure and left the schools' top leadership shaken.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Revises Profit
description: Network Associates, the maker of McAfee antivirus software, said yesterday that profit was 3 cents a share higher in 2003 than previously reported because of a change in accounting for international sales. Sales were $936.3 million, not the $932.5 million stated initially, after applying a different exchange rate to sales outside the United States. The change resulted in net income of 43 cents a share, up from the 40 cents reported earlier, Network Associates said in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission. In October the company restated its sales for 1998 through 2000 after Terry Davis, a former vice president, pleaded guilty in June to engaging in a plan to inflate revenue. The S.E.C. is investigating Network Associates' accounting, the company said in its filing. Shares of Network Associates fell 42 cents, to $17.58.

title: KROLL BUYS CREDIT NETWORK TRUST FOR $20.5 MILLION

The chief executive, Michael Cherkasky, said Kroll owned credit rating businesses in the West and the acquisition of Credit Network Trust would help it expand to the Northeast. Kroll expects Credit Network Trust will generate revenue of $16.3 million for 2004.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Summit: Fire Disrupts Rail Service
description: Commuter rail service in part of New Jersey was disrupted last night by a four-alarm fire at a car dealership near a New Jersey Transit rail line in Summit, fire officials said. The fire, which began about 10:30 p.m., quickly spread through the Infiniti dealership, at 68 Franklin Place, said Rick DeGroot, a battalion chief in the Summit Fire Department. The fire caused transit officials to halt train service between Summit and Short Hills, the next station, about 11 p.m., and provided bus service between the two stations, said Ken Hitchner, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit. No one was injured, Chief DeGroot said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Foreign Minister, But Reformers Stay
description: President Vladimir V. Putin selected Sergei Lavrov, who has represented Russia in the United Nations since 1994, to be foreign minister, and in a signal that he plans to continue economic reforms, reappointed Finance Minister Aleksei Kudrin and Economy Minister German Gref, the government's chief liberal ideologists. He appointed Aleksandr D. Zhukov, an economist with reformist credentials, to be the sole deputy prime minister. The moves come just days before the presidential election on Sunday and follow Mr. Putin's appointment of a low-profile technocrat, Mikhail Fradkov, as prime minister. Mr. Lavrov replaces Igor Ivanov, who had taken a comparatively hard-line stance toward the West, according to political analysts. Defense Minister Sergei Ivanov, a hard-liner seen as a possible heir to the presidency, retained his job. Seth Mydans (NYT)

Long before the supersized voice and heft of Luciano Pavarotti -- outstanding even in a field of weighty talent -- there was Luisa Tetrazzini, an early 20th-century diva who famously filled open space with a huge, electronically unassisted voice from a zaftig body. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Celebrates Anniversary Of 311
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg blew out candles on a yellow-frosted cake yesterday to celebrate the first anniversary of the 311 information center at its Lower Manhattan office. The 311 help line, which takes all complaints, requests and inquiries about city services, received 6.5 million calls in its first year of operation. Noise was the No. 1 complaint, with 255,000 calls, followed by complaints about landlords, and calls about recycling and trash collections, potholes and towed vehicles. ''Finally, New Yorkers don't have to search through a phone book or experience the frustration of being bounced around from one agency to the next as they try to find the service they need,'' Mr. Bloomberg said. Operators for 311 answer calls 24 hours a day, seven days a week, in more than 170 languages. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: A Night of Bouncing Balls

Ms. Dean builds small dances around rubber and plastic balls of all colors, from small irridescent ones to large blue exercise balls. She is clearly fascinated - or perhaps even obsessed - by their look and heft and the ways they may be used to move along a dance. But 90 minutes is a long time to spend watching otherwise inanimate objects bounce and roll.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: I.B.M. To Acquire Trigo Technologies
description: I.B.M. has agreed to buy Trigo Technologies, which is closely held, to add programs that help companies manage product data. Terms of the deal were not disclosed by I.B.M. yesterday. Trigo's software lets clients integrate and manage product information and then links it with items like pricing. I.B.M. has bolstered its software lines as demand for hardware slows. It bought the Rational Software Corporation for $2.1 billion last year and has made smaller purchases including that of the closely held Green Pasture Software Inc. in December, to add document-management programs. Trigo, which is based in Brisbane, Calif., also has offices in Amsterdam and Bangalore, India. The company has 150 employees, and its customers include Staples Inc. and Sony. Shares of I.B.M. fell 6 cents, to $94.53. The companies expect to complete the transaction in the second quarter.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Phone Stake Sale
description: Orange, the wireless unit of France Tlcom, will sell for 1 baht (3 cents) most of its stake in a Thai mobile phone venture it bought for $550 million two years ago after the company lagged market share targets. Orange will sell 39 percent of the TA Orange Company to the TelecomAsia Corporation, Bangkok's biggest fixed-line phone company, TelecomAsia said. Orange will keep a 10 percent stake and allow the venture to use its brand for three years. Shares of TelecomAsia rose 4.6 percent, to 8.05 baht, in Bangkok on optimism the company would be able to increase sales after the takeover. The company is controlled by the Charoen Pokphand Group.

title: Scientists Find Indications That Ovaries May Be Replenished

title: Extra-Low Cholesterol
description: A cholesterol-lowering study whose results were announced this week has a wealth of important implications. The findings could certainly presage a significant change in the way heart disease patients are treated. It should also start a careful evaluation of whether normally healthy people could benefit from a sharp drug-induced reduction in their cholesterol levels. There may also be major side effects for the economy: the potential health benefits could drive up the use of high-cost drugs in a nation that is already struggling to pay its medical bills. Finally, the study should send a message to Congress and federal regulators about the value of comparative testing of prescription drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUADROZZI, JOHN
description: QUADROZZI--John, born August 18, 1928, the son of a Blacksmith. Starting his life, he swung his father's hammer as he learned the trade of a steel man. Most noting his physical stature said he was the Man of Steel. His repertoire expanded to truck building and mechanics. However in 1964, John changed gears and became co-founder and President of Quadrozzi Concrete Corporation, a company now celebrating its 40th year anniversary as New York's oldest and most respected name in concrete. The company John sculpted from conception has become synonymous with quality. With his dedicated family at his side, John thrusted Quadrozzi into the major leagues with its first mammoth project, the Cross Bay Bridge -- gracefully swung across Jamaica Bay into the Rockaway's to John and his company's birthplace. John then swung Quadrozzi across the bay, as it increased its range and added multiple concrete plants throughout the boroughs. Now, as the industry - recognized pioneer and leader in high strength concrete, Quadrozzi Concrete supports the all-concrete Trump World Tower on Manhattan's 1st Avenue--standing virtuously as the tallest residential building in the world, and the AOL Time Warner building on Manhattan's Columbus Circle--the Making of a Landmark and single largest and most expensive private building project in North America's history. It is said that these two projects, requiring a consistent delivery of the highest strength concrete ever produced in the city, could not have been built if not for Quadrozzi. John's legacy continues as the company he created actively supplies Building 7 of the new World Trade Center. A philanthropist, John generously gave to all that asked--especially his hometown, the Rockaway's. He was a Rockaway Chamber of Commerce-Member of the Presidents Club and 3 times Man of the Year, Rockaway's Peninsula HospitalBoard Member, former President and Co-founder of the Association of NYC Concrete Producers and recipient of countless awards for his contribution to the industry. Loyal son of the late Costantino and surviving Catherine Quadrozzi. Beloved husband of Theresa Quadrozzi. Devoted father of their four daughters Juliana, Regina, Theresa, Catherine and their only son John, Jr. Cherished grandfather of their children Darien, Quinn, Leonor, Theresa and Isabella. John died Sunday, March 7, in the year 2004, one year after a long fight against multiple ailments. He defied medical science as he cheated death again and again. Those who said he was the Man of Steel were wrong, he was ''The Man of Concrete''--John Quadrozzi goes out a winner! Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr, Rockaway Beach, NY. Visiting Wednesday 2pm-5pm & 7pm-10pm and Thursday 2pm-5pm & 6pm-10pm. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday 9:45am at St. Rose of Lima Church, Rockaway Beach, NY. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in John's name be sent to the Chamber of Commerce of the Rockaway's, 253 B. 116th St, Rockaway Park, NY 11694. Some of us will remember him for his brilliance--others as simply the nicest man they ever met, but those who knew him best--will remember him for both.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Industrial Production Rises
description: German industrial production declined in January, led by a decline in construction. Production at factories, construction sites, utilities and mines fell 0.1 percent from December, when it increased by the same amount, the Economics and Labor Ministry said. The data was in line with economists' forecasts but it was the fourth report in the last two weeks to indicate that Germany's economy is struggling to pick up pace. ''The recovery is still pretty sluggish,'' said Udo Ludwig, an economist at IWH, a German economic institute. ''The euro appreciation means the upswing will be more moderate.'' The decline in production was led by a 7.4 percent drop in construction. Production of durable goods like washing machines and television sets fell 1.5 percent from December, while companies produced 1.5 percent more goods like factory machinery.

Excluding Sundays, it was 451,974, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations; 302,851 was the average circulation on Saturdays.

title: Algerian Celebration: Audience Joins the Spectacle
description: A dance program became a celebration when the Algerian National Ballet made its New York debut on Sunday afternoon at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center at Borough of Manhattan Community College.

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Bishop For Troubled Diocese
description: The Vatican has appointed a new leader of the Diocese of Springfield, Mass., less than a month after Bishop Thomas Dupre resigned amid reports of sexual abuse. Bishop Timothy A. McDonnell, who has been an auxiliary bishop in the Archdiocese of New York City since 2001, will head the diocese of about 250,000 Roman Catholics in western Massachusetts. The Vatican also named Prof. Mary Ann Glendon of Harvard Law School as president of the Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences, making her the Catholic Church's highest-ranking woman in an advisory position. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Spalding Interrupted
description: In ''Swimming to Cambodia,'' Spalding Gray quotes his mother, who committed suicide when she was 52 and who always said, ''Think of the starving Koreans.'' When his obsessions begin to overtake him in that monologue, he reflects on ''the therapeutic joys of living in New York City. It always works. As soon as you think you're crazy, all you have to do is look over your shoulder.'' But at a certain point for Mr. Gray, it was no longer possible for him to look over his shoulder for someone worse off than he was. Starving Koreans no longer did the trick. They never do if you're as depressed as Mr. Gray was for much of his life. He disappeared on Jan. 10, and his body was found in the East River on Sunday.

title: PEPSI PLANS TO INTRODUCE MIDCALORIE SOFT DRINK
description: Pepsi Cola North America, a unit of PepsiCo Inc., said yesterday that it would introduce a midcalorie soft drink this summer with 50 percent less sugar, carbohydrates and calories than regular Pepsi. The new drink, Pepsi Edge, has 70 calories and 20 grams of sugar in each 12-ounce can. Food scientists reduced the drink's calorie and sugar count by using a combination of Splenda and high fructose corn syrup, the company said. The new soft drink is Pepsi's latest attempt to lure consumers back to colas. Pepsi said its new drink is aimed at health-conscious consumers who drink both regular and diet colas, but sometimes shun diet soft drinks because of their taste. Both Coca-Cola and Cadbury Schweppes are exploring midcalorie soft drinks, industry analysts said. Sherri Day (NYT)

Funeral Mass 10AM Saturday, March 13th, Saint John Nepomucene, 411 E. 66 St., N.Y.

description: ONE of the beauties of TriBeCa is its low-key charm. As a neighborhood, it wears its wealth well, casual Calvin rather than outlandish Gaultier. description: JERUSALEM, March 10  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel and his Palestinian counterpart, Ahmed Qurei, intend to hold their first summit meeting next week, with the talks likely to focus on a possible Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip, officials said today.

title: Kidd Is Hoping to Play Tonight
description: The diagnosis of rest and a day-to-day wait for an answer had grown tedious for Jason Kidd, so he worked through the entire practice Tuesday, joining his teammates in every drill, then lingering on the court after the rest of the Nets were done. But no amount of work could change the reality that even Kidd did not know if he would be able to play against the Nuggets on Wednesday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Prosecutor In Crime-Torn State Quits
description: The leading prosecutor in the crime-plagued state of Chihuahua, Jesus Jos Sols, resigned amid a storm of accusations in the press that allege he is linked to drug trafficking organizations. The state has been the focus of international outrage over the murders of some 300 women over the past decade in the border city of Ciudad Jurez, and rights groups have charged state officials with neglect in the investigations. This week, a Jurez newspaper published accusations that Mr. Sols was suspected of providing protection to the powerful Jurez cartel. He denied the accusations. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: INGERSOLL-RAND RAISES QUARTERLY PROFIT ESTIMATE
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company raised its first-quarter profit forecast because demand is increasing, though it did not say in which markets. The company, which is based in Bermuda, also said it would have a pretax gain of $31.5 million for antidumping claims, a payment companies get when the Commerce Department determines imports have been sold at less than fair market value. Profit excluding the payment under the Continued Dumping and Subsidy Offset Act will rise to as much as 80 cents a share, from 55 cents a year earlier, the company said. It earlier forecast profit of 65 cents to 75 cents.

description: ONE of the toughest wines to sell in this country is one that costs $10. Forget the name, the origin, the style. title: I'll Have What the Young Japanese Are Having
description: Shochu, the cool drink among the younger set in Japan, is beginning to show up on these shores. Like sake, shochu (or soju), can be made from rice, but more often is based on barley, buckwheat or sweet potatoes. Whereas sake is brewed like beer, shochu is distilled like vodka, often twice. At about 50 proof, it has less alcohol than vodka, whether on the rocks or in cocktails like the honeyed shochu at Sushi Samba, and the kumquat sour at Riingo, both in New York. The shochus at left, from Landmark Wines and Spirits, 167 West 23rd Street, range from $10.99 to $24.99 a bottle. I liked two made from barley, the fruity Iichiko and the citrusy Alakey. Zuizen Awamori, similar to shochu and made from rice, had a mushroomy bouquet and a creamy aftertaste. There are also Korean brands, like the syrupy Green, made from sweet potatoes.

title: Sports of The Times; Rookie Card Could Say Air James

description: Senators John McCain and Russell D. Feingold said Wednesday that groups like the ones using unregulated donations to pay for efforts against President Bush this campaign season are circumventing the new campaign finance law that they sponsored.

title: When Media Giants Bicker
description: The struggle between content and distribution to reign supreme in the realm of television is intensifying. In the latest skirmish, EchoStar, the nation's second-largest satellite broadcaster, with nine million subscribers, pulled the plug on Tuesday on CBS affiliates owned by the network's parent company, Viacom, as well as on Viacom's stable of popular cable channels, which include MTV and Nickelodeon.

title: Housing From the Dawn of the Atomic Age
description: One new quarterly seems long overdue. Atomic Ranch: Midcentury Marvels, left, is devoted entirely to ranch houses. Jim Brown, the publisher, and Michelle Gringeri-Brown, the editor, above right, believe they are in virgin territory. And Mr. Brown said that they expected ranch houses to be ''the next big wave of interest.'' The first issue includes the history of a home in Glendale, Calif., above, from its original architect, Clair Earl, to its current owner.

title: Death of Girl, 16, Spotlights Hard Drugs in New Jersey Suburbs
description: When 16-year-old Samantha Dolan of Morristown died on Sunday morning, apparently of a drug overdose, her parents did something unusual. Instead of keeping quiet about the circumstances of her death, Lorraine and Patrick Dolan chose to speak out about how their daughter died, hoping to save other young people, they said.

title: House Votes to Raise Indecency Fines
description: WASHINGTON, March 11 — An overwhelming majority of the House of Representatives voted today to greatly increase the maximum penalties for obscenity, indecency and profanity on radio and television.

title: A Watchdog Sees Flaws In Bush's Ads On Medicare
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said on Wednesday that advertisements and brochures prepared by the Bush administration to publicize a new Medicare law, although not illegal, misrepresented the prescription drug benefits that would be offered to millions of elderly and disabled people.

title: Liberal Talk Radio Network To Start Up in Three Cities
description: The creators of a fledgling liberal talk radio network who hope to challenge the dominance of conservative voices on the nation's airwaves said yesterday that its programming would make its debut on March 31 on low-rated stations in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago.

description: A doctors' Web site that compiled and posted the names of patients who have sued doctors for malpractice closed on Wednesday after complaints that it amounted to a blacklist.

title: U.S. Laws Said to Impede States' Moves In Foster Care
description: Federal laws enacted in the 1990's that were meant to create more accountability in state foster-care systems are instead stifling needed innovations and endangering parts of the $4.6 billion in federal financing going to states for the care of poor children, according to a report to be released today.

title: If Fido Strays, Fear Not: His Collar Stays In Touch
description: With the proliferation of homing devices and navigation gadgets that use the Global Positioning System, one would expect that an entrepreneurial animal-lover would have already developed a high-tech tool for tracking lost pets. But Morgan Hatch, president of a Los Angeles company called PetTrax, says G.P.S. would be overkill.

title: Yankee Way of Disclosure Gets Under Sheffield's Skin
description: Gary Sheffield has no intention of submitting to surgery on his injured right thumb this season, and Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman needed to calm him down Wednesday after the publication of Cashman's comments that surgery could force him to miss up to three months.

description: Congress will act if Major League Baseball's leaders fail to strengthen and expand the sport's drug-testing policy, Senator John McCain warned Wednesday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Council Adopts Budget
description: The City Council yesterday adopted a $45.8 million operating budget for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. The Council's budget, which includes salaries for council members and their staff, represented a change of only $7,165 from the year before. Councilman David I. Weprin, chairman of the Finance Committee, pointed out that council leaders had kept their overall spending level virtually unchanged in spite of inflation, rising rents and the addition of several legislative committees. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Chief Resigns

Accident investigators concluded last month that the pilot of the Crossair passenger plane from Berlin to Zurich was flying too low. Swiss International was formed in March 2002 out of Crossair, a unit of the collapsed national carrier, Swissair. Mr. Dose, above, was in charge of Crossair in 2001. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

description: COLORADO: PASTOR WHO POSTED SIGN QUITS A Denver pastor who posted a widely criticized sign outside his church that read, "Jews Killed the Lord Jesus" has resigned. The man, Maurice Gordon of the Lovingway United Pentecostal Church, posted the sign on Ash Wednesday to coincide with the release of the film "The Passion of the Christ." Mr. Gordon has since apologized and said he did not intend to promote anti-Semitism but rather wanted people to read the Bible. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Shock Hazard Persisted After Con Ed's Inspection
description: The underground wires that shocked two dogs on a sidewalk in the East Village on Tuesday had been inspected and found to be safe on Jan. 17, a Consolidated Edison spokesman said yesterday. That inspection date was the day after a woman was electrocuted two blocks away while walking her dogs, prompting citywide inspections for stray voltage in light poles, manhole covers, construction plates and service box lids.
