title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Credit Rating Raised
description: Lucent Technologies, which has had seven debt downgrades since 2000, had its credit rating raised by Standard & Poor's yesterday after the company stemmed three years of sales declines last quarter. The rating, which remains below investment grade, was raised to B from B-, Standard & Poor's said. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., is the nation's biggest maker of telephone equipment. The company had never had a rating increase from S.&P. or Moody's Investors Service since it was spun off from AT&T in 1996. The upgrade may reduce Lucent's borrowing costs the next time the company, which had $4.42 billion in long-term debt at year's end, needs to raise money. The chief executive, Patricia F. Russo, has used cost cuts to return Lucent to profitability in the last two quarters after sales plummeted to $8.47 billion last year, from $30.6 billion in 1999. Shares of Lucent rose 1 cent, to $3.91.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Trade Deal Advances
description: Mexico and Japan have resolved the final disputes in negotiations for a free trade pact, clearing the way for the deal to be ready by the end of the month, officials from both countries said. Mexico won more favorable access from Japan for its agricultural products. Japan negotiated better terms for entry of its steel and cars into Mexico.

title: New Domain Is Proposed
description: In a sign that the wireless Internet is coming of age, Nokia, Vodafone, Microsoft and six other technology and telecommunications companies joined Wednesday to propose the equivalent of a .mobile Internet address category for mobile Web access.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about American pressure on the International Atomic Energy Agency to condemn Iran's nuclear program misidentified the nation that has insisted its nuclear program is peaceful and has demanded a stop to the agency's ''propaganda war.'' That nation is Iran. (Libya has admitted to a nuclear weapons program and, as the article stated, has since cooperated with the agency in dismantling that program.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alstom Cuts Outlook
description: The French industrial company Alstom warned of an increase in restructuring costs and said that it might miss its earlier forecast of profits, a development that would force it to renegotiate $1.8 billion in loans. The company was rescued last year from near bankruptcy by the French government and 32 lenders. Alstom said that restructuring costs would be $799.5 million, higher that the expected $550 million to $610 million. In addition, its operating margin will fall short of the 2 percent to 2.5 percent expected as a result of cost overruns at a power plant in Seward, Alaska. Helene Fouquet (NYT)

title: SIX FLAGS TO SELL TWO OF ITS DIVISIONS FOR $345 MILLION
description: Six Flags, the amusement park operator, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its two worst-performing businesses for $345 million. Six Flags, based in Oklahoma City, plans to sell its European division to an undisclosed company in London for $200 million, and has agreed to sell Six Flags Worlds of Adventure, near Cleveland, to Cedar Fair for $145 million, the company said. Six Flags lost money in 2003 for the fifth consecutive year.

title: $5 Million Settlement Ends Case of Tainted Texas Sting
description: Five years after 46 people, almost all of them black, were arrested on fabricated drug charges in Tulia, Tex., their ordeal will draw to a close today with the announcement of a $5 million settlement in their civil suit and the disbandment of a federally financed 26-county narcotics task force responsible for the arrests.

title: Police Kill Man in East Harlem
description: A detective fatally shot a man who had a loaded gun during a struggle yesterday in the lobby of an East Harlem apartment building, the police said.

title: National Briefing | West: Oregon: Assisted Suicides Rise Slightly
description: The number of Oregonians who died using doctor-assisted suicide rose slightly last year, according to a report by the State Department of Human Services. In 2003, 42 terminally ill patients in Oregon died after taking medication prescribed by a doctor, 4 more than in 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARZ, JAY
description: SCHWARZ--Jay. On March 10, 2004, beloved son of the late Ethel and Mortimer, brother of the late Joseph M., uncle of Karen and Maggie, dear friend of Frank Bamberger for forty-seven years, outstanding member of the NYC Ramblers Appalachia Mountain Club, and Miramar Ski Club. Services Friday 11:15 A.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The NY-NJ Trail Conference Inc, 156 Ramapo Rd, Mahwah, NJ 07430.

title: Making a Pitch to a Client On a Digital Whiteboard
description: It used to be that engaging points, note cards and perhaps a blackboard were enough to make an effective presentation. But that was before presentation software like PowerPoint, running on notebook computers connected to digital projectors and whiteboards, became standard equipment.

title: Bertuzzi's Punishment To Come Today
description: Todd Bertuzzi, the Vancouver Canucks forward who has been suspended indefinitely for an attack on Colorado forward Steve Moore that left Moore hospitalized with a broken neck, a concussion and deep facial cuts, attended a one-hour disciplinary hearing here Wednesday with National Hockey League officials.

title: Judge Affirms Life Sentence for Teenager in Washington-Area Sniper Killings
description: Lee Malvo, the teenager who was convicted of murder in the sniper attacks that left 10 people dead and terrorized the Washington area in 2002, was formally sentenced Wednesday to life in prison without parole in a proceeding that lasted barely 15 minutes.

title: Study of Mice Reproduction Discovers Egg Regeneration
description: Challenging the bedrock verity of mammalian biology that a female's eggs, like private reserve wines, are made one time only, in limited numbers, and are apt to turn to vinegar if left on the shelf too long, researchers have found startling evidence that the ovaries may instead be replenished with new eggs throughout a female's reproductive career.

title: Pentagon Pays Iraq Group, Supplier of Incorrect Spy Data
description: The Pentagon is paying $340,000 a month to the Iraqi political organization led by Ahmad Chalabi, a member of the interim Iraqi government who has close ties to the Bush administration, for ''intelligence collection'' about Iraq, according to Defense Department officials.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline To Cut Jobs
description: Asia's leading air carrier, the Japan Airlines System Corporation, warned that it would lose more money this year than it previously expected and said that it planned to eliminate 4,500 jobs, or 8 percent of its work force, over the next three years. The airline is trying to reduce costs to help offset rising fuel prices and a decline in air travel since the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome and the war in Iraq. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: To Banish Pop-Up Ads, Block Stealthy Software
description: Q. Ever since my daughter used my computer, a five-inch advertisement has been popping up on my screen up to 20 times a day. Paradoxically, the ad is for pop-up blocking software. Is there any way to get rid of it? Are there any laws to protect people from this sort of thing?

title: Schools' Top Lawyer Quits In Uproar Over Nepotism
description: The city Department of Education's top lawyer resigned yesterday, becoming the second casualty in a widening scandal over the hiring of a deputy chancellor's husband without the proper conflict-of-interest clearance.

title: 4 Big Internet Providers File Suits To Stop Leading Senders of Spam
description: Four major Internet providers announced yesterday that they had filed lawsuits meant to shut a number of leading senders of unsolicited junk e-mail, or spam.

title: Intel to Miss China Deadline On Standard For Wireless
description: Intel took a hard line on Wednesday in a festering trade dispute with the Chinese government, declaring it would not meet China's June 1 deadline for adhering to its proposed new standard for wireless computing.

title: Remote Piano Lessons, in Real Time
description: AT 12, Lucas Porter already has the distinction of being one of the few musicians to have played the challenging third movement of Beethoven's ''Moonlight'' Sonata on two pianos at the same time.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Growth Estimate Cut
description: Japan reduced its estimate for fourth-quarter economic growth to a 6.4 percent annual pace because makers of machinery cut inventories more than anticipated. Business and consumer spending rose faster than first reported. The expansion compares with the 7 percent pace announced by the cabinet office in Tokyo last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODWIN, MICHAEL
description: GOODWIN--Michael. Died on March 10. Husband of Deborah. Father of Peggy and Jean. Father-in-law of Raymond. Grandfather of Rebecca, Benjamin, Leah and Ruth.

title: Alarm Raised Over Quality Of Uranium Found in Iran
description: United Nations nuclear inspectors have found traces of extremely highly enriched uranium in Iran, of a purity reserved for use in a nuclear bomb, European and American diplomats said Wednesday.

title: An Effort on Atomic Waste Is Called a Failure
description: A multibillion-dollar program to deal with millions of gallons of high-level radioactive waste at a nuclear weapons plant in South Carolina is failing because technicians cannot get the waste out of the tanks where it has been stored for the last half-century, an influential environmental group says.

title: B.C. and Virginia Tech Open Tourney in Style
description: There was nothing new or unexpected in what happened to Georgetown yesterday in the opening round of the Big East tournament. Overmatched by Boston College, the Hoyas lost, 68-57, which put the finishing touches on a season full of dubious achievements from a team that was once a perennial championship contender in the Big East.

title: Faith and Narcissism in America
description: To the Editor:

title: An Oops Button, or a Tool for Retrieving That E-Mail Note You Sent
description: THE speed and efficiency of e-mail can present problems for an impulsive person. A message written in haste can be dispatched instantly on a whim (''Sell 2,000 shares''; ''I resign''; ''We should see other people''), and there is no going back once one has clicked Send.

description: ''This bill says, 'Don't run off and file a lawsuit if you are fat.' It says, 'Look in the mirror because you're the one to blame.' ''

title: Corrections
description: A brief note in the Soccer Report column on Feb. 24 about the death of John Charles, a British player known as the Gentle Giant, misstated the basis for his nickname. What Charles never received during his playing career in the 1950's and 60's was an oral caution by a referee. (Yellow cards and red cards for a referee's caution or a dismissal were not used until 1970.)

title: DEFICIT IN TRADE TOPS $43 BILLION, MONTHLY RECORD
description: The United States trade deficit climbed to a monthly record of $43.1 billion in January as imports continued to flood in from China and American exports were hurt by slumping demand from Europe and other parts of the world.

title: Nets Relieved to Have Kidd but Don't Rely on Him
description: The wait had gone right up to game time, the status of Jason Kidd a mystery that might have echoed Willis Reed's Game 7 hobble out of the Madison Square Garden tunnel if only this wasn't a game of little consequence being played in front of a crowd that barely filled half of Continental Arena on Wednesday night.

title: Ex-Congressional Aide Accused of Working With Iraqi Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Federal prosecutors charged a former Congressional aide on Thursday with working with the Iraqi intelligence service before the war, and investigators said she had sought to influence American policy by presenting herself as an intermediary to a highly placed relative, Andrew H. Card Jr., the White House chief of staff.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Central Islip: Suit Filed Against Former Nassau Deputy
description: A Nassau County employee filed a sex discrimination suit in United States District Court here on Tuesday accusing her former boss, Peter Sylver, of harassment and assault. The suit also accused the Nassau county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, of failing to check Mr. Sylver's background before hiring him as his deputy and accused the County Legislature's Republican minority leader, Peter Schmitt, of violating her privacy by publicizing her complaint. The woman was identified in the suit only as ''L.'' Mr. Sylver, who resigned his post after charges of fiscal irregularities, has denied any wrongdoing. Mr. Suozzi's office said that the administration had properly settled the woman's initial complaint with a transfer, promotion and raise. Mr. Schmitt's spokesman said the case should have been referred to law enforcement agencies. Bruce M. Lambert (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: EASIER TO BE EUROPEAN The European Parliament adopted a law that released millions of European Union citizens from getting new identity papers when they live in another European Union country. The new law also introduces an unconditional right to permanent residency if a European Union citizen has lived continuously in another member state for five years, and strengthens the rights of the resident's non-European Union spouse and children. (Agence France-Presse)

title: House Votes to Raise Penalities for Broadcasts of Indecency
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  An overwhelming majority of the House of Representatives voted today to greatly increase the maximum penalties for indecency and profanity on radio and television.

description: DeLUCA--Rose (nee Trivento) on March 10, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Ernest. Loving mother of the late Joan D'Erasmo and Geraldine DeLuca. Cherished grandmother of Russell Aragon, Linda Aragon Papa, Katharine Seizer and Jeffrey Seizer, cherished great grandmother of Nathan and Stephen. Visiting Friday 2-5 and 7-9 p.m. at Louis DeLuca Mayflower Funeral Home, 6022 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:45 a.m. at St. Athanasius R.C. Church. Interment at Calvary Cemetery.

description: Halliburton , the oil services company formerly headed by US Vice-President Dick Cheney, was awarded a $1.2bn (660m) contract in Iraq just three days after Pentagon auditors warned about "systemic" problems in its cost controls.

description: SHEA--Mortimer. Our husband, father and friend

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Rabbis Strike
description: Rabbis protesting salary delays went on strike across Israel, threatening to disrupt services varying from marriages to funerals to the ritual slaughter of livestock. The strike involves more than 3,000 people, including many rabbis, who work at municipal rabbinates and religious councils. The protesters say the government has failed to pay their salaries for months, and in some cases for up to a year. The chief rabbis said they were concerned that the government's failure to pay salaries on time was part of an effort to undermine the authority of the Orthodox rabbinate, which controls many aspects of life in Israel. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Can Plants Survive A Martha Drought?
description: WHEN Barbara Walters interviewed Martha Stewart in November, she didn't ask what kind of tree Ms. Stewart would choose to be, as she has done before with celebrities. It would have come as no surprise if Ms. Stewart had said oak, the strongest and straightest of trees. But she probably has more in common with the apple tree, an American icon with fruit that is alternately sweet and tart and capable of turning up as an old-fashioned dumpling or a fancy tarte Tatin.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Retort To U.S.
description: Syria responded indirectly to United States complaints that it had violated diplomatic protocol by detaining for an hour on Monday a junior American diplomat who was at the scene of a rare human rights demonstration in downtown Damascus. An editorial in a state-run daily questioned why the diplomat was there in the first place and why the State Department had raised questions about the protesters being stopped. The protest lacked a permit, it said, adding ''Was there any prediction or desire to see thousands of Syrians demonstrating against their national authority?'' Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: The Oil Company as Social Worker
description: Siadys Bayuelo, 33, has spent four years urging local authorities to pipe potable water into her home in this dusty town in eastern Venezuela, sparing her the trouble of walking a mile every day to the nearest well.

title: Vote in House Offers a Shield In Obesity Suits
description: Saying overeating is a problem for individuals, not the courts, the House easily approved legislation on Wednesday to bar people from suing restaurants on the ground that their food makes customers fat.

title: Economic Scene; With free trade, what goes abroad usually finds its way back, to everyone's benefit.
description: THE Jan. 31 issue of The Economist described the consequences of high-tech jobs moving overseas.

title: TITAN REDUCES PROFIT TO SAVE MONEY FOR POSSIBLE FINES
description: The Titan Corporation, a maker of military communications equipment, has reduced its fourth-quarter and 2003 profit to set aside cash for potential fines related to reported improper payments to foreign officials. Net income last year was $29.1 million, or 34 cents a share, instead of $32.1 million, or 38 cents, Titan said in its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which was filed yesterday. The S.E.C. and the Justice Department are investigating whether Titan consultants made the payments after receiving money from the company. The Lockheed Martin Corporation, which has agreed to buy Titan, is reviewing whether payments to the consultants were accurately reflected on Titan's books. Shareholders of Titan, which is based in San Diego, are scheduled to vote on Tuesday on the sale to Lockheed. Lockheed is based in Bethesda, Md.

title: Faith and Narcissism in America
description: To the Editor:

title: Empowering the Wi-Fi User to Foil the Snoop
description: FROM parks to coffee bars, wireless networks based on the standard known as Wi-Fi are increasingly letting people go online in public places. And at home, they are providing a wireless new way to allow PC's to share connections to printers and other devices and to the Internet itself.

title: Former Deputy Chancellor Blames Dismissal on Politics
description: Diana Lam, the ousted deputy chancellor of the New York City public schools, said in an interview yesterday that she believed it was largely politics, not a lapse in ethics, behind her abrupt dismissal on Monday.

title: East Meets West, at Least on Paper
description: It was a rare scene of historical redemption on Monday when Sayyed Muhammad Bahr al-Uloum, a 76-year-old religious scholar and one of the first Iraqis imprisoned and exiled by the Baathist regime in the 1960's, presided over the Iraqi Governing Council as it unanimously approved the country's interim Constitution. But beyond the symbolism of Mr. Uloum's role, the document should be seen as an important text for the entire world: in it, East and West meet in an unprecedented manner; it incorporates a salute to Islamic law along with the adoption of federalism and Western-style personal rights for citizens.

title: Senate Raises Bar to Enact New Tax Cuts; Rebuff to Bush
description: Correction Appended

title: Confidence In Shell May Depend On New Blood
description: A committee of Royal Dutch/Shell Group directors who are reviewing the overstatement of oil and natural gas reserves is continuing to back the company's management despite disclosures that senior executives knew of the shortfalls in 2002. A growing number of investors, however, are saying that Shell may ultimately need to bring in outside executives to restore confidence.

title: Target Indicates It May Sell Department Store Chains
description: Ending years of speculation, the Target Corporation announced yesterday that it might jettison both its department store divisions: Mervyn's, with 266 stores, and Marshall Field's, the much-talked-about Midwest chain, led by a glittering, recently renovated Chicago flagship.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank's Profit Falls
description: Julius Baer, one of the few private Swiss banks with publicly listed shares, said that its profit last year fell 55 percent, to 82 million Swiss francs ($63.7 million), the result of efforts to focus on its core asset management business combined with one-time restructuring costs. The company said it reduced operating expenses and increased its assets under management last year. Analysts said the bank's profit was less than expected and its shares fell 7 percent.

title: Pain Threshold for Mets' Cameron to Be Tested
description: Sitting next to each other in the clubhouse or playing next to each other on the field, outfielders Mike Cameron and Cliff Floyd provide a running commentary of their personal competition.

title: People
description: Art Chavez was named president at the New York office of Gerbig, Snell/Weisheimer, part of InChord Communications. He had been executive vice president and director for operations worldwide at Grey Healthcare Advertising, New York, part of the Grey Global Group.

description: EUROPE

title: Saying No to Polio Shots
description: On the eve of total victory, the struggle to wipe polio off the face of the earth is being undermined in Africa by politically motivated misinformation. This crippling disease, which as recently as the late 1980's afflicted 350,000 people annually, was expected to become extinct next year. Last year, fewer than 1,000 people contracted polio. But the decline has not been steady -- there was a spike in 2002, and now eight countries in Africa that had eradicated the disease have had recent outbreaks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALMER, MARCIA S.
description: PALMER--Marcia S. Elegant; strong; composed; stunning; sharp; exquisite; sound; mighty; refined. March 8, 2004. Wife of the late Bernard Palmer; Mother of Robert and Sandee Palmer, Diane and Buddy Flateman, Mickey and Diane Palmer; Grandmother of Cary and Lori, Mindy, Jennie, Sadie, and Dana; loving and loved aunt; great friend to many. For 86 years, the world has been blessed with her grace, wisdom and quiet power. We will go on breathing the air that she made sweet. Service 11 AM, Thursday at Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St.

title: Hong Kong to Borrow, Avoiding New Tax
description: The government here said on Wednesday that it would sell bonds for the first time in more than a decade as local authorities, facing political pressure particularly on democracy issues, shied away from new taxes.

title: A Failed Tourney Is Revived
description: An improving economic picture has been reflected in the world of tournament bridge. Several European events intended for expert fields folded a few years ago when sponsorship failed, but one has now been revived.

description: LEACY--Rose, on March 9th. Beloved wife of the late Miles. Favorite Mommy of Rosanne. Beloved mother of Miles. Mother-in-law of Patricia. Loving grandma of Miles, Adrienne, Maria, Deanna and Caren. Dear aunt of John and Tina. Reposing Joseph Duffy Chapel, 255 9th St, Brooklyn until Friday 8 AM.

title: Fields Leads Xaverian Past Rice
description: Guard Lavance Fields had 14 points and 11 rebounds to lead Xaverian past Rice, 59-44, in the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championships yesterday at Fordham.

title: A Victorian Party For a Slow Slide To an Earthquake
description: Any visit by Netherlands Dance Theater with choreography by Jiri Kylian, its longtime artistic director, is a major event. On Tuesday night in the first of two programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the company offered some stunning surprises.

title: Police Officer Found Guilty In Videotaped Assault Attempt
description: The videotape, played at normal speed and then in slow motion on a small television screen in a Brooklyn courtroom, showed a chaotic scene on a hot August night in 2002 on the edge of Prospect Park: A group of police officers pulled a shirtless, handcuffed man toward a patrol car as a crowd taunted and ran about.

title: Krispy Kreme Says Its Profits Nearly Tripled
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc., the second-largest United States doughnut chain behind Dunkin' Donuts, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit nearly tripled. But average weekly sales declined, helping send the stock down 10 percent for the day.

title: CD's That Still Sound Good Years Later
description: While it can feel like Christmas every day, reviewing music can also be a Sisyphean task. As soon as one week of releases has been listened to and evaluated, a new week begins, bringing with it another half-dozen mail crates full of new music.

description: KORN--Shirley. On March 9, 2004. Beloved wife of Seymour. Loving mother of Rita and Billy. Dear sister of Florence Bograd. She will be deeply missed by all who loved her.

title: Zimbabwe Holds 64 Men Said to Be Part of African Coup Plot
description: Zimbabwean authorities said Wednesday that 64 men on a plane seized Sunday at the airport in Harare, the Zimbabwean capital, were mercenaries on their way to sow conflict in Equatorial Guinea, and threatened to execute them.

title: Oracle Trial Set for June 7
description: The Oracle Corporation's fight with the Justice Department over its proposed $9.4 billion takeover of PeopleSoft Inc. will go to trial June 7, a federal judge said yesterday.

title: Recent Slide in Stocks Steepens, With Dow Falling 160
description: Shares continued their recent slide yesterday as investors seemed increasingly worried about weakness in the economy and the prospects for growth in profits.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Urges Phone Companies to Settle on Rates
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission urged the nation's telephone companies yesterday to sit down for 30 days to settle on the appropriate rates for gaining access to local networks. If they cannot agree, the chairman, Michael K. Powell, said he will propose that the commission adopt interim rules for the use of the networks.

title: Russian Plane Maker Embraces Capitalism
description: In another sign of just how far Russia has changed, Irkut, a formerly secret maker of military airplanes that had spent decades helping the Soviet Union defend itself against the capitalist West, has turned to the stock market to raise cash to buy other companies and develop new planes.

title: Bishop Sees Spiritual Merit In 'Passion'
description: The bishop of Brooklyn says Mel Gibson's ''Passion of the Christ'' bears a ''powerful spiritual message'' and provides images that will forever shape how he contemplates the suffering and crucifixion of Jesus.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Controversy Over Parade
description: Members of the Correction Department's Emerald Society, angered over the demotion of one of their colleagues, have withdrawn an invitation to the correction commissioner, Martin Horn, to march with them in the St. Patrick's Day Parade in Manhattan. A spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the mayor will not march with the correction officers if Mr. Horn, at left, is excluded. The dispute, reported yesterday in Newsday and The Irish Voice, centers on disciplinary action taken in September against Roger Slattery, a warden and an Emerald Society official, who took a $50,000 salary reduction. ''We find ourselves unable to extend the usual invitation,'' said the Irish-American correction officers' group in a letter to Mr. Horn. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Attorney General To Run For Senate
description: Attorney General Ken Salazar, a Democrat, said he would seek the Senate seat of Ben Nighthorse Campbell, who is retiring. Representative Mark Udall, also a Democrat, who had announced his intention to run for the seat, said he would support Mr. Salazar. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: BodyVox, Grown From Pilobolus But Also a Distinctive Departure
description: BodyVox specializes in dance whose humor and imagination clearly show the company's Pilobolus lineage. But the vivid little pieces that rolled out and jounced together like a handful of brightly colored, tangy Jujubes in BodyVox's New York debut on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater were also a distinctive departure from the Pilobolus canon. BodyVox, based in Portland, Ore., approaches dance with a breezy freshness and simplicity that is all its own.

title: Among Cancer Doctors, a Medicare Revolt; New Payment System Spurs Talk of Return to Hospital Care and Old Drugs
description: Years ago, doctors hospitalized cancer patients before giving them chemotherapy, so worried were they about the retching, dehydration and weight loss that the drugs could cause. Now, most doctors treat cancer patients in their offices, allowing them to return home quickly or even go to work.

title: Death Wish
description: Because I've written about the cadavers used in medical research, I am frequently asked if I plan to become one. While I haven't yet signed the forms, I find the idea appealing. I'm an altruistic sort, but more than that I'm cheap -- and the thousands of dollars in savings on funeral expenses is hard to pass up.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BRITAIN: EX-GUANTANAMO PRISONERS FREED Four men who were arrested on their return to Britain from United States military detention at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, were released without charge, police said. Five men returned Tuesday, but one was freed within hours. The other four were arrested under an antiterrorism law, but lawyers and relatives insisted that they were mistakenly caught up in the American campaign against terrorism. The United States government says the roughly 640 prisoners held at Guantanamo are suspected of links to the Taliban or the terror network Al Qaeda. (AP)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Cricket In Pakistan
description: India's cricket team began its first tour of Pakistan in 15 years, another move in increasing people-to-people contacts between the nuclear-armed neighbors. Before its departure, Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee presented the team with a cricket bat that read, ''Win not only the game but hearts also.'' Pakistan is issuing 8,000 visas to Indians who want to watch the matches. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Verdict On Fatal Strike

But Lt. Col. Brian Hilferty, a spokesman for American-led coalition forces in Afghanistan, said the investigation resulted in a change in the American rules of engagement in Afghanistan. title: CONSECO SAYS IT HAS SETTLED S.E.C. ACCOUNTING INQUIRY
description: Conseco, an insurance company that emerged from bankruptcy protection in September, said yesterday that it had settled a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into accounting practices at its former Conseco Finance unit. Conseco, which is based in Carmel, Ind., settled without admitting or denying the regulators' findings and without paying a fine, the company said. The settlement was not related to investigations by regulators into Conseco's former variable annuities business, according to Jim Rosensteele, a company spokesman.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Gas Grills Recalled
description: More than 100,000 gas grills have been recalled because glass covers on the temperature gauges have shattered, federal officials said. The manufacturer is the Grand Hall Enterprise Company, of Taiwan. The grills were sold from January 2002 to November 2003 under the brand name Char-Broil. Char-Broil, of Columbus, Ga., urged owners to call (866) 239-6769 for a free replacement gauge.

title: Shabby, as in Elegant And Also Affordable
description: The expensive Shabby Chic brand, with its fabrics that look like well-worn vintage textiles, has spun off an affordable cotton bedding collection, Simply Shabby Chic, at Target. Rachel Ashwell, the brand's designer, locates its style somewhere between old English elegance and California casual. Sets from twin to California king come in paisleys, stripes and florals, which can be mixed and matched. Lavender Jewel is $39.99 for a twin-size set of two sheets and one pillowcase. A queen-size set is $59.99. At www.target.com or (800) 800-8800 for stores. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: Sounding every bit a candidate for governor, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer gave a detailed critique of New York State last night, covering everything from education to immigration and saying that the state has gone from being a ''blue chip stock that you would tell your grandmother to invest in to being a penny stock at best.''

description: Hard-pressed to fill critical jobs in places like Iraq and Afghanistan, the Army is retraining thousands of forces essential to the cold war, like tank operators and artillerymen, to be military police officers, civil affairs experts and intelligence analysts, positions the Pentagon needs for long-term stabilizing operations.

But as word trickled across the country, dozens of battered women seeking refuge in the United States felt the first stirrings of hope.

title: The Great Indian Dream
description: Nine years ago, as Japan was beating America's brains out in the auto industry, I wrote a column about playing a computer geography game with my daughter, then 9 years old. I was trying to help her with a clue that clearly pointed to Detroit, so I asked her, ''Where are cars made?'' And she answered, ''Japan.'' Ouch.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Exports Decline
description: Canada's exports shrank 4.7 percent in January, largely as a result of a decline in shipments of motor vehicles and parts to the United States, Statistics Canada reported. With imports also falling, the over all trade surplus dipped fractionally to 5.2 billion Canadian dollars ($3.93 billion). The decline in exports was the biggest in nine months, leading some analysts to forecast that the Bank of Canada will lower interest rates next month for the third time this year as a way of putting a brake on the strong Canadian dollar and making exports more competitive.

title: Helsinki Journal; A Word to Finns: 'For Your Own Good, Blow Your Top'
description: Turo Herala is the first to admit that his mission to teach Finns how to get angry and make a scene, or even to feel joy and happiness is, in all likelihood, bound for failure.

description: To some of the people who live and work near them, the trains were an accident waiting to happen. They rumble slowly through a four-mile stretch of Queens and Brooklyn, often at night, with no gates or fences at the road intersections. Sometimes cars screech to a halt to avoid hitting them in the darkness, several neighbors said.

title: Revive Your Faded Beauty, Or Tone Down Your Lipstick
description: Current versions of Adobe Photoshop, including the consumer edition called Photoshop Elements, can automatically correct minor color or exposure problems in pictures. But dealing with faded photographs or those with extreme color casts is another story. Correcting those kinds of mistakes is often time-consuming and can require specialized skills.

description: COGAN--Arrial Seelye. Age 74, died on March 9, 2004. Widow of the late James R. Cogan, she is survived by her children, Sarah E., George W. and Julia C. Finney, and nine grandchildren. The report was from The Associated Press, which later transmitted a correction saying that according to HBO, the idea was still being discussed and that Michael Patrick King, executive producer, had not said there were no plans for a movie. The correction went astray at The Times.

title: A Forgotten Star Helps Lift No. 1 Suffolk to 31-0
description: Mo Manning had been away from basketball for nearly five years. There was the occasional pickup game in a park or a gym, but for the most part he avoided it. There were too many questions from guys he had known when he was a star high school player, all-Long Island three years in a row, and the 1997 Suffolk County player of the year. But after leaving Bridgehampton High School without a diploma, he tried a prep school and left there without a diploma. There was no college basketball in his future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISHMAN, MARGARET
description: TISHMAN -- Margaret. The Board and Staff of AIPAC express our profound sorrow at the passing of a devoted proIsrael activist and friend of Israel, Peggy Tishman. Bernice Manocherian, President-Elect Howard Kohr, Exec Director Michael Sachs, North East Regional Director

title: New Haitian Prime Minister Arrives, Vowing to Restore Unity
description: Grard Latortue, the economist and former diplomat chosen by a United States-backed council to lead Haiti out of its political crisis, arrived in the country from southern Florida on Wednesday, promising to reconcile bitterly opposed factions and bring peace and prosperity to a nation long wracked by poverty and brutalized by generations of dictators.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTFRIED, TED M.
description: GOTTFRIED--Ted M. Age 75. Died March 7, 2004. A lifelong New Yorker, he was the author of over 100 books ranging from racy adult fiction to young adult non-fiction, including a notable series on the Holocaust. He worked for social justice, first in the civil rights and anti-war movements, recently in the peace movement. He was an avid chess player, playing for the Stuyvesant Town Chess Club. He was a founding member of the National Writers' Union. A world wide traveler, he also enjoyed kayaking and vacationing in Vermont. He is survived by his wife Harriet, five children, Julie, Daniel, Katherine, Toby and Valerie, two stepdaughters, Melanie and Lisa, twelve grand children and many friends. He will be greatly missed. Memorial service will be held Saturday, March 13th at All Souls Unitarian Church in New York at 11AM. Memorial donations may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: For Mayor, Accountability Poses Hurdles
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has repeatedly said that he alone should be held accountable for whatever happens within the Department of Education. After an embarrassing scandal that has cost the department a deputy chancellor and its top lawyer, it seems that many people will be willing to take him up on the offer.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cosmetics Maker Rescued
description: The Industrial Revitalization Corporation, a government agency established last year to help debt-ridden companies, approved a rescue package of 366 billion yen ($3.3 billion) for the cosmetics and pharmaceutical maker Kanebo Ltd. Under the bailout plan, the revitalization corporation will get an 86 percent stake in a new subsidiary made up of the main cosmetics operation of Kanebo, the most valuable part of the company. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: Marshall Frady, a political diarist of the South in transition and the author of a widely read biography of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, died on Tuesday at his home in Greenville, S.C. He was 64.

title: The Internet and Political Campaigns
description: Last Sunday, CBS News Sunday Morning broadcast my report on the Internets effect on this years presidential elections. The story described such inventions as blogs (Web logs, or journals), meetups (local special-interest groups, held at bars or restaurants, organized at Meetup.com), and MoveOn.org (a liberal political-action group that tries to merge thousands of small contributions into large, visible actions).

title: Robots That Build (But Still Won't Do Windows)
description: IN a laboratory in Los Angeles early this year, a robot armed with a concrete pump built its first wall. Just a small wall, about a yard wide, a foot high and an inch thick, but beautifully formed in a graceful oval sweep.

title: Scientist In Plague Case Is Sentenced To Two Years
description: An expert on plague who caused a bioterrorism scare in January 2003 when he reported plague bacteria missing from his laboratory at Texas Tech University was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison even though a jury had cleared him of the most serious charges.

title: Soft Money Slinks Back
description: We are now engaged in the first federal election contest under the new campaign finance law prohibiting open-ended donations from corporations, unions and wealthy individuals in federal elections. Already, political insiders are carving a giant loophole that the Federal Election Commission must swiftly close. Otherwise, the system will be flooded again with the large and politically destructive contributions the new law was meant to stop.

title: Sharon and Palestinian Prime Minister Prepare for First Meeting
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and his Palestinian counterpart, Ahmed Qurei, intend to hold their first meeting next week, with the talks likely to focus on a possible Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip, Palestinian and Israeli officials said Wednesday.

title: Mayor Bloomberg's Commitment Issue
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg and marriage do not go together like a horse and carriage. He is divorced. He has said that he doesn't see matrimony again in his future. He doesn't officiate at weddings at Gracie Mansion, a previously time-honored tradition for mayors of New York. And it seems that he has a problem committing on the issue of gay marriage.

description: When the European Union expands eastward this spring, it will end the 65-year divide caused by the 20th century's hot and cold wars and shift the union from a plush club of 15 like-minded nations into a street bazaar of countries differing in wealth, stature and outlook.

description: Executives from Viacom Inc. and the EchoStar Communications Corporation said yesterday that they were close to ending a dispute that has kept the signals of Viacom's 16 CBS stations and its 10 cable channels, including MTV and Nickelodeon, off EchoStar's satellite TV service since early Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDSAY, MARY
description: LINDSAY--Mary. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center Theater are saddened by the death of Mary Lindsay, loving and beloved wife of Founding Chairman, John V. Lindsay. Mary was such an extraordinary and vivacious person whose enthusiasm swept away all obstacles and impediments that life strew in her path. She reveled in John's success in bringing this theater back to life and was an avid first nighter here. Condolences and sympathy to Katharine, Margaret, Anne, John Jr., & the grandchildren. John B. Beinecke, Chairman John Chalsty, President Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLANSKY, DR. OLEH M.
description: WOLANSKY--Dr. Oleh M., 89, of Kerhonkson, NY. He was born April 15, 1914, in Ukraine, the son of the late Pavlo and Haylna Vytvytska Wolansky. Dr. Wolansky had been employed as a psychiatrist for the New York State Dept. of Mental Hygiene as a hospital administrator and served as Director of Letchworth Village Developmental Center for 10 years. He was a distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Assoc. and past President of Ukrainian Medical Association of North America. He was also a composer and conductor. He was active in PLAST and many other Ukrainian organizations. He was married to the late Ludmyla Shara Wolansky, who predeceased him June 22, 2001. Surviving are two daughters and three sons. The Holy Sacrifice of the Divine Liturgy will be celebrated 10:00 AM, Saturday, March 13th, at Holy Trinity Ukrainian Catholic Church, Kerhonkson, NY. Burial will be in Holy Spirit Ukrainian Cemetery, Hamptonburg, NY. The family will receive friends at Humiston Funeral Home, Friday, March 12, 2004, from 2-4 PM and 6-8 PM.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Corpse Exhibitor Cleared
description: A German doctor who displays preserved human corpses in a traveling exhibit has been cleared of charges that he illegally obtained some of the bodies from China and Kyrgyzstan. Prosecutors said the doctor, Gunter von Hagens, had purchased the bodies from their legal owners. German news reports said some of the bodies had been those of executed Chinese prisoners, a charge Dr. von Hagens denied. Mark Landler (NYT)

Adored grandmother of Dr. Deena and Rabbi Samuel Zimmerman, Drs Matthew and Sharon Cohen, Dr. Jessica and Richard Langer and ten great grandchildren. Aunt Sara to generations of the Cohen, Rubin, Novick and Posner clans and Bubby to one and all. A lifelong Zionist and Eternal Optimist. Longterm president of Borough Park Hadassah. She lived a long, full, productive life with great joy in every minute. Funeral Thursday March 11 at Jeffers Funeral Home, 4620 Ft. Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn. Shiva will be at the home of Charles Cohen. Donations in her memory to Hadassah.
