title: Like a Trip to Machu Picchu Without the Thin Air
description: The Cholita Bar and Grill, a Peruvian restaurant, has opened on Smith Street in the restaurant row of Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. The owner, Martin Tisoc, is from Cuzco, Peru, the former Inca capital near the ruins at Machu Picchu. And much of the dcor at Cholita reflects ancient Peruvian culture. Mr. Tisoc and his brother Fernando run Cholita and Coco Roco, which opened six years ago in Park Slope, Brooklyn. They have acted as designers for both places and as chefs. The extensive Cholita renovation and decoration took a year and a half.

title: Sober Intent And a Touch Of Calm Youth
description: Christoph Eschenbach brought the Philadelphia Orchestra to Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, and judging from the emotionally weighty scores by Schoenberg and Mahler with which he framed his program he clearly had the most sober intentions. So he was taking a chance when he invited Lang Lang along as the soloist in Beethoven's Fourth Concerto.

title: Publishers, Note: Novelist Available
description: Martin Amis has a story in the current issue of The New Yorker, a twisted and profane tale of a despot's body double in the midst of a collapsing regime. It is in many respects a typically Amis affair, an exercise in extreme fiction rescued from puerility by taut, cutting prose. But in the wake of a novel that was panned by critics and that concluded his American publishing contract, the story conveys another message: Mr. Amis is alive and kicking and, in case anyone's interested, up for grabs.

title: A Departing Bush Ally Hails an Ascendant Spain
description: Years ago, Prime Minister Jos Mara Aznar of Spain was called Mr. Nobody because he seemed so pinched and boring. More recently, opponents have branded him a ''vassal'' of President Bush for embracing and defending the American-led war in Iraq.

title: Mountain Resorts Foster Togetherness in Families
description: Brian Fairbank, owner of the Jiminy Peak Resort in the Berkshire Mountains in Massachusetts, knew something was up when three brothers from Long Island walked into his office and wanted to pay cash for adjoining condominiums at the foot of his mountain.

title: A Widening Inquiry Focuses on Officers Tied to Drug Money
description: The police corruption investigation that began when a detective and his retired partner were seen taking $169,000 from a drug courier has grown to include as many as 10 other active or retired officers, several people with knowledge of the investigation said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Programming Tools To Be Delayed
description: Microsoft said yesterday that its new SQL database server software and Visual Studio tools for building programs would be delayed until the first half of 2005 to ensure they work right. Microsoft wants to be certain that the software, to be named SQL Server 2005, is a ''quality release,'' and will delay it to issue a third test version in the second half of the year, said Tom Rizzo, product management director for SQL. Product delays are hampering Microsoft's efforts to win more sales of two-year licenses that entitle users to updates, analysts have said. Mr. Rizzo said the delay would not hurt Microsoft's database software sales because SQL Server 2000, released in September 2000, is still selling well.

title: Powell Wavers on Run for Rangel's Seat in Congress
description: Adam Clayton Powell 4th, an assemblyman from East Harlem with longstanding Congressional aspirations, has formed an exploratory committee, conducted several fund-raising events and met with supporters and advisers throughout Harlem. But he still seems somewhat tentative about whether he will run in this year's Democratic primary against Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of New York's Congressional delegation.

title: CANADIAN COMPANY TO BUY U.S. BUSINESS FOR $858 MILLION
description: The CGI Group, one of Canada's biggest computer services companies, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy American Management Systems for $858 million. As part of the transaction, CACI International will buy the United States assets of American Management's military and intelligence unit for $415 million, CGI said. An undetermined number of job cuts are expected, CGI said. CGI is based in Montreal. American Management is based in Fairfax, Va. CACI International is based in Arlington, Va.

title: A Lightning Rod on Gay Marriage, and Her Split Town
description: Representative Marilyn Musgrave must surely have done other things in her life besides sponsor a proposed amendment to the Constitution to ban same-sex marriage.

title: Spain Struggles to Absorb Worst Terrorist Attack in Its History
description: MADRID, March 11 - Ten bombs ripped through four commuter trains in Madrid during the morning rush hour on Thursday, killing at least 192 people and wounding more than 1,400 in the deadliest terrorist attack on a European target since World War II.

title: BARR SAYS SOME ANALYST FORECASTS MAY BE TOO HIGH
description: Barr Pharmaceuticals said fiscal 2004 profit might fall short of some analysts' forecasts as it spent more to market the Seasonale oral contraceptive. Barr shares fell 6.3 percent. The company, which is based in Pomona, N.Y., said it was not changing its forecast of $3.14 to $3.28 a share, excluding any one-time costs, for the year ending in June, but the $3.27 average estimate reported by Thomson Financial may be high. Barr may reach the high end of its estimate if Seasonale sales are better than expected, the chief executive, Bruce L. Downey, said. Stock in Barr fell $4.97, to $74.08 a share.

title: $575 MILLION INSURANCE PAYMENT TO HALLIBURTON
description: The Halliburton Company can receive $575 million from Equitas to settle asbestos-related insurance claims against underwriters at Lloyd's of London, a federal judge has ruled. Judge Judith K. Fitzgerald of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Pittsburgh approved the accord, resolving Halliburton's claims against Lloyd's underwriters that are reinsured by Equitas. The agreement is part of a plan by Halliburton to set up a $4.2 billion trust to resolve its current and future asbestos liabilities. The accord covers 25 percent of the $2.3 billion of insurance proceeds that Halliburton expects to use to help finance the trust. Two units of Halliburton have filed for bankruptcy protection as part of a plan to settle asbestos claims.

title: A Buddhist Floral Aesthetic by Way of California Dreaming
description: Aviva Stanoff, right, has created in her studio in Dumbo, which has a view of the Manhattan Bridge, a hand-decorated line of home accessories. Her aesthetic combines California 70's hippie chic with summers tending flowers near a Buddhist temple in Japan, where her grandfather was a priest. ''My designs are a fusion of the natural and urban,'' she said. Glass vases (8 inches high by 6 inches wide and 2 inches deep), far right, are $90, in patterns like Tranquil (rear) and Stargazer (front). The embossed hand-painted silk pillow on which she leans is $225. Silk throws and lacquered wooden trays are also available. Orders from Ms. Stanoff at (718) 422-1262 or information at www.avivastanoff.com.

title: Monmouth Gains Its Third Bid Since '96
description: Tyler Azzarelli, an unsung sophomore guard from Tampa, Fla., rose to the biggest occasion of his college career Wednesday night with a 19-point, 4-steal performance that led Monmouth to a 67-55 defeat of Central Connecticut State for the Northeast Conference tournament championship and an automatic bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: MetroStars Draft Pick Signs in Norway
description: Olivier Occean, who was drafted by the MetroStars in the third round (60th over all) in January, signed a three-year deal with the Norwegian club Odd Grenland yesterday. The MetroStars, who open their Major League Soccer season early next month, had taken Occean with them to Spain for La Manga tournament, where he had played well. Jack Bell

title: ImClone Sues Founder Over Taxes Owed on Stock
description: ImClone Systems sued its founder and former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, yesterday, contending that he owed the company more than $21 million in taxes from personal sales of ImClone stock.

title: The Camera Never Lies, But the Software Can
description: WHEN John Knoll created Photoshop in 1989, he knew he was designing an image-editing program that could be used in good ways and bad. But even Mr. Knoll, who wrote the software with his brother, Tom, was unprepared for how outlandish photo manipulation would become. ''When we worked on it, mostly we saw the possibilities, the cool things,'' said Mr. Knoll, 41. ''Not how it would be abused.''

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: CALL FOR MORE NATO TROOPS President Hamid Karzai requested additional NATO troops as a security backup for elections in June. His appeal came ahead of a conference at which NATO defense officials will start pooling troops and equipment to establish civilian-military reconstruction teams in two northern towns. NATO took command of the International Security Assistance Force in Kabul last August.    (Reuters)

title: Eating Too Much? Time to Pay the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Ruth Ellington Boatwright, 88, The Sister of Duke Ellington
description: Ruth Ellington Boatwright, Duke Ellington's only sibling, who for many years took care of his business affairs, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: 2 People Die As 12 Vehicles Pile Up On Turnpike
description: Two people were killed yesterday afternoon in a 12-vehicle pileup on the New Jersey Turnpike that delayed thousands of drivers during the evening rush, a turnpike spokesman said.

title: Group Sues Federal Agency Over 9/11 Health Hazards
description: The health of tens of thousands of people who live and work in Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn has been endangered by the way federal officials mishandled the environmental hazards caused by the collapse of the World Trade Center, according to a lawsuit filed yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: World Briefing: Middle East
description: SAUDI ARABIA: A HUMAN RIGHTS FIRST King Fahd approved the establishment of The National Society for Human Rights, the first nongovernmental rights group in Saudi Arabia, the state-run news agency SPA reported. The association's chairman, Dr. Abdullah bin Salih Alobaid, said it has 42 members, including 10 women, and that its guiding principles were rooted in the Koran, Sharia Islamic law and Saudi Arabian law. The charter stipulates protection of human rights and combating torture, violence and intolerance. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Two Setbacks for Advocates of Same-Sex Marriage
description: BOSTON, March 11  In near-simultaneous setbacks to advocates of same-sex marriage, Massachusetts legislators gave preliminary approval this afternoon to a state amendment banning gay marriages while the California Supreme Court ordered the City of San Francisco to halt gay marriages.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Suit Involving Fire Radios Is Dismissed
description: A federal judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit yesterday that accused the City of New York City and Motorola of providing firefighters with faulty radio equipment that was in use on Sept. 11, 2001. Representatives of 12 firefighters who died in the collapse of the World Trade Center filed the suit. They claimed that the faulty radios deprived the firefighters of information that could have saved their lives. Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court dismissed the case, saying that the plaintiffs waived their right to sue when they decided to participate in the Victim Compensation Fund. Susan M. Saulny (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with the continuation of an article in The Metro Section about the Chemical Waste Management landfill in Model City, N.Y., was published in error. It was a duplicate of the one on the section's front showing a worker in a hazardous materials suit, not a view from the top of the landfill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, JACK
description: KLEIN--Jack. 95, recently of Amityville, died peacefully at his home with his children at his side. Devoted father to Joan Tell, Neal and wife Cyla, his grandchildren David Reader, Cheryl and Don Freund, Jeffrey and Cara, Michael, Jonathan and Alan, and his great-grandchildren, Jacqui, Kelly, Stephen, Phoebe and Ross. He lived a life devoted to his family, giving help to whoever needed it. First in his family to graduate from City College at night, a proud CPA. He touched and shaped all our lives.

title: Sports of The Times; It's a Curious Way To Play Truth or Dare
description: BEFORE interrogating the union boss Donald Fehr on baseball's toothless drug policy, Senator John McCain all but asked Fehr if he wanted a cigarette -- like the Marlboros that Gene Orza has declared are no worse than steroids.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about American pressure on the International Atomic Energy Agency to condemn Iran's nuclear program misidentified the nation that has insisted its nuclear program is peaceful and has demanded a stop to the agency's "propaganda war." That nation is Iran. (Libya has admitted to a nuclear weapons program and, as the article stated, has since cooperated with the agency in dismantling that program.) ( Go to Article )

title: Eating Too Much? Time to Pay the Price
description: To the Editor:

title: Serious About Settings In 26 Fraught Minutes
description: A 26-minute documentary by Judy Fiskin, ''50 Ways to Set the Table,'' follows the judges of the 2001 tablescaping competition at the Los Angeles County Fair as they examine and score table settings. The categories that year were valentine, magic, sports, vineyard, country Christmas and ''The Lion King,'' below. Among the highlights are the judge's comments, which include, ''The cow skulls don't say 'Christmas!' '' These table settings will not be showing up at Le Cirque, but the competitors are serious. ''We had someone a few years ago that had died, and her family actually came and set up her table,'' one judge says. The film, part of a group of shorts titled ''Real People,'' will be shown at the 11th New York Underground Film Festival on Saturday and Monday; information from www.nyuff.com. Tickets are $8.50 at the box office at Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue (Second Street).

title: Bush Plans Talk on Jobs At L.I. Plant
description: President George W. Bush plans to visit Long Island today, and his first stop -- a small but growing company called U.S.A. Industries in Bay Shore -- is aimed at underscoring administration efforts to revive the economy.

title: Chvez Says U.S. Is Fueling His Enemies
description: Under United States pressure to allow a recall referendum against his rule, President Hugo Chvez has in recent days counterattacked, charging that the Bush administration is trying to oust him by aiding his adversaries, including those who briefly overthrew him in a 2002 coup.

title: Sorry, Wrong Number
description: DOROTHY NEPJUK, an 80-year-old widow and retired printer, never takes her car out of Thunder Bay, Ontario, let alone on the 14-hour trek to Toronto. So Mrs. Nepjuk was puzzled just over a year ago when a bill arrived from the 407 Express Toll Route, a highway that skirts the western and northern fringes of Toronto.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deutsche Telekom Posts 4th-Quarter Loss
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's leading telecommunications group, posted a fourth-quarter loss yesterday because it had to write off 442 million euros ($544 million) on Germany's road toll system, a project being developed largely by Deutsche Telekom and DaimlerChrysler. The company's net loss was 364 million euros ($448 million), up from 77 million euros a year ago. Pretax earnings rose 3.4 percent to 4.5 billion euros while sales remained at 14.55 billion euros, as growth at T-Mobile International, especially at T-Mobile USA, balanced dropping revenues at the group's fixed-line unit, T-Com. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Finding the Ideal Jury, Keeping Fingers Crossed
description: WATCH the body language of jurors as they file back into a courtroom after deliberations. Eyes bright, postures erect, smiles broad? You know the verdict. These people are about to give a defendant really good news.

title: Treatment Is Seen to Cut Breast Cancer Recurrence
description: Drugs that completely block estrogen can lower the risk of breast cancer recurrence in postmenopausal women after surgery, according to the latest study to suggest that some women can improve their chances of recovering from breast cancer with aromatase inhibitors.

title: National Briefing | South: Texas: Sheriff Is Indicted
description: Sheriff Jim Bowles of Dallas County, who was defeated Tuesday in a primary election, was indicted by a state grand jury on Wednesday, accused of misapplication of more than $100,000 in campaign funds. Mr. Bowles, a Republican, had been under investigation by a special prosecutor for accepting gifts from a businessman who won a contract to run a county jail. Sheriff Weldon Lewis of Denton County was charged with perjury. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLER, JEAN
description: STOLER--Jean. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with sorrow the passing of the mother of our good friend, Michael R. Stoler, a past chairman of our Men's Division and a current member of its executive board. To Michael and his family, we extend our deep sympathy. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Neil A. Clark, Chairman Men's Division

title: Diamonds Find a Friend in the Semiconductor Sector
description: AS anyone who watches the Academy Awards knows, diamonds are still the most glamorous of gemstones. But as laboratory techniques for synthesizing diamonds improve, the stones may one day be found not only on movie stars, but also in lasers, light-emitting diodes, integrated circuits and other nondecorative but highly practical applications.

title: 2 American Civilians Killed by Fake Iraqi Policemen
description: Two American civilians and their Iraqi interpreter were killed on Tuesday night in what American officials described as a ''targeted killing'' by terrorists posing as Iraqi police officers. They were the first American civilians working for the American occupation authority to be killed since American forces toppled Saddam Hussein last April.

title: Where the Boldface Bunk
description: Correction Appended

title: Photo Forgery
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Building Confidence
Gallic Treats
description: Images from "Rendez-Vous With French Cinema," a film series at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center through March 21.

title: A Tour of Miami's Art Collections
Explosions in Madrid
description: Powerful explosions rocked three Madrid train stations Thursday just days before Spain's general elections.

title: Mourning in Spain
description: Millions streamed into streets and city squares in a nationwide cry against the violence that left nearly 200 people dead in Madrid.

title: Bombings in Madrid
description: Ten bombs exploded during the morning rush hour in three commuter train stations in Madrid, killing at least 192 people and wounding more than 1,400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLER, JEAN
description: STOLER--Jean. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute express our sincere sorrow at the passing of the mother of Michael R. Stoler, a current and loyal member of the Board. We extend our sympathy to Michael and the entire Stoler family. John N. Kastanis, President & CEO William A. Perlmuth, Chairman of the Board

title: The Thriller According To Mamet
description: It seems unlikely that David Mamet, one of the most admired American playwrights of the past 30 years, will ever become a great filmmaker. But that may not be his ambition. On the evidence of his last few pictures -- the show-business satire ''State and Main,'' the bluntly titled ''Heist'' and now ''Spartan,'' which opens today nationwide -- Mr. Mamet appears to be more interested in professional mastery than in the production of masterpieces. For most of its running time ''Spartan,'' a political thriller with the lonely, aching, slightly musty soul of a film noir, is a vigorous and engrossing genre exercise that manages the difficult trick of being both logically meticulous and genuinely surprising. Its elaborately implausible story gestures now and then toward an idea, but the movie's main concern is technique.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Vote On Judicial Candidate
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee split along party lines in recommending William J. Haynes II to the full Senate for a seat on the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said that as general counsel of the Department of Defense, Mr. Haynes had helped formulate legal arguments to justify the detentions at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, and plans for military tribunals of some prisoners there.

title: Julian Stanczak -- 'Master of Op Art: Highlights of the Past 40 Years'
description: Stefan Stux Gallery

title: New Security Worries for Europes Sprawling Rail System
description: LONDON, March 12  Senior European intelligence and security officials have expressed increasing concern in recent months that terrorists would make targets of the still relatively open rail networks of a region that depends heavily on passenger rail transport.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Divorce Legalized
description: Congress approved a new marriage code that legalizes divorce. The revised law permits couples to dissolve marriages after a year of separation and eliminates a loophole that had allowed citizens, including President Ricardo Lagos, who campaigned for the new code, to obtain ''civil annulments.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: 'Maestro'
description: Directed by Josell Ramos

title: Immigrants' Businesses Are Seen As Crucial to City's Economy
description: An Asian-American businessman wanted to borrow money to import bear gallbladders, but all the banks he approached turned him down. ''They said, 'What, are you crazy?''' recalled Joyce O. Moy, director of the Small Business Development Center of LaGuardia Community College, who was on a lively panel yesterday on how the city can better tap the economic potential of immigrant entrepreneurs.

title: Back to the 1960's On Tiny Wheels
description: THE racecar driver Tom Kanan was feeling right at home. Striding toward his flashy 1997 Panoz GTR in the pit area of TK Motorsports Park in Middletown, N.Y., he was hailed by his fellow racers, who paused from tuning their motors to chat about gear ratios. Though Mr. Kanan, 39, is a disciplined, factory-sponsored driver who finished second at last year's national championships, no one was surprised to see him arrive at the track on foot, wearing bedroom slippers.

title: Online Book Clubs as Lit 101 Fun
description: Oprah calls him Gabo, just as she might on her show. ''You've started Gabo's masterpiece, and you love it!'' says a message on the part of her Web site devoted to her current book club choice. Since she announced on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' in January that she would be reading Gabriel Garca Mrquez's ''One Hundred Years of Solitude,'' the book club's online counterpart has nudged viewers to ''read along with Oprah,'' pacing them to finish by the end of this month.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Truck Recall
description: Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus, an affiliate of DaimlerChrysler and Mitsubishi Motors, said faulty design might have been a cause in several accidents, including a fatal one, involving wheels falling off moving trucks. Mitsubishi Fuso, which was spun off from Mitsubishi Motors last year, said it would recall 45,000 trucks to repair defective wheels. More than 50 accidents involving Mitsubishi trucks losing wheels have been reported since 1992. Mitsubishi Motors has suffered a sharp decline in sales since a series of recalls beginning in 2000. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about advertisers' and agencies' criticism of the way they buy commercial time on networks, misstated a finding of a survey of members of the Association of National Advertisers. Respondents proposed beginning the ''up front market'' in the fall, when most marketers have a better idea of their ad budgets for the coming year. (May is the current beginning month.)

title: National Briefing: Plains
description: OKLAHOMA: JURY SEATED IN BOMBING CASE A jury of six men and six women were seated to hear the capital murder trial of Terry L. Nichols in the bombing of the Oklahoma City federal building in 1995. Six alternate jurors were also chosen. Mr. Nichols, 48, is being tried in a state court in McAlester in the murders of 161 of the 168 people who died in the blast. He was convicted in 1997 of federal charges in the case and sentenced to life in prison. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Imagining Business Without Stewart
description: After a week of negotiations with lawyers, Martha Stewart could learn as early as today whether she will be allowed to continue to be a creative influence at the company that bears her name, a person briefed on the talks said yesterday. But such a role may not be acceptable to shareholders, business partners, shoppers and securities regulators.

title: Senator Lott Says He Will Back Drug Imports
description: Supporters of legislation to allow imports of low-cost prescription drugs gained a significant convert on Thursday when Senator Trent Lott, the former Republican leader, said he would back the effort.

title: Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller
description: Luhring Augustine

title: Bombs Fall, and an Affair Is Disrupted
description: Jake Heggie's ''Dead Man Walking'' has been the surprise opera hit of this new millennium. With a taut libretto by Terrence McNally, based on the book by Sister Helen Prejean and the subsequent film, the opera tells the gripping tale of a condemned man, his relationship with a sympathetic nun and his inexorable execution.

title: State Blocks Klein's First Choice for Deputy
description: State education officials dealt a sharp rebuke to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday for relying on non-educators to run the New York City public schools, saying Albany would not approve Chancellor Joel I. Klein's choice for the system's top instructional post because she lacked the required superintendent's license.

title: 'Distant'
description: Directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan

title: Weekender | Frenchtown, N.J.
description: THE last 12 miles of the drive from New York to Frenchtown is a quintessential country scene, with rolling hills, quaint farmhouses, hayfields and the occasional yellow tractor-crossing sign. But then a dip in the two-lane road reveals something quite different: a tiny river town that bustles on weekends with tourists roaming antique shops, dining at restaurants and playing, weather permitting, in the Delaware River.

title: Spain Struggles to Cope As the Equation of Terror Changes in an Instant
description: Dr. Eduardo Asensio, a rescue worker, has waded in death for two decades, but none of it prepared him for the torment he saw at the height of rush hour Thursday morning.

title: Irving Penn -- 'Present Concerns'
description: Pace/MacGill Gallery

title: Brooklyn Grade School Closed After Asbestos Contamination
description: A Brooklyn elementary school was ordered closed yesterday after workers contaminated an area in it with asbestos while replacing the gymnasium floor, the Department of Education said.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

title: Economic Forecasts
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.+ means discounted tickets were available at the Theater Development Fund's TKTS booth for performances last Friday and Saturday nights.++ means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth for last Friday night only.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on March 4 about a planned UPN reality show tentatively called ''Amish in the City'' misspelled the Pennsylvania Dutch term for a rite of passage in which some teenagers experiment with the outside world. Authorities on Amish tradition use various renditions of the dialect, but the most common version is rumspringa, not Rumpspringa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIVA, FRANK
description: RIVA--Frank. The Board of Directors, staff, membership and participants of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children, New York City Chapter, wish to convey their condolences to the family of Frank Riva, one of the founders of the Association, and longtime member. Frank, You remain in our memory for the depth of your commitment. Frank Riva is survived by his wife, Margaret, who was for many years a member of the original Board of Directors of the Association, and three children: Frank, Jr., Lorraine and Carol. Funeral Mass will be held Saturday, 11 AM, March 13, at Our Lady of Peace in Lynbrook, NY. Genevieve O'Neil, President Michael Goldfarb, Exec. Dir

title: BBDO West Wins Lottery Account
description: The California Lottery Commission in Sacramento has tentatively awarded BBDO West in Los Angeles and San Francisco, part of the BBDO Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, a four-year contract to handle its general account, with total billings estimated at $100 million. The selection requires ratification at a commission meeting next month to become final.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Three Men Held On Weapons Charges
description: Prosecutors charged three men yesterday with selling illegal weapons, forged credit cards and counterfeit brand-name goods out of a College Point furniture store, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said. The men were identified as Joe Sonenfelt, 35, the owner of the store; Lawrence Decker, 53; and Joe Morales, 51. The three were arrested after police officers executed a search warrant at the store, on College Point Boulevard, and discovered weapons including a machine gun, a machete, a sword and dozens of rounds of ammunition, prosecutors said. The officers also found about 500 counterfeit DVD's and hundreds of counterfeit brand-name handbags, prosecutors said. The men could each face up to seven years in prison Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: St. Patrick's Reminder For Firefighters
description: New York City firefighters are being reminded by letter to be on their best behavior on St. Patrick's Day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The letter is being sent by the Fire Department and the two firefighters' unions, the Uniformed Firefighters Association and the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, in the wake of several embarrassing department incidents involving alcohol. ''We're all a little bit Irish on that day,'' Mr. Bloomberg said, ''but in this day and age in particular, we just wanted to take the preventive step of reminding people that their conduct is something that everybody else sees, and that the bravest are role models for our young people and for everybody else.'' Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend last Friday about the New York City Opera's current production of ''Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street,'' associated a production erroneously with Beverly Sills's role in bringing popular musicals to the company when she was general director. The musical ''110 in the Shade'' was staged in 1992 when the general director was Christopher Keene, her successor, though she had made arrangements for it.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Computer Associates' Debt Rating Reduced
description: Computer Associates International's debt rating was cut below investment grade yesterday by Moody's Investors Service, which cited a federal government inquiry into how the company accounts for sales. Computer Associates, a business software maker based in Islandia, N.Y., had its senior unsecured credit rating lowered one level to Ba1 from Baa3, and its short-term rating cut to Not Prime from Prime-3, Moody's said. Shares fell 77 cents, to $26.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Maker's Chairman To Quit
description: AstraZeneca, the drug maker, said its chairman, Percy Barnevik, who helped create the company in a 1999 merger, would leave its board, the fourth he has quit since investors protested his retirement package from the engineering company ABB Ltd. AstraZeneca said that Mr. Barnevik, 63, would step down at the annual meeting on April 29. Louis Schweitzer, 61, the chairman and chief executive of Renault, has been nominated to succeed him.

title: 10 Bombs Shatter Trains in Madrid, Killing 192
description: Ten bombs ripped through four commuter trains in Madrid during the morning rush hour on Thursday, killing at least 192 people and wounding more than 1,400 in the deadliest terrorist attack on a European target since World War II.

title: 2 Iraqi Women Working for U.S. Are Shot to Death in Taxi
description: A day after two American civilians and their Iraqi translator were killed in a roadside ambush, two Iraqi washerwomen working for American forces were attacked by masked gunmen and shot to death, police officials said Thursday.

title: You Want Me To Put My Shoes Where?
description: For anyone who has flown recently, chances are that the airport security checkpoint -- that travel spot where anxious passengers meet guards and their equipment -- didn't provide a very nice experience. Surely there has to be a better way for the paraphernalia on one's person (or in one's person: think pacemaker) to mesh with instruments and instructions that are supposed to ward off trouble. While the ordinary goods of daily life receive exacting attention from industrial designers, ergonomic experts and human behavior analysts, airport security artifacts are the products of casual indifference. The stuff is terrible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, SARAH
description: COHEN--Sarah. The Mohegan Park Jewish Center joins the family of Sarah Cohen in mourning her passing.

title: Confronting Rape in the Military
description: An Air Force general who took it upon himself to look into the festering problem of sexual assault in the military has come up with a deeply troubling picture of his command: scores of rape accusations, a rising trend of reported abuses and the most basic shortcomings in tracking the crime and attending to its victims. ''I found it disturbing; we've got to take this on,'' said the general, William Begert, commander of Pacific Air Forces, in an interview about the results of the study he had ordered.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: A young man approached the man seating people in the dining room at Junior's, on Flatbush Avenue Extension in downtown Brooklyn, a week ago and said he was there to meet his mother. The young man was wearing a letter jacket decorated with old N.B.A. logos and a matching cap. ''She's a large woman,'' he said, putting his arms out a foot or so from his sides. ''Big woman.''

title: A Fresh Look At Palladio On Paper
description: A pen-and-ink drawing of a palace in Venice is one of the many treasures that the Bard Graduate Center in Manhattan will show beginning on Thursday, when it opens ''The Devonshire Inheritance: Five Centuries of Collecting at Chatsworth.'' The drawing, 18 by 42 inches, is by the Mannerist architect Andrea Palladio (1508-1580) and is a proposal for a new Doge's Palace in Venice. The original palace burned in 1577 and had to be rebuilt. Palladio's drew a design for a new one that was never used.

title: Ground Zero, Madrid

They were also a reminder that terrorism is a worldwide threat and that fighting it is not America's problem alone. Combating terrorism effectively requires the fullest possible international cooperation, especially in intelligence, law enforcement and the tracking of terrorist finances. Most of the hard work will be far less dramatic than the successful military campaigns in Afghanistan and Iraq. Indeed, each new terrorist act demonstrates that military action alone is not the solution. Terrorism cannot be eradicated simply by driving the Taliban out of Kabul or capturing Saddam Hussein.

But last summer Ms. Metcalf found herself checking the two of them into the $270-a-night Victorian-era Hotel del Coronado, just 15 minutes from home. The reason? Ashley had heard about the hotel's Coast Club Teen Lounge and Lucky Chick spa package, and talked her mother into a visit. ''I played pool in the teen center, and got my first facial,'' said Ashley, a 10th grader. ''And it sure was nice not having to go somewhere cold for a change.''

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS IS BUYING ALVIS OF BRITAIN
description: General Dynamics said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Alvis, the maker of the Challenger II battle tank, for 309 million ($556 million). General Dynamics, based in Falls Church, Va., is offering 280 pence a share for Alvis, 33 percent more than the closing price on Wednesday. Alvis, based in London, will recommend the offer to shareholders, the chief executive, Nicholas Prest, said. Alvis, 29 percent owned by BAE Systems, also makes all-terrain mine-clearing and scouting vehicles. After the acquisition, General Dynamics, builder of the Abrams battle tank, expects to win combat vehicle orders from the United States, Britain and possibly Sweden. Alvis's shares rose 41 percent, to 296 pence.

title: NASD FINES AMERITRADE AND TWO UNITS $10 MILLION
description: Ameritrade Holding, the biggest discount brokerage firm, and two units it acquired in 2002 have been fined $10 million by NASD, the securities regulator, for improperly extending credit to clients. Ameritrade's Datek Online Financial Services and iClearing units, which focus on day traders, allowed clients to make purchases using funds from sales that were not completed, NASD said. The agreement will not affect earnings and customers were not harmed by the violations, Ameritrade said. The fine partly reflected the units' failure to respond quickly to NASD's concerns, the regulator said. The company did not admit or deny NASD's accusations.

title: Haiti's New Leader Sees a Long Transition
description: The newly appointed prime minister, Grard Latortue, said Thursday that it might take as long as two years to prepare for elections. That would put a new elected government beyond the 2005 timeline envisioned in the United States-backed transition plan to help Haiti recover after the departure of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: A Ride on Waves of Musical Discourse
description: Graceful lyricism and dissonance would seem to be polar opposites and impossible to reconcile, yet Mark-Anthony Turnage, an English composer born in 1960, has built his art on fusing those qualities. Some of his works - including a few performed on an installment of the Making Music series at Weill Recital Hall on March 4 - tilt one way or the other. But where his music is at its most magical, he is able to continuously renegotiate this amalgam through the length of a piece, letting a listener ride the waves of musical discourse without worrying, from one phrase to the next, which way the balance is tilting.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Jobs Paid $74.8 Million In Stock
description: Apple Computer paid its chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, $74.8 million in restricted stock in the last fiscal year after the company replaced his unprofitable stock options. Mr. Jobs, 49, takes ownership of his five million restricted shares in two years. He received $1 in salary, as he has since returning to the company in 1997, and no bonus, Apple said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. A three-year slide in Apple's stock price before last March made Mr. Jobs's 27.5 million options unprofitable. The company approved a plan last year to replace his options.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts 3rd-Quarter Profit
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported a $93.1 million profit yesterday for the third quarter, in contrast to a loss of $36.4 million in the third quarter a year earlier, on improved sales of chips for wireless and personal computer products. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes microprocessors used for power management, audio applications and imaging technology. Earnings for the quarter that ended Feb. 29 were 48 cents a share in contrast to a loss of 20 cents a share in the third quarter last year, beating analysts' estimates. Net sales rose to $513.6 million, from $404.3 million. As the company disclosed last year, the third quarter included 14 weeks instead of the usual 13 weeks. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Editorial Observer; Martha Stewart's Legacy: 'It's a Good Thing'
description: A dozen years ago, I wrote a profile of Martha Stewart for The Los Angeles Times Magazine. I spent a day or two with her, had lunch with her in Westport, Conn., and dinner in SoHo, visited the house she calls Turkey Hill, listened to her give a lecture at the New York Botanical Garden, and stood in the wings while she did her regular segment on the ''Today'' show. I asked a lot of nave questions, and I suspect myself of having wanted to know more about her garden than I did about her. Later, I even wrote a couple of articles for her magazine. But it was obvious, even in 1992, even to me, that there were many Marthas, a fact that her recent trial and conviction have confirmed in ways that have left a lot of people with a subdued sense of sadness.

Maax said its shareholders would receive 22.50 Canadian dollars a common share, 22 percent more than on Sept. 8, the day before the company put itself up for sale. Childs was started in 1995 by former executives of Thomas H. Lee Partners, including John W. Childs. Maax said its chairman, Placide Poulin, wanted to retire; he started the company in 1969.

title: Touching All Bases At the Biennial
description: THAT the latest Whitney Biennial is easily the best in some time probably won't exempt it from the usual carping, the art world's blood sport, although the troika in charge clearly took pains to anticipate some of their critics. The team of curators that the former Whitney director, Maxwell L. Anderson, threw together -- Chrissie Iles, Debra Singer and Shamim M. Momin -- overcame the inevitable strains and nicely capitalized on their differences in taste, coming up with the most cogent and layered biennial in years.

title: 36 Hours | Scottsdale, Ariz.
description: SCOTTSDALE has long had a reputation as a sunny haven for retirees and golf devotees. But in recent years, this city of 200,000 -- in one of the country's fastest-growing metropolitan regions -- has emerged as a hip destination for visitors seeking boutique hotels, trendy restaurants and luxurious spas that soothe both body and soul. The old Scottsdale still thrives, of course, with galleries, golf greens and shops devoted to haute couture, but it has undergone a sea change. The restaurateur Stephen P. Hanson recently opened the James Hotel, with sleek rooms, plasma television screens, an upscale restaurant and a fashionable bar. The two-year-old Sanctuary on Camelback Mountain has a window-wrapped restaurant and a luxurious spa with Zen overtones. The acclaimed Boulders Resort has added a Golden Door Spa, a sibling to the original in Escondido, Calif., and the venerated Marriott's Camelback Inn recently completed an $8 million renovation of its spa. The new Willow Stream spa at the Fairmont Scottsdale Princess offers a cascading waterfall, meditation gardens and a eucalyptus steam room. Once a small farming community, Scottsdale retains the friendliness and slow pace of life in a small town -- perhaps because stress can't survive on a massage table, golf course or any place where the sun shines more than 330 days a year. LYNN CLINE

title: An Epicure's 15-Course French Feast
description: IT was almost exactly a year ago that a stilted new term, ''freedom fries,'' abruptly entered American parlance by addressing an embarrassing political schism. As a result of France's refusal to support the American cause in Iraq, freedom fries, and their cousin, freedom toast, replaced French fries and French toast on the menus of some outraged restaurateurs. That name change, silly as it was, bared a long-simmering cultural antagonism between imperial (American) machismo and a more feminine (French) Epicureanism, and ratcheted it up a notch.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Insurer Posts Loss
description: The British property and casualty insurer Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group said it lost 382 million ($689.5 million) last year, more than analysts had expected, as it raised reserves for workers' compensation claims in the United States. The loss was Royal and Sun's fourth consecutive yearly loss; the restated loss for 2002 was 871 million ($1.57 billion). Analysts expected a loss of 156 million last year. The company raised reserves by 96 million in the fourth quarter, primarily for claims in the United States, the chief executive, Andy Haste, said. Royal and Sun has also been hurt in America by asbestos claims.

title: A Big Test Looms for a Horse That Needs One
description: Throughout his career, Michael Dickinson has proved capable of extraordinary accomplishments. When training steeplechase horses in England, he saddled the first five finishers in the 1983 Cheltenham Gold Cup, the Kentucky Derby of British jump racing. He once won 12 races in a day. After reinventing himself as a Maryland-based trainer of flat horses, he stunned the sport by winning the 1998 Breeders' Cup Mile with Da Hoss, who had started just once, in a minor allowance race, over the previous two years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Officer Shot Was Armed, Police Say
description: A man shot and killed by a police detective in East Harlem on Tuesday had drawn a gun and was pointing it at the detective's partner, a Police Department spokesman said yesterday. The spokesman, Chief Michael Collins, said that the officer's partner, who was interviewed by police investigators, said he tried to wrest the gun from the man, Leroy Smalls, 41. The detective who fired had ordered Mr. Smalls to drop the gun, but he continued to resist and was kicking the officer, the chief said. The first detective fired, gave another warning, then fired again, hitting Mr. Smalls twice. Mr. Smalls was on parole, and the gun he carried had been reported stolen in Maryland, Chief Collins said. Shaila Dewan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASEY, JOHN L. JR.
description: CASEY--John L. Jr., author of business ethics and managing director of the investment firm Scudder, Stevens & Clark, died on February 9, 2004 at 80. Born in Medford, MA, the son of Ruth Jones Casey and John Louis Casey, Sr., Jack graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School, served in the US Navy during World War II, and became Chairman of Youth for Eisenhower. He spent over 30 years at Scudder, went on to publish two books on business ethics, titled ''Ethics in the Financial Marketplace'', and ''Values Added'', and became the first Executive Fellow at the Bentley College Center for Business Ethics. Jack also served as president and chairman of the board of trustees at Saint David's School in New York. Married for 42 years to the late Marilyn Fuller Casey, Jack is survived by three sons, John Milton Casey, Charles Frederic Casey and Edward Canfield Casey. He loved his family, playing his clarinet, and sailing, and had an eternally positive outlook on life. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas More Church in New York on March 16, 2004 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John L. Casey Jr. Scholarship at The Bentley College Center for Business Ethics (781.891.2981).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Manhole Explosions Near Times Square
description: Explosions and a fire in a manhole on West 44th Street last night forced the evacuation of several restaurants and brought traffic on the busy block, between Broadway and Avenue of the America just off Times Square to a standstill, the authorities said. The explosions, which firefighters said were caused by an electrical fire in an underground transformer, occurred about 11:30 p.m. Diners and workers were evacuated from Virgil's Real BBQ, Viva Pancho, the Times Deli and Jimmy's Corner, a bar. Acrid smoke poured from the manhole and flames rose at least four feet in the air. The fire was extinguished by 12:45, firefighters said. No one was injured. Exploding manhole covers are common in the spring, when salt washes into manholes, corroding wires, which heat up, said Firefighter Paul Iannizzotto, a Fire Department spokesman. The rising temperature increases the pressure inside the manholes, causing the covers to blow off, he added. Lily Koppel (NYT)

The truck struck the boy as it crossed the intersection of Baychester Avenue and Crawford Avenue on a green light, the police said. The victim's brother, Horace Brown, 25, said the boy was the second youngest of six children of Jamaican immigrants. The victim was a fourth-grader at Public School 111, and was walking from school to his home two blocks away, when he was hit about 3:45 p.m. Inez Scavella, whose son was a classmate of the victim, said there are three schools in the area, and the traffic has been a cause for concern for parents. The production values were first rate and the theme was promising. Anja Hitzenberger's soft-edged photographs and film of Barcelona created a sense of that vital city. Edward Ratliff's incident-packed music, performed live and on tape, gave the dance component the context and support of a good film score. But in the end this introduction to the city seemed merely a prop for the self-involvement of David Zambrano, the internationally known modern-dance choreographer and teacher who conceived the piece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSLER, ABRAHAM G.
description: OSLER--Abraham G. May 16, 1911-March 10, 2004. Son of immigrant parents, Max and Fanny Osofsky. Born in NYC, grew up on the lower east side and then Brooklyn. Graduated from DeWitt Clinton HS. BA from CCNY 1931; M.Sc 1933 and Ph.D. 1948 in Bacteriology from Columbia University. During the 1930's, he worked as a bacteriologist at Bronx Hospital until he was fired for trying to organize the hospital workers into what eventually became Local 1199. Married Sonia Fellner in 1938. In the early 1940's he worked for the NYC Health Department before undertaking doctoral studies. Moved to Baltimore in 1948, teaching immunology and conducting highly significant research on complement fixation at Johns Hopkins Medical School until moving to the Public Health Research Institute of the City of NY in 1968. On retirement in 1978, he moved to the UC San Diego where he consulted at the Salk Institute for two years. In 1992, he and Sonia moved to Harbour's Edge in Delray Beach, FL and in 1997 to Vantage House in Columbia, MD. Predeceased by his brothers David Osler and Louis Osler and his wife Sonia, he leaves behind his daughter Margaret J. Osler of Calgary AB, Canada; his sister Miriam Krantz of Brooklyn and several nieces and one nephew. A successful scientist and influential teacher, his friends will remember his commitment to working-class politics and his lifelong passion for art, music and literature.

description: MADRID:  Spaniards turned out in huge numbers Friday evening to protest against a synchronized series of explosions on city commuter trains here on Thursday that claimed almost 200 lives.

title: New Darlings for Some Inflation-Wary Investors
description: An investment that Wall Street was trying to kill off just three years ago is coming on strong.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Tune In to Democracy
description: After several embarrassing attempts to corral the news media in Iraq, the Coalition Provisional Authority is about to get it right. L. Paul Bremer, the authority's administrator, has signaled his approval of coming Iraqi Governing Council legislation that will establish an independent interim media commission. The commission will have the power to issue broadcast licenses, provide a system of self-regulation for the fragmented press and bring order to the way news and information flows in Iraq.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Acquisition Of Pubs
description: Enterprise Inns may sell as many as 250 pubs to satisfy antitrust regulators after it buys most of the Unique Pub Company for 609 million ($1.1 billion). The acquisition will probably be completed this month, Enterprise said in a Regulatory News Service statement.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Kidnapped Engineers Freed
description: Two Turkish engineers and an Afghan translator kidnapped in December were rescued by the Afghan police, the Interior Minister announced. The men had been working on a well-digging project near Kabul. The minister said two ''terrorists'' were killed in the rescue operation, in a village in Logar Province but provided no information about their identities. Amy Waldman (NYT)

title: Chamber Music at Weill for a Sunday Afternoon
description: In his chamber music concerts with players from the Metropolitan Opera's orchestra, James Levine has made a point of assembling varied programs with a healthy quotient of post-Romantic works. And because these superb players typically present this music in finely polished performances, the Met Chamber Ensemble concerts have come to be, at the very least, a pleasantly reliable way to spend a Sunday afternoon, and at best, an adventure with exciting twists, deftly executed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Move To Restrict Citizenship Rights
description: Justice Minister Michael McDowell has announced a national referendum, expected in June, on whether to remove the automatic right of Irish citizenship for Irish-born children of immigrants. Mr. McDowell wants citizenship limited to children whose parents have lived in the country for three years, to prevent foreign pregnant women from immigrating in order to gain citizenship for their children. Opponents of the move say it will fuel racism. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CASSIDY, JAMES JOSEPH
description: CASSIDY -- James Joseph. Dec. 31, 1916--Mar. 13, 2003 From Oakley to Southbury your wit and spirit never failed you, and they remain my inspiration. With thanks and love, Jim

title: The Meaning of 'Human' In Embryonic Research
description: Last month the first cloned human embryo was produced by South Korean scientists who said they would continue their research despite the queasiness of critics.

title: Oil Prices Drop on Senate Vote to Hold Some Out of Reserve
description: The price of crude oil futures fell yesterday after the Senate voted to sell oil intended for the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, increasing supplies to refiners.

title: The Pundit on the Desktop
description: Ars Magna, the software program that always answers in anagrams, has been giving some thought to the presidential election. When we say senator, for instance, it replies treason; and if we ask it about tax policies, it comes back with axe politics. Recently, we settled in for an interview about the 2004 presidential race:

title: Study Finds a Nation of Polarized Readers
description: ''Bush at War'' and ''Sleeping With the Devil'' are just two of the political books that have dominated the best-seller list of The New York Times in recent months. But according to Valdis Krebs, a social-network analyst in Cleveland, these volumes -- the first a blow-by-blow account of White House deliberations in the aftermath of Sept. 11, the second an expos of corruption and hypocrisy in American-Saudi relations -- share an unusual distinction. They occupy a sparsely populated middle ground, rare titles that have been bought by people who generally tend to shop for much more partisan polemics.

title: Campbell Sets 200 Mark
description: Veronica Campbell of Arkansas set a collegiate record in the women's 200 meters at the N.C.A.A. indoor championships yesterday in Fayetteville, Ark. Campbell held off Sanya Richards of Texas to win in 22.44 seconds. Richards was second in 22.49, equaling the old record. The defending champion, Muna Lee of Louisiana State, was fifth (22.87).

title: High-Wire Act With Hooks And Heartache
description: A white net, like a circus safety net, hung above Jonatha Brooke as she sang at the Public Theater on Thursday night, starting a run of 10 shows there through March 21. And her first song was a waltz about a girl who joins a circus to get away from her small town. Music is Ms. Brooke's safety net, cushioning heartache with melody and poised reflection. ''You're gone, and there's another song,'' she sang in ''Better After All,'' the single from her new album, ''Back in the Circus'' (Bad Dog/Verve).

title: Brown U. to Examine Debt to Slave Trade
description: When Ruth J. Simmons became the president of Brown University nearly three years ago, one striking fact could not be overlooked.

title: AETNA RAISES FORECASTS FOR EARNINGS THIS YEAR
description: The health insurer Aetna raised quarterly and full-year profit forecasts yesterday as it said it was adding customers for the first time in five years and controlling medical costs. The company will probably report profit of $1.68 to $1.73 a share for the first quarter, excluding some costs, and $6.60 to $6.75 for the full year, Aetna said. The company, which is based in Hartford, had forecast $1.50 to $1.55 a share for the quarter and $6.25 to $6.35 for the full year. Aetna is enrolling new customers this year for the first time since 1999 after dropping six million people who were not profitable to insure. Aetna shares rose $4.77, or 6 percent, to $84.42 a share.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Appeal In G.E.-Honeywell Rejection
description: Appeals against the European Commission's rejection of General Electric's acquisition of Honeywell in 2001 are expected to be heard in late May, said Louise Binns, a spokeswoman at G.E. The European Court of First Instance in Luxembourg has proposed that Honeywell's appeal be heard on May 25 and G.E.'s appeal will be heard two days later. The commission blocked the deal, valued at $45 billion at the time, because it believed it would harm competition in the market for aircraft parts. G.E. and Honeywell abandoned the deal, but G.E. is pursuing the appeal to overturn the commission's ruling in case it pursues another merger. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Manager of Bronx Video Store Is Acquitted on Rape Charge
description: The 26-year-old manager of a Hollywood Video store in the Bronx was acquitted yesterday of rape, attempted rape and sexual assault after a weeklong trial in which his lawyers argued that his accusers had trumped up the charges to bolster their $50 million civil lawsuit against the video company.

title: GRIEVING CROWDS IN SPAIN SEETHE AT TRAIN ATTACKS
description: Grief and fury blanketed Spain on Friday evening as the country mourned the victims of its terrorist attack and struggled to discover who was responsible.

title: Jobs Czar Left Jobless
description: Every now and then, a hollow gesture actually does come back to haunt a politician. For President Bush, his ballyhooed announcement last Labor Day to appoint a ''jobs czar'' in the Commerce Department has boomeranged badly. The expected appointment of Anthony Raimondo, a Nebraska businessman, as the new assistant secretary for manufacturing suddenly fell through as Democrats circulated word that Mr. Raimondo had laid off 75 of his workers two years ago and planned to open a $3 million factory in China.

description: To the Editor:

description: Diagnostic Imaging Moves Into Many Doctor's Offices

description: LEWIS--Sherman R. Jr., on March 11, 2004, at age 67. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Thomas, Catherine, Elizabeth and Michael and grandfather of Olivia and Riley. Dear brother of Robin and Randal. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday 2-5 and 79pm. Funeral services at Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 92 Street, Tuesday 10:30am. Interment private.

title: 50, She Still Just Wants To Have Fun
description: If you're searching for evidence that 50 is the new 40, as the saying goes, you need look no further than to Cyndi Lauper, the endearing outer-borough, dumb-like-a-fox kook, whose kewpie-doll face and piercing little-girl voice suggest a fusion of Betty Boop and Melanie Griffith.

title: MAXWELL SHOE REJECTS $300 MILLION BID FROM JONES
description: The Maxwell Shoe Company, maker of AK Anne Klein shoes, rejected the Jones Apparel Group's unsolicited $300 million cash bid, saying the offer was too low. No discussions with Jones will be pursued, Maxwell said. Jones offered last month to buy Maxwell for $20 a share to expand its footwear offerings, which include Nine West, and consolidate the Anne Klein shoe business with its AK Anne Klein clothing brand. Maxwell's chief executive, Mark Cocozza, said in a statement that the company's plan to add product lines would increase shareholders' value more than accepting the offer would. Maxwell said this month that the company was increasing its market share at each price range. Maxwell is based in Hyde Park, Mass., and Jones is based in Bristol, Pa.

title: BRITNEY SPEARS SIGNS DEAL WITH ELIZABETH ARDEN
description: The pop star Britney Spears has signed a deal with Elizabeth Arden Inc. to develop and market her own line of perfumes and cosmetics, the company said yesterday. Ms. Spears' first product will be a fragrance, which will be introduced in the fall at department stores, the company said, adding that Ms. Spears is personally involved with all aspects of developing the product. On Thursday, Elizabeth Arden posted a loss of $11.1 million for the fourth quarter as a result of restructuring and debt-reduction costs. But sales for the quarter rose 26 percent, helped by new products and the weak dollar.

title: President of Delta Air Lines to Join Virgin
description: The president of Delta Air Lines, Frederick W. Reid, said yesterday that he was joining the Virgin Group and would be overseeing the low-fare carrier that Sir Richard Branson hopes to start in the United States next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, PATRICIA M.
description: GOLDMAN -- Patricia M. passed away peacefully on March 11, 2004. Loving wife of the late Albert S. Goldman. Wonderful mother of Andrew & Nancy Goldman, Lynn & Larry Schan, Susan & Gene Resnick, Jane Goldman, and John & Wendy Goldman. Adored grandmother, greatgrandmother and step-grandmother. Dear friend of the late John Kubie. Born in London, England, she was a woman of grace and elegance, and was devoted to community and charitable causes. Funeral service at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Westchester Ave, Rye, NY on Sunday March 14, 2004 at 2:30pm. Family will receive visitors at home following the service on Sunday and on Monday March 15 from 69pm. In lieu of flowers, please send gifts to the Sarah Neuman Center for Healthcare and Rehabilitation, a Division of the Jewish Home and Hospital, 845 Palmer Ave, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

title: North Carolina Is Ousted With a Shot and a Shout
description: A busted play, a shocked crowd, a typical day at the annually frenzied Atlantic Coast Conference men's basketball tournament on Friday.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Governor Commutes Death Sentence
description: Gov. Rick Perry commuted to life imprisonment the death sentence of a retarded Houston man, Robert Smith, who was convicted of murder and robbery in 1990. A state court had ruled that Mr. Smith, 36, was not eligible for capital punishment under a Supreme Court ruling barring execution of the retarded. Largely a formality, it was the first death sentence commutation by the governor, a Republican, since he took office in 2000. There have been 81 executions. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: A Red Planet Forever in the Orbit of Science and Dreams
description: Mars and science fiction came of age together in the 1890's, and ever since they have had a tight relationship, a feedback loop that has made both famous.

title: Keeping Needed Cash Flowing to Relatives in Haiti
description: In the best of times, Boby Express, on a street corner in Flatbush, is a busy place, allowing Haitians in this Brooklyn neighborhood to send money to relatives back in Haiti for whom getting by is an everyday struggle.

title: Credit Agency Lowers Its Outlook on Shell
description: Fitch Ratings lowered its outlook yesterday for the credit rating of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the latest fallout from the company's decision to reduce the estimates of its proven oil and gas reserves.

title: Spanish Officials Divided on Whom to Blame for Train Attacks: Basques or Islamists
description: Spanish officials investigating the Madrid terror attacks provided little new information yesterday about who might have carried out the bombings, and gave conflicting interpretations of the evidence that emerged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SELEVAN, BASHIE R.
description: SELEVAN--Bashie R. Of Lawrence, NY and North Miami Beach, FL on March 12th. Predeceased by her adored husband Irwin Selevan. Loving mother of Lois Goodstein and Alan Selevan. Beloved sister of the late Freda Panzier, E.G. Rosenblatt and Belle Holtz. Beloved sister-in-law of Chanchy Blumenthal and Maxine and Bernard Selevan. Grandmother of Sam Holtz. Survived by a large, devoted, extended family and friends. Funeral Sunday, March 14th, 2:15PM Boulevard Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, NY.

title: National Briefing | West: California: State Sets Goal On Water Pollutant
description: The state moved toward becoming the first to regulate a widespread rocket fuel contaminant, known as perchlorate, by setting a goal of 6 parts per billion for the chemical in drinking water. The federal Environmental Protection Agency, in 2002, issued a draft recommendation of 1 part per billion, but that figure is a matter of dispute among the E.P.A., the Department of Defense and NASA. The Pentagon, which is responsible for much of the perchlorate contamination found across the country, has argued for a standard of 200 parts per billion. Perchlorate affects the thyroid gland and has raised concerns among scientists for how it affects the development of infants and fetuses. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

description: AFGHANISTAN: KIDNAPPED ENGINEERS FREED Two Turkish engineers and an Afghan translator kidnapped in December were rescued by the Afghan police, the Interior Minister announced. title: Judge Bars Stock Exchange From Security Action
description: A Manhattan judge, in a ruling yesterday, gave the New York Stock Exchange five days to remove security blockades and stop conducting vehicle searches on the streets surrounding its headquarters, saying that only the Police Department could operate such blockades and conduct searches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STONE, SANFORD HERBERT
description: STONE -- Sanford Herbert. Scientist, professor, WWII soldier, loving husband and father, dedicating his life to public service, health and wellbeing of all people, died at home in Mt. Airy, MD, December 23, 2003, at 82. Dr. Stone (Sandy), immunologist at NIH for 40 years, and professor for 15 years at Howard University, Washington, DC, was an international leader in cellular immunity research. His seminal adoptive-immune guinea pig model of multiple sclerosis advanced understanding of chronic auto-immune diseases and possible treatments. Sandy enlisted in WWII was NCO Med Tech in a clearing company, served in the liberation of Wobbeline Concentration Camp in Germany, and remained a deeply committed fighter against Fascism. He received his bachelors at CCNY and Doctor of Science, in 1951, at University of Paris, Sorbonne, Pasteur Institute, with very high honorable mention. He leaves bereaved wife Audrey Larack Stone, sons Andrew, Leland and Roger, their wives Barbara and Christine, and three grandchildren. A memorial gathering for Sandy will be held March 14, 2004, in Plaza Room, 777 United Nations Plaza, NYC, at 12:30 pm; reception until 4 pm.

title: President's Impeachment Stirs Angry Protests in South Korea
description: With just a month to go before crucial National Assembly elections, South Korea entered uncharted political waters on Saturday after President Roh Moo Hyun was impeached and stripped of power by the National Assembly, unleashing protests in the capital.

title: Knicks Find Way to Lose Despite 3 Chances to Win
description: The Knicks had three opportunities to reclaim what they thought was theirs. But when the minutes ticked to seconds, those chances turned to strikes against them.

title: Reyes Is Working Hard to Have an Easy Transition
description: The infielder with the most athletic ability on the Mets, the infielder with the best throwing arm and the infielder who played shortstop splendidly last season was talking about his transition to second base. Fortunately for the Mets, Jos Reyes is excited about leaving his glamour position and gliding to the left.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a concern among aviation experts that a proliferation of small jets may crowd the airspace once left to big ones misidentified the type of plane with which the larger jets will have to compete for the use of longer runways. It is the smaller regional jets; turboprops, which the airlines may phase out, need less space for takeoff. ( Go to Article )

title: Furor Over Student Aid Ban For Long-Ago Drug Offenses
description: Given that she had been thrown out of the house by 13 for declaring herself a lesbian, spent her teenage years sleeping on subway trains and rotting piers and yet still managed to get her G.E.D., Laura Melendez figured she had kept her nose pretty clean.

title: RECORDS FALL AT SCHOLASTIC MEET
description: Briana Jackucewicz, a 13-year-old seventh grader from Howell, N.J., and the girls' distance medley relay from Mount View High School in Utah posted United States records at the national scholastic indoor championships yesterday at the Track and Field Center at the Armory in Upper Manhattan.

title: Iran Postpones a Visit by U.N. Nuclear Inspectors Until April
description: Iran on Friday postponed a planned visit of United Nations nuclear inspectors in what diplomats said was a tactical move to head off international criticism of its nuclear activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUTHERLAND, DR. GEORGE L.
description: SUTHERLAND--Dr. George L. Died March 10, 2004. He was 81. Research chemist and community leader. George had a long and successful career with American Cyanamid Company, retiring as VP Director of Research and Development, Lederle Labs. George was very active in the Rockland County community. He served on various boards, including Ramapo College, The Salvation Army, Good Samaritan Hospital, Association for the Visually Impaired and Helen Hayes Theatre. He was past President of Rockland United Way. Survived by his devoted wife Carol and a large, loving family. A Memorial Service will be held at Wanamaker & Carlough, Suffern, New York at 2 PM on March 14th.

title: Creating the Next Crime Wave
description: President Bush surprised some people when he spoke sympathetically about ex-convicts during his State of the Union address and announced a proposal to furnish mentoring, job placement and transitional housing for ex-offenders. The $300 million budget is far too small, but it was heartening to hear Mr. Bush acknowledge that there was more to crime prevention than just locking up people -- and that pushing ex-cons into a hostile world without help is a recipe for civic disaster.

title: G.E. Signals a Growing Interest in Solar
description: General Electric will acquire the major assets of the largest American-owned maker of solar equipment, in a move the solar power industry sees as a major vote of confidence in the business.

title: Spain Announces Five Arrests in Bombings
description: MADRID, Spain (AP) -- Spain's interior minister Saturday announced the arrest of five suspects in the Madrid bombings, including three Moroccans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORSTER, LOUIS P. JR.
description: FORSTER--Louis P. Jr. 93. Cornwall, PA. Formerly of New York City. Died March 11, 2004 in Cornwall Manor. Retired Associate Editor of the New Yorker Magazine. 1933 graduate of Harvard. Member of Harvard Club of New York City. Last of family. Survived by friends, Douglas and Joan Fenwick, Richland, PA. At his request private services will be held.

title: Illusions and Elections in Russia
description: This city and the rest of Russia will vote in presidential elections tomorrow, but most Westerners would be baffled by the campaign that has led up to the voting. In his re-election bid, President Vladimir Putin refused to participate in any debates, make any policy statements, respond to his few timid detractors or explain his plans for Russia's future.

title: CUNY Administrator to Lead Historical Society
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: SK Management Backed
description: The chief executive of the SK Corporation, Chey Tae Won, defeated an attempt by Sovereign Asset Management Ltd. to oust him from the holding company of South Korea's fourth-largest business group. Shareholders in SK voted at their annual general meeting against Sovereign's call to fire Mr. Chey, 43, for his involvement in a fraud of at least $1.3 billion at a trading unit. They also rejected four of five candidates that Sovereign nominated for the 10-member board. Sovereign, which owns 14.99 percent of SK, said Mr. Chey had failed to deliver shareholder value. Sovereign, which is based in Monaco, is SK's biggest shareholder.

title: Editorial Observer; The Americans in Moscow: How to Spin a Russian Election
description: Tomorrow's presidential election in Russia is so predictable that it's not surprising to see a certain nostalgia for the Boris Yeltsin campaign eight years ago. Instead of only one real candidate, as with President Vladimir Putin now, there were a handful in 1996. And the results seemed far from inevitable; a few months before the first vote, President Yeltsin's approval rating was slithering along at 6 percent. A grim Communist leader was trouncing him in those early polls, and the Russian president was not even doing well against a right-wing extremist who posed for the cameras in his underwear.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: U.N. Freezes Ex-Leader's Assets
description: The Security Council unanimously passed a United States-drafted resolution freezing the money and property of the former Libyan leader, Charles Taylor, who went into forced exile in Nigeria under pressure from the Bush administration in August. The resolution said Mr. Taylor and his allies were undermining the transition to democracy in Liberia. Stuart Holliday, an American envoy, said Mr. Taylor was suspected of using misappropriated funds to meddle in Liberian affairs. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: NEW MEXICO: GAS BLOWOUT KEEPS AREA SHUTTERED Between 1,200 and 1,500 people prepared for a second night away from their homes and businesses near a the blowout of a natural gas well in south Carlsbad. A drilling crew accidentally opened a vast underground pocket of natural gas on Thursday, prompting an evacuation that was expanded yesterday. Efforts to cap the well, which did not explode or burn, were suspended in the evening for safety reasons and would resume at sunrise, said Elizabeth Baggs, the city's emergency services coordinator. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Skybound Los Angeles Traffic Reporter Sees Job as a Dying Art
description: The first voice many Los Angeles commuters hear in the morning, when the clock radio bleats at 6, is that of Cmdr. Chuck Street, talking about traffic. He knows this, and so tries to put the good before the bad, to set a meditative mood with a poetic description of the rain, say, before launching into the annoyances or horrors of the day.

title: Book Says U.S. Aides Lied In Nuclear-Arms Plant Case
description: The Justice Department lied about its reasons for not pursuing the most serious accusations of environmental crimes at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in the 1980's and 1990's, according to a new book written in part by the foreman of the grand jury that investigated the case.

title: Announcement of Aristide Plan to Visit Jamaica Draws Complaints
description: Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haiti's exiled president, said Friday that he would leave his temporary refuge here on Sunday and fly to Jamaica, which agreed on Thursday to allow him to visit for up to 10 weeks, a decision that drew protests from Haitian leaders.

title: Kerry Calls for Halt to Work of Base-Closing Panel
description: Senator John Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, called Friday for a halt to the work of the Bush administration's commission on closing military bases, saying it ''is driven more by ideology than by careful planning.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Challenges Union
description: Ryanair, the discount Irish airline, began a legal challenge to plans by the country's largest transportation union, SIPTU, to stage a strike at three state-owned airports next Thursday. The walkouts would follow a 24-hour strike by workers in state-owned bus and train companies on Wednesday. The Irish High Court will hear Ryanair's case on Tuesday. SIPTU is protesting plans to privatize state-run transportation services. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Mystery Disease Fells Hundreds of Wyoming Elk
description: Since a coyote hunter found two paralyzed elk near here on Feb. 8, close to 300 elk have been felled by a mysterious illness that no one can identify.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Industrial Output Slips
description: French industrial production unexpectedly fell for the second time in three months in January, as makers of cars and consumer products scaled back output. Industrial production declined 0.5 percent from December, when there was a revised 0.2 percent increase, said Insee, the government statistics office. Economists had forecast a 0.4 percent increase.
