title: Low Labor Standard Leads South Africans to Export Jobs
description: When Tiger Wheels opened a wheel plant six years ago in this faded industrial town, the crush of job seekers was so enormous that the chief executive, Eddie Keizan, ordered a corrugated iron roof to shield them from the midday heat.

title: National Briefing: South
description: ALABAMA: NO NEW TRIAL IN GAS ROYALTY SUIT A judge said she would not order a new trial in the state's lawsuit against Exxon Mobil, which resulted in an $11.9 billion verdict against the company, and she criticized the oil company for not providing a document she considered vital to the case. In November a Montgomery jury decided Exxon Mobil cheated the state of royalties from natural gas wells drilled in state waters around Mobile Bay. It awarded $63.6 million in compensatory damages and $11.8 billion in punitive damages, the largest verdict ever in Alabama. The judge, Tracy McCooey of Circuit Court, said she would decide by March 29 whether to uphold the punitive award. She said that she needed to see the company's final natural gas price forecast for 1993, the year production began along the Alabama coast. A company lawyer said it would be supplied next week. (AP)

title: An M.R.I. Machine For Every Doctor? Someone Has to Pay
description: This aging city is an unexpected epicenter for a high-tech medical arms race. But employers and insurers here say that is just what they are paying for, as doctors, their traditional sources of income squeezed, discover a new one: diagnostic imaging.

title: Prep Races Expected to Clarify Derby Field
description: With this weekend's four major prep races for the Kentucky Derby having attracted 35 entries, there will be no shortage of top-quality horses in action across the nation. But the most talented 3-year-old in the country might not be found in the Florida Derby, the Tampa Bay Derby, the Swale or the San Felipe, but in a race for fillies.

description: Elise Asher, a painter and a poet who blended images and poetry in her work, died last Sunday at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 92 and also had a studio and summer home in Provincetown, Mass.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC TO SELL DISTRIBUTION UNIT
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its building products distribution business to Cerberus Capital Management L.P. and members of the unit's management for about $810 million. Georgia-Pacific, which is based in Atlanta, said it expected the sale to close in the second quarter, and expects to then record a $20 million gain on the sale. As part of the agreement, the distribution business signed a five-year contract to continue purchasing structural panels, lumber and other building products manufactured by Georgia-Pacific.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: BOSNIA: BIRTHDAY WARNING FOR OUTLAW A birthday greeting displaying handcuffs wrapped in a red ribbon was sent by NATO peacekeepers in the form of posters and newspaper ads to Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb military commander indicted by the international war crimes tribunal eight years ago and observing his 62nd birthday in hiding. "Ratko, we have not forgotten about you," the text read. "This will be your only present soon." The posters were put up in the Bosnian Serb wartime stronghold of Pale, east of Sarajevo, but soon most were removed by residents. General Mladic and the tribunal's other most-wanted fugitive, Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader, are still fiercely protected by a part of the population. (AP)

title: Second Base Is Wilson's Job to Lose
description: When the Yankees started spring training, Manager Joe Torre gave Enrique Wilson the edge as the starter at second base. Torre planned to look at other candidates, but Wilson's experience with the Yankees made it his job to lose. After the first few exhibition games, Wilson has done everything to keep it.

title: MICROSOFT IS SAID TO FILE SUIT AGAINST LINDOWS
description: Lindows, barred from using its name in three European countries after lawsuits brought by Microsoft, said yesterday that Microsoft has asked a Dutch court to fine the company 100,000 euros ($122,000) a day. Lindows said that Microsoft was asking for the fine for permitting the Lindows Web site to be reached by people in the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg. Microsoft has said the Lindows name harms the value of its Windows trademark. Courts in Finland, Sweden and the Netherlands have barred Lindows.com from using the word, and Microsoft is also suing in Seattle. Lindows, based in San Diego, finds it impossible to comply with Microsoft's demand since visitors to its Web site come from international Internet service providers and other methods, Lindows chief executive, Michael Robertson, said. The Lindows software lets Windows programs run on computers that run the rival Linux operating system, and the company said in November that it expected to have 30,000 systems with its programs in Canada within a year.

description: This once-thriving seaside resort where Bruce Springsteen started his career has gone through many changes since Rita M. Marano moved here more than 40 years ago.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Gas Blowout Keeps Area Shuttered
description: Between 1,200 and 1,500 people prepared for a second night away from their homes and businesses near a the blowout of a natural gas well in south Carlsbad. A drilling crew accidentally opened a vast underground pocket of natural gas on Thursday, prompting an evacuation that was expanded yesterday. Efforts to cap the well, which did not explode or burn, were suspended in the evening for safety reasons and would resume at sunrise, said Elizabeth Baggs, the city's emergency services coordinator. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Ethics Panel Withdraws Critique
description: A scientific ethics panel has withdrawn its criticism of the book ''Skeptical Environmentalist,'' an upbeat analysis of global trends that was embraced by conservatives and attacked by environmental scientists after it was published in English in 2001. The decision was prompted by a Ministry of Science rebuke that the panel presented no evidence supporting its conclusion that the author, Bjorn Lomborg, displayed ''scientific dishonesty.'' Dr. Lomborg, a statistician, challenges many goals of environmental groups, including curbing gases linked to global warming. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Corrections

It is the smaller regional jets; turboprops, which the airlines may phase out, need less space for takeoff.

Bloomberg, after an accident involving a runaway locomotive drew reporters and television crews to a place filled with long rows of boxcars. But for the absence of cornfields, it could have been a Midwestern freight yard, rather than a bustling neighborhood in New York City.

title: Batons Raised, Voices Lifted
description: AMONG classical music festivals, those devoted to opera came first and still dominate the festival spectrum. The grandest of them spill over from opera into concerts and on to dance, theater and even film and the visual arts. The granddaddy of these all-inclusive festivals is Salzburg, in Austria. Cradled by the Alps and surrounded by blue-green lakes, Salzburg, with its Baroque old city, is a heavenly place to be. The music isn't bad, either, even if the sometimes annoying, always exciting innovations of the Grard Mortier decade have now given way to Peter Ruzicka's more placid approach.

title: In This Recovery, a College Education Backfires
description: ROBERT B. REICH called them ''symbolic analysts.'' They were the college-educated workers supposedly insulated from the global pressures that condemned others with less schooling to job insecurity and layoffs. ''Symbolic analysts are in ever greater demand in a world market that places an increasing value on identifying and solving problems,'' Mr. Reich wrote in 1991.

title: Side Kick
description: I began practicing karate 15 years ago. My motivation was . . . I just wanted to be male. If I ever found myself in a dangerous situation, I didn't want to have to run. And I was tired. I felt as if my body had become weak. Especially after flying between Tokyo and Paris four times a year -- which in those days was an 18-hour journey. Then I met an English guy, Richard Amos, who would go to my mother's house for language lessons; he knew karate. At first I hated it, but when I realized I could use it to keep my body in condition, I got very serious about it. It took five years for me to become a black belt.

title: Seafood by the Beach (Minus the Beach)

Tables are covered in paper, and the floor, if I remember correctly, is concrete. Waiters bring red plastic buckets for your shells, and your coffee may be served in a plastic (high quality) mug.

title: LIFE INTERRUPTED
description: ON Dec. 15, 2003, Spalding Gray performed a monologue in front of an audience for the last time. It was at the downtown theater space P.S. 122, where he had developed many of his acclaimed solo shows, including ''Swimming to Cambodia'' and ''Monster in a Box.'' The work-in-progress, titled ''Life Interrupted,'' tells the story of Mr. Gray's trip to Ireland in 2001, in which he celebrated his 60th birthday with his wife, Kathleen Russo, two sons, a stepdaughter and friends. The getaway turned tragic when Mr. Gray was injured in a car accident that fractured his skull, crushed his hip and sent him into a deep depression.

title: Making the Cut
description: I have always found it puzzling that while millions of songs have been written about love and, by extension, sex, a mere handful have been written about food or eating, which is at least as important and often more satisfying. There's a great song I remember from my childhood called ''Just a Bowl of Butter Beans,'' but it doesn't even have its own music -- it's sung to the tune of ''Just a Closer Walk With Thee.'' We are reminded that ''The Lady Is a Tramp'' because ''she gets too hungry for dinner at 8,'' and among the pleasures of being taken ''out to the ballgame'' is the box of Cracker Jacks. But I think we deserve more. If there is, for example, ''Shall We Dance?'' why not ''Shall We Dine?''

title: He's Firing As Fast As He Can
description: THE night before the jury elected to send Martha Stewart to the slammer, some 20 million Americans watched with glee as another businesswoman got her comeuppance. On ''The Apprentice,'' Donald Trump fired Omarosa Manigault-Stallworth, the contestant audiences loved to hate in NBC's hit reality show pitting 16 aspiring Trumps in a dog-eat-dog weekly battle to win a $250,000-a-year job in his employ. The ritualistic weekly firing on ''The Apprentice'' is an instant TV classic -- right up there with Rod Serling beckoning us into the Twilight Zone. Mr. Trump seems to grab a gnat out of the air with his fingers as he focuses on his prey, and then, wham, it comes: ''You're fired!'' We just can't get enough of hearing Mr. Trump say, ''You're fired!'' Even the network promos featuring the bit are music to a nation's ears.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE FAMILY ON BEARTOWN ROAD: A Memoir of Learning and Forgetting, by Elizabeth Cohen. (Random House, $12.95.) Talk about a rough spell: first, the author's declining father is shipped across the country to live with her in upstate New York. Then her husband abandons her and their baby, leaving Cohen to make do as caretaker of this unlikely pair, a struggle she handles without self-pity and with the help of neighbors and colleagues. Her simply spun memoir, originally published as ''The House on Beartown Road,'' is ''frank, funny and unexploitative,'' Maggie Jones said here last year.

Then he disappears or is hung up on a next album or has trouble finding and accepting an audience. Consider Terence Trent D'arby. Consider Bilal. title: Editors' Note
description: A letter to the editor last Sunday, arising from the County Lines column of Feb. 15 about the television show ''Friends,'' carried a false signature, intended as a spoof. The letter, which said a situation comedy like ''Friends'' should be taken as a comedy, not realism, bore the signature of Phoebe Buffay, a character on the show. title: The Colombo Bay
description: ome in, Colombo Bay ," a radio voice squawks. "Ignore it," says Shakeel, who has just arrived on the bridge at noon to relieve Simon. "Come in, Colombo Bay , do you read me?" The two mates smile and continue to disregard the insistent pleas, which offer no official identification and likely come from an Egyptian vendor trying to drum up business, probably by selling us some stores. At 1230, Suez harbor control makes contact, and Peter, who has come to the bridge finishing his sandwich lunch, responds that our ETA is 1400 and our draft is forty feet. We are heading for the collection anchorage on the east side of the Bay of Suez, where ships gather to form the convoys that the Suez Canal Authority requires for passage in either direction. The chart shows twenty-nine spots in this marine parking lot, and Peter is hoping for one on the outside so we can make a quick getaway when entering the canal. We reach the bay right on schedule, with eleven hours to spare before the 0100 deadline that ships must meet to be included in the next morning's convoy, the only northbound transit of the day. Just a half dozen large vessels have arrived at the anchorage so far; nonetheless, harbor control directs us to a slot in the middle. Que sera, sera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSKIN, JULES JAY
description: ROSKIN--Jules Jay. 95, businessman, art collector and interior designer died Tuesday, March 9, 2004 in Albuquerque, from declining health due to age. Mr. Roskin had a career as the owner of I. Gerson & Sons Metal Co. in Toledo, OH and in his father's NYC jewelry manufacturing company, I. Roskin Co., Inc, but his real passion was collecting modern art and designing residential spaces. In the 1950s he was an innovator in the use of the principles of solar heating in residential design long before such ideas were truly accepted. The Roskin Toledo home won many awards including the 1951 American Architects Award as ''best residence'' in Ohio. Before going to NM in 1990, he lived for 15 yrs in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico where he created the Culture Series at the Bellas Artes, as well as programs for indigent children. He resided before for 20 yrs in Westport, CT. Born in NYC, he was a graduate of Muhlenberg College and did graduate work in psychology at N.Y.U. and Heidelberg Univ., Germany. His wife of 59 years, Phyllis Kasle Roskin, a concert pianist, died in 1995. Mr. Roskin is survived by three daughters, Roa Lynn, Arlington, VA, Nina Liebman, NYC, Lyra Grant, Santa Fe; his sister, Miriam Roskin Berger; three granddaughters, Sophie Oberstein, Hanna Dershowitz, Tessa Liebman; three great grandchildren, Lily and Evan Oberstein, Zara Dershowitz; nephew Jonathan I. The second thing of any note he ever said to me was ''I am basically an amorphous blob of nothing.'' The first thing was ''I'm shy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARTLETT, AMY WYLLYS
description: BARTLETT -- Amy Wyllys. Poet and poetry editor, died on February 29, 2004, at the age of 54, at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center in New York City. Amy is survived by her son Byron, her sisters Lucia, Susan and Eliza, her brother John, her mother Christina, her brothers-in-law Robert Bernstein and Karim Anis, her uncle Scott Bartlett and his wife Barbara Forman, her uncle Paul Bartlett and his wife Barbara. The eldest of five children, Amy grew up in Concord, Massachusetts. She graduated from Concord Academy in 1967, from Vassar College in 1972. She did graduate studies at Cambridge University and received a Master's Degree in Creative Writing from New York University. A poet, her book ''Afterwords'' was published in 1985. She served on the Board of Directors of Poets House and as poetry editor of ''Tin House Magazine.'' A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, March 27th at 1:00 PM, at All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue (at 80th Street), in New York City, New York 10021-1157. Contributions in her memory may be made to Poets House, 72 Spring Street, Second Floor, New York, New York 10012.

title: Lady-Slippers Reward Growers' Years of Waiting
description: A FEW years ago, I was walking with friends in a rare bit of undisturbed Northeastern woodland when I discovered something even rarer: three pink lady-slippers in full flower. With their plump rosy pouches surmounted by three delicate petals, they bore an uncanny resemblance to their exotic cousins, the Paphiopedilum orchids. Habitat loss has threatened many species of these hardy North American terrestrial orchids (Cypripedium acaule), and I began to wonder about breeding them in captivity. When ''nursery propagated'' cypripedium popped up in a garden catalog, I decided to investigate further.

title: In a Blossoming Sport, Runners Hit the Slopes

title: Why She Went Home
description: At sixty-five, despite waning lung power, Leonard Milton Fine was still lead oboist of the Newark Symphony Orchestra. He was also one of few musicians in the troupe whom Newark's car thieves hadn't scared off from driving to work; he figured his 1986 Yugo hatchback wasn't tempting even for spare parts. On the evening of the NSO's season opener, he set off down the New Jersey Turnpike with a full car. Next to him in the front, a lugubrious cellist wearing loafers that looked like bedroom slippers stared blankly at the toxic plumage of two dozen industrial smokestacks, which was bleeding into a violet and gold sunset. In the back, Leonard's younger daughter, Phoebe, barely visible beneath a battered cello case covered with stickers from obscure music festivals, attempted to make conversation with the cellist's flute-playing wife, a dark-browed blonde who seemed to have memorized the seating chart of every musical ensemble in the tristate area. Phoebe's left ear was pinned against the neck of the case. As uncomfortable as she was, she considered herself lucky not to be sitting up front, in the death seat. Her father had the alarming habit of turning around while driving to talk to the passengers behind him. Earlier in the trip, while availing them of his many superlative buys on raingear at Burlington Coat Factory, he had narrowly avoided scaling the turnpike divide and then swerved into the middle lane, where he nearly got swiped by an eighteen-wheeler.

title: Life in the Age of Old, Old Age
description: At a recent forum on aging, held in my church, a woman in her 30's spoke of the high stress under which she is living. A mother of two, a wife and a career woman, she said she longs for the freedom and rest she imagines will come with retirement. Many of us acknowledged that at her age, we had never given a thought to retirement, nor had we lived under the stress experienced by many two-wage-earners today. It made us wonder, sadly, whether this current high-paced living will cut short opportunities to reach a healthy old age and the pleasures this young woman envisions.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about leaders driven into exile misstated the number of years Jean-Claude Duvalier held power in Haiti. It was 15; 29 was the total number of years his family held power. The article also misstated the number of years Jean-Bertrand Aristide served as president of Haiti. During three periods, from 1991 to his ouster this month, he served in the office about four years, not a dozen. His times in office were broken by a three-year period of military rule, when he was in exile, and by a five-year term won by another member of his party, Rene Preval.

title: The Great Influenza
description: On September 12, 1876, the crowd overflowing the auditorium of Baltimore's Academy of Music was in a mood of hopeful excitement, but excitement without frivolity. Indeed, despite an unusual number of women in attendance, many of them from the uppermost reaches of local society, a reporter noted, "There was no display of dress or fashion." For this occasion had serious purpose. It was to mark the launching of the Johns Hopkins University, an institution whose leaders intended not simply to found a new university but to change all of American education; indeed, they sought considerably more than that. They planned to change the way in which Americans tried to understand and grapple with nature. The keynote speaker, the English scientist Thomas H. Huxley, personified their goals.

description: HACKETT--Dr. Elizabeth. 73, of New York, NY, and Cannes, France, passed away on March 8, 2004. A graduate of the Fieldston School and Radcliffe College, Dr. Hackett received her Ph.D. from Harvard. In 1969, she joined Pfizer Pharmaceuticals where she made major contributions to the development of drugs in Pfizer's Central Nervous System Program, with her most noteworthy contribution on the anti-depressant Zoloft. In addition, she was the primary clinician for a number of Pfizer clinical trials and contributed to many publications. After retiring from Pfizer in 2001, Liz split her time between her apartments in New York, where she volunteered at the Museum of Natural History and Cannes, France, where she volunteered at a local library. Predeceased by her beloved husband John, Liz is survived by a close knit family of cousins from the New York area, present and former Pfizer co-workers, and many others on both sides of the Atlantic. A memorial service will be held in her honor on Friday, March 19, 2004, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street at 3:30 PM, in the Madison Room.

title: A NEW LONESOME WHISTLE
description: After many delays and charges of cost overruns and instant obsolescence, the New Jersey Transit River Line was scheduled to begin operation this morning. The first train on the 36-mile light-rail route from Trenton to Camden was scheduled to pull out at 5:27 a.m. With debt service, the River Line will cost $1.1 billion for only 5,700 estimated riders a day, about 10,000 a day less than the Hudson-Bergen light rail in North Jersey. Service was supposed to start last year, but complications with Conrail, which operates freight trains on the same tracks, and neighbors who insisted on speed and time modifications delayed that start. Initial fares have been kept low -- $1.10 for a ride of any distance. Schedules have expanded on weekends to accommodate events along the Delaware River entertainment district in Camden. On weekdays, the last trains leave Trenton and Camden between 9 and 10 p.m. and on weekends, about midnight. It is the first new transit line in South Jersey in 35 years. Robert Strauss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSLER, ABRAHAM G.
description: OSLER--Abraham G. May 16, 1911-March 10, 2004. Son of immigrant parents, Max and Fanny Osofsky. Born in NYC, grew up on the lower east side and then Brooklyn. Graduated from DeWitt Clinton HS. BA from CCNY 1931; M.Sc 1933 and Ph.D. 1948 in Bacteriology from Columbia University. During the 1930's, he worked as a bacteriologist at Bronx Hospital until he was fired for trying to organize the hospital workers into what eventually became Local 1199. Married Sonia Fellner in 1938. In the early 1940's he worked for the NYC Health Department before undertaking doctoral studies. Moved to Baltimore in 1948, teaching immunology and conducting highly significant research on complement fixation at Johns Hopkins Medical School until moving to the Public Health Research Institute of the City of NY in 1968. On retirement in 1978, he moved to the UC San Diego where he consulted at the Salk Institute for two years. In 1992, he and Sonia moved to Harbour's Edge in Delray Beach, FL and in 1997 to Vantage House in Columbia, MD. Predeceased by his brothers David Osler and Louis Osler and his wife Sonia, he leaves behind his daughter Margaret J. Osler of Calgary AB, Canada; his sister Miriam Krantz of Brooklyn and several nieces and one nephew. A successful scientist and influential teacher, his friends will remember his commitment to working-class politics and his lifelong passion for art, music and literature.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: YEARS before his Oscar-nominated performance in ''Lost in Translation,'' Bill Murray was experiencing ''dizzy spells, nausea, cold sweats, hot sweats, difficulty swallowing, blurred vision, involuntary trembling, dead hands, numb lips, fingernail sensitivity, pelvic discomfort.'' Those, at least, are the symptoms that his character, Bob Wiley, describes to his psychiatrist in WHAT ABOUT BOB? (1991), a neurosis-drenched comedy that also features Richard Dreyfuss as Dr. Marvin, the finicky shrink. Bob can't stand it when Dr. Marvin escapes from New York for a monthlong vacation in New Hampshire, so he follows him up there. title: The Origins of the Final Solution
description: In a brief two years between the autumn of 1939 and the autumn of 1941, Nazi Jewish policy escalated rapidly from the prewar policy of forced emigration to the Final Solution as it is now understood-the systematic attempt to murder every last Jew within the German grasp. The mass murder of Soviet Jewry had already begun in the late summer of 1941, and only one-half year later the Nazi regime was ready to begin implementing this policy throughout the rest of its European empire and sphere of influence. The study of these 30 months-from September 1939 through March 1942-is crucial for understanding the genesis of the Final Solution and constitutes the core of this book. At this time the Nazi regime stood on the brink of a true watershed event in history. But why, after two millennia of Christian-Jewish antagonism and one millennium of a singular European anti-Semitism, did this watershed event occur in Germany in the middle of the 20th century?

title: Somerset Maugham
description: The early death of his parents and his consequent exile from home and country gave Somerset Maugham a wretched start in life. He shared Kipling's belief that "when young lips have drunk deep of the bitter waters of Hate, Suspicion, and Despair, all the Love in the world will not wholly take away that knowledge." "I had many disabilities," he wrote, looking back on his early days. "I was small; I had endurance but little physical strength; I stammered; I was shy; I had poor health. I had no facility for games." His miserable childhood left permanent scars, but provided rich material for the poignant, autobiographical Of Human Bondage and for the deeply moving Cakes and Ale. His stammer, a psychological and physical handicap, and his gradual awareness of his homosexuality made him furtive and secretive, and caused "an instinctive shrinking from my fellow men that has made it difficult for me to enter into any familiarity with them." A lifelong exile and wanderer, Maugham gave the impression of being icy, remote and arrogant. The love and affection, insight and sympathy that he repressed in everyday life were channeled into the creation of plays and stories. Maugham's teasing combination of passion and tenderness, coldness and cynicism was stamped on his life and work.

title: The Pull of Family
description: Traub's opposition to preferential admissions for legacies and minorities assumes that ''merit'' can be accurately measured in college admissions. In reality, the process is distorted by a number of factors that have more to do with parental involvement and luck than academic merit. Many students applying to elite universities have become expert at positioning themselves. They select classes, teachers and activities to strengthen their college applications. Their parents pay for tutors to improve their grades and their SAT scores, and they help with essays designed to impress college-admissions officers. All of this makes perfect sense for families who want the best for their children, but let's not pretend that abandoning preferences for legacies and minorities would result in students being selected solely on academic merit.

title: Many Ways to Wrap Your Head
description: In HEADWRAPS: A Global Journey (PublicAffairs, $35), Georgia Scott explores a common practice that dates back to the initial recording of human history and remains prevalent throughout the world today. Packed with captivating photographs and enlightening details on the practices of covering the human head by the people of 32 countries on five continents, the book discusses the vagaries of head covering: though culturally specific, headwraps transcend the boundaries of sex (men and women use them) and social class. There are cultures and communities in which the use of headwraps hold religious and moral values, as for men and women in North Africa and the women of the former Soviet Republics; in others they are decorative and ceremonial, as in rural Thailand; and in yet others they are used to establish social status and rank, as with the male spiritual leaders and chiefs of northern Nigeria. Scott, a staff artist at The New York Times, does not always adequately document the ethnic diversity of many of the nations she covers; for example, in her discussion of Trinidad and Jamaica, she ignores the sizable groups of ethnic Asians and Europeans as well as the indigenous population, and focuses only on people of African descent. On the other hand, ''Headwraps'' does provide excellent documentation of the increased use of traditional headwraps in nontraditional places and for reasons other than tradition. Nurah-Rosalie Jeter

title: The Coming of the Third Reich
description: Is it wrong to begin with Bismarck? On several levels, he was a key figure in the coming of the Third Reich. For one thing, the cult of his memory in the years after his death encouraged many Germans to long for the return of the strong leadership his name represented. For another, his actions and policies in the mid-to-late nineteenth century helped create an ominous legacy for the German future. Yet in many ways he was a complex and contradictory figure, as much European as German, as much modern as traditional. Here, too, his example pointed forwards to the tangled mixture of the new and the old that was so characteristic of the Third Reich. It is worth calling to mind that a mere fifty years separated Bismarck's foundation of the German Empire in 1871 from the electoral triumphs of the Nazis in 1930-32. That there was a connection between the two seems impossible to deny. It was here, rather than in the remote religious cultures and hierarchical polities of the Reformation or the 'Enlightened Absolutism' of the eighteenth century, that we find the first real moment in German history which it is possible to relate directly to the coming of the Third Reich in 1933.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIHS, KURT (WEISZ)
description: WEIHS--Kurt (Weisz). Fine Artist, Painter and Sculptor, Art Director/Designer, Holocaust Survivor, Greenwich Village resident since 1947. Born March 5, 1918, Vienna, Austria. Educated at the Graphic Research Institute, Vienna. Trained at the prestigious Vienna Academy of Art, where he received a full scholarship and every award. After the Anschluss (Hitler's invasion of Austria), he escaped Nazi persecution, the only person in his family to survive. As a Jewish refugee, he spent several years in a camp. Worked at CBS for 12 years (1948 to 1960) with William Golden, where he executed the timeless design of the CBS eye. A pioneer of Madison Avenue advertising, with George Lois, his career spanned more than 50 years. A fine artist, graphic talent, innovative thinker, deeply admired and respected by his family, friends and co-workers. He passed away, Sunday March 7, 2004. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Erika Weihs, his son, John S. Weihs MD, MPH, and his grandson Kris Weihs. Services were held at Frank E. Campbell, Wednesday, March 10, 2004, 12:00 noon. title: Wolf 'Control' in Alaska
description: In Alaska, the wolf wars have taken a sobering turn for the worse. For 30 years hunting lobbyists have campaigned for what is euphemistically called wolf ''control.'' Thanks to the compliance of Gov. Frank Murkowski and the state's official game board, the legal protections for Alaska's 7,000 to 9,000 wolves have been seriously eroded. In nearly 20,000 square miles of the state it is now legal for private citizens to shoot wolves from airplanes and helicopters. In one district the limit has been increased from 10 wolves a year to 10 wolves a day.

title: And, of Course, There's the Art
description: IT was Fashion Week for the art world, with the Whitney Biennial and the sixth annual Armory Show -- a giant art fair and shopping extravaganza -- occurring back to back for the first time in memory. This was a week to see, be seen, look at art, haggle over art, and, of course, network.

description: WHEN a 20-minute, just-for-men fitness center opened in Wallingford last May, it served as something of a social experiment.

title: Bookless in Bavaria
description: Iinhabit a doomed attempt at minimal living. The shelves on my restricted wall space hold just a fraction of my books. Hence, like a hideous example of urban sprawl, my active library has invaded the floor, forming a labyrinth of precarious stacks and sliding heaps.

description: Unrest set off by Kurdish demonstrators demanding minority rights spread across northeastern Syria on Saturday, with Kurdish leaders saying up to 15 people were killed and scores wounded over two days as the riot police put down the rare protests with gunfire.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Dollar
description: EARLY last year, an American arriving in Europe might have reckoned that a dollar exchanged for pounds or euros might just suffice to buy a newspaper or maybe, in some places, a coffee. Twelve months later, don't be so sure.

description: COINCIDING with Women's History Month, four solo exhibitions in New York City highlight the work of distinguished female artists who have studios on Long Island.

description: More than 50 representatives of various faith groups in New Jersey gathered at the Statehouse on Thursday to unveil the Interfaith Campaign Against Tobacco. The Rev. Jack Johnson, a United Methodist district superintendent and the campaign's coordinator, seeks to spread the gospel of good health.

title: The Good Jailer
description: On a sunny winter afternoon, Warden Jeanne Woodford walked the grounds of San Quentin State Prison on the San Francisco Bay. The prison officers wore green-and-khaki uniforms and inmates were in faded blue work shirts and jeans or orange jumpsuits, but Woodford was fashionably dressed in an olive green wool skirt and cream V-neck sweater. Her auburn-and-gold hair was clipped short. There was a pair of diamonds in each ear, more diamonds on her fingers and a gold chain around her neck. Woodford, who is 50 years old and 5-foot-7, was, as usual, unarmed. She walked past throngs of prisoners, and though she was the first female warden in San Quentin's 152-year history, and all 5,600 inmates were male, there was not a catcall or whistle. Inmates greeted her, ''Good afternoon, ma'am,'' ''Godspeed, Mrs. Woodford'' and ''Yo, Miss Warden.''

title: Undampened
description: The romance of early daffodils, flowering trees and Paris in the rain set the mood for the elegant throngs of international fashion buyers and editors at some of this month's designer shows and accessory fairs under the tents in the Tuileries garden. The fashion star was the dashing trench coat, some versions etched in tweed and beads.

description: To the Editor: ''If Cleopatra Visited Burgundy'' (Feb. 1), by Sarah Ferrell, helped us relive our time on the Esprit seven years ago, when we celebrated our 50th anniversary.

title: Lethargic Recovery of Uranium
description: At a time when the United States is trying desperately to keep nuclear weapons out of the hands of rogue nations and terrorist groups, it is disheartening to learn of the government's pathetically weak efforts to recover bomb-grade uranium from research reactors around the world.

description: SHENANDOAH and Creamery Road are two neighborhoods in this Dutchess County town with names that evoke pastoral, wholesome country life. They also have something much grimmer in common: both now have ground water contaminated by toxic chemicals.

description: For the climactic showdown of the four-and-a-half-month Alpine ski season, it was an oddly muted day.

description: Iran indefinitely suspended international inspections of its nuclear facilities on Saturday in an angry response to a resolution by the United Nations atomic agency that criticized its activities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMPBELL, MARILYN (NEE BAILEY)
description: CAMPBELL--Marilyn (nee Bailey). On March 12, 2004 of Purdys, NY. Beloved wife of William Reason Campbell. Devoted mother of Morgan and Sarah. The family will receive friends at the Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Rd., Katonah, NY, on Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, March 16, in the funeral home at 10 AM. Interment Ivandell Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Alzheimer's Association are requested.

title: U.S. Gives Brookhaven Lab Inside Track on Projects
description: After lobbying by members of New York's Congressional delegation, the Department of Homeland Security has reversed an earlier decision and agreed to offer Brookhaven National Laboratory preferential treatment in national security research projects.

title: Face-Off
description: John Galliano opened the fall 2004 men's shows in Paris on a Friday evening, and Hedi Slimane closed them a few days later, and the fact that the two Dior stars were on the same bill gave the weekend a frisson you normally expect of a Sam Peckinpah western. No blood would be spilled, though some of Galliano's men were made up to at least look bruised and hardened from a fight. And really, there was no logic to this notion of a Dior duel, since Galliano, the Dior women's-wear designer, was showing his clothes under his own label, which has been around since 1984, when Slimane, the Dior Homme designer, was a sapling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUNEBAUM, GABRIELE HILDEGARD
description: GRUNEBAUM--Gabriele Hildegard. Of Rye, NY, and East Orleans, MA, died Monday, March 1, 2004, at her home in Westchester. She was 93 years old. Mrs. Grunebaum was born Gabriele Neumann in Cottbus, Germany, in 1910. She earned her law degree in Berlin before fleeing Germany with her late husband Erich in 1938. After settling in Scarsdale, Mrs. Grunebaum earned a masters degree in social work from Adelphi University and was a founder of Camp Shalom, a summer program for underprivileged New York City kids based at Congregation Habonim. Mrs. Grunebaum served for many years as the Vice President of the Okiyoe Society of New York. A resident of Dobbs Ferry for 27 years, she was a member of the Historical Society, the Friends of the Croton Aqueduct, and the Hudson River Museum. She is survived by her three children, Ernest Michael Grunebaum of Pound Ridge, NY, Dr. E. Irene Koppel of Springfield, NJ, and David F. Grunebaum of Sudbury, MA, eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Donations can be made to Self Help Community Services and Congregation Habonim at 44 W. 66th St, NY, NY.

title: Origin of Species
description: Nandan Nilekani, C.E.O. of the Indian software giant Infosys, gave me a tour the other day of his company's wood-paneled global conference room in Bangalore. It looks a lot like a beautiful tiered classroom, with a massive wall-size screen at one end and cameras in the ceiling so that Infosys can hold a simultaneous global teleconference with its U.S. innovators, its Indian software designers and its Asian manufacturers. ''We can have our whole global supply chain on the screen at the same time,'' holding a virtual meeting, explained Mr. Nilekani. The room's eight clocks tell the story: U.S. West, U.S. East, G.M.T., India, Singapore, Hong Kong, Japan, Australia.

title: Questions for Robert Rauschenberg
description: Robert Rauschenberg was asked about an exhibition of his work currently showing at Yale, to which he responded: ''I am not happy with it. It was organized by the gay studies department, whatever that is. It's not an approach that makes sense. I refused to give them permission to reproduce the works in a catalog'' (The Way We Live Now, Deborah Solomon, Feb. 15). I write to remind Rauschenberg: the exhibition is in the Jonathan Edwards College master's house, organized by me (the college master), with the assistance of the Larry Kramer Initiative for Lesbian and Gay Studies.

title: On Baseball; Phillies Hope Reality Matches Expectations
description: LARRY BOWA was not manager of the year last season, but credit him with making the most perceptive and realistic comment of the year.

title: Lincoln And Telfair Advance
description: It seemed as if half of Coney Island had made the trek to St. John's yesterday for the Public Schools Athletic League semifinal between neighborhood rivals Grady and Lincoln. Although the outcome was what mattered most for both Brooklyn schools, most in the crowd of 3,312 had come to see Sebastian Telfair, whose high school career could have come to an end.

title: First the Free Test, Then the Free Tunes
description: Nicole and Chalome Bergan had given up any hope of attending the hottest concert around, a show featuring the Grammy winners Beyonc, Alicia Keys and Missy Elliott. But five hours before the concert began on Friday night, the sisters learned that they were getting in. Free.

title: Sarah Hurwitt, Ian Clark
description: Sarah Ellen Hurwitt, a daughter of Susan and David Hurwitt of Rowayton, Conn., was married yesterday to Ian Clark, a son of Marjorie Clark of Denbigh, North Wales, and the late Michael Clark. The Rev. J. C. Austin performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: Rehabilitating Little Black Sambo
description: The century-old tale of the steadfast boy menaced by a succession of hungry tigers who melt into butter has never been forgotten, though in recent years ''Little Black Sambo'' all but disappeared from bookstores and library shelves. To some, of course, the story, by an Englishwoman living in India, is irredeemably freighted with racist associations; ''Sambo'' was a pejorative term applied to blacks from the mid-18th century onward, and in early editions the boy looked like a guileless, wide-eyed simpleton. The elaborate new edition of THE STORY OF LITTLE BLACK SAMBO (Handprint Books, $17.95; all ages), by Helen Bannerman, which has been meticulously reimagined and lavishly illustrated by Christopher Bing, struggles mightily against that legacy.

title: Enough Already

title: Just the Man to Bring Wotan Down to Size, With Stature
description: A PARTICULAR fascination of the Eos Orchestra's ''Valkyrie'' is its Wotan, Sanford Sylvan. Mr. Sylvan's high reputation rests on his skills as an empathetic interpreter of Bach, Mozart and Schubert. As Zhou Enlai in the famous Peter Sellars production of John Adams's ''Nixon in China,'' he limned a tender, introspective portrait of Mao's second in command. Wotan -- nominally first in command, actually a leader whose authority is traumatically unraveling -- represents a different kind of challenge from any previously associated with Mr. Sylvan's smooth baritone, keen diction and humane presence.

title: In Labor Dispute, Double Takes For Union's 'Duane Reade' Bags
description: The tourists gawking in Times Square had one more distraction last Wednesday, in an unlikely place. It was the Duane Reade drugstore on Broadway near 42nd Street, where a labor union locked in a bitter dispute with the pharmacy chain had parked two flatbed trucks hauling large signs that bore the slogan ''Dwayne Greed,'' in the company's familiar red and blue color scheme.

title: A Plea to Foster Families: Keep Muslims Muslim
description: Six years ago, a Muslim businessman in Riverdale, the Bronx, named A.T. Alishtari learned of a Pakistani-American brother and sister, 4 and 5, whose family had been destroyed by drug abuse. Mr. Alishtari asked some local Pakistani imams to find a family to take them in.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Feb. 22 about eight books on the domestic effects of the war on terrorism misstated the timing of detentions and expulsions of suspected subversive aliens now known as the Palmer raids. They took place in 1919-20, not during World War I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHSCHILD, CHARLES HERBERT

description: The police said Saturday that a Fresno man, Marcus D. Wesson, would be charged with murdering nine of his children, a crime so gruesome and distressing that police officers wept at the sight of the bodies.

title: Giving Life to the Characters of Myth
description: MARY ZIMMERMAN'S exhilarating vision of ''Metamorphoses'' is now, happily, at Hartford Stage. The play is adapted from the narrative poem about the symbolic origin of everything by the ancient Roman poet Ovid. In Ms. Zimmerman's work, the poem is illuminated so that it sparkles for us, here and now.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Adapting a New Haven Tower for Assisted Living
description: RENOVATION has started on 60 units in an apartment tower for older residents in New Haven under a new government program designed to create assisted-living units in developments that have not previously had them.

title: Sighted: 100 Pies In Silent Flight
description: RUTH, all a-rustle in eyelet lace and beribboned petticoat, her golden curls bobbing like Slinkies, had trouble to spare. For one thing, her imperious father, Brewster Thickwad III, refused to let her marry the penniless charmer Billy; for another, it looked as if she might have to wed the sinister rake Lionel Drippinwithit. But when the actress playing Ruth saw that a hapless visitor was about to experience her first pie fight, she put her character's troubles aside and offered some useful advice: ''Try to keep your eyes closed!'' And then the foam began to fly.

title: A Trooper Unwelcome at the Courthouse

title: Piazzaman
description: ''Could I have some more ah-gua, per fah-for-eh?'' Owen Wilson asks the waitress in a restaurant just off Piazza di Spagna in Rome. His Italian is 100 percent Texas tourist; you almost hear President Bush speaking Spanish. ''I don't know why they can't make the Italian food at home taste like here,'' Wilson says, eyeballing a piece of tuna in his salad. ''Go into any dive, and it's the best Italian food you ever had.''

title: The Paradox of the Self-Effacing Diva
description: IN the 10 months since she became a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, 23-year-old Alexandra Ansanelli has provoked passionate speculation among New York's balletomanes as to whether she is to become a major star. In the season that just ended, she drew critical accolades for her performances in Susan Stroman's ''Double Feature'' (''sweetly demure, but also gutsy,'' said Backstage); ''Harlequinade'' (she showed ''aplomb, musicality, and charm'' said The New York Observer) and ''Jewels'' (she was ''deliriously applauded,'' according to this newspaper). The ballerina herself denies that fame is a goal to which she consciously aspires. ''At this stage, I still feel like a novice,'' she said in an interview at the New York State Theater last month, a few days before her debut in her biggest role thus far: Aurora in ''The Sleeping Beauty.''

He went on to explain that he wanted to tell me about a new county program called ''You Are Not Alone,'' in which I could arrange to have loved ones who live alone checked on by telephone.

title: Making Charity Dollars Go Farther
description: LONG ISLAND'S social safety net is in danger of unraveling. State and county governments are suffering unprecedented financial pressures, and beleaguered residents are experiencing tax increases as a result of rising Medicaid costs and exploding pension costs. Predictably, governments have had to review all nonmandated spending including spending on the safety net constructed to prevent our most vulnerable neighbors from falling through the cracks.

They were Channing Daughters and Wlffer, on the South Fork, and Bedell, Lenz, Paumanok and Raphael, on the North Fork.

title: Beware of Islanders Bearing Slugs
description: IN a looking-glass universe where consumer goods are small and light enough to be carried away on the slightest breeze, indentured servants on a Pacific island tote, ''from dock to inland rail,'' the lead slugs necessary to weigh down toasters and telephones. A well-intentioned philanthropist decides to bring them ''that form of prose poetry known as 'consumer fiction' '' -- i.e., appliance instruction manuals. But the natives resist its charms.

title: Ellen Manaker, Gerald Cohen

title: Life in the Age of Old, Old Age
description: Susan Dominus's article (Feb. 22) set out the ethical problems that arise in creating a superaging population but only hinted at the positive effects on society, and the individual, of ''living past the prime.'' Many of us use the years beyond our primary careers to embark on new ones.

title: Wholesalers Eye Queens As a Warehouse Wonderland
description: Jay Chung, a wholesaler of desk clocks and snow globes on West 27th Street near the Avenue of the Americas, believes that he and his business partner have found his industry's promised land in northern Queens. It is 26 acres of soggy soil that was once Flushing Airport and is now part of the College Point Corporate Park, a low-lying area convenient to several expressways and La Guardia Airport.

title: Emulating the Real and Vital Guthrie, Not St. Woody
description: WOODY GUTHRIE'S ghost must be getting exhausted. Ever since Guthrie -- the Oklahoma-born singer, writer and activist who wrote and recorded American classics like ''This Land Is Your Land'' -- died in 1967, musicians on the political left have been invoking his spirit.

title: Maier Completes Comeback of All Comebacks
description: SESTRIERE, Italy  No matter how many World Cup points Hermann Maier ends up with when the last race is completed here on Sunday, he is the winner this season. No matter how many crystal globes he presses to his barrel chest and grizzled face, no other skier, perhaps no other athlete, has been as inspirational as Maier over the last year.

title: An Official Not Afraid to Speak His Mind
description: WHEN state lawmakers were still hesitant to form an opinion on Gov. John G. Rowland's behavior and held press conferences where they announced how ''sad'' and ''solemn'' they were, Alan S. Plofsky, executive director of the state's ethics commission, struck a different chord. Speaking to a Hartford Courant reporter shortly after the governor admitted he had lied, Mr. Plofsky compared the insider deals in the administration to ''what takes place in a Third World, despotic regime, where I think they call it baksheesh.''

title: Muchachos Of Summer
description: There was a time when making it as a ballplayer in the Dominican Republic required not just talent but also superhuman effort and ingenuity. In Rob Ruck's informative history ''The Tropic of Baseball,'' the catcher Tony Pea, who grew up in Palo Verde in the late 1960's and early 70's, remembers having to make his own mitt out of cardboard and his own ball out of rubber salvaged from old tires. To sharpen his skills, he improvised ways to make the game even more difficult: ''We took the seed from the guasima tree, and Ramn'' -- his brother -- ''pitched that to me instead of a ball, so I could learn to hit fastballs better,'' he says. ''For curves, he threw me bottle caps.''

title: Honeymoon
description: To the Editor: We read with amusement ''Honeymoon Retreat'' (Feb. 1) about Brenda Fowler's camping honeymoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHANIEL, GEORGE S.
description: NATHANIEL--George S. Born 86 years ago today in Baghdad, Iraq, died on January 4, 2004 of complications following a broken hip. His family moved during his adolescence to Tehran, Iran where he eventually attended the American University. Sponsored by his American professor, George left all he knew and loved in the old world, to meet the future in the USA, which he believed then and for the rest of his life to be the land of freedom and opportunity. He accom plished much for those he cherished most in his life: his family. He married Dr. Semha Sheena, also of Baghdad, and they raised three children. One of the original handful of Iraqi Jews to settle in the US, he was the keeper of the continuity of the family, both here and abroad. He helped bring his mother, six siblings, seven in-laws and 15 nieces and nephews to the US and Canada. He loved education and was unflaggingly interested in the welfare of all members of his family until his death. His wife, one daughter, two sons, seven grandchildren and an eighth on the way survive him.

title: Common Of Earthly Delights
description: Times Square is surely the most familiar and most frequently reproduced fragment of urban real estate on the planet. Even those of us who are too young to have known Times Square in its age of glory -- even many people who have never been to New York, for that matter -- carry in their heads a nocturnal black-and-white image of glowing signs for Camel cigarettes and the Bond Clothing store, of humpbacked taxis coursing through the X-shaped crossroads of Broadway and Seventh Avenue, of crowds of men in dark suits and fedoras gazing up at the news zipper on the Times Tower. They're nostalgia magnets, these pictures. We look at them and think, That was life. The hats, the crowds, the shows, the bars -- yes, here was life in the center of the city that was the center of the world. And as Times Square is in so many ways the incarnation of urban life itself, so nostalgia for Times Square is nostalgia for a lost idea of urbanness, or of urbanity -- for a time, before the advent of television and the suburbs, and before riots and drug wars, when everyone knew that city life was the best life of all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, SHERMAN R., JR.
description: LEWIS--Sherman R., Jr., 67 of Manhattan, New York, died March 11, 2004. Mr. Lewis was a vice chairman and international investment banker at Lehman Brothers Holdings, Inc. Throughout his 30-year career at Lehman Brothers, he held numerous senior positions, including partner in the Corporate Finance Department at Loeb Rhoades & Co., a predecessor firm of Lehman Brothers, and, after Loeb Rhoades was acquired by Shearson Hayden Stone, Mr. Lewis was named president. Born in Ottawa, IL, Mr. Lewis was a graduate of Northwestern University and the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business Administration. He served on the President's Commission on Housing and the President's Council for International Youth Exchange during the Reagan administration. He was a University Trustee, a founding member and past Chairman of the Board of Visitors of the College of Arts and Sciences and a former Alumni Regent at Northwestern University. Mr. Lewis was also a member of the Advisory Council to the Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago. In addition, Mr. Lewis served as a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, the U.S.-Japan Business Council, The Korea Society, The U.S.Greece Business Council, Euro-Amer Holding S.A., Infraworks Corporation and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Marine Corps Heritage Center Founders' Group. Mr. Lewis served in the United States Marine Corps and was a commissioned officer on active duty from 1958 to 1961. He is survived by his devoted wife of 37 years, Dorothy, and by his beloved children, Thomas, Catherine, Elizabeth, and Michael, and cherished granddaughters Olivia and Riley, and brothers Robin and Randal. Calling hours are from 2:00-5:00 p.m. and 7:009:00 p.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., in New York City, on Monday, March 15. The funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 16 at 10:30 a.m. at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 1140 Park Ave. at 91st St. Contributions can be made to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, P.O. Box 19024, J5-200, Seattle, WA 98109 to Dr. Rainer Storb's research in memory of Sherman R. Lewis, Jr. or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021 to Dr. Mark Heaney's research in memory of Sherman R. Lewis, attention Jennifer Jacobson, Development Office.

title: An Expat's Dilemma
description: The airport in Port-au-Prince was chaotic. I got there at 8 o'clock in the morning, and it was already crowded. People were screaming and crying; everyone was trying to get out. In Haiti, just by looking at you, people can tell that you don't live in the country. By the way you dress, and by how healthy you look, they can tell that you are part of the diaspora. They see you as someone who has money, maybe as someone who is better than they. But what can I do? I try to help them. You have to do that if you can. Luckily, I had called the airline a few days ahead. I was able to change my reservation and get my father a ticket. He's the only family I have in Haiti, and I wanted to get him out until things were more stable. Our flight to Boston on Feb. 26 was the second to last one leaving the country.

title: The Personal Jesus
description: Stephen Prothero (Feb. 29) puts his finger on the key mystery of Mel Gibson's ''Passion of the Christ'': why do so many evangelical Protestants, heirs to a tradition that long vilified Catholics for visualizing a bleeding and wounded Jesus, turn around and champion Gibson's film? One answer is that the traditionalist Catholic Gibson actually surrenders the heart of the traditional Catholic Passion: its mystery. He makes it easy for evangelicals to endorse his film by giving them a visually literalist Passion to go with their literalist reading of the Bible. Traditional Catholic piety dwelt reverentially upon Christ's ''five most precious wounds'' (two in his hands, two in his feet, one in his side) as signs of his complete obedience to his father's will.

title: MOZART BY ITS RIGHTFUL NAME
description: A Mozart mystery has been solved at last. So says the musicologist Michael Lorenz, an expert on the Viennese music of the late 18th and early 19th centuries, and the proof of the pudding will be served on Thursday in Vienna when the pianist Robert Levin sits down to join Sir Roger Norrington and the Radio Symphony Orchestra Stuttgart to play Mozart's piano concerto in E-flat (K. 271) for the first time under its proper name. For more than a century, Dr. Lorenz says, the identity of the French pianist for whom the young Mozart, above, wrote the piece has baffled Mozart scholars, and the work has been known as the ''Jeunehomme'' Concerto. Dr. Lorenz says that jeune homme, or young man, a reference to Mozart, was the name given to it by a pair of French scholars in a 1912 biography because they couldn't identify the woman for whom he actually wrote it. After that, he says, scholars refrained from further research. Mozart, in a letter to his father, Leopold, after finishing the concerto in January 1777, referred to the pianist as ''jenomy,'' and Leopold referred to her as ''Madame genomai.'' Dr. Lorenz says the mystery woman was actually Victoire Jenamy, a daughter of Jean George Noverre, a famous dancer who was one of Mozart's best friends. Dr. Lorenz says a bit of research in the City Archive of Vienna last year established that Victoire was an excellent pianist, and it was she who commissioned the concerto in Vienna in 1776. Adieu Jeunehomme. Enter, for the first time, the ''Jenamy'' Concerto. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: A Solo, With a City in the Background
description: The apparent intention of "Barcelona in 48 Hours," an hourlong multimedia piece performed on March 6 at Dance Theater Workshop, was to evoke the anomie of the constant traveler and perhaps the bittersweet impermanence of two lovers meeting in a foreign city for a mere two days. The production values were first rate and the theme was promising. Anja Hitzenberger's soft-edged photographs and film of Barcelona created a sense of that vital city. Edward Ratliff's incident-packed music, performed live and on tape, gave the dance component the context and support of a good film score. But in the end this introduction to the city seemed merely a prop for the self-involvement of David Zambrano, the internationally known modern-dance choreographer and teacher who conceived the piece.

title: Beyond the Duck Blind

To protect the Supreme Court's integrity and legitimacy -- and honor the rule of law -- the final choice can no longer be left to Justice Scalia alone. Unless he suddenly reverses himself, the Supreme Court as a whole has a duty to intervene, much as it reviews the recusal decisions of lower-court judges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HACKETT, DR. ELIZABETH
description: HACKETT--Dr. Elizabeth. 73, of New York, NY, and Cannes, France, passed away on March 8, 2004. A graduate of the Fieldston School and Radcliffe College, Dr. Hackett received her Ph.D. from Harvard. In 1969, she joined Pfizer Pharmaceuticals where she made major contributions to the development of drugs in Pfizer's Central Nervous System Program, with her most noteworthy contribution on the anti-depressant Zoloft. In addition, she was the primary clinician for a number of Pfizer clinical trials and contributed to many publications. After retiring from Pfizer in 2001, Liz split her time between her apartments in New York, where she volunteered at the Museum of Natural History and Cannes, France, where she volunteered at a local library. Predeceased by her beloved husband John, Liz is survived by a close knit family of cousins from the New York area, present and former Pfizer co-workers, and many others on both sides of the Atlantic. A memorial service will be held in her honor on Friday, March 19, 2004, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street at 3:30 PM, in the Madison Room.

title: $3 MILLION GRANT FOR FILM FESTIVAL

The money is to be used for expanding the festival's free programs and increasing downtown economic activity, which suffered after the 2001 terrorist attacks. This year's festival, the third, is scheduled for May 1 through 9. The grant will help finance the festival's guide and events, including a drive-in, panels, workshops and a seven-block family festival. ''The TriBeCa Film Festival has been a wonderful cultural event and economic boost for the downtown area,'' Kevin M. Rampe, the president of the development corporation, said in a statement late last week. ''We are pleased to be a part of the festival's continued success.'' In addition, Gov. George E. Pataki announced a $200,000 Empire State Development grant to support the TriBeCa Film Institute Inc., which will subsidize the institute's year-round education and networking programs. ROBIN POGREBIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAW, JOHN F.
description: SHAW--John F. Of John's Island, Florida, died after a brief illness on March 13, 2004. Mr. Shaw was known to many as ''Jack,'' the owner and proprietor of the famous Emily Shaw's Inn in Pound Ridge, New York, which he operated for 40 years. He attended the Hun School in Princeton, New Jersey, and graduated from the Pace Institute in New York City. For four years during World War II, Mr. Shaw headed the 24 hour commissary at the Norton Bomb Sight in Danbury, CT. Mr. Shaw was the former co-Chair of the House Committee at John's Island Golf and Beach Club in Vero Beach, Florida. Mr. Shaw was a fine golfer, participating in 16 club championships, of which he won 11. His record low round of 64 at the Waccabuc Country Club in Waccabuc, New York, still stands, as well as his amateur club record of 66 at the High Ridge Country Club in Stamford, CT. He won the Ridgewood Country Club Golf Title for three consecutive years. Mr. Shaw also played semi-professional hockey with the Metropolitan All-Stars, New York CurbExchange and New Canaan Oilers and was twice the league's leading scorer. Mr. Shaw was inducted to the Hun School Sports Hall of Fame in 1997. Mr. Shaw is survived by his brother, Ralph Shaw of Jupiter, FL, son Steven C. Shaw of Southampton, NY, and daughters, Linda S. Neave of Rowayton, CT, and Emily A. McDonough of Vero Beach, step-daughter Pamela Bellmore of Berkeley Springs, WV, and five grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. A graveside service will be held at the Pound Ridge Cemetery. Contact Franklin Hoyt Funeral Home, 203-966-0700. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 27, at Christ by-theSea, at 11 AM, in Vero Beach, Florida. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the VNA Hospice of Indian River, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960, in memory of Jack Shaw.

title: Bombs won't deter Europe, they assert : Bush aides confident over war on terror

title: Celebrating Women Composers, for the Last Time
description: SAN FRANCISCO - The Women's Philharmonic has been a distinctive institution here for more than 23 years. A concert on March 7 at the Herbst Theater was in many respects a celebration: really good music by female composers played by female musicians under a female conductor. The largely but by no means exclusively female audience applauded lustily.

title: A Tug of War Over 'Stupid White Men'
description: Next week, a tiny Brooklyn-based publisher will bring out ''How to Get Stupid White Men Out of Office.'' The book, a low-budget paperback written by a group of political activists, is not to be confused with ''Stupid White Men,'' a HarperCollins best seller by the filmmaker and author Michael Moore, which remains in hardcover.

title: Cid Corman, 79, Prolific Poet, Editor and Translator
description: Cid Corman, a prolific American poet, editor and translator who lived in Japan for the last four decades, died on Friday at a hospital in Kyoto. He was 79.

title: BLOOMBERG WINS ON SCHOOL TESTS AFTER FIRING FOES
description: The city's Panel for Educational Policy yesterday approved Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan to impose strict promotion requirements for third graders, but only after the mayor and the Staten Island borough president fired and replaced three members just before the vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODSIDE, VICTOR, M.D.
description: GOODSIDE--Victor, M.D. Of Mount Vernon, age 97, passed away peacefully at home, March 13, 2004. A graduate of Virginia Medical College, he had been a practicing clinician, scholar, and Chief of Ophthalmologic Surgery at Bronx Lebanon and Montefiore Hospitals. He pursued his multitude of interests with intellectual rigor and an elfin sense of humor. He is survived by his beloved wife of 69 years, Ray, and daughters Fran Feigert (Frank), Marian Goodside, and Elaine Stone (Bob). He was a devoted and proud brother to Grace Paley, brother-in-law to Evelyn Perlman, and grandpa to Ben, Dan, Liz and Amy. He had a great life, enriching so many, and we miss him already.

title: Two Ministers Are Charged In Gay Nuptials
description: The Ulster County district attorney filed criminal charges yesterday against two Unitarian ministers who performed same-sex marriage ceremonies in New Paltz, N.Y., after a court barred the mayor from doing so.

title: 3M RAISES FORECAST OF QUARTERLY EARNINGS
description: The 3M Company, the maker of Scotch tape, Post-it Notes and touch computer screens, raised its first-quarter profit forecast to a range of 86 cents to 88 cents a share. The company had previously forecast profit of 80 cents to 82 cents a share for the period, up from net income of 63 cents a year earlier. For the year, the company, which is based in St. Paul, expects earnings per share of $3.52 to $3.62 a share, up from its previous forecast of $3.46 to $3.52 a share and its year-earlier income of $3.02. The forecast was higher than the predictions of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. In after-hours trading, 3M's shares rose more than $2.

title: Weak On Terror
description: ''My most immediate priority,'' Spain's new leader, Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, declared yesterday, ''will be to fight terrorism.'' But he and the voters who gave his party a stunning upset victory last Sunday don't believe the war in Iraq is part of that fight. And the Spanish public was also outraged by what it perceived as the Aznar government's attempt to spin last week's terrorist attack for political purposes.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES TO BUY GERMAN REFRIGERATION UNIT
description: The United Technologies Corporation, the world's biggest maker of air- conditioners, agreed to buy the refrigeration unit of Linde of Germany for 325 million euros ($398 million) to gain customers and expand the product range. Linde brings with it a 40 percent share of the European market for United Technologies, which makes Carrier air-conditioners. The purchase price includes unspecified debt plus 70 million euros in pension and related obligations. United Technologies is based in Hartford. ''The two companies balance each other well geographically, in product and service ranges,'' Carrier's president, Geraud Darnis, said in a statement. The Linde unit has sales of about $1 billion.

description: West Virginia has just five presidential electoral votes, but they are five crucial electoral votes as evidenced by the intensity of campaign activity today both on the ground and over the air in the Mountain State.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Utility Sale Delayed
description: Faced with protests by labor unions, Thailand has delayed for at least two months plans to privatize the national utility, the Electricity Generating Authority of Thailand. The government of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra had planned to sell a 25 percent stake in the utility this spring for as much as 70 billion baht ($1.8 billion). But unions oppose the sale, saying it would probably put the company in the control of politicians or foreigners and result in job losses, and have demanded that it be canceled. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AVEDON, EVELYN FRANKLIN
description: AVEDON--Evelyn Franklin. Wife of Richard, mother of John, mother-in-law of Laura, grandmother of William, Matthew, Michael, and Caroline. Died peacefully March 13, 2004. Her grace, beauty, and loving heart will be missed by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUONOCORE, LUKE
description: BUONOCORE--Luke. He had great strength, integrity, vitality, creativity and judgement. It was a privilege to have known him. My sincere condolences to his family and friends. John T. Hunter

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EHRICH, DR. F. FREDERICK
description: EHRICH--Dr. F. Frederick, of Wilmington, DE, on March 14, 2004, at the age of 84. Beloved husband of Ceceil (nee Rinder); loving father of Anne Alden and her husband David of Bloomfield Hills, MI, Beth Ehrich Berkeley and her husband Dr. Alan of Scarsdale, NY, and Meg Goodman and her husband Bennett of Scarsdale, NY; adoring grandfather of Ben, Peter, Lauren, Lissy, Lisa, Jared, Ellen, Alex, Rachel and Julia; dear brother of Lillian Rapp of Cranbury, NJ and Herbert Ehrich of Mountainside, NJ. Fred lived his life to the highest standards and taught his family by example. He was dearly loved and will remain in our hearts forever. Funeral service Tuesday, March 16, 12:30 PM, from the ''Westchester Reform Temple,'' 255 Mamaroneck Rd., Scarsdale, NY. title: Stumping Kerry Sidesteps Blasts and Election in Spain
description: Senator John Kerry has conspicuously avoided speaking out on the terrorist attacks in Spain and the fall of the government there, a departure from his practice of trying to use the events of the day to bolster his case against President Bush.

title: Dairy Diet Found Good for Gout
description: Doctors usually recommend a diet heavy on dairy products and light on meat and fish for people who have gout. Such diets can also help prevent the disease, researchers report in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Sedna Beyond Pluto
description: On March 27, a naked-eye observer in mid-northern latitudes will be able to see five of our neighboring planets in the evening sky at once: Mercury, Venus, Mars, Saturn and Jupiter. It will take a low horizon and, of course, good weather to witness this unusual sight. While you're watching, it's worth thinking about the fact that there is no formal astronomical definition of ''planet.'' Until recently, there has simply been no need to define the term officially. Here in the inner reaches of the solar system it's been quite enough to know a planet when you see one.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Sumatran Tiger Reportedly Near Extinction
description: The Sumatran tiger is on the brink of extinction because illegal poaching and logging is destroying its natural habitat, the World Wildlife Fund and Traffic, the British-based wildlife-trade monitor, report. Only about 500 to 600 Sumatran tigers still live in the wild, and poaching is reducing the number by 50 a year. Sue Lieberman, director of the W.W.F. species program, said the tiger could be saved if Indonesia enforced bans on poaching and trade in animal parts, and if international donors helped villagers find alternative means of earning a living. Two Indonesian tigers have died out: the Bali tiger in the 1940's and the Java tiger in the 1980's. Fiona Fleck (NYT)

title: A Crazy Day, With Slapstick Mozart
description: ''La Folle Journe'' (''The Crazy Day'') was the original title of the Beaumarchais play also known as ''Le Mariage de Figaro,'' and it's an apt epithet for the opera that Mozart based on it, especially as done at the New York City Opera in John Copley's traditional and effective production. The day is folle indeed, thanks to a healthy dose of slapsticky stage business, sometimes threatening to slide into exaggeration, and it's also a whole journe, since City Opera offers it with its original three intermissions, which means it extends over the entire afternoon.

title: Officials Tending to Blame Qaeda for Madrid Attack
description: As the Spanish government all but dropped its claims on Monday that the Madrid train bombings were probably the work of Basque separatists, senior counterterrorism officials in the United States said they were increasingly convinced that Islamic militants were behind the attacks.

description: OREGON: COUNTY SAYS IT WILL CONTINUE GAY MARRIAGES Officials for Multnomah County said they would continue to issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples despite a ruling by the state attorney general, Hardy Myers, that doing so violates Oregon law. Gov. Theodore R. Kulongoski has asked the county to stop issuing licenses until a decision by the state's Supreme Court. The county, which includes Portland, began issuing the licenses two weeks ago after the county attorney said that not doing so could expose the county to lawsuits from same-sex couples. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Nations With Troops in Iraq Make No Move to Join Spain
description: The announcement by Spain's prime minister-elect that he would withdraw Spanish troops from Iraq by midyear was clearly bad news for the other countries that have contributed forces there, but on Monday none of them gave indications that the Spanish move would affect their own troop commitments.

title: JUDGE APPROVES BRIDGESTONE'S SETTLEMENT OF TIRE SUIT
description: A Texas judge has approved the Bridgestone Corporation's $149 million settlement of lawsuits stemming from the recall of more than 10 million tires that safety officials linked to more than 271 highway deaths. The settlement means the company might pay $70 million to replace tires; $41 million to make improved tires; $19 million in cash for lawyers' fees and expenses; and $15.5 million to establish a consumer education program, according to the consumers' lawyer, Zona Jones. More than 40 named plaintiffs in the suit will get $2,500 each, Ms. Jones said. The settlement, approved Friday in Beaumont, Tex., by Judge Donald J. Floyd, resolves 30 class-action suits filed nationwide. The settlement is on behalf of consumers who were not injured and had not suffered property damage linked to the failure of the tires.

title: Gunmen Kill 3 U.S. Civilians In Car in Mosul
description: Three American civilians were killed and two others wounded Monday when their vehicle was raked by gunfire in the northern Iraqi city of Mosul, a military spokesman said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Rikers Officer Sentenced For Murder
description: A former Rikers Island correction officer was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life for fatally beating her father and assaulting her half-sister in what prosecutors claim was an inheritance scheme. On Feb. 9, the former officer, Renee Dasque, 38, was convicted of murder and assault in connection with an attack on her father, Jacques, 63, and half-sister, Jeanine, 33. The Queens district attorney's office charged that Ms. Dasque struck them with a pipe at the family's Queens home in July 2001. As the family's sole heir, Ms. Dasque would have inherited more than $1 million in stocks, bank accounts and real estate, prosecutors said. Part of the evidence at her trial was a list in her handwriting, describing assets and materials needed to carry out the plot. Jeanine Dasque, who escaped after being struck and called the police, committed suicide last year. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Pakistani's Nuclear Earnings: $100 Million
description: The Bush administration said Monday that the clandestine network created by Abdul Qadeer Khan, the Pakistani nuclear scientist, netted $100 million for the technology it sold to Libya alone, and for the first time officials displayed a carefully selected sample of the type of equipment that the network sold to arm Libya, Iran and North Korea.

description: President Bush brought his campaign to the suburbs of Philadelphia on Monday, seeking to appeal to the moderate voters he needs if he is to bring Pennsylvania into his column in November.

title: Record Gas Pump Prices Expected in Spring
description: HOUSTON, March 16 — Anyone who has not been shocked yet by the rapid climb in gasoline prices in recent weeks might want to brace for what is to come. The fear of disruptions in oil supplies and stricter environmental regulations are expected to push prices at the gas pump to record levels this spring and summer.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Starbucks' New Music Service
description: The Starbucks Corporation is introducing a music service to make personalized CD's for customers while they sip. Working with Hewlett-Packard, Starbucks will open its first Hear Music store in Santa Monica, Calif., today, and plans to put music kiosks in 2,500 stores over the next two years. The system allows users to choose from more than 250,000 online songs, and to burn CD's for $6.99 for five songs, with each additional tune costing $1. Howard Schultz, Starbucks' chairman, called the move a natural extension of the company's success in selling its own brand of CD's in stores around the world. John Schwartz (NYT)
