title: Critics' Choices: After the Shows, Looks to Watch; The Dresses of Yore, With a Little Something Extra
description: SIX months from now, when the new fall clothes and accessories land in stores, you'll be an expert on the shrug, the tea-cozy capelet and the ''new eccentricity.'' So let's not go there. Let's consider a few trends from the shows that are likely to get under a woman's skin, induce a little longing and curiosity while flagrantly picking her pocket. Here, then, is a glimpse at the pencil shirt (fashion's new fanny pack), the latest vintage cult contender and one designer's bid for a 21st-century silhouette.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Memorial For '93 Trade Center Victims
description: The design for an interim memorial to the six victims of the 1993 explosion at the World Trade Center was unveiled yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The authority said it had won the approval of all the surviving family members. Jacqueline Hanley, senior architect for the Port Authority, working with the Pentagram studio, has designed a stainless-steel pylon about nine and a half feet tall, echoing the tower's proportions. Set within it would be a fragment of the original fountain, inscribed with ''John D,'' the partial name of a victim, John DiGiovanni. Ever since the original memorial was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001, survivors of the 1993 attack have had no focal point for remembrance services or visits. The pylon is to be installed by the end of fall in the family viewing area at the southwest corner of the site. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: A Leaner, Meaner Jihad
description: The coordinated train bombings in Madrid have altered Europe's political structure, shaken global financial markets and unsettled the American-led coalition in Iraq. title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Coca-Cola Closing Plant In Water Dispute
description: A local affiliate of the Coca-Cola Company suspended production at its Perumatty plant, in Kerala, in response to an order by the provincial government. Local villagers opposed the plant on the ground that it was depleting the water table. The plant consumed 110,000 gallons of water a day and accounted for less than 2 percent of Coca-Cola's production in India. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Oil Profit
description: CNOOC Ltd., China's largest offshore oil and gas company, reported a record net profit for 2003 on the back of surging oil prices. Under American accounting standards, net profit in the year to Dec. 31, was $1.45 billion, up 32 percent from 2002. Analysts said the company's results were in line with expectations.

description: Fannie Mae, the second-largest financial institution in the United States, said yesterday that an important measure of its performance had been strong in 2003 after three relatively weak years.

description: Hans Blix, the former chief United Nations weapons inspector, said Monday that the Bush administration convinced itself of the existence of banned weapons based on dubious findings before invading Iraq and was not interested in hearing evidence to the contrary.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Final Water Taxi Victim Found
description: The body of the last passenger missing since a water taxi capsized in the Baltimore harbor was recovered, the authorities said. Crews pulled from the harbor the body of the passenger, Corinne J. Schillings, 26, of Alexandria, Va., about 3:30 p.m. Monday. Her body was found near where crews found two other victims on Sunday. They were identified as 6-year-old Daniel Bentrem of Harrisonburg, Va., and Andrew Roccella, 26, of Vienna, Va., who had planned to propose marriage to Ms. Schillings. Two other passengers also died. Gary M. Gately (NYT)

title: Aramcons Find Arabia Like Home, Sort Of

Not to say that its offerings are weedlike: some blossom, others wither. But with almost unlimited access to its home in the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion (now that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has moved across the street to its new Walt Disney Concert Hall), the Los Angeles Opera can program throughout the season.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Interior Department Told To Shut Down Internet Access
description: A federal judge ordered the Interior Department to shut down much of its Internet access because of security problems related to a trust fund for American Indians that is administered by the department. The ruling was the third in three years in which the judge, Royce C. Lamberth of Federal District Court in Washington, had ordered that the systems be disconnected in an effort to protect millions of dollars of oil, gas, timber and grazing royalties from Indian land. The judge said he was not satisfied that the agency's computer system was safe from hackers. John Files (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUNDES, LESTER
description: DUNDES--Lester. The former Publisher of Interior Design Magazine for over 45 years, died of a sudden heart attack in his home in Watermill, on Saturday, March 13. He was 90 years old and also lived in NYC. Mr. Dundes, a dynamic force within the design industry is credited with having built Interior Design Magazine from a small, unknown trade magazine into a leading publication. Although he retired from the magazine in his 80's, he created a second career with the launch of five Corporate Interiors books. He was a robust figure and devoted husband of Seena Dundes for over 51 years. Adoring father of Kate Shattan and Liza Schaeffer. Loved by his sons-in-law Thomas Shattan and Edward Schaeffer, and his grandchildren, Cecily and Woody Shattan, and Olivia and Alex Schaeffer. A memorial service will be held at 4 pm, on Tuesday, March 16, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 81 St at Madison Ave.

title: Rewarding Terror in Spain
description: It must be said: Spanish voters have allowed a small band of terrorists to dictate the outcome of their national elections. This is not how democracies are supposed to react when they are attacked by fanatics. Americans were visibly united and hardened by Sept. 11; the Italians overcame deep political differences to unify in their determination to crush the Red Brigades; Israeli cohesion has only been increased by decades of terrorism. When threatened by a violent few, democratic political communities will normally react by enforcing the will of the many.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Venezuela: Court Ruling Goes Against Chvez
description: The electoral chamber of the Supreme Court overturned a recent decision by electoral authorities that temporarily disqualified 876,000 signatures that opposition groups had collected to force a recall referendum on President Hugo Chvez. If the decision stands, the opposition will have the 2.4 million signatures needed to permit a referendum, but the government and its allies in the constitutional chamber of the Supreme Court are expected to contest it fiercely. Earlier this month, the National Electoral Council said 1.1 million flawed signatures had to be validated through a complex ''repair period'' that would require citizens to confirm that they had signed petitions. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Volvo Posts Loss
description: Volvo, Europe's largest truckmaker, restated fourth-quarter earnings to post a loss because of a write-down from spinning off its stake in a competitor, Scania, to comply with a European Commission directive. Volvo had a loss of 2.9 billion kronor ($383 million) in the fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of 638 million kronor a year earlier, it said. In its original report last month, the company reported a fourth-quarter profit of 1.14 billion kronor. The loss resulted from Volvo's writing down the value of its Class A shares in Scania. The truckmaker plans to transfer 99 percent of the shares to a wholly owned holding company called Ainax, and Ainax will then be distributed to Volvo shareholders. They will get 2 Ainax shares for each 31 Volvo shares they own.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Echostar To Restate 2002 Results
description: The EchoStar Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest satellite television service, will restate 2002 results to reverse expenses incorrectly taken in 2000, 2001 and 2002, narrowing the company's loss by $30 million. The Securities and Exchange Commission told EchoStar that it reserved $9 million more than needed in 2002 for the replacement of so-called smart cards, that allow only paying customers to receive company programming. EchoStar reserved $17 million too much in 2001, and $4 million too much in 2000. EchoStar said in a regulatory filing that the restatement would narrow the company's 2002 loss to $779 million from $809 million.

title: World Briefing: The Arctic
description: SOLO EXPLORER PRESUMED DEAD Chances are "nearly nil" of finding the adventurer Dominick Arduin alive, 10 days after she disappeared while trying to become the first woman to reach the North Pole alone. Christian de Marliave, a member of her support team, said, "The chances that she is still alive are close to zero." But the team plans a final attempt to find her this week, using a heat-detecting infrared camera. On March 5, Ms. Arduin, 43, who holds both Finnish and French passports, set out from Northern Russia. Her support team lost contact with her just a day later. (Agence France-Presse)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, PHILIP C.
description: SMITH--Philip C. Retired Chairman and CEO of Yardley of London, Inc, and a director of mutual funds from the early days of their development as investment entities, died on February 17, 2004. He was living in Weston, CT where he had resided for forty-nine years. He was ninety-two. Born in Prestwich, England, Philip Smith's family came to the United States when he was ten years old. He graduated from Princeton University in 1932, and from the Harvard Business School AMP in 1954. He served in The Honorable Artillary Company in England and was an Officer in The United State Army during World War II. Beginning in the 1950's and extending into the 1990's, he served on the boards of a great number of mutual funds. At times he was a director of more than twenty different mutual funds. During his long residence in Weston, he was an active participant on civic boards, and served and supported numerous public interest organizations. He was also a prolific, skilled and talented painter. Mr. Smith was predeceased by his wife of fifty years, Elizabeth Odell Smith, in 1984. He is survived by his three sons, Lawther O. Smith, of Doylestown, PA, Richard C. Smith, of Pinellas Park, FL, and Owen C. Smith, of New Canaan, CT; seven grandchildren, and nine great grandchildren. There will be a Memorial Service on March 20th at The Norfield Church in Weston, CT at 11 A.M.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Abu Abbas To Be Buried Near Damascus
description: Abu Abbas, the Palestinian militant who died last week in American custody in Iraq, is likely to be buried near Damascus, said a member of his group, the Palestine Liberation Front. The group had been seeking to bury him in the West Bank, but Israel refused permission, said the spokesman, Wasel Abu Yussef. Mr. Abbas masterminded the hijacking in 1985 of the cruise ship Achille Lauro, in which a 69-year-old American, Leon Klinghoffer, was shot and thrown into the Mediterranean. Beloved husband of Leona, father of Ruth Varaiya of Berkeley, CA and Diana Lieb Sands of West Orange, NJ, grandfather of Daniel Lieb and step-grandfather of Sandy and David Lieb, he died peacefully on March 12th at age 88. A long-time resident of New Jersey and Florida, a loyal CCNY alumnus and co-founder of Case Paper Co., Oscar had a long and distinguished record of involvement in Jewish and humanitarian endeavors. A past Chairman of the Federation of Jewish Charities of the New York Graphic Arts Industry, he was an active supporter of the Israel Bond campaign in the Oranges, a prime mover of what has become the Jewish Community Center of Metrowest New Jersey, and an officer and trustee of Temple Israel of the Oranges and Maplewood. After moving to Florida, he became a leading supporter of Jewish education for children. He was also an active Board member of Israel Cancer Association-USA. He gave generously of himself to all in need, and he was an inspiration to his many admirers. A devoted friend and loving uncle, he will be sorely missed. Funeral services at 11:00 a.m. Tuesday, March 16th at Riverside-Gordon, 7205 W. Atlantic Ave., Delray Beach, FL. Send remembrances to your favorite charity.

title: Maybe He's Grateful, but Get Out of His Way
description: How do you release a 400-pound Siberian tiger? Very carefully. Early this month two Russian students hiking in a forest reserve about 120 miles northeast of Vladivostok found a tiger caught in a snare, roaring in distress. The students notified forest guards, who brought in a team of scientists from the Wildlife Conservation Society, based in New York, and from Russia's Ministry of Natural Resources. The tiger was anesthetized, observed for a while to make sure it had not been injured, fitted with a radio collar so its movements could be tracked, and let go. It waited a minute after the door to its cage was opened, then leapt out and headed for the woods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, SHERMAN R., JR.
description: LEWIS--Sherman R., Jr., 67 of Manhattan, New York, died March 11, 2004. Mr. Lewis was a vice chairman and international investment banker at Lehman Brothers Holdings, Inc. Throughout his 30-year career at Lehman Brothers, he held numerous senior positions, including partner in the Corporate Finance Department at Loeb Rhoades & Co., a predecessor firm of Lehman Brothers, and, after Loeb Rhoades was acquired by Shearson Hayden Stone, Mr. Lewis was named president. Born in Ottawa, IL, Mr. Lewis was a graduate of Northwestern University and the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business Administration. He served on the President's Commission on Housing and the President's Council for International Youth Exchange during the Reagan administration. He was a University Trustee, a founding member and past Chairman of the Board of Visitors of the College of Arts and Sciences and a former Alumni Regent at Northwestern University. Mr. Lewis was also a member of the Advisory Council to the Graduate School of Business at the University of Chicago. In addition, Mr. Lewis served as a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, the U.S.-Japan Business Council, The Korea Society, The U.S.Greece Business Council, Euro-Amer Holding S.A., Infraworks Corporation and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Marine Corps Heritage Center Founders' Group. Mr. Lewis served in the United States Marine Corps and was a commissioned officer on active duty from 1958 to 1961. He is survived by his devoted wife of 37 years, Dorothy, and by his beloved children, Thomas, Catherine, Elizabeth, and Michael, and cherished granddaughters Olivia and Riley, and brothers Robin and Randal. Calling hours are from 2:00-5:00 p.m. and 7:009:00 p.m. at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., in New York City, on Monday, March 15. The funeral service will be held on Tuesday, March 16 at 10:30 a.m. at the Brick Presbyterian Church, 1140 Park Ave. at 91st St. Contributions can be made to the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, P.O. Box 19024, J5-200, Seattle, WA 98109 to Dr. Rainer Storb's research in memory of Sherman R. Lewis, Jr. or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021 to Dr. Mark Heaney's research in memory of Sherman R. Lewis, attention Jennifer Jacobson, Development Office.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Veritas To Restate Results Again
description: The Veritas Software Corporation, the world's second-largest maker of data-storage programs, will restate some results for the third time in 15 months and delay filing its 2003 report because of accounting errors. The company plans to restate 2002 and 2001 results. The changes will cut sales in 2001 and 2003 and increase 2002's, Veritas said. The company said it expected to file its 2003 yearly report, which was due yesterday, with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the second quarter. Veritas, which makes software that backs up and restores data on computer networks, said it wrongly deferred professional-services sales and improperly booked some estimated expenses. Last year, Veritas, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., restated results for 2000 and 2001 after finding other sales accounting mistakes. The first restatement last year fixed accounting for a barter deal with Time Warner. The second also resulted from exchanges of programs for advertising that were booked incorrectly in 2000, in deals the company said were unrelated to Time Warner. Shares of Veritas fell $1.87, or 6 percent, to $29.14.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: Seeking New Charges Against Yugoslav General

The prosecutor, Nikola Petkovic, said he had filed a motion to reopen the case, the state-run Tanjug news agency reported. His announcement came exactly two years after Mr. Perisic was arrested in Belgrade. The general, who was elected a member of Parliament, has avoided prosecution by invoking parliamentary immunity. That immunity was lifted on March 5 after new parliamentary elections in December. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Efficiency Of School Guards' Radios Questioned
description: A report to be released today by Representative Anthony D. Weiner found that radios carried by school safety officers at 137 New York City high schools occasionally did not work, because of dead spots in the coverage area and equipment failures. For the study, Mr. Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Brooklyn and Queens, and his staff spoke with security workers at 250 schools, with about half reporting problems with radios and 18 reporting they did not have enough radios, according to the report. Deputy Police Commissioner Paul J. Browne denied security officers lacked radios, and said Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly had previously appointed a group to resolve the problem of dead spots. Among other steps being taken, the School Safety Division is moving and will soon receive a new communications system, Mr. Browne said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

Leaders for pilots at Northwest will decide next month whether to negotiate with the airline based on the $200 million target, said Will Holman, a union spokesman. Northwest is seeking to cut $950 million in costs this year, including $442 million from pilots, after pretax losses of almost $2.2 billion in airline operations over the last three years. Northwest is based in St. Paul.

title: National Briefing: South
description: MISSISSIPPI: ABORTION BILLS PASS The House passed four abortion bills on Monday and yesterday. They would classify the death of a fetus as a murder unless it was induced by the mother or a medical professional she approved; require doctors to report physical or psychiatric complications that they believe are a "primary, secondary or tertiary result" of abortions to the State Department of Health; protect health care providers and insurance companies who refuse to participate in abortions; and make it a felony to intentionally allow the death of a viable fetus delivered in a failed abortion. The bills now go to the Senate. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Banker's Outlook

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teacher Arraigned On Sex Charges
description: A teacher in a parochial high school was arraigned yesterday on charges that she engaged in a sexual relationship with one of her under-age students, the Queens district attorney's office said. The teacher, Cheryl Reyna, 32, who teaches Spanish at Martin Luther High School in Maspeth, pleaded not guilty to charges that she engaged in a nine-week sexual relationship with a 16-year-old girl beginning last August. The authorities said that Ms. Reyna, who was a longtime friend of the girl's family, engaged in the sexual acts at her home and the girl's home. Ms. Reyna, who is charged with sex abuse and child endangerment, faces up to four years in prison if convicted. Her lawyer did not respond to a telephone message seeking comment. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: The Return of the (Alaskan) King

For the next month, a few fish markets will sell fresh legs. At Wild Edibles, 535 Third Avenue (35th Street), the manager, Steve Schaffer, right, sells the crab cooked for $34.95 a pound. (It is also at the Grand Central Market branch.) At the Citarella markets in Manhattan and in the Hamptons the cost is $24.95 a pound for a 6-to-8-pound crab, uncooked, yielding about 3 pounds of meat. At RM, 33 East 60th Street, king crab pot-au-feu is $30 at lunch and $15 extra on the prix-fixe at dinner. Sumile in Greenwich Village and Esca near Times Square are also serving king crab.

title: Forward Into Spring
description: It doesn't take much of a snowstorm in the middle weeks of March to remind inveterate weather watchers of the great March snowstorms of the past. Particularly -- for those of us in the Northeast -- the blizzard of 1888 and the superstorm of 1993. The 1888 blizzard, which killed some 400 people across the region, is now part of our meteorological ancestry, the kind of event that has continued to grow in stature even though the last witnesses are long gone. A blizzard will probably never be able to sneak up on us again the way that one did. We now have the luxury of seeing what's coming, watching open-mouthed as an event like the March 1993 storm develops. That one, as many of us remember, cut through 26 states and killed some 270 people.

title: LEHMAN BROTHERS EARNINGS DOUBLE IN QUARTER
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings said yesterday that quarterly earnings more than doubled, helped by higher revenue from bond trading and stock underwriting. Net income rose for a sixth consecutive quarter, to $670 million, or $2.21 a share, in the quarter, which ended Feb. 29, from $301 million, or $1.15 a share, a year earlier, the company said. Revenue from equity trading and equity underwriting more than doubled from a year ago. First-quarter trading revenue rose to $2.2 billion, or 71 percent of net revenue, up from 67 percent the prior quarter. Fixed-income trading was 72 percent and equity trading 28 percent of total trading revenue in the quarter. Revenue from equity underwriting rose to $143 million from $59 million a year earlier. Debt underwriting revenue was little changed from a year ago.

He will be remembered by those who were fortunate enough to have known him as a man who was warm, generous, fun loving and genuinely happy. Services will be held on Wednesday March 17 at 1PM at Temple Beth Shalom, Roslyn Heights.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon Raises Forecast
description: Canon, the camera and office equipment maker, said it expected to earn a record profit for this quarter, helped by strong sales of digital cameras and multifunction copier-printer machines. Canon forecast a net profit of 90 billion yen ($827 million) for the quarter ending March 31, which would be a 26 percent increase from 71.6 billion yen in the quarter last year. Canon, a leader in digital camera sales, had previously forecast a net profit of 73 billion yen for the quarter. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Tokyo Officials Struggle to Hold the Yen in Line
description: Japanese financial authorities are waging a battle against what they see as one of the biggest threats to the nation's economic recovery -- a rising yen. And while the effort seems to be working so far, analysts and investors are questioning how long they can keep it up.

title: Dozens Pick Through Rubble in Search for Survivors
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 17  A massive explosion ripped through a Baghdad neighborhood today, killing at least 27 people, the military said. The blast caused severe damage to an apartment building and a hotel, the Mount Lebanon, in the Karada district of Baghdad, and it shot a huge fireball into the night sky.

title: Frippery And Fantasy That Dazzle
description: Like diplomacy or insider politics, concert programming is often approached with a spirit of quid pro quo. An artist gives the audience something it really wants to hear, and in so doing earns the right to indulge his own personal taste or curiosities. This was certainly the formula for the pianist Mikhail Pletnev's recital in Carnegie Hall on Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: More Subpoenas In Rowland Inquiry
description: The House committee investigating whether to recommend the impeachment of Gov. John G. Rowland, left, a Republican in his third term, issued 11 more subpoenas on Monday. Mr. Rowland is also under federal investigation. Last December, he admitted that he had lied about accepting gifts and free work on his Litchfield home from people doing business with the state. Among the recipients of the subpoenas were three state agencies (the Bond Commission, the Department of Children and Families, and the Properties Review Board); two moving companies, one of which was paid by the state to shuttle furniture, including a hot tub, between Mr. Rowland's official residence and his Litchfield cottage; the Connecticut Lottery Corporation; Hartford Downtown Revival; and Richard Gray, the executive director of the Connecticut Health and Educational Facilities Authority. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Off the Menu
description: MARC MURPHY, left, who first attracted attention when he was the chef at the Cellar in the Sky at Windows on the World in the World Trade Center and then went on to La Fourchette on the Upper East Side and Chinoiserie on Park Avenue South, now has a place of his own. With his wife, PAMELA MURPHY, he has turned what was THE INDEPENDENT, 179 West Broadway (Worth Street), into LANDMARC. Though the dcor is bare-bones wood, brick, steel and glass, he has made it an inviting setting for hearty bistro fare, including moules and frites, duck confit, lamb shanks, grilled tuna, steaks and roast chicken. None of the entrees top $25. Through Monday, there will be a 25 percent discount on the food.

title: 2 Engineers Killed in Iraq in Latest Attack on Foreigners
description: Two European engineers were shot to death in a drive-by attack on Tuesday, the latest killings in a rash of attacks on foreign civilians in Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERK, JOSEPH P.
description: BERK--Joseph P., 77, of Cambridge, MA on March 12, 2004. A graduate of Wyoming Seminary and Harvard College, Joe was founder and President of Pathways of Sound, a recording company ''founded for children and others who share their good taste.'' Over a span of four decades, its recordings were done by important figures of 20th-century culture. He is survived by his wife, Adeline, of 37 years, a sister, Marian Barr, his children, Stephanie Berk of Cambridge, John Berk, MD of Newton, MA, a stepson, Nicholas Gomez of Los Angeles, and five grandchildren.

A caring great aunt of Ken, Karen, Jon, and Lisa Roberts; Joe Feinstein; Kathi and Mark Rerek; Amy and Larry Golodner; Barbara and Jeffrey Scheine; and Lori and Neil Plotkin, Ken and Kate Nadler, and Marsha Miller. description: Hundreds of Islamic militants and Pakistani government paramilitary troops engaged in heavy fighting for more than six hours on Tuesday at a fort in the Pakistani tribal areas, just miles from the Afghan border, Pakistani officials said.

title: Rumble at the Sierra Club
description: The Sierra Club, which spends its energy battling others on environmental issues, is now caught up in a nasty debate of its own. The issue is immigration, the battleground this year's election of new directors. On one side are dissidents who would have the club promote more restrictive federal immigration policies. A majority of the organization's current board members and its senior management rightly feel that the club must remain neutral on an emotional issue they regard as largely irrelevant.

title: Bodies of Woman And Foster Son, 3, Found in Queens
description: A Queens woman and her 3-year-old foster son were found dead yesterday, and the police believe that the woman, who had serious medical problems, collapsed while giving him a bath, officials and neighbors said. Autopsies are to be performed today, but the police said they did not suspect foul play.

He is talking about the fund's wranglings in federal court over the attempt by Freehold Borough in Monmouth County, N.J., to prevent day laborers from gathering at a vacant lot to scout for work.

title: PARIBAS TO BUY COMMUNITY FIRST FOR $1.2 BILLION
description: BNP Paribas, France's biggest bank, agreed to buy Community First Bankshares for $1.2 billion and said it might make more purchases in the United States to expand its consumer banking business. The BancWest Corporation unit of BNP, the fifth-largest consumer bank in California, will pay $32.25 for each share of Community First, Paribas's chief executive, Baudouin Prot, said at a news conference in Paris. The price is 15 percent more than Community First's Monday closing price of $28 a share. Paribas, which is based in Paris, will add 155 branches in 12 states. The combined bank will operate in 18 states. BNP's consumer banking unit will have $44 billion in assets and 3.4 million customer accounts in the United States after the acquisition. Community First is based in Fargo, N.D.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Spending Increases For Snow Removal
description: The city's Sanitation Department has spent more than $32 million for snow removal this winter, $11 million over its planned budget, to cope with the more than 35 inches of snow that have fallen, the sanitation commissioner, John J. Doherty, said yesterday at a City Council hearing. The average snowfall for the city is 20 to 25 inches per winter. Last year more than 55 inches fell. The extra spending this winter was used to help pay overtime costs and for more than 321,000 tons of road salt, Mr. Doherty said. The department's proposed snow budget for next winter is $26 million. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: GEORGIA: BLOCKADE OF REBEL AREA HALTS OIL CARGOES A Georgian blockade of the secessionist Adzharia Province halted rail cargoes of oil to the port at Batumi and the local authorities declared a curfew from 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. President Mikhail Saakashvili, seeking to bring pro- Moscow Adzharia under central control before parliamentary elections on March 28, said he would block cargo routes to Batumi, but did not threaten to use force. Soldiers loyal to Adzharia's leader, Aslan Abashidze, turned back Mr. Saakashvili over the weekend when he tried to enter the region, prompting the crisis. (Reuters)

title: NRG ENERGY PLANS TO RELOCATE ITS HEADQUARTERS
description: NRG Energy, a power producer that emerged from bankruptcy protection in December, said it would move its headquarters to the Northeast from Minneapolis and cut 42 percent of its home-office staff. The company said it would make the move because many of its power plants are in the Northeast. The work force will be cut to 140 from 240, NRG said. A location for the new headquarters has not been chosen, the company said. NRG, formerly a unit of Xcel Energy Inc., a utility holding company based in Minneapolis, began trading as a separate company in December. About 43 percent of its generating capacity in the United States is in Connecticut, New York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maine.

title: The Cost of Cheap Money
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that it would keep its overnight interest rate where it has been for nine months -- at 1 percent, its lowest level since 1958. Factor in inflation, and Alan Greenspan is essentially lending money at a loss. This cannot go on indefinitely, and it should not go on much longer. In this election year, Mr. Greenspan and the other Fed officials are under tremendous pressure to stay put on rates in the absence of a tightening labor market or other signs of inflation, but such a stance would be a mistake. There are other costs associated with exceptionally cheap money that the Fed must recognize, and address by gradually raising rates.

title: Senior Moments Involving Divorce
description: On ''The Stones,'' a sitcom that starts tonight on CBS, Winston and Karly Stone (Jay Baruchel, Lindsay Sloane) give their parents an audiovisual presentation on why they should not get divorced. Along with family photos from happier times Winston and Karly, who are adults, offer statistics about the positive effect of marriage on the immune system. The senior Stones, Barbara (Judith Light) and Stan (Robert Klein), are unmoved. They can't stand each other in an old-fashioned way that predates today's immune concerns.

It is cheap, easy to prepare and convenient, and its health benefits are close to overwhelming: studies have indicated that a diet high in soy protein, which is what tofu is, can reduce cholesterol and the risk of heart disease, as well as certain cancers.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Abortion Bill Killed
description: The State Senate, by a single vote, killed a measure that would have banned abortions except where a woman's life or health was in danger. An earlier version of the bill, a direct challenge to Roe v. Wade that would probably have wound up in the Supreme Court, had already passed in the House and Senate. But when it reached Gov. Mike Rounds, a Republican, he revised the measure. This amended version had passed in the House. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LA GRANGE, EILEEN MORGAN
description: LA GRANGE--Eileen Morgan, 95 years old. Wife of Frank Crawford La Grange, deceased in 1964. Mother of Brenda Eileen La Grange Johnson and Louise La Grange Hitt. Eileen loved her life in the Forest Hills Gardens where she lived for over 65 years. The Church in the Gardens and The West Side Tennis Club were her homes away from home. She served as an officer of The Women's Guild and was a leader of the Congregational Church in the Gardens' Sunday School. She worked on Wall Street beside her husband whose company was La Grange and Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange. She leaves an incredible legacy: her sonin-law J. Howard Johnson and her grandchildren Grange (wife Susan) Grant, Brett and Heather (husband John Sargent). We are proud that Eileen met her greatgrandchildren Crawford and Schuyler Sargent and Garrett Johnson. Louise and her husband Buman added grandsons Ralph, Harold, Crawford and David Hitt. She loved us all. We will miss her forever. The family sends special thanks to her ''Angels''-Mary King, Peggy Hosty, Cathy Meehan and Nora Buckley--for their loving care and to Cathy Cooke for her devotion. Memorial service will be held on Monday, April 12th, at 11 AM at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., NY. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to M.D. Anderson Cancer Hospital C/O Dr. John Mendelsohn at 1515 Holcombe Blvd., Houston, TX 77030.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett To Sell Linux PC's In Asia
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company plans to sell personal computers in Asia based on the Linux operating system, Hewlett's Japanese unit said yesterday. Other details, including the timing of the start of such sales, have not been set yet, said a spokesman at the unit, Hewlett-Packard Japan Ltd. This will make Hewlett the world's first major PC maker to sell PC's operating on Linux.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Security Office
description: Boston has established a Homeland Security Office that will oversee use of a $40 million federal grant to improve terrorism preparedness in Boston and surrounding cities and towns. The office will be run by Carlo A. Boccia, who spent 27 years at the Drug Enforcement Agency. He is to start on April 12. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Consumer Group Opposes Con Ed Increases
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board filed testimony with the state Public Service Commission yesterday opposing rate increases requested by Consolidated Edison for its natural gas and steam operations. In November, Con Ed proposed rate increases of 9.8 percent for its natural gas operations and 14.6 percent for its steam operations. Those increases, which are still being considered by the commission, would be effective on Oct. 1 of this year. Jon Sorensen, a spokesman for the consumer board, said that the utility's last increase for gas prices was in 1995 and for steam in 2000. He added that the utility could avoid requiring a rate increase by better economizing current revenues. David C. Flanagan, a commission spokesman, said that additional testimony was expected in the coming weeks and that a hearing was scheduled for next month. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: Irish Masterpiece Returning to Its Bleak Home

title: 3 Banks Had Early Concern On WorldCom
description: Three big banks expressed misgivings internally about WorldCom's financial soundness in early 2001 just months before they helped the company sell $12 billion in debt, according to documents filed in federal court in Manhattan on Monday. But their doubts -- and the basis for them -- were not disclosed to investors who bought the debt 14 months before WorldCom filed for bankruptcy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Merger Of Black-Owned Banks
description: Carver Bancorp announced on Tuesday that it would acquire Independence Federal Savings Bank, which is based in Washington, for $32.6 million, creating the largest black-operated bank in the country. Under the agreement, Independence stockholders will receive $21 in cash for each share of their common stock, said Carver's president and C.E.O., Debbie C. Wright. Carver, which is headquartered in Harlem, has branches in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Crown Heights, Jamaica and St. Albans. Independence operates five branches. Ms. Wright, who will be the president of the new company, said that together, the two banks were worth more than $750 million, and that the boards of both banks had approved the deal, which is awaiting approval from Independence shareholders and government regulators. John Holl (NYT)

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS FIGHTING WENDY'S PLAN TO BUY A COMPANY
description: Dunkin' Donuts is fighting Wendy's International's plan to buy the bankrupt Bess Eaton Donut Flour Company and expand its Tim Hortons chain. Wendy's bid this month for Bess Eaton's 48 coffee and doughnut restaurants in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island for $35 million after Bess Eaton filed for bankruptcy. Bess Eaton has asked Judge Arthur N. Votolato of United States Bankruptcy Court in Providence, R.I., to approve Wendy's offer as the bid to beat at auction. Dunkin' Donuts filed an objection with the court on Monday arguing that the judge, not Bess Eaton, should determine which bid is the best. Dunkin' Donuts said in the filing that it was studying Bess Eaton's assets to prepare its own offer. Dunkin' Donuts is a unit of Allied Domecq of Bristol, England. Bess Eaton, founded in 1954, is based in Westerly, R.I.

title: Aches, Pains and Warning Labels
description: Over-the-counter pain medication is the most convenient way to ease a minor headache caused by tension or fatigue. But too many people are unaware of the dangers of excessive use of these drugs, especially acetaminophen.

title: Killing Iraq With Kindness
description: One year later, most of the stated reasons for invading Iraq have been discredited. But advocates of the war still have one compelling argument: our troops are not there to impose American values or even Western values, but ''universal'' ones. The underlying assumption is that the United States itself represents these universal values, and that freedom to pursue happiness, to elect our own leaders and to trade in open markets, should be shared by all, regardless of creed, history, race or culture.

Brant, had resigned as chairman and director of the company. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Lego Cutting Costs
description: Lego, the money-losing toymaker, said it would reduce costs by 700 million Danish kroner ($115.2 million) and cut about 500 employees to break even this year. About one-third of the layoffs will be in Denmark. The company has also started a plan to increase promotional spending and reduce the time it takes to put an idea on store shelves by half. Future annual sales growth is estimated at 3 to 5 percent. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: WAYNE--Michael, age 79. Beloved father and renowned restauranteur of New York, NY, passed away on March 15, 2004 in Miami Beach. He is survived by his five children, Neal, Meri, Elizabeth, Christina, and Michael; and his four grandchildren, Alejandro, Mattias, Sofia, and Raquel; and his sister, Estelle. We will miss the wrinkles in his nose every time he smiles. Services Wednesday, March 17, 1pm, at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp. the LIRR), Great Neck, NY. 516-487-9600.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Abortion Bills Pass
description: The House passed four abortion bills on Monday and yesterday. They would classify the death of a fetus as a murder unless it was induced by the mother or a medical professional she approved; require doctors to report physical or psychiatric complications that they believe are a ''primary, secondary or tertiary result'' of abortions to the State Department of Health; protect health care providers and insurance companies who refuse to participate in abortions; and make it a felony to intentionally allow the death of a viable fetus delivered in a failed abortion. The bills now go to the Senate. Ariel Hart (NYT)

title: HEALTHSOUTH OFFERS DEAL TO ITS BONDHOLDERS
description: The HealthSouth Corporation offered to pay bondholders $10 for every $1,000 of debt to waive restrictions that might cause the company to default on loans. The proposal would double the limit on bank loans, to $750 million, HealthSouth said. The company now has access to about $374 million under an agreement with J.P. Morgan Chase, a spokesman, Andy Brimmer, said. HealthSouth, which runs rehabilitation-care hospitals, wants more flexibility to restructure its debt and raise capitalization, Mr. Brimmer said. An Alabama court last week granted a company request to prevent bondholders from demanding accelerated repayment, which HealthSouth said might have pushed it to insolvency. HealthSouth is based in Birmingham, Ala.

title: PROVIDENT AGREES TO BUY WARWICK COMMUNITY BANCORP
description: Provident Bancorp, which owns bank branches in Rockland and Orange Counties in New York, agreed to buy Warwick Community Bancorp for about $153.4 million in cash and stock. Provident, based in Montebello, N.Y., will pay $79.3 million in cash and issue 6.3 million of its shares for Warwick, it said. The stock offer represents a 1.8 percent discount, based on Provident's closing price, or a 3.9 percent discount in cash to Warwick's $33.57 closing price Monday. Provident's acquisition of Warwick, based in Warwick, N.Y., will add seven Warwick Savings Bank branches in Orange and Putnam Counties and Towne Center Bank's two branches in Bergen County, N.J., the company said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Investors' Confidence Falls
description: German investor sentiment dropped sharply in March, reflecting concern about the terrorist attacks in Madrid and the already weakening optimism for stronger growth of Europe's largest economy. The ZEW Center of European Economic Research said its index measuring the confidence of institutional investors and analysts hit a 16- month low as a result because of reduced growth forecasts published by German research institutes and, to some extent, because of the bombings in Spain. Based on slowing export growth and stagnating consumer spending, three of the leading institutes recently lowered their estimates ranging now from 1.3 to 1.8 percent growth for 2004. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Parmalat to Shed Some Assets as Part of Restructuring
description: Parmalat, the fallen Italian dairy and food giant, announced plans on Tuesday to emerge from bankruptcy as a slimmed-down beverage company, saying it would seek to swap most of its $18 billion in debt for equity in the company.

title: Politics and School Promotion
description: There is nothing about Mayor Michael Bloomberg that's more admirable than his determination to improve New York City schools. But lately he has been acting as if he believes he is the only person in town who cares about the welfare of the students. This week, he fired members of the public school governance board who disagreed with his new initiative to stop social promotion and rammed through that controversial policy. Mr. Bloomberg was wrong on two counts. He made a political mistake in reinforcing the worst fears of opponents of mayoral control of the schools. He made an educational mistake in imposing a plan that sounds good but is likely to hurt more children than it helps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALL, ROBERT H.
description: HALL--Robert H. of Wyckoff, NJ. Sailor, student, athlete, loving husband, beloved father, grandfather and great grandfather, beloved brother, respected business executive, mentor, volunteer and benefactor passed on Sunday, March 14, 2004. He was a devoted family man who invariably put his family ahead of himself. He was widowed in July '97 (Mimi Juppe) and leaves behind four children (Candace, Robert, Christopher, Bettina), seven grandchildren, one great grandchild and a number of friends scattered around the globe. Mr. Hall lived his life as though Teddy Roosevelt's famous ''Man in the Arena'' quote was written with him in mind. He ''...strove valiantly; ...knew great enthusiasms, great devotions; spent himself in a worthy cause; who at the best knew in the end the triumph of high achievement, and who at the worst, if he failed, at least failed while daring greatly, so that his place shall never be with those cold and timid souls who neither knew victory nor defeat.'' Friends and family may visit at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, NJ (201) 444-7650 on Wednesday 79pm. Funeral services will be held Thursday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel RC Church, 1 Passaic St., Ridgewood, where a funeral mass will be held at 10:45am. Burial will follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. In lieu of donations it is requested that a silent prayer be said for worldwide peace and harmony.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Real Estate Empire Expands
description: The Corcoran Group, the New York real estate firm, announced yesterday that it had acquired Dayton-Halstead, a real estate firm in the Hamptons. The move came just six months after Corcoran bought Cook Pony Farm Real Estate in East Hampton, and a month after its parent company, Cendant Corp., bought licensing rights and 15 offices of Sotheby's International Realty. In all, Cendant, through its subsidiary NRT, has bought about 270 companies in 31 cities. ''We're gobbling,'' said Pamela Liebman, president and chief executive officer of the Corcoran Group, which will put its name on the three offices of Dayton-Halstead in East Hampton, Bridgehampton and Sag Harbor. Dayton-Halstead, whose predecessor company was founded in 1906, will add 44 agents to Corcoran's empire. Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead, will remain as a vice president of sales in the Hamptons. Motoko Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAGRO, FRANK J.
description: MAGRO--Frank J., born in Valetta, Malta on June 21st, 1924 and a resident of NYC since 1929, passed away Sunday, March 14th. Died peacefully at home with his family. He will be mourned by his wife Patricia, son Christopher, sister Mary Litris, brother Joe Magro, the balance of his large and incredibly close family and numerous friends who gave meaning to his life. After growing up in Yorkville in the 30's, he was honorably decorated as a combat soldier in Europe during WWII. He went on to an award-winning career as a commercial illustrator and fine artist. All who were exposed to the genius and beauty of his creative talent, the multi-faceted, infinite knowledge which he imparted with joy, and the limitless warmth of his heart were enriched by the experience of knowing him. Family will receive friends on Wednesday, 5-9 PM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10 AM, at St. Ignatius Loyola. Entombment to follow at Trinity Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Doctor Pleads Guilty To Sex Charges
description: A New Jersey doctor has pleaded guilty to charges that he traveled to Connecticut last June to have sex with a teenage boy. The doctor, Michael G. Spero, 42, an anesthesiologist from Morganville, N.J., posed as a 23-year-old medical student on the Internet to entice a 15-year-old boy to meet him on June 10 at the Grantmoor Motor Lodge in Newington, where he had sex with the boy, according to court records. The next day, the boy contacted the local police. An undercover federal agent, posing as the boy, continued communicating with Dr. Spero, who was arrested 12 days later and held without bond, according to information released on Tuesday by the office of the United States attorney. Dr. Spero faces a maximum prison term of 30 years and a $250,000 fine when he is sentenced in federal court in June. He may be transferred to New Jersey to face similar charges. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Morgenthau Supports Hearings On Drug Laws
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan added his support yesterday to an effort to push for changes to New York's mandatory sentences for drug crimes, a legislative initiative that has been virtually dormant since last summer. Mr. Morgenthau, in office since 1975, stopped short of advocating specific reforms to the drug laws that were enacted in the 1970's under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. But he said that in his experience, the laws that impose mandatory prison sentences for certain drug felonies could, at times, ''be unnecessarily harsh.'' He hailed a move yesterday by State Senator David A. Paterson, a Manhattan Democrat, to hold public hearings on proposals to change the laws, including greater sentencing discretion for judges. title: SOUTH FINANCIAL BUYS FLORIDA BANKS FOR $169 MILLION
description: The South Financial Group, which operates banks in South Carolina, North Carolina and Florida, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Florida Banks Inc. for about $169 million in stock. The acquisition will give South Financial seven banking centers in seven Florida counties with assets of about $944 million as of Dec. 31, South Financial said. Florida Banks' shareholders will receive 0.77 share of South Financial for each share of Florida Banks. Based on South Financial's closing price of $29.66 yesterday, the deal values each Florida Banks share at $22.84, a premium of 19 percent over Florida Banks' closing price yesterday.

While his physics research examines the earliest moments of the universe, including the possibility of multiple universes, Dr. Ellis, 64, has also written about ethics and the boundaries of physics and metaphysics. He said he would donate half of the $1.4 million prize money to social causes, including a campaign to establish a basic income grant for all South African citizens to alleviate poverty. title: A Soap Opera in County Clare

Tadhg and his best pal, Bobby, lead aimless lives gutting fish for a living and inhaling beer. The most glamorous thing they can conceive of is renting a car. Only the lady of the house seems fully alive, maybe because her other son, Michael, who moved to the United States five years ago, is coming home to visit. What she doesn't know is that he's bringing home an American wife.

Enough of the playful sweetness that coats even the meanest acts and goads people who have endured many an amateur and professional production to swear that if they depart this life without ever seeing another ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' they will depart satisfied.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Somerville: Prosecution Rests In Williams Case
description: The prosecution rested its case yesterday in the manslaughter trial of the former Nets star Jayson Williams, left, after the defense again tried to suggest that the shotgun that killed a chauffeur in Mr. Williams's bedroom had malfunctioned. The defense has claimed that the shotgun discharged accidentally while Mr. Williams, 36, was holding it, releasing a blast of pellets that killed the chauffeur, Costas Christofi, 55. Mr. Williams's lawyer, Michael T. Kelly, conducted a contentious, sarcastic cross-examination of a state firearms expert who testified on Tuesday that he test-fired the gun two weeks after Mr. Christofi was killed and found it mechanically sound. Mr. Christofi was killed in Mr. Williams's bedroom on Feb. 14, 2002. Mr. Kelly suggested that a wood chip, together with gun oils and ''guck'' near the gun's firing pin could cause it to malfunction without anyone touching the trigger. Robert Hanley (NYT)

description: LIBERIA: EX-PRESIDENT SUES TRIBUNAL A Liberian criminal court took up a lawsuit brought by former President Charles Taylor against the United Nations-based war crimes tribunal in Sierra Leone for what he alleged was an illegal search of his former residences. Mr. Taylor was indicted by the Sierra Leone tribunal in March 2003 on 17 counts of crimes against humanity for his suspected role in arming and training rebels in a decadelong conflict in Sierra Leone that left as many as 200,000 dead. He has been in exile in Nigeria since August. (Agence France-Presse)

description: NORTH CAROLINA: EMBEZZLER FAKED $175,000 IN CAMPAIGN POSTAGE A former assistant treasurer for Senator Elizabeth Dole's 2002 fund-raising committees admitted that he had embezzled $175,000 from campaign accounts, the Justice Department said. The former aide, Earl A. Haywood, 40, of Washington, pleaded guilty in federal court to charges of mail fraud. Mr. Haywood wrote checks to himself from the accounts and tried to label many expenses as postage for official business, prosecutors said. He has agreed to repay the money and faces up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine when he is sentenced in May. Eric Lichtblau (NYT)

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Redistricting Map For Minorities
description: The state's House of Representatives has redrawn election districts in the Boston area three weeks after a federal appeals panel ruled against it, finding that a map from 2001 denied minorities equal voting rights. The panel said that map intentionally packed black voters into one district to benefit incumbents. The new plan, which adds districts with black majorities, was sent to the plaintiffs for reaction. The House is to vote on a new map and submit it to the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, which can accept it or draw its own. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: State Board Warns About City Finances
description: The New York State Financial Control Board warned yesterday that while the city's economy has grown and tax revenues are up, fiscal problems might still be on the horizon. The board cited new labor contracts for municipal employees as one potential problem. A wage increase at the projected rate of inflation would add $2.8 billion to the city's expenses by the 2008 fiscal year, an increase that the Bloomberg administration has not included in its preliminary budget estimates for the next four years. The mayor has said that the cost of any wage increases would have to be offset by savings from productivity improvements. The control board has the authority to take over municipal finances if the city fails to balance its budget. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SNYDER, ARTHUR I., M.D.
description: SNYDER--Arthur I., M.D. With immense sadness, the family of Dr. Arthur I. Snyder of New York City and Washington, CT. announces his death on March 15, 2004 from complications resulting from pneumonia. Dr. Snyder was an internist and rheumatologist for 54 years, practicing most recently as a founding partner of New York Physicians, Inc. He graduated from Columbia University and Columbia College of Physicians & Surgeons, and served in the U.S. Navy and the U.S. Coast Guard. He was an adoring husband of 32 years to Marilyn Benstock Synder, and a kind, loving and ever-supportive father to daughters Margaret Hamilton and Katherine Snyder, and their husbands Robin Hamilton and Tim Culvahouse, and to step children Eric Berkeley and Nancy Berkeley Bynum, and their spouses Christina Berkeley and Frank Bynum. He took tremendous pride in his grandchildren, Rebecca, Emily, Jessica, Sasha, Theo, Kit and Georgia. Dr. Snyder is also survived by his sister, Judith Jaffe. He graced our days with his warmth, elegance and dry wit. Arthur, you were the best part of us and will be missed more than words can say. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Arthritis Foundation, New York Chapter, 122 E. 42 St, 18th Flr, N.Y., N.Y. 10168. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cisco Chief Says Dividend May Not Be First Priority

Mr. Chambers, who is also Cisco's president, also discussed paying a dividend during the annual shareholders meeting of the company last November. But shareholders, he said at a conference yesterday, want Cisco to repurchase company stock, which may mean they view the shares as undervalued. Cisco can repurchase an additional $8.1 billion in stock under its current board-authorized buyback program. As of Jan. 24, Cisco had repurchased 735 million shares under that program, costing $11.9 billion, or $16.14 a share, a Cisco spokeswoman, Terry Anderson, said. Like many other high-tech companies, Cisco, a network equipment maker, has never paid a dividend. Microsoft was among the first to break that mold, starting payment of a dividend early last year. Cisco, based in San Jose, Calif., has said it will not hire new employees until its current workers produce, on average, $700,000 a year in revenue. They produced $632,000 each during Cisco's fiscal second quarter, which ended Jan. 24.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAICKS, DAVID P.
description: JAICKS--David P., 78, a pioneer in food processing and education activist, successfully introduced new technologies to the production and distribution of food processing for an ever larger population, and, among other community actions, was a leader in the integration of local schools in the 1960s and 1970s, died Monday at a nursing home in Ridgewood, NJ. The cause was complications from Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease. Born in Lake Forest, IL, he entered the US Navy in 1943 at the age of 18. The Navy selected him for the V12 program for officer training. In 1945, while the war in the Pacific was still raging, he shipped out to Japan, arriving just after the second atomic bomb. His first task was to lead his men in the SEABEES in the clean-up and re-building of Nagasaki's infrastructure. After the War, Mr. Jaicks took his family to the East Coast to join American Home Products Corporation (now Wyeth) in their foods division. American Home Foods, makers of Chef-BoyAr-Dee, Gulden's Mustard, and Jiffy Pop-Corn, was just beginning to be an important company when he joined in 1964. In 1990 when he retired from the company as CEO and President of seven plants, he had introduced state of the art technology and a major R and D department run by scientists. Mr. Jaicks also led the movement to integrate both in his company and in the community. He campaigned successfully to join the Waldwick Board of Education, ultimately becoming president of the Board. Together with a small band of community activists, he canvassed door-to-door to win an election giving the community the funds to build a school. The Waldwick High School still stands as a monument to that Board. In the 1960s and the 1970s Mr. Jaicks worked tirelessly with Fair Housing and Ridgewood Association of Good Schools (RAGS) to move his new town, Ridgewood, away from de-facto segregation. He had a reputation for scrupulous fairness and for mentoring. ''He showed me that he had faith in me--he pushed me to broaden my expertise and my experiences in the company. Everyone loved him,'' Ken Martin, CFO of Wyeth Corporation, said yesterday. Not content with staying home as a retiree in the 1990s, Mr. Jaicks accepted lengthy tours of duty in Ukraine and Poland working as a volunteer for the Citizens Corps for Democracy and the International Executive Service Corps. Mr. Jaicks, who lived in Ridgewood, NJ with his wife, Nancy, is survived by her, by four sons, Bryan of Ridgewood, Andrew of Tucson, Perry of Mesa, AZ, Cameron of Vail, two stepsons, Raul Cintra-Leite of Saddle Brook, NJ and Alex Cintra-Leite of San Mateo, CA, and five grandchildren. The funeral will be held at Christ Church in Ridgewood, NJ on Friday at 12 Noon.

Companies like Intel and Texas Instruments have been setting up research and software development centers in India to cut costs by taking advantage of the country's lower wages and pool of technically skilled workers. Qualcomm, the world's second-biggest maker of wireless telephone chips, expects sales of handsets using its code division multiple access, or CDMA, technology to reach 13 million in the year to Sept. 30, Mr. Jacobs said, as operators like Reliance Infocomm Ltd. and Tata Teleservices Ltd. sign up subscribers. Eileen loved her life in the Forest Hills Gardens where she lived for over 65 years. The Church in the Gardens and The West Side Tennis Club were her homes away from home. We are proud that Eileen met her greatgrandchildren Crawford and Schuyler Sargent and Garrett Johnson. Louise and her husband Buman added grandsons Ralph, Harold, Crawford and David Hitt. She loved us all. We will miss her forever. The family sends special thanks to her ''Angels''-Mary King, Peggy Hosty, Cathy Meehan and Nora Buckley--for their loving care and to Cathy Cooke for her devotion. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Aircraft Parts Contracts
description: The European aircraft maker Airbus has chosen four Japanese manufacturers, including Koito Industries, to supply parts for its 555-seat A380 jumbo jet. Koito will make seats for the aircraft, which is scheduled to begin flights in 2006. Matsushita Avionics System was chosen to supply entertainment equipment. Sumitomo Precision Products will make parts for the landing gear, and the Jamco Corporation will produce galley equipment. Airbus has been awarding a large share of supply contracts for the A380 to Japanese companies, in part to make the jet more attractive to Japanese airlines, which have been loyal customers of Airbus's rival, the Boeing Company. In all, 18 Japanese suppliers have been awarded contracts worth a total of $4.25 billion on the A380 project. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Police Station House Evacuated For Radioactivity
description: A police precinct station house in- northern Queens was evacuated briefly yesterday morning after slightly elevated radiation levels were discovered in an impounded city sanitation truck, the police said. They also said that literature on aircraft, circuitry and anti-terrorism were found in the truck, which was impounded in the 114th Precinct. The written material had been thrown out with the trash by a cabdriver, the police said, a Pakistani citizen who was recently evicted from an apartment on 36th Street after a dispute with his landlord. No one answered the door there yesterday. Slightly elevated radiation levels are common in sanitation trucks, due in part to material discarded by people receiving chemotherapy treatment, said Keith Mellis, a Sanitation Department spokesman. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

title: Losing Time on North Korea
description: The North Korean nuclear threat is not the kind of problem that grows easier to solve with time. If time is on anyone's side, it is on that of Pyongyang's aspiring bomb makers. The country continues to reject the restraints of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, keeping international inspectors away from its known plutonium reprocessing unit and suspected uranium enrichment plants, while defiantly proclaiming progress toward building a bomb. Yet the Bush administration appears oddly content to let the situation drift forward, at least through this year's presidential elections. Such a lack of urgency could prove costly to America's future security.

Kroger is trying to reduce expenses as Wal-Mart Stores opens outlets in California that also sell groceries. Kroger had a $75 million expense last quarter to write down assets in 74 stores where sales lagged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, LEO S.
description: WALSH--Leo S. With much sadness, we mourn the passing of Leo S. Walsh, truly beloved husband of Sandra L., and devoted father of Devon K. On March 17, 2004, he passed away at his home in Manhattan. Born in Philadelphia, he attended the Sacred Heart School. After a stint in the Army, from there, with scholarship, he furthered his academic career by graduating from Drexel University in 1963, majoring in Applied Economics and Commerce, and then on to University of Pennsylvania where he excelled in Mathematics, graduating in 1966. He worked in the financial banking industry as an investment analyst in Philadelphia, and then perservered onward to New York City, where he made a strong and lasting impression at the Commodities Exchange, where he specialized in the volatile silver market. He established his own clearing house business, T. and S. Commodities. He invested his energies in the art world, as well as re-enthusing and reenergizing The Patio Restaurant in Westhampton Beach. A respected golfer, he was at one time a member of the Golf Association of Philadelphia, a founding member of the Old Marsh Golf Club, where he previously maintained a winter home in Lost Tree Village in North Palm Beach, FL, and was currrently an active member of the Westhampton Country Club. Leo was also active at the University Club in Manhattan, as well as the La Ronde Beach Club in Westhampton. Leo was a brilliant man who created and lived a cultured life on his own terms, often generously supporting others with initiative and drive. He will be dearly missed by many. ''When we are in relationships with others that our lives have significance.'' Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9PM and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell,1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral mass Saturday, 10AM, at the St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church, 66th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett Shareholders Want Options Expensed
description: Shareholders of the Hewlett-Packard Company voted Wednesday to approve the expensing of stock options, in a setback for Carleton S. Fiorina, the chairwoman and chief executive officer. A nonbinding proposal from the Massachusetts Laborers' Pension Fund was approved by 1.21 billion shares, with 925 million against, according to a Webcast of the annual shareholder meeting in Houston. The board of directors, which had opposed the measure, will now study the issue, Ms. Fiorina said. She told shareholders that expensing options would put the company at a disadvantage when its results are compared with those of rivals. The Laborers fund, which owns 87,100 shares, said that not expensing options understates the cost of executive compensation and encourages management to foster short-term price appreciation rather than long-term goals, according to Hewlett-Packard's proxy. Shares of Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., fell 5 cents yesterday, to $22.07. If Hewlett-Packard had expensed options in its fiscal first quarter, it would have reported net income of $786 million, or 26 cents a share, rather than the $936 million, or 31 cents a share, it actually did report, according to a quarterly report filed by the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HATFIELD, ROBERT S.
description: HATFIELD--Robert S. The Boards, Faculty and Staff of NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital and Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the passing of our dear friend and esteemed Hospital Trustee Robert S. Hatfield. A business leader and a man of great personal warmth, Mr. Hatfield served as President of the Board of Governors of The Society of The New York Hospital from 1981 to 1987. He retired in 1987, but remained a member of the Board of Trustees of the merged entity, NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital, until the time of his death. Mr. Hatfield's commitment to corporate citizenship was demonstrated by his long years of devoted service to enhancing health care and higher education. He leaves an outstanding legacy of leadership and dedication, and will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. John J. Mack Chairman, Board of Trustees NY-Presbyterian Hospital Dr. Herbert Pardes President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Board of Overseers Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

She will be missed by her mother, Eleanor Rader, of Tulsa, OK and brother, John L. Rader of San Rafael, CA. She was the treasured wife of Wright, loving mother to Mike and Steve and David, adoring grandmother to Cara, Connor, Caitlyn, Sophie and Charlotte, and dearest friend to many. Jane was born on June 7, 1939 in Hobbs, NM, and a resident of Bronxville 40 years, where her devoted volunteer work will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed. She was a Director of Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, on the Boards of Directors of the Counseling Center of Southern Westchester and the Junior League of Bronxville, President of the Women's Society of the Reformed Church of Bronxville, and a very active volunteer with the Botanical Garden of New York. Jane, you meant the world to all of us, and you will be in our hearts forever. We miss you already. Services at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, Thursday, March 25 at 11 AM.

''They called to say that this time I survived, but next time they are going to kill me,'' he said. Oaxaca has a small leftist guerrilla movement and a large drug-trafficking network. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Rochester: County Spared School Nurse Costs
description: A state court ruled yesterday that Monroe County could discontinue its 46-year practice of financing the school-nurse program for Rochester public schools. The financially strapped county has sent out layoff notices to the district's 72 nurses. Yesterday, Justice Kenneth R. Fisher of State Supreme Court denied the school district an injunction to prevent the layoffs. Under state law, schools must have nurses, but the Rochester school district does not have the authority to raise taxes to pay for the nurses. Michael J. Looby, a lawyer for the Rochester city school district, said the district was considering appealing the decision. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALSH, LEO S.
description: WALSH--Leo S. With much sadness, we mourn the passing of Leo S. Walsh, truly beloved husband of Sandra L., and devoted father of Devon K. On March 17, 2004, he passed away at his home in Manhattan. Born in Philadelphia, he attended the Sacred Heart School. After a stint in the Army, from there, with scholarship, he furthered his academic career by graduating from Drexel University in 1963, majoring in Applied Economics and Commerce, and then on to University of Pennsylvania where he excelled in Mathematics, graduating in 1966. He worked in the financial banking industry as an investment analyst in Philadelphia, and then perservered onward to New York City, where he made a strong and lasting impression at the Commodities Exchange, where he specialized in the volatile silver market. He established his own clearing house business, T. and S. Commodities. He invested his energies in the art world, as well as re-enthusing and reenergizing The Patio Restaurant in Westhampton Beach. A respected golfer, he was at one time a member of the Golf Association of Philadelphia, a founding member of the Old Marsh Golf Club, where he previously maintained a winter home in Lost Tree Village in North Palm Beach, FL, and was currrently an active member of the Westhampton Country Club. Leo was also active at the University Club in Manhattan, as well as the La Ronde Beach Club in Westhampton. Leo was a brilliant man who created and lived a cultured life on his own terms, often generously supporting others with initiative and drive. He will be dearly missed by many. ''When we are in relationships with others that our lives have significance.'' Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9PM and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell,1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral mass Saturday, 10AM, at the St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church, 66th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CILO, CHARLES M. JR.
description: CILO--Charles M. Jr. Novelist, Retired Ad Executive. Charles ''Chuck'' M. Cilo, Jr., writer, advertising executive, loving husband, and father, died Sunday, March 14. He was 65 and lived in South Salem, NY. Mr. Cilo was born in Passaic, NJ. His family moved to Connecticut where he attended Naugatuck High School excelling in literature, calculus, and sports, chiefly baseball. He later earned a BA from the University of Connecticut at Storrs. Mr. Cilo started his advertising career at McCann Erickson in New York City working in the mailroom in a graduate training program. His command of the English language, coupled with a brilliant creative mind, propelled his ascent through several agencies before landing him at the William Esty Agency (now Campbell Mithun Esty) from which he retired in 1992 as Executive VP, Creative Director. It was there that he helped create many of the most effective slogans and campaigns of the '70s and '80s for clients such as Datsun/ Nissan, Minolta, and MasterCard. Upon hearing of Mr. Cilo's death, Gordon Bushell, former Chairman/CEO, William Esty had this to say: ''A man with big, original ideas who could express them in unforgettable words, and presented all like nobody else could. A loved and respected leader.'' After retiring, Mr. Cilo continued his craft in the form of short stories and novels. He was working on his fourth novel at the time of his death. He will be missed for his humor, his conversation, his passion for baseball and music, and his overwhelming capacity for love and the support for others. He leaves behind his wife Eleanor, his son Charles M. Cilo III, his daughter-in-law Jill, and his sister Ruth Nord. A private memorial ceremony will be held in his honor. Contributions may be made to Ridgefield Fire Deptartment Ambulance Fund, 6 Catoonah Street, Ridgefield, CT 06977.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: New Brunswick: Pleas In Rutgers Rape Case
description: Two men pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that they broke into an off-campus apartment near Rutgers University and raped and robbed three students there. The men, Timothy Heard, 18, and Raymond E. Dargan, 20, are both being held on $500,000 bail, said an assistant Middlesex County prosecutor, Andrea Carter. Mr. Heard pleaded not guilty to charges of aggravated sexual assault, burglary and robbery. Mr. Dargan entered a plea to charges of burglary and robbery. Ms. Carter also said that a third man, Kyle Parker-Hall, 20, was in custody in Maryland and was expected in New Jersey on Monday. The police are still looking for a fourth suspect in the March 8 attacks, Jalon Lassiter, 24, of New Brunswick. Yaniv Gafner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Says Income More Than Doubled
description: Adobe Systems, the world's biggest maker of graphic-design software, said yesterday that first-quarter net income more than doubled, increased by sales of new design and publishing programs and Acrobat document software. Net income rose to $123 million, or 50 cents a share, from $54.2 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier, the San Jose, Calif.-based company said. Sales were $423.3 million. Earnings and revenue beat analyst estimates and Adobe increased its forecast for second-quarter profit to as much as 39 cents a share. The chief executive, Bruce Chizen, is reaping the benefits of his strategy to shift the 22-year-old company away from single graphics programs toward selling systems that can be used by large corporations. Adobe shares rose $2.81, to $39.08, in after-hours trading. In regular trading, the stock rose 1 cent, to $36.27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLLAND, IRA E
description: HOLLAND--Ira E, Businessman, Advocate and Founder of Concepts of Independence, Inc, dies at 64. In 1955 Ira contracted Polio that left him a Respiratory Dependent Quadriplegic. He was dependent upon people for all of his care and upon machines for each breath he took for the remainder of his life. Although this life-shaping event placed many obstacles in Ira's path, he found ways to overcome or go around most of them. Despite his disability, he traveled, married his late wife Victoria; graduated from LIU with honors; worked to create and shape the first consumer Directed Personal Assistance Program in NY State; was an advocate for Non-Invasive Ventilation and other issues that affect severly disabled people; and he was able to create a life in the Roosevelt Island community after spending more that 21 years in a hospital. Ira is survived by his family & friends, that include Maria A. Manrique, a person who played a significant role in his life for more that 20 years; Ed Litcher who became more of a brother than a friend; Margo and John--friends who shared the 60's & the years beyond; Michael who gave good counsel, even when Ira didn't listen; his Personal Assistants Ibeth, Susana, Tamara and Ann; each member of his family that he was close to; and all of the physicians, advocates and fellow disabled persons with whom he worked with on the many projects he was devoted to. As a colleague and friend wrote upon hearing the news, ''we are all a little more alone now.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Debate Over Start Of Fiscal Year
description: The start of the New York State fiscal year should be moved to July 1 from April 1, Carole E. Stone, below, the director of the State Division of the Budget, said in a March 2 letter to a committee of state lawmakers working to reform New York's budget-making process. The bipartisan committee, with legislators from the Senate and Assembly, favors moving the start of the fiscal year to May 1 to, among other things, have more time to analyze the annual state budget. The state is likely to miss its budget deadline for the 20th consecutive year. Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Democratic co-chairman of the committee, said he believed that Gov. George E. Pataki would ''reconsider his position'' about a July 1 start date once the legislators finished their work and put forward a clear proposal urging a May 1 start.
