title: 36 Hours | Bakersfield, Calif.
description: BAKERSFIELD is the land that time and tourists forgot. Its heyday was 150 years ago, when oil was discovered in the Kern River region, bringing wealth-seeking prospectors from all over the country and Europe. Now, this sprawling community (population 250,000) is a ghostly industrial town, a sleepy Nowheresville in which laborers who toil in the San Joaquin Valley farmbelt saunter around with unironic trucker caps perched high on their heads. The city's appeal isn't readily apparent; you have to dig deep into its native culture to discover how sui generis it truly is. It is the country music capital of the West Coast, for starters, and its polyglot culture (Spanish shepherds settled here in the early 1900's) has also made it the United States capital of Basque cuisine. In the spring and summer, it becomes a hub for outdoor types, with white-water rafting, bicycling and hiking in the nearby Sequoia Forest. As for tourist-friendly gentrification, forget it. In a state that prides itself on civic reinvention, Bakersfield is refreshingly fossilized. MARC WEINGARTEN

The appeals court sent the case back to the trial judge in Los Angeles for reconsideration. The companies are battling to supply chips to the market for metal oxide semiconductor field-effect transistors, which are switching devices that regulate the electricity supply in products like computers. Based on the judge's finding of infringement, a jury awarded $9.06 million, which the judge tripled based on the jury finding that Ixys intentionally infringed the International Rectifier patents. Shares of Ixys rose 36 cents, to $8.94. International Rectifier shares fell $1.01, to $44.56.

Redick, who led Duke in scoring this season, made only 5 of 13 shots and scored 14 points. His fellow guard Chris Duhon, who has bruised ribs, sat out most of the second half and did not score. Viv Bernstein

title: Boy Drops the Remote; Out Pops $100,000
description: When a toddler drops a television remote control it usually means trouble: another gadget to buy, another gadget to fix. But not 21-month-old Billy D'Onofrio. When he dropped the family remote, a prize-winning battery popped out, making his family $100,000 richer.

title: PRIVATE EQUITY FIRM TAKES OVER MAIDENFORM
description: Ares Management, a private equity firm, agreed to purchase the women's lingerie maker Maidenform Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection in the mid-1990's after defaulting on loans and failing to find a buyer. Ares, which is based in Los Angeles, said it would keep Maidenform private and maintain its management team. The price was not disclosed. Ares also owns stakes in the luggage company Samsonite and the mattress maker Serta. Maidenform, based in Bayonne, N.J., filed for Chapter 11 protection in 1997. It is now profitable and has annual sales of more than $300 million.

title: Interim Judge Steps Down Over Work For Rowland
description: An interim judge whose final confirmation was clouded by his disclosure that he had provided free legal services to Gov. John G. Rowland withdrew his name from nomination on Wednesday and resigned.

title: Two Officers Hurt in Crash Remain on Life Support
description: A day after two police officers were critically injured in a car accident in Queens, they lay on life support yesterday at Jamaica Hospital Center, with family members and friends praying by their bedsides.

title: In Shift, City Will Buy Buses for Private Lines
description: Under pressure from City Council leaders and community groups, the Bloomberg administration reversed course yesterday and said that it would begin buying more than 450 new buses for seven aging bus lines operated by private companies.

title: COURT EXAMINER FINDS FOR UAL ON RETIREE BENEFITS
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, did not mislead employees about possible changes in medical benefits to persuade workers to retire early, a court-appointed examiner found. The examiner found no evidence that United ''had a financial incentive to induce flight attendants to retire'' before July 1, 2003, United said in a statement. Unions representing United flight attendants, baggage handlers and mechanics say that thousands of employees agreed to retire before July 1, 2003, believing that if they did so, their benefits would remain intact. UAL has since said it will pursue reductions in benefits for those retirees. United wants to cut annual costs by $5 billion by 2005 in a effort to exit bankruptcy later this year.

title: Constantly Shifting Rhythms In a Lurching Ode to a Drunk
description: A lot of jazz over the last 20 years has sought to show its reach. Instead of staying inside one conception, it combines several, shifting among them in one piece. (The explanation is either multiculturalism or the too-much-on-cable effect or both.) The drummer Jeff (Tain) Watts exemplifies that jump-cut approach. ''Vodville,'' one of the tunes in his new incarnation as a bandleader, makes it literal, hopping into new kinds of rhythm several times in each chorus.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Restaurants are theater, of course. This is as true in a Greek diner as it is at Le Bernardin. Whether the waiter mutters ''whiskey down'' in response to your order for rye toast or bows discreetly as he unveils a Dover sole, a little drama plays in each place we eat. The performance is as much a part of the meal as the silverware, the ingredients, the cost.

We extend our deepest condolences to his family, especially his daughter, our colleague, Rabbi Iscah Waldman, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate.

title: Bloomberg Urges Stiffer Law Against Sales of Illegal Guns
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday sent a letter to legislative leaders in Albany urging them to pass legislation that would strengthen New York State's law against illegal gun sales.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Farmingville: Two Plead Guilty In Firebombing
description: Two Long Island teenagers admitted in court yesterday that they set a house ablaze last July because Mexican immigrants were living there. The teenagers, Kyle Mahler, 18, and Scott Soucek, 16, each pleaded guilty to a charge of reckless endangerment as a hate crime in Suffolk County Court. They could be sentenced to 1 1/3. to 4 years in prison when they are sentenced this spring. Three other youths were accused in the case; two pleaded guilty and the other's case is being handled in juvenile court. Mr. Mahler said that on July 5, he drove a car with several of his friends to the victims' home. Mr. Soucek admitted that he tossed a lit firecracker and bottle rocket into an open window. No one was hurt. Patrick Healy (NYT)

description: Morgan Stanley said yesterday that quarterly earnings increased 35 percent, helped by gains from trading, selling and underwriting stocks.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Interest Rate Cut
description: Brazil's central bank cut its benchmark lending rate to the lowest level in almost three years to help an economy that shrank last year for the first time since 1992. Central bankers lowered the overnight interbank rate by 0.25 percentage point, to 16.25 percent. The reduction was the first in three months. The monthly inflation rate in Brazil's economy, the biggest in South America, declined to 0.61 percent in February.

title: Spanish Government Seeks to Document That It Did Not Lie About Suspects

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Posts Slightly Wider Loss
description: The 3Com Corporation, the networking equipment company that has been struggling in the face of a decline in technology spending, reported a slightly wider loss for the third quarter as sales dropped 21 percent. Revenues for the quarter that ended Feb. 27 were approximately $172 million. The company reported a net loss of $86 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $79 million, or 22 cents a share, during the third quarter of 2003. The quarter included $40 million in restructuring charges. Shares of 3Com, which is based in Marlborough, Mass., fell 11 cents in after-hours trading, after closing down 3 cents at $7.06 in regular trading. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Pole Feels Misled Over Iraqi Arms
description: President Aleksander Kwasniewski, who has allied Poland strongly with the Bush administration in the war in Iraq, said on Thursday he felt ''misled'' by information about illicit weapons that have not been found there.

title: Seeing Pessimism, Not Science, as the Enemy
description: THERE are few battles as divisive in science as human embryonic stem cell research. Those who believe in it as passionately as Dr. Wise Young laud it as revolutionary, holding out hope for a cure for spinal cord injuries, while others in the field see the possibility of treating diseases like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's. Those who oppose it, including anti-abortion groups and the Roman Catholic Church, say it will allow scientists to play God, to control and direct the course of life itself.

title: U.N. to Send Envoy Back to Iraq to Help in Transfer of Power
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 19  The chief United Nations envoy for Iraq, Lakhdar Brahimi, will return to Iraq in coming weeks to help shape the transfer of power scheduled for June 30, Secretary General Kofi Annan said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAUBER, PETER AARON LEE
description: TAUBER--Peter Aaron Lee. 56, of NYC, celebrated writer, performer, political commentator and wit, died suddenly on the ski slopes of Deer Valley, UT, on Friday, March 12, 2004. The son of Rhea S. Tauber and the late Dr. Abraham Tauber, he is also survived by his sisters Lucy Tauber Brysk of San Francisco, and June Tauber Golden of NYC, and his brother-in-law Dr. Marcel Brysk, nephews and nieces, Alison Brysk, Joshua Brysk, Jordan Brysk, Seth Brysk, Sarah Brysk of California, and David Golden of NYC, and four grandnieces and grandnephews. His career spanned two landmark books about the sixties, ''The Sunshine Soldiers,'' and ''The Last Best Hope,'' numerous magazine articles, political speech writing, scientific and cultural journalism, and satire. His life knew no boundaries: a lover of words, a student of science, a man of poetry, an athlete, a true intellectual with gusto and joie de vivre. He was a loving uncle, brother and son, who left us quietly and with grace from the ski slopes that he loved. A funeral was held on March 15. A memorial service is planned in NYC for May 19. Donations can be made to The Doe Fund, 232 E. 84th St, NYC 10028. A website has been set up at www.petertauber.org with more information. He will be profoundly missed, but his love and joy remain with us.

title: ALLEGIANCE TO END BANKRUPTCY WITH SALE TO XO
description: Allegiance Telecom Inc. filed a plan to emerge from bankruptcy that would sell most of its assets for $631 million to the telephone and Internet access company XO Communications Inc, controlled by Carl C. Icahn. Allegiance would repay $477.8 million owed to senior lenders, and unsecured creditors would receive stock in a surviving subsidiary. Allegiance will ask the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York to approve its disclosure statement on April 16, which would clear the way for creditors to vote on the plan and Allegiance to emerge from bankruptcy by the middle of the year. XO, based in Reston, Va., won court approval to buy the assets in February. Allegiance, which is based in Dallas, filed for bankruptcy protection in May.

description: BRUSSELS, March 19  In the wake of the Madrid train attacks, European Union justice and interior ministers today rejected proposals to create a Central Intelligence Agency for Europe, but they agreed that a growing threat to the region makes greater intelligence coordination essential.

title: Fired Education Panel Member Says She Was Mischaracterized
description: A member of an education panel who was fired by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for failing to get on board with his decision to end so-called social promotion for third graders said yesterday that her thoughts on this issue had been mischaracterized by City Hall. She added that the work of her board had been ignored and that the suggestion that she or her colleague would have cried while mulling the choice was untrue.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Army Officer Charged
description: A Military Court filed a manslaughter indictment against an army lieutenant colonel in connection with a tank shooting that killed four Palestinian's at a food market almost two years ago. The officer was not named but was identified as the battalion commander in the West Bank town of Jenin on June 21, 2002, when a tank fired to enforce a curfew. The shooting killed a man, two brothers, ages 13 and 5, and a 6-year-old girl. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: WARNACO AND S.E.C. DISCUSS SETTLEMENT OF COMPLAINT
description: The Warnaco Group, the maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Olga bras, said the Securities and Exchange Commission had proposed a settlement of its investigation into the company's financial statements. A settlement will not have a material effect on its business, financial condition or results of operations, Warnaco said in a regulatory filing. Under the proposed settlement, the commission would charge Warnaco with violations of securities laws and issue a cease-and-desist order, the company said. Warnaco would also be required to review its internal controls and policies. Warnaco, which is based in New York, is in talks with the commission's staff about the proposed order, it said.

title: Hotel Attacks Linked to War Anniversary

Thursday night, only hours after the Basra attack, two more Baghdad hotels came under rocket attack, inflicting only minor injuries.

title: World Briefing: Asia
description: AFGHANISTAN: 2 U.S. SOLDIERS KILLED Two American soldiers were killed and two others were wounded in fighting in central Afghanistan, the United States military said. At least five guerrilla fighters were killed in the battle, officials said. The United States Central Command said the Americans were accompanied by Afghan troops when they were attacked by "anticoalition militia" near Tarin Kowt. The Americans were not identified by name or military unit. (AP)

title: Cold Murder Of a Girl Thaws Feelings Locked in Ice

And when she finally answers him, she's as good as dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SNYDER, ARTHUR I., M.D.
description: SNYDER--Arthur I., M.D. With immense sadness, the family of Dr. Arthur I. Snyder of New York City and Washington, CT. announces his death on March 15, 2004 from complications resulting from pneumonia. Dr. Snyder was an internist and rheumatologist for 54 years, practicing most recently as a founding partner of New York Physicians, Inc. He graduated from Columbia University and Columbia College of Physicians & Surgeons, and served in the U.S. Navy and the U.S. Coast Guard. He was an adoring husband of 32 years to Marilyn Benstock Synder, and a kind, loving and ever-supportive father to daughters Margaret Hamilton and Katherine Snyder, and their husbands Robin Hamilton and Tim Culvahouse, and to step children Eric Berkeley and Nancy Berkeley Bynum, and their spouses Christina Berkeley and Frank Bynum. He took tremendous pride in his grandchildren, Rebecca, Emily, Jessica, Sasha, Theo, Kit and Georgia. Dr. Snyder is also survived by his sister, Judith Jaffe. He graced our days with his warmth, elegance and dry wit. Arthur, you were the best part of us and will be missed more than words can say. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Arthritis Foundation, New York Chapter, 122 E. 42 St, 18th Flr, N.Y., N.Y. 10168. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, April 13th, 2:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

title: Delirious Decay From a Prolific Jack-of-All-Arts
description: A WORD of caution before you wade into the dissonant, oceanic survey of the work of Dieter Roth, the German-born, Swiss multimedia dynamo, at the Museum of Modern Art in Long Island City, Queens. Expect to be bewildered and even put off: Roth is as irksome as he is awesome, but ultimately awesome wins out. This long overdue exhibition introduces Americans to an artist who not only erased the line between art and life but also pulverized the two into a single process.

title: A Thousand-Year Treasury Of Chinese Masterpieces
description: It's hard to believe that the almost mythical hunk of horseflesh known as Night-Shining White really existed. But this powerful, sexy, all-white steed with lustrous eyes and bristling mane was actually a favorite mount of the eighth-century Chinese emperor Xuanzong. The portrait of Night-Shining White, from the idealizing brush of Han Gan, a leading horse painter of the Tang dynasty (active 742-756) -- the George Stubbs of his day, so to speak -- is intended to evoke a dragon in disguise, a celestial being with supernatural powers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEASE, DONALD E.
description: PEASE--Donald E. died on March 15, 2004 at the age of 83. He was admitted to practice law in Delaware, the District of Columbia and North Dakota. He was a member of the Delaware Bar Association and Chairman of its Lawyers Assistance Committee from 1985 to 1995 and continued as a member until his death. In 1987, the association awarded him a presidential citation for ''exceptional service to the profession'' and in 1996, he received the Longterm Service award. After his retirement from DuPont in 1983, he was offered a position as a professor of law at the Widener U. School of Law where he taught until 1995. While at the law school, he was faculty advisor to the Delaware Journal of Corporate Law and the Moot Court Honor Society. In 1992, he was selected by the graduating class as the ''Outstanding Faculty Member.'' He often said that he was most proud of his more than 25 years of service as a vice-president and pro bono attorney for the nonprofit corporation Child, Inc. Child, Inc. is a private agency providing many social services, including shelters for abused and battered spouses and abused and neglected children. In 1999, he was given the American Institute Jefferson Award in recognition of his volunteer service for Child, Inc. A Memorial Mass will be offered at 10AM on Monday, March 22nd, 2004 at Saint Joseph's on the Brandywine Catholic Church, 10 Old Church Road, Greenville, Delaware. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions be made to Child, Inc., 507 Philadelphia Pike, Wilmington, Delaware 19809-2177. For information, Chandler Funeral Homes. www. chandlerfuneralhome.com

title: Global Crossing Settles Suit on Losses
description: Investors and former workers who lost money and their pensions in the 2002 collapse of Global Crossing, the telecommunications company, will receive $325 million in a settlement of a class-action lawsuit reached late yesterday.

title: A Victory by Three-Hundredths After Three Appeals in Reno
description: A New York partnership appeared to have won the North American Pairs title in Reno, Nev., on Thursday night on the eve of the Spring National Championships, but a bizarre combination of circumstances deprived them of victory.

title: On One Town Hall Evening, It Was 1935 All Over Again
description: The year 1935, when the country was staggering in the throes of the Depression, wasn't the brightest year in the history of the American musical, at least not commercially. All 10 shows that appeared on Broadway that season, including ''Porgy and Bess,'' lost money. When Gershwin's masterwork opened, New York's drama critics liked it much more than its music critics. The same year, two luminous standards, ''Just One of Those Things'' and ''Begin the Beguine,'' from Cole Porter's ''Jubilee,'' were widely dismissed as sub-par Porter, with dim commercial hopes.

title: Hussein's Fall Leads Syrians To Test Government Limits
description: A year ago, it would have been inconceivable for a citizen of Syria, run by the Baath Party of President Bashar al-Assad, to make a documentary film with the working title, ''Fifteen Reasons Why I Hate the Baath.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CULLMAN, JOAN PALEY STRAUS
description: CULLMAN -- Joan Paley Straus. The Board and Staff of National Dance Institute mourn the passing of arts advocate, visionary producer and philanthropist Joan Cullman, mother of our Associate Artistic Director and Board member Tracy Straus. NDI joins the numerous arts organizations and artists whose work she helped make possible in remembering and celebrating her life. We extend our sincere sympathy to her beloved family. Elliott Slade and Diane Volk Co-Chairmen Jacques D'Amboise, Founder Ellen Weinstein Artistic Director Lesli Kapell Executive Director

title: National Briefing: Midwest
description: ILLINOIS: STATE FLAGS FINANCIALLY AILING SCHOOLS The number of Illinois school districts in the worst financial shape grew by nearly 80 percent this year, renewing calls for financing changes and providing fuel for Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich's effort to cut school costs. The State Board of Education said 156 districts would be put on its "financial watch" list, up from 87 last year. The board's financial categories were based on factors like a district's expenditures versus its income. Brenda Holmes, the governor's education chief, said that Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, had proposed increasing school financing by nearly $400 million. He has also proposed saving $1 billion by creating statewide pools to buy supplies and health insurance. (AP)

title: As Pressure on Rowland Intensifies, Few Express Support
description: Walking to the Capitol on Friday before a meeting of the special committee that is considering whether to recommend the impeachment of Gov. John G. Rowland, one of the committee's co-chairmen, who like the governor, is a Republican, was asked to name an elected official who would stand up for the governor against the seemingly endless accusations being made against him.

description: Pakistan Standoff Goes On

title: CINCINNATI 80, EAST TENNESSEE STATE 77
description: Murry Bartow never beat Cincinnati in seven attempts as the coach at Alabama-Birmingham. Now at East Tennessee State, Bartow fell just short again against the fourth-seeded Bearcats in Columbus, Ohio. Tony Bobbitt's 3-pointer from the left wing with 17 seconds to play helped Cincinnati defeat the 13th-seeded Buccaneers. Pat Borzi

title: XAVIER 80, LOUISVILLE 70
description: Xavier remained one of the hottest teams in the tournament, overcoming a 14-point second-half deficit with a 36-10 run in Orlando, Fla. The seventh-seeded Musketeers have won 14 of their last 15 games. Louisville (20-10), seeded No. 10, faded late in the season and finished with 9 losses in its final 13 games. Lionel Chalmers led Xavier (24-10) with 25 points and Sato had 24. Tom Spousta

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Broker Acquired
description: The online securities company Monex will buy a rival, Nikko Beans, in a 47 billion yen ($440 million) deal that will create Japan's largest online brokerage firm. The merged company will have client assets of 1.1 trillion yen, more than the current market leader, E*Trade Securities. The Sony Corporation will hold 20 percent and the founder of Monex, Oki Matsumoto, will hold 12.8 percent; he will be president of the new firm. Todd Zaun (NYT)

description: CANADA: QUEBEC COURT UPHOLDS GAY MARRIAGE The top court in Quebec Province ruled that same-sex couples have the right to marry, upholding a lower court decision that said the traditional definition of marriage is discriminatory. The ruling by the Quebec Court of Appeal follows similar decisions last year in British Columbia and Ontario. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: CHARGES DROPPED AGAINST CHAPLAIN
description: The military said Friday night that it was dropping all charges, including one of mishandling classified information, against Capt. James J. Yee, the former Muslim chaplain at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: KENTUCKY 96, FLORIDA A&M 76
description: Florida A&M Coach Mike Gillespie jokingly said he wished his 16th-seeded Rattlers would defeat Kentucky so he could stick around for the Sunday brunch at the team hotel. That did not happen, but Florida A&M (14-17) -- the only team in the tournament with a losing record -- gave the Wildcats an up-tempo fight into the second half. Terrence Woods, who led the nation by averaging 4.4 3-pointers a game, had six 3's among his 24 points. Pat Borzi

title: Justice in a Bind
description: In an angry 21-page memorandum fired off on Thursday, Justice Antonin Scalia went to unbecoming lengths to justify his refusal to withdraw from a case challenging the secrecy surrounding the energy task force headed by Vice President Dick Cheney, his duck-hunting companion.

title: OKLAHOMA STATE 75, EASTERN WASHINGTON 56

The Eagles' Alvin Snow did not score until 2:09 remained. Snow, the Big Sky player of the year, finished 1 of 10 from the field. Ray Glier

title: LEUCADIA REVISES TAKEOVER BID FOR PLAINS RESOURCES
description: The Leucadia National Corporation revised its offer for Plains Resources to include preferred stock to counter an all-cash bid for the oil company from Plains's top two executives and Vulcan Capital. The offer of cash, newly issued notes and preferred stock values each Plains share at about $18.75, $18 at a minimum, Leucadia said in a letter to Plains Resources' directors. Plains, which is based in Houston, rejected an offer of cash and notes valued by Leucadia at $18.19 a share in favor of an all-cash offer from Vulcan Capital valued at $16.75. Leucadia said it reworked the offer to answer concerns raised by a special committee of the Plains board that reviewed the bids.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sanyo Cuts Forecast
description: The Sanyo Electric Company warned that profit would fall short of its earlier forecast because of weak sales of home appliances. Sanyo cut its forecast for net profit for the year ending March 31 to 3 billion yen ($28 million) from an estimate of 25.5 billion yen. Sales of washing machines, refrigerators and other appliances have been weakening amid growing competition from cheap Chinese brands. Sanyo has had strong sales of digital cameras and mobile phones. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Reporting Live, Outside Credibility
description: In a foolhardy obsession, the Bush administration continues to insist that a woman it used to portray a television reporter is actually a freelance journalist, not an actor. The woman appears in free videos distributed to local TV stations by the Health and Human Services Department. The videos, which many stations used, are plugs for the controversial new drug program the White House is selling to elderly voters. But the videos pretend to be balanced news accounts, and even end with a facsimile of the tag line delivered by real reporters. ''In Washington, I'm Karen Ryan reporting.''

title: Analysts Question Value of Coke's Old Guard

title: Winter's Last Snowy Effort, Spring's First Hint of Thaw
description: As if teasing people on the eve of the new season, Mother Nature dumped a few inches of snow on the New York region overnight and early yesterday. But the sun peeked out by noon in most places, and thoughts of a thaw filled many gardeners' minds.

title: Corrections

They are not compatible with some Dish Network satellite receivers, and only some models can record two television programs simultaneously.

title: Europe Takes On Windows
description: Microsoft is widely expected to suffer a major defeat next week in Europe, the latest front in the antitrust wars. The European Commission will follow the lead of American regulators and courts in declaring that Microsoft illegally abused its monopolistic market share in computer operating systems to harm competitors. But the commission is overreaching in seeking remedies that could hurt not only Microsoft, but consumers as well.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: ZOO OFFICIALS DON'T KNOW HOW GORILLA ESCAPED Dallas Zoo officials say they cannot explain how a 340-pound gorilla escaped from his enclosure, injuring four people before he was shot to death. The police evacuated about 300 people from the zoo on Thursday and killed Jabari, a 13-year-old male western lowland gorilla, after he charged at officers. The injured included Rivers Noah, 3, who was bitten on his head and chest and was in fair condition at Children's Medical Center. His mother, Keisha Heard, 26, who was bitten on the legs, and Cheryl Reichert, who had arm injuries, were treated at hospitals and released. A fourth victim, a child, was treated at the scene. (AP)

title: KANSAS 78, ILLINOIS-CHICAGO 53
description: There were some restless moments for the loud Kansas fans, who only had to travel 40 minutes from Lawrence and filled up the 18,500-seat Kemper Arena in Kansas City, Mo. The Jayhawks made just one field goal in the first five and a half minutes of the second half and saw a 15-point halftime lead trimmed to 45-35. Kansas finally pulled away with a 22-4 run over a seven-minute span. Ray Glier

title: MEMPHIS 59, SOUTH CAROLINA 43
description: Memphis, which vowed to take away South Carolina's 3-point shooting, took away more than that, holding the Gamecocks without a field goal for the last 9:38 of the first half on its way to victory in Kansas City, Mo. Ray Glier

description: A look of frustration seldom left Julius Hodge's face. Hodge, the A.C.C. player of the year, missed 6 of his first 8 shots and was constantly cut off by Louisiana-Lafayette's double-team defense.

title: Bush Urges Nations To Help Rebuild Iraq
description: Rallying support for the fight against terrorism, President Bush urged the nations around the world to put aside past differences and focus on stabilizing and rebuilding Iraq. ''Any sign of weakness or retreat simply validates terrorist violence, and invites more violence for all nations,'' he told a group of foreign emissaries at the White House.

title: Stanford and Its Star Hope They Can Finally Rate a Mention
description: She watched the previews about the N.C.A.A. women's tournament, and her team was barely mentioned. Then she picked up a copy of USA Today that listed five players to watch in the Midwest Regional, and it did not mention her.

description: Competing with 133 years of history is not easy, but the 134th edition of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus can hold its head high.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Court Refuses Khodorkovsky Bail
description: A Moscow court kept Russia's richest man, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, in jail with a ruling that extends the oil baron's pre-trial detention until at least May 25. Mr. Khodorkovsky, former chief executive of Yukos, the oil company, was arrested in October on charges including fraud and tax evasion, in what was viewed as a Kremlin-backed attack to clip his political ambitions. His detention was to end next Thursday. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: 90-DAY STRATEGY BY BUSH'S AIDES TO DEFINE KERRY
description: President Bush's campaign is following an aggressive and precise 90-day media strategy to define Senator John Kerry as indecisive and lacking conviction, with a coordinated blitz of advertisements, speeches and sound bites, senior campaign advisers said this week.

title: Seeking Top Qaeda Figure, Pakistanis Battle Militants
description: Thousands of Pakistani soldiers backed by artillery and helicopter gunships made limited progress on Friday advancing into a 10-square-mile pocket of farming villages where 300 to 600 suspected militants have been surrounded near the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani officials said.

title: Bergen County House on Historic Register Is Fire Victim
description: An 18th-century Dutch Colonial that was placed on the New Jersey registry of historic places 25 years ago to save it from the encroachment of a road expansion project was gutted by a four-alarm fire early Friday.

title: For Coke, it's water down the drain
description: LONDON:  Last month, Coca-Cola introduced its Dasani bottled water in Britain with advertisements showing a man in a scuba outfit waiting at a bus stop. "Prepare to get wet," the poster ads said.

description: A former police officer convicted of spraying pepper spray into the mouth of a man who died in custody after being wrongly picked up in the investigation into the shooting of an Orange policewoman was sentenced on Friday to nine years in federal prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOOD, JANE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DI GANGI, LINDA, PH.D.

Dear aunt of Christi, Becky, Kate and Matt. Linda was a psychologist for the Bellmore-Merrick School District as well as in private practice in NYC. Linda was an avid traveler and bicyclist. She was a member of the Nassau County Psychology Assn., NYS Psychology Assn., American Psychology Assn. and the Society for Psychoanalytic Training. Cremation services will be private. Cusimano & Russo Funeral Home., 2005 W. 6th St., Brooklyn, NY. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend yesterday of ''Greendale,'' written, directed and photographed by the musician Neil Young, misstated the format in which the film was made. It was shot with a Super 8 underwater camera, not on video.

title: John Rodgers, 89, Geologist; Mapped Bedrock
description: Dr. John Rodgers, a Yale geologist who mapped the patterns of Connecticut bedrock and helped support the theory of continental drift with his ideas about mountain formation, died on March 7 in Hamden, Conn. He was 89

title: Terror Of Childbirth
description: Zara Fatim, a 15-year-old girl, was in labor for four days before her family loaded her onto public transportation -- the back of a truck -- and took her to the dilapidated National General Reference Hospital here on Tuesday. Her blood pressure was high, 170/80, and she soon lapsed into a coma. The baby arrived stillborn. Zara needed oxygen, but the hospital had none to spare.

title: Perlman Plays a Different Instrument, the Orchestra
description: Fame is an invaluable asset in establishing a late conducting career, but it cuts both ways. A young, unknown conductor might spend a decade or two with smaller orchestras, learning all the while. Itzhak Perlman, a household name as a violinist, is cutting his teeth in the big spotlight. Having already led some of the world's most streamlined orchestras -- from the Philadelphia Orchestra to the Berlin Philharmonic -- he made his New York Philharmonic podium debut Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: SUDAN: `GREATEST HUMANITARIAN CRISIS' A senior United Nations official said fighting in western Sudan had intensified and accused Arab militia of systematically attacking villages and raping women. Mukesh Kapila, the United Nations resident coordinator for Sudan, said attacks against tribes in the Darfur region were "close to the definition of ethnic cleansing." He said: "In my view, this is the world's greatest humanitarian crisis and possibly the world's greatest humanitarian catastrophe. There has been systematic burning of villages and displacement of the population." In one attack, on Feb. 27, more than 100 women were raped in the northern town of Tawilaa, Mr. Kapila said. Fighting has raged across Darfur since February 2003, when rebels took up arms. They accuse President Omar Hassan Ahmed al-Bashir's Islamic government of arming and supporting the Arab militia. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the Political Points column on March 7 about a response by Senator John Edwards during a presidential debate incorporated an anecdote in which President Ronald Reagan in 1988 misidentified the person who praised the boxer Joe Louis at an event during World War II. Louis proclaimed that America would win the war because it was on God's side. The master of ceremonies, who praised Louis, was the former mayor of New York, Jimmy Walker, not, as Mr. Reagan said, the comedian George Jessel. ( Go to Article )

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Sale Of Oil Stake Delayed
description: The government will delay selling the state's shares in the Russian oil company Lukoil until 2005, rather than sometime this year, the company's president said. Lukoil's president, Vagit Y. Alekperov, said at a news conference on Thursday that a draft of the proposed share sale would ''more than likely'' be submitted to the government for 2005. A Lukoil vice president, Leonid Fedun, said in January that market conditions were favorable for a sale this year. The state's stake is 7.59 percent. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: We Don't Want to Be Alone
description: It has been an uneasy week for the citizens of Madrid. Not because we are new to the fears and destruction of terrorism. We have long known how fragile human life is and how easily disaster can be sowed in the places that seem safest. And yet, we have often felt alone. Many times, it seemed as if the world had more sympathy for our longtime scourges, the Basque separatists of ETA, than for the victims of their terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, ROBERT
description: GREENBERG--Robert. The Monroe College community notes with profound sadness the untimely passing of Robert Greenberg husband of Roberta Greenberg, Vice President of the college. Bob was a very real and special part of Monroe for more than 28 years. He had a love for the success of students and was a great booster for all events at the college. We extend our sincere condolences to Roberta, their daughters Shari Gold and Bonnie Stern, their sons-in-law Dr. Jay Gold and Scott Stern and their five grandchildren. Stephen J. Jerome, President

title: Spanish Judge Holds 3 Moroccans on Murder Charges
description: A Spanish judge ordered Friday that three Moroccans be held on multiple provisional charges of terrorism and murder in the Madrid train bombings, as investigators uncovered new details suggesting that Europe's deadliest terrorist attack in 25 years was carried out on a slim budget by men who used a stolen van and explosives they got free.

title: Keeping Things Austere, Even if Seeking Intimacy
description: Austerity prevailed when the Charles Linehan Company of London made its United States debut on Thursday night in the Global Exchange series of the Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church in the East Village. Mr. Linehan offered two works he choreographed in association with his dancers. Neither was fancy or fussy, yet both demonstrated that austere steps can be rich in emotional implications.

title: Sherman Lewis, 67, Financier Who Was Executive at Lehman
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Telecom Shares Sold
description: Eircom sold shares on the Dublin and London exchanges in Europe's largest public offering so far this year and the largest in Ireland since Eircom, the former state telephone company, first floated shares in 1999. The stock, which attracted investors with a dividend yield of 7 percent, dipped to 1.49 euros before recovering to close at 1.53 euros in Dublin, 0.02 euro below opening price, and at 1.54 euros in London. Providence Equity Partners, the fund that took Eircom private with the billionaires George Soros and Sir Anthony O'Reilly, received as much as $463 million for the 44 percent stake it bought for $280 million less than three years ago. The chief executive of Providence, Jonathan Nelson, said the fund had worked closely with Eircom's chief executive, Phil Nolan, above, to prepare for the opportunities the company sees in providing the broadband Internet access that is currently rare in Ireland. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Calhoun and Coaching Pupil Are Cut From the Same Cloth
description: BUFFALO, March 19  Jim Calhoun stomps along the Connecticut sideline in a slightly rumpled suit and a dress shirt fighting to stay tucked in. Dave Leitao strolls in front of the DePaul bench in haberdashery meant for a fashion runway.

description: Richard A. Brown, a leading tactician of the New York Democratic revolt against the Tammany Hall machine half a century ago, died on Feb. 13 in Washington, where he had lived for the last 40 years. He was 85.

title: MISSISSIPPI STATE 85, MONMOUTH 52
description: ''They didn't allow us to dictate the tempo,'' Monmouth Coach Dave Calloway said. Playing in Orlando, Fla., Mississippi State scored 31 points off 17 turnovers. The Bulldogs outrebounded Monmouth, 47-20, pulling their starters midway through the second half. Lawrence Roberts led the Bulldogs with 19 points. Tom Spousta

title: National Briefing | Religion: Jury Deliberating In Church Trial
description: Closing arguments in the church trial of a lesbian minister ended and jury deliberations were expected to stretch into the weekend. The minister, the Rev. Karen Dammann, could be defrocked if found in violation of Methodist law, which excludes self-avowed, practicing gays from the clergy. The trial, conducted at the Bothell United Methodist Church northeast of Seattle, comes just before the United Methodist Church's quadrennial conference. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Influential Technology Writer Sells Her Newsletter Business
description: CNET Networks, the online publisher of technology news and reviews, said on Friday that it had acquired EDventure Holdings, the technology newsletter company run by Esther Dyson, the industry analyst.

title: Boy, 6, Badly Hurt in Queens Hit-and-Run
description: A 6-year-old boy was critically injured yesterday in a hit-and-run accident in Queens, the police said.

title: Jordan's King Visits Sharon To Discuss Withdrawal Plan
description: King Abdullah II of Jordan paid a rare, unannounced call on Prime Minister Ariel Sharon on Thursday to discuss Mr. Sharon's plan for ''disengagement'' from the Palestinians, an Israeli official said Friday.

title: Uta Hagen Memorial
description: A memorial service for the actress and teacher Uta Hagen will be held on Thursday at 1 p.m. at the Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, Manhattan. She died on Jan. 14 at 84.

title: SMURFIT-STONE FORECASTS SIXTH CONSECUTIVE LOSS
description: The Smurfit-Stone Container Corporation said its first-quarter loss would be almost double what it was a year ago because of falling prices for corrugated containers and higher benefit costs. The loss, its sixth in a row, will widen to 22 cents to 25 cents a share from 13 cents a year earlier, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected Smurfit-Stone to lose 11 cents a share.

description: KLEIN--Irene Vladeck, 90, of Putnam Valley, NY died peacefully March 19, 2004. Predeceased by two loving husbands, William Vladeck and Abraham Klein. She was a devoted sister to her brothers, Drs. Sigmund and Jacob Lichterman. She was a teacher and a city planner by profession, and an involved community volunteer in Three Arrows and Putnam Valley; but mostly she was a devoted mother and motherin-law to Susan, Amy and Richard, and Bobb and Cheryl; a loving and devoted grandmother to Aaron and Shelley, Joshua and Candace, Leah and Adrian, Andrew, Naomi and Eric, Michael, Will, and Daniel; and a proud great-grandmother to Molly, Arwyn and Samuel. Against the Minnesota Wild on Friday night, he got in a barking match with the Wild's 6-5, 220-pound Alex Henry, posturing like a terrier challenging a Great Dane.

title: NEBRASKA COURT REVIVES SUIT AGAINST MICROSOFT
description: The Nebraska Supreme Court revived a class-action lawsuit yesterday contending Microsoft overcharged consumers in the state for its Windows 98 operating software. The lawsuit is similar to dozens filed against Microsoft after a federal appeals court in 2001 said the company had illegally exploited its Windows monopoly. Microsoft has settled consumer suits in 10 states for $1.55 billion and is on trial in Minnesota in a $425 million class-action damage case. The Nebraska Supreme Court reversed its own June 25, 2003, decision, which had upheld a lower court's dismissal of the case. A state court judge in Fremont had held that under Nebraska law only consumers who had purchased Windows 98 directly from Microsoft could seek monetary damages.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE 58, UTAH 51
description: Time-zone changes meant the Utes began the game in Milwaukee at 10:30 a.m. on their body clocks. Was sleepiness to blame for Nick Jacobson's 0-for-10 shooting in the first half? The Utes were still dozing in the game's final minute when a shot-clock violation after a timeout ruined their last chance to tie the score. Craig Smith of Boston College was most effective, with 19 points and 8 rebounds, but he winced and was limping late after he hit the floor hard. Uka Agbai (10 points) said of the Eagles' subdued celebration: ''We belong here. We're not going to do jumping jacks and act like little kids.'' Joe Lapointe

description: About 300 people marched through the city's financial district on Friday during the morning rush hour to protest the one-year anniversary of the start of the war in Iraq.

title: ILLINOIS 72, MURRAY STATE 53
description: Bruce Weber, Illinois' first-year coach, faced Murray State last year at Southern Illinois, so he thought he knew what to expect from the 12th-seeded Racers today: lots of pressure defense. But the Racers, playing without their scoring leader, the suspended Kelvin Brown, largely sat back in a 2-3 zone.

description: ''You'll get some lady who was selling teapots and baby clothes and all of a sudden she's an electronics kingpin.''

title: Batting .185, Lofton Wants More Practice
description: Kenny Lofton thrives on plenty of batting practice, particularly during spring training. But the Yankees did not know that about Lofton, their new center fielder, and he was initially reluctant to mention it.

title: A Playboy King's Life: Intrigue, Plague and Torn Bodices
description: Hectic tableaus define ''The Last King,'' the BBC's mini-series about the reign of King Charles II. This is a serviceable, if boring, English costume drama, yet the creators have tried, somewhat embarrassingly, to sex it up. A movie about a playboy king and his cloak-and-dagger court, set in a time of dissipation and spectacle, requires more austere staging, lest the whole flamboyant sensibility be ladled on uncritically -- and too thick.

title: Taiwans President Appears to Win Election
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 20  The presidential candidate of the opposition Nationalist Party refused on Saturday night to accept results showing that he narrowly lost an election to President Chen Shui-bian, and demanded that ballot boxes from all 13,000 polling places nationwide be impounded and recounted.

title: Favored Providence Is Sent Packing by Pacific
description: Providence spent the season ripping up all projections that labeled it a second-division team in the Big East.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Quebec Court Upholds Gay Marriage
description: The top court in Quebec Province ruled that same-sex couples have the right to marry, upholding a lower court decision that said the traditional definition of marriage is discriminatory. The ruling by the Quebec Court of Appeal follows similar decisions last year in British Columbia and Ontario. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: In Tuesday's column I quoted the European Commission's president, Romano Prodi, telling the Italian newspaper La Stampa that force was not the answer to terrorism. I was relying on an Agence France-Presse translation, which was incorrect. Prodi actually said force should not be the only answer to terrorism. He said terrorism would not abate until the Israeli-Palestinian dispute was resolved.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Bid For Canary Wharf
description: A group led by Morgan Stanley raised its bid for the Canary Wharf Group by 6 percent, to 1.7 billion ($3.1 billion), to surpass the Brascan Corporation of Canada in a nine-month takeover battle for the London real estate developer. The offer, 292 pence a share, compares with earlier bids of 275 pence by Morgan Stanley and by Brascan, which is backed by Canary Wharf's founder, Paul Reichmann. The British Land Company, a leading property developer in Britain, has agreed to join the Morgan Stanley bid, the group said. Canary Wharf shares rose 14.5 pence, or 5.2 percent, to close at 292.5 pence in London, the highest since November 2002. Brascan said it was considering options.

title: I.O.C. Considers Monitoring The Preparations in Athens
description: Less than five months before the start of the Summer Olympics and with fewer than half the arenas and competition halls ready, the International Olympic Committee is considering sending monitors to Athens, the host city.

description: KIRSCH--Leslie, 99, a lifelong New Yorker, passed away peacefully in his Manhattanhome March 17. He was a lawyer and scholar who loved languages, literature, and music. Beloved husband of the late Adele Epstein Kirsch, he is survived by his loving children, Carol Dietz and John Kirsch, four grandchildren (Adam, David, Laura, Vivien), five great-grandchildren (Aidan, Alexander, Nicholas, Olivia, Zoe), and his dear friend Dr. Ildiko Mohacsy. Contributions may be sent to French Institute Alliance Francaise, Jewish Home and Hospital of NY, and Lighthouse International. Funeral 12:00 PM, Sunday, March 21, Levine Chapel, 470 Harvard St, Brookline, MA. Burial Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. Shiva at the home of John Kirsch and Sandra Shapiro, 7:00 PM, Sunday-Thursday.

title: Program Questioned After Another Dead Baby Is Found
description: As New Jersey's Legislature considers strengthening a program that encourages mothers not to abandon their infants in places like toilets and trash cans, another discarded baby was found this week -- this time, a dead newborn boy.

title: Coke Recalls Bottled Water Newly Introduced to Britain
description: Only weeks after it introduced Dasani bottled water into Britain, the Coca-Cola Company ordered a recall of some 500,000 bottles on Friday after finding excess levels of bromate. The chemical, with long-term exposure, has been linked to a higher risk of cancer.

title: Logo Shirts Eluded Embargo
description: An apparel merchandiser for President Bush's re-election campaign sold fleece pullovers with a Bush-Cheney logo that were made in Myanmar, even though the United States has banned imports from that country, campaign and company officials said yesterday.

title: Schools Stance Scores Points For the Mayor, Strategists Say
description: There may not be agreement over the educational value of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's strict new standards for promoting third graders, but it is clear that the very act of imposing those standards -- and the bare-knuckle manner in which he imposed them -- will be central to his campaign for re-election in 2005.

title: ALABAMA-BIRMINGHAM 102, WASHINGTON 100
description: In its first tournament appearance in five years, Alabama-Birmingham won a first-round game for the first time since 1986, when Gene Bartow was the coach. But in a furious finish in Columbus, Ohio, it took an off-balance, shot-clock-beating 3-pointer by Carldell Johnson with 1:08 remaining to stay ahead of the Huskies, the only team to beat Stanford this season.

title: To Convict Kozlowski, Jury Must Find Intent, Judge Says
description: Jurors considering fraud and larceny charges against L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, need to find that he ''acted with larcenous intent'' in order to convict him, the judge in the case said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBLATT, FLORA SIEWICZ

title: GEORGIA TECH 65, NORTHERN IOWA 60
description: Northern Iowa, which was seeded 14th, overcame a 17-point deficit and took a one-point lead early in the second half. They worked a last-second shot to Ben Jacobson, who could have sent the game into overtime with his 3-point attempt from the left side over the Yellow Jackets' Clarence Moore. But the shot hit the rim and bounced out, and Georgia Tech survived to face Boston College in Milwaukee tomorrow. Luke Schenscher, Georgia Tech's 7-foot-1 Australian center, scored 13 points but took a beating from Northern Iowa's David Gruber, who led Northern Iowa with 16 points. ''He played tough, he didn't back down, he took it right at me,'' Schenscher said. Joe Lapointe

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chemicals Deal
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals agreed to buy Raisio Chemicals of Finland for 475 million euros ($589 million), making the Swiss company the world's No.1 maker of chemicals used in paper and pulp production. Adding Raisio Chemicals, a unit of Raisio, will catapult Ciba, now ranked sixth, to the top of an industry with annual sales of more than $16 billion. The acquisition is Ciba's second this week. The company, based in Basel, said Tuesday that it would buy Pira International of Britain, which provides consulting and services in the packaging, paper and publishing industries, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Throwing the Book Away
description: The Stanford assistant coach Tony Fuller noticed during his team's first-round victory against Texas-San Antonio in Seattle on Thursday that Alabama's assistant coaches were watching the game, frantically scribbling down plays. So he made eye contact with them, smiled and flipped through his voluminous binder of offensive sets. The Crimson Tide coaches threw away their notes and held their hands up.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Racketeering Suspect Is Arrested
description: Coast Guard officers arrested Jose M. Battle Jr., the reputed leader of an organized crime family in the Miami area known as the Corporation, aboard a cruise ship on course for Costa Rica. Hours earlier on Friday, Mr. Battle and 24 other people were accused in a federal racketeering indictment of crimes ranging from illegal gambling and drug smuggling to murder. Mr. Battle, 51, had been one of four suspects at large. With the consent of Royal Caribbean International Cruise Lines, officers boarded the ship, the Celebrity Summit, arrested him and took him to a Coast Guard cruiser. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Finland: Ex-Leader Acquitted On Secrets Charge
description: Former Prime Minister Anneli Jaatteenmaki, forced to resign last year for her role in leaking classified documents about Finnish policy on Iraq, was acquitted of criminal charges. She led her Center Party to power last March in part by claiming that Paavo Lipponen, then prime minister, had exaggerated official support for the United States-led war in Iraq during a visit to Washington. But Ms. Jaatteenmaki's use of leaked documents became the bigger scandal, forcing her to leave office after two months. According to the SST news agency, the court found her innocent of ''assisting or inciting'' the leak but convicted the presidential aide who faxed her the documents. Walter Gibbs (NYT)

Bloomberg's dismissal on Monday of members of the Panel for Educational Policy who opposed his third-grade promotion policy may discourage some people from applying.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Swaziland: Topping The World In AIDS Infection
description: Forty percent of the country's population has contracted AIDS or carries its virus, giving the nation of 1.1 million people the world's highest H.I.V. infection rate, state radio quoted a United Nations official as saying. Stephen Lewis, the United Nations' special envoy for H.I.V. and AIDS in Africa, was reported to have told King Mswati III that the infection rate had risen slightly since the last official tally, which concluded that 38.6 percent of the population was H.I.V. positive. Estimates of infection elsewhere in southern Africa have been falling in recent months. Mr. Lewis was quoted as saying that Botswana, once said to have the greatest share of infected people, has recorded a drop of 1.3 percentage points, to 37.5 percent. Michael Wines (NYT)

description: The government declared a day of mourning and ordered flags to be flown at half-staff after 24 people, many of them teenagers, were killed when their bus collided with a heavily laden tractor-trailer on an icy road 190 miles north of Helsinki. title: Civil War Still Haunts Spanish Politics
description: While rescue crews were still picking through the rubble from the devastating explosions in Madrid last week, Spanish commentators were already making comparisons, not to 9/11, not to other terrorist attacks that had occurred in Europe over the last couple of decades but to the unrest in 1934 through 1936, the bloody period preceding the bitter Spanish Civil War.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BETTINGER, BEATRICE

Services at 11:30am on Sunday, March 21 at Weinstein Garlick and Kirschenbaum, 1153 Coney Island Ave at Avenue H, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you make a donation to the charity of your choice.

title: Times Scholarships Reward Achievement and Sacrifice
description: Matthew Berenguer's parents sacrificed all they owned so he could get the one thing he could keep forever: an education. When his father lost his job, they lost their apartment. The family put everything in storage, and all seven of them lived in homeless shelters. If that was not hard enough, his parents had to decide how to spend what little money they had left: continue paying storage fees for their belongings or send Matthew to a summer program at Syracuse University.

title: Once a Singer From Texas, Now a Texan Who Sings
description: Betty Buckley enters the Cafe Carlyle singing ''As Time Goes By,'' and then segues into ''Where or When.'' What follows in her new show is an hour of songs, diverse but all deeply felt -- blues, ballads, country and a few Broadway tunes. The title of the show, ''Portraits,'' is meant to be taken literally. Ms. Buckley regards herself as a portrait painter in her selection of material, whether she is in a Broadway musical or appearing in a supper club.

Graco's TurboBooster, a colorful, sporty car seat, can grow as a child grows.

Politicians of both parties -- led by President Bush, with his support of an amendment banning gay marriage -- have avoided the main issue and sought refuge in the abstractions of the Constitution. Instead of asking what kind of society we want, they argue about what our structure of government can permit.

A far-reaching cultural revolution has started, reversing the course of the previous one and taking this ancient civilization back to its age-old passion, collecting the art of its past.

title: CHIRON HALTS DEVELOPMENT OF EXPERIMENTAL MEDICINE
description: The Chiron Corporation, maker of the Proleukin drug for skin and kidney cancers, halted development of an experimental medicine after studies showed it did not work against tumors in the stomach and esophagus. The company last year halted work on the drug, called tezacitabine, in colon cancer patients. Chiron, based in Emeryville, Calif., said it would also end the stomach cancer studies based on results from the second of three phases of tests usually required for federal approval. Chiron does not have any other tests of tezacitabine and may seek to license it to another company, a spokesman, John Gallagher, said.

title: Word for Word/Scalia's Defense; A Case of Blind Justice Among a Bunch of Friends

His 21-page memorandum, in which he denied a request by the Sierra Club that he recuse himself from a case involving Mr. Cheney, bristles with vigorous rhetoric, powerful advocacy and a confident command of history and precedent. The Sierra Club had argued that the trip required the justice to recuse himself from a case considering whether the vice president should be required to turn over records from his energy task force.

title: The Strip-Mall Revolutionaries

When I called Yasith Chhun, the group's leader, he didn't hesitate to invite me to the next meeting.

But voters went to the polls with another uncertainty hanging over them: Who shot President Chen and Annette Lu, his vice president, on the eve of the vote? Mr. Chen and Ms. Lu were only slightly injured, and the election went ahead as planned. But Taiwan's often raucous democracy faced its sternest test. Joseph Kahn

title: The Sky Box

The artist says that his work is ''like trying to make the emperor's clothes visible.'' Turrell calls his latest work -- a 350-square-foot concrete ''skyspace'' -- a garden folly. It hangs 200 feet above Benedict Canyon in Los Angeles, cost more than a million dollars and took 13 years to complete because of its precarious site. It even outlived the renowned modernist architect John Lautner, whose office got the commission, and was completed by Lautner's project architect, Duncan Nicholson.

Dressed in a tan-and-cream seersucker suit, French-cuff shirt and maroon bow tie, the taller of the two held a white parasol over the other, also well appointed in an aqua-and-white-striped shirt, linen drawstring pants and Gucci sandals. The man in the designer footwear would need no introduction. By that time, Sean Combs, better known as P. Diddy, had already become an international superstar. The umbrella-holder, on the other hand, was a mystery -- that is, until photos of the scene made their way back to the United States.

title: The Honesty Virus
description: Everyone tells a little white lie now and then. But a Cornell professor recently claimed to have established the truth of a curious proposition: We fib less frequently when we're online than when we're talking in person. Jeffrey Hancock asked 30 of his undergraduates to record all of their communications -- and all of their lies -- over the course of a week. When he tallied the results, he found that the students had mishandled the truth in about one-quarter of all face-to-face conversations, and in a whopping 37 percent of phone calls. But when they went into cyberspace, they turned into Boy Scouts: only 1 in 5 instant-messaging chats contained a lie, and barely 14 percent of e-mail messages were dishonest.

title: Editorial Observer; Justice Rehnquist Writes on Hayes vs. Tilden, With His Mind on Bush v. Gore
description: The presidential elections of 1876 and 2000 have the sort of eerie parallels that make amateur historians' pulses race. Both ended in a deadlock, with Florida holding the key. Each time, Florida officials who were partisan Republicans gave the state's electoral votes to the Republican candidate, and Democrats challenged the result. Both challenges were decided by a single vote, cast by a Republican Supreme Court justice, in favor of the Republicans.

title: A One-Woman Show Learns to Share
description: FOR anyone who has seen Lisa Kron's work, it may come as a shock to find that her new play features a performer who is not named Lisa Kron. Acclaimed for her autobiographical one-woman shows, the 42-year-old writer-comic-actor has always kept other characters at bay, preferring to report on their doings like a correspondent just back from the war zone of her own life. Sometimes almost literally: in her Obie-Award-winning ''2.5-Minute Ride,'' about a trip she took with her father to the concentration camp in which his parents were murdered, her father never even appears, and the slides purporting to document their journey are completely blank. Life as we experience it, that play seemed to demonstrate, is not a documentary: all we have is our own point of view and our own story.

A loving father and husband, a trusted advisor to many, a great sportsman and philanthropist, he had strength and good humor to the end and will be missed by all who knew him. Born June 8, 1928, the son of F. Skiddy von Stade and Kathryne Steele von Stade, he grew up with his seven brothers and sisters in Old Westbury, NY and Aiken, SC. He graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, Amherst College and the University of Virginia Law School. While he practiced law at the outset of his career, he soon moved to Scudder, Stevens & Clark--an investment advisory firm, where he spent almost 40 years as a Partner and Managing Director. He served on the boards of the Saratoga Museum of Racing, Greenvale School and Piping Rock Club. For the last 10 years he served as President and then Chairman of the Board of the Shelburne Museum in Shelburne, Vermont. Under his leadership this remarkable institution made many outstanding changes that enhanced its reputation, its collections and its financial strength. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Marjorie Mueller von Stade, five children: Philip (Jr.) and MaryAnne von Stade, Robert and Elizabeth (Munson) von Stade, Richard and Kimberly von Stade, Kathryne and Brett Lewis, F. Skiddy (III) and Elizabeth von Stade; and nine grandchildren, the most recent having been joyfully introduced to him only a short time before his death. He is also survived by four siblings -- Frederick, John, Kathryne Krumpe and Nannie Ward. Friends may attend a memorial service Friday, April 30 at 11am in St. John's of Lattingtown with the Rev. Foster officiating. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family ask that gifts be made to the Shelburne Museum, P.O. Box 10, Shelburne, Vermont 05482

title: O.K., So It's Not His Funniest Film
description: ''JERSEY GIRL,'' starring Ben Affleck, Jennifer Lopez, Liv Tyler and George Carlin, is a curveball from the writer-director Kevin Smith. Mr. Smith's previous features, including ''Clerks'' (1994), ''Chasing Amy'' (1997) and ''Dogma'' (1999), relied on rapid-fire obscenities and chatter about pop minutiae and on Mr. Smith's turns as the recurring character Silent Bob. ''Jersey Girl,'' by comparison, is a PG-13 film with a Hallmark Channel plot: a high-powered Manhattan music publicist abandons the city, and his career, to raise his daughter after his wife dies in the delivery room. In this case, Mr. Smith has shed the anti-establishment vibe of his earlier movies for what he calls the clichs of mainstream filmmaking. Earlier this month, he spoke with Bryan Curtis, the film editor at Slate.com, about his career path, his fans, and fellow Roman Catholic Mel Gibson. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

title: True West
description: One reason, possibly the major reason, that the Hollywood western never dies is that it offers such a tempting target for artists eager to make their names by propping it back up and shooting it full of holes. Like the serious novel and the Broadway musical, the western exists, it seems sometimes, only so that it can be neglected and revived in a perennial, ritualistic cycle that's meant to create the sensation of cultural progress. But whatever the form supposedly used to be -- a historically simplistic melodrama brimming with offensive stereotypes, cardboard conflicts and wooden heroes and villains -- it hasn't been that way in a very long time. From John Ford's ''Searchers'' to Sam Peckinpah's ''Wild Bunch'' to (forgive me, film historians) Kevin Costner's ''Dances With Wolves,'' the western has been dismantled and demythologized almost since its beginning. The form lives on by being reborn to die.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RESTOUT, DENISE THERESA
description: RESTOUT--Denise Theresa. 88, of 63 Millerton Rd, died Tuesday, at the St. Francis Medical Center in Hartford, CT. She was born November 24, 1915, in Paris, France, daughter of the late Fernand and Julitte (Frangois) Restout. Miss Restout has been a resident of the United States since 1941. She arrived in America December 7, 1941, through Ellis Island, accompanied by her mentor Wanda Landowska, and became a naturalized citizen in 1961. She received a Certificate of Primary Studies with honors from the public schools in Paris, and then had five years of private tutoring. She studied drawing, geometry, history of arts, and painting at the Bazot Studios in Paris, and was admitted to the school of Applied Arts of the City of Paris in 1928. Miss Restout also received the Frist Medal of the National Conservatory of Music (Paris) in 1930, and studied piano, harmony, counterpoint, musicology, voice and organ with expert teachers, and harpsicord, along with keyboard repertoire of the 15th and 18th centuries, with the noted Wanda Landowska, beginning in 1933. As a performer, Miss Restout gave numerous appearances as a harpsicord soloist at the Landowska's Public Master Classes in France and the Netherlands; recitals in Paris, Strausbourg, and elsewhere. From 1935 to 1959 she was Landowska's only assistant. She also taught piano and harpsicord at the Brooklyn School of Music for two years and at the Barlow School in Amenia, NY, for five years. Miss Restout was a member at large of the faculties of Peabody Institute, Hartt College of Music, Southern University of Mississippi, Purchase College, and others. She lectured in Connecticut and New York between 1960 and 1969. She and Madame Landowska recorded a Bach Concerto together. She was a member of the French and American Musicological Societies, American Federation of Musicians, American Guild of Organists, and the 1961 and 1981 Juries of the Johann Sebastian Bach International Competitions (of which she is an honory patron). She served St. Mary's Church as the secretary of the parish council, a religious instructor, and organist. She was honored with the ''Amicus Poloniae'' Citation. A Mass of Christian Burial was offered on Saturday, March 13, 2004, at St. Mary's Church, Lakeville, CT. Bishop Peter A. Rosazza was the principal celebrant. There are no calling hours. Burial will be in St. Mary's Cemetery in the spring. Memorial donations may be sent to Father Forte Scholarship Fund, in care of Church of St. Mary, 76 Sharon Rd, Lakeville, CT 06039. For information contact Newkirk-Palmer Funeral Home, 118 Main St, North Canann, CT 06018.

The first workday of the season, traditionally the first weekend in April, was still weeks away. Karen Stead Baigrie, who is one of the garden's general administrators, surveyed the barren plots.

title: From Gauls to Ducasse, French Made Easy
description: IN the beginning, the French created food. The neighborhood bistro, the brasserie, the literary cafe and the three-star restaurant quite naturally followed. That's more or less how I might have summarized the development of French cuisine before I attended classes in la gastronomie Franaise at a language school in Paris last summer.

title: David Auburn's Burden Of 'Proof'
description: YOUNG playwrights dream of having a runaway success like ''Proof.'' David Auburn's drama ran for 917 performances at the Walter Kerr Theater before closing on Jan. 5, 2003, making it the longest-running Broadway play in two decades. ''Proof,'' which originally opened Off Broadway in 2000 at the Manhattan Theater Club and then transferred to Broadway, won the the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize. It has been performed from Iceland to the Philippines in more than 30 languages, according to Mr. Auburn's agent, William Craver. The Goodman Theater in Chicago is staging an African-American production beginning Saturday. The film version, which Miramax will release in December, stars Gwyneth Paltrow as Catherine, the unstable daughter of a renowned mentally ill University of Chicago mathematician.

title: My Name Is Bill
description: The evening before Thanksgiving on November 25, 1895, Mrs. Emily Griffith Wilson, twenty-five years old, very confused and very pregnant, might have been found in the Wilson House hotel kitchen as the afternoon cold settled in outside and the steam formed on the windowpanes. She was preparing to bake an apple pie, cutting the apples and then rolling out the crust, and keeping an eye on the popcorn just warming up in a cast-iron pan over the woodstove. The big north-facing room where she worked smelled of cooking: of flour and the sweetness of apples, of a batch of sugar cookies and the sausage frying for the stuffing. Usually, she found these smells delicious, but this afternoon they were nauseating. Pregnancy ruined everything, she thought.

title: Wake-Up Call
description: My grandmother, born and raised in Maine, always referred to a cast-iron skillet as a ''spider.'' Perhaps spider cake is named for its cooking utensil, in the tradition of pancakes and pot roast.

title: Behind Many Enticing Hedge Funds, Stale Prices
description: STALE prices, which have been a problem for mutual funds, afflict hedge funds as well. A group of researchers has concluded that these out-of-date prices have made many hedge funds appear to be better performers than they really are.

title: A Tucked-In Paradise

True fans resorted to buying pieces on eBay at four times the usual price. Now those stripes are back in the form of tank tops, T-shirts, skirts and more dresses. The collection is at Intermix stores in New York and Fred Segal in Los Angeles, from $65 to $160. But act with dispatch: there is already a waiting list for a green tank dress, and the new patterns will again be discontinued come fall.

I would never buy a new fur, but is it wrong to wear an old one I didn't pay for, as a parody of fashion-conscious women who do? (Does parody count if I'm the only one who knows it's parody?) If it's wrong to wear the furs, what should I do with them? Hattie Fletcher, Pittsburgh

title: Madrid Struggles To Get Back to Normal
description: After three days of official mourning -- marked by enormous displays of public support in the streets and squares of virtually all Spanish cities -- for the victims of the terrorist bombings on March 11 on one of the city's commuter rail lines, Madrid is struggling to return to normal. Visitors to the Spanish capital will find that rail services have been restored to their regular schedules, though ridership has been down and those who do board the trains -- especially the Cercanas commuter line No.2, along which the attacks took place -- do so in a mood of sadness and defiance. In the days following the attack, the destroyed train cars remained in some of the stations as the investigations continued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FISHER, GRACE S.
description: FISHER--Grace S. Passed away on March 20, 2004, at the age of 57, after a brave struggle with pancreatic cancer. She was the loving daughter of the late Dr. Morris and Myrtle M. Fisher, the adored sister of Estelle Comay, and Susan, Frank, and Gordon Fisher, and their spouses, Dr. Bruce Rabin, Gary Schieneman, Lynn Fisher, Wesley Scott, and the late Sholom Comay. She was cherished by her brother-inlaw Joe Wasch and his wife Laurie, and sisters-in-law Barbara and Michelle Wasch. She doted on her nieces and nephews, Laura, Arthur, Reid, Joe, Todd, Samantha, Elyse, Adam and Hillary, as well as her grandnieces Morgan and Madeline, and her grandnephew Andy. She made her husband, Monte Wasch, happy and proud of her accomplishments for 34 wonderful years. She was loved and admired by her many cousins, as well as colleagues and friends. Her honesty and integrity, sense of humor, and passion for justice and common decency made her a role model for everyone who knew her. A gift to WAMC/Northeast Public Radio, PO Box 66600, Albany, NY 12206 (or at www.wamc. org) in her memory will help to keep her spirit alive. Services Monday, 9:45 am, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam. Burial at Beth Shalom Cemetery, Pittsburgh, PA, on Tuesday.

title: Springtime for John Kerry
description: These days, everybody knows that a presidential campaign has to have a rapid-response machine. Rising above opposition attacks is so . . . Dukakis. And everybody also agrees that you have to start hitting hard early. In 1996, President Bill Clinton caught the Republicans off guard by saturating swing states with aggressive TV ads long before Bob Dole was ready to make a move. The next generation of political consultants learned a lesson, and now, viewers with the bad luck to live in swing states are being barraged with both attacks and counterattacks while the snow is still falling. There's something deeply disconcerting about greeting the first day of spring with a presidential race already in full bloom.

title: The Pull of Family
description: Illustrating James Traub's essay (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 29), which offers an effective case against legacy in college admissions, was a 1959 photo of a father and son outside Michigan State University's Spartan Stadium, waving Michigan State pennants. This photo would be the perfect art supporting the article if M.S.U. had a policy of legacy admits. But we never have had such a policy. As the nation's pioneering land-grant college, we take a holistic approach to admissions, based on consideration of broadly defined merit, earned not inherited. Spartan pride is handed down generation to generation, but admission always is earned on one's own.

title: European Leaders Seek to Separate Iraq and Terror Issues

title: Small Victories in Afghanistan
description: The Taliban may be out of power, but the plight of Afghanistan's women goes on. There are trappings of new freedoms -- foremost among them a constitution that recognizes women's rights -- but in much of the countryside women and girls are still treated like chattel. As Carlotta Gall of The Times has described vividly, many young women find their lives so unbearable that they set themselves on fire to escape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HADLEY, DR. JANE B.
description: HADLEY--Dr. Jane B., died on March 18, 2004 at 74 years after a courageous battle with cancer. Jane was born in New York City, graduated from Music and Art High School in 1945, and from the University of Virginia in 1949 on a full scholarship, Junior Phi Beta Kappa and Summa Cum Laude. She also modeled, becoming Miss Chesterfield in the early 1950's. When her marriage began dissolving in the 1960's she entered Columbia Graduate School in psychology and did her analytical training at the Metropolitan Center for Mental Health. She interned at Queens College and went on to became a noted psychotherapist in Manhattan. In 1979, she married Arthur T. Hadley, who survives her. She is also survived by two daughters, Elisabeth Wheeler of Stockbridge, MA and Caroline Thies of Boston, along with four grandchildren, Alexandra, Angus, Benjamin and Austin. She was on the boards of Planned Parenthood of New York and the American Liver Foundation, Greater New York Chapter. She was a member of The Cosmopolitan Club and The Century. A memorial service will be held for her at The Century on Friday, April 2nd at 3:00 P.M.
