description: For the Howard family of Atlanta, this is destiny, an inevitability since the day Dwight Howard was born less than seven months into his mother's pregnancy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Underground Fire Disrupts Neighborhood
description: An underground fire blew off four manhole covers in the Morris Heights neighborhood yesterday morning before spreading to three adjacent service boxes, said Joe Petta, a Consolidated Edison spokesman. The cause of the fire, which spread to service boxes on University Avenue between West Tremont Avenue and 176th Street, was not immediately known, Mr. Petta said, but there were no reported power failures or injuries. A section of University Avenue was closed until 3 p.m. after fire officials found elevated levels of carbon monoxide. Officials detected 200 parts per million in a building at 117 West 176 Street, which was immediately ventilated, he said. Carbon monoxide levels of 100 parts per million can sicken people and cause flulike symptoms. Ian Urbina (NYT)

title: CALENDAR
description: Learning Table Manners

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARVEY, DR. GLENDA J.
description: GARVEY--Dr. Glenda J. Died on Monday, March 22. Esteemed and beloved Professor of Medicine at Columbia University for nearly three decades. Survived by her brother Dr. Thomas Q. Garvey III, sister-in-law Dr. Carol Garvey, and nephew Dr. Thomas Q. Garvey IV. Funeral Mass Friday at 11 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave at 83rd. Memorial contributions should be sent to Glenda Garvey Academy of Medical Education, C/O Dean's Office, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, 630 West 168th St., New York, NY 10032.

title: Silver Offers Antiterror Plan As Feud With Pataki Grows
description: A week ago, Gov. George E. Pataki and a chorus of Republican leaders accused the Democratic State Assembly of endangering the welfare of all New Yorkers by failing to act on a set of antiterrorism laws they have been pushing for two years.

title: The Murdoch Empire Looks to Italian TV
description: Pay television has always been a losing proposition in Italy, where no company has ever turned a profit at it. Rupert Murdoch is out to change that with Sky Italia.

title: Editorial Observer; Taking Broadband Internet Access to the Last 'Last Mile': to Rural America
description: When tech people talk about providing residential users with new phone and Internet services, they talk about the challenges of wiring that ''last mile'' separating your home from the main network. But beyond those last miles now being wired in cities and suburbs, there are still miles and miles of rural America to go. I know. I live there.

title: Union Leaders Allege Fudging Of Statistics On City Crime
description: The presidents of the main police union and the sergeants union said yesterday that political pressure to keep the crime rate down was leading some precinct commanders to fudge their numbers. They contend that there were more rapes, robberies and other felonies in the city than have been made public.

title: 11 Iraqi Police Officers Are Killed by Gunmen
description: In the latest attacks against Iraqi police officers, gunmen on Tuesday killed nine officers riding in a minibus in southern Iraq and two officers parking a car in northern Iraq.

title: Recipe: Flourless Chocolate Cake With Halvah Honey Sauce
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Bush and Clinton Aides Grilled by Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Members of the commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks said on Tuesday that a series of intelligence reports sent to President Bush in 2001 warned of an imminent, possibly catastrophic attack by Al Qaeda. The disclosure prompted harsh questioning of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other administration officials about why they had not done more to pre-empt a possible terrorist strike.

title: Supreme Court Hears Arguments on Under God in Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Michael A. Newdow stood before the justices of the Supreme Court today, pointed to one of the courtroom's two American flags, and declared: "I am an atheist. I don't believe in God." With passion and precision, he then proceeded to argue his own case for why the daily recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in his daughter's public school classroom violates the Constitution as long as the pledge contains the words "under God."

title: Teenager Is Critically Injured In Attack With Baseball Bat
description: A teenager was in critical condition after two men beat him with a baseball bat in his Bronx apartment yesterday, the police and a neighbor said.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: DISPUTE OVER OUSTER OF TEACHERS Facing a $40 million deficit in the district's $1.3 billion budget, Houston school administrators said 65 teachers would be laid off when the school year ends in May. The teachers' union said the action violated a district policy requiring teacher layoffs to be approved by the school board and vowed to appeal the decision. A district spokesman called its action routine. The district has also dismissed more than 120 administrative and clerical workers. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about economists who would welcome an increase in the yen's value against the dollar to spur American exports, misidentified the organization directed by C. Fred Bergsten, a longtime advocate of a cheaper dollar as the best approach to leveling global trade imbalances. It is the Institute for International Economics, not the Institute for International Finance.

description: Correction Appended

title: John Gregory Dunne Eulogized at Cathedral
description: In a service that joined literature, liturgy and laughter, the author John Gregory Dunne was memorialized yesterday at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine as a fiercely devoted husband, father and friend and a man indelibly marked by his Irish lineage, Roman Catholic religion and family history of premature death.

title: Taiwan Leader's Agreement on Recount Seen as Shrewd Politics
description: A surprise agreement by President Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday to a recount of votes in the disputed election last Saturday is a shrewd move that has put the opposition Nationalist Party in a difficult position, politicians and political analysts said.

title: Rangers Drop Seventh in a Row
description: The crowd at Madison Square Garden cheered sarcastically for each of the 12 saves by Rangers goaltender Jamie McLennan during last night's 5-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: The President, the Insider and 9/11
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Says Discharges Continue Under 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
description: In the decade since President Bill Clinton and Congress adopted a policy allowing gay men and women to serve in the armed forces as long as they kept their sexual orientation to themselves, about 10,000 service members have been discharged on the ground of failing to do so, according to a report by the Servicemembers Legal Defense Network. The study says such discharges are continuing at a rate of one or two a day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIN, LEONARD
description: LEWIN--Leonard. Age 87, of New York, died Monday in Tampa, FL. New York Post sports writer since 1963. Inducted into the NBA Hall of Fame as Gowdy Award recipient. Survived by wife of 62 years, Phoebe, son, John Ira Lewin, two grandsons, Jamie and Lee, great-grandson, Jake. Funeral today, Wednesday, 11:45 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St, NY. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ.

title: Conclusions Of 2 Reports
description: Following are excerpts from the conclusions of reports issued yesterday by the National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States on efforts to counter the danger posed by Al Qaeda and the role of military force in combating terrorism before Sept. 11, 2001. The full reports are on the Web at nytimes.com/washington.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Alcatel To Build Iran's First Broadband Network
description: Alcatel, the French telecommunications company, said yesterday that it had signed a deal to build Iran's first private high-speed Internet network. Alcatel, in partnership with the private Iranian company Asre Danesh Afzar, plans to install 100,000 broadband DSL lines over the next three years, with 23,000 by May. A January report by the Geneva-based International Telecommunication Union showed Internet usage in Iran had grown 1,167 percent since 2000, the fastest rate in the Middle East. Borzou Daragahi (NYT)

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: RUSSIA: NUCLEAR FLAGSHIP ORDERED TO PORT The Navy recalled to port the flagship of its Northern Fleet, the nuclear-powered cruiser Peter the Great. Adm. Vladimir I. Kuroyedov, the chief of the Navy, warned in remarks reported by Interfax that the ship was in such a state of disrepair that "it may blow up at any moment." Within hours, he clarified his remarks, saying that neither the ship nor its reactor was in danger of exploding. The ship, he said, would remain in port for at least two weeks for repairs and retraining of its crew. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Putnam Faces Big Penalties For Improper Fund Trades
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 'Lotto Lout' Sentenced To Drug Treatment
description: A 20-year-old man who won an $18 million lottery jackpot but was later convicted of possessing cocaine, marijuana and psychedelic mushrooms was ordered to undergo counselling and drug testing. The man, Michael Carroll, who was dubbed the ''Lotto Lout'' by the British tabloids when he showed up to collect his winnings wearing a court-issued electronic tag, has a long history of convictions for low-grade offenses, including drunk and disorderly behavior, falsely claiming unemployment benefits and failing to pay for train tickets. His lawyer attributed Mr. Carroll's drug use to the stress of winning the National Lottery in November 2002 and the subsequent breakdown of his marriage, and promised that Mr. Carroll would change his ways. As he left court, Mr. Carroll gestured obscenely at the waiting reporters. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Kohlberg Kravis Sets $5.9 Billion Payout
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company is returning about $5.9 billion to investors after more than tripling their money from holdings in companies including the insurance broker Willis Group Holdings of London.

title: Drug Company With No Products Raises $250 Million
description: Jazz Pharmaceuticals, a year-old company with no products on the market, said yesterday that it had raised $250 million from private investors, apparently a record amount for a second round of venture capital financing in biotechnology.

title: Bush Campaign Gets Backing of a Democrat
description: President Bush's campaign showcased its favorite Democrat this afternoon, turning Senator Zell Miller of Georgia loose on Democrats in general and Senator John Kerry in particular.

title: Sports of The Times; Don't Put Blame on Greece Alone For This Latest Olympic Confusion
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDLER, LYNN
description: SEIDLER--Lynn. The Board and staff of The Shubert Foundation are deeply saddened by the loss of Lynn Seidler, our longtime Executive Director. Her exceptional vision and dedication were instrumental in the development of The Foundation as a leading supporter of not-forprofit theatre and dance companies in America. Lynn was also the motivating force behind the establishment of The Shubert Archive, which has become one of the foremost theatre research institutions in the country. She will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathy to our dear friend and Board member, Lee, daughter, Laurie, and grandson, Isaac. Gerald Schoenfeld, Chairman Michael I. Sovern, President Vicki Reiss, Exec. Director The Shubert Foundation

description: The Navy recalled to port the flagship of its Northern Fleet, the nuclear-powered cruiser Peter the Great. Adm. Vladimir I. Kuroyedov, the chief of the Navy, warned in remarks reported by Interfax that the ship was in such a state of disrepair that ''it may blow up at any moment.'' Within hours, he clarified his remarks, saying that neither the ship nor its reactor was in danger of exploding. The ship, he said, would remain in port for at least two weeks for repairs and retraining of its crew. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: 'Go-to Guy' Sheds Bureaucrat's Anonymity
description: With a parade of cabinet secretaries, the Tuesday meeting of the commission that is investigating the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks hardly lacked star power. But the real star of the show was not even in the room -- Richard A. Clarke, the Bush and Clinton administrations' former counterterrorism chief.

title: Decision Said to Favor YES
description: The YES Network must be carried on Cablevision's expanded basic tier for six years, an arbitration panel decided unanimously yesterday, executives informed of the ruling said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Police Find No Terror Link And Free 3
description: The police said three Pakistanis and a Ukrainian arrested over the weekend were not terrorists but people seeking asylum. Investigators were concerned about the four men in part because of a map found at their home that appeared to mark off several sensitive sites in Warsaw. Yesterday, the police said the markings on the map were actually places connected to gaining residents' permits. Three of the four men have already been released. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: For Halvah, Use  1/2 Cup Nostalgia
description: SMALL sand-colored blocks of halvah may be a familiar sight on the counters of delis and Middle Eastern markets all over New York City, but not even diehard fans would call it candy with cachet. Falling into the same category as pastel strips of sugar buttons and sticky jelly rings -- things your grandparents ate as children -- halvah is as much about nostalgia as it is about dessert.

title: Trying to Squeeze More Oil and Gas From the Gulf of Mexico
description: With energy prices climbing to their highest level in more than a decade, amid OPEC threats to cut oil production and concern about soaring demand for natural gas, federal officials and energy companies are making the Gulf of Mexico the focus of a renewed push to increase domestic production.

title: Overprescribing Prompted Warning on Antidepressants
description: The government's warning on Monday that people newly taking antidepressants can become suicidal and must be closely monitored grew at least in part from a concern that the drugs were being handed out too freely and without enough follow-up, especially in children and teenagers.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: When ''Chef's Theater,'' a cooking demonstration and dinner in a cabaret setting, opens on Tuesday at the Supper Club, 240 West 47th Street, TODD ENGLISH , the chef and an owner of Olive's, will show how to prepare a Mediterranean seafood chowder, filet mignon with wild mushrooms and a chocolate pudding cake. But behind the scenes, preparing that meal for the audience to eat later, will be RAD MATMATI , above, a chef who was previously at American Park at the Battery, now closed. A dozen or so guest chefs will take part in six performances each, and Mr. Matmati will cook for all of them. Dinners, Tuesday through Sunday, start at 7 p.m. and are $115 to $125: (212) 239-6200. There will be brunches on Saturday and Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, DR. MYRON
description: GOLDBERG--Dr. Myron. Beloved husband of Lourdes. Loving son of Marcus and the late Rose. Dear brother of Lois and Elyse. Adored uncle of David and Cheryl. Service Friday, March 26 at 12 noon at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Metro Briefing: New York
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLACHTER, DIANE
description: SCHLACHTER -- Diane on March 23, 2004. Adored wife of Leonard. Loving mother of Jordan and Heather. Dear sister of Barbara. Beloved sister-in-law of Marvin and Trudy Schlachter. Cherished aunt of Brad, Scott, Sandra, Kristofer. Services Thursday 10:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Justices Hear Arguments About H.M.O. Malpractice Lawsuits
description: With the debate over patients' rights stalled in Congress, the issue moved to the Supreme Court on Tuesday in an argument about whether patients can invoke state law to sue managed-care companies for medical malpractice when treatment recommended by their doctor is withheld.

title: IRISH COMPANY TO BUY 2 U.S. BEVERAGE BUSINESSES
description: The Kerry Group, an Irish food maker, agreed to buy Oregon Chai and Extreme Foods for a total of $96 million to help expand its coffee flavoring and beverage business in the United States. Oregon Chai, based in Portland, Ore., is the largest branded supplier of chai tea lattes and latte mixes, concentrates and ready-to-drink products in the United States, Kerry said in a Regulatory News Service statement. Extreme Foods, based in Las Vegas, makes and markets flavored ice-blended beverages for coffeehouses in the United States. Kerry, which is based in Tralee, is transforming itself from a dairy cooperative to a maker of ingredients and flavorings for food and drinks.

title: The Newest Sound in Music City
description: Six months after Vanderbilt said goodbye to its athletic department, the university said goodbye to its basketball team yesterday in Nashville.

title: Proposal to Limit Oil and Coal Projects Draws Fire
description: African mining companies, governments of developing countries and international banks have expressed concern over a proposal that the World Bank restrict oil and coal projects to protect the environment.

title: Public Testimony Before 9/11 Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 - Following is the the transcript of public testimony from four high-ranking officials from the Bush and Clinton administrations before the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks, as recorded by Federal News Service.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 'Sister Beating' Remark Draws Fire
description: President Thabo Mbeki drew bitter criticism from opposition politicians after he said at a campaign rally that he would beat his sister should she fall in love with the leader of the rival African Christian Democratic Party. Aides said the remark, at a rally for the ruling African National Congress, was made in a lighthearted vein. But the No. 2 party, the Democratic Alliance, said Mr. Mbeki's statement, on the nation's Human Rights Day, was a low point in his tenure. A spokesman for the Christian Democrats said the remark was evidence that Mr. Mbeki was becoming desperate in advance of elections next month. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: NPR News Is Replacing Morning Host
description: Morning radio will soon lose one of its most familiar news anchors. Bob Edwards, who for nearly 25 years has greeted millions of weekday listeners with the distinctive and richly toned opener ''This is 'Morning Edition' from NPR News,'' is being replaced as host of that flagship morning program.

title: Counterterrorism 101
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Comparing the Cameras
From Museum to Bedroom
description: An exhibition of quilts was a must-see last year at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Now Anthropologie is to sell copies.

title: Good Night, Boring Bedding
description: Beyond pale and pink in sheets and quilt covers.

title: Absenteeism Among Doctors
description: Rampant absenteeism among government doctors and nurses is an open secret across India and much of the developing world.

title: Israeli Soldiers Thwart Bombing
description: A Palestinian teenager stopped at a border checkpoint in the West Bank was wearing a gray vest packed with explosives under his sweater.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Firm Pleads Guilty In 2002 Explosion
description: A signmaking company pleaded guilty yesterday to reckless endangerment in connection with an explosion that injured more than 30 people, some critically, in April 2002, the Manhattan district attorney's office said. Investigators found that the explosion was caused by workers at Kaltech Industries Group, at 111-123 West 19th Street, who mixed volatile chemicals and that the company had failed to provide basic safety training to those workers. Kaltech will be required to provide and pay for chemical safety training courses for all employees of sign manufacturers in the metropolitan area who want to attend the courses. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Robert Kleiman, 85, An Editorial Writer And Correspondent
description: Robert Kleiman, a journalist specializing in foreign affairs and arms control and a former editorial writer for The New York Times, died Monday at his home in Washington. A former resident of Manhattan's Upper West Side, he was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOTCH, SALLY
description: SCOTCH--Sally of Astoria, Queens, at 91. Survived by husband George, children Arlene Wysong and Bill Schreiber, Carol Tweedy, Marty and Mary Alterman and grandchildren Justine Wysong, Jacob and Josh Alterman. First woman board member of the Board of Directors of the Astoria Center of Israel and President of its Ladies Guild. Loved by those touched by her passion for life and commitment to her community.

title: Assessing the Blame for 9/11
description: The seminal moment of this week's hearings on 9/11 surely came yesterday when Richard Clarke, the former antiterrorism chief in the Bush and Clinton administrations, opened his testimony by apologizing to the families whose loved ones died in the terror attacks. The government, Mr. Clarke said, had failed them, ''and I failed you.'' He added, ''We tried hard, but that doesn't matter because we failed.'' It suddenly seemed that after the billions of words uttered about that terrible day, Mr. Clarke had found the ones that still needed saying.

title: No Vote for Al Qaeda
description: There is nothing more important for the future of Western democracies than the question of whether, in the wake of the Madrid bombings, the new Spanish government will go ahead with its plan to withdraw Spanish forces from Iraq -- unless the U.N. assumes control of the occupation forces there by June 30. If Spain goes ahead, every terrorist in the world will celebrate, and every democracy will be a little more endangered. I so hope Spain's incoming prime minister, Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, reconsiders this decision.

title: This Queer Eye Takes Design to the Masses
description: HE'S rushing, perhaps because he's unaware that he's right on schedule -- like most people whose wrists are girded by watches costing in the five or six figures, he's way too busy to actually pause and consult the timepiece.

title: U.S. Loses Murder Case Over Lying Witnesses
description: A Brooklyn gang murder case is in disarray after a federal judge overturned the conviction of a Red Hook man for the killing, saying prosecutors had relied on ''blatant, critical perjury by all of the key witnesses.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NATHAN, MAXWELL P.
description: NATHAN--Maxwell P. on March 18, 2004 at age 69. Beloved husband of Mara. Loving father of Donald, Jennifer and Christina and grandfather of Jennifer, Maggie, Robert Allan and Jonathan. Step-father to Louis, Larry and Lee. Interment private. Memorial services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St, Thursday March 25th, 7pm.

title: All in the Family; Firewall, Filter and Virus Buster, Rolled Into One
description: McAFEE is not the only Internet security software maker that has branched out into spam filtering; the other major antivirus and firewall players have added spam to their hit lists as well. Buying an antispam program from the same company that makes your other security software has some benefits: a familiar user interface, and less potential for a software squabble between Company A's antivirus program and Company B's spam-filtering product.

title: JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR VIVENDI AND DILLER TO GO TO TRIAL
description: The lawsuit filed by Vivendi Universal to force Barry Diller to get out of the way of a planned deal with the General Electric Company's NBC unit will go to trial in a Delaware Court in May, after a ruling yesterday from the judge overseeing the case. The request on expedition made by Vivendi, which is based in Paris, said the suit must be resolved before Vivendi's United States unit can combine with NBC. ''I'm satisfied there's a need for expedition,'' Vice Chancellor Stephen Lamb said at the conclusion of a hearing on the question of how fast the Delaware Chancery Court should move on the case. The judge set a trial date of May 7, if the matter is to be tried in a single day. If the trial is to take two days, it will be May 6 and 7.

title: An Olympic Theme Park
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Good Cars, Bad Checks
description: Law enforcement officials say Betty A. Gooch, 75, spent the last four years swindling car dealers in the Chicago area by paying for vehicles with bad checks. Tony Kotlarz, an investigator for the McHenry County state's attorney, said Ms. Gooch, who used a cane and carried an oxygen tank, duped dealers into accepting checks in the ''$30,000 range'' for new vehicles, including a Mazda sports utility vehicle, a Toyota van and a Harley-Davidson motorcycle. She is charged with theft by deception and could face up to seven years in jail. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIDSON, GRACE M.
description: DAVIDSON--Grace M. Died on March 17 peacefully after a long illness. Widow of Sidney W. Davidson, Jr. and former resident of Bedford, NY, Milwaukee, WI, and Lyme, CT. She is survived by her children, Susan of Hanover, NH, Mary of Somers, NY, Sidney III (Tres) of Steamboat Springs, CO, Anne Hardy of Waccabuc, NY, Sarah O'Leary of Steamboat Springs, CO, by her sons-in-law, David Hardy and Sean O'Leary, and two grandchildren, Treat Hardy and Kaleigh O'Leary. Also survived by her two sisters, Margaret Young and Jane Mueller, both of Lancaster, PA; her three brothers, Stanley and David Moffat, both of Honolulu, HI, and Charles Moffat of Scranton, PA. Memorial service to be held May 22, 2004, 10am at the Presbyterian Church, Bedford, NY. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY, 12604 or Planned Parenthood, Hawthorne, NY. A mother and citizen of unfailing moral character and strong faith has passed from our midst after a full and gracious life.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on Page B1 yesterday about a Brooklyn man charged with having tried to hit police officers with a dropped bowling ball misstated the continuation page number in some copies and included a garbled passage. It continued on Page B2 in those copies and should have read: ''They call it airmail. Even so, a bowling ball is an unusual piece of correspondence, the police said.''

title: Packing Comfort Into a Pod
description: WHEN Andrea Burns and Peter Flynn were expecting their first child last year, they considered a two-bedroom Midtown apartment that a relative was giving up and looked in their Greenwich Village neighborhood, where they wanted to stay. Their choices seemed to come down to a fifth-floor walkup in a neighborhood they did not like (with no washing machine in the basement) or apartments for at least twice their rent of under $1,000 a month.

title: What Do I Want? It's Just One Word
description: Solo autobiographical shows are so popular now that it's easy to walk into one with a chip on your shoulder. If the performer is not well known, you think, ''O.K., prove your life deserves 90 minutes of my time.'' If the star is indeed famous, you're inclined to be cynical. It's all those People magazine features. Is this one more star who's going to court us with a display of just-folks vulnerability?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Arms-Control Group Says U.S. Inflated Libya's Nuclear Bid
description: Rekindling debate on how close Libya actually came to acquiring a nuclear bomb, a private arms-control group says the Bush administration overstated the number of devices the country had for making uranium fuel.

title: Putting Past Rivalry Aside, Kerry and Dean Rally Together
description: Today was unity day for the Democrats, so Howard Dean and John Kerry each managed to say nice things about one another at an outdoor rally on the campus of George Washington University . title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEALE, RICHARD LEWIS
description: NEALE--Richard Lewis. Of Chappaqua, NY, died Sunday, March 21, 2004, after a lengthy illness. Mr. Neale, 82, was the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Peter Charles Neale of Cleveland, OH. He was a graduate of Yale University, Class of 1943. He was married for 52 years to his beloved wife, Claudia Garesche, who predeceased him in l998. He was a founding associate publisher of Sports Illustrated. He was awarded the Hungarian Freedom Medal for arranging the resettlement of members of the Hungarian Olympic Team in the United States in 1954. His later career included senior positions with This Week and Parade magazines and the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. Mr. Neale served on the Chappaqua School Board, The Northern Westchester Hospital Board and the Chappaqua Historical Society Board. He served as Town of New Castle Historian from 1987 to the end of his life. He was locally recognized as ''the'' authority on Horace Greeley. Mr. Neale is survived by his children, Richard Garesche Neale, Peter Charles Neale, Patricia Van Clief, Claudia (Tootie) Brodlieb, Mary Corinne Zanoni, eight grandchildren and one great - granddaughter. For information about funeral arrangements and memorial contributions, please call the Beecher Funeral Home, 914-769-0001.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Micron Loss Narrows and Costs Fall
description: Micron Technology, the maker of computer memory chips, said yesterday that it had a narrower second-quarter loss as sales rose 26 percent and manufacturing expenses fell. The net loss narrowed to $28.3 million, or 4 cents a share, for the period that ended March 4 from a net loss of $619.2 million, or $1.02 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $991 million from $785 million, the company said in a filing. Micron, based in Boise, Idaho, has lowered production expenses by using new machines to build its chips and is benefiting from increased corporate spending on information-technology equipment that uses its products, analysts said. The cost of goods sold fell 26 percent from a year earlier, according to the company's statement. The loss per share beat analysts' estimates of a 7-cent loss, the average estimate of 21 analysts in a Thomson Financial survey. Shares of Micron fell 62 cents, to $15.19, in extended trading after the announcement. The stock fell 1 cent, to $15.81, in regular trading.

The tape had been shown to the grand jury that indicted Justice Garson and was later given to Mr. Fischetti and lawyers for Justice Garson's co-defendants. title: World Briefing | United Nations: Measure To Keep Arms From Terrorists
description: The United States and Britain introduced a Security Council resolution aimed at filling a gap in existing international law that they said did not bar nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, and the materials to make them, from falling into the hands of terrorists. ''There are lots of disarmament and nonproliferation agreements that bind states to certain standards of behavior,'' said John D. Negroponte, the United States ambassador, explaining that the measure would apply to ''nonstate actors'' -- groups and individuals not tied to states, a diplomatic characterization of terrorists. Emyr Jones Parry, Britain's ambassador, said the resolution was intended to prevent ''the ultimate nightmare -- the bringing together of weapons of mass destruction and the terrorists.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

His release came after Russia released two wrestlers from Qatar's Olympic team who had been detained at a Moscow airport. Their release, like their detention, came with little explanation, though it appeared to be a effort to exert pressure on Qatar. They were released after President Vladimir V. Putin spoke by telephone with Qatar's emir, Sheik Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani. Two Russian secret agents remain in custody, charged with organizing the killing of Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, a former president of Chechnya suspected of financing terrorist operations there. It competes for long-haul business with airlines like British Airways, Europe's biggest. ''There are encouraging signs that the market, particularly the all-important business travel sector, is returning to health,'' Sir Richard said in a statement. Alan Cowell (NYT)

The third in a line of five generations of Cornellians, Noyes made an indelible mark on the university's history. He was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1961 and served as chairman from 1978 until 1984, and in 1985 was named a Presidential Councillor. He also served as a member of the Board of Overseers of the Weill Cornell Medical College. Noyes was a remarkable leader who will be missed by the entire Cornell community. We express our sincere condolences to his wife, Dorothy (Dottie) O'Day Noyes; his sons, Michael O'Day Noyes and Jansen Noyes III '69; and his beloved grandchildren, Jansen Noyes IV, '04, Jennifer and Logan Brackett. title: National Briefing: South
description: FLORIDA: DEADLY CURRENTS Rip currents along the coast have caused at least four deaths in the last week, leading lifeguards to warn swimmers to stay out of the water. On Sunday, a rip current killed an 82-year-old woman who jumped in the water off Palm Beach to help a friend who had been knocked down by a wave. Also in Palm Beach, a Boston man who tried to save his two nieces was killed, as was another man who jumped in the water after two friends off Melbourne Beach. A 13-year-old boy disappeared Saturday in shallow water near Jacksonville and may have drowned. Rip currents are channels of water that can pull even strong swimmers into deep water. Since 1989, about 19 people have died each year as a result of rip currents in Florida, the National Weather Service said. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

Federal regulators granted the drug orphan status, which is given to medicines that treat rare diseases. The designation provides seven years of exclusive marketing rights unless another treatment is found to be safer or more effective.

description: A semiconductor maker, Siltronic, postponed its initial public offering planned for tomorrow because of adverse market conditions, the company said. The delay came only a week after X-Fab, another German semiconductor supplier, canceled its listing plans, blaming market reactions to the Madrid bombings. The shareholder's association SdK, however, contended that Siltronic's shares were overpriced and investors had become more cautious in view of heavy losses from most new listings since 1997. Wacker Chemie, Siltronic's parent company, aimed to raise 834 million to 1.09 billion euros ($1.02 billion to 1.33 billion) from the offering. Siltronic is based in Munich. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: State Pension Officials Accuse Safeway Leaders of Conflict
description: Fresh from a victory against Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, some state pension officials are taking aim at the leadership of Safeway, the supermarket chain.

description: Samuel Sadin, a lumber executive who became an advocate for the elderly, died Sunday at his home in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 86.

description: Q. When I click on Organize Favorites in Microsoft Internet Explorer for Windows, one of the options offered is ''Make available offline.'' What does this mean? Why would you want to use it?

title: Corrections

It is NodeDB.com, not Nodeb.com. The article also misstated the number of such locations in the United States listed by the service. It is about 1,100, not more than 11,000.

description: Four firefighters were suspended yesterday for a month without pay and face departmental charges arising from a New Year's Eve brawl at their Staten Island firehouse that a new report says was fueled by a pot of sangria, a case of beer and an argument over the date of Elvis's birthday.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Court Overturns Internet Ruling
description: A federal appeals court overturned a ruling that had ordered the Interior Department to shut down much of its Internet access because of security problems in a trust fund it administered for American Indians. Last week, a federal district judge in Washington, Royce C. Lamberth, ordered that the systems be disconnected to protect millions of dollars of oil, gas, timber and grazing royalties from Indian land. Judge Lamberth said he was not satisfied that the agency's computer system was safe from hackers. The agency contended that he did not have the authority to make such a ruling and that the order prohibited it from functioning properly. John Files (NYT)

description: ''Your government failed you. Those entrusted with protecting you failed you. And I failed you.''

title: ATHEIST PRESENTS CASE FOR TAKING GOD FROM PLEDGE
description: Michael A. Newdow stood before the justices of the Supreme Court on Wednesday, pointed to one of the courtroom's two American flags and declared: ''I am an atheist. I don't believe in God.''

title: Ex-adviser says Bush undermined war on terror
description: WASHINGTON:  In the gripping conclusion to an extraordinary two-day hearing on the 2001 terror attacks, a former counterterrorism adviser in the past two U.S. administrations said President George W. Bush had undermined the war on terror by starting a war with Iraq and giving the fight against terror a lower priority than assigned it by President Bill Clinton.

title: Legislator Says Tax Breaks Went to G.O.P. Donors
description: Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky charged today that the Pataki administration had let Monroe County officials overseeing a tax-free economic development zone revise its boundaries dozens of times to encompass vacant suburban buildings owned by developers who were big contributors to the county's Republican Party.

title: S.&P. Lifts Outlook on Japan On Signs of a Lasting Recovery
description: The ratings agency Standard & Poor's lifted its outlook on Japan on Wednesday, saying that growth prospects have improved for the country, the world's second-largest economy.

description: For eight months, there was so much else to do, the serious and the frivolous meshing into a scheduling tsunami that sent Serena Williams spinning far from the tennis universe.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: L.C.D. Joint Venture
description: Sanyo Electric and Seiko Epson agreed to merge their liquid crystal display businesses in a move aimed at trimming costs to better compete with larger rivals. The two will form a company by October to develop, produce and market the small displays used mostly in mobile phones and digital cameras. The new company, the Sanyo Epson Imaging Devices Corporation, is expected to have annual sales of about 360 billion yen and rank behind Samsung Electronics, LG.Philips and the Sharp Corporation in the global L.C.D. market. The companies say combining resources will help them compete in a market that has high development costs because of the rapid pace of product introductions. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHRISTIAN, DIANE COLLINGS
description: CHRISTIAN--Diane Collings. On March 23 at her home on Amelia Island, FL, following a lingering neurological illness. She was the loving wife of Dr. Charles L. Christian and adoring mother of Victoria, Jennifer and Matthew and grandmother of Maxmillian, Daphne, Luke and Maria. Mrs. Christian died a few months short of her 50th wedding anniversary; she was born 72 years ago in Conway, MA of immigrant English parents, lived most of her life in Englewood, NJ prior to moving to Amelia Island in 1995. A memorial service will be at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Fernandina Beach, FL, Saturday March 27 at 11AM; a later service (to be announced) will be at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, North Engle Street, Englewood, NJ 07631.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: 4 Bodies Found After Crash
description: The bodies of four men thought to have been among 10 people aboard a helicopter lost over the Gulf of Mexico were found yesterday about 100 miles from the Texas coast, the Coast Guard said. A life jacket bearing the name of the air charter company, Era Aviation, was also found. The helicopter left Galveston Tuesday for an oil drilling ship 130 miles east of South Padre Island and at the time of its last radio transmission was more than halfway toward the vessel. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: That Lyricist With a Brain, A Heart . . . and the Noive
description: The 92nd Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series has been a cultural fixture in New York City for so many years (34 to be exact) that its original concept of inviting legendary pre-rock songwriters to discuss their work became sadly obsolete as one by one the great craftsmen of an earlier era died. The death of Maurice Levine, its longtime artistic director, in 1997, left the series rudderless.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Criticizes Pledge Challenge
description: About two dozen City Council members, including the speaker, Gifford Miller, left, gathered on the steps of City Hall yesterday to call on the United States Supreme Court to allow the words ''under God'' to remain in the Pledge of Allegiance. The court is expected to rule by June on whether ''under God'' violates the First Amendment; a California atheist argued yesterday before the court that it does. Mr. Miller said the pledge recognized the nation's values and history, and maintained that ''it poses no risk to the separation of church and state.'' Councilman Simcha Felder of Brooklyn later recited the pledge during the Council's meeting, but then apologized after several members criticized him for being out of order. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Proving Time For St. Joseph's And Syracuse
description: One regional has played to form, the other has been tossed and tumbled. When the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament resumes Thursday night here and in Phoenix, the sites will be linked by two Eastern teams, St. Joseph's and Syracuse, that share a surprising connection: they have been underestimated.

title: Was an Official 'in the Loop'? It All Depends
description: It is a strange occurrence in Washington when members of the well-ordered Bush White House publicly disagree with each other, but it happened on Wednesday.

title: Senate Outlaws Injury to Fetus During a Crime
description: WASHINGTON, March 25 - The Senate approved legislation on Thursday making it a separate offense to harm the fetus in a federal crime committed against a pregnant woman, sending the measure to President Bush for his signature.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Guilty Plea In Prostitution Case
description: A former F.B.I. informant has pleaded guilty to promoting prostitution at a spa in Lodi that he owned, which was the center of an investigation into police corruption. The informant, Luke Hoffmann, 40, pleaded guilty Tuesday as part of a deal that called for one year of probation and his continued cooperation with the investigation. Prosecutors plan to dismiss money-laundering and conspiracy charges and return about 50 percent of the $480,000 seized from Mr. Hoffman after sentencing, on May 28. The investigation focused on charges that police officers and other law enforcement officials were linked to gambling and prostitution. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Bronx Officer Is Said to Steal Debit Card From Suspect
description: A Bronx police officer stole a debit card from a suspect while arresting him in October and used it to withdraw about $1,800 from cash machines over the next four days while the suspect was in custody, the police and prosecutors said yesterday.

title: To Save a Life or a Limb, Gently Shake a Minefield
description: MILLIONS of unexploded land mines lie beneath the dirt and sand of Afghanistan, Bosnia, Rwanda, Iraq and many other nations. If the mines are made of metal, detectors can usually find them. But when more sensitive detectors are used to locate plastic-based mines with little metal in them, they often fail to distinguish between mines and metal debris. As a result, for every actual mine found, there are thousands of false alarms.

title: Economic Scene; In their hiring of teachers, do the nation's public schools get what they pay for?
description: PUBLIC-SCHOOL teachers just aren't as smart as they used to be. After all, women have more job opportunities. Bright women who once would have taught school today become doctors and lawyers. The gain for individual women is a loss for education.

title: A Home for Modern In a Country Setting
description: Jonathan Gallin, a former photo stylist for New York retailers, moved to the Catskills three years ago with the idea of building houses ''in the style of Richard Neutra,'' he said. Instead he rented a former luncheonette, right, in a slumbering town called Rosendale, near New Paltz, N.Y., and transformed it into Mid-Century Modern (above). Mr. Gallin sells classics by Knoll, and vintage pieces, to urban refugees like the Sports Illustrated swimsuit model Chandra North. Reproductions of Architectural Pottery planters in white or celery glaze start at $125 and are perfect for the spot in front of the picture window. The store is at 404 Main Street, Rosendale; (845) 658-7500 or www.midcenturymodern.biz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTINSON, PAUL
description: MARTINSON--Paul. The partners, counsel, associates and staff at Phillips Nizer LLP deeply mourn the passing of our distinguished former partner and mentor. Together with Louis Nizer, he counseled business leaders, entertainment luminaries and government officials during his forty years with the firm. He will long be recognized for his brilliant work in the landmark case of John Henry Faulk vs. AWARE which served to defeat blacklisting in the 1950's. Countless attorneys credit him with teaching them the art of advocacy, and many institutions of music and art benefited from his sage advice. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved wife, Frances, and his family. Perry S. Galler, Chairman Executive Committee Phillips Nizer LLP

description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the hospital chain, said yesterday that it would pay the government $30.75 million to settle two investigations into its billing practices.

title: A Lightweight Notebook Gets More Miles to the Charge
description: Everything is relative: nine hours may seem ordinary for a workday, but when it comes to a laptop battery, nine hours is a wonder to behold. The Actius MM20 notebook computer from Sharp can run for three hours on its own battery power, but an optional high-capacity battery can triple the time it stays up and running.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Record Oil Profit
description: China's top oil and gas producer, the PetroChina Company, posted a 48 percent increase in profit for last year, helped by a sharp increase in the average selling price of crude oil. PetroChina said it earned 69.6 billion yuan for the year. ''The strong growth in China's economy and the jump in the oil price were our growth drivers in 2003,'' said PetroChina's president, Chen Geng. The company said all four of its divisions -- exploration and production, chemicals, refining, and natural gas and pipelines -- were profitable. PetroChina has not had profits simultaneously in all four divisions since it listed in April 2000.

''Well,'' he said, ''it's a chance to see some old friends.''

title: 100 Photos, Compressed In a Svelte E-Mail Album
description: Digital photography makes taking pictures an act of almost immediate gratification, but sharing more than a few images by e-mail remains a bothersome task for both senders and receivers. A new program from AvailaSoft, Photo2Album, means that digital photographers need no longer use slow-loading and confusing Web photo galleries to share shots over the Internet.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Robbery Suspect Shot In Store
description: A man was shot while attempting to rob a bodega in Queens last night, the police said. The man, who the police said was 26 but otherwise did not identify, was wearing a ski mask, when he entered the store, at 107-52 Van Wyck Expressway , about 8 p.m. He pointed the gun at someone, but the magazine fell out of the weapon, the police said. A store worker, 35, then pulled out his own gun and fired, striking the man in the head, according to the authorities. The suspect was arrested and taken to Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, the police said. His injury was not life threatening, they added. The worker did not have a permit for the gun, and he might face charges in the case, the police said. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page credit yesterday for a rendering of the proposed Jets stadium in Manhattan misspelled part of the architectural firm's name. It is Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, not Pederson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLOSS, EMANUEL M. (AMBY)
description: SCHLOSS--Emanuel M. (Amby). 91. Passed away on March 21 at his home in Palm Beach FL after a lengthy illness. He was born on November 22, 1911 in Washington DC to Gertrude and Leonard Schloss. He graduated from Syracuse University where he was an All American in baseball and soccer. He enjoyed a successful career in the jewelry and men's apparel industries for many years. He has lived in New York City and Palm Beach since retiring in 1990. He is survived by his wife of 29 years Suzanne, daughter and son-in-law Susan and Don Meredith, son and daughter-in-law Leonard and Jane Schloss, daughter Carole Kiernan and son James Lifton, granddaughter and her husband Kimberly and Todd Markin, grandsons Scott and Christopher Kiernan and granddaughter Isabelle Lifton. He is also survived by his sister Evelyn Eichberg. A private service is being held in New York.

title: Domestic Security Gets a Mixed Appraisal
description: One year after a vast reorganization of domestic security, the government has made important strides in defending the nation against another terrorist attack but still faces critical gaps that could take years to close, according to an internal review released on Wednesday.

title: From the Walls of Museums To a Bedroom Very Near You
description: An exhibition of quilts made by a group of African-American women in the small town of Gee's Bend, Ala., was a must-see last year at the Whitney Museum of American Art and continues as a traveling exhibition. Now copies of the quilts are to be sold at Anthropologie. The first reproduction, available in June, is of ''Medallion With Center Bars'' (above), made in 1943 by Polly Bennett, now 82. It will be queen-size and cost $298. The other two quilts shown will be available later in the year.

Bialos, who is dearly missed, father of Jeff Bialos & Ellen Fielding, & grandfather of Tyler, Tiffany & Tiara Fielding & Jeffrey Bialos. WW II veteran, salesman, small businessman. His spirit, love of life & family, and zest for politics will be deeply missed & remembered. Memorial Service March 28, George Wash. Manor, Roslyn. 516-938-2330 for info.

description: The City Council's Finance Committee agreed yesterday to delay for two years the collection of a $44 million property tax surcharge on absentee landlords, in return for the Bloomberg administration's agreement to restore millions of dollars in proposed budget cuts to city services and college programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   UNTERMEYER, SALLE PO DOS
description: UNTERMEYER -- Salle Po dos. Of New York City and Wainscott, N.Y. Passed away March 20, 2004. Beloved wife of Walter, devoted mother of Richard and Lisa, caring daughter of David and Rose, fond sister of Harriet, and cherished friend of many-she will be greatly missed. Graduate of Vassar College, M.A. from Brandeis University, J.D. from Columbia University, and Fellow of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation, she will be remembered for her many accomplishments in the fields of law, urban affairs, politics, and philanthropy, as well as her passion for culture and the arts, and her inimitable sense of style. May her energy and vivacity be her legacy to us all. Services on Friday, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to the Women's Campaign for UJA-Federation of New York or the Doctor Herbert Kleber Research Fund at Columbia University School of Medicine.

description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship continued yesterday at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., with 16 teams surviving.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Eyesore Meets The Wrecking Ball
description: To the strains of Tchaikovsky's ''1812'' Overture, British workers began demolishing a 1960's shopping center that Prince Charles had likened to a ''mildewed lump of elephant droppings.'' City authorities in Portsmouth decided earlier this month not to grant the Tricorn Center a protected status. When it was built in 1966, its developers called it ''an orchestration in reinforced concrete that is the equivalent of the '1812' Overture.'' But it was never a success and had stood derelict for the past 15 years. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EVANS, DR. JANE
description: EVANS--Dr. Jane. Born to the late James Harry Evans and Maybelle Holden Evans on October 31, 1907 passed away on March 24, 2004 after a year of illness. A woman of great intellect, integrity, and energy, who devoted herself to Jewish and philanthropic causes throughout her long and active life. Widely known as a distinguished national leader, a religious pacifist and an advocate for human rights and world peace. Dr. Evans was President of the Jewish Braille Institute, Executive Director of the National Federation of Temple Sisterhoods and a Life Honorary Officer of the World Union for Progressive Judaism. She was awarded an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters Degree from the Hebrew Union College Jewish Institute of Religion. A founder and former president of the Jewish Peace Fellowship, she was awarded the Abraham Joshua Heschel Award for peace work in the Jewish tradition. Named ''A Woman of Distinction in Religion'' by New York Governor Mario Cuomo as a result of her involvement in world affairs. An inventor, avid sports fan, boating enthusiast, art collector and animal lover. A cherished friend and revered colleague, Jane Evans will be deeply mourned. Funeral services will be held at Temple Israel of New Rochelle (1000 Pinebrook Boulevard, New Rochelle, New York) at 12:00 P.M. on Friday, March 26, 2004. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Jewish Braille Institute, Women of Reform Judaism, Jewish Peace Fellowship, or Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEIDLER, LYNN
description: SEIDLER--Lynn. The Board and staff of The Shubert Foundation are deeply saddened by the loss of Lynn Seidler, our longtime Executive Director. Her exceptional vision and dedication were instrumental in the development of The Foundation as a leading supporter of not-forprofit theatre and dance companies in America. Lynn was also the motivating force behind the establishment of The Shubert Archive, which has become one of the foremost theatre research institutions in the country. She will be greatly missed. Our deepest sympathy to our dear friend and Board member, Lee, daughter, Laurie, and grandson, Isaac. Gerald Schoenfeld, Chairman Michael I. Sovern, President Vicki Reiss, Exec. Director The Shubert Foundation

But instead of coal and billowing steam, the clattering looms do their work with nimble fingers, taut ropes, cast-iron flywheels and a harplike scrim of lustrous threads.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Deadly Currents
description: Rip currents along the coast have caused at least four deaths in the last week, leading lifeguards to warn swimmers to stay out of the water. On Sunday, a rip current killed an 82-year-old woman who jumped in the water off Palm Beach to help a friend who had been knocked down by a wave. Also in Palm Beach, a Boston man who tried to save his two nieces was killed, as was another man who jumped in the water after two friends off Melbourne Beach. A 13-year-old boy disappeared Saturday in shallow water near Jacksonville and may have drowned. Rip currents are channels of water that can pull even strong swimmers into deep water. Since 1989, about 19 people have died each year as a result of rip currents in Florida, the National Weather Service said. Terry Aguayo (NYT)

title: M.L.S. Drops Sudden-Death Overtime
description: Major League Soccer fell in line with the rest of the soccer world yesterday when it announced that it had dropped its 10-minute sudden-death overtime after having used it the past four seasons. FIFA, the sport's worldwide governing body, recently dropped its ''golden'' and ''silver'' goals to settle tie games and mandated that leagues around the world would have to conform to the overtime rule by July 1.

title: Corrections

title: Missed Chances In a Long Hunt For bin Laden

By early 1997, the office, known as the bin Laden station, had concluded that he was also a terrorist organizer, based in Afghanistan, with a military committee planning operations against American interests worldwide.

title: Microsoft faces risky future of regulation

The flowers, or more precisely the floral spadix sheathed by a cowled spathe, are as much a herald of spring as is daylight at 6 p.m.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANTANGELO, FRANCIS R.
description: SANTANGELO--Francis R. of Boynton Beach, Florida and Harrison, New York died of lung cancer on Monday, March 22, 2004 at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Florida. He was 71. Mr. Santangelo founded Santangelo and Company Specialist Firm on the American Stock Exchange until 1987. He continued to trade and was a consultant until his death. He was born in 1932 to the Honorable Robert V. and Juliette Santangelo. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1953 and later earned a law degree from St. John's University and his graduate degree from New York University. He served in the United States Marine Corps during the Korean War and earned the rank of First Lieutenant. He is survived by his wife Barbara Taccetta and four children, Toni Archibald, Robert Santangelo, Linda Santangelo and Dina Pfohl, eight grandchildren and brother Robert V. Santangelo, Jr. He will be remembered for his love of family, friends and great zest for life, along with his passion for thoroughbred racing, boating, fine art and his retreat on Hen Island. Family will receive friends on Friday, March 26, 2004 from 2-4PM and 7-9PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, New York. Funeral mass is 10AM on Saturday, March 27, 2004 at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. Interment will follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Lung Cancer Research Fund, C/O Dr. Mark Kris, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Bicycling Across Brazil, in Search of a Better Future

After the shot rang out, theater workers turned on the lights and called the police. Mr. Clark ''was bleeding a lot from his leg,'' another usher, Melissa Masse, said. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Global Chip Sales To Rise This Year
description: Global chip sales may surge as much as 30 percent this year on demand for semiconductors used in consumer electronics like camera-equipped cellphones and digital cameras, the technology market researcher Gartner said yesterday. Intel, the world's top chip maker in 2003, and Samsung Electronics of South Korea, the second biggest, benefited as chip sales rose 14 percent, to $177 billion last year. Sales will rise 20 percent to 30 percent this year, Gartner, based in Stamford, Conn., said in a news release. Gartner joins other industry researchers like IC Insights and IDC in forecasting a recovery in demand for chips as businesses and consumers replace their computers. Demand for so-called NAND flash memory, which are chips geared for consumer electronics like digital cameras and mobile phones, is also fueling industry growth, Gartner said. Image sensors, used in digital cameras and camera phones, and NAND flash memory, used to store pictures when gadgets are turned off, ''drove amazing growth'' last year, said Jeremey Donovan, vice president for Gartner Dataquest's worldwide semiconductor group. Shares of Intel rose 37 cents, to $26.53.

Standard & Poor's reduced the company's noninvestment grade rating to BB from BB+ two weeks ago and said that it might cut it again. Toys ''R'' Us, based in Wayne, N.J., had $2.35 billion in long-term debt at the end of January. Sales at stores open at least a year in America fell 5.1 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Railway Bomb Threats Suspended
description: A group or person calling itself A.Z.F. said it was suspending its threat to blow up railways in France. A.Z.F. has threatened since mid-December to detonate bombs on French railroad tracks if not paid more than $5 million by the government. On Wednesday, a bomb was found on the tracks southeast of Paris similar to one that A.Z.F. had directed the police to last month. But in letters addressed to President Jacques Chirac and his interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, A.Z.F. said it was suspending its activities to overcome ''technological, logistic and other weaknesses.'' Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Goodbye Nuns. Hello Hamptons.
description: THE view from the window at Sue Daniels's desk hadn't changed much in years. A big open field, a crooked dock and a turreted manor house with flaking paint and crumbling roofs dominated the scene. Some plastic play equipment added a little color, but otherwise the estate -- where Ms. Daniels runs a preschool in a second house -- looked as drab and dated as an abandoned gold mine.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Protest Against Bullfighting
description: Hundreds of animal rights supporters protested against bullfighting outside Barcelona City Hall, where they presented a petition with 245,000 signatures demanding that the centuries-old sport be banned. The deputy mayor, Jordi Portabella, who opposes bullfighting, said the City Council would consider a ban next month. Such a ban would make Barcelona the first major Spanish city to prohibit the sport. Dale Fuchs (NYT)

title: Kelly Reports a Sharp Decrease In Bank Robberies in the City
description: After a sharp increase in the number of bank robberies in New York City in the first half of last year, the number began to decrease because of improved security measures in the banks, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly told a gathering of state bankers yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Ex-Curator Accused Of Theft
description: A museum employee, already charged with stealing museum artifacts, has been indicted on charges that he stole a Wright Brothers artifact that was later sold at auction for more than $100,000. Earlier this year, the employee, Richard Kappeler, a former conservator of the Nassau County Museum, was charged with stealing more than 100 of the museum's artifacts. The Nassau County district attorney's office announced yesterday that Mr. Kappeler has also been indicted in the theft of a model airplane that replicated the Wright Brothers' airplane. Mr. Kappeler later sold the model at Christie's in London, to the owner of the New York Jets, Woody Johnson. Mr. Kappeler's lawyer, William Petrillo, said his client was not guilty because the model belonged to the Kappeler family for many years. Stacy Albin (NYT)

description: Apple Computer said yesterday that it had postponed the overseas introduction of the smaller version of its iPod music player from April to July, citing unexpectedly strong demand in the United States since the product's beginnings last month. ''The iPod mini is a huge hit with customers in the U.S., and we're sure it will be the same worldwide once we can ramp up our supply in the July quarter,'' said Timothy D. Cook, Apple's executive vice president for worldwide sales and operations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Airline Expects Profit
description: Lufthansa said it ex-pected a net profit this year after posting a loss of nearly 1 billion euros last year. The company said that its results began improving in the fourth quarter and that passenger traffic so far this year had increased. Last year's loss, 984 million euros ($1.2 billion), resulted largely from one-time write-downs, which included 705 million euros at its catering unit, LSH Sky Chefs. The chief executive, Wolfgang Mayrhuber, above, said the company would continue the restructuring of Sky Chefs. Operating profit, which excludes one-time items, fell to 36 million euros from 718 million euros. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: In Games' Birthplace, Flame Is Lighted and Relay Begins
description: From the ancient Greek grounds that gave birth to the Games, the Olympic flame sparked to life on Thursday, setting off on a global odyssey to be capped by its arrival in Athens in time for the Summer Games, which begin on Aug. 13.

title: 36 Hours | Quechee, Vt.
description: IN Vermont, spring usually means one thing: the end of ski season and the beginning of Mud Time, when the melting snow has turned the landscape, well, to mud. This might sound like the perfect time to flee the state, except that this is also the season when sap saturates the sugar maples, the latest batch of leaf-shaped candies stack up on store shelves, and towns like Quechee shift into high gear. Settled in the 1760's, Quechee (pronounced KWEE-chi) at one time produced white baby flannel and the fabric for the uniforms of both the Yankees and the Red Sox. That industry has long since left town, but Quechee (along with surrounding towns in Windsor County and across the Connecticut River in New Hampshire) has reinvented itself as a tourist destination, trading on its quintessential New England spirit. TINA KELLEY

title: World Briefing | Australia: Fishing Banned From A Third OF Great Barrier Reef
description: Australia will ban fishing on a third of the Great Barrier Reef, the Italy-size band of coral and fish along its northeast coast that has been degraded in recent decades by fishing pressure, runoff from farms and development and warming sea temperatures that harm corals. The new policy will take effect in July, expanding no-fishing zones from 4.5 percent of the reef to 33.3 percent. Owners of commercial fishing vessels in communities near the reef would be compensated for losses, although a formula for doing so has yet to be worked out, officials said. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

And why not -- in its 43 years in business Cabela's has built itself into the Sears catalog of the outdoors, its pages glutted with fishhooks, telescopic gun sights, handheld Global Positioning System receivers and powerboat covers. And the only thing better than poring through its main catalog's 530 pages is actually visiting Cabela's in person.

title: A Whiff of Prewar Paris: Feminine Forces in Fashion
description: The glamorous party that took Paris from the end of World War I to the beginning of World War II was arguably attended by some of the best-dressed, most wonderful-smelling people in history. Their sartorial needs were met by a cluster of talented, competitive couture designers, many of whom began to create and market their own perfumes in the early 1920's. Et voil: the beginning of the modern designer-driven, license-leveraged, luxury-goods industry so prevalent today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: High Court Rules In Lead Case
description: A child poisoned by lead may not sue New York City for slipshod inspections that contributed to the poisoning, the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, ruled yesterday. The court cited a long line of precedents stating that in general, local governments are not liable for their employees' negligent conduct. The 7-to-0 decision dismissed the case of Ashley Harris, a Brooklyn girl, and a similar case filed by another child against Putnam County. Both of them had very high levels of lead in their blood. A city inspector found a lead hazard from the paint in Ashley's apartment. The inspector later said the landlord had fixed the problem and pronounced the apartment safe. But Ashley continued to suffer from lead poisoning, and after three years, an independent inspection showed that the danger in the apartment had not been corrected. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Early Bulbs
description: Oh, yes, crocuses. We'd almost forgotten. The glacial mantle of ice and snow has withdrawn, and in the disorder it left behind -- matted lawns, pulped leaves -- the first bulbs are rising. And not merely rising, but standing tall, as tall as a crocus gets, quivering in a southerly breeze. The crocuses come up in the colors of repudiation, rejecting winter and all its monochromatic affairs. It's always something to see the stems of the early bulbs cleaving their way up through the soil, a reminder of the power of small things, the undeterred thrust of the season.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Comcast Agrees To Buy TechTV
description: The Comcast Corporation, the world's largest cable television operator, agreed yesterday to buy TechTV from Paul Allen's Vulcan Programming and will merge the cable TV network with its G4 channel, which features shows about video games. The combined network will be available to 44 million cable and satellite viewers in the United States, Comcast said. Comcast, based in Philadelphia, did not disclose terms of the transaction. TechTV's programs include ''Nerd Nation,'' a series about people and technology, and ''Fresh Gear,'' which reviews equipment like printers and videophones. Comcast shares rose 47 cents, to $28.47. title: The Medicare Muddle
description: In advance of Tuesday's reports by the Social Security and Medicare trustees, some credulous journalists wrote stories based on tips from advocates of Social Security privatization, who claimed that the report would offer a radically downgraded vision of the system's future. False alarm: projections for Social Security are about the same as last year. Projections for Medicare, however, have worsened: last year the trustees predicted that the hospital insurance trust fund would last until 2026, and now they've moved it back to 2019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANCER, MICHAEL
description: TANCER--Michael. Dearest husband of Francine Tancer for 55 years, passed away on March 24 after a long and beautiful life. Loving and greatly loved in return by his devoted daughters Joan and Susan and son-in-law Les Tolchin, granddaughter Jennifer and grandson Eric and sister Frances Decker. He loved and lived life fully with great courage fighting illness and disabilities with amazing determination. He served in the US Army Air Force Intelligence Unit during WW II in the Pacific. He graduated from NYU and the NYU Law School, however, his career was in business. He founded and was President of Tancer & Two a costume jewelry company. He was President of Coro, Inc. He was an avid reader, golfer, friend to many, elegant and handsome, generous & compassionate. Our mighty oak has fallen. We will miss him forever. Funeral services at Temple Kol Ami, White Plains, Monday March 29 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The American Cancer Society, or the Arthritis Foundation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on March 17 about Sidney Lorraine James, founding editor of Sports Illustrated in 1954, misstated the name of the publisher Mr. James joined as a part-time writer in 1929 and referred imprecisely to his title at Sports Illustrated. The publisher was Time Inc., not Time-Life. His title, managing editor, has always been the top editing post, not just when he held it. The obituary also misstated the period in which Sports Illustrated became profitable; it was several years after its founding by Time, not immediately.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANTANGELO, FRANCIS R.
description: SANTANGELO--Francis R. of Boynton Beach, Florida and Harrison, New York died of lung cancer on Monday, March 22, 2004 at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Florida. He was 71. Mr. Santangelo founded Santangelo and Company Specialist Firm on the American Stock Exchange until 1987. He continued to trade and was a consultant until his death. He was born in 1932 to the Honorable Robert V. and Juliette Santangelo. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1953 and later earned a law degree from St. John's University and his graduate degree from New York University. He served in the United States Marine Corps during the Korean War and earned the rank of First Lieutenant. He is survived by his wife Barbara Taccetta and four children, Toni Archibald, Robert Santangelo, Linda Santangelo and Dina Pfohl, eight grandchildren and brother Robert V. Santangelo, Jr. He will be remembered for his love of family, friends and great zest for life, along with his passion for thoroughbred racing, boating, fine art and his retreat on Hen Island. Family will receive friends on Friday, March 26, 2004 from 2-4PM and 7-9PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Rd., Rye, New York. Funeral mass is 10AM on Saturday, March 27, 2004 at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd., Rye, NY. Interment will follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Lung Cancer Research Fund, C/O Dr. Mark Kris, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Cheap, Ugly and Tough. Meet the Pinzgauer.
description: TO capture the material he needs for his work, Warren Cross, a sound designer, ranges far and wide, recording everything from storms and waterfalls to police sirens to be used on stage or in films. A few years ago, he discovered what he considers the perfect vehicle for his work: a 1974 Pinzgauer 710K. The Pinzgauer is a boxy, canvas-topped military vehicle built in Austria, and Mr. Cross and other Pinz owners insist that it is the toughest off-roader in the world. ''It'll go over anything, especially ditches,'' Mr. Cross said. ''It doesn't matter how you attack them, it's not going to get stuck.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poet's Nobel Medal Stolen
description: The Nobel Prize medal awarded to Rabindranath Tagore, the Bengali poet, playwright and author, in 1913 was reported stolen from a museum in West Bengal. Tagore, who died in 1941 at the age of 80, was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature for ''Gitanjali,'' a selection of his poetry. Visitors to the museum noticed that the gold medal and other items were missing from a glass showcase. Burglars are believed to have broken a window to enter the museum and raid the showcase. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Lawyer Admits Video Disclosure
description: A lawyer for a co-defendant in the corruption case against State Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Garson said yesterday that he was the one who released to a television news program a surveillance video of Justice Garson, left, receiving money in his robing room. The tape was broadcast on Tuesday on Fox 5 News, prompting complaints from Justice Garson's lawyer that its release violated a court order. Yesterday, Gerald J. McMahon, the lawyer for Nissim Elmann, who is accused of lining up litigants who would bribe Justice Garson, wrote to the judge hearing the Garson case, Steven W. Fisher, saying that he had released the tape. Mr. McMahon said he believed it had been unsealed already. Justice Fisher is considering the matter, a spokesman said. The Brooklyn district attorney's office has asked the state to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate Mr. McMahon's actions. Andy Newman (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SADIN, SAM
description: SADIN--Sam. Sam was our mother's cousin but undertook after we lost our parents to fill the role of father, mentor, advisor and especially friend to all of us. He and Terry made their home our home and made our wives and our children part of their close family. They were there to celebrate with, to share in our joys and our sorrows, to applaud our successes and to comfort us at times of loss. Sam was a constant presence in our adult lives, available whenever we needed him--the best listener, the most understanding and perceptive of men. Even in his waning days we saw flashes of his great wit and incisive intelligence. He led the fullest of lives, a man of great passion for social justice, of great appreciation for poetry and art and music, of deep love for friends and family. He inspired all of us and in memory will continue to do so. Michael, Jesse, & Ed Levine
