title: Ban Is Overturned for Heavy Trucks on New Jersey Highways
description: TRENTON, March 25 - New Jersey's restriction on interstate heavy-truck traffic on state and local roads, the only such prohibition in the nation, has been struck down by a federal district court.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Kansas: Letter From Killer
description: The police say they believe that a letter recently sent to a local newspaper was written by a serial killer who has eluded the authorities since the 1970's, when seven deaths were attributed to him. The letter, sent to The Wichita Eagle last week, contained a copy of a slain woman's driver's license, which was stolen when she was killed, and grainy images of her body. The woman, Vicki Wegerle, was found dead on Sept. 16, 1986. The police said the killer, known as B.T.K. for his chosen method of murder -- bind, torture and kill -- probably lived in the Wichita area. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Outspoken Chief Is Ousted At German Chip Maker
description: Ulrich Schumacher, an outspoken German executive who sharply criticized his country's high taxes and rigid labor laws, was ousted unexpectedly on Thursday as the head of Infineon Technologies, the world's sixth-largest semiconductor maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHARDSON, BARBARA P.
description: RICHARDSON -- Barbara P. Passed away on March 8th, 2004 at age 85. Formerly of Westport and Southport, CT, she was the beloved wife of the late Derek Richardson and leaves behind her five children, Derek P., David S., Gay R. Smith, Franklin S. (Tony), and Kate R. Jamison. She is also survived by her brother, William Proctor of Sanibel Island, FL, 13 grandchildren, and four greatgrandchildren. She was a graceful, strong lady who will be remembered by old friends and new. A Memorial Service will be held at the Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT, on April 3rd at 3 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Dr. Stephen Ariyan Fund for Melanoma Research, c/o The Community Foundation for Greater New Haven, 70 Audubon St., New Haven, CT 06510. For more information, or to sign an online register, please visit www.leskofuneralhome.com

description: Just days after President Vladimir V. Putin publicly scolded his cabinet for not setting ambitious enough growth goals for Russia, the economics minister raised his forecasts for the economy on Thursday, citing high global oil prices.

description: ''Dig!'' a new documentary by Ondi Timoner, gives a cinma vrit spin to the endlessly fascinating pop-music soap opera formula of VH1's ''Behind the Music.'' But Ms. Timoner's film, which traces the linked fortunes of not one band but two -- the Dandy Warhols and the Brian Jonestown Massacre -- feels more archetypal than formulaic, and also more real.

title: How to End a Career: Take a Baby to a News Conference
description: The production notes for ''Jersey Girl,'' Kevin Smith's widowed-father-raises-spunky-moppet film, come with a warm and fuzzy director's statement in which Mr. Smith, the creator of ''Clerks,'' ''Chasing Amy'' and ''Dogma,'' baldly states that this paean to fatherhood and family ties is his most personal film.

title: Nearing 34, Agassi's Only Retirement Plan Is to Conserve His Energy
description: His conversation was more about the next generation than his own, about conserving energy to postpone the inevitable farewell tour. Andre Agassi's words are dotted with reminders that as he is nearing his 34th birthday without a retirement announcement -- and can still summon sublime tennis -- almost every one of his decisions to play is calculated against the cost to his longevity.

title: Sports of The Times; A Quick Note to Jets Fans: A Plan Is Not a Promise
description: IT was a bad omen. Here I had gathered with the assembled notebooks, microphones and cameras for the announcement of a $2.8 billion expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and the construction of the Jets' football stadium with an exhibit hall on the West Side of Manhattan when I noticed somebody passing out the requisite news releases. But when I asked for one, I was told, ''We don't have any more.''

title: Nelson Leads, and St. Joseph's Follows
description: He is a consensus all-American, college basketball's player of the year, the 5-foot-11 captain of an overachieving team. Over 40 minutes of helter-skelter basketball Thursday night, Jameer Nelson turned in so many signature moments that a highlight reel could not do it justice.

title: Prescription for an Ailing Village: A Plastics Plant (Physician Required)
description: ''Seducing Doctor Lewis,'' which will be shown tonight and tomorrow night in the New Directors/New Films series, takes place in a grizzled fishing village in Quebec. Its characters may speak French, but the film, the first feature directed by Jean-Franois Pouliot, would fit comfortably in a British comic tradition that stretches from the old Ealing Studios films to recent hits like ''The Full Monty,'' passing through Bill Forsyth's Scotland along the way.

title: The Wrong War
description: The most compelling aspects of Richard Clarke's take on the world have less to do with the question of whether the Bush administration could somehow have prevented the Sept. 11 attacks and much more with the administration's folly of responding to the attacks by launching a war on Iraq.

description: To swelling trumpets, the biggest stars in the Democratic firmament strode on stage here Thursday night, but true to form, they seemed to lack a certain coordination.

title: Dying Without Remorse, A Bad Guy Who's Lonely
description: With his compulsively slamming lyrics and king-of-the-world delivery, DMX intuitively echoes the existentialism of the projects of the novelist Donald Goines. He's the perfect actor for the stylized and often satisfying film adaptation of Goines's ''Never Die Alone,'' directed with street-corner majesty by the cinematographer-turned-director Ernest Dickerson.

title: WYETH TO SHUT PENNSYLVANIA FACTORY AND LAY OFF 440
description: Wyeth is laying off 440 workers and shutting a factory in Marietta, Pa., after completing its part of a manufacturing agreement with a partner, MedImmune Inc., for an experimental flu vaccine, CAIV-T. The product is an improved version of FluMist, the inhaled influenza vaccine that MedImmune and Wyeth introduced last year but that failed to catch on with consumers. MedImmune is based in Gaithersburg, Md., and Wyeth is based in Madison, N.J.

title: So, It's Jets Versus Striped Bass?
description: REMEMBER the old joke about the eternally optimistic boy? Nothing could faze him, not even waking up on Christmas Day to find a lump of horse dung in his stocking. ''There's a pony around here somewhere,'' he said brightly.

A man of exceptional wit and humor and a clever pen who enthralled all with his magic. Former President of Mackay Publishing and Editor of Intimate Fashion News. Loved by all. title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: You can get your expectations right up there with the kids' on ''American Idol,'' but chances are you will not be dining at Masa any time soon. Masa Takayama's temple of sushi, on the spare and desolate fourth floor of the Time Warner Center, accepts reservations only during the first week of the month for the subsequent month. (The restaurant opened in late February, and is fully booked for March.) Next Thursday, presumably, operators will be standing by with open dates for May.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Place Where Spring Arrives On the Wings of a Sandhill Crane
description: BENEATH the fading presence of a high half moon, the pink light of a recent Saturday morning began to wash over a grassy field in central Nebraska as a dozen figures, dressed in Gore-Tex and Thinsulate, walked determinedly across the landscape. A strong wind from the south whipped their coats as they moved silently toward a low cooing sound emanating from the wetlands beyond.

title: Chalabi, Nimble Exile, Searches for Role in Iraq
description: When a handful of the most Islamist-minded Iraqi leaders gathered in Najaf last month to consult Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, there was an unexpected guest.

title: The Overleveraged Disneyland: Will Disney Take Losses in France?
description: WHEN the Walt Disney Company decided to build a Disneyland in Europe, it was clever in many ways -- perhaps too clever. It managed to build first one, and then a second, theme park largely with other people's money while not showing any of the loans on its own balance sheet. If all had gone well, it would have shown profits without much in the way of expenses.

title: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution Condemning Israel for Hamas Killing
description: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution Thursday night condemning Israel for killing the Hamas leader, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, because it did not denounce killings of Israelis by Hamas.

title: RICE WOULD TAKE MORE QUESTIONS FROM 9/11 PANEL
description: Under mounting pressure from Democrats about its response to the investigation into the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, the White House offered Thursday to have Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, answer more questions from the Sept. 11 panel. At the same time, President Bush forcefully denied accusations that he had ignored the severity of the threat from Al Qaeda.

title: U.S. Calls Apartment Interiors Safe After Its Post-9/11 Cleanup
description: A report by the federal Environmental Protection Agency shows that the agency's efforts to clean up thousands of apartments in Lower Manhattan after the World Trade Center attack were successful in removing asbestos and other harmful materials.

title: WIRE MAKER FOR CARS AND COMPUTERS SEEKS BANKRUPTCY
description: The International Wire Group, a producer of wire used by makers of automobiles and computers, filed for bankruptcy protection to permit it to reorganize. In papers filed late Wednesday in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York, International Wire said a ''meteoric rise'' in the price of copper had eroded its liquidity and forced it to seek court protection from creditors. International Wire has been in talks with holders of 11.75 percent bonds due 2005 to grant them ownership of 96 percent of the equity in the company through a restructuring plan, David J. Webster, the chief restructuring officer, said in the court papers. International Wire is based in St. Louis.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing of Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly to spending plans this year by Hotwire.com, the discount travel Web site. The increase in its budget to $55 million is for overall marketing efforts, not for advertising only.

title: Alabama Run Topples Syracuse Title Defense
description: Alabama may be seeded No. 8 in the Phoenix regional of the N.C.A.A. tournament, it may have lost 12 games this season and it may have finished with a .500 record in the Southeastern Conference. The Crimson Tide may play in an area where basketball is an afterthought behind football. But none of that matters. Alabama has rolled all the way to the Round of 8.

description: The 75,000 seats of the city's proposed Jets stadium might barely contain the myriad, often unexpected views offered by New Yorkers yesterday about the project.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: ADC To Acquire Krone Group For $291 Million
description: ADC Telecommunications, a network-equipment and software maker, has agreed to buy the Krone Group phone-gear business of GenTek Inc. for $291 million to increase sales outside North America. ADC, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., will also assume about $59 million of pension and employee-related liabilities, the companies said yesterday. Krone sells fiber optic and copper cable and network devices. GenTek, which exited bankruptcy protection in November with $280 million of debt, will use most of the sale's $250 million in net proceeds to repay debt.

title: For Kansas and U.A.B., Its an Endurance Test
description: ST. LOUIS, March 25  It is not unusual for Kansas to be in the Round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. tournament with expectations of going farther. With two national championships in its history and a near-miss last season, it is one of the nation's most prestigious programs.

description: SCHUTZ--Bernard, on March 25, 2004 at age 85. Adoring father of Liz Weinstein and Caroline Schutz, and grandfather of William and Matthew. Dear brother of Harriet Miller and Edward Schutz. Loving father-in-law of Steven Weinstein and future father-in-law of David Gould. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday March 28th, 11:30AM.

title: 28 Companies Are Selected To Provide Drug Discounts
description: The Bush administration announced Thursday that it had selected 28 companies to provide drug discount cards to the elderly, and it said the benefits of such cards should reverse a tide of criticism from Democrats who have been denouncing the new Medicare law for three months.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Convicted Of 1984 Murders
description: A man was found guilty yesterday of two 20-year-old murders because of his application for a school bus driver's job. The application required his fingerprints, which were matched to prints at the crime scene. He faces a sentence of 50 years to life. The man, Louis Telese, 44, of Nanuet, was convicted of murdering a Long Island woman and her 17-year-old son in 1984 in the family's Oceanside home. Mr. Telese was arrested in June 2002, after the authorities linked him to the crime scene through the job application, the district attorney's office said. One victim, Susan Eigen, 41, had been strangled, bound to her bed and sexually assaulted. Her son, Richard, had been suffocated and bound to a banister. An assistant district attorney, Robert P. Biancavilla said Mr. Telese, who was a cousin of the family living next door, had planned to rob his relatives, but turned his attention to the Eigens because a relative was home. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: 25 Killed in Antigovernment Protest in Ivory Coast
description: Violent clashes erupted on the streets of Abidjan, the commercial capital of Ivory Coast, on Thursday, killing 25 people, prompting rebels to withdraw from a power-sharing government and raising new doubts about the prospects for disarmament.

description: A Good Time To Transfer

A reception with her family will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Star Learning Center, St Matthew's and St Timothy's, 26 W. 84 St, NY, NY 10024

title: LIGHTNING 2, DEVILS 1
description: One game after the Devils clinched a playoff berth with an impressive surge, fortune turned against them, thanks to a seemingly harmless centering pass. With 4:58 to play and no teammate nearby, Tampa Bay's Brad Richards circled the Devils' net and flipped the puck in front. The pass struck Viktor Kozlov's skate and deflected past Martin Brodeur to give the Lightning a 2-1 victory in Tampa, Fla. Tom Spousta

title: Robber's Gun Didn't Go Off; Police Say Bodega Man's Did
description: The man who entered the Ramon Food Market, a Queens bodega, looked like any other customer. That is, until he rushed behind the counter, pulled a stocking over his face and jammed a 9-millimeter Glock pistol to the right temple of Edwin Marte, who was working the cash register, Mr. Marte recalled.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Children And Medical Studies
description: Children who participate in medical research need special protection from risky or unethical studies, a government advisory group said, and it urged that federal research rules be applied to all pediatric studies. A report by the group, the Institute of Medicine, notes that research involving children is essential to develop new treatments for diseases that affect them, but that families must understand the risks and purpose of the experiments. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: SEPRACOR TO END ABBOTT DEAL AND SELL DRUG ON ITS OWN
description: Sepracor Inc., which adapts other drug makers' medicines to make new products, plans to end a promotion agreement with Abbott Laboratories in December and will start marketing the asthma drug Xopenex on its own. As part of the agreement, Sepracor will pay the Ross Products division of Abbott $33 million by the end of 2006. Sepracor, which is based in Marlborough, Mass., will account for the payments this quarter, it said.

title: BLOOD TEST MAKER PREDICTS LOWER 2004 EARNINGS
description: Immucor Inc., which makes blood testing products, said 2004 earnings would fall as much as 18 percent because of higher expenses and increased maintenance costs for older equipment. Immucor said it expected net income to fall to $11.8 million to $12.3 million, or 58 cents to 60 cents a share, in its fiscal year ending May 31. The company earned $14.4 million, or 71 cents a share, in fiscal 2003. Immucor is based in Norcross, Ga.

title: Decay and Glory: Back to Byzantium
description: IN 1440, Canon Fursy de Bruille arrived in Cambrai, France, with an icon of the Virgin and Child he had received in Rome, which he had been told was a holy relic painted by St. Luke. The image shows Jesus squirming in his mother's arms. Mother and child, doleful and shy, turn slightly toward us, as if they are watching or waiting for something. Many artists copied the picture. The canon gave it to the Cathedral of Cambrai, where thousands of pilgrims saw it.

title: The Wrong Target
description: It cannot have escaped anyone's attention that the Bush administration has spent the better part of the week in full counterattack mode against Richard Clarke, the former White House antiterrorism czar who says the president and his senior officials greatly underrated the threat from Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda in the months leading up to 9/11. Nearly everyone of consequence in President Bush's inner circle appears to have been requisitioned to challenge Mr. Clarke's integrity and motives, accusing him of everything from trying to drum up sales for his new book to auditioning for a job in a John Kerry administration. The field of critics is so crowded that they're tripping over each other, as when Condoleezza Rice felt obliged to correct Vice President Dick Cheney's assertion that Mr. Clarke had never been ''in the loop.''

title: One Verdict on Verdi Singing, With Room for an Indulgence
description: Old-timers may grouse that opera singing isn't what it used to be, but there are plenty of good singers out there to prove them wrong. In fact, certain kinds of singing -- Baroque, contemporary, art song -- are having a wonderful flowering. But it's hard to deny that Verdi singing has lost some of its luster. Those big, rich over-the-top voices are practically extinct.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Diamond Mine Bid Rejected
description: BHP Billiton, the world's biggest mining company, plans to expand its Ekati mine in Canada, which supplies about 6 percent of the world's diamonds by value, after rejecting two offers for its stake from the DGI Group of Israel. BHP Billiton, which made 56 cents profit from every $1 of sales from Ekati last quarter, aims to expand its diamond business, a spokeswoman said. DGI said yesterday that it made a second approach to BHP Billiton, which rebuffed a first approach in June to buy its 80 percent share of Ekati, valued at $1.1 billion by ABN Amro Holding.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Pennsauken Township: 2 Students Stabbed
description: Two students were stabbed in the parking lot of Pennsauken High School on Wednesday afternoon after a brawl with two other students and two adults, the police said yesterday. The stab wounds were described as not life threatening -- one student was stabbed in the abdomen and the other in the buttocks. Lt. Thomas Connor of the Pennsauken Police Department said witnesses helped lead the police to quick arrests. One suspect, Hieu Tra, 19, of Pennsauken, was charged with two counts of aggravated assault and weapons offenses, Lt. Connor said. The other suspect, Van Nguyen of Willingboro, N.J., was charged with assault and drug possession. Both men are being held at the Camden County Jail. The two students involved in the incident were also arrested on unspecified charges, but not identified. John Holl (NYT)

description: FALLUJA, Iraq, March 26 - At least 12 people, including one American marine, were killed in a series of gunbattles today, as guerrilla violence swept the Sunni-dominated area north and west of the Iraqi capital.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: Exports Rise
description: New Zealand's exports rose 9.5 percent in February from the month a year ago to 2.53 billion New Zealand dollars ($1.65 billion), according to preliminary figures released by Statistics New Zealand, pushing the country to a trade surplus of 136 million New Zealand dollars. The agency also announced that New Zealand's current account deficit in the fourth quarter of 2003 narrowed to 1.92 billion New Zealand dollars, down 1.7 percent from the quarter in 2002, lifted by receipts from overseas tourists. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Jefferson, Madison, Newdow?
description: When Michael Newdow stood before the Supreme Court on Wednesday and made the case for atheism, he probably didn't win many converts. But his quixotic crusade to rid the Pledge of Allegiance of the words ''under God'' is a peculiarly American act of courage. And somewhere the spirits of Jefferson, Madison and Franklin may well be smiling.

title: Corrections
description: A letter on Tuesday about the killing of Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the founder of Hamas, referred incorrectly to the Israeli military. It is not the largest in the Middle East; some Arab countries and Iran have larger military forces.

title: Study Doesn't Link Abortion To Higher Breast Cancer Risk
description: Miscarriages and induced abortions do not increase a woman's risk of developing breast cancer later in life, according to a study of 83,000 women worldwide being published today.

title: China Tells Japan to Release 7 Arrested on Disputed Island
description: China accused Japan of violating its sovereignty on Thursday and demanded the immediate release of seven activists who had landed on a disputed island chain in the East China Sea.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose after reports showed overseas investors bought a record amount of Japanese shares and the country's trade surplus widened. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.04 yen, down from 106.10.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GILLETTE CO., Boston, the razor and battery company, announced that its chairman and chief executive, James Kilts, would extend his employment contract for one year to Jan. 16, 2006.

title: SENATE OUTLAWS INJURY TO FETUS DURING A CRIME
description: The Senate approved legislation on Thursday making it a separate offense to harm the fetus in a federal crime committed against a pregnant woman, sending the measure to President Bush for his signature.

title: Corrections
description: The Boldface Names column yesterday, about a lion tamer at the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus, misstated the way 12 elephants were confined backstage at Madison Square Garden. They were kept inside electrical fencing, and two were tethered at the ankle. They were not shackled.

title: Council Leader Vows to Reopen Six Firehouses
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller took a swipe at Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday on a particularly touchy issue -- the closing of six fire engine companies -- all but inviting a confrontation between the two political rivals when the Council unveils its budget plans next week.

title: Push Is On to Limit Aid to Rich Universities
description: Following the Bush administration's lead, Republicans in the House say they will push to overhaul a financial aid system that often sends a disproportionate share of federal education money to wealthy universities with relatively few low-income students.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Computer Purchases Surge In India
description: Consumers and business in India bought 800,000 personal computers in the October-to-November quarter of 2003, an increase of 87 percent over the year-earlier period, the Manufacturers Association of Information Technology said yesterday. It said sales could total more than three million in the fiscal year ending in March. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EVANS, DR. JANE
description: EVANS--Dr. Jane. Women of Reform Judaism is deeply saddened by the passing of our visionary and beloved first Executive Director, Dr. Jane Evans. During her 43 years as Executive Director she demonstrated her passionate commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes. Dr. Evans played a dynamic role in reform and progressive Judaism worldwide and also in her untiring efforts for peace. We will miss Jane Evans, and will remember her warmth and wisdom. Helene H. Waranch, Pres. Shelley Lindauer, Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALSEY, RALPH W. JR.
description: HALSEY--Ralph W. Jr. of Noank, Connecticut died at Lawrence & Memorial Hospital in New London on March 20, 2004 after a short illness. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, Betsey Avery Copp Halsey. Mr. Halsey was born in Orange, New Jersey on December 3, 1919. He attended The Hotchkiss School graduating in 1938. He graduated from Yale College in 1942. He served as a Lieutenant in the United States Navy from 1942 until 1945. After the war, Mr. Halsey worked as an Assistant Treasurer and Trust Officer at the Bankers Trust Company in New York City. In 1953 he became the Associate Treasurer and Investment Officer at Yale University, managing Yale's endowment. in 1967 Mr. Halsey founded Halsey Associates, an investment management firm in New Haven. He was a Trustee and Treasurer of The Hotchkiss School and also served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Middlesex Mutual Assurance Company from 1963 until 1992. He was the Harbormaster of Noank for many years and was an Associate Fellow of Berkeley College at Yale. Mr. Halsey is survived by his sister, Dorothy H. Hughes of Shawnee Mission, Kansas and his brother Anthony P. Halsey of Mason's Island, Connecticut. He was predeceased by a sister, Margaret H. Storer. He leaves four children Avery H. Dickinson of Wakefield, Rhode Island, Ralph W. (Peter) Halsey III of New Haven, Thomas S. Halsey of Dallas, Texas and Andrew M. Halsey of Mystic; 14 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. There will be no services and the family requests that no flowers be sent nor contributions be made. For obituary information or to send a condolence to the family please visit www.dinotofuneral.com

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOUDRY, PIERRE D.
description: HOUDRY--Pierre D., Sportsman, (80), of Jupiter Island, FL, died Tuesday 23 March. Born in Paris, France, he had been a resident of Jupiter Island since 1973 coming from Berwyn, PA. He was Vice President of Oxy-Catalyst, a firm founded by his father, Eugene Houdry, the inventor of the catalytic cracking process of oil refining to produce high octane gasoline. He attended the Episcopal Academy in Philadelphia and Lawrenceville School, NJ; he served in the US Army from 1942-1945 as a Platoon Staff Sergeant in chemical warfare and field artillery units. He was awarded numerous medals including the EuropeAfrica-Middle East Medal with two bronze stars, and the Asiatic Pacific Campaign Medal. Mr. Houdry was a lifetime member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. Mr. Houdry was active in international hunting, fishing, field sports and competitive trap shooting. He was a member of the Jupiter Island Club, Hobe Sound Yacht Club, FL and the Misquamicut Club in Watch Hill, RI. Survivors include his wife of 58 years, Louise Walker Houdry of Jupiter Island; his daughters Genevieve (Ginette) Brockway of Acton, MA and MarieChristine Quinn of Newtown Square, PA; six grandchildren; and a brother, Jacques H. Houdry, of Palm Beach, FL and Philadelphia, PA. A daughter Daniele, predeceased him. Funeral services and interment will be private. A memorial service will be held at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, 4:00 pm Saturday March 27. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Jupiter Island Clinic, PO Box 375, Hobe Sound, FL 33475.

The two men, Robert Lnu, a Malaysian national, and Coung Chi Dinh, 44, of Brigantine, N.J. and six casino employees were charged with conspiracy to arrange prostitution services for casino customers, according to an assistant United States attorney, Jason Richardson. The casinos were not identified. According to a 24-count indictment, Mr. Lnu recruited more than 20 women to travel to the United States from Asia to work for the prostitution ring allegedly operated by Mr. Dinh. description: VERGARA -- Raymond, 92, New York City, on March 25, 2004. Born Colombia, S.A. Served U.S. Army during World War II in Normandy, Northern France, Ardennes, Rhineland, Central Europe; Cpl. Recipient World War II Victory Medal, American Defense Medal, Occupation Medal of Germany, EAME Ribbon with 5 bronze stars. Beloved brother of Maria Teresa and the late Isabel Vergara de Cortes and Lucrecia Vergara Munoz; uncle of Hugo (Maria Rosa), Cesar (Marina), Nhora (Harold Comerer), and the late Maria Consuelo (James McEntee, Jr.); greatuncle of Maria Rosa, Luis (Myriam), David, Carolina, Andrea, James, and Christopher; great-great-uncle of David. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, Saturday March 27th, 2-5, 7-9. Mass of Christian Burial, Holy Trinity, 213 W. 82 St., Monday, March 29, 10AM. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWYER, BARBARA A.
description: DWYER--Barbara A., on March 25, 2004, of Westbury, LI. Devoted wife of the late Thomas F. Daughter of the late John W. and Rose Kennedy. Beloved mother of Thomas J. (Lorraine), Amsterdam, NY and Rose Quinn (James), Westbury, LI. Loving grandmother of Thomas J. Jr. (Caryn), Melissa D. Lescault (OJ), Colleen A., Kelly H. Quinn, Kathleen C. and the late Kerry Rose. Devoted sister of Patricia Sharkey and the late Jane Russo. Also survived by numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. Reposing Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave., Westbury, LI on Saturday from 79pm and Sunday 2-4 and 79pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, 11am, St. Brigid's RC Church, Westbury, LI. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Maurer Foundation for Breast Health and Education, 800 Port Washington Blvd., Port Washington, NY 11050 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Rhoda L. Fisher, 79, Therapist And Multifacted Writer of Books
description: Dr. Rhoda L. Fisher, a psychotherapist who with her husband, Seymour Fisher, wrote popular books on subjects as varied as humor and child-rearing, died on Sunday at the home of her daughter, Dr. Eve Whitmore, in Medina, Ohio. She was 79 and had a home in Manlius, N.Y., a Syracuse suburb.

title: When You Aren't Who You Think You Are
description: We first meet Cristina Quadri, the heroine of Gastn Biraben's ''Captive,'' at her 15th birthday party, in 1994. She appears to be a perfectly ordinary, if exceptionally lovely, Buenos Aires teenager. Cristina lives with her doting upper-middle-class family (her father, now retired, was an officer in the national police force) and attends a starchy Catholic girls' school, where she daydreams through her lessons and sneaks cigarettes with her best friend. But Brbara Lombardo, the extraordinary young actress who plays Cristina, has the kind of soft, melancholy features that seem to hold reservoirs of emotion, as if she were haunted by the memory -- or perhaps the premonition -- of an unbearable hurt.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATES EL PASO'S RESERVE ESTIMATES
description: The El Paso Corporation said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating a recent reduction of 41 percent in the company's estimate of oil and gas reserves. El Paso was notified of the formal investigation in a letter from the commission, which was accompanied by a subpoena requesting documents related to the estimate cut last month, El Paso said. The company is cooperating with the investigation, Doug Foshee, the chief executive, said in a statement. The company cut its estimate of year-end natural gas and oil reserves by the equivalent of 1.82 trillion cubic feet of gas, to 2.64 trillion cubic feet. The company has since said it will have to restate financial statements for prior years.

title: In Connecticut, No Solutions So Far for Jammed Roadways
description: The chaos created by a fuel-truck crash Thursday night in Bridgeport underscored how much must still be done -- and how little, relatively speaking, has been accomplished -- to relieve what experts say is an interstate highway system in crisis in southwestern Connecticut.

title: After May 1, East Europe's 'Haves' May Have More
description: For 60 years in this place of lakes and forests, Gerard Pakura's life has unfolded in step with Europe's history, from the Nazi occupation of his land to the rise and fall of Soviet Communism.

title: $6 Billion Loan Deal by Freddie Mac Examined by U.S.
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development is examining an unusual $6 billion deal made last year by Freddie Mac to fulfill its federal requirements on loans for affordable housing.

title: Dual career couples : The travails of a commuter marriage
description: LONDON  Three days after our honeymoon, I left my wife in London and flew to Milan. This wasn't some fit of pique or the siren call of some classy Italian dame. No, the reason was work, which is to say money. I had been living and working in Italy for the past six months and that wasn't about to change for a couple of gold rings. At home, Gill had a growing business and an ailing mother: it was deadlock.

title: Anglicans' former leader angers Muslims with criticism of Islam
description: MILAN:  George Carey, the former archbishop of Canterbury, has incensed Muslims by criticizing Islam for being "associated with violence throughout the world."

title: Reducing Fractures
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the diversity of cultures along Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn referred imprecisely in some copies to Hecht's, where Harriet Flusberg was shown at work. While it sells some novelties, it is primarily a Judaica store.

title: State's Budget Is Expected to Be Late Again
description: In the clearest sign yet that the state's budget will be late for the 20th consecutive year, the Pataki administration has been making plans to pay the state's bills after April 1, the day a new budget is supposed to be in place.

title: See Dick Spin
description: Warren Bass, Michael Hurley and Alexis Albion are not exactly household names. But they are a few of the authors of the outstanding interim reports released by the 9/11 commission this week. In clear, substantive and credible prose, these staff reports describe the errors successive administrations made leading up to the terror attacks. More than that, they describe the ambiguities and constraints policy makers wrestled with.

title: INSIDE
description: Campaign Ads Questioned

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERNBERG, SAMUEL
description: STERNBERG -- Samuel, of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on Thursday, March 25th, 2004 at the age of 81. Beloved and devoted husband of his wife of 57 years, Beverly (nee Tartell), cherished father of Wilma, Marcia, and Stuart, adored grandfather of Marissa, Morgen, Sandy, Jake, Natalie, and Ella, loving fatherin-law of Michael, Lisa, and Charles. Mr. Sternberg graduated from Yeshiva of Flatbush in 1939, as part of its first graduating class. He was a proud WWII veteran, having served in the 3rd Army Resupply Squadron of the US Army Air Corps which supplied General George Patton's 3rd Army on its march through Europe. He was an officer of the Seaview Jewish Center and owned the Pillow Shop in Brooklyn, NY. All of us will miss him deeply for his support, wisdom, sense of humor and zest for life. He had a love for sports, movies, and good food, but most importantly, for good friends and good times. He was always so very proud of his whole family. Memorial services will be held at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY, on Sunday, March 28th, 2004 at 11 AM. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations may be made in his memory to the NYU Cardiovascular Center, c/o Dr. William Cole, 530 1st Ave., NY NY 10016.

title: Sports of The Times; Resentment for Duke Is the Name of the Game
description: THE boos began as the Duke players bounced toward the court for the pregame warm-ups. They smiled, almost as if they liked it.

title: As Brackets Shrink, The Black Market Booms for Tickets
description: Just 43.6 seconds remained on the clock, and Wake Forest had closed to within 2 points of St. Joseph's, turning a game that was on the verge of a rout into a nail-biter instead.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Profit Declines
description: Shares in China Unicom fell 12 percent after the company reported weak 2003 earnings. Net profit for the 12 months ended Dec. 31 was 4.22 billion yuan ($509 million), down 8.3 percent from a year earlier. Wang Jianzhou, chairman of China Unicom, said the earnings decline was mainly a result of a write-off related to its paging division. But analysts said full-year results showed weaker operating results as a result of marketing expenses, lower revenue per subscriber and a high rate of customer turnover.

title: A Jailed Father Leaves a Void In His Teenage Daughter's Life
description: In the cooled-out melodrama ''B-Happy,'' from Chile, the curiosity of Manuela Martelli, the young actress starring as the 14-year-old Kathy, glows in her large, clear eyes. A coming-of-age story featuring a teenage female protagonist has already been seen at this year's New Directors/New Films series: in the impressive ''Strong Shoulders,'' an aggressive teenage athlete inadvertently damages the lives of those she loves while pursuing her dreams.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 3 Held In Rail Bomb Threats
description: French antiterrorism police detained two men and a woman in connection with threats made against the French railway system by an obscure entity calling itself A.Z.F. The three were taken into custody around Paris and in the Loiret region of central France, according to news reports. The reports said the three were detained because of suspicious movements but gave few other details. The government has received a series of letters and telephone calls from someone claiming to represent A.Z.F. and threatening to bomb rail tracks unless paid more than $5 million. Two unexploded bombs have been found on railways since the threats began in mid-December. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: For Insight on the Way We Act, Read the Philosophers
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Yukos Co-Owner Faces Trial
description: Russian prosecutors called for Platon Lebedev, a major shareholder in Russia's richest company, Yukos Oil, to stand trial. It was unclear what sentence he might face. His trial could start next month or in early May, the newspaper Izvestia reported, and could signal how the case against Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the country's richest businessman and Mr. Lebedev's co-owner in Yukos, will develop. Mr. Lebedev, who was arrested in July, was the first of several Yukos stockholders to be detained on fraud and embezzlement charges. The investigation is widely viewed as a Kremlin-inspired effort to curb the influence of Mr. Khodorkovsky, who was arrested in October and also remains in custody. Erin E. Arvedlund (NYT)

title: Riders on No. 4 Subway Line Rerouted by Station Upgrades
description: Starting this morning, the 167th Street and Mount Eden Avenue stations on the No. 4 subway line in the Bronx will be closed for renovations, city transit officials said. The stations will be closed for three months.

title: U.S. and France Apparently at Odds Over Labor Rights
description: A squabble over whether to encourage the involvement of workers in corporate management has at least temporarily derailed, and could even kill, efforts of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to publish a comprehensive revision of its principles of corporate governance.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Copter's Wreckage Found
description: The wreckage of a helicopter that crashed in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday night was found submerged with four bodies inside, bringing to eight the number of victims recovered. Two are still missing. The wreckage was discovered 72 miles south of Galveston, from where the charter helicopter had departed for an oil drilling ship 130 miles east of South Padre Island. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Elections Put Off, Diplomats Say
description: National elections scheduled for June will be postponed until September, diplomats in Afghanistan said, to allow more time to register voters and improve security. President Hamid Karzai, who heads the transitional administration, made the decision this week and will announce it officially next week at an international donors conference in Berlin. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Demand blossoms for Chinese art
description: NEW YORK:  Untroubled by economic worries, the Chinese art market is being carried by a tidal wave. In an extraordinary sale held at Christie's this week, the reason for its unique vigor came out with unprecedented clarity. Four different constituencies spread across the globe from America to Europe to the Far East compete for Chinese art. Economic weakness in one part of the world has little effect on bidders, goaded by intense rivalry.

title: Japanese Household Spending Rises for 4th Month in a Row
description: Spending by Japanese households rose for a fourth consecutive month in February, the government said Friday, offering evidence that a recovery driven so far mostly by exports is beginning to catch on with consumers.

title: Healing a Gash Among the Brownstones; Park Slope Struggles to Crowd Out Ghosts of 1960 Disaster
description: In New York City, even the empty places are already full.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chinese Activists Released
description: Japan released and deported seven Chinese activists two days after they were detained for landing on an island claimed by both countries. The landing on the remote chain of islands, called the Senkakus by Japan and the Diaoyus by China, highlighted the continuing World War II-era tension between the two powers. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

title: Top-Seeded Duke Keeps Defending Reputation
description: Duke never, ever walks out on the floor for a basketball game and counts on its reputation to do the work. The Blue Devils stand in to take a charge, hustle for loose balls and fight for space on defense.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LIPMAN, SAMUEL
description: LIPMAN--Samuel. Dad, we miss spending time together and laughing with you. Larry, Donna, Beth, Reed, Samara and Paige

title: In Defeat, Nets Clinch Their Place In Playoffs
description: When the Nets and the Boston Celtics staged dramatic playoff battles the past two seasons, they seemed on the verge of a rivalry. The results left bitter memories on both sides.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia And New Zealand: Australia: Bank Seeks Director's Ouster
description: National Australia Bank will ask shareholders to dismiss a nonexecutive director, Catherine Walter, after she refused to resign from the board. Ms. Walter, 51, was removed as head of the board's audit committee after PricewaterhouseCoopers reported this month on currency trading losses of 252 million Australian dollars ($187 million). That report, and another by the Prudential Regulation Authority of Australia, were critical of the audit committee. The chairman, Graham Kraehe, said Ms. Walter had lost the trust of the other nonexecutive directors. The currency losses led to the firings of four traders and their boss and the dismissal of three executives after the PricewaterhouseCoopers report said loopholes allowed employees to hide losses and protect bonuses.

title: A New Prescription for the Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: The Star Next Door Is Lifting Minnesota
description: In his law office in Hutchinson, Minn., Ron McGraw devotes a room to Lindsay Whalen, the closest thing to a homegrown celebrity Hutchinson has. Clippings from the twice-weekly newspaper, The Hutchinson Leader, and the two Twin Cities dailies cover the walls, all in devotion to Whalen, a University of Minnesota women's basketball standout who grew up down the street from McGraw.

title: Taxing matters : Coping with a low dollar
description: LONDON  Many Americans living abroad, especially in Europe, received a stealth pay rise last year when surging foreign currencies boosted earnings when translated back into dollars. Because their expenses are denominated in the same currencies, these expats may not have noticed their good fortune, but they can be sure the Internal Revenue Service will.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 589 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDEVITCH, IGOR
description: GORDEVITCH--Igor, Publisher and resident of Pawling, NY, suddenly on March 24, 2004. He began his career as a reporter covering the Vatican and European affairs for the International Herald Tribune. He became Editor and later Publisher at Vision Inc., a publisher of Latin American business magazines. He was Publisher at Gruhner and Jahr USA for GEO magazine. He created and published IMPACT, US Investment Report and ECO, magazines on international business, investment and ecology. He is survived by his wife, Carin Gordevitch, his children, Alexandra Gordevitch Rota, Tatiana Gordevitch, Christopher D. Kirsten, Michelle K. Krepak and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations to Convent Novo Diveeno, 100 Smith Rd., Nanuet, NY 10954.

title: Mother, 19, Charged in Death of Newborn
description: The mother of a newborn girl found dead in a laundry basket behind a Staten Island home on Tuesday was charged yesterday with criminally negligent homicide, the police said.

title: Is There an Ethicist in the House?
description: Like some election-cycle cicada, the House ethics committee has broken its long silence and begun making a bit of noise. It is taking notice of public pressure for an investigation of allegations that bribe offers and intimidation were part of the long night of Republican arm-twisting when the Medicare drug subsidy bill squeaked through Congress last year. Representative Nick Smith, a Michigan Republican, had angrily complained of ''$100,000-plus'' bribe offers and threats against his son's political career. He later backed off a bit, but a full investigation of the gamesmanship under way that night is clearly needed. Whether the ethics panel is up to the task remains doubtful. The committee has been more or less flat-lining for years, ever since the rules were changed in 1997 to block outside complaints about suspect members and questionable behavior.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Slips
description: German business confidence fell in March for a second consecutive month, raising doubts about the country's economic recovery and setting off calls for a reduction in interest rates. The Ifo Institute, which is based in Munich, said an index based on its survey of 7,000 businesses fell to a five-month low of 95.4, from 96.4 in February. Hans-Werner Sinn, president of the institute, said the decline showed that recovery in the German economy, which has been hurt by a high unemployment rate, was at risk. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Bill, Jimmy . . . Meet Q-Tip
description: TWO ex-presidents and a rapper walk into a nightclub . They don't say much, especially the ex-president from Georgia. "I don't want to interfere with your music, so God bless you," he says, flashing his famous grin and exiting the stage. The rapper and the other ex-president say a few more words and leave. There's no punch line, but there is a bottom line: $250,000 for the Democratic party .

title: About New York; DUMPBUSH? Don't Try It On a Plate
description: THE phrase that came to his mind was evocative, to the point, and in perfect conformity with the eight-figure character as allowed by the Custom Plate Unit of the New York State Department of Motor Vehicles. His muse had surely blessed him, he thought; it seemed that he had achieved a kind of license plate haiku.

title: With Serbs And Muslims In the Muddle Of Bosnia
description: The title of the incident-filled but relaxed and oddly courtly comedy-drama ''Fuse'' isn't exactly misleading. Watching the story unfold is akin to watching a ridiculously extended fuse burn for so long that you almost forget there's a bomb at the end.

title: Answers on 9/11, But Under Oath
description: To the Editor:

title: Above All, Money Matters Are What Matter to Poles
description: Poles are more than aware that this is a dizzying moment. Just a month before they shuck off the last traces of their Communist past by joining the European Union, their government is collapsing and they worry that, like Spain, their friendship with the United States may provoke a terror attack against them.

title: Bonds's Trainer Wants Items Retested
description: The lawyers for Greg Anderson, Barry Bonds's personal trainer, asked a federal judge in San Francisco yesterday for permission to retest items that the government had seized in its search of Anderson's home last September in connection with an investigation into the sale of steroids to professional athletes.

title: Dr. Zhong Wei Chen, Pioneer In Microsurgery, Is Dead at 74
description: Dr. Zhong Wei Chen, a leader in the field of microsurgery who was among the first doctors to perform a successful operation to reattach a severed hand, died Tuesday in Shanghai. He was 74.

title: Dual career couples : Trailing spouse's job needs start to get more company time
description: VIENNA  Ruth Whitby loves her husband, Ben  and she also loves her job. When he was transferred to Japan, Whitby, a British medical doctor, struggled for a year to get a license to practice in Japan. She eventually succeeded and built a thriving medical practice in Tokyo, only to see her diplomat husband transferred again. This time all attempts at practicing medicine in their new home of Vienna failed.

title: Increasing Turmoil on Jury Threatens Tyco Trial
description: Escalating turmoil in the jury room appeared to bring the six-month-long trial of two former Tyco International executives to the verge of collapse yesterday after several highly unusual events, including an ''O.K.'' hand gesture from one juror in open court that seemed to signal her support for the defense.

title: NASA Seeks New Frontier in Jet Engines
description: It is to last just 10 seconds, but researchers say this brief firing of a new kind of jet engine could be the first step toward revolutionizing high-speed air and space travel.

title: Bergtraum Back in Final On Late Rally
description: Midway through the fourth quarter of Friday's Class AA girls semifinal at the State Federation Championships, Murry Bergtraum of Manhattan looked like a beaten squad.

title: Up to 16 Die in Gun Battles in Sunni Areas of Iraq
description: As many as 16 people, including a United States marine, were killed in a series of gun battles on Friday, as guerrilla violence swept the Sunni-dominated areas north and west of Baghdad in the latest show of strength by the insurgency here.

title: Dual career couples : The travails of a commuter marriage
description: LONDON  Three days after our honeymoon, I left my wife in London and flew to Milan. This wasn't some fit of pique or the siren call of some classy Italian dame. No, the reason was work, which is to say money. I had been living and working in Italy for the past six months and that wasn't about to change for a couple of gold rings. At home, Gill had a growing business and an ailing mother: it was deadlock.

title: Just 20, She Captures Altered Japan in a Debut Novel
description: HITOMI KANEHARA'S 20-year-old face is now a staple of weekly magazines and subway posters, the valuable Japanese real estate usually reserved for starlets with a hit song or movie. But what propelled Ms. Kanehara there was the unlikeliest of events, here in this most digitalized of societies: the publication of her debut novel, a work in the category of ''serious fiction'' no less.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES TO CUT 400 JOBS
description: Abbott Laboratories said it would cut about 400 jobs and close an office in Bedford, Mass., to prepare for its planned purchase of TheraSense. Operations at Abbott's MediSense unit in Bedford will be combined with the diabetes business of TheraSense, an Abbott spokeswoman, Melissa Brotz, said. The employees who lose their jobs will be offered severance or retirement packages. About 100 people will be offered other employment within the company. Shareholders of TheraSense, which is based in Alameda, Calif., will vote on the acquisition next month. Abbott is based in Abbott Park, Ill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORITZKY, AUDREY MILLER
description: PORITZKY--Audrey Miller, on March 25, 2004. Beloved wife of David, loving mother of Sophie Lena, devoted daughter of Anne and Laurence Miller, dear sister of Robert and his wife Amy. She will be deeply and sadly missed by her grandparents Beatrice and Joseph Miller, her nephews Jacob and David Miller, her husband's family Susan, Sandy, Eric and Dan Poritzky. She is predeceased by her grandparents Sophie and David Knopping. Service Sunday, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Thursday, April 1, at Jewish Oakland Cemetery, Little Rock, Arkansas. Donations to The Audrey Miller Poritzky Educational Fund for Children, PO Box 688, Summit, NJ 07902-0688.

title: China Warns Taiwan It Won't Tolerate Post-Vote Turmoil
description: Beijing issued a strong warning on Friday that it would not tolerate turmoil here, as hundreds of stone-throwing protesters fought with the riot police in an unsuccessful attempt to prevent the official certification of President Chen Shui-bian as the winner of a disputed election last Saturday.

title: Moscow Court Bans Jehovah's Witnesses From Practicing in City
description: After six years of civil proceedings, a court here on Friday banned activities by Jehovah's Witnesses in what members of the group said could be a first step toward a nationwide ban.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the stir created by the publication of ''Against All Enemies: Inside America's War on Terror'' by Richard A. Clarke, who attributed counterterrorism failures to the Bush administration, misstated the number of additional copies issued by its publisher, The Free Press, as of Thursday. Beyond the initial printing of 300,000, the number was 250,000, not 150,000.

title: Even While Struggling, Woods Is a Cut Above
description: Whatever happens at the Players Championship this weekend, Tiger Woods will be a part of it.

title: Charge Upheld Against Parolee
description: A Superior Court judge here denied a motion on Friday to dismiss a domestic violence charge against Thomas Trantino, who was released from prison two years ago after serving 38 years for killing two police officers.

title: Demand blossoms for Chinese art
description: NEW YORK:  Untroubled by economic worries, the Chinese art market is being carried by a tidal wave. In an extraordinary sale held at Christie's this week, the reason for its unique vigor came out with unprecedented clarity. Four different constituencies spread across the globe from America to Europe to the Far East compete for Chinese art. Economic weakness in one part of the world has little effect on bidders, goaded by intense rivalry.

title: Men's Wearhouse Net Cut
description: Men's Wearhouse, the men's clothing retailer, has reduced fiscal 2003 earnings by 6 cents a share because of legal costs associated with allegations that it failed to pay overtime.

title: Excerpts From Frist's Speech on Ex-Official
description: Following are excerpts from a speech on the Senate floor on Friday by Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the majority leader, as prepared for delivery and supplied by his office. A full transcript is online at nytimes.com/politics.

title: Israelis Say Hamas Is Not Able to Mount Major Retaliation
description: Israeli officials expressed growing confidence on Friday that Hamas militants would not manage to fulfill their threats of extraordinary retaliation for Israel's killing of their spiritual leader, Sheik Ahmed Yassin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, JUNE PARKER
description: WILSON--June Parker, of New York City and Chilmark, MA, died on March 6 of Alzheimer's disease. She was 87 years old. Ms. Wilson translated 10 books from French to English, most in collaboration with Walter Benn Michaels, including the best-seller Papillon, by Henri Charriere. She was born in Oakland, CA, the daughter of Carleton H. Parker, a well-known labor expert, and Cornelia Stratton Parker, a writer best known for ''An American Idyll'', an account of her marriage to Dr. Parker. Ms. Wilson graduated from Bennington College in 1939, and served on its board. Her husband of 51 years, Kenneth Wilson, died in 1991. She is survived by daughters, Cornelia Higginson, Lee Badger, and Meredith Michaels, nine grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren.

title: Political Memo; The West Side's Yours, Ground Zero Mine
description: It is not exactly a municipal version of Yalta. But through a deal made for two politicians with pressing political needs, shared electoral constituencies and eyes on the history books, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have each carved out a piece of Manhattan on which to fasten their economic development visions, with one another's blessing.

description: Afront-page article yesterday about the stir created by the publication of "Against All Enemies: Inside America's War on Terror" by Richard A. Clarke, who attributed counterterrorism failures to the Bush administration, misstated the number of additional copies issued by its publisher, The Free Press, as of Thursday. Beyond the initial printing of 300,000, the number was 250,000, not 150,000. ( Go to Article )

title: DEMOCRATS ISSUE THREAT TO BLOCK COURT NOMINEES
description: Senate Democrats, turning up the heat in their long-simmering feud with President Bush over judicial nominations, vowed on Friday to block all new federal court appointments unless the White House promises to stop installing judges while Congress is in recess.

title: Corrections
description: A credit in some copies yesterday with an article about the truck fire on Interstate 95 in Connecticut misspelled the surname of a contributor. He was Robert Davey, not Davy.

title: An African Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Relic of an Enlightened Age, Led by a French Harpsichordist
description: Emmanuelle Ham, the French harpsichordist, is a powerhouse interpreter who has been enlivening the European early-music scene as a conductor for the last four years and is now making rapid inroads in this country. Two recent recordings -- a spectacular account of Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' and an equally vivid reading of Monteverdi's ''Orfeo,'' both on the Virgin label -- are enlivened by daring choices of tempo, ornamentation and orchestral color, as well as by dynamic and articulation touches that are Mahleresque in their detail and sweep.

title: LEADERS OF G.O.P. TRY TO DISCREDIT A CRITIC OF BUSH
description: Republican Congressional leaders said Friday that they would seek to declassify past Congressional testimony from Richard A. Clarke, President Bush's former counterterrorism chief, in an effort to demonstrate that the former aide had lied this week about Mr. Bush's record.

title: Another Round in the Fight Over Fire Company Closings
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday defended his decision to close six fire companies during last year's fiscal crisis, suggesting that Council Speaker Gifford Miller was making an issue of it as a means of ''pandering to try to get the votes of the firefighters and their union endorsements.''

title: An African Tragedy (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Albertsons Buying Shaw's, New England Grocery Chain
description: Seeking a strategy that skirts the widening influence of Wal-Mart Stores in the grocery business, Albertsons said yesterday that it would spend $2.47 billion to buy the New England-based Shaw's chain of supermarkets from its British parent, J Sainsbury.

title: 911 System Shuts Down In 3 Boroughs
description: New York City's 911 emergency line went down for about two hours in three boroughs last night in what city officials said was a telephone company problem. The malfunction left city officials frantically trying to set up alternative ways to get help to New Yorkers who heard only busy signals when they tried to call 911.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: FRANCE: 3 HELD IN RAIL BOMB THREATS French antiterrorism police detained two men and a woman in connection with threats made against the French railway system by an obscure entity calling itself A.Z.F. The three were taken into custody around Paris and in the Loiret region of central France, according to news reports. The reports said the three were detained because of suspicious movements but gave few other details. The government has received a series of letters and telephone calls from someone claiming to represent A.Z.F. and threatening to bomb rail tracks unless paid more than $5 million. Two unexploded bombs have been found on railways since the threats began in mid-December. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Cashmere Moves On, And Scotland Feels a Chill
description: At first glance, this modest town of aging textile mills set by a river in a bowl of hills seems an unlikely link in a chain of commerce that stretches from the pastures of Inner Mongolia to the designer boutiques of New York, Paris and London.

title: Confidence Unexpectedly Shows a Rise
description: Consumer sentiment has unexpectedly risen this month, suggesting that tax refunds and an accelerating economy are giving Americans reasons for optimism even as job growth lags.

title: The Brain? It's A Jungle in There
description: Spend enough time talking with Dr. Gerald M. Edelman, and eventually his theory about how consciousness develops will seem confirmed by experience. Somehow, out of anecdotes about Andy Warhol, Friedrich von Hayek, Jascha Heifetz and Linus Pauling, out of free-floating riffs, vaudevillian jokes, recollections, citations, arguments and patient explanations, out of the excited explosions of example and counterexample, associations develop, mental terrain is reordered, and ever grander patterns emerge.

title: Economy Is the Star of the Campaign Trail as Bush and Kerry Court Voters
description: The presidential race turned squarely to the economy on Friday, as Senator John Kerry courted this hard-hit state with a promise of new jobs, while President Bush promoted his tax cuts as an engine for growth.

title: Four-Month Walkout Ended At Oyster Bar Restaurant
description: Striking workers at the Oyster Bar restaurant in Grand Central Terminal returned to work yesterday after reaching an agreement that ended their nearly four-month walkout.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dual career couples : Trailing spouse's job needs start to get more company time
description: VIENNA  Ruth Whitby loves her husband, Ben  and she also loves her job. When he was transferred to Japan, Whitby, a British medical doctor, struggled for a year to get a license to practice in Japan. She eventually succeeded and built a thriving medical practice in Tokyo, only to see her diplomat husband transferred again. This time all attempts at practicing medicine in their new home of Vienna failed.

title: When You Aren't Who You Think You Are
description: We first meet Cristina Quadri, the heroine of Gastn Biraben's "Captive," at her 15th birthday party, in 1994. She appears to be a perfectly ordinary, if exceptionally lovely, Buenos Aires teenager. Cristina lives with her doting upper-middle-class family (her father, now retired, was an officer in the national police force) and attends a starchy Catholic girls' school, where she daydreams through her lessons and sneaks cigarettes with her best friend. But Brbara Lombardo, the extraordinary young actress who plays Cristina, has the kind of soft, melancholy features that seem to hold reservoirs of emotion, as if she were haunted by the memory  or perhaps the premonition  of an unbearable hurt.

title: Fast Saliva Test for H.I.V. Gains Federal Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved yesterday the first H.I.V. test that uses saliva rather than blood and delivers results in 20 minutes.

title: Bumper to Bumper, Travelers Ride Out An I-95 Nightmare
description: Nearly two miles of Interstate 95, the main highway linking New York and Boston, will be closed for one to two weeks and require millions of dollars in repairs after a fiery truck crash Thursday night that buckled part of an overpass here, Gov. John G. Rowland said on Friday.

title: A New Prescription for the Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay? No Marriage License Here. Straight? Ditto.
description: Here in the rain-soaked Willamette Valley, wedding season doesn't arrive in earnest until July. But that didn't stop Benton County from jilting everyone at the altar this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the new exhibition of Byzantine art at the Metropolitan Museum credited its curator, Helen C. Evans, erroneously with having organized an earlier Byzantium exhibition also. The curator of ''The Age of Spirituality'' was Kurt Weitzmann. (Ms. Evans mounted another previous show on Byzantium, in 1997.)

description: The testimony of Richard A. Clarke illustrates the perennial problem with intelligence: how do you get leaders to accept information they do not want to believe?

description: Correction Appended

title: Calhouns Concerns Dont Seem Troubling
description: PHOENIX, March 26 — Jim Calhoun says he has to have something to fret about. The best he can come up with is the idea that his team has not yet been tested in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: No Doubt On Result As Kansas Cruises
description: The University of Alabama at Birmingham brought a style called ''the fastest 40 minutes in basketball'' into the regional semifinals of the N.C.A.A. tournament Friday against Kansas.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Bald Eagles Make Chicago Home
description: Two bald eagles have created a nest on the southern outskirts of Chicago, the first time in 100 years that this once-endangered species has ventured so near the city. The birds, which do not yet appear to have laid eggs, have settled alongside the Little Calumet River about 15 miles south of the Loop. The bald eagle population has rejuvenated since the 1970's; there are 3,980 in Illinois, according to a recent count. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Senator John Kerry's support for a plan to increase fuel economy standards omitted a passage at the continuation in some copies. The affected section should have read, '' 'We've all talked to the Kerry camp individually, and together,' said Gov. Jennifer Granholm of Michigan, a Democrat whose husband is one of two state campaign chairmen for Mr. Kerry.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by pension fund administrators to transform corporate America misstated the purpose of a meeting of state officials in July 2002. It was to consider measures to protect investors after the scandals in the investment banking industry -- not to plan a response to the WorldCom bankruptcy.

title: Washington Fires Health Chief Over Handling of Lead in Water
description: With concern growing over unsafe lead levels in the drinking water here, city officials blamed the federal government this week for the problem. On Friday, the city fired the head of the Health Department because, the officials said, he had in part not adequately responded to the problem.

title: An Injured Houston Inspires the Knicks
description: When Knicks guard Allan Houston hobbled off the floor only eight minutes into last night's game, the Knicks were losing to Toronto and his aborted attempt at helping his team regain some grip on a slippery playoff spot looked like pure folly.

title: An Agonizing Dance of Love Is Choreographed for Three
description: One of the most heart-wrenching French movies of recent years, ''Eager Bodies'' lures you into an excruciating cul-de-sac where love, hate, jealousy, despair and guilt become so intertwined that the movie's three characters live out a variation of Sartre's ''No Exit.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRACCO, RICHARD A., M.D.
description: BRACCO--Richard A., M.D. on March 5, 2004. Preceded in death by his loving wife Janet and daughter Alice. Survived by sons Andrew, Edward and Arthur and brother Arthur, as well as four beautiful grandchildren. We will always remember his enthusiasm for life and passionate pursuit of all that interested him.

title: Driver Killed And Traffic Is Tied Up At Goethals
description: An accident involving four trucks near the toll plaza of the Goethals Bridge killed at least one man yesterday and snarled traffic for miles between Staten Island and New Jersey.

title: DIRECTV SELLS STAKE IN XM SATELLITE FOR $230 MILLION
description: The DirecTV Group, the satellite television service, sold its remaining stake in XM Satellite Radio Holdings to exit a business unrelated to consumer television. DirecTV sold nine million shares of XM, the satellite radio provider, for about $230 million, a DirecTV spokesman, Bob Marsocci, said. DirecTV is shedding assets unrelated to its consumer satellite service, Mr. Marsocci said. The company sold some of its XM holdings in January and has said it may sell its 81 percent stake in the PanAmSat Corporation, another commercial-satellite operator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KIACHIF, M. FRED
description: KIACHIF--M. Fred, 83, of Greenwich, CT, died Tuesday in Greenwich Hospital. Husband of Carol Valenzano Kiachif. Memorial Mass will be held Monday at 10 AM in St. Mary's R.C. Church, 178 Greenwich Ave., Greenwich. Friends may call at the Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home, 267 Greenwich Ave., Greenwich from 4-8 PM on Saturday and from 2-6 PM on Sunday. Memorial contributions may be made to Kids in Crisis, 1 Salem St., Cos Cob, CT. 06807.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parmalat Meets With Creditors
description: Enrico Bondi, the administrator of Parmalat, left, held his first meeting with creditors to outline a plan to save the insolvent food company from liquidation. The plan, first made public last week, calls for asset sales outside of Italy and the conversion of most of Parmalat's $18 billion in bonds and bank debt into shares. The asset sales would cut Parmalat's work force in half, to about 17,000 employees, according to the chairman of the consumer group Adoc, Carlo Pileri, who attended the meeting in Milan with Mr. Bondi. A final version of the plan is subject to approval by Parmalat's creditors. Eric Sylvers (NYT)

title: A Battle-Hardened Guard Gives St. Joseph's the Edge
description: To Tyrone Barley, the bald man on the sideline is not Phil, as he likes to be called by his players, or Coach, as he will accept. He is simply Martelli. Barley, St. Joseph's senior guard, also confesses to being the only person on Hawk Hill to be bummed last June when the all-American guard Jameer Nelson decided to skip the N.B.A. draft .

title: World Business Briefing | Australia And New Zealand: New Zealand: Tissue Concern Acquired
description: Svenska Cellulosa of Sweden is buying the tissue business of Carter Holt Harvey of New Zealand for 1.01 billion New Zealand dollars ($658 million). Carter Holt, just over half-owned by the International Paper Company, put the tissue unit up for sale in November to focus on its core forestry and wood products business.

title: Ladies of Hip-Hop, Receiving Their Due
description: Respect, independence, fidelity and great sex that's what the women on the Ladies First Tour want, and they'll bump and grind to get it. The tour features Beyonc, Alicia Keys and Missy Elliott, with a brief opening set from Tamia, and they filled Nassau Coliseum on Thursday night with fans who cheered every affirmation of a woman's worth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHUTZ--Bernard, on March 25, 2004 at age 85. Adoring father of Liz Weinstein and Caroline Schutz, and grandfather of William and Matthew. Dear brother of Harriet Miller and Edward Schutz. Loving father-in-law of Steven Weinstein and future father-in-law of David Gould. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Sunday March 28th, 11:30AM.

title: GENERAL MARITIME TO BUY SOPONATA FOR $415 MILLION
description: The General Maritime Corporation, an operator of midsize tankers, agreed to buy a rival, Soponata of Portugal, for about $415 million to expand its fleet. Soponata, Portugal's largest oil shipper, will extend General Maritime's reach in the Atlantic basin. The purchase includes five vessels, contracts for four ships under construction and a management company, General Maritime said. It will help the company increase earnings and lower the average age of its fleet, the chief executive, Peter Georgiopoulos, said on a conference call in New York, where the company is based.

title: Bill Would Help Thousands Exposed to 9/11 Dust Plume
description: Thousands of people who live or work in Lower Manhattan and were exposed to the dust plume after the World Trade Center attack would be eligible to undergo health screening under a bill expected to be introduced in Congress on Monday.

title: Democrats' Ads in Tandem Provoke G.O.P.
description: Senator John Kerry's advertising campaign is so closely complemented by those of two major liberal groups running commercials against President Bush that Republicans are accusing the Democrats of trying to evade campaign finance laws.

description: Should pure silliness be allowed to sound this ravishing? Unforgivable puns, kindergarten-level double entendres, a plot that staggers like a drunken dervish and a chorus line of dancing psychiatrists all named Freud, Adler or Jung. Hey, isn't this the surefire turkey that Bialystock and Bloom were trying to come up with in ''The Producers''?

title: Corrections

title: Smarter Welfare Reform
description: The Welfare Reform Act of 1996 cut the national welfare caseload by more than half. But hundreds of thousands of families could end up back in poverty -- and on the dole -- unless Congress honors its longstanding commitment to provide child care, not just for welfare recipients who must work outside the home in exchange for benefits, but also for low-income families who are struggling to stay off welfare. They have a better chance of succeeding if the government helps them with day care.

description: RUPP -- Lawrence C. on March 26, 2004. Loving son of the late John and Anastasia. Dear brother of William, Gerald, and John. Cherished uncle of five. For further information contact the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, 718-429-0552.

title: 2 Officers Hit by Livery Cab in Brooklyn
description: Two police officers were injured, one seriously, after they were hit by a livery cab in Brooklyn early today while they were chasing a man with a gun, the police said. The cab, they said, then kept going.

description: For decades, whenever the topic of genocide has come up, the refrain has been, ''Never again.''

title: Stirrings on Clean Air
description: Michael Leavitt, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has before him two excellent opportunities to improve the Bush administration's dismal record on clean air issues. The first, which he seems willing to grasp, is to overhaul his agency's pallid proposal to reduce mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants. The second is to strengthen a companion proposal aimed at reducing smog and acid rain.

title: Fast Recovery After Disasters Offers Hope to Connecticut
description: Although the section of an Interstate 95 overpass in Connecticut where a tractor-trailer exploded on Thursday is badly damaged, engineers, working under emergency conditions, may be able to restore the span surprisingly quickly, if similar accidents elsewhere in the country offer any guidance.

title: Spain Says It Holds Half of Group That Bombed Trains
description: Spanish investigators believe that they have identified the core group of Islamic militants who carried out the deadly train bombings in Madrid this month and that more than half of those involved are now in custody, a senior Spanish official said Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADLER, ELIAS

title: Faster, Simpler Test Approved for H.I.V.
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first H.I.V. test that uses saliva rather than blood and delivers results in 20 minutes. Public health officials hope it will encourage wider testing. About 25 percent of Americans carrying the virus do not know that they are infected, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates.

description: WASHINGTON  In today's climate of global tension, the monuments to the American founding fathers may stand as inspiration or paradox for many expatriates making their way in the nation's capital.
