title: Only One Lead Was Wrong, And It Led to a 31-Imp Swing
description: At the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Reno, Nev., four world-class teams battled on Friday in the semifinal stage of the Vanderbilt Knockout, the planet's oldest championship.

title: A Dogged Pursuit of Detail in a Violent Land
description: The weary acceptance of violence in an atmosphere of perpetual siege is the subject of the Israeli journalist David Ofek's small, chilly documentary ''No. 17.'' The film, which has its first of two screenings as part of the New Directors/New Films series tonight at the Gramercy Theater, is a glum detective story in which the filmmaker methodically tracks down the name and hometown of the sole unidentified victim in the suicide bombing on June 5, 2002, at Meggido Junction, near Tel Aviv. After a car packed with explosives struck a bus, 16 of the 17 victims were accounted for.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Walt Disney Company's problems in filming ''The Alamo'' misstated the distance between Austin, Tex., and Dripping Springs, where the studio recreated the Alamo and 19th-century San Antonio. It is 22 miles, not 75.

title: Trump Drops Golf Course In Favor Of Homes
description: In the 1990's, Donald Trump snatched up hundreds of acres of land in Westchester and Putnam Counties with visions of building four gilded golf courses. One was built: the Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor, famed for its over-the-top 13th hole, featuring a 101-foot black granite waterfall.

title: Looking Homeward, With Mahler and Adams
description: Michael Tilson Thomas's grandparents Boris and Bessie Thomashefsky were legendary figures of the Yiddish theater whose productions catered to the language and the longing of immigrant Jews in their new American homes.

title: STAPLES MAKES ACQUISITION TO EXPAND IN BRITAIN
description: Staples agreed to buy Globus Office World from the Globus Group of Switzerland for about $59 million to expand in Britain. Globus Office World, which is based in London, operates 59 stores, Staples said. The transaction must be reviewed by Office of Fair Trade in Britain, Staples said. Staples operates 93 stores in Britain and plans to open 20 stores in Europe this fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PSYHOS, HELEN
description: PSYHOS -- Helen, 90, on March 22, 2004 in California. Helen and her husband Sarantos owned Windsor Florists in Manhattan until 1980 when they retired to Florida. Preceded in death by her husband and son Sarantos, Jr., she is survived by daughter Elenitsa Fields, granddaughter Marika Rice, sister Evelyn Patsalos and many nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway, Tuesday & Wednesday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Services at Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 E. 74th St., Thursday, April 1 at 10 AM.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Yahoo Buys Vendor
description: Yahoo said that it had agreed to buy a European e-commerce provider, Kelkoo, for $579 million to widen its worldwide shopping services and generate new advertising opportunities overseas. The addition of Kelkoo, which specializes in online comparison shopping, gives Yahoo the world's broadest e-commerce network, Yahoo said. Kelkoo, which is based in Paris, is the largest online shopping service originating in Europe, with an average of 30 million site visitors a month. The company provides comparative product information on a range of items, from books to electronics devices, through a network of about 2,500 retailers. The Kelkoo deal is the latest move by Yahoo to expand its marketing and advertising prospects.

title: Stepping In, China to Rule On Hong Kong Democracy
description: The Chinese government said Friday that it would decide next week what moves toward democracy will be allowed here in coming years, angering democracy advocates here.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Reversal In Gay-Parent Case
description: A state appeals court overturned a lower court order that barred a man from exposing his son to his ''gay lifestyle.'' The appeals court had upheld the order in January, though it had overturned a two-day jail sentence imposed on the father, Joseph R. Hogue Jr., for violating it by telling his son he is gay. In its new decision, prompted by Mr. Hogue's request for reconsideration, the three-judge panel said the lower court's order was too vague and noted that ''neither gay parents nor heterosexual parents have special rights.'' Adam Liptak (NYT)

title: Why Nobody Saw 9/11 Coming
description: Did the Bush administration, before the 9/11 attacks, fail to take terrorism seriously enough? At first the contention seems unlikely. Isn't this the most hawkish administration in living memory? Wasn't it President Bush who coined the phrase ''war on terror''?

title: 8 HOSTAGES KILLED IN PAKISTAN SIEGE
description: Eight Pakistani soldiers who had been taken hostage by militants in Pakistan's tribal areas have been executed, officials said Friday, in the latest sign that the effort by Pakistan's government to flush foreign militants from the region has gone badly awry.

title: Deal Is Close on Landmark Church Near Central Park
description: The answering machine at the First Church of Christ, Scientist, a century-old granite-clad landmark that towers over Central Park at West 96th Street, may sound oddly mercantile.

title: Yanks Debark in Japan on Matsui's Red Carpet
description: It is almost a rite of passage in the major leagues. When a high-profile free agent leaves his team in the prime of his career, he is jeered when he returns to his former home. It happened to Alex Rodriguez in Seattle. It happened to Jason Giambi in Oakland. But it will not happen to Hideki Matsui in Tokyo.

title: Mylan Loses Suit on Generic Pain Patch
description: Mylan Laboratories, a maker of generic drugs, has lost a patent lawsuit that will delay its generic version of the Duragesic pain-relief skin patch.

description: Serena Williams gave a peek into her confidence level as she made her return to tennis Friday after an eight-month layoff: she has assured her Nike dress designers that, while she is concerned with looking good on the court, she does not have to be as comfortable in her clothes as the next player.

title: Expat adviser : How to vote in U.S. election
description: [Q.] We've received many e-mails from Americans abroad seeking information on voting. Here is some basic information on how to vote and where to go if you need help.

title: Finance Group for L.I. Diocese Calls Reserve Funds Adequate
description: The financial overseers of Long Island's Roman Catholic diocese say that its reserves are barely adequate, disputing an accountant's criticism that it has been hoarding funds.

title: RESEARCH IN MOTION TO BE PAID IN SETTLEMENT OF SUITS
description: Research in Motion, the maker of BlackBerry pagers, will receive a payment for an undisclosed amount from Good Technology to settle a series of lawsuits between the companies. Research in Motion will receive a lump- sum settlement in the first quarter of fiscal 2005 and quarterly royalties thereafter, the companies said in a joint statement. The companies declined to disclose the terms of the settlement. Research in Motion, which is based in Canada, sued in June 2002, claiming Good Technology infringed four patents through the sale of hand-held communication devices and its GoodLink mobile e-mail service that works with BlackBerry equipment. Good Technology, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., also sued Research in Motion in federal court in May 2002, asking a judge to declare invalid Research in Motion's patent for wireless e-mail technology.

title: J. Crew Reports a Loss, but a Narrower One
description: The J. Crew Group, an operator of casual-clothing stores that began as a catalog retailer, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss narrowed to $19.4 million after it cut discounts and updated merchandise.

title: Burgers Make A Mayor's Day
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is no fan of the Atkins diet, but chances are he would not pass up that big, fat, juicy burger, either.

title: Chip Designer Accuses Intel And Dell of Patent Violations
description: A chip design company that was once one of Silicon Valley's highfliers filed a patent infringement suit yesterday against Intel and Dell, contending the companies have copied its technology for multimedia computing.

title: U.S. General Envisions Libya as Possible Ally
description: The senior American commander for Europe and North Africa expressed optimism on Friday that Libya was on the path to becoming a valuable military partner in fighting terrorism.

title: U.S. Trims Request for Exemptions From Pact on Saving Ozone Layer
description: The United States and 10 other nations agreed yesterday to reduce their requests for exemptions to a ban on methyl bromide, one of the last remaining ozone-destroying compounds being produced and used extensively in wealthy countries.

title: Blake to Miss a Month
description: Islanders center Jason Blake, the team's second-leading scorer with 47 points, has a sprained ankle and will miss at least a month, the team said yesterday. He was hurt apparently when he collided with the Flyers' Tony Amonte during the Islanders' 4-2 victory Thursday in Philadelphia. Steve Webb has been called up from Bridgeport of the American Hockey League as a replacement. Ron Dicker

title: Beliefs; Some believers, believe it or not, are cringing at the defense of 'one nation under God.'
description: Americans who take religion seriously must surely have winced this week at some of the defenses mounted of the phrase ''under God'' in the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Johnson & Johnson, New Brunswick, N.J., the world's biggest maker of medical devices, said its Centocor unit that makes the rheumatoid arthritis drug Remicade agreed to buy a manufacturing plant in St. Louis from Wyeth, Madison, N.J., the health care products company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Annan, At Rwanda Memorial, Admits U.N. Blame
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan opened a United Nations memorial conference on the 1994 mass killings in Rwanda by accepting personal and institutional blame for the massacre of 800,000 people that occurred after the Security Council declined to send extra troops to bolster a small peacekeeping force. Mr. Annan, who was then head of United Nations peacekeeping, said, ''I believed at the time I was doing my best, but I realized after the genocide that there was more that I could and should have done to sound the alarm and rally support.'' A 1999 report held the United Nations, the United States and other Security Council members responsible. Mr. Annan said, ''None of us must ever forget, or be allowed to forget, that genocide did take place in Rwanda, or that it was highly organized, or that it was carried out in broad daylight.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

description: An increasing number of new-car buyers are finding themselves owing more than their trade-ins are worth.

title: History Reappears in Argentina
description: Thousands of Argentines were kidnapped, tortured and killed by military death squads during the 1970's and early 1980's -- most of them innocent casualties of a dirty war against leftist dissenters and guerrillas. The governments of that era offered no information about the fates of these victims. Relatives and friends were merely told that their loved ones had disappeared. When democratic rule returned in 1983, there was an initial attempt to render a public accounting. Then, intimidated by a succession of military protests and revolts, Argentine governments backed off, hoping the issue itself would fade away, to become the ultimate ''desaparecido.''

title: Dear Editor...
description: Q.I am going soon to my first gay wedding, the ''I do'''s of my nephew and his companion. But the whole idea of a grand, gay wedding ceremony and reception seems to me to be an open call for a topsy-turvy mad hatter's tea party. Which one is the bride? Am I a member of the bride's family or the groom's? Who dances with the father first? Who throws the bouquet? Who is eligible to catch it? And, frankly, I have never actually seen two men kiss in person. Don't you suppose there will be some kind of kiss at the altar to seal the deal? The entire prospect makes me nervous, and when I am nervous, I tend to get the giggles and say very silly things. Should I just stay home?

title: New Barbados Rules For North Americans
description: Responding to fears of terrorism and increased security rules throughout the world, the government of Barbados is now requiring visitors from the United States and Canada to show valid passports to enter the country. In recent years, North Americans needed only photo identification and an original birth certificate or proof of citizenship to visit the island. In the 1970's, hoping to lure more tourists, Barbados loosened its entry requirements for United States and Canadian citizens. The decision to tighten the entry regulations ''was made for obvious reasons,'' said Bill Silvermintz, Barbados's vice president for marketing for the Americas. ''We felt we needed to be as responsible as the rest of the world, post 9/11.''

title: I Saw Her on the L Train
description: THE New York subway has become the city's last bastion of hope for romantics. That's partly because the subway is one of the only places where people aren't subdivided into small cliques depending on social class or musical tastes. And instead of the carefully selected and touched-up photos that people present online, under the bright, fluorescent lights of the subway you can see exactly what someone looks like. There is no dark lighting to cover a premature wrinkle, a scary makeup job or a bad hair day.

title: Pandoras Baby
description: On a cool fall morning in 1973, Doris and John Del-Zio arrived with her luggage at New York Hospital. It was a familiar routine for the Florida couple; Doris had been a patient there before. On three earlier occasions her Manhattan infertility specialist, William Sweeney, had tried surgically to remove obstructions in Doris's blocked fallopian tubes. The first surgery worked and Doris became pregnant, but three months along she had a miscarriage. The second and third surgeries had no effect at all. Neither did attempts at artificial insemination using her husband's sperm, not after the first insemination, nor the second, nor the third. Month after month after disappointing month, Doris Del-Zio, then approaching thirty, got her menstrual period, and each one was a stinging rebuke. Every period taunted her-no baby, no baby, no baby-forcing her to acknowledge that she still wasn't pregnant and probably never would be. Maybe she and John should have just left well enough alone.

title: 'Against All Enemies'
description: Iexpected to go back to a round of meetings examining what the next attacks could be, what our vulnerabilities were, what we could do about them in the short term. Instead, I walked into a series of discussions about Iraq. At first I was incredulous that we were talking about something other than getting al Qaeda. Then I realized with almost a sharp physical pain that Rumsfeld and Wolfowitz were going to try to take advantage of this national tragedy to promote their agenda about Iraq. Since the beginning of the administration, indeed well before, they had been pressing for a war with Iraq. My friends in the Pentagon had been telling me that the word was we would be invading Iraq sometime in 2002.

title: Less Wackiness, More Dad

The doctor who treated her painful sun condition prescribed a healing steroid cream that gave her a luxuriant furze of facial hair. ''I went door to door with this burn, the mustache and a sack of knives,'' she said. ''I ended up winning two trophies and a VCR for selling the most knives in the tri-state area.''

title: BackTalk; Tournament Has Become March Monopoly Madness
description: Every March, college basketball fans have been primed to experience one of the world's most powerful monopolies -- the N.C.A.A. tournament. This event, which is enjoying a $6 billion, 11-year agreement with CBS, has become the poster child for commercialism in college sports and all of its adverse consequences on student athletes. What most fans don't realize, however, is that the N.C.A.A. tournament did not acquire, and does not maintain, its monopoly fairly. It does so through a set of anticompetitive rules that force all invited schools, under pain of severe penalty, to participate only in the N.C.A.A. tournament and to boycott any competing events. This was not always the case.

description: This small city in the state's Southern Tier was not the setting for fence painting or frog-jumping contests, and its river could never compare with the Mississippi. But that mattered none to Mark Twain, who spent many summers and wrote some of his most famous works here. It was in Elmira, from his sister-in-law's hilltop farm overlooking the Chemung Valley, that Twain imagined Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn.

This is the domain of Edgardo Zamora, who at 43 is Hollywood's leading ''ambience designer,'' responsible for the look of many of L.A.'s most glamorous events, including the wedding of Brad Pitt and Jennifer Aniston, the Academy Awards Governors Ball, the opening of the Walt Disney concert hall and the premieres of movies like ''Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle'' and ''The Matrix: Revolutions.''

title: Mayor With A Mission
description: Jason West, the mayor of the little Hudson Valley village of New Paltz who married 25 gay couples last month before receiving a court injunction to stop, has been thinking about gay marriage for a long time. In fact, immediately after taking office last summer, the two things the 27-year-old asked his new village attorney to check on were, first, the state and local beaver trapping laws, since a dog had recently been caught and killed in a beaver trap on the old Bienstock property -- a huge New Paltz scandal that was soon labeled Beavergate; and second, whether a mayor could perform gay marriages. The attorney, Spencer McLaughlin, is a Republican legislator from Orange County and a former deputy executive director of the New York City Human Rights Commission under Ed Koch. That West would turn to a Republican for advice was a surprise to the people who thought the mayor, who was elected on the Green Party line, was a radical liberal activist about to turn the town into a socialist enclave. In his reply to West, McLaughlin noted that the law is unclear. ''That's because the laws were written around the late 19th century, and no one ever conceived of wanting to do this then,'' McLaughlin said recently. The attorney ended his memo to mayor saying, ''That's a very long-winded explanation of why you can't perform a same-sex marriage, but does not address the issue of whether you should or not.''

title: Somebody Big Slept Here
description: ROBERT AND JILL CARR had been living in Princeton for nearly a dozen years last March when they noticed that a house on Library Place was for sale. It was a Tudor, built in 1896 but renovated and modernized several times over the years. It was set back from the somewhat busy street with lots of other beautiful houses surrounding it. It seemed like a place they'd like to move themselves and their three teenage children into.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLERTSON, CHARLOTTE, PH.D.
description: ELLERTSON -- Charlotte, Ph.D. March 22, 2004, breast cancer. The Members, Counsel, associates, paralegals and staff of Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy deeply mourn the untimely passing of Dr. Charlotte Ellertson, wife of our colleague and Member, Paull Hejinian. Dr. Ellertson, although only 38, was an internationally recognized expert and spokesperson in the field of women's reproductive rights. She worked for Population Council for a number of years, traveling worldwide, leading research efforts and developing health programs. Most recently, Dr. Ellertson founded Ibis Reproductive Health, an international women's reproductive rights, research and advocacy group headquartered in Cambridge, Massachusetts. She wrote widely in the field and contributed to numerous publications. Dr. Ellertson led an extraordinarily accomplished life in a tragically short period of time. It was simply impossible to meet Charlotte and not be deeply impressed. Our entire firm extends its heartfelt condolences to Paull, daughters Marka (4) and Amy (2) and all of the family. Fragomen, Del Rey, Bernsen & Loewy, P.C.

title: Habitats/West 73rd Street; Acting Couple Set Up A Room With a Brew
description: TEMPERATURE is an issue -- the issue -- for Adair Moran and Nicholas Little, two young actors living in a studio apartment on West 73rd Street. They're brewing beer there, and beer likes to ferment at a cool 65 degrees.

description: EUROPEANS continue to pile into subways, streetcars, buses and trains, nearly three weeks after terrorist bombs ripped apart four commuter trains in Madrid, killing 202 people, wounding more than 1,800, and bringing the specter of radical Islamic terrorism to the Continent.

title: If the Subway Had Never Been
description: THEY are the events that gave birth to modern New York. In 1898, the five boroughs united in one enormous city of more than 300 square miles and upward of 3.4 million people. Two years later, to serve the huge new city, New York's fledgling Rapid Transit Commission contracted with the financier August Belmont to build, equip and operate the first stage of an unprecedented underground railroad system. In 1904, the first trains rumbled below the streets, and by the time the United States entered World War II the combined routes of the IRT, BMT and IND included more than 400 stations and more than 700 miles of track.

title: Virginia Political Shocker: Republicans for High Taxes
description: In a year when Republicans nationwide are embracing President Bush's tax-cutting mantra, an influential group of Republican state senators here is advocating the unthinkable: a multibillion-dollar tax increase that dwarfs a competing proposal by the Democratic governor.

title: The New Math of Long-Term Care Insurance
description: LONG-TERM care insurance is one of those financial products you know you should have but can't imagine being able to afford. If you don't have it and eventually need it, you'll be kicking yourself. If you buy a policy and don't use it, you may still be kicking yourself.

title: Some Bumps in the Road for Corporate Bonds
description: THE corporate bond rally, which has provided a return of 17 percent in 17 months, is running into head winds.

title: It's Brash, It's British, It's Not PBS
description: A YOUNG woman working for a married politician is murdered, and her boss is forced to reveal their affair -- it sounds so American, so Gary Condit-Chandra Levy. But if the politician is a Member of Parliament you have ''State of Play,'' a sophisticated, cynical British thriller arriving next month on the cable network BBC America. With tricky investigative journalists and a politically connected oil company, this mini-series translates so fluently for Americans that it may become the network's defining drama, just as the brilliant mock-documentary ''The Office'' has become its signature comedy.

title: The Passions of the Repeat Viewers
description: ON St. Patrick's Day, March 17, Mel Gibson's ''Passion of the Christ'' was three weeks into its $300 million (and counting) run and still drawing a big enough crowd to make it the nation's top box-office draw. The film has generated passionate opinions -- among critics, who have not been kind to it, and among audience members, many of whom have been so moved by what they saw that they returned for second and third screenings. To find out why the controversial film is still attracting viewers at a point in its release when most other films have already tapered off, Alex Abramovich visited the AMC Empire 25 on West 42nd Street. Over the course of 16 screenings that day, 642 people had attended the film, resulting in $6,091 worth of tickets sales. Some members of the audience were out-of-towners who said they had waited to see it while vacationing in New York, and some were New Yorkers returning for repeat viewings. No one said they had come expressly for the gore, but most said that the violence was warranted by what they saw as the film's moral: that the degree of Christ's suffering was directly proportional to Christ's love for mankind. In some cases, at least, what the viewers had gotten out of the movie seemed to depend entirely on what they brought to it. Herewith, a sampling of their comments.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 14 about the Forum Barcelona 2004, a festival for artists, intellectuals and politicians this summer, misstated the origin of the Poble Espanyol, or Spanish Village, a section of Barcelona that represents architectural styles of Spain. It was built for the 1929 Universal Exhibition, not the 1992 Olympics. In addition, the singer Maria del Mar Bonet, who will perform during the festival, was described incorrectly. She is from Majorca, not Catalonia.

title: Long After Guerrilla War, Survivors Demand Justice From Brazil's Government
description: At the cemetery here, a half dozen bodies once secretly buried have been unearthed. More skeletons have been recovered from an Indian reservation just to the north. Somewhere out in the jungle lie the remains of 50 or so others, whose relatives are now belatedly demanding justice.

title: Screech, Memory
description: MY first memory of boarding the IRT was of not boarding the IRT: my mother getting on at the Simpson Street station in the East Bronx while I daydreamed on the platform. As the doors slid shut between us, she took her seat and, with what seemed an eerie calm, regarded me as I frantically slapped my palms on the outside of the windows. I was 4 years old, and when a faceless Samaritan forced the doors to reopen, I rocketed across the car into her lap, acutely aware that some of the passengers were softly laughing at my oversized relief.

title: North Korea Rejects U.S. Demand to Scrap Its Nuclear Programs
description: North Korean radio on Saturday explicitly rejected the formula the United States has put forward as its bottom-line position in talks aimed at ending North Korea's nuclear programs, raising doubts about whether the fitful negotiations are making even limited progress.

title: The White Zone is for Loading and Unloading Art
description: PEOPLE don't often go to an airport for the art, but that might begin to change next month when travelers start hustling by Gate 122 of the new Terminal 1 at Pearson International Airport in Toronto. Here, working from high up on a scissor lift, the German artist Katharina Grosse spray-painted a 75-foot-long burst of color on the gleaming white walls. Unruly abstract clouds of orange and pink climb up into the skylights and surround the windows as if this Air Canada gate were an Abstract Expressionist chapel. Ms. Grosse thinks her mural ''looks like a child has gone mad with a felt pen.'' But really it looks like artists have taken over the building.

description: VINE--Shirley Sarah. March 23, 2004. Beloved youngest child of the late Mollie and Samuel Vine. Sister of bereaved Dorothy Vine. I loved you not only as a sister but as my child. Forever innocent, forever pure, forever loving, forever beloved, forever remembered. Donations may be made to New Horizons Resources for the Retarded, 21 Van Wagner Rd, Poughkeepsie, NY 12603.

description: MELISSA DVORAK and 20 other M.B.A. students from Indiana University's Kelley School of Business decided to spend spring break this year traveling around India. But the trip was not meant to be a vacation.

title: All Over the Maps
description: CONTRARY to the assertion that real men do not ask strangers for directions, or consult a map when sightseeing (''Trust me, the baguette museum is in that direction!''), my travel strategy unabashedly employs both, sometimes to an extreme. Maps, in particular, are my obsession, and I study them avidly and incessantly, even when I'm not going anywhere.

title: The Human Factor
description: How much is your life worth to you? On the face of it, that's an idiotic question. No amount of money could compensate you for the loss of your life, for the simple reason that the money would be no good to you if you were dead. And you might feel, for different reasons, that the dollar value of the lives of your spouse or children -- or even a stranger living on the other side of the country -- is also infinite. No one should be knowingly sacrificed for a sum of money: that's what we mean when we say that human life is priceless.

title: Dane, Go Home
description: To the Editor:

title: The Year of Living Dangerously
description: When Michael Ignatieff remakes his case for the war in Iraq, or at least for his support for it, he makes those of us who opposed the war sound cowardly or indifferent or nave at best. But it was clear as day to many who opposed the war that the way the Bush administration promoted it and thought about it made winning the war and the peace a very long shot. It is not enough to have the right motives; a war-making administration also has to know what it is doing. The important thing about the failure to find W.M.D.'s and the failure to pacify Iraq and the failure to protect the treasures, the infrastructure and the women of Iraq is that these failures were foreseen by many who opposed the war. The war could never have gone the way the Bush administration claimed that it would because the administration didn't have the wherewithal to make that happen. In trusting the Bush administration's competence, it was Ignatieff who was nave.

title: Give Us Produce. Hold the Farmer.

For those who make their living off their gardens, this is particularly troubling.

title: The Year of Living Dangerously

title: Shrimp Cocktail
description: In this age of power drinks and protein shakes, when people skip breakfast entirely, grab ''a bite'' for lunch and drink dinner from a can, food has become as much about speed as taste, and convenience is now as important as nutrition. So when entertaining, why not save time by combining cocktails and appetizers into one quick course? At least that's waht the photographer James Wojcik and the guerrilla food stylist Brett Kurzweil wondered. Their answer is a series of tiny, layered concoctions, including the Incan Ruin here, as beautiful as they are mulitifaceted. ''We wanted to present people with a whole range of flavors -- from the spicy to the sweet -- in one drink,'' Wojcik says. adds Kurzweil, ''We're hoping to start a new drink dialogue.'' Michael Boodro

title: Carmakers Pull Plug On Electric Vehicles
description: FIVE to 10 years ago, when the future seemed to belong to electric cars -- and California clean-air rules forced reluctant automakers to offer them -- a small but enthusiastic group of optimists and environmentalists signed on as pioneers. While a few bought electrics outright, most signed leases that obliged them to return the vehicles after a few years.

title: Jill Gaspar and Mark Higgins
description: ALTHOUGH they were classmates in the early 1990's at Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., Jill Ann Gaspar and Mark Daniel Higgins never actually met there. That's because, friends agree, they inhabited distinctly different worlds.

description: A map with the Correspondent's Report column last Sunday about the marketing of Rwanda for tourism omitted a border and a country. Somalia lies to the east of Kenya and, beyond the edge of the map, east of Ethiopia. The corrected map appears below.

title: The Price of Open Space
description: FOR five years now, a fountain of money has allowed the five East End towns of Suffolk County to dramatically accelerate their efforts to preserve open space. Together the five towns have spent more than $170 million since 1999 to buy the title or development rights to 4,134 acres of farmland, woodland and other properties ranging from the pending acquisition of a private golf course to a nightclub with four acres of waterfront on Little Peconic Bay.

title: Chez Depardieu
description: Late last September, in the thick of a glorious Indian summer in Paris, I booked a table for dinner with my friend the film director Euzhan Palcy on the terrace of the hottest restaurant in town, La Fontaine Gaillon. It had been open for only three weeks, but already the place was creating a high-volume buzz across the city -- Isabelle Adjani, Jean Reno, the French rocker Johnny Hallyday and the French television fashion doyenne Marie-Christiane Marek had already been spotted there. The draw? It is owned by the actor Grard Depardieu and was decorated by his friend the actress Carole Bouquet. Another movie-star-owned eatery, I thought with a shrug. But Depardieu is a foodie, so I reasoned that even though he'd probably be an absent propritaire, the food would be particularly good.

description: If you have been tying flies, repairing waders, sorting out fishing gear or simply chafing at the bit in anticipation of good angling conditions on Thursday's opening of New York State's trout season, there is an excellent chance that the weather gods will grant your wish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WOLFE, HILDA
description: WOLFE--Hilda. 1910-2004. Our beloved mom died Saturday evening. She was wife of 65 years to Dr. Milton Wolfe. She was a lifelong inspiration to her three children, Allan, Robert and Wendy, and their spouses, Susan Wolfe, Jill Wolfe and Paul Goldberg, and loved by her surviving brother Phillip Savage. Her 15 grandchildren shared years of love, laughter and learning with her, and nine greatgrandchildren will learn more of her beauty and verve through the years. Her accomplishments were many but her greatest legacy of all is her adoring family. Hilda's vibrant spirit will always be a role model for all whose lives she touched. Beseme Mucho, Mom.

And they are not alone, either.

title: The Sly Fox of 'The Sly Fox'
description: LARRY GELBART'S career began at 16, when his father, a barber, bragged about his smart son to a customer -- the comedian Danny Thomas. Over 60 years, Mr. Gelbart, 76, wrote for all the greats, including Sid Caesar, Bob Hope and George Burns. He received Oscar nominations for ''Tootsie'' and ''Oh God.'' And he became a TV legend for his writing on the bitterly funny wartime sitcom ''M*A*S*H.'' He has also had a long presence on Broadway, having written the books for musicals, including ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' (with Burt Shevelove) and the 40's fantasia ''City of Angels.''

title: Joan Wasser, Jason Gish
description: Joan Michele Wasser, a senior policy adviser to Senator John Kerry, and Jason Charles Gish, a lawyer, were married last evening in Newport, R.I. Rabbi Richard J. Plavin officiated at the Hotel Viking.

title: Bumps Along the Rails
description: AS you ride the A train or the 2 train or any other line on the New York subway, you may want to mull an essential but mostly forgotten fact, one that could be posted aboard every train as a civics lesson.

title: Dorothy Denny Scardino, 82, Musical Star of the Bank Lobby
description: Dorothy Denny Scardino, a jazz pianist who rubbed elbows with the form's superstars but found her biggest following through a 25-year gig in a Manhattan bank lobby, died on March 9 at a hospice. She was 82 and had recently been told that she had cancer, her son Donald said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOVIA, JOSEPH
description: SOVIA--Joseph. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Joseph Sovia, associated with The Times from March 1956 until retiring in January 1977

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERGUSON, PERCIVAL, PHD
description: FERGUSON--Percival, PhD died February 29th at the age of 77 after battling Cancer. Percy was a Psychology Professor in upstate NY and a musician in Montreal, upstate NY and NYC. He was an avid recreational ice hockey goalie who played until the age of 69 at Sky Rink in Manhattan. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife Linda Ferguson (August 2, 2003). He is survived by two sons; trumpeter Peter Ferguson of Henderson, NV and Dr. David Ferguson (Dr. JoAnn Sekiguchi) of Ann Arbor, MI and his brother, jazz trumpeter Maynard Ferguson. Percy's charm and sense of humor will be missed dearly by all who knew him.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-22

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERNBERG, SAMUEL
description: STERNBERG -- Samuel, of Brooklyn, NY, passed away on Thursday, March 25th, 2004 at the age of 81. Beloved and devoted husband of his wife of 57 years, Beverly (nee Tartell), cherished father of Wilma, Marcia, and Stuart, adored grandfather of Marissa, Morgen, Sandy, Jake, Natalie, and Ella, loving fatherin-law of Michael, Lisa, and Charles. Mr. Sternberg graduated from Yeshiva of Flatbush in 1939, as part of its first graduating class. He was a proud WWII veteran, having served in the 3rd Army Resupply Squadron of the US Army Air Corps which supplied General George Patton's 3rd Army on its march through Europe. He was an officer of the Seaview Jewish Center and owned the Pillow Shop in Brooklyn, NY. All of us will miss him deeply for his support, wisdom, sense of humor and zest for life. He had a love for sports, movies, and good food, but most importantly, for good friends and good times. He was always so very proud of his whole family. Memorial services will be held at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Forest Hills, NY, on Sunday, March 28th, 2004 at 11 AM. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations may be made in his memory to the NYU Cardiovascular Center, c/o Dr. William Cole, 530 1st Ave., NY NY 10016.

title: Great Performers
description: I agree, in part, with your letter writer's contention that excellent acting ''remains the filmmaker's most valuable tool'' (March 14). But the subsequent question (''When was the last time you were emotionally moved by a special effect?'') demands a rejoinder.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; No Parking Worries At Norwalk Condos
description: EARLIER this month a new five-story, 750-car public garage owned by the City of Norwalk opened in South Norwalk opposite the Maritime Aquarium on North Water Street. The structure, which also holds 10 condominium apartments and three commercial condominium spaces, was financed with $11.5 million of city bonds and $3 million of private funds.

title: Russia; Cream of Dublin; Cornwall
description: Russia

title: The Limits of Opening Arteries
description: A changing notion of how heart attacks occur ought to lower expectations for the traditional methods used to prevent arteries from clogging shut. It has long been customary for cardiologists to treat narrowing arteries by either enlarging and holding open the restricted channel or performing bypass surgery to carry blood around the narrowed section. The problem is, the vast majority of heart attacks are now known to originate in sections of artery that have not yet narrowed.

title: President Asked Aide to Explore Iraq Link to 9/11 Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 - The White House acknowledged Sunday that on the day after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, President Bush pressed his top counterterrorism adviser, Richard A. Clarke, to find out whether Iraq was involved.

title: Coats From the Underground
description: THOUSANDS of people walk past Max Greenstein's new clothing store daily. His prices are reasonable. And there's no competition to speak of. But ever since he opened just before Christmas, he gets just a few dozen customers -- on good days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TANCER, MICHAEL
description: TANCER--Michael. Dearest husband of Francine Tancer for 55 years, passed away on March 24 after a long and beautiful life. Loving and greatly loved in return by his devoted daughters Joan and Susan and son-in-law Les Tolchin, granddaughter Jennifer and grandson Eric and sister Frances Decker. He loved and lived life fully with great courage fighting illness and disabilities with amazing determination. He served in the US Army Air Force Intelligence Unit during WW II in the Pacific. He graduated from NYU and the NYU Law School, however, his career was in business. He founded and was President of Tancer & Two a costume jewelry company. He was President of Coro, Inc. He was an avid reader, golfer, friend to many, elegant and handsome, generous & compassionate. Our mighty oak has fallen. We will miss him forever. Funeral services at Temple Kol Ami, White Plains, Monday March 29 at 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The American Cancer Society, or the Arthritis Foundation.

title: A Long Fuse Links Tangier To Bombings In Madrid
description: Here in the city's casbah, where European diplomats once competed for influence over the surrounding North African coast, Islamic terrorists now plot, intelligence officials say.

title: Armstrong May Be Facing His Farewell Tour de France
description: GIRONA, Spain, March 24 — When Lance Armstrong announced a few weeks ago that he would ride in a new bicycle race in Colorado, the buzz started. After years of infrequent appearances in American races, Armstrong will race in the Tour of Georgia in April, then in the Rocky Mountain Classic in Colorado in September and, a week later, in the T-Mobile Classic in San Francisco.

title: Cashing In on Chips
description: IN Nebraska, farmers don't necessarily get into the corn oil or muffin business. Boatmen in Louisiana may not deliver ready-made shrimp cocktail to restaurants. And loggers in the Northwest don't produce their own furniture. But on Long Island, two farm families are not only growing potatoes but are turning them into packaged potato chips with hopes to expand to an entire line of snacks. From where they live now, this could be a way to rescue local potato farming.

title: They'll Have the Usual
description: FOR half of the year, a Hewlett Neck couple eat every single night at La Viola in Cedarhurst. It used to be 12 months a year until they decided to spend their winters in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BOLOTOW, HERBERT
description: BOLOTOW--Herbert. 3/28/84. A remarkable man remebered with love today and always. Carol, Melissa & Katie

title: Disenfranchised Florida Felons Struggle to Regain Their Rights
description: Gov. Jeb Bush looked out over a roomful of felons appealing to him for something they had lost, and tried to reassure them.

title: PLAN TO BATTLE AIDS WORLDWIDE IS FALLING SHORT
description: Correction Appended

title: Uptown Moving Upscale
description: WITH apartment prices rising across Manhattan, Vivian Ducat, a documentary filmmaker and creator of multimedia Web presentations, found the home of her dreams on the top floor of the Riviera, an aging but opulent building on Riverside Drive at West 157th Street, built in 1910 on a site where John James Audubon had an estate in the early 19th century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMAS, ANNE DAVIS ROBINS
description: THOMAS--Anne Davis Robins. Widow of Evan Welling Thomas II, died on March 22, 2004 at Hilton Head Island, SC. Survived by three children: Wendy Zara, Beaufort, SC; Louisa Thomas Hargrave, Jamesport, NY; and Evan W. Thomas III, Washington, DC; six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at All Saints Episcopal Church in Hilton Head on Saturday, April 3rd. Memorial contributions to the South Carolina Environmental Law Project, PO Box 1380, Pawley's Island, SC 29585.

title: Cavs' James Outduels Nets' Jefferson
description: LeBron James had already mesmerized the Nets and the sellout crowd at Gund Arena on Saturday night, putting up career highs in points and assists and carrying the Cleveland Cavaliers in a game they desperately needed to win.

description: STEINFELD--Julian S. In Loving Memory March 25, 1924 to May 1, 200

title: Playgrounds Of Timeless Beauty
description: IT'S Sunday afternoon, and James McAuley is on safari at the Newark Museum. So far he has spotted a big cat, a macaw, a magical dragon and a half boy, half elephant animal called Ganesha, which he likes best. ''It's really big and 200 million years old,'' said James, 7, with an air of breathless excitement. It is his first museum visit.

title: Give Him a Tasking and Caveat the Report
description: THE lengthy reports issued last week by the National Commission on Terrorist Attacks Upon the United States laid out in detail the intelligence and law-enforcement failures before the Sept. 11, 2001 attacks.

title: Celebrity-Chef Backlash
description: Ann Harada is savoring her curly fries. The actress, who plays the cranky therapist Christmas Eve in the wacky Broadway musical ''Avenue Q,'' is on a dinner break between the matinee and evening shows at a closet-size restaurant in Hell's Kitchen. She's a friend, a foodie and the one I turned to when I began noticing some strange goings-on in the world of celebrity chefs.

title: Holly Laningham, George Mattson
description: Holly Melissa Laningham, a daughter of Joan and Glen Laningham of Huntington Beach, Calif., was married yesterday evening in Miami Beach to George Nathaniel Mattson, a son of Helen and Gregory Mattson of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Dr. Karl R. Rodig, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Vanderbilt mansion on Fisher Island.

title: Stepping Out To Unlikely Places
description: SOPHISTICATION, nightlife, that savoir faire tends to be lacking in the state's towns and small cities. For that kind of experience, residents head to New Haven, Stamford, and, of course, Manhattan and Boston.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Automobiles section last Sunday about engineers who control the Mars rovers referred imprecisely to a recent competition in which unmanned vehicles tried to travel from Barstow, Calif., to Primm, Nev. A sport utility vehicle developed by some of those engineers traveled autonomously, not by remote human control.

title: Letters
description: Michael Ignatieff's assessment of Iraq one year later prompted many to agree that they, too, remain conflicted about the war. Others said a prison warden's liberal ideas were a good thing. Also: Recruiting in Times Square, movies' ''moving'' special effects and a food critic's musical smorgasbord.

title: Sometimes the Grave Is a Fine and Public Place
description: THE story goes that Paul Tulane, who made his fortune as a haberdasher in 19th-century New Orleans, wanted to give part of that fortune to the university in his hometown, Princeton. The catch was that he wanted the university renamed for him. When that didn't happen, he gave his money to the university in New Orleans that now bears his name. He eventually came back home. But before he died it is said that he demanded that the statue on his grave face away from the Princeton University campus.

title: Amanda Britz, David Cole
description: Amanda Lauren Britz, a daughter of Sheila and Jeffrey E. Britz of Manhattan, was married last evening to Dr. David Harris Cole, a son of Maxine and Robert J. Cole of River Edge, N.J. Rabbi Leon A. Morris officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Sofia Golovkina, 88, Head of Bolshoi's School
description: Sofia Golovkina, a former ballerina with the Bolshoi Ballet who directed the Moscow Ballet School, the company's affiliated academy, with an iron grip for 40 years, died on Feb. 17 in Moscow. She was 88.

title: Corrections
description: A diagram last Sunday with an article about the aerospace industry's readiness for future space exploration omitted a company that worked on the Saturn V rocket and spacecraft used in the Apollo program. The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, now part of Northrop Grumman, made the lunar module.

title: Deals and Discounts
description: LUXURY FOR LESS -- The Berkeley and the Savoy hotels in London are including three nights for the price of two under a Great London Weekend program, available until May 18 and again from July 4 to Sept. 12. Guests must stay Friday through Sunday nights. At the Savoy, the rate is $258 a night for a double room (at $1.85 to the pound) for the first two nights in a superior king room, or $295 a night for a deluxe king. At the Berkeley, the rates are $369 a night for the first two nights in a superior king, and $406 in a deluxe king. The rates do not include V.A.T. of 17.5 percent and a 5 percent service charge; (800) 637-2869 or www.savoygroup.com.

title: The Shrinking $1 Million House
description: THE center-hall colonial had curb appeal. It sat well back on a two-acre plot on a winding road in Laurel Hollow. The neighborhood looked serene; the location just off Route 25A was convenient. But as soon as Tony and Joan Emanuel began to tour the house, listed at $1,375,000, disappointment crept in.

title: Editorial Observer; The American Tribes Prepare Their National Showcase
description: The word Potomac means ''where the goods are brought in'' and it dates from the local Indian tribe rudely displaced here centuries ago by colonial whites intent on a New World. The word seems perfect for the whiff of irony and history in the air this month as the last of 800,000 Indian artifacts -- priceless goods, in fact -- were trucked in from New York City to become the bedrock treasure of the new National Museum of the American Indian.

title: Page Two: March 21-27; BONDING WITH QADDAFI
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair's historic handshake with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last week was executed with such lightning speed by an uneasy British leader that it had to be done again for the cameras. Mr. Blair had gone to Tripoli to reward the colonel with a visit after Libya announced in December that it would give up its quest to acquire nuclear, chemical and other dangerous weapons. A pall was cast by the memory of Pan Am Flight 103, which Libyan agents are believed to have brought down. British and American statecraft believes, at the moment, that Colonel Qaddafi can be rehabilitated. They are negotiating deals to rebuild Libya's crumbling economy. Patrick E. Tyler

title: Sweat the Cheesy Stuff
description: As Sheldon Silver, the New York Assembly speaker, learned recently, whatever happens in Vegas does not always stay in Vegas. Mr. Silver and his wife went there on vacation two years ago. They hit the jackpot as soon as they checked into the Paris Las Vegas Hotel. The Silvers were upgraded to a $1,500-a-night suite usually reserved for high rollers. Never mind that he was paying a $109 government rate; these things happen, and Mr. Silver would have you believe it had nothing to do with the fact that Caesars Entertainment Inc., the hotel's owner, is hoping to get a slice of the casino action in New York State. Presumably Caesars lobbyists invite all visitors to Las Vegas out to dinner, as they invited the Silvers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAUSMAN, LEO
description: HAUSMAN--Leo. The Board of Directors and staff of The Lown Cardiovascular Research Foundation are deeply saddened by the passing of our long-time friend and benefactor, Leo Hausman. As a dedicated member of our Board of Directors, Leo gave generously his gifts of counsel, insight, candor and time, helping to make the Foundation and, indeed the world, a better place. While we will miss his passion, his unselfish energy and his inimitable sense of adventure, we are everlastingly grateful for the guidance and vision he always provided. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his children, Martin and Helaine Hausman, Jane and Richard Karp, and to their entire families. Bernard Lown, M.D., Chairman Emeritus Thomas B. Graboys, M.D., Chairman and President Carole A. Nathan, Exec. Dir. Lown Cardiovascular Research Foundation

title: Operation Iraqi Infoganda
description: REAL journalism may be reeling, but faux journalism rocks. As an entertainment category in the cultural marketplace, it may soon rival reality TV and porn. Television is increasingly awash in fake anchors delivering fake news, some of them far more trenchant than real anchors delivering real news. Even CNBC, a financial news network, is chasing after the success of Jon Stewart; its new nightly fake newscast, presided over by a formerly funny ''Saturday Night Live'' fake anchor, Dennis Miller, is being promoted with far more zeal than was ever lavished on CNBC's real ''News With Brian Williams.''

title: Stanford and Cal Crews Win Heavyweight Races
description: Stanford and California won races yesterday in the second Windermere Collegiate Crew Classic, a round-robin format of dual races against East Coast crews in Redwood Shores, Calif.

description: OPENING MEXICO

title: When Newbies Ride The Rails
description: MARCI BRALLIER moved here last month, and for the first two weeks she was too intimidated to take the subway. ''I did a lot of walking, which I enjoy, and I took taxis,'' said Ms. Brallier, who had spent half her life in Albany, and half in Florida. ''I wasn't afraid. It was more like, what if I get on the wrong train? It seemed so overwhelming.''

title: At Cricket Matches, Indians and Pakistanis Cheer for Friendship
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 24  When Deepak Sapra, 29, and his wife, Ipsita, 25, crossed the Indian border to watch the final one-day cricket match of the series between India and Pakistan, they hardly expected a warm welcome.

description: ARTHUR--Hartney J., on March 24, 2004 in Connecticut. He had a long and distinguished career as producer, theatrical and film agent, casting director and actor. He is survived by his many friends. There will be no service.

John Bryant was face down in front of the bench. Delonte West was in the far corner of the court fighting back tears.

title: The World; In Pakistan, the Riddle of a Big Fish That Got Away
description: BY the end of last week, the news from Pakistan's remote tribal areas seemed the exact opposite of what it had been just seven days earlier. Again, the pivotal question centered on Pakistan's army: Just how hard was it really trying to capture and kill terrorists?

It is "The Myth of Moral Justice: Why Our Legal System Fails to Do What's Right" - not "The Morality of Justice."

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: NOT every woman has the courage of Ibsen's Nora to walk out on an unappreciative husband. Some wives need a push. Rosalba Barletta (the glowing, inspiring Licia Maglietta) gets hers in Silvio Soldini's BREAD AND TULIPS (2000) when her tour bus, carrying her husband and their two teenage sons, leaves her behind at a rest stop. She doesn't really plan it but soon finds herself in Venice, and she keeps missing her train home. So she gets a job with a florist, takes a room in the apartment of a charming Icelandic waiter (Bruno Ganz) and rediscovers her own worth. Her husband (Antonio Catania) reacts with indignant rage and asks his mistress to iron his shirts -- Saturday at 8 a.m. and 7 p.m. on Sundance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOGIL, KENNETH
description: MOGIL -- Kenneth. Beloved husband of Randi, father of Bari and Dylan, brother of Jeffrey and Robert, son of Merle and the late Alvin Mogil. Ken was a partner in the Mogil Organization, an insurance management firm based in New York City. He was actively involved with the Cornell University Alumni Association since his graduation from Cornell's School of Hotel and Restaurant Management in 1978, and was recently named president of his class. Ken and his wife were volunteers and wish-granters for the Make-A-Wish Foundation. Services Monday, 1:30 PM, at Temple Shaaray Tefila, Baldwin Road, Bedford Corners, NY. Memorial contributions should be sent to Mt. Pleasant PBA, P.O. Box 223, Hawthorne, NY 10532, designate contributions to: Dive Team Equipment.

description: SILVERMAN--Rabbi Martin I., D.D. Of Albany, NY. Died March 24, on Kauai. Rabbi Silverman was Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Beth Emeth in Albany. He was the beloved husband of Phyllis Olshin Silverman; loving father of Sara Silverman (Audrey Valenciano), Amy (Paul) Cohen, and Ethan (Erica) Silverman; cherished grandfather of Alyssa and Jason Cohen, and Windsor and Chris Flynn; brother of Paula Isenberg and the late Julian Silverman. title: Personal Business; Those Dents and Demos Can Save You Dollars
description: SHOPPERS looking for a great deal on a new or almost-new television need not haggle with a store manager for a floor-model discount or scan an outlet store for a factory second. They need only to browse the shelves of local retail stores.

title: Rhodes Is a Fan of Yanks Jeter
description: TOKYO, March 27  Tuffy Rhodes is one of the best players in Japan. Alex Rodriguez may be the best player in the United States. But if Rhodes were starting his own team, he said, the first player he would pick is Derek Jeter, the Yankees' shortstop.

title: Taiwan's President Seems Secure Despite a Huge Rally
description: Hundreds of thousands of Nationalist Party supporters crowded this city's center on Saturday in a peaceful protest of the island's disputed presidential election. President Chen Shui-bian agreed to one of the demonstrators' demands, but seemed to be in a strong position to fend off others and to remain Taiwan's president for the next four years.

title: House Is Raided In Madrid Inquiry
description: The investigation of the attacks on four commuter trains on March 11 led the police to a house outside Madrid where the bombs, which killed 190 people, may have been assembled, an Interior Ministry official said Saturday.

title: Ready or Not, Here Comes Earnings Season
description: CORPORATE earnings reports, the scorecard of capitalism, will start appearing in the next couple of weeks, as companies disclose their first-quarter results.

title: Vintage Fur
description: The 1950's mink stole, an Easter parade signature of the era, has been rediscovered by a new generation. But now it is worn informally with jeans and the mix that represents current fashion. Several of the wearers expressed no guilt, provided their fur was vintage. The furs here were photographed in New York and Paris, inherited from grandmothers and other family members. Others were found in thrift shops. A few were new, made from ranched fur. Left, a secondhand treasure, a white mink capelet with a flyaway silhouette. Fur remains a popular solution for capricious spring weather.

title: Casting Reality TV, No Longer a Hunch, Becomes a Science
description: In a suite high above Columbus Circle, Rob LaPlante is looking for next season's breakout television star. title: Another Schism on the Border
description: FOR Yonkers officials, the 81-acre parcel of land on the city's northern fringes is full of promise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVIN, FANNY
description: LEVIN--Fanny. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of a long-time friend and supporter of medical research and education programs at our institution. With her late husband, Milton, who was an esteemed member of our Board of Overseers, she was among the earliest members of our Society of Founders and a University Guardian. An ardent supporter of our cancer research programs, Mrs. Levin, along with her son, James, served on our Cancer Research Advisory Board. To James, to her daughter, Gene Heller, and to the entire family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Ronald P. Stanton, Chairman Board of Trustees Albert Einstein College of Medicine Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson Board of Overseers Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Marilyn Katz, Chairperson Cancer Research Advisory Board

description: The G.O.P. knock on John Kerry, the Democratic nominee presumptive, is that he flip-flops. The senator's defenders counter that his stands are nuanced.

title: Hobbled Knicks Overrun By Pistons
description: There are no secrets in the visitors' locker room at the Palace of Auburn Hills. The two trainers' tables are in full view of everyone. Ninety minutes before the Knicks played the Pistons on Saturday night, the trainer Mike Saunders worked on Allan Houston and Penny Hardaway, who along with Tim Thomas would not play because of injuries.

title: The Tie That Binds Is the Hamptons
description: AS at other reunions, the crowd was thinner than in years past, and some familiar faces were missing. But an annual gathering here is special to a certain set of snowbirds and retirees: it's called the Bonac Reunion, and it brings together South Florida residents who have East Hampton in common.

description: Kerry Assails Bush on 9/11

title: A Long, Long Muddle
description: George Bush's vision of the nation's future will undoubtedly be one focus of the presidential campaign. We suggest the debate start with the question of whether Mr. Bush actually has one. The White House has been driving Congress -- and the nation -- in wildly contradictory ways that suggest a deeply muddled, or perhaps nonexistent, set of domestic goals.

title: The Case of the Cherry Hill Cluster
description: Janet Skarbek is 36 years old and lives in Cinnaminson, N.J. She is the author of ''Planning Your Future: A Guide for Professional Women,'' a book about managing the unknown. It was published in 2001 by the Professional Women's Institute, a small networking and support organization that Skarbek and three other women jointly ran out of their homes. ''Planning Your Future'' presents a world where exemplary order and control are possible. It urges working women to get ahead by thinking ahead: choosing a career with their children in mind, timing pregnancies so as not to lose traction at work. It tells them to fend for themselves in a society they may sometimes perceive as unsympathetic to their needs. Skarbek herself turned down a plum corporate job for the sake of her two kids. ''I knew that I wasn't willing to work the hours that a vice president of a Fortune 500 company would require to get the job done right,'' she said.

title: Russia
description: To the Editor: It was with great pleasure that I read Douglas Martin's upbeat essay, ''To Russia With 2 Adolescents: Mission Possible'' (March 14).

title: Emulating the Romantics in a 'Love Song'
description: ALTHOUGH the violin concerto may have reached its zenith in the 19th century, it has proved remarkably durable. Twentieth-century masters like Stravinsky, Berg, Britten and Shostakovich added their thoughts to the noble tradition, and more recently, composers as disparate as Gyorgy Ligeti, John Adams and Nicholas Maw have written formidably for the violin.

description: An article in the Automobiles section last Sunday about engineers who control the Mars rovers referred imprecisely to a recent competition in which unmanned vehicles tried to travel from Barstow, Calif., to Primm, Nev. A sport utility vehicle developed by some of those engineers traveled autonomously, not by remote human control. ( Go to Article )

title: Cellphones Ringing at Home and at Work
description: SITTING at a meeting at a glossy conference table not long ago, I found myself listening to snatches of music. The ''1812'' Overture blared from someone's purse. A calypso tune trilled from someone else's pocket. Here a few bars from Bach; there a few chords from the Beatles. In between there were buzzes, beeps and dings. With each new sound or vibration, someone darted sheepishly from the room, holding a cellphone.

title: A Raw Bar Renaissance in Boston
description: THE seafood raw bar is a tradition that dates back to Colonial times in New England, yet this regional specialty never goes out of style. In Boston there are a number of institutions, like the Union Oyster House and Legal Sea Foods, that are renowned for their raw bar offerings. And at many of the city's most stylish restaurants, raw shellfish is a standard item. But in the past few years, there has been a flurry of raw bar openings. A few fit the classic formula, while others, run by Japanese chefs, add a new dimension to the New England raw bar concept.

title: Rome
description: In its architecture, seasonal rhythms and aspects of its character, Rome is connected closely to Christianity; key dates on the Christian calendar are peak moments for this blessed city. Easter's celebrations and events augment the usual attractions.

title: Hillary Greenman, Lance Milken
description: Hillary Gail Greenman, the daughter of Geraldine and Herbert Greenman of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married last evening to Lance Aaron Milken, a son of Lori and Michael R. Milken of Encino, Calif. Rabbi Eli Herscher officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Hamas Leader Says God Has Declared War on U.S.
description: JERUSALEM, March 28  The new Hamas leader in the Gaza Strip, Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi, called President Bush the enemy of Muslims and said today that God had declared war on the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRAUNSTEIN, CHARLES STUART
description: BRAUNSTEIN -- Charles Stuart. With great sadness, the family of Charles Braunstein announces his death on March 24, 2004 in Scottsdale, AZ. His warmth, humor and caring will be remembered and missed by family and friends and especially by his wife, Ruth and sisters, Phyllis Margolin and Edith Magaziner. Donations may be made to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 East Flower St, Phoenix, AZ, 85014 or Self-Help for Hard of Hearing People (SHHH), 7910 Woodmont Ave, Suite 1200, Bethesda, MD. 20814.

title: The Year of Living Dangerously
description: Ignatieff writes in his essay that ''it turned out, nobody actually knew very much about Iraq.'' But it is now painfully obvious that although many respected Mideast experts knew a great deal about Iraq, the Bush administration chose instead to rely on a small group of Iraqi exiles and others who supported a radical pre-emptive agenda, even long before 9/11.

title: Uptown With Hirschfeld
description: Mixing the contemporary with vintage nostalgia, HIRSCHFELD'S HARLEM (Glenn Young, $75) pairs Al Hirschfeld's Harlem drawings with commentary from a dizzying variety of African-American notables -- some intimately involved with Harlem, past and present, some not. Each is cleverly matched with a drawing. Representative Charles B. Rangel considers ''Sugar Hill Statesman''; the Rev. James A. Forbes discusses the preacher of ''Yeah, Men!''; Eartha Kitt celebrates ''Cocoa Venus,'' a smoldering odalisque. Drawings of Harlem's legendary dances show Hirschfeld's line at its greatest: the Lindy Hop and the Boogie-Woogie carry the book from its Harlem pages to ''Hirschfeld's Gallery of African American Legends,'' a sampling of illustrations from The New York Times. If this section is perhaps a victim of somewhat lazy editing (what, for instance, is Halle Berry accepting the Oscar doing in the middle of the introductory essay on the Harlem Renaissance?) the two halves are indeed linked -- for Hirschfeld, the great chronicler of theater, Harlem was but another stage. This goes some way toward explaining the inscrutably masked countenance that features on so many of the figures depicted. Many of the habitus of Hirschfeld's Harlem have no eyes -- that is to say, they can't look back. As has often been true, Harlem remains in the eye of the beholder. Sharifa Rhodes-Pitts

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about similarities between George W. Bush and John Kerry referred incorrectly in some copies to their ethnic backgrounds. Mr. Kerry was raised as a Catholic; they are not both WASP's, or White Anglo-Saxon Protestants.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Jeffrey Vanderbeek, the new principal owner of the New Jersey Devils hockey team, misstated the precedent for the team's three-time Stanley Cup championship since 1995. It is not unique; the Detroit Red Wings have also won the cup three times in that period.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; 1920's Factory in Bloomfield to Be Converted to Lofts
description: A VACANT Bloomfield factory building that had a significant role in labor union history will be turned into moderately priced loft apartments by a novice developer from Brooklyn. The financing is coming from a nonprofit lending company that supports increasing the supply of low- and moderate-priced rental housing in New York and New Jersey.

title: What Unions Can Gain From Immigration
description: IN February 2000, leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. agreed on a major shift in immigration strategy. After decades of mistrust of immigration, its executive council was now calling for an amnesty for the millions of illegal immigrants living and working in the United States.

title: For These Artists, The Raw Material Is Close to Home
description: THE Long Island landscape has inspired artists for centuries. Painters have captured its scenery; sculptors have portrayed its birds and beasts; and photographers have chronicled its development. But for as long as there have been artists on the Island, some have responded to the landscape in a more literal way, by using it as their medium rather than as their subject.

title: Rumbling Through History
description: By 1850 the island of Manhattan was bottom-heavy. People were packed into its southern tip, and a population explosion was adding wave upon wave of immigrants. The city needed new transit networks to ease crowds on its clogged streets and to expand into openland to the north and south. Subways won out over elevated trains, and New Yorkers have been riding in a hole in the ground ever since. Here are some of the high points and low of a system riders love, hate and depend on every day.

title: The City Line
description: THIS middle-class, mid-Camden County burg has always had an identity problem. Sure, the director Steven Spielberg lived here as a teenager, but even he claims to have lived in nearby, more upscale Haddonfield.

description: THE scaffolding has come down at the train station in downtown Yonkers, revealing the brick and granite building designed by Warren & Wetmore, the architectural firm that created the facades and interior of Grand Central Terminal.

title: Closing In on the Killer of the Lobsters
description: SCIENTISTS who have been studying the sudden decline of the lobster population in Long Island Sound in 1999 are still months away from releasing their findings, but they said they have narrowed down the likely causes.

description: The Connecticut women's basketball team has won in all conditions.

description: TOKYO, March 28  They have seen it so often that they come to expect it. So here, in an emotional and intense setting, Hideki Matsui's teammates had a feeling he would come through again.

title: Ideas & Trends; Oh, No, Not Again: Chronicling Chronic Losing
description: THE baseball season starts this week, so expect to hear the usual songs of despair from the Chicago Cubs and Boston Red Sox, who are to futility what the Yankees are to success. Their World Series droughts of 96 and 86 years, respectively, are easily the longest titleless streaks in North American professional sports. But they came so close last year, surviving deep into the playoffs, that losers everywhere will be watching closely again.

title: DataBank; S.&P. 500 Extends Its Losing Streak
description: A strong rally on Thursday was not enough to prevent the broad stock market from declining again last week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell slightly, for its third consecutive weekly decline.

description: Construction is under way on a 12-story building on West 90th Street that will house both the Stephen Gaynor School, which teaches children with learning disabilities, and dance studios for the Ballet Hispanico.

title: Bangles Galore
description: The New York jewelry designer Alexis Bittar, known for hand-carved Lucite pieces illuminated with color from within has opened his first store, a 450-square-foot space in SoHo. His lines include one with pieces made of Lucite and another with pieces made of semiprecious stones, all displayed in sleek iridescent white cases set against clear plastic walls that protect pink hand-painted wallpaper from 1910. ''It would have been easy to do a retro 1950's or 60's interior,'' Mr. Bittar said. ''But this blends my interests in antiques and modernism.''

title: Spadea's Defeat of Safin Starts a Davis Cup Debate
description: Andy Roddick had the cheering section in the upper deck and Roger Federer has the No. 1 ranking. But on a day when all six of the Stadium Court matches at the Nasdaq-100 Open featured players who have been No. 1 in the world, and when Federer had a close call in his first match of the tournament, it was Vince Spadea, ranked 36th, who trumped the limelight names on Saturday.

title: Before Facing Judge, Stewart Is Out and About
description: She was spotted a few weeks ago at the Four Seasons, perched on a plush banquette at power-lunch time. She was among the glittering crowd at the Manhattan premiere of "Fahrenheit 9/11'' on June 14. And at the party held by Calvin Klein last weekend to unveil his new summer place in Southampton, she appeared in a sunshine-yellow ensemble, smiling for the cameras alongside the host and Barbara Walters.

title: Rare Birds: American Tourists
description: THE British are coming to South Africa: 463,000 of them last year, up 45 percent in the last five years. So are the Germans: an increase of better than 50 percent since 1998. The Chinese may be the fastest-growing segment of all: more than 33,000 in 2003, an increase of almost 30 percent in a year.

title: The Week Ahead; CONGRESS
description: They have hit a few potholes along the way, but House Republicans are finally planning to bring a highway measure to the floor this week, satisfying an election-year craving for road money.

title: Clash of Cultures
description: I am a Peace Corps volunteer living in a conservative Muslim village in Central Asia. My host brother, who is 12 years old, often hits his younger sister and female cousins. According to the boy's grandmother, this is acceptable because he is older, he is a boy and ''such bad, rowdy girls deserve to be hit.'' I disagree, but should I speak up or remain silent? What takes precedence: my responsibility to respect their culture or my belief that hitting is wrong? Anonymous

description: SOME shrug, calling it the price they pay for living in the country. Others describe a camaraderie so earnest that it sounds like a rolling A.A. meeting. One grumpy fellow said it was like doing the Bataan Death March every day, twice a day, 50 weeks a year.

title: Israeli Report Faults Intelligence on Iraq
description: JERUSALEM, March 28  A parliamentary subcommittee delivered today a rare criticism of Israel's intelligence services, saying the agencies overestimated Iraq's weapons programs prior to last year's war because they could not obtain "hard facts."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORITZKY, AUDREY MILLER
description: PORITZKY--Audrey Miller, on March 25, 2004. Beloved wife of David, loving mother of Sophie Lena, devoted daughter of Anne and Laurence Miller, dear sister of Robert and his wife Amy. She will be deeply and sadly missed by her grandparents Beatrice and Joseph Miller, her nephews Jacob and David Miller, her husband's family Susan, Sandy, Eric and Dan Poritzky. She is predeceased by her grandparents Sophie and David Knopping. Service Sunday, 11:45am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Thursday, April 1, at Jewish Oakland Cemetery, Little Rock, Arkansas. Donations to The Audrey Miller Poritzky Educational Fund for Children, PO Box 688, Summit, NJ 07902-0688.

title: Bobby Fischer Goes to War
description: It is five o'clock in the evening of Tuesday, 11 July 1972. The seats filling the arena of the sports hall, the Laugardalsholl, in Reykjavik's featureless leisure complex are sold out. On the platform, the world chess champion, thirty-five-year-old Boris Vasilievich Spassky, sits alone at the chessboard. He is playing white. Precisely on the hour, the German chief arbiter, Lothar Schmid, starts the clock. Spassky picks up his queen's pawn and moves it forward two squares. The Soviet Union's king of chess has begun the defense of the title that has been his since 1969, and his country's without interruption since World War II. He glances up at the other side of the board. The expensive, low-slung, black leather, swivel chair, specially provided for his opponent, is empty.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Katy Rose; Beauty and Beastliness
description: AS 17-year-old Katy Rose walked out of her home here with her friend Anna Petrosyan, 18, they looked just-out-of-bed chic in a California girl kind of way. ''I can tell you where I got every one of these items,'' Ms. Rose said later, pointing to her cut-off-at-the-ankle cords, Lilith Fair halter tank and masses of silver necklaces and rings. Ms. Petrosyan was in an outfit seemingly inspired by Marc Jacobs, from her white shirt with a Peter Pan collar to her short red nails and pink plastic headband.

title: Fare-Beater Inc.
description: ON fare-beating, the criminal cause and commercial activity around which his life found meaning, Alan Campbell speaks softly, almost monkishly. Far more than a simple acrobat who jumped turnstiles, or a bottom-feeding hustler who sucked tokens out of slots, Mr. Campbell worked on a scale of dizzying, historic proportion. He manufactured slugs by the millions over years and years, but remained a phantom, hidden behind layers of distributors. Unable to hunt him down, the transit system struggled to mount a defense. It deployed an army of police officers. It tinkered with turnstile mechanisms. Even the design of the token was changed over and over.

title: Dorothy and Toto, In Kansas After All
description: It's now possible to visit Oz without the tornado ride. The new Oz Museum in Wamego, Kan., features more than 2,000 items collected by Tod Machin, a native of Wamego, including first editions of ''The Wizard of Oz'' books and costumes worn by the Munchkins in the 1939 MGM musical and the 1978 film ''The Wiz.'' As visitors step inside the 1880's mercantile building at 511 Lincoln Avenue, they find themselves in a sepia-tone re-creation of the Gale farmyard from the film's opening sequence.

title: On the Internet, Nobody Knows You're in Mahwah

The beverage of choice was coffee, and they were talking about things like how often they check their Technorati numbers. These people are all New Jersey bloggers: They all keep Weblogs, or online journals.
