It was built for the 1929 Universal Exhibition, not the 1992 Olympics. In addition, the singer Maria del Mar Bonet, who will perform during the festival, was described incorrectly. She is from Majorca, not Catalonia.

title: Children Alone and Scared, Fighting Deportation
description: Once a month, in a windowless courtroom at 26 Federal Plaza in Manhattan, children are summoned before a judge who can decide whether they will be removed from the United States. One afternoon, there is a Haitian girl of 17 who escaped her father's killers; another time, a 15-year-old Ecuadoran who came 3,000 miles to earn money for his ailing mother. There is even a disabled boy of 5 from Morocco who lacks the visa needed to stay here with his parents.

title: Sumi Gupta, Michael Glickman

title: Dylan on the Verge

The remark is typical of Mr. Dylan's humor -- sly, self-referential and cryptic enough to cause alert listeners to question how much truth lies beneath the laughter. The last four decades have, of course, revealed Mr. Dylan to be an ultimately unknowable master of disguises -- ''Masked and Anonymous,'' as the title of his recent film aptly put it.

''A friend,'' Mr. Garcia says, harking back to late 2001, ''I won't say her name, but in charge of a very big company in the classical-music business, told me that there was about to be a production of 'La Bohme' on Broadway. 'I hear they're looking for you,' she said. 'Don't do it.' ''

title: Cake Masters
description: 'Coming from New Orleans, food is a big part of my consciousness,'' the photographer Sharon Core says as she separates eggs, dropping the whites into a gleaming KitchenAid mixer. She stirs a stick of butter that is melting in an aged copper saut pan. Today, on another frigid February morning, in her sun-filled loft in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Core is preparing her 20th angel food cake, one of approximately 200 cakes she has prepared during the last year and a half. For her exhibition at Bellwether Gallery, nearby in Williamsburg (which ended last week), she is recreating the cake, pie and hot dog paintings of Wayne Thiebaud, the famed San Francisco artist who began painting everyday food items at the same time Andy Warhol found his muse in a Campbell's soup can.

title: It Happened One Saturday Night
description: Elton John sang about it, as did Sam Cooke. And the Bay City Rollers came up with one of history's most annoyingly catchy songs about it in 1975. Clearly, we love Saturday night. For her 1997 book, ''Saturday Night,'' Susan Orlean traveled the country, immersing herself in the rituals and excitement of the biggest night of the week in towns both big and small. In the same vein, we went to the gulf-breeze-kissed beach town of Pensacola, Fla., to take a Saturday snapshot of its citizenry. From a group that socializes with their dogs to one drawn together by auto-mania, we found a small town with a big social life.

The crowd of 200 or so activists carried the usual placards denouncing war, oil and environmental policies. One Sierra Club member wore a doormat decorated with tufts of glued fuzz to resemble, she said, ''Mothra, the giant moth that defeated Godzilla.'' Across a vast artery of screaming traffic stood the Bush supporters, maybe 50 people. A small blond girl waved a big flag. Then a new group of Bush supporters tumbled out of a van on the wrong side of the street.

description: WHEN Mary Williams decided that her home in Roosevelt was in dire need of repairs and that she needed financial help to make them, she turned to the Community Development Corporation of Long Island, a nonprofit housing group based in Centereach.

Now that she has finally made the leap, however, it is obvious that the architect's timing is beyond reproach. Hadid had to keep us waiting. If you have the reputation of a diva, that is what you are supposed to do. The suspense is meant to drive us crazy. And Hadid is not a woman who would ever disappoint her fans.

title: The World; 'No One Can Dismantle Hamas': The Voice of Its New Leader
description: LAST August, William Helmreich, a professor of sociology at City University of New York Graduate Center, conducted a two-hour interview with Dr. Abdel Aziz Rantisi at his home in Gaza. Mr. Rantisi, a prominent Hamas leader, had just survived an attack by Israeli helicopters.

title: WHO'S YOUR DADDY?
description: WENDY SPERO'S father died when she was 10 months old. In her one-woman show ''Who's Your Daddy?,'' she candidly discusses being brought up by her devoted, free-thinking mother. title: County Tax Increase? Don't Look at Us
description: WHEN Westchester County legislators voted recently to increase the county's property tax revenue by 18.8 percent, making this the second year in a row for a double-digit tax increase, municipal officials were perhaps among the angriest county residents.

title: Commons of Earthly Delights
description: I enjoyed James Traub's paean to Times Square, both old and new (March 14). But he might have mentioned one institution that has remained constant in Times Square -- when it was gaudy, when it was derelict and even today when it is Disneyfied -- the Armed Forces recruiting station. For more than three generations, young men and women, whether because they were patriotic, pressured or perhaps even tipsy, have enlisted to become soldiers, sailors and marines at the crossroads of the world in Times Square. How appropriate that a place filled with so much freedom, commerce and light should play that role in our New York!

title: For the Young at Art, Playgrounds of Beauty
description: ALICIA CONGER and Joshua Wright are guiding a rowdy group of fifth-grade students from Birchwood Intermediate through ''Red Grooms: Selections from the Graphic Work'' at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington. They pause in front of a colorful collage of a New York diner, explain its meaning and then respond to questions from the floor. title: Stilettos In The Grass
description: When I was very young, the woman who took care of me when my parents were away sat on the edge of my bed and sang, always, ''He's Got the Whole World in His Hands'' to put me to sleep. When it was her turn, my mother inexplicably chose the Johnny Mercer and Hoagy Carmichael tune ''In the Cool, Cool, Cool of the Evening.'' Coatee's rhythmic reassurances of the Lord's (and her own rather more palpable) protection always sent me straight to dreamland. But after my mother finished her song, I'd lie awake for hours, imagining -- yearning for, really -- the party that was ''getting a glow on,'' and the ''singin''' that ''fills the air.'' By the time I'd gotten around to ''better save a chair,'' I had the whole scene in my head: a gilded ballroom chair waiting for me next to a dance floor on a wide green lawn. The orchestra would be playing, and I'd arrive, late, ''in the shank of the night/When the doin's are right,'' trailing a white mink stole behind me. All the women would have on diamonds and gardenias, and all the men would have already shed their white dinner jackets. I'd drink Champagne out of those old-fashioned saucers and listen to faint tinklings of laughter drifting in from discreet pockets farther afield, where the trees would be hung with strings of white lights.

title: Live and Forget
description: I got on the train to Madrid early that morning. I live in Alcal de Henares, a town about 19 miles east of the city. It is famous for being the birthplace of Miguel de Cervantes. The trip takes an hour. I'm 28, and I work in a savings bank. My wife and I have a baby, so I'm often tired these days. As I sometimes do, I fell asleep in my seat. Suddenly I heard an explosion, and then, right away, another. When I opened my eyes, the world around me was bathed in white smoke. I was half asleep and half awake. It was a choking smoke, the kind produced by combustion. Just then I felt something hit me on the head and something else strike my back. I might have been in great pain, but I wasn't able to judge at that moment. All I could think about was escaping the smoke. Someone yelled out, ''Jump through the window!'' By great fortune, I was seated in the front of the train car, right next to a window. I didn't have to break it, because the glass had shattered. It took about 10 seconds for the smoke to clear. I could see three trains, the one I'd been riding in and two others. That was when I realized we had suffered a terrorist attack. My car, well, the windows and doors were gone. One train had the roof blown clear off of it. The next one had been gnarled into a twisted circle. It didn't seem to have a roof. At that point, those of us who could -- three men and I -- jumped back into our car to see if we could do something for the people inside.

title: Coach Fitz's Management Theory
description: When I was 12, I thought that when The New Orleans Times-Picayune wrote about the ''struggle for control of the West Bank,'' it meant the other side of the Mississippi River. I thought that my shiny gold velour pants actually looked good. I kept a giant sack of Nabisco chocolate-chip cookies under my bed so that they might be available in an emergency -- a flood, say, or a hurricane -- that made it harder to get to the grocery store. From the safe distance of 43, ''12'' looks less an age than a disease, and for the most part, I've been able to forget all about it -- not the events and the people, but the feelings that gave them meaning. But there are exceptions. A few people, and a few experiences, simply refuse to be trivialized by time. There are teachers with a rare ability to enter a child's mind; it's as if their ability to get there at all gives them the right to stay forever. I once had such a teacher. title: City Boy
description: They had a bad neighbor. Bad in all the usual ways, and difficult to ignore. Music, noise on the stairs, carelessness about the disposal of garbage. Above their heads, he carried on wrestling matches with the furniture. His uncarpeted floors were a soundstage. He dropped and bumped and scraped. Jack and Chloe called him Hippie Pothead Rasta Boy, or sometimes just H.P.R.B. Being witty made them feel better, although not for long. Pot smoke wafted down to them along with other alarming vegetarian burnt smells, brown rice flambe or tofu gone wrong. A perpetual low-grade party reigned upstairs. There were muffled shrieks, more of the furniture wrestling, comings and goings late at night. When, after a time, they complained, they got nowhere. The kid was too stoned, his life already too full of mess and distraction for anything they said to register. The landlord was no help, nor were the police, unless they wanted to get him busted for the drugs. Even under the circumstances that seemed like a crummy thing to do. So eventually they learned to live with annoyance, grievance, and the sense that an unfairness had been done to them.

title: Swan Song
description: When I found out that La Cte Basque was closing its doors, I was sad -- irrationally so, since it later occurred to me that I hadn't actually eaten there in almost 14 years. I remember the occasion clearly because it was the birthday of my ex-fianc, almost a year to the date that I sort of, more or less, left him at the altar. Still guilt-ridden (but happily about to leave New York for an extended stay in New Orleans), I thought I should create a celebration, one in which we'd emphasize his birthday rather than my departure and finally close the door on what was left of our relationship. So I assembled my own version of Capote's swans, those chic society ladies like Babe Paley and Gloria Guinness; mine were Joan Buck, Kathleen Tynan and my childhood friend M.T. -- and they did not let me down. We hauled out all our jewels and finery (I wore a black Chanel suit, my first), picked up the birthday boy in a Town Car and spent the rest of the night lavishly fussing over him -- and drinking, a lot. We started with Champagne and caviar and the excellent foie gras terrine and progressed through many bottles of Puligny-Montrachet to those chocolate and Grand Marnier souffls you had to order ahead of time. When the bill arrived, I didn't flinch -- the entire evening had been a triumph of sophisticated merriment.

The labeling change is intended to make doctors more cautious about prescribing the drugs and patients more cautious about taking them. Such vigilance is crucial. But if the labeling scares depressed people away from medications that would help them, it is also dangerous.

description: A woman drowned yesterday after jumping into frigid waters to save her 5-year-old son, who had fallen from a canoe, authorities said. Around 12:50 p.m. the child and his father were riding in the canoe about 100 feet from their house on Culver Lake in Sussex County in northwestern New Jersey. Suddenly, the canoe capsized and the mother, Debbie Snook, 33, who was watching from the shore, jumped into the lake, said Thomas Preston, a New Jersey State Police detective. After helping her son onto a neighbor's boat, the woman vanished into the 40-degree water. State police and county divers found Ms. Snook's body about two hours later. It was not immediately clear whether the child was wearing a life preserver. He was listed in stable condition at a local hospital, and his father, Chris Snook, was uninjured. John Holl (NYT)

title: BERLIN: RETURNED PAINTING RETURNS
description: In a ceremonial act and in the presence of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany, the Caspar David Friedrich (1774-1840) painting ''Der Watzmann'' was returned last week to the Alte Nationalgalerie in Berlin. Created in 1824-25, the painting, an oil on canvas depicting the Watzmann mountain in the Alps, is a key work of German romanticism and, at more than 4 feet 5 inches by 5 feet 7 inches one of the few large Friedrich paintings. In 1937 the museum bought ''Der Watzmann'' from a Berliner, Martin Brunn, a Jew who was forced to sell it to finance his escape from the Nazi terror. The painting remained the property of the Nationalgalerie until 1999, when the heirs of Mr. Brunn reclaimed and then resold it to the Deka-Bank of Germany, which lent it to the museum on a permanent basis last week. Chancellor Schrder called the return of the painting to its Jewish owners the historical and ethical obligation of Germany. Nonetheless, he said, ''we will not be able to undo the injustice.'' KIRSTEN GRIESHABER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHE, TYGE ERNST
description: ROTHE--Tyge Ernst. Of Greenwich, CT, and Espergaerde, Denmark, passed away Tuesday, 23 March, at the age of 95. Born 29 April, 1908, and raised in Copenhagen, Denmark, he was the son of Ernst and Ebba Sorensen and brother of Ellen Olrik, and Eigil. He worked as an export salesman and then established his own export-import company, Moller & Rothe A/S in Copenhagen, in the latter half of the 1930's. Stranded outside his homeland during the Second World War, he emigrated to the United States and established his residency in NYC, where he resumed his commercial export activities as president of Moller & Rothe, Inc. He also founded Unified Data Products, a data forms printing company with plants and affiliates in New Jersey, Vermont and Pennsylvania. An avid and skilled sailor and successful ocean racer, he was a member of the New York Yacht Club, the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, where he was Rear Commodore, the Cruising Club of America, and the Royal Danish Yacht Club. He supported cultural activities related to Denmark through his membership in the American Scandinavian Foundation in NYC. He is survived by Annelise, his wife of 45 years, his children, Ernst of NYC, Lillian Dick of Newport, RI, Eigil of McLean, VA, Kirsten Meberg of Greenwich, CT, and Annemarie of Espergaerde, Denmark, 12 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He will be interred in Copenhagen, Denmark.

title: NASHVILLE: REMEMBERING HENDRIX
description: Jimi Hendrix, left, is a longtime member of the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, but on Saturday his largely forgotten Nashville roots were recalled at the Country Music Hall of Fame as part of a new, groundbreaking 5,000-square-foot multimedia exhibition, ''Night Train to Nashville: Music City Rhythm & Blues 1945-1970.'' The display, continuing through December 2005, is the museum's first rhythm-and-blues exhibition. After completing military service at nearby Fort Campbell, Ky., Hendrix and the bassist Billy Cox moved to Nashville to work in the thriving black club scene there and to get road gigs. ''That's where I learned to play really . . . Nashville,'' said Hendrix, who was billed in 1962 as ''Jimmy Hendrix and his Magic Guitar.'' His first known television appearance was as a backup musician on the locally produced ''Night Train.'' In conjunction with the exhibition, CMF Records/Lost Highway has just released ''Night Train to Nashville,'' a two-CD set featuring 35 vintage tracks and extensive liner notes. PHIL SWEETLAND

On Thursday, Captain Iovino was acquitted. After the verdict, he filed a $10 million lawsuit against the Westchester County police commissioner, Thomas Belfiore, and against that county's police department, claiming that the Westchester police had violated his civil rights, among other claims. title: Keeping Intellectual Borders Open

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Avocent To Buy OSA Technologies
description: The Avocent Corporation, which sells equipment for managing multiple computer networks, agreed yesterday to buy OSA Technologies Inc., which is closely held, for about $100 million to extend its presence in Asia and increase software sales. The company, based in Huntsville, Ala., will pay about $55 million in cash and $45 million in stock for OSA, and assume liabilities and employee stock options, Avocent said. OSA, based in San Jose, Calif., develops technology that allows companies to remotely manage computer servers. The acquisition would add to Avocent's products for accessing and controlling multiple servers and network data center devices. Avocent will also gain access to clients like Dell, which plans to use OSA's technology in its next generation of servers. Dell is also an investor in OSA, Avocent said in the statement. The deal is expected to close sometime next month and will reduce reported earnings for the year by about 14 cents a share, Avocent said. The acquisition is expected to add to earnings in two years, the company said. Shares of Avocent fell 29 cents, to $36.97.

title: TYCO SELLS SONITROL SECURITY PRODUCTS UNIT
description: Tyco International Ltd. said it sold its Sonitrol monitoring unit to a group of private equity investors for $125.5 million. The buyers are Spire Capital Partners, Carlyle Venture Partners and Wachovia Capital Partners, Tyco said. Sonitrol, which provides audio-alarm monitoring products, had about $80 million in revenue for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, Tyco said. The sale is part of the Tyco's plan to divest itself of more than 50 businesses with a total of $2.1 billion in revenue. Tyco's chief executive, Edward Breen, is streamlining the company after taking over in July 2002 from L. Dennis Kozlowski, who is on trial in New York on charges that he looted the company. Sonitrol, which has 500 employees, has a network of 170 franchises in the United States, Canada and Britain.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Oil Acquisition
description: Petrofund Energy Trust, one of Canada's oldest oil and natural gas income trusts, agreed to buy the Ultima Energy Trust for about 446 million Canadian dollars ($341 million) to reduce the cost of borrowing money for acquisitions. Petrofund will pay 0.442 unit and 17 Canadian cents for each Ultima unit, the trusts, based in Calgary, Alberta, said in a statement. The acquisition will increase Petrofund's production to the equivalent of 37,133 barrels of oil a day and reduce interest costs, the trusts said. The expanded trust will have net debt of 231.7 million Canadian dollars. ''The larger size will improve Petrofund's financing ability and its ability to compete for future acquisitions,'' Chris Dutcher, Petrofund's director of business development, said. The acquisition would also help Petrofund comply with a provision of the federal budget proposed by the Canadian government last week that would limit foreign ownership of oil and gas trusts to about 49 percent, beginning in 2007, Mr. Dutcher said. About 66 percent of the units of Petrofund, which was created in 1988, are held by foreign investors, he said.

description: The Toyota Motor Corporation and Volvo signed separate deals to make automotive engines in China with local companies, in the latest of a string of investments by foreign manufacturers in the world's fastest-growing major auto market. Toyota, which hopes to capture 10 percent of the Chinese market by 2010, said it had formed a joint venture with China's largest carmaker First Automotive Works to build a $150 million engine plant in the northern China city of Changchun. The companies plan to make 40,000 engines next year and later raise the plant's capacity to 130,000 engines a year. Volvo plans to make 50,000 engines a year by 2010 in a $200 million venture with First Automotive and the China National Heavy Truck Corporation. Volvo will own 52 percent of the plant while each of the Chinese partners holds 24 percent. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'HERRON, SHIRLEY
description: O'HERRON--Shirley, of Darien, CT and Quissett, MA, age 74, died peacefully at the Richard Rosenthal Hospice Residence in Stamford on March 27, 2004 after a courageous battle with cancer. She had the good fortune of benefitting from 3 years of expert care provided by the physicians and staffs of New York Presbyterian and the Stamford Hospitals, the Rosenthal Hospice and by several very special ladies, formerly of Jamaica. She was the beloved wife of Jonathan O'Herron and devoted mother to Jonathan O'Herron Jr, Anne Burleigh and Sarah Casey. She is survived by 11 adoring grandchildren. Shirley had a lively intelligence, great character, and remarkable courage. She cared deeply for those less fortunate and had a deep faith in her religion. She was a fabulous cook and a gifted artist. ''Wherever people gather, her deeds will speak her praise.'' Her children and grandchildren have inherited her character and integrity. A graduate of Brown University, she also held a masters degree in religion from Fordham University and was a former member of its Board of Trustees and Executive Committee. She was recently elected a trustee emerita. She was a former board member of the Education for Parish Services, which trains lay people to minister in local communities, and was deeply committed in her support of St. Margaret Mary School in the Bronx and St. Vincent's Hospital in NYC. There will be no calling hours. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held privately at St. John's Church in Darien, followed by interment at Spring Grove Cemetery. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11AM on Friday, April 2, 2004 at St. Thomas Moore Church, 374 Middlesex Rd, Darien. The Rev. Gerald Blaszczak, S.J., of Fordham University, will officiate. Edward Cardinal Egan, the Archbishop of NY, will offer a Mass celebrating her life at St. Patrick's Cathedral at a date to be announced. Memorial donations may be made to Fordham University Development Fund, Bronx, NY 10458.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, GEORGE HEARD
description: HAMILTON--George Heard. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of our Life Trustee George Heard Hamilton. His scholarship was unparalleled, and the art historians whom he trained and influenced are innumerable. As Chairman of the Committee on Painting and Sculpture, he deeply influenced the shape of the Museum's collection. His relationship with the Museum began in 1929, when, as a sophomore at Yale, he visited the first exhibition we mounted. Since then, his love for and knowledge of the Museum--and for the artists and staff who have shaped it--grew and buoyed us all. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his wife, Polly, and to their family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Leon D. Black, Chairman, the Trustee Committee on Painting and Sculpture Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: 8 Terror Suspects Arrested in England
description: LONDON, March 30  In one of the largest antiterrorism operations since those that followed the Sept. 11 attacks, 700 British police officers swept through London and parts of southeast England today, arresting eight men suspected of preparing a terror attack. The police were holding the suspects, all reported to be of Pakistani origin, without charge.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Bulletproof Vests Investigated
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday an investigation into a company suspected of selling flawed bulletproof vests to law enforcement officials. More than 6,000 of the vests were sold under the brand names Ultima and Ultimax to police officers in Hempstead and Long Beach and to City University security guards, an official close to the investigation said. Mr. Spitzer's office said there was a possibility that the vests could wear out before the five-year warranty was up. Stacy Albin (NYT)

title: Nothing Less Than Life or Death

The two new pieces Mr. Dorfman and his superb performers presented on Sunday afternoon at the Duke on 42nd Street, produced by the 92nd Street Y, had strong fresh things to say about some of the most complicated yet fundamental human predicaments, in handsome, urgent movement abstract enough for the most extreme dance purists.

description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that profit at its 234 member brokerage firms that do business with the public more than tripled to $3.1 billion in the last quarter of 2003. Its seven market-making firms lost a record $135 million.

title: PEPSICO TO RAISE DIVIDEND AND BUY BACK SOME SHARES
description: PepsiCo Inc. raised its annual dividend by 44 percent after saying its quarterly and annual profit will be at the high end of forecasts. The company raised its annual dividend to 92 cents a share from 64 cents, payable in June, according to a statement made late yesterday. PepsiCo, based in Purchase, N.Y., last raised its dividend in May. The company expects first-quarter earnings of about 46 cents a share, compared with analysts' estimates of 44 cents, and full-year profit at the high end of the forecasted range of $2.27 to $2.29 a share, a company spokesman said. PepsiCo also said it planned to buy back as much as $7 billion of common stock in the next three years.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Teacher Arrested After 'Joke'
description: A teacher at Public School 279 in Canarsie was arrested yesterday after an investigation of a complaint that he hung a 5-year-old boy in a closet by his belt last Thursday, the police said. The teacher, Jason Schoenberger, 24, who teaches music, was said to be playing a practical joke on another teacher, the police said. The child hung from a coat hook for three or four minutes and was not harmed, the police said. Mr. Schoenberger, who is in his second year of teaching, faces misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment and endangering the welfare of a child, and has been placed on administrative duty. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

title: Expert Says He Can't Be Sure Williams's Shotgun Misfired

As the teacher calls out instructions, they sweat profusely, performing a sequence of 26 yoga postures, repeated in every 90-minute class.

title: Far From Home and Out of Sorts, Yankees Lose Opener
description: TOKYO, March 30  The faint voices came from the left-field bleachers, not the right, which could have been the first hint that something was backward at the Yankees' opener at the Tokyo Dome today. Right was left, night was day, road was home, rich was poor.

title: A Pakistani Approaches Manhood Angry and Brutish
description: ''Silent Waters'' is several different movies, and most of them feel negligible and meandering, until the film finally packs a wallop. The director, Sabiha Sumar, starts the film in 1979 with a widow, Ayesha, doting on her 18-year-old son, Saleem, who walks around their small Pakistani village with the uncomplicated, bored smile of a milk-fed prince.

title: A Young Writer, Lover of Life and Women, Caught in the Claws of Fascism and War
description: Mihail Sebastian was a young man on the rise in 1935, a 28-year-old Romanian Jew whose talent had brought him from the provinces to the best artistic circles of Bucharest. He published novels and essays. He wrote plays. He drank Champagne in cafes and savored each feverish moment of his love affairs. (''Like a fool, here I am smitten, jealous of every man she's ever slept with,'' he wrote. Then, not long afterward: ''I am a lot clearer about her. A likable, slightly frivolous blonde, more curious than sensual.'')

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACKETT, SIDNEY A., D.D.S.

Contributions may be made in his memory to the Sidney A. Sackett Scholarship at the University of Michigan School of Dentistry. Harvey, Patti, Kevin and the Schwartz Family

title: Saudis Signal They Will Proceed With Oil-Production Cut
description: VIENNA, March 30 — Saudi Arabia signaled today that it was proceeding with its plans to cut oil production, prompting a gathering of OPEC officials here this week to voice support for higher crude oil prices, which have become a sensitive political issue in the United States.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Telecom Executive Resigns
description: Tapio Hintikka, left, chairman of the telephone company, TeliaSonera, has resigned under pressure from the Swedish government after a disagreement over the makeup of the board. Mr. Hintikka said the dispute stemmed from his effort to appoint a director with more international experience. He said the Swedish government demanded his resignation. Sweden's minister of industry, Leif Pagrotsky, said the resignation came after a ''confidence rift.'' The vice chairman, Carl Bennet, will take over as temporary chairman. The board plans to name a permanent chairman at a meeting on Friday, he said.

title: Literary Journal's Editor To Leave in Budget Dispute
description: Under the editorship of Anne Fadiman, The American Scholar, one of the country's premier literary journals, has been a magnet for both prizes and buzz. Its witty essays by leading writers on subjects as varied as jigsaw puzzles and diabetes have sparked intellectual discussion, lured fresh talent and earned this quarterly three National Magazine Awards in six years. It is currently a finalist for two more: one for general excellence in a publication with a circulation of less than 100,000, and one for profile writing, an article by Ms. Fadiman about an Arctic explorer that appeared in the winter issue.

title: Legal Actions Over Foreign Misdeeds
description: The Supreme Court hears arguments today in a case that may determine how open American courts are to lawsuits filed by foreign victims of human rights abuses. It tests the scope of the Alien Tort Claims Act, a 1789 law that is increasingly being used to hold American companies accountable for their abusive actions outside this country. Companies doing business abroad have tried to block these suits, and the Bush administration has now joined in, arguing that such lawsuits could interfere with the war on terrorism. The Supreme Court should follow the lead of the appeals court that heard the case and recognize that the act provides victims of American misconduct abroad with a right to be heard.

Billings have not been determined. Diego Heymann will also create ads for Latin America, collaborating with local agencies on the Delta roster there.

description: Underground Biology

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Police Release 3 Held In Rail Threats
description: The police have released three people detained for questioning in connection with a blackmail threat against the national railways by an entity called A.Z.F. The police said an amateur pilot, his girlfriend and an antiques dealer taken into custody last week had been cleared of any involvement. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MBIA INC., Armonk, N.Y., the bond insurer, said it had sold 1838 Investment Advisors, King of Prussia, Pa., an asset management company, to executives at the company and investors led by Orca Bay Partners, Seattle. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Kerry, Cool on MTV's Hot Seat
description: Unlike Bill Clinton, Senator John Kerry is not a candidate young people want to flirt and giggle with. They want to come off deep, show him they dig the 60's. And that may be right where Mr. Kerry wants young voters, since he is not much for standard charm: not amused but impressed, even a little self-conscious.

title: Oiling the Revolving Door
description: The American corrections system will release more than 600,000 prisoners this year -- and half will commit new crimes and be back in prison three years from now. There is at least one proven way to break the cycle. Researchers have discovered and rediscovered that inmates who earn college degrees tend to stay out of jail. But former offenders have found it increasingly hard to educate themselves and gear up for productive lives since Congress began to cut them off from federal education aid in the 1990's.

title: A Character In Reverse, An Author In the Clouds
description: The title character in Andrew Sean Greer's ingenious new novel, ''The Confessions of Max Tivoli,'' is born old -- looking like an aged gnome -- and grows younger as he becomes older. At 60 he is playing in a sandbox with other children. In a review in The New Yorker, John Updike wrote, ''Like Proust, Greer presents life as essentially a solitude, an ever-renewed exile from the present, a shifting set of gorgeous mirages that nothing but descriptive genius can hold fast.''

title: Urgency Overwhelms Big Picture
description: Emergency room doctors generally focus on immediate problems, not broader health care. But a new study suggests that as a result, they may often miss opportunities to head off major health problems down the road.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Malpractice Bill Advances
description: The State Senate approved legislation yesterday overhauling medical malpractice laws, the subject of strikes and demonstrations last year by doctors across the state. The 22-to-15 vote followed party lines. The measure establishes a fund to help pay malpractice insurance premiums for doctors in high-risk specialties like obstetrics and neurosurgery. It does not cap damages awards, as Republicans had wanted, but gives judges more authority to limit them. The General Assembly, which has approved a similar bill, will now receive the Senate version. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: STATE COMMISSION WANTS BILLIONS TO HELP SCHOOLS
description: Providing a sound basic education to every child in New York will cost an extra $2.5 billion to $5.6 billion a year and require aggressive new measures to ensure that the money is well spent, Gov. George E. Pataki's Commission on Education Reform said yesterday.

I will help you with your goals, challenges or problems while you're waiting.''

description: Medical texts describe chickenpox, or varicella, as a highly contagious but rather mild childhood disease that only rarely results in serious complications, a fact that has set off decades of controversy over whether the vaccine to prevent chickenpox is warranted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, GERTRUDE
description: EPSTEIN--Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Felix. Devoted mother of Peter and Phyllis Epstein and Sonia and Sidney Mauthner; Adored grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside services Wednesday 11:30am at Beth David Cemeter, Elmont, N.Y.

title: INSIDE
description: Central Asian Terror Attacks

title: A Certain Little Jacket Is the Copycats' Meow
description: ''It's funny,'' Nanette Lepore, a New York designer, was musing last week. ''Women don't really know why they want something -- they just do.'' Ms. Lepore was trying to puzzle out why little boucl jackets -- and in particular a tweed plaid version with a boxy shape and frayed edges, a knockoff of a Chanel original -- should be the surprise hit of the season, igniting a feeding frenzy somewhat akin to last year's madness for the Louis Vuitton Murakami bag.

title: For the Mets, Bad News Hits From All Directions
description: One week before the beginning of the regular season, the Mets gathered Monday morning beneath some telling storm clouds.

title: Big Pay Luring Military's Elite To Private Jobs
description: Senior American commanders and Pentagon officials are warning of an exodus of the military's most seasoned members of Special Operations to higher-paying civilian security jobs in places like Baghdad and Kabul, just as they are playing an increasingly pivotal role in combating terror and helping conduct nation-building operations worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   USTINOV, SIR PETER
description: USTINOV--Sir Peter, who worked for global governance and peace through international institutions such as the International Criminal Court. We will all miss his leadership as president of World Federalist Movement. World Federalist Association Greater New York Chapter

title: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Annan Offers New Plan
description: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, gave a revised draft of his blueprint for reunifying Cyprus to negotiators from the Greek and Turkish sides of the island and said he would make the plan final tomorrow by exercising his mandate to fill in any blanks they could not resolve so the document could be submitted to an islandwide referendum vote on April 20. The talks, in Brgenstock in the Swiss Alps, are aimed at ending the 30-year partition by May 1, when Cyprus joins the European Union. Mr. Annan's plan calls for a loosely federated state with Greeks and Turks maintaining autonomous powers over domestic affairs. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Radio Advertising Increased in February
description: Radio advertising revenue improved slightly in February, according to the Radio Advertising Bureau in New York.

title: People
description: Larry Tolpin was named to the posts of president and chief creative officer at Yesawich, Pepperdine, Brown & Russell, Orlando, Fla. He had been chief creative officer at D&A, Los Angeles, and before that held creative posts at agencies like BBDO Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson. Also at Yesawich, Pepperdine, Peter Yesawich, managing partner, was named chairman and chief executive.

title: Agassi to Play on Long Island This Summer
description: Andre Agassi has committed to play in the 24th TD Waterhouse Cup this summer in Commack, N.Y. Agassi will be playing on Long Island for the first time since 1988, when he defeated Yannick Noah of France in three sets to win the event when it was an exhibition tournament called the Hamlet Challenge Cup. The tournament, which became an ATP-sanctioned event in 1990, runs from Aug. 21-29 at the Hamlet Golf and Country Club in Commack. Paradorn Srichaphan of Thailand is the two-time defending champion. Vincent M. Mallozzi

title: Corrections
description: A list of American military deaths on Friday misstated the unit designation for Pfc. Christopher E. Hudson of Carmel, Ind. It was the Second Battalion, 12th Armor, First Cavalry Division.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: French Rock Star Gets 8 Years In Killing
description: Bertrand Cantat, the lead singer of Noir Dsir, France's leading rock band, was sentenced to eight years in prison by a Lithuanian court for fatally beating his companion, the French actress Marie Trintignant, last July in their hotel room in Vilnius, where she was filming a movie. The beating left Ms. Trintignant, 41, the daughter of the actor Jean-Louis Trintignant, in a coma, and she died five days later. Mr. Cantat, 40, has been held in a Lithuanian prison since then, and the case has dominated French society pages. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Tighter Security For Passover
description: The New York Police Department will step up security around the city for Passover, which begins at sundown on April 5, Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. The department, which dispatched detectives to Madrid and Moscow recently to study terrorist attacks in those cities, will step up foot patrols and cars patrolling houses of worship. The department will place heavily armed officers in other ''sensitive locations,'' Mr. Kelly said. Also, the Department of Consumer Affairs is turning its attention to retailers who price-gouge on kosher items, and advises New Yorkers who suspect such overcharging to call 311. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Promotion at Times
description: Judy E. Gross, group director for customer order fulfillment of The New York Times, has been named vice president for publishing operations, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: After 13 Years, Judge Dismisses Case on Pooh Bear Royalties
description: The Walt Disney Company prevailed on Monday in a 13-year legal dispute over royalties related to its Winnie the Pooh franchise when a judge dismissed the case, contending the plaintiff altered confidential memorandums and covered up the theft of documents obtained by a private investigator who sifted through the company's trash.

title: Russians Buy Gold Fields Mining Stake
description: Norilsk Nickel said on Monday that it had acquired 20 percent of Gold Fields, the South African mining corporation, from Anglo-American for $1.16 billion in cash. The move, which took the industry by surprise, propels Norilsk, a large Russian metals producer little known in the West, into the top ranks of gold producers.

title: Hearts, Minds and Padlocks
description: With so many forces trying to prove that America cannot bring stability and democracy to Iraq, it was sad to see the Bush administration's proconsul there, Paul Bremer III, issuing an order that is likely to set back both of those desirable goals. In a scene distressingly evocative of neighboring Middle Eastern autocracies, Mr. Bremer sent American soldiers to shut down and padlock a popular Baghdad newspaper on Sunday. The stated reason was that by printing false anti-American rumors, the Shiite weekly, Al Hawza, stirred up hatred, undermined stability and indirectly incited violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COMORA, ROSE, NEE KOPPEL
description: COMORA--Rose, nee Koppel, of Leonia, NJ on March 28, 2004. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Herman. Devoted mother of Constance Greenfield, the late Elizabeth Comora, & Susan Rosenfeld. Dear sister of the late Stanley Koppel. Loving grandmother of Michael, Amy, Matthew, Joanna, and Roger. Great grandmother of Raul & Max. Services will be held today, March 30 at 2 PM at ''Gutterman - Musicant'', Hackensack, NJ. 800-522-0588

title: World Briefing | Europe: Poland: Economist Picked As Next Premier
description: President Aleksander Kwasniewski nominated a new prime minister -- Marek Belka, a former finance minister who is finishing his tenure as a top economic official in the American-led civilian authority in Iraq. The current prime minister, Leszek Miller, who has become unpopular because of high unemployment and corruption scandals, agreed last week to step down the day after Poland joins the European Union on May 1. Mr. Belka, 51, who is known more as an economist than a politician, is considered a strong backer of the United States. A parliamentary vote on his nomination is expected on May 16. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Learning the Way The Game Is Played
description: Alex Rodriguez was allowed to be relatively anonymous, at least for him, on a number of occasions at the Tokyo Dome this week. If Hideki Matsui even sneezed, dozens of reporters and photographers were close enough to catalog it. Japan is Matsui's home, and Matsui mania turned Rodriguez, the splashiest story of the spring for the Yankees, into just another player wearing pinstripes as Tuesday's regular-season opener approached.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about the troubled jury deliberations in the Tyco trial gave an incorrect affiliation in some copies for Prof. William E. Hellerstein, who commented on the case. He is at Brooklyn Law School, not Fordham Law School.

title: Senate Panels to Get New Iraq Weapons Report
description: The new chief American weapons inspector in Iraq has prepared a classified report on the hunt for illicit weapons there and will brief two Senate committees in closed sessions on Tuesday about his interim findings, Congressional officials say.

title: World Briefing: Europe
description: POLAND: ECONOMIST PICKED AS NEXT PREMIER President Aleksander Kwasniewski nominated a new prime minister  Marek Belka, a former finance minister who is finishing his tenure as a top economic official in the American-led civilian authority in Iraq. The current prime minister, Leszek Miller, who has become unpopular because of high unemployment and corruption scandals, agreed last week to step down the day after Poland joins the European Union on May 1. Mr. Belka, 51, who is known more as an economist than a politician, is considered a strong backer of the United States. A parliamentary vote on his nomination is expected on May 16. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Temporary Bridge Is Latest Link in the Repair of I-95
description: Cranes swung the skeleton of a temporary bridge into place over a destroyed section of the southbound side of Interstate 95 on Monday, four days after a fiery crash engulfed the highway in flames.

title: U.S. Accepts Responsibility, but Not Blame, in Deaths of 2 Iraqi Journalists
description: American authorities accepted responsibility on Monday for the shooting deaths this month of two Iraqi journalists at an army roadblock, but said the soldiers had fired in self-defense.

title: 1904:Giving to Red Cross : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: ST. PETERSBURG: Countess Nierod, whose son was recently killed on board the Variag, at Chemulpo, has just come to St. Petersburg from her residence in the Government of Kieff, to take leave of another son, just starting for the Far East as a midshipman in the fleet. In every sphere of life the Russians, throughout the entire land, are taxing themselves in order to send money to one or other of the war funds. Thus children empty their savings boxes, and constantly cases are recorded of people in humble spheres of life turning over the money saved in a lifetime to the Red Cross or a patriotic fund of some kind or another.

title: BUSINESS TRAVELERS: SET YOUR CLOCKS
description: For fliers, this is the week of confusion: the interlude between time changes. Last weekend, most European countries switched to daylight saving time, moving their clocks forward one hour. That means that if you thought you were supposed to meet a business partner in Paris for breakfast on Thursday when it is 4 a.m. back home, you had better make sure it isnt really 5 a.m.

title: A Band Reveling In 'Pantaloons' And Other Lyrical Mischief
description: Halfway through the Decemberists' sold-out show at the Bowery Ballroom on Friday night, Colin Meloy said, ''I'm going to tell you a little story about my upbringing.'' And then he sang ''The Chimbley Sweep,'' a ridiculous fable about an unloved boy: ''I am a chimbley, a chimbley sweep/No bed to lie, no shoes to hold my feet.''

description: The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to settle one of the most disputed questions in civil rights law: how to win an age discrimination case in the absence of proof that an employer deliberately singled out older workers for unfavorable treatment.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose after a report in London said Japan would end its currency sales because its economic recovery was strengthening. In New York, the dollar settled at 105.46 yen, down from 105.90 on Friday.

title: SETBACK IS DEALT TO GAY MARRIAGE
description: The Massachusetts legislature on Monday approved a state constitutional amendment that would ban gay marriage and create same-sex civil unions instead.

title: Asbestos Left From 1990 Cleanup Closes L.I. High School for Week
description: A sprinkling of asbestos left over from a botched cleanup 14 years ago forced a 1,500-student high school on Long Island to shut down Monday for a week as crews collect the toxic dust and scour the air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWHOUSE, ALICE GROSS
description: NEWHOUSE -- Alice Gross. On Sunday March 28, 2004 at 11:45 AM at Tourno Infirmary, New Orleans, LA. Wife of the late Norman N. Newhouse and by later marriage to the late Bob Cahlman. Mother of Robyn Newhouse of Suffield, CT, Mark W. Newhouse of New York, NY, Peter C. Newhouse of New Orleans, LA, Jonathan E. Newhouse of New York, NY and London, England and David A. Newhouse of Middletown, PA. Sister of Robert Gross of Great Neck, NY and Jerry Gross of New York, NY. Grandmother of Jesse, Charlotte, Adam, Rebekah, Emily, Nora, Hope, Lily, Macrina and Magdalena Newhouse. Special friend of James O. Charbonnet. Relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend the visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. , Tuesday, March 30th, 7-9 PM with service Wednesday 11:30 AM. title: Statue of Liberty to Be Reopened This Summer
description: The Statue of Liberty, shuttered since the terrorist strikes on Sept. 11, 2001, will likely reopen to visitors sometime this summer, Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said today.

title: Edward J. Piszek, 87, Dies; Founded Mrs. Paul's Brand
description: Edward J. Piszek, who once made too many deviled crab cakes for a local bar and threw the extras in a freezer, an accident that led to a frozen seafood empire, Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, died on Saturday at his home in Fort Washington, Pa. He was 87.

title: MEMO PAD
description: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES BRACES FOR BATTLE -- Southwest Airlines is doubling its ammunition for the looming battle of Philadelphia. Southwest, which starts service with 14 daily flights on May 9 at the US Airways bastion there, says it will add another 14 daily nonstop departures from Philadelphia, starting July 6. Southwest's move into Philadelphia, a hub where fares have traditionally been significantly higher than the national average, is a direct challenge to US Airways, which has about 195 daily departures from Philadelphia, while its subsidiary US Airways Express has about 180. US Airways is preparing to lower fares in Philadelphia as Southwest arrives. ''Southwest is coming to Philadelphia in May,'' David Siegel, the US Airways chief, said in a videoconference last week. ''They're coming for one reason. They're coming to kill us.''

title: Compromise Virtually Assures New Term for Taiwan's Leader
description: The opposition Nationalist Party on Monday publicly dropped its demand that the Taiwan military be allowed to vote again after a disputed presidential election a week ago, making it nearly certain that President Chen Shui-bian will be sworn in on May 20 for another four-year term.

title: Morgan Steers Iowa St. Away From Infamy
description: The long and often difficult road through his first season as coach at Iowa State has wound its way back home for Wayne Morgan. A native of Brooklyn, he will coach the Cyclones in tonight's National Invitation Tournament semifinal against Rutgers, in front of family and friends in an arena he dreamed about as a child.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a demonstration in Brooklyn by the group Develop Don't Destroy, protesting a proposal for a sports arena, misspelled the surname of the group's lawyer in some copies. He is Norman Siegel, not Siegal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, JOHN G.
description: QUINN--John G., 62, of Pinehurst, NC, died Saturday, March 27, 2004 at First Health Moore Regional Hospital in Pinehurst. He is survived by his wife, Joan, his two sisters, Ellen Anderson and Kathleen Quinn Schmidt, and ten nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends on Tuesday from 6-8 PM at Boles Funeral Home in Pinehurst. A Mass of Resurrection will be held on Wednesday at 2 PM at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Pinehurst with Father William L. Pitts as celebrant. Burial will follow in Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOUBET, NATHANIEL R.
description: LOUBET--Nathaniel R. We remember with great fondness our close friend of nearly 65 years with whom we enjoyed countless wonderful times. May all the Loubets be comforted by the cherished memory of his verve and spirit. Sam and Nancy Gordon and family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MIRON, JULIE
description: MIRON--Julie. Of New York, Boston and Palm Beach, at Miami Beach on March 28, 2004 after a brief illness. Founder and Chairman of Miron Building Products and its affiliated companies in New York and Florida. He was a visionary in pioneering a full service source from the foundation to the roof for residential contractors and, later, home owners. He changed the lives of thousands who worked with him and many more who lived in the homes he supplied and in the communities he helped build. Born in Brooklyn, NY, son of Abraham and Pauline Miron. He is survived by Ryna Greenbaum, his devoted and beloved companion of 26 years. Admired and loving father of Stephen and Stephanie of Greenwich, CT and Kenneth and Andrea of Poughkeepsie, NY. Grandfather of Alexis, and Anastasia, Alexandra, Tatyana and Nicholas; Russel and Randy, Monique and Jonathan Cayle, Gregg. Great-grandfather of Andrew Coleman and Leigh Anne Miron. Dear brother of the late Mae Miron Held; Michael and the late Ruth Miron; Herbert and Marcy. Brother-in-law of the late Marvin and Bess Tannenbaum; Harold and the late Frances Jacobson; Jess and Eugenia Frankel. Predeceased by devoted wife and mother, Ann Eagle, who forever lives in the hearts of her children, grandchildren, sister, nieces and nephews. Funeral services to be held Wednesday, March 31 at 11 AM at Temple Beth El, 2815 N. Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, FL. Interment and graveside services to be held Friday, April 2, 1:00 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 13004 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in Julie Miron's memory to the American Jewish Committee; Dartmouth College; Benedectine Hospital (Kingston, NY; Brigham & Womens Hospital, Boston), or a charity of your choice. For information: Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Miami Beach:, 305-531-1151.

title: Season Opens At Crack Of Dawn
description: The Yankees played an exhibition game here on Sunday night, slept for a few hours and came back to the Tokyo Dome for another exhibition game on Monday afternoon. It was the dreaded day-game-after-a-night-game routine, but this time the Yankees welcomed it. The schedule gave them more than 24 hours to relax for their faraway opening act.

title: Smoking, and a Link to Drink
description: Sometimes when former smokers go out drinking, by the end of the evening they are hooked on cigarettes again.

title: Artist Who Worked With 9/11 Dust Is the First Winner of a Welsh Prize
description: Xu Bing, a Chinese-born New York artist whose works include one featuring dust he collected in Lower Manhattan after 9/11, has won the first Artes Mundi prize, a new $75,000 art award created here to stimulate interest in contemporary art in Wales.

title: JARDEN ENDS TALKS TO BUY DIXON TICONDEROGA
description: The Jarden Corporation, the maker of Diamond matches and Ball home canning jars, said it ended talks to buy the Dixon Ticonderoga Company. Jarden agreed in January to buy all of Dixon's outstanding shares for $5 each, valuing the transaction at about $16 million. Jarden's planned acquisition of Dixon would have given it well-known brands like yellow Ticonderoga No. 2 pencils and felt-tip markers. Jarden is based in Rye, N.Y., and Dixon is based in Heathrow, Fla.

description: A senior national security official who worked alongside Richard A. Clarke on Sept. 11, 2001, is disputing central elements of Mr. Clarke's account of events in the White House Situation Room that day, declaring that it ''is a much better screenplay than reality was.''

title: Making a List and Checking It As School Funds Are Awaited
description: The Zarb Commission report released yesterday did not quite answer how much extra money city schools will be getting in the years ahead as a result of a lawsuit filed by the Campaign for Fiscal Equity -- or how much of the burden will be shouldered by the city, state and federal governments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACK, JOHN
description: SACK--John, one of the founders of the new genre of literary journalism, died in San Francisco on March 27. The author of ten books and numerous magazine articles, he was a correspondent in every major war fought by the U.S. from Korea to Afghanistan. Earlier in his career, he was a writer, producer, and special correspondent for CBS television news. He was a graduate of Harvard College. His principal residence was in Ketchum, ID, where he was an avid skier and one-time ski instructor. For the past two years, he had been living in San Francisco. His last work was an article on his final illness and is scheduled to be published in the July issue of Esquire

title: At Season Opener in Japan, Yankees Fall to Devil Rays
description: TOKYO, March 30  Joe Torre had a feeling this would be a weird experience. He followed some of his usual rituals for opening day, calling Billy Crystal, taking a call from George Steinbrenner, gathering his players together and wishing them well.

title: China Detains 3 Relatives Of Victims At Tiananmen
description: At least three family members of people gunned down by the Chinese military during the crackdown on dissent in Beijing on June 4, 1989, have been detained, as the authorities seek to prevent protests connected with the 15th anniversary of the massacre, relatives said Monday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Father Arraigned In Son's Shooting
description: An 81-year-old man was arraigned last evening on charges of attempted murder and assault in the shooting of his son, a movie and television actor, in the family's residence in South Jamaica on Sunday. Neighbors say that the man, Vincent Ford Sr., is suffering from Alzheimer's disease. According to the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, Mr. Ford shot his son, whose professional name is Keith Diamond, three times, striking him in the face, chest and left arm. Mr. Diamond was reported to be in stable condition yesterday at Mary Immaculate Hospital. Officials said that Mr. Ford had been talking about his wife, who is dying of cancer, at the time of the shooting. He is believed to have been considering a mercy killing of his wife, the officials said. He is being held without bail. Robert F. Worth (NYT)

description: When MetroStars Coach Bob Bradley received a package from Drexel Coach Lew Meehl that carried a videotape, he popped the tape into his VCR.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Oil Profit Short Of Forecast
description: China's largest oil refiner, the China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, said its earnings in 2003 rose 32 percent, to 12.6 billion yuan ($1.5 billion), but its profit fell short of analysts' forecasts. The company, known as Sinopec, said revenue increased to 443.14 billion yuan from 345.15 billion yuan in 2002. The company's average crude oil selling price rose to $27.56 a barrel in 2003 as a result of low inventories in the United States and war in Iraq, up from $22.42 a barrel a year earlier. Sinopec said its crude oil production rose 0.43 percent, to 271 million barrels in 2003, and its natural gas production rose 5 percent, to 187.7 billion cubic feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTERMANN, BERTA E.
description: OSTERMANN--Berta E. The Liederkranz Foundation and the Liederkranz of the City of New York records with profound sorrow the passing of a long-time friend and supporter of our Foundation and club. With her late husband Hans Ostermann, who also was, as was Berta, an esteemed member of our Board of Trustees and Directors, she ardently dedicated herself to the activities of our Foundation, club and as President of the Damen Verein. Her presence will be greatly missed. To her sister, Emilie Flohr, and the entire family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Hans G. Hachmann, President The Liederkranz Foundation Liederkranz of the City of NY

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the jury deliberation in the Tyco trial misstated a comment by Ronald P. Fischetti and referred incorrectly to his background. Mr. Fischetti has been a defense lawyer in other white-collar cases; he is not a former prosecutor. He said it was the prosecution, not the defense, that had the burden of proving beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendants were guilty of crimes.

title: Shares Rally on Likelihood of Strong 1st-Quarter Profits
description: Stocks rallied yesterday but interest rates rose, which may not be a plus for equity investors.

title: American Express to Issue Cards in China
description: American Express announced last night that one of China's largest banks would begin issuing its credit cards later this year, significantly expanding Chinese consumers' access to United States credit cards.

title: Amid Great Expectations, Yankees Get Lost in Translation
description: TOKYO, March 30 — Alex Rodriguez's honeymoon with the Yankees lasted nine sluggish innings in a country 6,800 miles away from the new baseball address he is still waiting to inhabit in the Bronx. Rodriguez was able to meander through one game against the Tampa Bay Devils Rays before he learned how certain things evolve in George Steinbrenner's demanding world.

title: This Isn't America
description: Last week an opinion piece in the Israeli newspaper Haaretz about the killing of Sheik Ahmed Yassin said, ''This isn't America; the government did not invent intelligence material nor exaggerate the description of the threat to justify their attack.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITAN, JUDITH MORLEY (NEE RENEE GREENFIELD)
description: LEVITAN -- Judith Morley (nee Renee Greenfield). Born April 29, 1923, died at home March 28, 2004. Beloved wife for 56 years of David M. Levitan, mother of Barbara and Stuart, daughter of Ada Wolpert and Andrew Greenfield, sister of Daniel Morley and Janice Weiss, beloved friend, mentor and confidant of all who knew her. A longtime resident of Glen Head and Roslyn Harbor, L.I., she recently divided her time between Manhattan and Deerfield Beach, FL. Proud holder of a B.A., University of Miami; M.A., International College; and Ph.D., William Lyon University. Her career included the Committee for a Free Palestine, where she met her husband, David; broadcaster for Voice of America and NBC; theater as actor, playwright and producer; 50-year member of Actors' Equity; Democratic Party State Committeewoman; Dromenon Society; Jean Houston's Mystery School. A volume of collected poetry, Miss Laughinghouse and the Reluctant Mystic, was published in 1995. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, Wednesday, March 31, 1:30pm, interment following at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to The Nature Conservancy, Long Island Chapter.

title: Heat and Light Uptown; Benefit Salutes the Apollo With Songs and Goose Bumps
description: Onstage at the Apollo Theater on Sunday night, the octogenarian actor and activist Ossie Davis was talking about music and civil rights. When Sam Cooke, an Apollo legend, first heard the Bob Dylan song ''Blowin' in the Wind,'' Mr. Davis recalled, with its signature line, ''How many years can some people exist before they're allowed to be free?,'' Cooke was moved to write a rallying anthem of his own, ''A Change Is Gonna Come.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Governor Backs Youth Gun Bill
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich said he would sign a bill allowing 18-year-olds to obtain firearm owners identification cards, which allow a person to buy or possess a gun, without parental consent. Current laws require such permission until age 21. The bill has gained preliminary approval in the Legislature but will need to pass once more before it can be sent to Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

description: Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello said yesterday that defenseman Scott Stevens, who has missed the last 40 games with a concussion, was not fully recovered and would not join the team until he was.

Bloomberg's view of the city's fiscal horizon is a clouded panorama where modest revenue gains are threatened by the rising costs of Medicaid, employee pensions and debt. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Mobile Telecom Alliance
description: Four of Europe's biggest wireless companies will begin offering services under the Freemove name in an effort to increase competition with the Vodafone Group, the world's biggest cellphone company. The four companies -- Telecom Italia Mobile; T-Mobile International of Deutsche Telekom; Telefnica Mviles; and Orange of France Tlcom -- will offer products and services under the Freemove brand within a few months, the chairman of T-Mobile, Rene Obermann, said. The companies formed the group last year. They plan to purchase 25 percent of their handsets ''within 18 months,'' Marco de Benedetti, the chief executive of Telecom Italia Mobile, said. The goal for the year is six million cellphones. The four companies, which have more than 230 million clients worldwide, are getting together to help lower costs and offer seamless services to customers traveling in countries including Britain, France, Italy and Spain. Vodafone has 125 million subscribers.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Arch Wireless To Acquire Metrocall For $281.3 Million
description: Arch Wireless, the nation's biggest wireless-paging company, agreed yesterday to buy Metrocall Holdings Inc., its largest rival, for $281.3 million in cash and stock to compete with larger carriers like Nextel Communications Inc. Shareholders of Metrocall, which is based in Alexandria, Va., will receive $150 million in cash and a 28 percent stake in the combined business, the companies said. Based on Arch's closing price of $23.96 Friday and 19.9 million Arch shares outstanding, the stock portion is valued at about $131.3 million. Metrocall and Arch are seeking to cut expenses, increase sales and sell a broader array of products. The companies, which exited bankruptcy protection in 2002, face pressure from carriers like Nextel, which sell paging services along with voice calling. The indicated purchase price is less than Metrocall's market value on Friday of about $409.3 million. Shares of Metrocall fell $5.79, to $69.15. Arch shares rose $8.35, to $32.31. The transaction combines Arch's 4.4 million customers who generated $597 million in revenue last year, with Metrocall's 3.5 million users and $337 million in sales in 2003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CORRELL, JAMES SR., MD.
description: CORRELL--James Sr., MD. The Department of Neurological Surgery of the New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University notes with sadness the passing of Dr. James W. Correll in Hampstead, NC on Friday, March 26, 2004. Dr. Correll spent his entire career in our Department from 1955-1987. He made many contributions to the understanding of the pathogenesis of stroke and advanced the field by his extensive laboratory studies on the role of the autonomic nervous system and lipid release. He was one of the pioneers of surgery on the carotid artery to prevent stroke which led to the broader understanding of the prevention of this disease. A busy and indefatigable surgeon, beloved by his patients, a surgical pioneer, and a mentor to numerous medical students and neurosurgical residents, he made a lasting mark on our department, the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and the field of neurosurgery. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Cynthia, daughter Catherine, son William, their spouses and his five grandchildren. The Department of Neurological Surgery New York Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia University.

title: NPS PLANS TO SEEK APPROVAL OF OSTEOPOROSIS DRUG
description: NPS Pharmaceuticals said its main experimental drug, the Preos osteoporosis treatment, was effective in a study that might help the company win federal approval. The drug, a genetically engineered parathyroid hormone injected to promote bone growth, prevented initial fractures and worsening disease in women with mild to moderate osteoporosis, the company said. NPS, which is based in Salt Lake City, plans to file for Food and Drug Administration approval of Preos this year. Preos is the first drug the company has developed alone. The worldwide study involved 2,600 women with low bone-mineral density, 81 percent of whom had not had any fractures.

title: A Buddhist Observes Humanity With Sharp and Stern Eyes
description: ''Spring, Summer, Fall, Winter . . . and Spring'' is an exquisitely simple movie. Written and directed by Kim Ki Duk, it was filmed at a single location -- a remote and picturesque mountain lake in a South Korean wilderness preserve -- and it concentrates on the relationship between a Buddhist monk and his young protg, characters whose names are never spoken. But like Blake's ''Songs of Innocence and Experience,'' the film's lyrical plainness is the sign of a profound and sophisticated artistic sensibility. In five sharp, concise vignettes that correspond to the seasons of the title, Mr. Kim manages to isolate something essential about human nature and at the same time, even more astonishingly, to comprehend the scope of human experience.

title: Energy Scarce As Argentina Faces Winter
description: The nascent recovery that has lifted the Argentine economy over the last year is being threatened by a shortage of electricity and gas, which is appearing just as the weather in the Southern Hemisphere turns cool ahead of winter.

description: ADLERBERG -- Ruby (nee Orange). On March 25, 2004, of cancer. She is survived by Herbert, her husband of 52 years. Also survived by her son Scott. A memorial is planned. Call Rose Orange at 718-220-0445 for details.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Scooter Ban Being Considered
description: The City Council's transportation committee held a hearing yesterday on a bill that would prohibit the sale, rental or operation of small motorized scooters anywhere in the city, including on private property. Currently, they are banned only in public places. Under the bill, anyone who sells, leases or rents out a motorized scooter would be fined $1,000 and imprisoned for 15 days. Anyone who operates a motorized scooter would be fined $500, and the scooter would be impounded. Citing safety concerns, Councilman Michael E. McMahon, above, said that ''like a plague of locusts, children on motorized scooters are swarming through our neighborhoods.'' Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Alistair Cooke
description: As the master of ceremonies on ''Omnibus,'' the legendary arts and entertainment series that ran on network television in the 1950's, and later as the host for more than 20 years of ''Masterpiece Theater'' on public television, Alistair Cooke came to epitomize highbrow culture to a wide swath of American viewers. The role gave Mr. Cooke, an elegant and erudite transplanted Englishman, the status of a TV icon, and also made him the subject of good-natured parodies on television shows like ''Saturday Night Live'' and ''Sesame Street.''

title: Space Is Tight at the U.N., But Art Gifts Keep Coming
description: ACCORDING to its charter, the United Nations was established to maintain international peace and security, not to act as a curator of art and antiquities. But since its headquarters was completed in 1953, the spartan corridors, glassy lobbies and cavernous assembly halls have been augmented by works of art, donated by member nations and inspired, at least in theory, by postwar visions of a halcyon world.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Aladdin Shares Surge 27%
description: Shares of Aladdin Knowledge Systems, a maker of software used for secure Internet transactions, jumped 27 percent yesterday after the company increased its forecast for first-quarter revenue. Aladdin shares rose $4.20, to $19.79. The stock of the company, based in Tel Aviv, has more than doubled this year. Sales will be $15.9 million to $16.3 million, Aladdin said. It had forecast $14.4 million to $14.9 million. Sales were $13.2 million in the year-earlier quarter.

title: Ruling Leaves Nassau Facing $100 Million Tax Repayment
description: Nassau County's fiscal recovery is facing another potential hurdle: a new State Court of Appeals ruling that could result in $100 million or more of property tax refunds to utilities.

title: Police in Uzbekistan Arrest Dozens, Reports Say
description: MOSCOW, March 31  The police in Uzbekistan made dozens of arrests today in an effort to stem a wave of violence that included reports of at least one new explosion.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lithuanian Diplomats Expelled
description: Russia ordered the expulsion of three Lithuanian diplomats after Lithuania expelled three Russian diplomats last month, accusing them of improperly gathering sensitive information on the impeachment process of the country's president, Rolandas Paksas. The tit-for-tat expulsions come at a time of heightened tensions between Russia and its Baltic neighbors as they join NATO and the European Union. Earlier this month, Estonia and Russia each expelled two diplomats after trading accusations of espionage. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: A Vermeer, Once Suspect, Will Be Offered at Sotheby's
description: A painting by the Dutch master Johannes Vermeer that for decades was suspected of being a fake will be offered for sale at Sotheby's in London this summer, becoming the first Vermeer to go on the block in more than 80 years, the company announced yesterday.

title: National Briefing: Southwest
description: TEXAS: CRASH VICTIMS ARE RECOVERED The bodies of two men missing since the helicopter they were aboard crashed in the Gulf of Mexico on March 23 were recovered from the ocean floor south of Galveston. The remains of the six other passengers and the two pilots were found last week. The helicopter was flying from Galveston to an oil drilling ship. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Corporate Shelter Warning
description: The European Commission sent the German government a final warning to change its so-called Volkwagen law, which was intended to protect the carmaker from a hostile takeover, or face court action. The action is part of a campaign to force member countries to abandon protectionist measures that prevent cross-border investment. ''The VW law makes it substantially less attractive for other E.U. investors to acquire the company's shares with a view to participating effectively in management decisions or controlling the company,'' the commission said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MIRON, JULIE
description: MIRON--Julie. Of New York, Boston and Palm Beach, at Miami Beach on March 28, 2004 after a brief illness. Founder and Chairman of Miron Building Products and its affiliated companies in New York and Florida. He was a visionary in pioneering a full service source from the foundation to the roof for residential contractors and, later, home owners. He changed the lives of thousands who worked with him and many more who lived in the homes he supplied and in the communities he helped build. Born in Brooklyn, NY, son of Abraham and Pauline Miron. He is survived by Ryna Greenbaum, his devoted and beloved companion of 26 years. Admired and loving father of Stephen and Stephanie of Greenwich, CT and Kenneth and Andrea of Poughkeepsie, NY. Grandfather of Alexis, and Anastasia, Alexandra, Tatyana and Nicholas; Russel and Randy, Monique and Jonathan Cayle, Gregg. Great-grandfather of Andrew Coleman and Leigh Anne Miron. Dear brother of the late Mae Miron Held; Michael and the late Ruth Miron; Herbert and Marcy. Brother-in-law of the late Marvin and Bess Tannenbaum; Harold and the late Frances Jacobson; Jess and Eugenia Frankel. Predeceased by devoted wife and mother, Ann Eagle, who forever lives in the hearts of her children, grandchildren, sister, nieces and nephews. Funeral services to be held Wednesday, March 31 at 11 AM at Temple Beth El, 2815 N. Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, FL. Interment and graveside services to be held Friday, April 2, 1:00 PM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, 13004 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in Julie Miron's memory to the American Jewish Committee; Dartmouth College; Benedectine Hospital (Kingston, NY; Brigham & Womens Hospital, Boston), or a charity of your choice. For information: Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, Miami Beach:, 305-531-1151.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Tycoon Who Set Off Mexican Scandal Held
description: Cuban authorities reported the arrest of a Mexican businessman, Carlos Ahumada, who is at the center of a political scandal that has rocked the left-wing Democratic Revolutionary Party and dimmed the presidential ambitions of the popular mayor of Mexico City. Last month, Mr. Ahumada released a videotape that appeared to show a close ally of Mayor Andrs Lpez Obrador accepting a bribe of $45,000. Mr. Lpez is a leading member of the party, and polls regularly showed him as the most popular politician in Mexico. Polls now show his popularity in a steady decline. Mr. Ahumada, who owns a construction company and was seeking city contracts, said he made the video to show he was being extorted by local officials. The authorities in Mexico City have charged Mr. Ahumada with fraud. He fled the country. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)
