title: Diplomatic Memo; No Clear Favorite for Top U.S. Job in Iraq
description: It is described as the most challenging diplomatic assignment in the world, and the toughest to fill. Three months before sovereignty is restored in Iraq, the Bush administration is still looking for an ambassador to replace L. Paul Bremer III as the chief American political presence in Baghdad.

title: City Considered Dropping Verizon Before 911 Failure, Official Says
description: Weeks before a Verizon engineer's error shut down New York City's 911 emergency line, dissatisfaction with the company's service had already led officials to consider replacing it as the city's primary provider of telephone services, the commissioner of the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications said yesterday.

title: Justices Unanimously Bar Release of Photos From the Suicide of a Top Clinton Aide
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Tuesday that release of the death-scene photographs of Vincent W. Foster, the Clinton administration's deputy White House counsel who killed himself in 1993, would be an unwarranted invasion of the privacy of Mr. Foster's surviving family members.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Omits Dividend
description: Swiss Life Holding, the big life insurer, said it would omit a 2003 dividend and raise as much as 1.15 billion francs ($900 million) selling stock and bonds after failing to sell its Banca del Gottardo private bank. The shares slumped 9.9 percent. The insurer, which decided to keep Gottardo after talks broke down with UniCredito Italiano, will sell 800 million francs of shares and 350 million francs of convertible bonds to transfer the bank from a unit to the parent company, the chief executive, Rolf Doerig, said. Swiss Life, which bought Gottardo for 2.4 billion francs in 1999, has been trying to reverse a $3 billion move into banking to focus on insurance. The talks with UniCredito broke down over price.

title: American Express Reviews Its Account
description: The American Express Company yesterday concluded a three-month review of most media planning and buying duties for its worldwide account, with spending estimated at more than $500 million, by keeping the agency that has been handling those tasks, MindShare, part of the GroupM division of the WPP Group.

title: TWO CANADIAN GOLD-MINING COMPANIES AGREE TO MERGE
description: The Iamgold Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wheaton River Minerals Ltd., a Canadian gold-mining rival, for 2.9 billion Canadian dollars ($2.2 billion) in stock. Stockholders of Wheaton River, based in Vancouver, will receive 0.55 share of Iamgold for each of their shares, Iamgold said in a statement. The offer, which is subject to shareholder approval, values Wheaton River shares at 5.14 Canadian dollars, or 25 percent more than yesterday's closing price of 4.12 Canadian dollars. The combined company will produce about a million tons of gold a year from seven mines in the Americas, West Africa and Australia, according to Iamgold, which is based in Toronto.

description: The Bush administration, still sparring with Senator John Kerry over the issue of trade, said the practice of exporting work overseas had little to do with the loss of jobs in the United States.

description: VIENNA, March 30 - Saudi Arabia, the pivotal member of OPEC, signaled on Tuesday that it was pushing forward with a plan to lower the cartel's target for crude oil production by a million barrels a day, a move that would keep oil prices high.

description: Miroslav Deronjic, a confessed war criminal and an important prosecution witness in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic at the United Nations tribunal here, received a modest 10-year sentence on Tuesday. The sentence, suggested by the prosecution and accepted by two judges, seemed so light that it openly angered the leading judge in the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HAMILTON, GEORGE HEARD
description: HAMILTON--George Heard. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with sorrow the passing of our Life Trustee George Heard Hamilton. His scholarship was unparalleled, and the art historians whom he trained and influenced are innumerable. As Chairman of the Committee on Painting and Sculpture, he deeply influenced the shape of the Museum's collection. His relationship with the Museum began in 1929, when, as a sophomore at Yale, he visited the first exhibition we mounted. Since then, his love for and knowledge of the Museum--and for the artists and staff who have shaped it--grew and buoyed us all. We extend our sincerest sympathies to his wife, Polly, and to their family. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Robert B. Menschel, President Leon D. Black, Chairman, the Trustee Committee on Painting and Sculpture Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY

description: Racketeering indictments against two sons of the late Colombo crime family boss, Joseph Colombo Sr., and more than two dozen others were unsealed yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan, officials said. The Colombo brothers, Anthony and Christopher, and 29 of their associates are variously charged with loan-sharking, extortion, mail fraud and commercial bribery, among other things. The charges are the result of a four-year investigation. Most of the defendants were in custody yesterday. Racketeering, money laundering and extortion each carry a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACK, JOHN
description: SACK--John, one of the founders of the new genre of literary journalism, died in San Francisco on March 27. The author of ten books and numerous magazine articles, he was a correspondent in every major war fought by the U.S. from Korea to Afghanistan. Earlier in his career, he was a writer, producer, and special correspondent for CBS television news. He was a graduate of Harvard College. His principal residence was in Ketchum, ID, where he was an avid skier and one-time ski instructor. For the past two years, he had been living in San Francisco. His last work was an article on his final illness and is scheduled to be published in the July issue of Esquire

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Lifts Disputed Co-Op Fee
description: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against the city in an effort to overturn a $50 fee on co-op sales and transfers. But the city said yesterday that it would stop collecting the fees. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court last week, claims that the city's Department of Finance illegally charges a $50 fee every time a co-op is sold or transferred. The fee should not apply to co-ops, the suit contends, because co-op sales or transfers involve the exchange of shares in a corporation rather than real estate. Aaron Shmulewitz, a lawyer who is representing the plaintiffs, estimated that the city had collected more than $1 million in such fees. Martha E. Stark, commissioner of the Finance Department, said in a statement that the department had reviewed the fee. ''Accordingly,'' she said, ''Finance will identify those who paid a fee for nondeed transactions after Jan. 1, 2003, and provide refunds where appropriate and will stop collecting fees on these transactions.'' Mr. Shmulewitz said his clients would continue to pursue the suit. Motoko Rich (NYT)

title: Hope the Easter Bunny Likes Surprises

The treats suggest Marshmallow Peeps but have a real flavor difference. The bunnies get their blush and fruity taste from raspberry pure, and the chicks are tart-sweet with passion fruit, which also imparts their golden color. The marshmallows will be available at brunch ($65 prix fixe) and dinner ($69).

title: A Feast For Two Seasons
description: IT has been a long, bone-chilling winter, one that any sane person should be glad to see the back of. And yet, I feel a slight panicky sadness as the days of thick soups and warming roasts draw to a close. As the author of a book dedicated to the pleasures of summer food, I should perhaps be ashamed to admit this, but I am not. Anyone who likes cooking enjoys the culinary opportunities of the winter months and maybe now, with Easter only 10 days away, is the time to savor the last of them and celebrate with one final flourish. It is not yet so balmy and springlike that a Sunday lunch of spiced roast pork and apples, followed by a dessert of comforting baked custard is out of the question. Indeed, it seems to me the perfect way to say farewell to winter.

title: COURT REJECTS INVESTOR CLAIMS AGAINST JOHN HANCOCK
description: John Hancock Financial Services, the life insurer, said a federal court had dismissed shareholder accusations that the company overpaid its executives. A spokesman for the company, Steve Burgay, said the court did not dismiss one minor claim against Hancock directors, but the company also expected that allegation to be rejected. A lawsuit was filed on behalf of a shareholder in May, saying the company illegally tied executive compensation to the performance of its 2000 initial public offering. The suit said that the chief executive, David D'Alessandro, and other executives were wrongfully awarded compensation, and sought repayment. John Hancock, based in Boston, is being acquired by Canada's Manulife Financial Corporation.

title: American Express Reviews Account
description: The American Express Company yesterday concluded a three-month review of most media planning and buying duties for its worldwide account, with spending estimated at more than $500 million, by keeping the agency that has been handling those tasks, MindShare, part of the GroupM division of the WPP Group .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULMAN, DR. DAVID
description: SCHULMAN--Dr. David. Died on Sunday, March 28th, 2004 of complications from Parkinson's disease at his home in Manhattan. Beloved husband of Gloria Yevish Schulman, cherished father of Sarah Schulman, Helen Schulman & Charlie Schulman. Loving father-in-law of Bruce Handy and Juliet Bellow, devoted grandfather of Zoe and Isaac Handy. A memorial service will be conducted at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Division of Child Psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Hospital.

title: Tying George Washington Into the School Curriculum
description: IN the old days, every field trip to Mount Vernon was pretty much the same: a docent lectured as students trudged room by room through George Washington's house.

title: MetroStars' Stadium Deal Not Done Yet
description: Plans to build a stadium for the MetroStars as part of a development project in Harrison, N.J., are close, but not as close as Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber said they were.

title: A Newspaper Is Closed in Baghdad
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Privilege and Politics
description: President Bush finally agreed yesterday to allow his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, to testify publicly and under oath to the panel investigating the 9/11 attacks. But Mr. Bush did the right thing only under intense political pressure and after he had already undermined the principles he claimed to be upholding. His reversal came with disturbing conditions attached, wrapped up in a volley of spin. All in all, it leaves the impression of a White House less interested in helping the 9/11 panel perform its vital task than in protecting the president's political flanks.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Calls For Inquiry
description: France joined in calls for an independent inquiry into a violent march last week in Abidjan, and United Nations investigators have found themselves stymied in their efforts to look into what took place. The government says 37 people died, opposition party members put the number at over 200, and the Ivorian Movement for Human Rights says the figure is 600. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Spain Confirms Inquiry Focuses On Moroccans
description: Spain's government confirmed Tuesday that a Moroccan extremist group was the prime focus of the investigation into the bombings of four commuter trains on March 11.

title: Islanders Hearing Skate Steps
description: The Buffalo Sabres have graduated from pesky to relentless in chasing the Islanders for the eighth and last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

title: This Year, More Boards Feel Pressure To Show Up
description: For directors of publicly traded corporations, showing up at the annual shareholders meeting is not so optional anymore.

title: Improving the Environment for Creatures of Two and Four Legs
description: WHY did Seattle's Woodland Park Zoo design its jaguar habitat so the big cats can creep into tree branches and lurk over the heads of visitors?

title: Fuel Prices a Focus Of Both Campaigns
description: On a campaign stop in California, Senator John Kerry blamed the Bush administration's policies for rising fuel costs. In turn, the president's campaign attacked Mr. Kerry's support of gasoline taxes.

title: Clarett's Suit Against the N.F.L. Is Headed to the Court of Appeals
description: The sprint by the former Ohio State running back Maurice Clarett into the National Football League draft may have hit a hurdle.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Decline In Output
description: Industrial production fell 3.7 percent in February from January, but the government said it expected the decline to be short-lived as it forecast a rise in manufacturers' output. Japan's unemployment rate was 5 percent in February, unchanged from January. The job market worsened for young Japanese, with the unemployment rate for men age 15 to 24 rising to 12 percent in February from 10.5 percent in January. Todd Zaun (NYT)

title: The Balkans Flare Up
description: As if the world needs a reminder of how hard it is for occupying outsiders to build a nation, Kosovo exploded this month. Five years after a NATO bombing campaign put an end to atrocities by ethnic Serbs against ethnic Albanians there, Albanian mobs burned Serb-owned houses to the ground. It's yet another distressing instance in which victims of ethnic cleansing have resorted to the same horrific type of violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITAN, JUDITH MORLEY (NEE RENEE GREENFIELD)
description: LEVITAN -- Judith Morley (nee Renee Greenfield). Born April 29, 1923, died at home March 28, 2004. Beloved wife for 56 years of David M. Levitan, mother of Barbara and Stuart, daughter of Ada Wolpert and Andrew Greenfield, sister of Daniel Morley and Janice Weiss, beloved friend, mentor and confidant of all who knew her. A longtime resident of Glen Head and Roslyn Harbor, L.I., she recently divided her time between Manhattan and Deerfield Beach, FL. Proud holder of a B.A., University of Miami; M.A., International College; and Ph.D., William Lyon University. Her career included the Committee for a Free Palestine, where she met her husband, David; broadcaster for Voice of America and NBC; theater as actor, playwright and producer; 50-year member of Actors' Equity; Democratic Party State Committeewoman; Dromenon Society; Jean Houston's Mystery School. A volume of collected poetry, Miss Laughinghouse and the Reluctant Mystic, was published in 1995. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave, Wednesday, March 31, 1:30pm, interment following at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to The Nature Conservancy, Long Island Chapter.

title: Reason to Run? Nader Argues He Has Plenty
description: Ralph Nader knows all the arguments against him. He can recite, word for importuning word, the letters from old friends urging him not to run for president -- ''all individually written, all stunningly similar'' -- and he does so with the theatrical relish of a man whose public life has been one long, unyielding argument with the world.

title: Intergraph And Intel Settle Chip Dispute
description: Intel agreed to pay $225 million to the Intergraph Corporation on Tuesday to settle remaining claims that its Itanium chip infringed on Intergraph's patents. The settlement brings the total amount Intel has paid or will pay to Intergraph, a graphics software and systems company based in Huntsville, Ala., to $675 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WENTWORTH, BROTHER TIMOTHY
description: WENTWORTH--Brother Timothy FSC, Guidance Counselor at Manhattan College, former Director of Novices and former Provincial of the New York Province of the De La Salle Christian Brothers, on March 28 after a prolonged illness. The son of the late Raymond and Julie Wentworth, of Mattydale, NY, brother of the late Raymond Wentworth, he is survived by his brothers John and Frank Wentworth as well as several nieces and nephews. Wake will be held at the Christian Brothers Center, 4415 Post Road, Bronx, from 2-5 and 7-9PM on Tuesday March 30 and from 2-5 PM on Wednesday March 31. Viewing will continue in the chapel of De La Salle and his Brothers at Manhattan College from 7-8 PM on Wednesday March 31 at which time the Funeral Mass will be celebrated. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery will follow on Thursday April 1. (Funeral cortege leaving from Christian Brothers Center at 10AM). For info: Williams Funeral Home, 718-548-1100

title: Rutgers Gains the Other Final: N.I.T.
description: After Rutgers lost by 3 points to Virginia Tech in the Big East tournament, Coach Gary Waters said that he was pretty certain the Scarlet Knights would receive a bid to play in the National Invitation Tournament. He just wasn't sure his team wanted one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEIERTAG, HYMAN
description: FEIERTAG--Hyman, 85, of Manhasset Hills, New York. Beloved husband of Sylvia, devoted father of Therese Lichtenstein, Linda Strauss and Robert Feiertag. You touched so many with your love, kindness, intelligence, humility and sense of humor. Your memory will forever be in our hearts. You were perfect.

title: Sharon, Facing Criticism, Plans Vote on Gaza Pullout
description: Faced with sharpening opposition from his coalition partners and catcalls from leaders of Likud, his own rightist party, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon moved Tuesday to shore up his political base by agreeing to hold a party vote on his plan to withdraw from some Israeli-occupied territory.

title: Excerpts From White House Letter on Rice's Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from the letter sent yesterday to Thomas H. Kean and Lee H. Hamilton of the Sept. 11 commission from Alberto R. Gonzales, counsel to President Bush, as provided by the White House. The full text is online at nytimes.com/washington.

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Monday about the New York City Council's allocation of $37.5 million to reduce class sizes misstated the goals of a similar effort by the state. It seeks an average of 20 students in kindergarten through third grade. (Twenty in kindergarten and 25 in first through third grades is the goal the city has reached using state money in some recent years.)

title: The Statue of Liberty Is to Reopen in August, at Least Partly
description: Public access to the base of the Statue of Liberty, suspended since Sept. 11, 2001, is expected to resume by August, after safety and security improvements are completed, federal officials said yesterday.

title: Chancellor Appoints Press Chief For Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein yesterday appointed Stephen J. Morello, a former press secretary to Govs. Hugh L. Carey and Mario M. Cuomo, as director of communications for the Department of Education.

title: An Effort to Promote V-Chip for Television
description: In another attempt to address complaints about indecency on broadcast television, the four largest broadcast networks said yesterday that they had agreed to join with the Advertising Council in New York for public-service campaigns promoting the V-chip, which lets parents block television programs they consider offensive for their children.

title: Politeness Among Canadian Investors May Be Wearing Thin
description: A revolt among investors over a takeover bid involving two Canadian telephone companies is the latest sign that a long tradition of politeness toward corporate directors and managers north of the border is eroding.

title: World Briefing | South Pacific: New Zealand: Changes For Citizenship and Passports
description: The government plans legislation that would give it the power to revoke passports for security reasons and make it tougher for foreigners married to New Zealanders to obtain citizenship. The proposals come amid reports that Al Qaeda operatives may have looked at New Zealand as a place to secure passports, raise money and launder their identities. The proposals brought protests from civil libertarians. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about the difficulty of distributing drugs to AIDS patients in poor countries referred incorrectly to President Bush's January 2003 plan to spend $15 billion over five years to fight AIDS in the third world. While United States spending thus far has not kept pace with the plan, the president has issued a five-year budget plan that foresees reaching it; his requests have not fallen short of the goal.

title: 1954:Plane Hits Mess Hall : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: FORT BRAGG, North Carolina: An Air Force C119 Flying Boxcar, attempting an emergency landing with one engine blazing, clipped a barracks building and then smashed into a mess hall in a crowded troop area today [March 30]. At least six men and possibly nine were killed. Five bodies were recovered from the wreckage, and the pilot of the plane died in a hospital about three hours after the crash. Three men were missing, and an officer said "it is unreasonable to expect" they could have survived the crash. Both the plane and the mess hall were engulfed in flames and burned for more than an hour after the crash, which occurred before 10 a.m. Nine men were aboard the plane, which struck the roof of a barracks as its pilot tried to make an emergency crash-landing on a parade ground adjoining the mess hall. An undetermined number of men, perhaps 12, were inside the hall at the time.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: SBC To Offer Wi-Fi Net Access At UPS Outlets
description: SBC Communications will offer high-speed wireless Internet access in United Parcel Service stores this year to attract more business customers. The service, known as wireless fidelity, or Wi-Fi, will be available at 1,500 UPS and Mail Boxes Etc. locations by year's end and in 3,000 stores by the end of 2005, an SBC spokesman, Michael Coe, said yesterday. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: What He Ate: A Food Diary From New York
description: TUCKER SHAW, 35, is a writer who grew up in Denver and went away to Maine for college and moved to New York in 1991 for the reasons people do. Since Jan. 1, he has photographed everything he has eaten.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOKE, ALISTAIR
description: COOKE--Alistair. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of Thirteen/WNET, we lament the passing of Alistair Cooke and extend our sympathies to his wife and children. A broadcaster of extraordinary sophistication, wit and class, he was one of public television's most admired personalities and an international ambassador for culture and civilization. All America will miss his silver hair, his silver tongue, and the countless golden moments he shared with so many over the years. We trust his legacy of brilliance will live on in the work of thoughtful broadcasters throughout the world. Steven Rattner, Chairman William F. Baker, President

title: Prosecutions for Perjury in Legislative Settings Are Unusual
description: There has been a lot of talk of perjury in Washington in recent days.

description: There seemed no end to the parade of star power on display at the Paramount Pictures event at the movie industry's annual ShoWest convention here.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about Indian vegetarian restaurants in New York misstated the address of Vatan. It is at 409 Third Avenue (29th Street), not Lexington Avenue.

description: WASIAK--Madeleine R. On March 30, 2004. Loving wife of Kenneth. Devoted mother of Patricia, Eileen, Laura, and Kenneth. Loving grandmother of Danny, Matthew, Alison, Ellen, Elizabeth, Nora and Michael. Dear sister of Bernadette and Patricia. Reposing at Massapequa Funeral Home Inc., 1050 Park Blvd., Massapequa Park, NY (516) 798-2500

title: Testing the Boundary Lines of Eminent Domain; Long Branch Wants to Seize Old Homes to Make Room for New Ones
description: The government's power to seize private land for public use has historically been justified as benefiting the greater good. In Colonial America, that meant taking private land to build roads or government buildings. In the late 20th century, as cities cleared houses for shopping malls and factories, the ''greater good'' came to mean job creation and economic revitalization.

title: An Inclination to Serve, and the Power to Change
description: GAIL NAYOWITH, the executive director of the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York, knew at the ripe old age of 12 that she would help people as a grown-up. ''I didn't have the professional thing down, but I knew I'd lead a life struggle around the human condition,'' she says.

description: To the Editor:

title: About-Face in France: Government's Out, Then It's In
description: Governments come, and governments go, and on Tuesday the French government went and came back again.

title: Heiress's Estate Becomes A Showcase for Fine Art
description: THE Russian icons that are the focus of this year's main show at the Hillwood Museum and Gardens have been part of its collection for years. But they will be moving from their usual spots on the opulently decorated walls of this mansion turned museum, and mounted individually in the spare, understated space typical of most exhibitions.

title: 911 Failure Delayed Treatment As Deadly Heart Attack Struck
description: Last Friday night, Elsie Grier was sitting on the couch watching ''Jeopardy!'' at her daughter's house in Queens when she thought she heard her husband, Jasper Grier, stumble and fall in the next room. She went to the dining room and found him collapsed on the floor, she said.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Correction Appended

title: I.R.S. Request for More Terrorist Investigators Is Denied
description: The Bush administration has scuttled a plan to increase by 50 percent the number of criminal financial investigators working to disrupt the finances of Al Qaeda, Hamas and other terrorist organizations to save $12 million, a Congressional hearing was told on Tuesday.

title: In Wisconsin, Bush Offers a Hopeful Assessment of the Economy
description: President Bush campaigned in Wisconsin on Tuesday, saying he was optimistic about the economy and urging Americans to have faith in their ability to compete with the rest of the world rather than taking refuge behind what he called ''economic isolationism.''

title: Romancing the Collector: Will There Be a Storybook Ending?
description: WHEN Eli Broad strides into the boardroom of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art like he owns the place, he has reason to believe. Like a string of big museum donors before him, Mr. Broad is enjoying his moment. Last June, in celebration of his 70th birthday, he announced a gift of $50 million to the institution to pay for a new building with his name on it, along with $10 million for art acquisitions. It was the largest single monetary gift in the museum's 39-year history.

description: In percent

title: Enraged Mob in Falluja Kills 4 American Contractors
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, March 31 - Four Americans working for a security company were ambushed and killed Wednesday, and an enraged mob then jubilantly dragged the burned bodies through the streets of downtown Falluja, hanging at least two corpses from a bridge over the Euphrates River.

title: BASKETBALL: N.B.A. Analysis; Houston Finds Conditional Love From Fans
description: For a brief moment Tuesday, Allan Houston displayed the type of cockiness that might silence some of the fans questioning the severity of a knee injury that has sidelined him for the Knicks' playoff race.

title: Publicist Hired To Tell Iraqis Of Democracy
description: The United States-led occupation in Iraq has enlisted a British public relations firm to help promote the establishment of democracy in the country.

title: Aromas of Wood Smoke, Raising Hopes
description: RESTAURANTS are like small cruise ships, with a crew sweating in the galley and the paying customers taking their ease on deck. The best restaurant ships have a captain on duty at all times. At Le Cirque 2000, you can count on being greeted at the door by Sirio Maccioni or one of his sons. While you rarely catch sight of Danny Meyer at Union Square Cafe or 11 Madison Park, you always sense his hand at the helm, guiding your passage.

title: Cypriots Facing Deadline Today In Unity Talks
description: Almost 30 years after Turkish troops invaded Cyprus, forcing its partition, negotiators from the Greek and Turkish Cypriot communities entered the tense final stages of a make-or-break effort on Tuesday to reunite the island before it enters the European Union on May 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, FLORENCE
description: LEVINE--Florence. To our dearest Florence, our family wil always cherish your memory and the wonderful days that we spent together. You were very special in our lives. Your strength and positive attitude in the face of adversity as well as your children's are a role model for us all. We will miss you dearly. Beatrice and Sidney Solomon Susan and Bruce Waterfall Lauri and Steven Solomon Sara Guyer and Scott Straus Jane and John Waterfall Bonnie Spencer, Roxanne, Randall, Jacquie and Kate Solomon

title: Kerry and Bush Campaigns Trade Charges on Gas Price
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30  Pointing to California gasoline prices as high as $2.37 a gallon for premium, Senator John Kerry blamed the Bush administration's energy policies Tuesday for the nation's rising fuel costs, while the president's campaign introduced a television commercial attacking Mr. Kerry's past support of gas taxes.

title: Vineyards Take the Kosher Challenge
description: EVEN under ordinary circumstances, good wine is hard to make. Add in the difficulties of satisfying the religious criteria for calling wine kosher, and you've really got a challenge.

title: Kidd and Martin Showing Signs of Recovery
description: For the first time since sitting out with a bruised left knee after a Nets loss on March 18, Jason Kidd practiced with the team, running through light three-on-three and four-on-four drills on Tuesday. The Nets say he is still not ready to play, but he is looking comfortable enough that dire talk that he could miss part of the playoffs now seems too pessimistic.

title: Behind Every Acquisition Lies a Story, From 'Star Trek' to St. Francis
description: BEHIND every museum acquisition is a human story. The object was created by one person and possessed over the years by others (who may, in turn, have been possessed by it). Before finding a home in a collection, the piece has been touched by many hands, and hearts. A diary written by a former slave passes to his descendants generations later, and from them to all of us. A collection of ''Star Trek'' gear evokes a museum curator's youth -- and a slice of our cultural history. Here are the stories (and backstories) of some items that were recently acquired.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Crash Victims Are Recovered
description: The bodies of two men missing since the helicopter they were aboard crashed in the Gulf of Mexico on March 23 were recovered from the ocean floor south of Galveston. The remains of the six other passengers and the two pilots were found last week. The helicopter was flying from Galveston to an oil drilling ship. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: British Hold Terror Suspects

title: Head of France Tlcom's Cell Unit Is Out
description: Solomon D. Trujillo, the former chief executive of the US West regional phone company, is stepping down as head of Orange, the wireless arm of France Tlcom after a little more than a year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Telecom Stake Sold
description: The government sold a 9.4 percent stake, worth about 8.5 billion kroner ($1.2 billion), in Telenor, the telephone company, bringing it closer to its goal of holding 51 percent of the company. Norway took advantage of the stock's doubling in the last year to cut its stake to 53 percent. It has been reducing ownership in Telenor to lure foreign investors, first selling stock in December 2000.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bertelsmann's Profit Falls
description: The media company Bertelsmann said its profit dropped last year, hurt by a strong euro, declining CD sales and weak advertising spending. The company, based in Gtersloh, said net profit fell to 154 million euros ($187 million) from 928 million euros a year earlier. Sales dropped 8 percent, to 16.8 billion euros, partly because currency exchange rates reduced revenue from the United States, which accounts for 25 percent of Bertelsmann's sales. The chief executive, Gunter Thielen, above, said that after last year's restructuring, the company would be turning ''from consolidation to attack,'' helped by 2 billion euros it has available for acquisitions over the next three years. Bertelsmann said it was focusing on acquisitions in Asia and Eastern Europe. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: State Department Criticizes Election
description: A weekend parliamentary by-election in which the candidate of the ruling ZANU-PF party won a surprise victory was scarred by intimidation and violence and was not fair, the State Department said. The vote took place in the Zengeza district near Harare, normally a stronghold for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change; one oppositiuon party member was shot dead and 50 others were injured in attacks for which ZANU-PF supporters were blamed. With the victory on Sunday, the governing party is but two seats short of a two-thirds majority in Parliament, a proportion which would allow it to amend the Constitution without outside support. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Duck Under Cover
description: SINCE becoming a fan of braised duck a few years ago, I have latched onto every recipe I could find. Braising solves several of the challenges of cooking duck: it renders the fat completely and reliably; it browns the skin without spattering; and it makes the meat tender.

title: Internet Chatter on the Tyco Trial: What's With Juror No.4?
description: When it comes to the Tyco trial, the hot topic in Internet chat rooms and online message boards is motive.

title: Curators Go to Battle vs. Beetles
description: NOBODY loves natural history museums more than pests. Bones, paper, fur, feathers -- so many of insects' favorite foods.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Autodesk Raises Forecasts Again
description: Autodesk, whose design software helped create Time Warner's New York headquarters, raised its first-quarter sales and profit forecasts a second time as customers adopted updated products. Net income in the three months ending in April will be 23 cents to 28 cents a share on sales of $265 million to $275 million, Autodesk said on its Web site. The company, which held an investor conference yesterday, had net income of 7 cents a share on sales of $210.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Autodesk has cut jobs to increase profit, and it is replacing software with new versions each year to induce customers to pay an upgrade fee or buy a subscription. Autodesk shares rose $1.54, to $31.47. Excluding costs like layoffs, Autodesk said it would have first-quarter profit of 27 cents to 32 cents a share and full-year profit of $1.27 to $1.36 a share.

title: Kerry Shoulder Surgery Goes Well, Doctor Says
description: Senator John Kerry was in the recovery room at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston this afternoon after a 45-minute operation to repair a minor shoulder injury that will keep him off the presidential campaign trail for several days.

title: Prep Schools Flocking to Recruit Products of a Newark Education
description: EIGHTH graders applying to prestigious, $30,000-a-year private boarding schools are usually very nervous this time of year, waiting to hear. But in mid-March, as Devin Desir, a 13-year-old, checked the mail for letters from a half-dozen prep school admissions offices, he seemed positively calm.

title: Sales of College Stars' Jerseys Raise Ethics Concerns
description: With the N.C.A.A men's and women's basketball tournaments heading toward their championship rounds, sales of T-shirts, hats and scores of other products are booming. Production is timed so precisely that licensed N.C.A.A. tournament team T-shirts were on sale at the bookstore at the University of Alabama at Birmingham the morning after U.A.B. pulled off its upset of Kentucky to advance to the Round of 16.

title: Bet You Can't Eat Just One, But Why Try?
description: Saltines arrived on the scene more than 100 years ago. Ritz crackers were introduced in 1933, and went on to become the world's most popular cracker. And Cheez-Its made their debut not long after. But those were the days before people were aware of things like trans fats, artificial coloring and organic ingredients. Now, Steve Bernard, the founder of Cape Cod Potato Chips, and his daughter, Nicole Dawes, have started Late July Organic Snacks, with nostalgic packages of irresistible organic crackers made with unhydrogenated palm oil and no trans fats. The crackers, in six-ounce boxes, are $2.79 at Whole Foods markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SLOTOROFF, FAY
description: SLOTOROFF--Fay. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Devoted mother of Martin, Sondra Weiner-Winters, and Carole Siegel. Adored grandmother of seven, and great-grandmother of 16. Services Thursday, at Bloomfield-Cooper, Ocean, NJ at 11:30 AM. For more info.: 800-247-5235.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BULL, CORNELIUS H. III.
description: BULL--Cornelius H. III. Of Peterborough, NH. 78, educator, school headmaster and founder of the Center for INTERIM Programs, died peacefully after a long illness on March 16 at his home in Peterborough, NH. Mr. Bull is survived by his wife, Mary Bull of Peterborough, NH and Cambridge, MA; two sons, Cornelius Bull of Cambridge, MA and Samuel Bull of Healdsburg, CA; a daughter, Sarah (Holly) Bull of Princeton, NJ; and four granddaughters. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 2nd at 9AM at the Lawrenceville School Chapel in Lawrenceville, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in his name may be made to Cornelius Bull Endowed Scholarship Fund, Robert College of Istanbul, 276 5th Avenue #

title: 7 Companies Band Together in Hopes of Building Nation's First New Nuclear Plant in Decades
description: In an effort to revive the nuclear reactor construction industry, seven major companies plan to announce on Wednesday that they will apply for a license to build a new commercial power plant. The last time a plant was ordered but not later canceled was 1973.

title: Live From Tokyo, but Not Much Life in This Telecast
description: After the Yankees' 8-3 loss to Tampa Bay yesterday in Tokyo, John Kruk, ESPN's newly minted ''Baseball Tonight'' analyst, spoke for baseball xenophobes when he said: ''Opening day is in Cincinnati. It's America's pastime. Have opening day in America. It doesn't seem like a real game.''

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: City To Pay Wrongly Convicted Man
description: Chicago has agreed to pay $1.2 million to a former inmate pardoned by the governor last year after having served more than 11 years in prison. The man, Miguel Castillo, was convicted in 1991 in the killing of Rene Chinea. He was released in 2000 after his lawyers successfully argued that he was in jail on an unrelated charge at the time of the killing. Jo Napolitano (NYT)

title: Porch Failure Not Criminal, Police Find
description: The Chicago Police Department has found no evidence of criminal conduct in connection with a porch collapse that killed 13 people last summer.

title: Annan Presses for Cyprus Deal as Deadline Nears
description: FURIGEN, Switzerland, March 31  Laboring against Greek objections, Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, pressed today for approval of a final version of a plan to reunite Cyprus, the divided island nation whose ethnic hatreds once brought the threat of war to the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Make Good-Faith Gestures
description: JERUSALEM, March 31 - With three United States envoys coming to assess the state of the Mideast conflict, Israelis and Palestinians both made gestures today intended to show good faith in the stalled peace process.

title: Upstate Father and Son Convicted of Leaving Behind Asbestos and Faking Air Test Results
description: A father and son were convicted yesterday in Syracuse of running a 10-year asbestos-fraud scheme that put potentially thousands of people at risk of disease and death.

title: British Police Arrest 8 Suspected of Plotting Terrorist Attack
description: Hundreds of British police officers swept through London and parts of southeastern England on Tuesday arresting eight men suspected of preparing a terrorist attack. Officers also seized 1,000 pounds of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, which can be used to make explosives, from a commercial storage locker near central London, the police said.

title: A Young Work Revels Happily In Being Played as a Whole
description: When the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center decided to celebrate its history of commissioning new works in January, it made the peculiar decision to present truncated or excerpted versions of many scores it was supposedly honoring. Among its oddest choices was to insist that Derek Bermel's ''Soul Garden,'' a 13-minute work composed in 2000, be trimmed to eight minutes. The request brought the society a measure of well-earned derision among new-music fans, and Mr. Bermel pointed up the silliness of its position by proposing that the society just play the first eight minutes and stop, which is what it did.

title: Fight Against Illegal File Sharing Is Moving Overseas
description: The music industry announced legal action Tuesday against 247 people accused of illegal file sharing outside the United States, taking its war against Internet piracy abroad for the first time.

title: Family Treasures Hold Kosher America's Roots
description: HIGH on the shelf of a wooden bookcase in a West Side apartment sits a box, filled with recipes and handwritten cookbooks -- one family's chronicles of the Jewish kitchen. The oldest, lovingly covered in fabric and hand-written in ornate script, dates from 1879, just eight years after the first kosher cookbook was published in America. Its author, whose initials appear on the title page, was Justina Hendricks Henry, a New York housewife and the daughter of one of the founders of Jews' Hospital, now Mount Sinai.

title: AUDITORS QUESTION TRUMP HOTELS' FUTURE VIABILITY
description: The auditors of Donald Trump's cash-starved casino company, Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, are raising ''substantial doubt'' about its ability to continue as a viable business. The auditors, Ernst & Young, expressed concerns after reviewing Trump Hotels' financial results for 2002 and 2003. The company published Ernst's concerns yesterday in an addendum to its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. According to the report, the company's $1.8 billion bond debt is so burdensome that its interest payments entirely depleted the company's operating income last year, contributing to an $87.3 million loss. Trump Hotels also said that it ''anticipates but cannot ensure'' that it will have enough money on hand to provide for a May interest payment of about $73.1 million. The company is trying to negotiate a refinancing deal with its bondholders. Mr. Trump, the chairman and chief executive, received $1.5 million for his services but failed to earn a bonus. Eric Dash (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Missing Girl Found Dead
description: The police confirmed that human remains found by a hiker in a wooded area 30 miles from Toronto were those of Cecilia Zhang, the 9-year-old girl kidnapped from her bed last October. The case has gripped Toronto, and as the search has turned into a murder investigation, the police are still stymied. Cecilia's picture appeared on posters around the city, and her parents battled to keep attention on the case -- in newspapers and on television, including the series ''America's Most Wanted'' -- and even mortgaged their home for reward money. Colin Campbell (NYT)

title: A Quieter Game: Looking for Clues To Explain a Painting
description: Children who visit the Newark Museum are challenged to decode the ''Portrait of the Four Youngest Children of William Rankin, Sr.,'' an 1838 oil painting by Oliver Tarbell Eddy. This memorial portrait -- which was common in the 19th century -- commemorates the death of Rankin's daughter, Matilda. Eddy, a well-known portraitist and miniaturist in his day, incorporated many visual symbols in the painting.

title: Humanity and Nature Share a Timeless Dance on Persimmon Farms
description: At first glance ''Red Persimmons,'' a Japanese documentary that opens today at Film Forum in the South Village, looks like a simple sentimental paean to a vanishing way of life, but it turns out to have something more on its mind.

title: A White Elephant for the West Side
description: As New York rushes to expand the Jacob Javits Convention Center and build a new football stadium on the Hudson River, we might want to take a look up and down the Eastern Seaboard. Boston's gleaming new $800 million convention center will open in a few months, yet it has booked only a handful of conventions and will need at least a $12 million annual operating subsidy in its first few years. Baltimore officials are trying to increase flagging business at the convention center they expanded in 1997, and are considering spending millions more in public money to build a subsidized hotel next door.

title: J.C. PENNEY SAYS ITS ECKERD STAKE IS WORTH $4.37 BILLION
description: The J.C. Penney Company said the fair value of its stake in the Eckerd drugstore chain that it is trying to sell is $4.37 billion. Penney disclosed its valuation of the chain in a filing late Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wall Street analysts have estimated that the 2,700-store Eckerd chain could be worth $3.5 billion to $4.5 billion, but some have suggested that the drawn-out process of selling Eckerd might indicate that offers are on the low side.

title: Nixon's Tax Return, A Cyberspace Treasure

Even though $238 was withheld from her paychecks, Dawn had little idea what taxes were for until a teacher, Bob Magnuson, took the class to an unusual new museum, the Tax History Museum.

title: World Briefing: Africa
description: ZIMBABWE: STATE DEPARTMENT CRITICIZES ELECTION A weekend parliamentary by-election in which the candidate of the ruling ZANU-PF party won a surprise victory was scarred by intimidation and violence and was not fair, the State Department said. The vote took place in the Zengeza district near Harare, normally a stronghold for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change; one oppositiuon party member was shot dead and 50 others were injured in attacks for which ZANU-PF supporters were blamed. With the victory on Sunday, the governing party is but two seats short of a two-thirds majority in Parliament, a proportion which would allow it to amend the Constitution without outside support. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: PARSONS DEAN APPOINTED
description: The appointment of Paul Goldberger, the architecture critic for The New Yorker, as dean of the Parsons School of Design, is to be announced today by Bob Kerrey, the president of New School University. Until now Mr. Goldberger's career has focused more on journalism than on academia. He was an architecture critic for The New York Times, where he received a Pulitzer Prize in 1984, and he worked at Architectural Digest in the 1990's. He has taught architecture history and criticism at Yale University and is a visiting professor at the University of California, Berkeley. While dean at Parsons, Mr. Goldberger will continue to be a critic for The New Yorker. In September his book about designing at the site of the World Trade Center, ''Up from Zero: Politics, Architecture and the Rebuilding of New York,'' is to be published by Random House. JULIE V. IOVINE

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Miner Blows Self Up In Congress Building
description: A former miner who had invaded the Congress building in La Paz to protest delays in receiving his pension benefits blew himself up as he was being escorted from the annex of the Chamber of Deputies. Two other people, both government security agents who had been negotiating with him, were also reported killed in the explosion, and at least 10 more were injured. At a news conference, President Carlos Mesa urged calm, describing the blast as an ''isolated incident'' with no political connotations. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: BASEBALL: Baseball Analysis; The Boss, Far Away, Seems All Too Close

title: Crooning Softly to Conceal the Pain
description: The quality that most distinguishes Andy Bey, a jazz singer and pianist in his mid-60's who only now is gaining recognition as one of the greats of his generation, is his gentleness. Mr. Bey, whose three-night engagement at Le Jazz au Bar ended on Sunday, is best known as a baritone crooner whose cool, resonant voice and lingering phrasing, reminiscent of the very young Nina Simone in a moment of calm, suggest a clear mountain stream pouring over a song.

title: Editors' Note; Editors' Note
description: A restaurant review in the Dining section last Wednesday about Spice Market, on West 13th Street in Manhattan, awarded it three stars. The writer was Amanda Hesser, The Times's interim restaurant critic. Last May, before her assignment to that post, Ms. Hesser published a book, ''Cooking for Mr. Latte,'' that was praised in a jacket blurb by the restaurateur Jean-Georges Vongerichten, who later opened Spice Market. He wrote: ''Amanda Hesser's charming personality shines as the reader experiences the life and loves of a New York City gourmet. 'Cooking for Mr. Latte' is perfectly seasoned with sensuality and superb recipes.'' The review should have disclosed that background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'HERRON, SHIRLEY
description: O'HERRON--Shirley, of Darien, CT and Quissett, MA, age 74, died peacefully at the Richard Rosenthal Hospice Residence in Stamford on March 27, 2004 after a courageous battle with cancer. She had the good fortune of benefitting from 3 years of expert care provided by the physicians and staffs of New York Presbyterian and the Stamford Hospitals, the Rosenthal Hospice and by several very special ladies, formerly of Jamaica. She was the beloved wife of Jonathan O'Herron and devoted mother to Jonathan O'Herron Jr, Anne Burleigh and Sarah Casey. She is survived by 11 adoring grandchildren. Shirley had a lively intelligence, great character, and remarkable courage. She cared deeply for those less fortunate and had a deep faith in her religion. She was a fabulous cook and a gifted artist. ''Wherever people gather, her deeds will speak her praise.'' Her children and grandchildren have inherited her character and integrity. A graduate of Brown University, she also held a masters degree in religion from Fordham University and was a former member of its Board of Trustees and Executive Committee. She was recently elected a trustee emerita. She was a former board member of the Education for Parish Services, which trains lay people to minister in local communities, and was deeply committed in her support of St. Margaret Mary School in the Bronx and St. Vincent's Hospital in NYC. There will be no calling hours. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held privately at St. John's Church in Darien, followed by interment at Spring Grove Cemetery. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11AM on Friday, April 2, 2004 at St. Thomas Moore Church, 374 Middlesex Rd, Darien. The Rev. Gerald Blaszczak, S.J., of Fordham University, will officiate. Edward Cardinal Egan, the Archbishop of NY, will offer a Mass celebrating her life at St. Patrick's Cathedral at a date to be announced. Memorial donations may be made to Fordham University Development Fund, Bronx, NY 10458.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Spinoff
description: Hutchison Whampoa announced plans to spin off its Hong Kong telecommunications businesses and most of its emerging-market mobile units. Hutchison said it planned to bundle its fixed-line, second-generation and third-generation telecommunications businesses in Hong Kong with its wireless interests in seven emerging markets into a separate entity that would be listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange. The unit, called Hutchison Telecommunications International, will include the conglomerate's interests in wireless businesses in Ghana, India, Israel, Macau, Paraguay, Sri Lanka and Thailand, as well as its Hong Kong telecommunications unit. Hutchison said it would remain the majority shareholder.

title: Going Uptown for a Bite of Fried Soup
description: FOR lovers of Chinese food, one of the oldest rules for finding the best restaurants is to follow the chef. This is not an easy task for the casual eater. The cult of the superstar chef has not penetrated Chinese restaurants, where chefs generally toil in their kitchens unrecognized and uncelebrated. Yet for every American culinary school graduate who has the effrontery to open an eponymous restaurant, dozens of superior Chinese chefs remain anonymous, their comings and goings chronicled only by the most ardent and energetic fans.
